HEADLINE: Banks Lost $744 Million in Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The nation's banks lost $744 million from July to September after earning record profits in the first half of the year, Government regulators said today.
The quarterly loss, the first in more than two years, occurred mainly because large banks added to their reserves against losses from troubled loans to developing countries.
Although adding to their reserves cut their third-quarter profits, the moves should put the banks in a stronger position to negotiate with debtor countries, regulatory officials have said. 
 
Risks in Real Estate
But another source of problems for banks has emerged: risky real estate lending. The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, said he was concerned that souring real estate loans posed a serious threat to the industry.
As head of the agency that insures deposits in banks, Mr. Seidman urged the nation's 12,824 banks, which have stepped up their real estate lending recently, to be careful. ''The caution light is flashing,'' he said.
''We hope that banks will take a hard look at the real estate lending that is causing the problems,'' Mr. Seidman said.
The problems are concentrated in loans for development and commercial real estate rather than single-family home loans, he said.
 
A Rapidly Growing Sector
Regulators are particularly concerned by the rapid rise in real estate lending. Mr. Seidman said real estate loans, which accounted for 25 percent of all commercial bank loans in 1983, now make up 35 percent of the total.
The banks' problems are reminiscent of the savings and loan industry's woes, which led Congress to approve a $159 billion bailout of the industry earlier this year.
A number of savings and loan institutions in the Southwest became insolvent as real estate loans turned sour, but experts say real estate problems are less severe in other regions where economies are stronger.
The states with banks showing the highest proportion of bad real estate loans are Arizona, Texas and Alaska, Mr. Seidman said. As for commercial real estate, Connecticut has the highest vacancy rate, he said.
The banking industry's poor results in the third quarter contrast with record profits of $7.3 billion in the first quarter and $7 billion in the second quarter. Banks earned a record profit of $25.2 billion last year.
 
A Previous Loss
The industry's quarterly loss was the first since the second quarter of 1987, when banks lost $10.6 billion, again because they raised their loss reserves for loans to third world countries.
Some of the nation's largest banks again took write-downs in the third quarter on their loans to developing countries. J. P. Morgan & Company increased its loss reserves by $2 billion; the Chase Manhattan Corporation, by $1.3 billion, and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Corporation, by $950 million.
Mr. Seidman said the most recent decisions to raise reserves were appropriate, and he predicted profits in the fourth quarter would be back around the levels of the first half, although, he said, the deterioration in real estate loans will probably continue.
He said next year should be better because the current number of problem banks, 1,134, has fallen from 1,394 at the start of the year.
So far this year, 192 banks have failed. The total is likely to surpass 200 before the year is out but should be under last year's total of 220, Mr. Seidman said.

HEADLINE: Output Up By 2.5% in 2d Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
American workers made modest productivity gains in the third quarter, but the lackluster manufacturing sector posted its lowest output gain in three years and continued to slow the overall economy.
And for the first time this year, the quarter-to-quarter hourly wage gains made by workers outpaced the growth in consumer inflation, the Labor Department said today.
The department said overall productivity in the non-farm sector of the economy increased at a revised annual rate of 2.5 percent in the July-to-September period. This was moderately better than the 2.1 percent gain reported in preliminary data and more than double the anemic 1.1 percent annualized gain in the second quarter. 
But in manufacturing, a sector weakened by slumping automobile sales and other problems, productivity increased at a revised annual rate of just 1 percent after improving at a rate of 3.7 percent in the April-to-June period.
 
Slack Demand for Goods
The poor manufacturing performance came as output rose at a rate of just 1.2 percent and the number of hours worked increased at a rate of two-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting slackened demand for goods. The increase in output was the smallest since a slight decline in the second quarter of 1986.
Because of the poor productivity gain in manufacturing and a significant increase in wages, unit labor costs, a key determinant of future inflation, rose at at an annual rate of 4.9 percent after decreasing by 1 percent in the second quarter. It was the largest increase in unit labor costs since the 1982 recession, the department said.
Analysts said that increase would probably translate into either higher prices for consumers or lower profits for producers, or both. They also said such wage increases made it more difficult for American manufacturers to compete in overseas markets.
The overall 2.5 percent annualized productivity gain in the non-farm sector came as output rose at a rate of 3.7 percent in the third quarter while hours worked grew at a much slower annual rate of 1.3 percent.
For the overall non-farm sector, the data on unit labor costs were more encouraging. Costs for each good produced rose at a revised annual rate of 2.8 percent in the third quarter after rising at a rapid 4.5 percent rate in the previous quarter.

HEADLINE: Fed Says It Sold Dollars in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve actively sold dollars from August through October in an effort to prevent further appreciation of the dollar in foreign exchange markets, the central bank reported yesterday.
The heavy sales in the August-through-October period, totaling $5.8 billion, followed a record $11.9 billion of dollar sales by the Fed in the previous three months. Despite the intervention by the Fed and other central banks, analysts attributed the stabilization of the dollar since mid-October to changes in interest rates and economic conditions. 
The report by Sam Y. Cross, executive vice president of the Fed, said that the sharp decline in American stock prices on Oct. 13 caused concerns about a pullback in the heavy foreign investment that had been helping push the dollar higher. While the flow of Japanese capital to dollar investments continues to keep the dollar strong relative to the yen, he said that conditions in West Germany had caused the dollar to decline sharply against the mark recently.
 
Little Intervention Lately
Since the end of October, analysts said, there has been little intervention by the Fed and other central banks and the dollar is down from the late-summer levels that had caused economic policy makers in the Group of Seven industrialized countries to issue a statement on Sept. 23 warning that the dollar's rise was undesirable and further increases would hurt world economic growth.
''There is no longer any voice from the United States claiming that the dollar needs to be pushed down,'' said Mieczyslaw Karczmar, a New York economic adviser to the Deutsche Bank of West Germany. He said the dollar had weakened significantly against the mark in recent weeks because the West German economy was booming and the country's central bank had raised short-term interest rates. Prospects for more commerce with East Germany and Eastern Europe are likely to sustain the strength of the West German economy.
The dollar traded late yesterday at about 1.765 West German marks, down from slightly more than 2 marks on Sept. 15 and 1.84 marks at the end of October.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The New Lure Of 'Junk Bonds'

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
WHILE their numbers are small, a few professional money managers are beginning to edge back into the ''junk bond'' market, attracted by the flea-market philosophy that almost anything can be sold if the price is low enough.
Today's junk bond prices are certainly low, driven down by fears that a recession will make deadbeats of many of the heavily indebted companies that have issued the bonds. Junk bonds, which are corporate debt securities deemed too risky to qualify as ''investment grade,'' began weakening in September and fell sharply during the stock market selloff of Oct. 13. They have weakened even further since then. 
Moreover, skeptics point out, the market must still weather the publicity that will attend the coming criminal trial of Michael Milken, Drexel Burnham Lambert's former junk bond specialist. Also, there is a likelihood of one or more major corporate defaults in the next six months.
None of that alarms Frank Cappiello Jr., a partner of the investment firm of McCullough, Andrews & Cappiello in Baltimore and a frequent panelist on the public television program ''Wall Street Week.''
''I've been watching this market over the past two years, and the prices are so low now that there's really minimal risk,'' Mr. Cappiello said. ''We're looking at a washed-out group.'' Mr. Cappiello is sufficiently confident of the profits to be found in the junk market that he has signed on to manage the Diversified High Income Series, a new junk bond fund first offered for sale last Thursday. The new fund is one of four new open-end mutual funds being managed by Mr. Cappiello and the Carnegie Capital Management Company, which is based in Cleveland. The fund will be marketed through regional brokerage houses under the Carnegie-Capiello Trust label.
Mr. Cappiello does not have a lot of company in his mutual-fund foray into junk bonds. But he is not entirely alone. According to Elizabeth Johns, editor of the mutual fund newsletter published by the research firm of Charles E. Simon & Company in Washington, nine other junk bond funds were registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission this year. But only four have actually been offered on the market.
''We tend to see high-yield bond funds sitting in registration longer than other funds, as their managers wait for an opportune moment to bring them out,'' Ms. Johns said. Of the four new funds being sold, only the Franklin Multi-Income Trust made its debut after the stock market sold off heavily on Oct. 13.
The Franklin product, first offered on Oct. 23, is a closed-end fund, representing a fixed portfolio of bonds. The fund trades in the market like a common stock. Because investors sell their closed-end shares on the market, rather than selling them back to the fund, closed-end portfolio managers are not forced to sell bonds into an already declining market just to raise cash for redemptions.
That is a big asset for junk bond funds these days, given the bumpy road ahead, said John J. McElroy, a partner and chief investment strategist for 1838 Partners Investment Advisers in Philadelphia, a pension fund management company that broke off from Drexel Burnham Lambert two years ago. ''It will take a year, maybe more, for confidence to fully return to the market,'' Mr. McElroy said. ''The trouble with an open-end fund is that the very time you shouldn't be selling is when you have to sell.''
Still, Mr. McElroy is among the small band of investment managers who are looking over the junk bond market. ''It is something we are interested in,'' he said. ''My professional assessment has always been that the time to buy something is when nobody wants it. I think that fresh money coming in will be able to get a good bargain, so long as you are a long-term investor.''
One sign of improving demand for junk bonds came yesterday as Morgan Stanley & Company went to market with an $850 million junk bond offering for a new entity jointly owned by Morgan and Jefferson Smurfit. Unlike some previous junk deals, which have been postponed or restructured, yesterday's deal went smoothly, with institutional money mangers lining up to buy the bonds. The new entity will use the money to acquire and recapitalize Jefferson Smurfit and the Container Corporation of America.
No one is saying that the junk bond market is not still very risky. ''You will continue to have periodic problem credits that go sour in a very public way,'' said Gail Silberman, a vice president at Jefferies & Company in New York.
But the yields on junk bonds today exceed the yield on Treasury bonds by almost as much as the equivalent corporate bonds did during the Depression.''At those levels, you are being adequately paid to take the risk,'' Ms. Silberman said. ''In fact, I'm investing some of my personal funds in junk bonds.''
Some investment managers noted that some junk bond issuers have been entering the market in recent weeks to repurchase some of their own bonds at today's substantial discounts. ''They're not buying big,'' one portfolio manager said. ''But they are buying, which means that their bankers are giving them permission to use their excess cash or lines of credit for the purchases. This market still has a lot of potholes ahead, but that is a group of buyers that could add some stability.''

HEADLINE: Dow Retreats by 4.91 Points, to 2,736.77

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices tracked a weak bond market to lower ground yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 4.91 points, to 2,736.77.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances, 767 to 714, and volume contracted to 145.9 million shares, from 154.6 million on Tuesday.
''The Dow's close was within 55 points of its all-time high of 2,791.41 and it has appreciated 26 percent so far in 1989.'' said Harold A. Mackinney, head of the investment policy committee at the Fleet/Northstar Financial Group in Providence, R.I. ''Investors are reluctant to take the market to new highs in the face of obvious current weakness in corporate profits.'' 
He said that as the end of the year approaches, portfolio managers will be eager to show clients that they have a fairly full position in equities, thus limitng their downside potentential.
Some traders said investors appeared to be marking time until unemployment and non-farm payroll figures for November are released tomorrow. Current estimates are that unemployment will be in a range of 5.3 to 5.4 percent and non-farm payrolls at about 180 million.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that productivity in the non-farm sector had improved at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, while hours worked increased at a slower 1.3 percent, a sign of weakening demand for goods.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock dropped 1.03 points, to 348.55, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.37, to 192.82.
 
Bank Stocks Weaken
Bank stocks weakened after a Government report found that the nation's commercial banks lost $744 million in the third quarter, partly because of rising real estate loan problems.
Wells Fargo dropped 2 5/8, to 71 3/8, after Adam Starr, an analyst with the First Manhattan Corporation, downgraded the company's stock to ''sell'' from ''hold,'' citing problems with real estate and leveraged buyout portfolios.
At the same time, First Interstate Bancorp fell 1 1/4, to 52, while it was the most active issue on a volume of 3.6 million shares.
McGraw-Hill fell 2 points, to 61 1/2, after the company announced that it would cut jobs and take other steps that will adversely affect 1989 earnings by a larger amount than Wall Street had expected, analysts said.
I.B.M., which on Tuesday announced that it would reduce its work force by more than 10,000 and take a $2.3 billion charge against fourth-quarter earnings, dropped 1, to 98 5/8.
Chevron rose 1 1/4, to 72. The company said it had sold 14.1 million shares of newly issued common stock to the employee stock ownership plan formed last week at a price of $70.75 cents a share, for a total of about $1 billion.
Active blue chips included General Electric, unchanged at 63 3/8; Philip Morris, off 1/2, to 42 1/4; BankAmerica, off 1 3/8, to 26, and Ford Motor, unchanged at 45 1/4.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Defaults by Bond Issuers May Be Highest of Decade

 BODY:
Defaults by bond issuers are likely to reach the highest levels of the decade this year, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.
The rating agency issued a statement predicting that about 40 companies would default on bond debt in 1989, up from 33 in 1986, the record until this year. It said the rise in defaults, including unrated bond defaults mainly by smaller companies, would continue into 1990.
''We foresee a likely further increase in corporate defaults, especially among highly leveraged speculative-grade credits; possibly as much as twice the current level,'' said Christopher L. Baldwin, director of Moody's energy, technology, and communications rating unit. Mr. Baldwin made his comments earlier in the week at a gathering of corporate investors in New York.
He cited four factors likely to fuel defaults next year: a slowing economy; excessive debt burdens of industrial companies coupled with overly optimistic predictions for sales and profit growth; the disarray in the ''junk bond'' market, and a tightening of bank lending standards for leveraged buyouts.
The negative outlook is supported by both the current pace of downgrades and the magnitude of credit ratings now under review by Moody's, he said. For the first 10 months of 1989, he said, 134 junk bond issues were downgraded to lower ratings within the speculative-grade categories of Ba-1 to C.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines as Traders Remain Focused on Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against most primary foreign currencies in worldwide trading yesterday as dealers kept their buying interest focused on West German marks.
Gold prices edged slightly higher in the United States after turning in a mixed performance overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery ended at $404.90 an ounce, up $1.40 from late Tuesday. 
Currency dealers received an incentive to sell dollars from reports that a United States Treasury official said the dollar's recent decline against the mark was not alarming, said Thomas J. Palladino, an assistant vice president in the New York office of the Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank.
The remark, attributed to David C. Mulford, Treasury Under Secretary, was interpreted to mean that Washington would not intervene aggressively in foreign exchange markets to stem the dollar's slide against the mark.
''It seems everybody is looking for a lower dollar,'' Mr. Palladino said. ''It's more of a mark driven market than a dollar-driven market.''
Some dealers said the strength of the West German economy justified the rise in the mark's value.
The demand for marks has surged as the borders between East and West Germany have crumbled. The assumption is that liberalizations in East Germany and elsewhere in Eastern Europe could make the West German economy boom, possibly leading to higher interest rates there.
Higher interest rates in West Germany would tend to increase returns on mark-denominated investments.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 144.02 yen, up from 143.79 yen late on Tuesday. And the pound rose to $1.5765, from $1.5700.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.7772 West German marks, down from 1.7775; 1.5890 Swiss francs, down from 1.5915; 6.0690 French francs, down from 6.0670; 1,303.25 Italian lire, down from 1,309.50, and 1.16115 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1633.
The prices for precious metals were mixed, and gold lost ground on several world markets as dealers sold to collect profits amassed during the recent surge in gold prices.
Gold bullion prices dropped in London, a critical market, but were higher in Zurich, at $400 to $405 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Swiss Bank In U.S. Link

 BODY:
The Swiss Bank Corporation of Zurich is joining forces with O'Connor & Associates of Chicago, the leading trader of financial options in the United States, the two companies announced yesterday.
The new company, called SBC-O'C Risk Management Services, will expand the Swiss bank's business in options for equities, interest rates and foreign currencies. The capital base of the new company was not disclosed. It is to start operations in 1990 with 400 employees in the leading financial centers around the world.
Most of the 400 employees will come from the 600 currently employed by O'Connor & Associates. O'Connor's remaining 200 employees will handle the trading in the options and futures markets for American stocks.
O'Connor & Associates is a privatey held firm and the largest market maker in the financial options exchanges in the United States.

HEADLINE: Harland Bartholomew, 100, Dean of City Planners

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Harland Bartholomew, the dean of comprehensive city planning in the United States, died Saturday at his home in Clayton, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis. He was 100 years old.
Mr. Bartholomew, a consulting engineer, was appointed to Federal planning committees by three Presidents, Herbert Hoover, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Dwight D. Eisenhower. 
In 1941 President Roosevelt appointed Mr. Bartholomew to a committee to recommend a limited system of national highways. He also helped plan the Metro subway system in Washington, and he represented the Rockefeller interests in the restoration of historic Williamsburg, Va.
President Eisenhower appointed Mr. Bartholomew chairman of the National Capital Planning Commission a position he held for seven years, A City Planner in Newark Mr. Bartholomew became the nation's first full-time city planner in 1914, when he went to work for the city of Newark. Two years later he went to St. Louis as a city engineer, and he later opened a consulting firm, Harland Bartholomew & Associates, which now has its headquarters in Memphis. He retired in 1965. His firm prepared comprehensive plans for more than 500 cities and counties, including Bal Horbour, Fla., St. Croix, V.I., and Grand Bahama Island in the Bahamas. Mr. Bartholomew also prepared plans for the reconstruction of the resort community of Bar Harbor, Me., after two-thirds of it was destroyed by a forest fire in 1947.
His firm also assisted in the preparation of many zoning ordinances. including a statewide ordinance for Hawaii.
He was an early advocate of slum clearance and city planning, and served on the national Slum Clearance Advisory Committee. His ideas helped shape the Housing Act of 1937 and the Housing Act of 1949.
Mr. Bartholomew was born in Stoneham, Mass., and received his civil engineering training at Rutgers University. He taught civic design at the University of Illinois from 1918 to 1956.
Mr. Bartholomew, who was widowed three times, is survived by five stepchildren: George Ball of Travers City, Mich., Barbara Cosden of Manhattan, Dorothy Friestedt of Washington and Georganne Pollnow and R. F. Funston Jr., both of St. Louis. He is also survived by three grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Union Wonders if It Can Trust Owners

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Dec. 6

 BODY:
Mistrust of owners and treatment of younger players were the most widely discussed topics today at a meeting of the Major League Baseball Players Association's executive board.
The union representatives discussed those matters as they began to develop their proposals for a new collective-bargaining agreement. They will continue working on proposals at their session Thursday. 
Don Mattingly, the Yankees' player representative, appeared at a news briefing with Donald Fehr, the association's executive director, and summarized the concerns the players expressed during the meeting.
''There's a major distrust in the basic agreement we signed in 1985,'' Mattingly said. ''We basically look at it as having no meaning. Directly after that, collusion came about. There's a lot of problems believing we can trust that things we talk about and put in the basic agreement are going to be followed through.''
 
Younger Players Speak Up
The younger players on the executive board, Mattingly added, demonstrated a ''very strong interest in making sure that we take care of'' the younger players, those in their first three years in the major leagues.
''They felt they were left out of and taken advantage of in the last agreement,'' Mattingly said. ''There was a major discussion about taking care of these guys and making sure we do some things about the way they're treated in the first three years.''
In the 1985 negotiations, the union agreed to change the eligibility requirement for salary arbitration from two years in the majors to three years, thus forcing players to wait an extra year to gain the bargaining leverage of arbitration.
''The only reason the salary arbitration change was ever made,'' Fehr said, ''was in response to owners' claims of financial distress. Whatever merits those ever had - I don't think it had any - even the owners now concede that there is no merit to those arguments.''
The owners have acknowledged the players' concerns in the areas of trust and younger players. At the start of negotiations last week, they said they wanted to improve relations with the players and gain their trust. They also said their proposal for a new salary system would remedy any problems experienced by players in their first three years.
Under the system, salaries for players who have been in the majors from one year through five years would be determined by a pay-for-performance scale. The plan would eliminate salary arbitration, but, the owners say, it would increase the salaries for the younger players. ----Owners Call for 'Partnership' NASHVILLE, Dec. 6 - The major leagues closed their business meetings today with a call for an economic partnership with the players but with a pointed reminder that the club owners would press for a labor agreement to avoid a strike or lockout in spring training.
''We want an agreement in place to protect the season,'' said Charles O'Connor, the owners' new labor negotiator. ''And that includes spring training.''
Commissioner Fay Vincent said the labor issue had occupied the owners for the major part of their joint meeting today. They were briefed for nearly two hours by O'Connor, the lawyer who became their chief negotiator when Barry Rona was forced to resign the day before the clubs opened negotiations with the Players Association on a new basic agreement, or industry code.
Both Vincent and O'Connor were vague in reporting on the meeting. But O'Connor repeated the recent emphasis on conciliation, at least in tone, and said:
''We talked about achieving a better relationship on labor relations. We must forge an economic partnership for the future.''

HEADLINE: Mexican Politicians Look North of Border

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The migration of millions of Mexican workers into the United States in search of jobs has brought a new influx: Mexican politicians and leaders in search of their influence, money and votes.
While such contacts have always existed, dramatic changes in Mexico in recent months have stirred new interest in the nearly 20 million Mexicans and Mexican-Americans living north of the border. The attention is focused mainly on the greater Los Angeles area, which now has the largest concentration of people of Mexican origin, about three million, anywhere outside Mexico City.
With Mexican politics suddenly competitive, representatives of Mexico's three main political parties have visited Southern California recently. And more are expected soon, including the new President of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari. All sides have begun to see the potential for enlisting Mexicans and Mexican-Americans here to influence both Washington's stance toward Mexico and Mexican domestic policy, much the way American Jews do with Israel. 
 
Some Contradictory Emotions
''There is an awakening on their part, a recognition of their brothers and sisters on this side of the border, a real interest in developing ties,'' said Antonia Hernandez, president and general counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, a civil rights group.
But all of this has evinced complex and contradictory emotions among Mexican-Americans, who have spent years trying to gain acceptance and power in the American political system. The new approaches from Mexico are not universally welcomed; there is concern that they will aggravate American fears that the loyalty of this linguistic minority may be uncertain.
Representing the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI for its initials in Spanish, Mexico's new Foreign Minister, Fernando Solana, capped a visit to Los Angeles last Friday night with a speech at a black-tie awards dinner held by the Mexican-American civil rights group. Addressing more than 1,000 people at the dinner, he said their community was ''an ideal vehicle'' for better communication with the United States.
 
Visit From Opposition Leader
His visit followed a barnstorming tour last month by Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the leader of the left-leaning Revolutionary Democratic Party, who lost to Mr. Salinas in the July 1988 Presidential election despite a vigorous challenge to the PRI's 60-year monopoly on power. Hoping to gain support from disaffected Mexicans forced to emigrate because of economic decline at home, he gave many speeches, raised $31,000 and visited leading California liberals like Jane Fonda, Stanley K. Sheinbaum, who is a wealthy patron of liberal causes, and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. Earlier this year there was a visit from Manuel Clouthier, leader of the rightist National Action Party, who died in an automobile accident on Oct. 1.
''I receive every week Mexican politicians who come here to do politics,'' said Sergio Munoz, executive editor of La Opinion, the largest Spanish-language newspaper here.
Mr. Cardenas has proposed that Mexico allow emigres to vote by absentee ballot. Even without absentee voting, Mexican politicians have begun to grasp the political importance of the two-way flow of people, money, technology and ideas across the porous border. Mexicans working in the United States are Mexico's largest source of foreign exchange after tourism. They are concentrated in Texas, Illinois and California. Of the three million people of Mexican descent in the Los Angeles area, about one-third are believed to be Mexican nationals, here legally or illegally.
 
Dissatisfaction in Mexico
''The U.S. is still a foreign culture to Mexicans,'' said Richard Maullin, a political consultant in Los Angeles with extensive Mexican ties. ''They do not come flocking because they love it here, but to make a living and go back rich. If you were a Cardenas raising complaints about the way Mexico is run, there would be votes here. At the same time, the PRI has to be sensitive to the dissatisfaction.''
''People live here for a while and go back,'' agreed Mr. Munoz. ''If you leave your country you have resentment at the situation that makes that necessary. That dictates a strategy of PRI to win back support.''
The backdrop for this are powerful changes in Mexico. The 1988 Mexican election, the most closely contested in its history, brought Mr. Salinas to power with a vow to modernize Mexico and to integrate it into the world economy. Mr. Salinas, a 41-year-old Harvard-educated economist, lowered nationalistic oratory and brought in a new breed of intellectuals to help him, including Mr. Solana.
This left an opening for the more nationalistic message of Mr. Cardenas, whose father was Lazaro Cardenas, a founder of the PRI in the 1920's and one of Mexico's most beloved Presidents. The younger Mr. Cardenas bolted his father's party, saying it had corrupted his father's legacy. He won 31 percent of the vote against Mr. Salinas's 50 percent, but some say an honest count would have made Mr. Cardenas the President. He is revered among Mexicans here; many of them came from his home state of Michoacan.
 
Attacks on Both Governments
He is widely expected to run again in 1994, and that was what brought him to Los Angeles last month. He met with local editorial writers, did radio interviews, was given a reception at City Hall, held fund-raising events, spoke at California State University, the University of Southern California and other schools and made the keynote speech at the banquet of the Mexican-American Political Association.
He brought a strident message, denouncing both the Bush and Salinas governments for their handling of the drug trade, economic ties, Central American policy, the foreign debt and migration. And he openly appealed to Mexican workers here, calling on the Mexican Government to do more to protect them.
''Most Mexicans that migrate permanently, temporarily or cyclically to the U.S. become in fact citizens of a second class in both countries,'' he said. He urged his Government to use whatever ''leverage'' it could to help them and demanded that they be allowed to cast absentee ballots in Mexican elections.
''Cardenas considers these people as important to bring about democratic change in Mexico,'' said one of his leading backers, Raul Ruiz, a professor of Chicano studies at California State University in Northridge. ''Most here had to come as a result of economic problems. The PRI recognizes that these millions would not necessarily turn into a friendly vote for them.''
 
A Bid to Influence Congress
Mr. Cardenas called on Mexican-Americans to form lobbying groups to influence Congress and the President on behalf of Mexico. ''We are following what the Jews do for Israel,'' said Joe Sanchez, a Los Angeles grocery distributor who backs Mr. Cardenas. ''Mexico cannot change from within.'' The visit of Mr. Solana, the Foreign Minister, was less explicitly political. But he, too, met with opinion makers and gave interviews. And in his speech to the Mexican American Legal Defense Fund he appeared to be responding to Mr. Cardenas's criticisms, saying his Government was protecting the migrants. In a more muted way, he also called on Mexican-Americans to help Mexico's cause.
''Within the context of its new relationship with the United States, the Mexican Government wishes to establish closer ties with the Mexican-American community,'' he said. ''Because of our shared language, beliefs and values, we see the Mexican-American community as an ideal vehicle for better and more effective communication with the United States.''
A key dividing issue is the Cardenas call for an absentee vote for the migrants. The PRI strongly opposes it, and many Mexican-American leaders are also dubious even though they are American citizens and vote in American elections.
 
'A Degree of Skepticism'
''The quandary is that we have a strong civil rights movement in the Mexican-American community,'' said one of its leaders, Prof. Juan Gomez-Quinones of the University of California at Los Angeles, a historian of Mexican-United States relations. ''So along comes somebody who rings a bell and says, 'How about the old country?' It's seen with a degree of skepticism by many Mexican-Americans. But it does resonate with newer immigrants.''
Among those uneasy about the vote was Ms. Hernandez, the civil rights leader. ''We are trying to make a place in this dynamic American society,'' she said, adding that giving the Mexican vote to newer immigrants might feed American stereotypes that all Mexicans are foreigners. ''It's going to make our advancement more difficult.''
Professor Ruiz said he was ''indignant'' that a civil rights leader like Ms. Hernandez would oppose voting rights, regardless of the country in which they are exercised.''It has no negative impact on American citizens of Mexican ancestry,'' he added.
To Mr. Munoz, the newspaper editor, who has worked here for 14 years but remains a Mexican national, this debate is yet another manifestation of Mexico's long and difficult relationship with the United States. ''This reflects the deep contradictions that some Mexicans who live here have not solved yet: how to deal with the country of their ancestors.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1687 words

HEADLINE: WESTERN EUROPE MOVES TO EXPAND FREE-TRADE LINKS

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Western European governments plan to announce an agreement later this month to establish a free-trade zone that includes the 12 nations of the European Community and 6 others, diplomats and community officials said in recent days.
The officials said the six nations in the European Free Trade Association - Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland - had forged a joint pact with the community to ease the movement of goods, services, capital and people between the two groups.
 
'European Economic Space'
The proposed agreement, expected to be signed on Dec. 19 at a Brussels meeting of foreign and trade ministers from the 18 nations, will give the six smaller countries a special relationship with the community, creating what has been termed a ''European economic space.'' 
The tentative framework for expanding a European common market is a result of the rapid economic and political changes unfolding in both Western and Eastern Europe. In a European Community meeting that begins on Friday, President Francois Mitterrand of France is expected to push for a firm new commitment to rapid economic integration within the community to cope with those changes. [Page D5.] With the 12-member European Community moving to establish a single, barrier-free market by 1992, the small but prosperous nations of the European Free Trade Association are fearful of being excluded. With a total population of just 32 million, the six countries represent the European Community's largest trading partner, buying and selling far more with the community than the United States or Japan.
 
Compromise With Neighbors
For the community, a closer linkage with its nearest neighbors gives its drive to a single market in 1992 greater weight. In addition, it allows the community to offer the nations on its periphery the compromise of economic enfranchisement without membership, thus forestalling a potentially nettlesome issue for the integration of the community.
In Washington, United States trade officials said today that the proposal could make Europe a better trading partner by making it stronger economically.
''This is a further extension of free trade; it is a natural evolution,'' said the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills.
Franklin J. Vargo, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Europe, said the United States was counting on liberal trade and investment decisions to emerge from any new agreements.
With the proposed agreement, the community has presumably set aside for years the issue of taking new members. Austria, for instance, has applied for membership in the community, and there are pressures in other association nations to apply as well.
The tentative agreement for the economic integration of the two Western European groups is also seen as a model for eventually integrating the more politically and economically liberal East bloc nations. Moreover, the recent political developments in Eastern Europe and the warmer tone in East-West relations have made it easier for several association nations, which are committed to neutrality, to form closer links with the community, which is a linchpin of the Western alliance.
Details remain to be negotiated in talks that should begin early next year and take about a year, officials of both groups said. But under the framework drafted in a series of high-level working meetings in recent months, remaining tariffs and quotas would be abolished. Industrial and product standards would be harmonized, and government construction and telecommunications projects opened to outside companies.
Moreover, there is even discussion of setting up some new supranational institutions, like a special court to settle disputes between the groups of nations and a forum to give the association an opportunity to help shape some community decisions. There would also be increased cooperation in areas like education, the environment and research and development.
Foreign and agricultural policy are not covered by the proposed agreement. And the community would still handle its own negotiations on external trade matters, like disputes over dumping or trade barriers, with little reference to the association.
In many ways, the new economic zone would be a happy compromise between the association and the community, whose members are West Germany, Britain, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Denmark, Ireland, Spain, Portugal and Greece.
 
A Leading Advocate
Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the community's executive branch, has been a leading advocate of creating the envisioned European economic space.
Already, individual association countries already have free-trade agreements with community members for many products, but that level of integration falls far short of the proposed agreement.
About 55 percent of association's exports go to the community, and 27 percent of community exports go to association nations. Last year trade between the groups totaled $220 billion, or $56 billion more than trade between the community and the United States. The association countries have a population roughly a tenth the community's 325 million.
''Each is the other's most important trade partner by a long way,'' said Helen S. Wallace, director of the Western European program at the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London. ''This is important because it is creating a bigger common market, a bigger economic entity.''
 
No 'Fortress Europe' Danger
But Dr. Wallace said the proposed agreement does not seem to carry the danger of a larger but protectionist bloc, the ''Fortress Europe'' feared by many American and Japanese business executives. ''At the moment, there is not an indication that there will be a common policy vis-a-vis the United States or Japan.''
The association members view the proposed agreement as a sensible response to Europe's new economic realities. ''It is a necessity for E.F.T.A. companies to have access to the E.C. market, to be able to compete on an equal basis,'' said Jon Baldvin Hannibalsson, Iceland's Minister for Foreign Affairs and External Trade, who is also chairman of the European Free Trade Association's Council of Ministers.
The European Community has been worried about association nations applying for community membership. Many in the community say they already face enough challenges in creating a single, borderless market by 1992 without taking on more members.
Another obstacle to community membership is the neutrality of several association nations. Norway and Iceland belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, as do most of the community nations. But Sweden, Austria and Switzerland are neutral. So is Finland, but it is careful not to antagonize the Soviet Union, with which it shares an 800-mile border, extensive trade relations and a mutual defense agreement.
 
Little Strategic Importance
The community now has one neutral member: Ireland. But it is relatively small and has little strategic importance. Austria, which applied for community membership last summer, was mentioned by some community officials as most troubling to them.
There has been mounting pressure from business leaders in Sweden and Norway to apply to the European Community. Companies in the association nations have been greatly increasing investments in the community. Last year, for the first time, investment by Swedish companies outside Sweden exceeded domestic investment.
Business executives and some opposition parties in the neutral nations are even saying that with East-West tensions subsiding, their countries should re-examine the importance of maintaining their neutrality.
''Most managers believe Sweden sooner or later will be a member of the Common Market,'' said Christer Zetterberg, president of PKbanken, the state-controlled Swedish bank who next spring will become president of AB Volvo, the car maker. The issue of neutrality as an obstacle ''is undergoing a dramatic change'' because of improved East-West relations, he added.
 
Finns Encouraged by Gorbachev
The Finns, who are reluctant to irritate their powerful neighbor to the east, were greatly encouraged by an October visit from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, whose comments they interpreted as giving Helsinki tacit permission to form closer ties with Western Europe by becoming part of the European economic space.
To the Finns' delight, Mr. Gorbachev said he recognized Finland's neutrality and right to set its own social and political policies. ''The message was that we could choose our own way,'' a Finnish diplomat said.
The association and the community also believe the European economic space approach is especially important given the events in Eastern Europe. The developments ''give an added sense of urgency,'' said Ulf Dinkelspiel, Sweden's chief negotatior with the community.
Association leaders have worried that the issue of their nations forging closer ties with the community would become a second priority in the community because of the changes in Eastern Europe.
Many in the community and the association also believe closer, formal ties will enable Western Europe to act with greater unity in helping Eastern Europe move toward democracy and overcome its economic problems. ''The 18 countries will be in a better position to coordinate policies and to pool resources on a scale to be of real assistance to these countries,'' Mr. Hannibalsson said.
 
Integrating the East
In addition, the European economic space approach could serve as a way to integrate Eastern European countries one day with those of Western Europe. The economic zone should not be exclusive to the 18 nations of the community and the association, Frans Andriessen, the community's External Affairs Commissioner, stressed last month.
Poland, Hungary and Yugoslavia have expressed interest in joining the community or the association. But for many reasons community officials say it is better to have them or other Eastern European nations become part of the European economic space.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1012 words

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Quayle Gets Free Rein To Criticize Gorbachev

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The White House, concerned about conservative dissatisfaction with President Bush's warm praise for Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Malta summit, has given Vice President Dan Quayle free rein to criticize the Soviet President and his policies, Administration officials said today.
In a televised interview Wednesday night on the ''Larry King Live'' program on Cable News Network, Mr. Quayle suggested that Mr. Gorbachev probably enjoys more popularity abroad than at home and warned against ''getting caught up in the magnetic personality of Chairman Gorbachev.''
In an interview published by The Washington Post on Tuesday, Mr. Quayle said the Soviet Union had a ''totalitarian system'' that sought ''to create instability in areas like Central America.'' The next day he told editors and reporters of Knight-Ridder newspapers that he should have called the Soviet Union authoritarian rather than totalitarian, but repeated the negative tone of his earlier remarks. 
Mr. Quayle said today in an interview with reporters from the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia that the Soviet domestic economic problems had not prevented Moscow from giving $7 billion a year in aid to Cuba and $1 billion to Nicaragua. Mr. Quayle said he wondered if the Soviet people knew how much food, shelter and other assistance that money would buy.
On the face of it, the comments seem at odds with Mr. Bush's remarks that Mr. Gorbachev's handling of changes in Eastern Europe ''absolutely mandates new thinking'' in the West's approach to Moscow.
On Wednesday, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, described Mr. Quayle's comments as ''strange,'' and likened him to a character in Russian literature who stubbornly resisted change. ''Like Kozma Prutkov, this noble knight is in the same position, sitting on a stone while the world is changing,'' Mr. Gerasimov said. Speaking in a Different Voice But Mr. Quayle's statements, according to White House officials, Quayle aides and Republican political analysts, do not reflect differences in American policy, but rather a willingness to let the Vice President speak in a different voice about Mr. Gorbachev partly to reassure conservatives.
One top Administration official described the process as an attempt to tailor the optimism of Malta to the skepticism of some of the NATO allies in Brussels and to the criticism in some circles back in Washington.
''We got back here and noticed that while the summit was getting high marks, the euphoria, if there was any, had worn off,'' the official said. ''In fact, with some hard-headed looking around at the actual issues to be negotiated and the possibility of crackdowns, there wasn't any euphoria. At that point White House officials decided that we might have gotten a little bit far out in embracing Gorbachev on the ship and that the Vice President saying what he believed was kind of helpful to the President.''
The Administration's strategy is aimed in part at appealing to and reassuring the Republican Party's right wing. It also allows Mr. Quayle to say things that Mr. Bush or Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d believe but would feel uncomfortable articulating.
 
'Difference in Tonal Quality'
''What the Vice President is doing is articulating a part of U.S. policy: differences with the Soviet Union,'' said David Beckwith, Mr. Quayle's spokesman. ''You can call it a difference in tonal quality. We're all singing from the same songbook but there are different parts. Some people are singing bass, some alto.''
Another White House official put it more bluntly. ''It doesn't hurt to give some reassurance to those people within the party who may have doubts about the Administration's goals and objectives,'' he said.
Among those who expressed skepticism of Mr. Bush's performance at Malta was the former arms control negotiator Paul H. Nitze. At a breakfast interview with reporters this week, Mr. Nitze criticized Mr. Bush's promise to speed up three sets of arms control negotiations and warned against the mood of ''euphoria'' emerging from the summit. ''I don't think Mr. Gorbachev has become a democrat,'' Mr. Nitze said, adding that he ''continues to be a Communist.''
 
A Less Sanguine View
In private briefings since the summit meeting, Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle have reportedly taken a less sanguine view of Mr. Gorbachev's prospects. Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., president of the Hudson Institute and a Republican political strategist close to Mr. Quayle, described a meeting at the White House on Wednesday for American foreign policy leaders, including Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former chief American representative at the United Nations, and Zbigniew Bzrezinski, the former national security adviser, as ''a great deal more cautious and prudent'' than some of Mr. Bush's more enthusiastic remarks.
Mr. Daniels added, ''We heard a very sophisticated, realistic attitude about the depth of the problem and the lack of understanding of market economics on part of the Soviets.''
Similarly, at a briefing by Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle for the Congressional leadership today, the difficulty of change in the Soviet Union and lack of agreement between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev on Central America ''were prominent,'' according to one White House official. #2 Different Effects Mr. Quayle's remarks have had the effect of mollifying some conservative Republicans and insulting others.
Paul M. Weyrich, president of the Free Congress Foundation, sees Mr. Quayle's approach as ''part of a greater Administration strategy.'' He said, ''It is very useful to have a Vice President say certain things which you want said but you do not want to say for policy reasons.''
L. Brent Bozell, a conservative organizer, on the other hand, described himself as ''offended'' by Mr. Quayle's comments if they reflect a White House strategy to deal with the right. ''What they are saying then is that Bush will state policy and Quayle will throw the bones to the rabid right to keep us at bay,'' Mr. Bozell added. ''We don't have any use for that.''

HEADLINE: Aid to Poland Sets Off a Fight Over Shipping

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
American ships carrying food aid began arriving in Poland last week. But they will deliver less food than they could, critics say, with correspondingly fewer benefits to American farmers, because of a law that results in higher shipping costs.
The cargo preference law, which requires that 75 percent of humanitarian food aid be shipped on United States merchant ships, rather than cheaper foreign vessels, has frustrated agricultural groups. They argue that the extra transportation costs could reduce grain shipments by as much as 40 percent. 
The application of the law to food shipments to Poland was challenged this year by members of Congress. They contended that every dollar of the $125 million in food aid was needed to bolster the shaky economy of Poland and help that country make the transition from a Communist to a more market-driven system.
Representative Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa, who spoke in favor of an amendment in October to suspend the law for Poland, argued that the cost differential between American and foreign ships prevented Poland from getting the most out of the aid. The amendment failed by 178 to 228.
In the House debate, Mr. Grandy cited the example of an American ship that left for Poland with 11,500 tons of grain sorghum at a shipping rate of $84.95 a ton. A Polish ship carrying an identical cargo charged $26 a ton.
 
Shipments Will Be Less
The cost of grain and the cost to transport cargo fluctuate constantly, making it difficult for even the Congressional Budget Office, the budgetary arm of Congress, to estimate the amount of food Poland will receive. But both sides concede that under the cargo preference law the shipments will be less than they would be without it.
''It begs the question of whether food aid helps the Poles or the U.S. shipping industry,'' said George Berg Jr., an assistant director at the American Farm Bureau Federation in Washington.
Congress approved the law in 1953 as a way to subsidize privately owned American ships to insure that the United States would have a cargo fleet ready in the event of war. It was also seen as a way to preserve jobs for union workers. Because of higher labor costs, American ships have difficulty competing with foreign ships.
Lewis Paine, director of market development at the United States Maritime Administration, said that American merchant ships are more expensive but that it is ''fiction'' to say that farmers are substantially affected. Since the foreign assistance programs were enacted, the agencies responsible for providing food aid have factored the extra costs into their budgets, he said.
 
A Bitter Debate in Congress
Though efforts to overturn the law are made in Congress every year, the debate this year was unusually bitter, with farm states and maritime interests charging that the other side was exploiting the food aid package for its own benefit.
''We made a real issue about it on the floor of the House,'' said Representative Virginia Smith, Republican of Nebraska. ''It's not fair to the Polish people when we want to send food to them we have to send the food on more expensive American ships. We would rather send them the grain.''
Mrs. Smith suggested that if the fleet is needed for defense, the Department of Defense should finance its costs. ''This is really subsidizing the maritime industry on the backs of farmers,'' she said.
But members from industrial states argued that agriculture, as the most highly subsidized sector of the American economy, should bear some of the burden. Pro-labor members are also involved in the debate, arguing that suspending cargo preference in the case of Poland would be an insult to union workers who have supported Polish workers since 1980.
Supporters of the law also suggest that if the primary concern of opponents is to get the most food for the money, the United States should buy grain abroad, where it is cheaper.

HEADLINE: Ex-Klan Leader Facing First Test in Senate Bid

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
To almost everyone in Louisiana politics, he is the most overpublicized man in American politics, a freshman state legislator without a substantive achievement who has nevertheless become a national figure.
But when Louisiana Republicans meet in party caucuses Saturday, all eyes will again be on David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader, who announced earlier this week that he planned to run for the United States Senate seat held by J. Bennett Johnston Jr., a three-term Democrat.
Political analysts give Mr. Duke virtually no chance of winning the seat, but the caucuses Saturday could help indicate whether the 38-year-old legislator is a serious candidate for higher office or just an extremist with a genius for garnering publicity and the contributions that come with it.
At the least, Louisiana's quirky political history, its unusual electoral framework and Mr. Duke's knack for serving as a lightning rod could allow him to play a role that is out of proportion with his chances of success. 
 
'The Ability to Polarize'
''I don't think he can win, but I think he has the ability to polarize and poison our politics in a way that's very unhealthy,'' said Lawrence N. Powell, a history professor at Tulane University.
Mr. Duke's conventional credentials for higher office are slim. He was elected to the Louisiana House of Representatives in February in a race that gained national attention because of Mr. Duke's longtime ties with far-right groups and causes.
But the district where he ran is 99 percent white, and he narrowly defeated his opponent, John Treen, who was widely viewed as unpopular.
Skeptics say Mr. Duke clearly taps into widespread economic and racial frustrations, but they also contend that his notoriety says more about what garners the attention of the news media than it does about politics.
 
'He's a Celebrity'
''I don't think he's really that strong in Louisiana; he's best at capturing attention from outsiders and raising funds from it,'' said Wayne Parent, a political science professor at Louisiana State University. ''He's a celebrity, a Jimmy Swaggart, a Zsa Zsa Gabor, who's very good at playing to the media.''
Mr. Duke says he has been underestimated before. ''They said the same thing about my House race,'' he said. ''I'm the only Republican who can attract a sizable number of the blue-collar, Ronald Reagan, George Wallace voters you need to win.''
The first test of Mr. Duke's appeal since his election to the Legislature will come Saturday when the Republicans meet in caucuses at 14 sites to pick delegates for the state Republican convention on Jan 13. The delegates will then select a nominee for the October 1990 Senate race.
Mr. Duke is one of three active candidates for the nomination. The others are Ben Bagert, a State Senator, and Fox McKeithen, the Louisiana Secretary of State.
 
'Silent Support' Cited
Top Republican officials say Mr. Duke will not be a major factor in the caucuses.
''There's no chance he will win enough delegates to be the endorsed candidate of the Republican Party,'' said William Nungesser, the state Republican chairman. ''With his past, why should we choose someone like him to lead us?''
But others note that Mr. Duke's followers are more likely to be motivated than those of the other candidates, and think he could make a strong showing.
''I think he'll surprise people; he has a lot of silent support,'' said Elizabeth Rickey, a frequent critic of Mr. Duke and a member of the 140-member state Republican Central Committee. ''His supporters are very comitted. The supporters of the others are not.''
He would probably need half the delegates to win the nomination, which even Ms. Rickey sees as unlikely.
 
Runoff With Johnston Sought
But in Louisiana, losing the nomination does not mean a candidate is out of the race. The state has an open primary in which Senator Johnston, the Republican nominee and other candidates will run against each other, and there is a runoff if no candidate gets 50 percent of the vote.
Mr. Duke says he will stay in the race if he does not get the nomination, and hopes to get in a runoff with Mr. Johnston.
Mr. Duke, who heads a group called the National Association for the Advancement of White People, has said he regrets some of his previous stands. He bills himself as a candidate who is pro-white rather than anti-black and has pushed for legislation to change welfare programs to curb the growth of what he calls the ''rising welfare underclass.''
But critics say Mr. Duke's appeal remains thinly veiled racism. A group called the Louisiana Coalition Against Racism and Nazism today released a interview with a former Tulane University student in which Mr. Duke said the United States should not have fought II against the Nazis in World War II and was quoted as saying: ''There's only one country anymore that's all-white, and that's Iceland. And Iceland's not enough.''
 
A Lonely Political Figure
Mr. Duke says a victory in the Senate race would inspire a torrent of similar candidacies, but political analysts say he remains a lonely figure in electoral politics because overt racial politics are difficult to make work in states where blacks are a sizable electoral block. Blacks make up about 25 percent of Louisiana's voters.
''These kind of candidacies made sense only when blacks didn't vote,'' said Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University in Atlanta. ''I think what he represents is alarming, but I don't think there's much of a market for it.''
But in Louisiana, a state whose most successful politicans were former Governors Huey P. Long and Edwin Edwards, the unexpected sometimes seems routine.
And even those who are skeptical of Mr. Duke's chances in a Senate race acknowledge that he serves as a social barometer and is a potential divisive force in Republican politics because of his racial stands.
''He makes explicit what the others leave unstated,'' Dr. Black said. ''He goes into the water and pulls the fish out.''

HEADLINE: San Francisco Journal;
Grimaces Over a Dab Of Glitz In Skyline

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7

 BODY:
In this city where glitter and glitz are dirty words, residents are trying to sort out how redevelopment has lit up their skyline with a hotel only Liberace could love.
The new 1,500-room San Francisco Marriott, which features giant fan-shaped windows of reflective blue glass, can be seen from virtually every part of the city. Viewed from the south, its 40-story tower tipped in gleaming glass reminds many of a thermometer. From other angles, its protruding half circles of glistening windows recall a jukebox, leading some to dub it ''the Wurlitzer.'' 
Garishness as a theme is carried to the interior as well, where the lobby features a chandelier the approximate shape and size of a city bus.
For San Franciscans who like to think of their city as some charming Mediterranean village, looking up from their morning cafe au lait to see the Marriott is as jolting as going to bed in Nice and waking up in Las Vegas. Some believe the hotel is simply in the wrong city and suggest alternative sites as though it could be moved. Some locals have taken to referring to it as the hotel designed for Cher.
''It is glitzy,'' said the hotel's designer, Tony Lumsden of the Los Angeles architecture firm of DMJM. ''The glass is more reflective than was proposed. It's not a mistake on my part,'' he continued. ''It was not the intention. It was not the agreed glass.'' Mr. Lumsden said the Marriott Corporation did not wish him to discuss the matter further.
The hotel stands as an example of the complex set of trade-offs cities make in trying to find the best use for public land. While Federal officials envisioned urban redevelopment in the 1950's as replacing dilapidated inner-city tenements with modern affordable housing, more often it has cleared blighted areas to build shopping malls, office buildings and condominiums. In exchange, revenue generated from leasing or selling the land or assessing fees, and tax laws allowing the higher taxes on new construction to flow directly to local redevelopment agencies, provide money for public projects.
Here, the new Marriott hotel is the cash cow, as such private projects are called by redevelopment agencies, that will finance the operating costs of the adjacent Yerba Buena Gardens. That 22-acre project will include a performing arts theater, landscaped open space and a visual arts center designed by the Japanese architect Fumihiko Maki. Similarly, Olympia and York, a Canadian developer, purchased publicly owned land in the same area for office buildings and is donating some of that land for the new home of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art to be designed by the Swiss Modernist Mario Botta.
But in exchange for the revenue, the city gave up the right to require that building designs be subject to review by the Planning Department and its commission. Officials for those agencies said the Marriott's design could never have passed. But Edward Helfeld, the executive director of the Redevelopment Agency, defends the Marriott. ''It's a building that's fun,'' he said. ''We don't have many of these. It's not austere or overly dignified.''
Attempts by Marriott to show that its heart is in the right place, even if its building is not, have been rebuffed by local critics. Last month, for instance, some architects boycotted the annual Beaux Arts Ball, a charity fund raiser of the San Francisco chapter of the American Institue of Architects, when it was moved from its usual location in the rotunda of City Hall to the new hotel after Marriott offered to underwrite the expenses.
The hotel, in the area south of Market Street that surrounds the Moscone Convention Center, is hardly the first controversial building in the city. When the Transamerica Corporation built its now famous pyramid-shaped headquarters in the financial district here, it met with howls of disapproval. Today it is viewed by many as one of the few buildings that make this city's skyline distinctive.
Some believe the hotel has been unfairly singled out. ''It's kind of pretty at sunset,'' said John Elberling, the director of a nonprofit housing corporation that has provided apartments for senior citizens in the Yerba Buena area. And after viewing the model of the 400-foot office tower planned by Olympia and York, he has taken a you-ain't-seen-nothing-yet attitude.
''They're going to build an equally tall office building with a metal sculpture that looks like a giant harp on top,'' Mr. Elberling said. ''That building is wild and crazy. Who knows what the public will think?''

HEADLINE: Head of Air Force Says Cuts In Spending May Delay B-2

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Donald B. Rice, the Secretary of the Air Force, said today that he was considering a slowdown in production of the B-2 Stealth bomber as military spending declines.
Mr. Rice also left open the possibility that the Air Force might eventually decide to buy fewer than the 132 B-2's it had wanted through the mid-1990's.
The Secretary spoke to reporters as Pentagon officials disclosed new details about President Bush's decision on the 1991 Pentagon budget. Officials said on Wednesday that the President had decided to budget about $295 billion for the Pentagon in the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1, 1990. This would lower the Pentagon's purchasing power by about 3 percent once inflation is taken into account. 
The figure is being derived from a $292.1 billion limit on actual outlays set by the President. The budget authority for a given year reflects money that will be spent over a period of years; the Federal deficit is measured in terms of outlays for that year alone. #1991: A 'Transition Year'
In his meeting with reporters, Mr. Rice said 1991 might be an important ''transition year'' as the Pentagon adjusts to lower military budgets.
Asked about the B-2 program, he said the Air Force was ''looking at the option of procuring it over a longer period of time.'' The Air Force had initially planned particularly heavy spending for the B-2 from 1992 through 1994: $7.8 billion in 1992, $8.4 billion in 1993 and $7.7 billion in 1994. An Air Force spokesman said the service had hoped to have 76 of its 132 planes by 1995.
But Pentagon officials are expecting much tighter restraints on spending in those years. And the B-2, whose cost was initially projected at $500 million apiece, has come under heavy criticism in Congress, though the lawmakers have approved billions in spending for it.
Mr. Rice did not say how such a slowdown might affect the eventual deployment of B-2's. The deployment schedule is classified secret and has not been disclosed.
But one Pentagon official said a slowdown would be likely to delay fielding of a force of B-2's from the mid-1990's until the late 1990's. This official said a slowdown was envisioned in the Air Force's proposals for cutting the 1992-94 budgets, which it submitted to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney last month.
 
Effect on Costs
One big question is whether a production slowdown would increase costs. In presentations to Congress, Air Force officials have argued that it would, but Mr. Rice said the Air Force was studying ways to avoid that problem. ''We're interested in doing that only if it can still be done efficiently,'' he added.
Asked whether the Air Force might buy fewer than 132 planes, the Secretary replied, ''I think 132 is a good number, and if it were to be questioned, it is something that doesn't need to be decided for quite a few years to come.''

HEADLINE: JUDGE BACKS RULE ON WORK AT HOME

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
In a defeat for organized labor, a Federal district judge today upheld a Labor Department regulation that allows people to work at home in five apparel-related industries.
The ruling by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell rescinded a ban on working at home in the five industries. He said the regulation represented a ''reasoned'' approach requiring companies seeking to institute home work to come forward and seek certification from the Government. They would also be subject to monitoring by department inspectors. 
The International Ladies Garment Workers' union and two other unions sued the Secretary of Labor in January, saying that tens of thousands of workers, mostly immigrant women, would be exploited by the rule and that the working standards of other workers would be threatened.
The five industries affected by the rule are those making gloves and mittens, handkerchiefs, buttons and buckles, some types of jewelry and embroidery. The department held several public hearings this year on its proposed rule and has yet to issue a final version.
 
Possibility of Exploitation
Judge Gesell said the concerns of labor unions about the exploitation of home workers ''are no doubt valid.'' A ban on home work in seven industries, including the five affected by the department rule, was adopted by the Labor Department in the early 1940's. Home workers in those industries are normally paid by a piece rate rather than hourly wages.
''The evidence is strong that the conditions present in the 1940's regarding the exploitation of home workers have not disappeared,'' Judge Gesell said.
But he said the sole issue before the court was whether the Labor Department provided ''a reasoned basis'' for concluding that a certification system is a better means of enforcing Federal labor law than a total ban on work at home. He said the department drew up the rule after nearly a decade of analysis.
Lorrie McHugh, a spokeswoman for the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said the 14.1-million-member federation was ''deeply disappointed'' by the court decision. ''Removing the ban on home work opens up new doors to exploitation of workers, doors that were closed over 40 years ago because abuse ran rampant,'' she said.
The labor unions contend that the rule lacks adequate safeguards to prevent violations of laws governing minimum wage, child labor, maximum work hours, workplace safety and other issues.
Judge Gesell said states that disagreed with the department's conclusion were still free to ban home work in those industries.
Judge Gesell questioned the possible motives of both sides, saying that the department's decision to lift the ban might be motivated by ''its sympathy for certain constituences or a certain political philosophy.'' He said the unions might be motivated by concerns of their members about the ''threat of economic competition from home workers and firms employing them.''
But Judge Gesell said his role was ''not to referee this dispute or to speculate on how it has shaded'' the debate between the unions and the Government.

HEADLINE: Governors and Presidential Aides Hear Advice on Education Goals

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
In the first public follow-up to the national ''education summit'' in September, a committee of governors and White House aides heard advice today about what the United States should expect from its schools and decided to focus for now on goals, not on how to achieve them or pay for them.
More than 200 educators and business leaders either appeared before the committee today or submitted their ideas in writing.
Even among those speakers who disagreed on strategies, several common themes emerged: the need to help young children get ready for school, both physically and intellectually; the crucial role of parents in helping children learn; the need to help all children reach higher standards, not just a select few and the potential harm to American competitiveness if schools do not improve. Some of the goals were broadly outlined at the September meeting between President Bush and 49 governors. 
Committee members said their most urgent task was first to set goals that appeal not only to educators, but to the public as a whole. Once this decision is in place, they said, they will talk about strategies.
 
Difficulty of Task
''We've been too conscious in education how we do something, not whether we do it,'' said Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr., a South Carolina Republican who is co-chairman of the Governors' Task Force on Education. Testimony today suggested just how difficult the task would be. Speaker after speaker said the country has no adequate way to measure whether any goals set are achieved, because standardized tests do not adequately measure what children learn. Several warned against defining the goals so narrowly that states or local districts could not devise their own ways to meet them or so broadly that expectations would be lost in platitudes.
''People have to feel a sense of passion,'' said Richard Mills, Vermont's Commissioner of Education. ''Someone has to say, this is what we want for our children. Follow-through is everything. This is the work of a decade.'' The speakers offered a range of specific proposals. Several urged the Government to provide enough money for Head Start preschool program for the disadvantage to reach all eligible children, instead of the current 20 percent. Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, said goals should not overlook inculcating such things as creativity, self-confidence and international understanding. Many educators urged greater attention to the effects of poverty on school performance and asked that the Federal Government play a larger role.
Lauro F. Cavazos, the Secretary of Education, and Roger Porter, Assistant to the President for Economic and Domestic Affairs, played down any suggestion that the Federal role in education would change dramatically. Mr. Cavazos said the Government would not impose ideas, but would hold up successful models, disseminate research and significantly increase investment in measuring educational progress.
 
Defining Education Aims
The committee emerged from a nearly two-hour private meeting this afternoon leading toward defining the goals as they were laid out at the September meeting of President Bush and the governors, according to Mr. Porter and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
Those goals included improving literacy, reducing dropout rates, finding more qualified teachers, improving nutrition and education programs for preschool children and assuring safe, disciplined and drug-free schools.
Over the next several weeks, committee members will sift through the proposals they received today. They plan to have the substance of their findings ready in time for President Bush to include them in his State of the Union Messsage in late January , and to publish their goals in final form by Feb. 27.
After that, Governor Clinton said, the committee will embark on what looks to be the more difficult political task: agreeing on ways to achieve the goals.
