HEADLINE: Who Can Predict Our Life in the Greenhouse?;
Dueling Computers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For the most part, your article on the costs of curing the greenhouse effect (front page, Nov. 19) is balanced and circumspect. However, you should reconsider your reliance on computer simulation models to draw conclusions far into the future. 
The limitations of even the most intricate econometric models to predict the performance of the United States economy even one year ahead are well recognized by anyone who follows economic matters. Variations of 1 or 2 percent from year-ahead forecasts of gross national product are not uncommon. Weather forecasting also relies heavily on computer modeling, and no meteorologist takes seriously any forecast of more than 30 days in the future.
In forecasting the impact of the greenhouse effect, several computer simulation models are used and cited in the article (and in most serious articles on the subject). It is far more difficult to simulate something as complex as the world environment 50 years from now than the U.S. economy or next summer's weather. Yet this and other articles blithely accept conclusions drawn from the model that was based on 1 percent alterations in the assumptions.
There is general agreement in the scientific community that the theory of the greenhouse effect is valid. There is considerable divergence of opinion on how real a threat it poses. Nonetheless, the threat is sufficient to require thoughtful (not precipitate) action now to prevent disaster later.
My quarrel is with the evidence you use. A 50-year computer simulation tells us nothing about what will really happen. The last thing we need is to see this high-stakes matter driven by warring computer models that can easily be skewed by slight changes in the assumptions used to show enormous variations in long-term results.
 
JAMES S. HOWARD
New York, Nov. 19, 1989

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Just One More Flop

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The Federal Government's decision to abandon its current development of the Yucca Mountain Nuclear Waste Depository in Nevada, and to start again on a new plan for the same site, repeats an old, discouraging story: a ballyhooed ''solution'' to the radioactive waste problem that turns out to be just one more flop.
After 30 years of failure, this latest fiasco - two years of effort and $500 million down the drain - involves more than another American technological failure. It suggests again that the disposal of dangerous nuclear waste is a political question almost as difficult to solve as the technological problem.
Because the redesigned Yucca Flats depository cannot be opened before the year 2010, even if both technological and political difficulties are overcome, the use of nuclear reactors to generate electricity will be even more constrained in the United States. Already, California law sensibly prevents new reactor construction before a solution to the waste problem is demonstrated. 
Because the further generation of electricity by nuclear means has been set back for decades and perhaps for much longer, economic growth and expanding population will bring increasing pressures for the use of fossil fuels. But excessive burning of coal, oil and wood already causes heavy environmental damage to the planet.
Thus the Yucca Flats failure puts higher priority on energy conservation and renewable energy sources. To what extent industry and the general population can be educated or might be lured or should be forced into adopting those alternatives are questions yet to be answered.
As pointed out by Matthew Wald in The New York Times, moreover, the question now has to be asked whether a solution will ever be found to the safe disposal of vast quantities of wastes that will remain dangerous to all life for literally thousands of years.
Mr. Wald raised the question in a scientific context. The U.S. already has tried and failed to find the answer in salt caves in Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi; engineers have talked fruitlessly of firing the wastes into space or into the sun, or of burying them under the polar ice caps; ''reprocessing'' the stuff to make it less hazardous is costly, could facilitate the proliferation of nuclear weapons and still leaves the problem of safely storing the reprocessed wastes for thousands of years; above-ground storage in special casks offers a solution only into the next century. But the question also has to be asked politically. Popular resistance in the states affected was not the least reason salt-cave storage had to be abandoned; it was perhaps the primary reason granite repositories in New Hampshire, Michigan and Maine were ruled out; and even the desert storage at Yucca Flats that once was considered so promising produced tenacious opposition in Nevada.
In the last case, the Government's faulty plans no doubt increased local resistance. But such resistance inevitably will arise wherever a repository is planned, and no wonder. Just ask yourself if you want highly radioactive material, that will remain so virtually forever, stored in your vicinity; and even if you are willing, ask yourself if, after 30 years of failure, inept management and deception (remember when nuclear power was going to be ''too cheap to meter''?), you could believe the assurances of either government or industry that the problem finally has been solved.
No doubt dedicated opponents of nuclear power - they are numerous, on both environmental and safety grounds - will consider the Yucca Flats decision one more reason why nuclear power should be abandoned altogether. I am among those not yet convinced either that a safe nuclear-power program cannot be developed or that such a program can be made superfluous by conservation and alternative energy sources.
But even if nuclear power production were to be entirely halted and the existing plants scrapped - even if nuclear weapons production were halted for good measure - the baffling problem of waste disposal would remain; in the short run it actually would be exacerbated by the greatly increased amounts of waste to be stored.
Either way, therefore, whether nuclear power is abandoned or continued, much less extended, the lethal waste disposal problem, both technological and political, will remain -humbling evidence of the arrogance of a course confidently embarked upon before anyone knew where it would lead.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Realities Of the Revolution

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
What world are they living in, our elected leaders in Washington, our bureaucrats and so many of our academics and journalists?
They actually tell us the new Europe coming alive because of the anti-Communist revolution will be taken over and shaped by a handful of Western politicians and financiers working cozily with the one important Communist apparatus that so far has managed to avoid destruction - the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
They tell us the West and the Soviet Union share one great enemy, political instability. They cluck nervously at the passion for freedom of the people of Eastern and Central Europe, whose very captivity was unfashionable to mention for many years. 
They talk busily about plans for future relations between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, maybe some kind of nice club, all together.
That is their world. In the world of Eastern and Central Europe there are different goals, standards, political morals and reality.
There it is understood, deep in blood and bone after decades of suffering, that the one great creator of instability since the end of World War II has been the imposition of Communism by the Soviet Union.
The goal of the revolutionaries is the end of Communist rule. They shout it out - with such wrath that every day Communist leaders disappear into shame and Communist governments crumble into dust.
In the streets of Prague, Warsaw, Budapest and Leipzig, there are no banners crying for the preservation of the Warsaw Pact. The nations in revolt were forced to join the organization for their own enslavement.
One day they will tell all Soviet troops to get out and will renounce that contract of captivity, just as soon as they can do so without Soviet punishment or selfish Western pressure.
To compare the Warsaw Pact, as the big thinkers in Washington now do, to the voluntary association of NATO is a moral and political obscenity. The goal of the revolution is not Communism with a human face or reformed Communism or any other such ridiculous contradiction in terms but the end, the absolute end of Communist domination.
In the Soviet Union itself, every day that goal becomes more obvious. There is a majority among those deputies in the Supreme Soviet who were really elected, not appointed by the Government, for the repeal of Article 6 of the Constitution. That article enthrones the Communists as the sole party and voice of the people.
In Kiev demonstrators march against Article 6, and in Moscow Andrei Sakharov organizes a strike to force a real debate. In Lithuania the parliament demands elimination of Communist one-party rule. Estonia prepares to do the same.
Time and again Mikhail Gorbachev has said he will fight that step and those who propose it. He has powerful weapons - millions who owe their jobs to the party, the huge police apparatus he never reduces and the Red Army.
Some day as the price of civil peace he may give in to the swelling demand to eliminate the Communist political dominion. But at Malta the United States helped him put off that day by lining up politically and economically with Mr. Gorbachev - with Gorbachev, not the Soviet people and their right to decide how they want to live.
How long can he put the day off, what will he decide, how harsh will his repression be when trouble grows in Soviet streets? We do not know; President Bush was too polite to ask him those questions.
That must have astonished Mr. Gorbachev almost as much as it hurt and disappointed the Soviet Union's liberal and radical fighters for political freedom.
But our leaders and bureaucrats go on talking and planning as if the revolution against the Communist Party were not flooding across Eastern Europe into the Soviet Union, as if the Soviet people's desire for full freedom, with or without Mr. Gorbachev, did not exist.
How sad it is that so often our leaders cannot understand the strength of the passion for freedom of political choice. They did not understand it in South Korea or the Philippines and looked on stunned when the young people of Beijing almost brought down their Government. All those people had seemed so faceless in the West before they rose in rebellion.
Now our leaders and advisers do not understand that neither we nor Mr. Gorbachev have the power any longer to decide what is best for the Soviet people. We can delay their time of choice, as we are. But we cannot talk or plan it out of existence or ignore their faces, not in the real world of the revolution.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New Jersey Acts to Save a Pygmy Forest of Pine and Oak

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODLAND TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
Sections of southern New Jersey's pygmy forest, where decades-old pitch pines and blackjack oaks reach only four to six feet in height, have been owned by the state for years, but environmentalists feared they still were not adequately protected.
So this fall the State Department of Environmental Protection designated 3,800 acres of stunted trees in the west pine plains here, about 40 miles east of Camden, as New Jersey's 42d Natural Area. That means the land where the rare trees grow must remain forever wild.
As a natural area, the pygmy forest becomes one of the most closely guarded lands in this populous state. The designation also means the state will manage the area so it retains its present features. That may mean allowing wildfires to burn. 
 
Reversals by the State
But does state control insure that this land in Burlington County will be permanently protected?
''This might be heresy coming from me,'' said Thomas Hampton, administrator of the Office of Natural Lands Management in the Department of Environmental Protection, ''but state ownership and state acquisition doesn't necesarily mean you're going to accomplish preservation or protection of habitat.''
Several times in the past, state parkland that many thought was safe ended up being damaged by inappropriate uses or sold to private interests.
In the late 1960's, Sunfish Pond in the Worthington State Forest in Warren County was sold to Jersey Central Power & Light for use as a pump-storage hydroelectric generating station. Under intense criticism and pressure, the utility eventually dropped the project and returned the land to the state, but the controversy led to creation of the natural lands program through legislation sponsored by then Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean.
Spread throughout the state, the natural areas cover 29,800 acres, including Bearfort Mountain in Wawayanda State Park, Bull's Island in Hunterdon County and a 36-acre tidal salt marsh at Liberty State Park in Jersey City.
In more recent examples of publicly owned land being sold or abused, the state agreed in 1986 to sell over a thousand acres of Hamburg Mountain in Vernon Township to a ski resort operator. Now there is a golf course on what used to be a wildlife management area.
When the state needed a place for thousands of barrels of radon-contaminated soil dug up in Montclair and West Orange a few years ago, it planned to use the Colliers Mills Wildlife Management Area until it bowed to public opposition.
Most recently the state approved a swap of 58 acres in the Stephen Section of Allamuchy Mountain State Park in Morris County for 68 acres of wetlands in the Mount Olive Foreign Trade Zone in the same county. The state land will become part of the site of the 500,000-to-600,000-square-foot North American headquarters of the BASF Corporation.
''All you have to do is take a look around,'' said David F. Moore, executive director of the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, a nonprofit organization involved in preserving open space, ''and you'll see that the process that the state uses to divest itself of some of its property acquired with public funds does not exactly happen under glass.''
The pygmy forest is not under pressure by potential developers, and it is regulated in part by the State Pinelands Commission. But even in this rural area, there are plans to exploit nature.
 
Bombing Range in the Area
There are more than 13,000 acres of pygmy forest in the area. The largest tract is owned by the Air Force and used as a bombing practice range. The Federal Government recently proposed erecting 16 radio transmission towers in the pygmy forest for use in the event of a nuclear war.
The state owns 3,800 acres in the natural area, as well as other scattered sites. The remaining plains are in private hands, and they include an automobile junkyard and an illegal toxic waste dump.
The pygmy pines natural area borders Route 72 in Woodland Township, and from the highway it is possible to see the tract extending to the horizon. The area includes the rare Broom Crowberry plant, a low shrub, and a dozen rare species of moths.
There are stunted trees like these on Long Island and near Albany, but in far smaller tracts, ecologists said.
Scientists from all over the world have studied these trees. They are not sure what caused them to stop growing, but they have theories. One hundred years ago it was believed the weak sandy soil did not provide sufficient nutrition. But a mile from here pitch pine trees in essentially the same soil grow to 30 to 60 feet.
Robert J. Cartica, a plant ecologist with the Office of Natural Lands Management, said more recent theories had focused on the cycle of natural wildfires that routinely sweep through southern New Jersey's 1.1-million acre pinelands region but occur in the pygmy forest about twice as often as in other areas.
 
Wildfires May Be a Benefit
The pitch pines seem to have adapted to the fires: their seed cones open under tremendous heat, and the trees themselves send up new shoots from the base of their trunks even if the rest of the tree has been killed in a fire. In one section of the natural area that was destroyed by fire last March, new shoots one and a half to two feet long are now flourishing.
Designation as a natural area minimizes human influence - there will be no dirt bikes or campgrounds, for example - but it does not mean the land will be left untended.
To preserve the area, the state is considering, whenever feasible, to let wildfires burn to roads or existing fire breaks, in order to duplicate the cycles of destruction and regeneration that created the stunted woods hundreds of years ago.
 
Role of Fires to Be Studied
''What we're doing is preserving the natural diversity of the area,'' Mr. Cartica said.
For generations now, fires in the pygmy forest have been surpressed, and while there is no scientific evidence yet showing that this has caused the trees to grow, photographs indicate that 30 years ago sections of the forest were only about two to four feet high rather than the four to six feet that now appears most commonly.
Mr. Thompson, the head of the natural lands office, acknowledged that simulating such volatile conditions as a wildfire, while insuring public safety, was a delicate task. He said the state had to do research and planning before such practices could be included in the permanent management plan for the natural area.
The prospect of more forest fires is not especially frightening for the 2,280 residents scattered throughout this 96-square-mile township, Mayor John Bowker said. They have learned not only to live with the fires, but also to rely on them, he said.
''Every once in a while you need wildfires,'' Mayor Bowker said, ''or the whole place turns into jungle.''

HEADLINE: Board Drops 1876 Building As Landmark

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, joined by almost every other member of the New York City Board of Estimate, voted yesterday to overturn the landmark status of a 113-year-old building on the Avenue of the Americas that was designated in October as ''a forerunner of the skyscraper type.''
It was only the third time in 15 years that the board overturned a designation of a Manhattan structure by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Mayor Edward I. Koch was alone in supporting landmark status for the six-story Coogan Building on the northeast corner of 26th Street.
An aide to Mr. Dinkins, Alicia Glen, read a statement from the Manhattan Borough President before she cast his vote against designation. 
 
'A Close Call'
''Permanent protection of the structure is a close call,'' she said. ''The economic realities make it unlikely that an owner would invest the capital dollars that a historic restoration would require. Nor do we believe that the Coogan Building has a major design impact on its surroundings.''
But Mr. Dinkins's statement also mentioned his ''strong commitment to an effective landmark preservation policy'' and said he respected the ''thoughtfulness'' of the designation and the ''architectural qualities'' cited.
Mr. Dinkins later joined in the unanimous approval of a proposal by Rockefeller University to build a 15-story biomedical laboratory directly over Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. The project was overwhelmingly opposed by the Upper East Side community board.
The Board of Estimate also approved leasing city-owned properties to the prospective buyers of two concrete companies whose previous owner, Edward J. (Biff) Halloran), was convicted of racketeering in 1988. One of the buyers, John Quadrozzi, has ''acknowledged associating with organized crime figures,'' according to Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General.
The purchase of the concrete companies by Mr. Quadrozzi and Michael DiBenedetto has been approved by the office of Otto G. Obermaier, the United States Attorney for the Southern District. The buyers have agreed to operate for seven years under the scrutiny of a federally appointed monitor.
Before discussing the concrete companies, the board voted to withdraw landmark status from a property for the first time since 1985, when it overturned the designation of the Ambassador Theater at 215 West 49th Street.
 
Monumental Arched Windows
The Coogan Building, whose facade is distinguished by monumental arched windows, was designed by Alfred H. Thorp and completed in 1876 for use by the Racquet Court Club, predecessor to the modern Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue. It now houses stores and several residents.
It sits in the middle of a three-block site assembled by a real-estate developer, Leonard Adell, who envisions a major commercial and residential project along the Avenue of the Americas, between 25th and 28th Streets, with as many as 1,000 new apartments. This project depends on a rezoning of the area that has been proposed by the City Planning Department.
''We're obviously delighted with the outcome,'' said Samuel H. Lindenbaum of Rosenman & Colin, a lawyer for Mr. Adell. ''It opens up an opportunity to go forward with the proposal to rezone Sixth Avenue. The Coogan site will be the first to be redeveloped.''
''I don't think this necessarily has any great precedent,'' he said of the board's denial of landmark status. ''It was a statement by the Mayor-elect that the building was not worthy of designation. He balanced the issue of landmark preservation and development policy.''
Of the Coogan Building, David F. M. Todd, the landmarks commission chairman, said: ''It was a very interesting old building, but not a flashy one. I just wish there had been an opportunity to work this into the fabric of what the new zoning may bring into that stretch of the city.''
 
A Laboratory Building
The Rockefeller University proposal involves a laboratory building that would fill the air space over Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, between 64th and 65th Streets, supported by two large V-shaped columns rising from the East River esplanade. It was approved unanimously in October by the City Planning Commission.
Community leaders worry that the building will intensify traffic and air pollution, compromise the esplanade, create a visual obstruction of the waterfront, throw unwanted shadows and increase the amount of hazardous waste produced as a result of the medical research to be done there.
But in a statement read by Ms. Glen, Mr. Dinkins said he was voting for the laboratory, ''given the fact that this particular project does not create significant negative impacts and that it will allow the construction of a valued facility dedicated to students and research.''
However, Mr. Dinkins also said, ''We do not welcome the construction of buildings over streets and we dislike a precedent that may be set in this case.''
The concrete plant sites in Manhattan and the Bronx are owned by the city and used by the Certified Concrete Company and the Transit Mix Concrete Corporation, which used to be controlled by Mr. Halloran and are now administered by David M. Brodsky, the court-appointed trustee for the concrete companies.
 
To Transfer Leases
Under the proposal before the board, the leases would be transferred to Mr. Brodsky and, through him, to Mr. Quadrozzi and Mr. DiBenedetto, who would then buy the concrete companies. That purchase is subject to a consent order that would, among other things, ''mandate that the principals not associate with organized-crime members or convicted felons and not violate labor and antitrust laws,'' as described in a letter to the Mayor's office from Mr. Obermaier.
''We are satisfied that there will be no recurrence of illegal conduct,'' Mr. Obermaier said yesterday after testifying before the board.

HEADLINE: Law;
A boy's paleontologic prize is now an ancient legal dispute.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
The fossil, along with other lizard specimens, is kept in a cabinet in the American Museum of Natural History. But to the man who found it - and has gone to court to retrieve it - the relic is scarcely more accessible now than it was for 175 million years, nestled in a hill in what was to become North Bergen, N.J.
Nearly 30 years ago, 15-year-old Alfred Siefker and two buddies discovered the remains of a prehistoric gliding reptile in a quarry. Paleontologically it was a first, the oldest airborne vertebrate known to man, and Mr. Siefker briefly achieved 1960's-style celebrity, appearing on ''To Tell the Truth'' and in Life Magazine. The previously unknown critter went into the books as ''Icarosaurus Siefkeri.'' 
Like Icarus, the creature's other namesake, Mr. Siefker quickly fell back to earth. His dreams of professional paleontology abandoned, he has shined shoes, sold fruit, painted signs, driven a truck, and is now unemployed. As he has made his rocky way, the fossil has acquired a significance more talismanic than scientific. Embedded in a modest block of shale is not just his name and his fame but, he believes, his fortune and future.
For the better part of two decades, he has tried to reclaim the relic, to prove legally that the deal he struck with the museum was a loan rather than a gift. As one might expect from a dispute involving fossils, his progress has been glacial. Mr. Siefker has gone through half a dozen lawyers, each thinking that with a little bit of work that he, too, could claim a piece of that magical rock. Each, in turn, gave up.
Now, Mr. Siefker and his latest lawyer, a Paterson, N.J., solo practitioner named Kashif Molamusa, are taking the museum to another rock pile: the United States District Court in Manhattan. His pleadings can only be described as skeletal but his demand is clear: $15 million for the fossil, $45 million more in damages.
To Mr. Siefker, it is a matter of righting an old wrong. To his adversaries, it is a holdup. ''This is not a case of some barefoot kid on summer vacation versus some big, bad, nasty museum,'' said Andrew Connick of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, the institution's longtime counsel.
The law may have its fair share of dinosaurs, but the world they roamed is one lawyers rarely encounter. The prehistoric exhibit at issue here measures only 7 1/2 inches across. But in it, one can clearly discern the skull, neck, pelvis, tail and elongated ribs of a primitive lizard, one which jumped off trees, glided through the air, and, at least once, missed its target, falling into the lake that once covered New Jersey's Meadowlands and getting buried under millenia of mud.
Fossils were young Siefker's passion; five or six times each week, even in winters when his hands turned numb, he scoured for specimens. ''My mother would scream and the garbage men would hate me,'' he recalled. ''They couldn't lift up the bags.''
Actually, a friend first spotted the icarosaurus. But Mr. Siefker promptly bought it from him for a telescope, a book, several other fossils and $30 in cash. The boys brought it to Edwin H. Colbert, then the chairman and curator of the museum's vetebrate paleontology department. It was Dr. Colbert, now emeritus curator at the Museum of Northern Arizona in Flagstaff, who analyzed it, described it and gave it its name.
The discovery was announced with great fanfare by the museum. ''They tried to butter me up, by letting me work in their lab, by sending me to Colorado on an expedition, by giving me a lifetime subscription to Natural History magazine which they discontinued once I went into the Army,'' Mr. Siefker said. ''But once they found out I was not going to donate it to them their attitude was no longer friendly.''
In fact, several press accounts at the time stated explicitly that Mr. Siefker still owned the skeleton. This the museum has repeatedly denied -''Our records clearly show that he did not have and does not have now any legal rights of ownership,'' its director, Thomas D. Nicholson, wrote two years ago - and a succession of lawyers representing of Mr. Siefker has negotiated with a succession of lawyers representing the museum, including Louis Auchincloss, lawyer and novelist.
At one point, Mr. Siefker claims, he was offered $200,000 to settle. The creature's current custodians at the museum, Richard Tedford and Eugene Gaffney of the department of vertebrate paleontology, think it is not worth nearly that much. In seeking to retain it, they say, their primary object is precedential: to safeguard the museum's holdings and investment in scientific research.
Mr. Siefker's case remains in its early stages. Meantime, he plans a return to the site of his triumph, even though, with the construction of a K-Mart and Pathmark nearby, whatever secrets it still contained have been obliterated. ''There's still a bit of the hill left,'' he said. ''Enough to make more discoveries.''

HEADLINE: Soviet Lawyers in Odyssey Through U.S. Law

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
''We,'' that pronoun of commonality and cooperation, runs wild as weeds through the conversation of Mahir Babayev, shifting its meaning as the Soviet legal expert describes his odyssey through American corporate law, the contacts made, the deals now brewing and the deals already done.
Sometimes ''we'' means Mr. Babayev and the New York City Bar Association, as in, ''We're working on a draft for a bilateral agreement on the protection of investment.'' Sometimes it means Mr. Babayev and his American hosts, the Wall Street law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. Sometimes it refers to his investment-hungry homeland. 
For another three months, ''we'' also refers to Mr. Babayev and his colleagues in a pioneer group of 17 Soviet legal professionals who, courtesy of the American Bar Association and the Soros Foundation-Soviet Union, are undergoing a seven-month immersion bath in American legal practice and legal culture.
 
Bureaucracy in the Gap
''The law has never played a role in our country as it has in your country,'' said Larisa Afanasyeva, a 30-year-old legal scholar at Moscow's Institute of State and Law. ''Even when good laws were adopted, there was an enormous gap between what the law said and how it was enforced. And in the gap is the bureaucracy.'' In the Soviet Union's political and economic culture, Ms. Afanasyeva added, ''We were oriented toward whatever institute we were subordinate to; the client was the last thing we thought of.''
Now, when her tenure at the Washington firm of Arnold & Porter ends and she returns to her dual roles at her institute and at Infex, a fledgling Soviet legal cooperative, she expects to have a new relationship with her clients and, as a result of the contacts she has made, new clients, too.
What has mattered most to Soviet participants has been not American legal theory, which they were already familiar with, but American legal practice: the power lunching, the long grind of the young associate and, most of all, the way lawyers and executives here approach their work.
 
What 'Mostly' Means
''To me, what's very important is how American lawyers think,'' said Mikhail Barshchevsky, 33, a defense attorney who is also the host of a Moscow television program that tries to explain Soviet law to the layman. He is with the Washington office of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy.
For example, Mr. Barshchevsky said, the Soviet Union's two-year-old law on joint ventures between Soviet enterprises and Western companies stipulates that such employees be ''mostly'' Soviet citizens. ''For me, it is absolutely understandable what the law means by 'mostly,' '' he said. ''But American lawyers think more concretely. They ask, 'What does it mean? Fifty-one percent? Seventy-five? Ninety?' ''
A Soviet lawyer, he said, would take the rule to mean that in any group of joint ventures the preponderance of the enterprises would have a majority-Soviet work force.
Mr. Barshchevsky's colleague, Leonid Kheifets, has chosen a different approach for his stay here. ''At the beginning I thought it would be a matter of doing research and finding out how American legislation will be useful for our dealings,'' Mr. Kheifets said. ''Now I think the main work I'm doing here is to be a translator of Soviet law for American lawyers.''
 
Wide Range of Legal Studies
While the Soviet lawyers concentrated in Washington and New York are making contacts and learning the skills that will make them the keystone in future business deals, other Soviet legal experts here are scattered throughout the country, exploring environmental law, entertainment law and criminal procedure.
Steven Raikin of the American Bar Association is largely responsible for creating and running the program. Working with the Soros Foundation-Soviet Union, a two-year-old fund whose goal is to aid Soviet systemic change, Mr. Raikin negotiated the terms of the program with Aleksandr Sukharev, now procurator general and president of the Association of Soviet Lawyers.
The foundation contributed $100,000, stipulating that all participants be chosen through an independent competition run largely by Westerners. #17 Applicants Selected From the 162 completed applications that were filed, Mr. Raikin and members of the Soros Foundation chose the final 17, selecting representatives of the various branches of the Soviet legal profession, which is divided between attorneys allowed to practice in court, legal scholars and legal advisers similar to England's solicitors.
The Soviets are paid a stipend by their host law offices. The amount varies, based partly on the cost of living in their community. Mr. Raikin declined to disclose the amount.
When they return to their homeland, a country still in the throes of political and economic overhaul, Mr. Raikin said, ''It wouldn't surprise me if these folks were called on to lend their expertise and help shape how the new laws being passed by the Supreme Soviet are implemented.''
Although the Soviets here do not talk in such bold terms, several hinted that they would put their new skills to use in furthering the rapid political and economic changes, particularly in easing business dealings between the two countries.
 
Links to Entertainment Business
For Valentin Blueger, a Latvian attorney who has spent the fall in the shadow of Nashville's Grand Ole Opry while working with the firm of Farris, Warfield & Kanaday, that may mean creating a new avenue for cultural and entertainment business between this country and the Soviet Union, or perhaps establishing a new record label to compete with Melodiya, the state monopoly label.
For his new contacts in the United States, like Michael Sukin of the New York entertainment law firm of Carro, Spanbock, Kaster & Cuiffo, Mr. Blueger is a wedge into a massive, untapped market.
For John Pritchard at the Wall Street firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens, the time invested in working with Sven Papp, an Estonian lawyer, will be returned in having an expert available to help the firm and its clients evaluate business opportunities in the Soviet Union.
''Maybe this will influence other other lawyers to come,'' said Mr. Babayev, an Azerbaijani law professor, who hopes not only to resume teaching in Baku, but also to branch out as a consultant in international business. ''Even hundreds of lawyers having this experience won't change our system. Thousands and thousands of lawyers should come. We should invade your country - not with tanks, but with lawyers. What would you call it? From Russia, with law.''

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Andres Serrano: Provocation And Spirituality

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
ONE of the few, unintended benefits of the Congressional outrage against Andres Serrano is that it has brought widespread attention to a good artist. His photographs are indeed provocative. They are also serious art. There are 14 of them at the Stux Gallery, including the reviled and dreaded one from 1987, with its 13-inch plastic-and-wood crucifix upright in a Plexiglas tank filled with the artist's urine. This religious emblem enveloped in a dreamy golden haze (without the title, there would be little or no way of knowing what the liquid is) suggests the arty images and the mass production of religious souvenirs that have been partly responsible for the trivialization and exploitation of both religion and art.
This photograph was, along with the photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe, at the center of the storm that broke last June about the National Endowment for the Arts' grants policy. It was included in a group show that received endowment funds. Many people were offended by the photograph, and offended that Government money was spent on it. 
The kind of art supported by the endowment was thrown into question. Because of objections raised by members of Congress like Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, there are now restrictions on endowment money, which may not be used for work the agency judges obscene.
Stux is a private gallery. There are no public funds involved in this exhibition.
If you haven't seen the work, you should. One of the more alarming aspects of the attack on the endowment has been the assumption of many of those doing the condemning that there is no responsibility to consider the art as it was meant to be seen.
The photograph needs to be seen on the wall, at its altarpiece scale, not in a catalogue or book. And it must be seen within the body of Mr. Serrano's work.
The first question the photograph usually raises is whether the artist is debasing religion or commenting on the way it has been debased. This is a familiar question, one that has been asked in some form or another about the relationship between art and tradition since Manet.
Mr. Serrano is not equivocal, although his titles may have a defiance and a descriptive purity that suggest the two sides of his work. He does not want to have it both ways: his photographs have a point of view. He is searching for a way to sort out what he values in religion from what he does not. There is strong belief in his work, but he is not going to allow anyone to kneel before the trappings of institutionalized art and organized religion without asking what it is they have decided to worship.
The exhibition includes 13 other Cibachrome color photographs, all but 1 of them made this year. Most are 60 by 40 inches; 3 are 30 by 40. All the photographs are clean, economical and seductively colored. Each image is substantially enlarged.
Four photographs contain hallowed, mass-produced, generic images. In ''White Christ'' it is simply a Gothic head. ''Madonna and Child II'' is also Gothic. ''Female Bust'' is representative of classical Greek statuary.
''Madonna and Child II'' and ''Female Bust'' are immersed in urine. ''White Christ'' is in a mixture of milk and water. Mr. Serrano may not have made another yellow Christ because the one he had made was enough of a response to Gauguin's ''Yellow Christ,'' that awkward, highly personal Post-Impressionist document that has become one of the monuments of its age.
Every photograph features bodily fluids. It may be cow's blood from a butcher that is photographically transformed into clouds and sea. It may be a menstrual pad that becomes part icon, part embryo, part dog on its hind legs. It may be sperm that seems capable of leaping whole rooms in a single bound of transcendent light, or milk or cream that, mixed with blood, suggests the break of dawn or an Old Master painting of a religious vision. There is a medieval sense of the human body as the center of the universe. Earth, air, fire and water are the four elements, and air, fire and water are clearly suggested by an almost alchemical blend of fluids in these works.
Like Robert Mapplethorpe, Mr. Serrano struggles against inhibitions about the human body. His use of bodily fluids is not intended to arouse disgust but to challenge the notion of disgust where the human body is concerned.
It is possible to see Mr. Serrano's use of bodily fluids as pure provocation. But you can also believe that Mr. Serrano views them as a form of purification. The fluids make us look at the images harder and consider basic religious doctrine about matter and spirit.
They also raise the issue that was so crucial to the Byzantine Iconoclast Controversy of the eighth and ninth centuries: the relationship of an image to what it represents. The controversy was a bitter and profound debate about the nature of images and the problem of mistaking images for religious truths that could never be entirely incarnated.
You cannot consider the content of Mr. Serrano's work without considering his attitude toward photography. It is the photograph that breaks through convention, that makes the search possible and that enables the artist to sort out what he likes and does not like in religion and art. It is the photograph that becomes the vessel of transformation and revelation.
The photograph then becomes an icon that, for Mr. Serrano, replaces the false icons in his work. The photograph is clean and purified, the reliquary or shrine in which he clearly believes that the word about the body can be stored and spread. People may agree or disagree with him, or they may question his belief in photography, but how can anyone find in his work just obscenity and disrespect? It is hard to believe that anyone whose faith is searching and secure would not be grateful for what Mr. Serrano has done.
The photographs of Andres Serrano remain at the Stux Gallery, 155 Spring Street, through Jan. 6.

HEADLINE: Takeover Of Lincoln Defended

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Government lawyers went to court today to defend the Federal takeover last April of the financially troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.
Facing the first legal test of the takeover, attorneys for Federal regulators began presenting arguments for their contention that Charles H. Keating Jr. and his colleagues operated Lincoln in an unsafe and unsound way, violated banking regulations and depleted the assets of the institution.
The hearing in Federal District Court in Washington, which is likely to continue for several days. is the result of a suit Mr. Keating filed challenging the Government's April 14 takeover of Lincoln, which is based in Irvine, Calif.
 
'Capricious and Arbitrary'
Mr. Keating, known for his propensity to sue opponents, filed the suit in May, saying that he had operated Lincoln soundly and that the Government takeover was ''capricious and arbitrary.'' 
James P. Murphy, an attorney for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said in court today that specific transactions to be examined during the hearing would show that Lincoln engaged in practices with no economic value that created a false appearance of profitability.
''We have literally just the tip of the iceberg'' with these transactions, Mr. Murphy told Judge Stanley Sporkin. The Government's investigation of Lincoln found numerous other transactions that were ''just as bad,'' Mr. Murphy said.
Regulators have said that losses of depositors' money from fraud, risky investments and sham real estate transactions at Lincoln total more than $2 billion, and that Lincoln is likely to become the costliest savings and loan failure on record.
 
Suit's Dismissal Sought
The Office of Thrift Supervision, formerly the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, asked the court to dismiss the Keating suit. But Judge Sporkin said that before he ruled on that request he wanted to hear some arguments and testimony. The judge ordered the attorneys for both sides to jointly select four transactions by Lincoln as the basis for arguments before him.
The transactions selected involve two land deals, a tax-sharing agreement and a deal involving the purchase and sale of stock in the Memorex Corporation.
The Government has summoned Mr. Keating to appear as a witness, but it is uncertain whether he will testify. On Nov. 21, in an appearance before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Keating cited his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and refused to answer questions.
In addition to being the subject of civil suits filed by Federal regulators, the Securities and Exhange Commission and bondholders of Lincoln's parent, the American Continental Corporation, Mr. Keating is also the subject of a Federal grand jury investigation in Los Angeles.
As part of Lincoln's defense, Charles M. Stern, a Los Angeles lawyer representing Mr. Keating and Lincoln, charged that the Government's presentation ''contained half-truths and erroneous statements.'' He said that Lincoln's situation on April 14 did not justify a regulatory takeover, which, he said, was the ''ultimate bomb'' in the Government's arsenal.
He said his side would show that there were numerous omissions and misstatements by the Government. ''When you hold it up to light, there is nothing there,'' he said of the Government's case.
 
Tax Payments at Issue
The tax transaction selected for presentation to the judge involved an agreement between Lincoln and American Continental under which Lincoln paid to the parent company $94 million during a three-year period, supposedly as tax payments to be forwarded to the Internal Revenue Service.
Kevin O'Connell, an examiner for the thrift supervision office and the first Government witness today, said Lincoln had been granted permission by the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco for such a tax-sharing agreement in 1986. But he said the accord was misused because since none of that money was ever used to pay taxes.
Mr. Murphy said that since the taxes were never paid, the payments to the parent company amounted to an interest-free loan by Lincoln to its parent company. That, he said, is ''against savings and loan regulations.''
 
Interest Income Lost
Mr. Murphy said that during the three-year period Lincoln lost interest income of about $20 million that would have accrued from the $94 million and that Lincoln remained responsible for the full $94 milion tax liability if it could not be recovered from American Continental.
Mr. Stern, in his response, reminded the judge that permission for the transaction had been granted by the San Francisco Home Loan Bank.
The two land transactions involved the purchase and sale of undeveloped land outside Phoenix on which a subsidiary of Lincoln, Amcor, was able to record substantial profits. The Government contends that these were sham transactions undertaken to create the appearance of a profit through accounting techniques.
The Government said that in one transaction Amcor bought in 1985 and 1986 an 8,500-acre parcel called Hidden Valley for an average price of $3,000 an acre.
In March 1987, Amcor sold 1,000 acres to a newly formed limited partnership, West Continental Land. Amcor had paid about $3 million for the acreage and sold it for $14 million, or $14,000 an acre.
Lincoln recorded the $11 million difference as a profit, and paid its parent company $4.4 million in tax payments.
 
Borrowed Money
Mr. Murphy contended in court today that West Continental's financed the purchase with a $10.5 million loan from Lincoln and a $3.5 million loan from E. C. Garcia, a Phoenix businessman, who had shortly before that borrowed $20 million from Lincoln.
Mr. Murphy said that West Continental had a net worth of only $31,000 and was not able to make payments on the loans, which required interest payments of $1.4 million a year. The regulators charged that the partnership never intended to make the payments, particularly since the loans were not secured by any of the partnership's assets.
''The buyer had none of its own money at risk, was not able to make any of the payments and actually had no intention of making payments on the loan,'' Mr. Murphy said, adding that the transaction was done to ''artificially enhance Lincoln's income statement.''
Mr. Stern said that the $3.5 million lent by Mr. Garcia did not come from American Continental or Lincoln.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Terrorist Victim's European Vision

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE complex job of rebuilding the international economic order in the wake of the upheaval in the Communist world and the apparent end of the cold war will require dedicated and brilliant leaders like those who created the Marshall Plan after World War II. The late chief executive of West Germany's biggest bank, the Deutsche Bank, Alfred Herrhausen, who was murdered by a terrorist bomb near Frankfurt last week, was such a leader. Before his death, Mr. Herrhausen had begun to spell out his ideas on the reconstruction of Europe and its economic implications for both East and West.
In a speech that was to have been delivered before the American Council on Germany in New York last Monday, Mr. Herrhausen stressed the need for continued progress toward a united Europe, with member countries giving up a good part of their autonomy over economic policy making. He wanted West Germany firmly linked to the European Community and wrote, ''That East Germans be given freedom and self-determination is more important than a united Germany.'' 
If, later, attainment of that liberty were to be followed by their decision to move more closely, or unite, with the West, that decision would be welcomed in West Germany, he continued, but at this point, it ''is still very much an open question.''
Mr. Herrhausen saw progress toward completion of the single market in 1992 as proceeding, more or less, on schedule, with even stronger growth than the optimists had expected. Europe, he wrote, is now in a much better position to cope with ''a recession in North America, should it occur, than was the case in the 70's or early 80's.''
Next on his priority list was completion of the European Monetary System, because ''a single market calls for a single currency,'' he said. Without specifically mentioning the resistance to monetary integration of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, he insisted that there would have to be sacrifices of national sovereignty in such areas as exchange rates, monetary policy and even, ''to a certain extent,'' fiscal policy. He maintained that these thorny issues could be resolved and ''the year 2000 is a realistic goal for the implementation of monetary union.''
Far from viewing Europe 1992 as a ''fortress,'' he saw it as part of a wider phenomenon, a worldwide interlocking of economies, like the United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement. Europe, he said, had to ''remain open for third countries in general and for its European neighbors in the East in particular.''
A philosophical man, Mr. Herrhausen saw dangers ahead in the effort of the Communist countries to convert to market economies. ''One is reminded,'' he said, ''of Alexis de Tocqueville's shrewd observation that authoritarian regimes run into difficulties precisely when they begin to change for the better.'' Political and economic reform would have to go hand in hand; the violent reversal in China, where reform had been restricted to the economic sector, taught him that ''freedom is a comprehensive concept and cannot be confined to just one sector of national life.''
Against those who argue that the United States should not prop up the Soviet economy, he contended that success with perestroika was ''necessary and very much in the West's interest as well,'' and would also give other Eastern European countries more scope to restructure their society and economy. He deliberately invoked the model of the Marshall Plan and called for granting credits and setting up development banks to work closely with Eastern European authorities and trade and industry representatives.
John D. Macomber, president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, who once served on the board of the Xerox Corporation with Mr. Herrhausen, called him a ''self-effacing, kind, decent and very hard-working man.''
Mr. Macomber said in an interview that the fastest way of helping the East would be through export credits and guarantees to private businesses, but said such actions should have the explicit support of Congress. He agreed with Mr. Herrhausen that Western countries should act ''in concert'' in helping the Eastern countries.
Mr. Herrhausen praised the courage of the East Germans for ''forcing upon their Government tremendous political changes,'' culminating in the opening of the Berlin wall. But despite the euphoria, he said, ''one could not miss the irony: The wall was built in an attempt to keep people in the country, and now it had to be opened for exactly the same reason.''
The irony might be explained through the American economist Albert O. Hirschman's concept of ''exit'' and ''voice'' - the two basic means by which people can discipline businesses, organizations or nations. When East Germany could no longer prevent its citizens from ''exiting,'' it had to give them ''voice'' at home. The opening of the wall was a symbol of a new freedom to protest and an implicit commitment to respond and change.
Mr. Herrhausen's speech here was dedicated to the memory of Arthur F. Burns, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and Ambassador to West Germany. The German banker concluded his remarks with a Latin quotation from Tacitus, which in translation said: ''We grieved at his passing and his friends were saddened. People abroad and strangers, too, were affected.''
It was his own epitaph, too. Obviously, the authoritarians and totalitarians had a lot to fear from this gentle man.

HEADLINE: Polish TV Joint Venture For Chase Enterprises

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
An American communications company today announced a joint venture to wire Poland for cable television and provide it with an array of Western programming.
The network, which is scheduled to begin in Warsaw and Cracow in June would, it is believed, be the first cable system in Eastern Europe. Eventually, it will carry 18 channels.
Wiring for the first 1.8 million of Poland's 8 million homes will begin in the next few months, the company, Chase Enterprises, said. 
Although Poles can currently receive some Western programs with satellite dishes, the cable service would make subtitled or dubbed foreign programs widely available. CNN, a news service, and ESPN, an all-sports network, are two American offerings likely to be included in the basic service.
 
Payable in Zlotys
The basic cable service will cost about $8.50 a month, payable in the local currency, the zloty.
Packages of additional channels will be offered at a premium of $8 a month for the first group and $6 a month for the second. Those charges will be due in dollars or another easily convertible currency, and Chase Enterprises will be permitted to export those earnings.
Asked whether these fees - $22.50 a month for the full package - were not too steep for most Poles, Chase officials said their research showed that the prices would be affordable because many Poles have working spouses, second jobs and income from other sources. More than 90 percent of Polish homes have television sets.
Chase officials said that the service would initially have no advertising but that this could come eventually.
''What we're trying to do is export a bit of democracy and way of life to Poland,'' said David T. Chase, the founder of Chase Enterprises, which is based in Hartford. A Pole who escaped from Auschwitz as a youth and came to the United States at the end of World War II, Mr. Chase, 60 years old, has built a communications, real estate and insurance empire.
Mr. Chase said he remembered passing the Statue of Liberty with 25 cents in his pocket when he entered the United States. He is now listed in Forbes magazine as having, along with his family, a net worth that places them among the 400 wealthiest families in the United States.
 
Base in Real Estate
Chase Enterprises is a family-owned business with assets estimated at $2 billion. From its base in New England real estate, the company has expanded into broadcasting in a half-dozen states and into banking and insurance.
Chase Enterprises will own 70 percent of the Polish cable system, to be called Polska Telewizja Kablowa.
Poltelkab S.A. will own the remaining 30 percent. It is a partnership of the Polish post, telephone and telegraph company; Polish Radio and Television Productions Company, and the local governments of Warsaw and Cracow.
Chase officials said the project had been under development for three years but had been expedited by the recent changes in Eastern Europe.
First-phase investment will require about $270 million, with the eventual total amounting to more than $900 million.
Chase's initial equity will be $20 million to $40 million, said Roger M. Freedman, president of the Chase International Corporation. Poland will put up the amounts necessary to maintain its equity at 30 percent.
The bulk of the money would be borrowed, and Chase officials said they hoped for a $100 million loan from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a United States Government agency that finances foreign ventures at concessionary rates and insures against expropriation.
 
Poland Seeks Loans
Poland itself is currently seeking two loans totaling $360 million from the World Bank for overall development. Officials began negotiations on these loans, which could be made as soon as early 1990, a World Bank official said.
Eugenio F. Lari, director of European, Middle East and North African operations for the World Bank, said the loans were part of a $1 billion package that the World Bank has ''on the shelf'' for Poland. The first loans, intended to improve efficiency in the industrial and agricultural sectors of the economy, would be practically automatic once Poland and the International Monetary Fund agreed on a broad economic program involving privatization and other market-oriented measures.
Poland owes $40 billion to Western creditors and inflation is running at a rate of more than 500 percent a year.
In the cable television deal, no programming commitments have been concluded, but Chase officials said it was likely that the 18-channel system would contain these channels:
Tier 1 would include TV 1 and TV 2, Poland's two national broadcasting systems; local programming, a sports channel like ESPN or Eurosports; Soviet, French and Italian channels; an educational channel, and the European Cable News Network.
Tier 2 would include Discovery, MTV, Disney and classical music, European Eureka channel, American Arts and Entertainment and a 24-hour movie channel.
Tier 3 would include satellite-received cable channels from Western Europe chosen by a survey of Polish viewers.
Mr. Chase said that the announcement of the project was an emotional one for him and that he would be traveling to Poland this weekend for the first time in more than 40 years.
In addition to exporting democracy and making a profit, Mr. Chase said he sought to expose the Polish economy - including the 250 initial employees there - to economic incentives and show skeptics that the Polish worker is as good as any.
''This is an exciting moment in the history of the United States-Poland relationship and Chase Enterprises is pleased to be so intimately involved in the development of the Polish economy,'' he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
First Interstate Moves To Shore Up Reserves

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The First Interstate Bancorp, plagued by troubles in the Southwest, moved to clean up its money-losing Texas operation today by adding $400 million to reserves before selling problem assets.
The move comes a quarter after the Los Angeles-based banking company took a $200 million write-off and set aside $150 million to cover problem loans in Arizona, where as in Texas, the economy is weak and real estate values are depressed. 
In Texas, First Interstate holds about $560 million in troubled assets, including problem real estate holdings. The company said that it was adding $300 million to reserves so it could accelerate the sale of its Texas assets and that it was adding $100 million to ''address the risk inherent in the company's real estate portfolio.''
Analysts said First Interstate needed to move now to dispose of the assets before the market becomes glutted with billions of dollars worth of sale properties when the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency created last summer to rescue the savings and loan industry, begins selling the holdings of seized institutions next year.
First Interstate entered the Texas market by agreeing to acquire Allied Bancshares Inc. in May 1987 with no Government assistance. The bank was betting that the Texas economy would improve, but that proved to be an incorrect and costly assumption. Last year, after setting aside $180 million in reserves, the First Interstate Bank of Texas lost $205 million. This year, the bank will lose more than $90 million, the analysts said.
''This is further proof that Texas was a mistake,'' said Dan B. Williams, an analyst at Sutro & Company in San Francisco.

HEADLINE: G.M. Chief to Head Panel

 BODY:
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday named Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, to head a panel on program trading and market volatility.
The panel is part of a five-point effort announced last month by John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, to examine the impact of program trading on exchange trading. Mr. Phelan's efforts have come amid contention that computerized trading programs may have caused several large drops in stock prices in the last few months. 
''Roger's experience gives him a long-term perspective on the interests of corporations and their shareholders, both large and small, and the importance of the American economy and maintaining strong capital markets for all participants,'' Mr. Phelan said in a statement yesterday.
Mr. Smith, who is also head of the Business Council, a lobbying group, said the committee would issue its findings in about six months. ''The issues are complex and the challenge before the panel is great,'' Mr. Smith said in a statement.
A spokesman for General Motors said that Mr. Smith and the exchange will jointly announce the selection of the 20-member panel in about a week and that work will begin after the first of the year.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls By 15.99; Chevron Off

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks moved broadly lower yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.99 points, to 2,720.78.
More than half the Dow's decline was accounted for by a 5 1/4-point drop, to 66 3/4, by Chevron, which had been widely rumored as a potential takeover target.
The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it held 8.8 percent of Chevron's stock and might buy more but had no present plans for a takeover bid. Pennzoil rose 5/8, to 83 1/4. 
The Dow was off as much as 30 points at 3 P.M. after several futures-related sell programs were executed.
 
Program Selling a Factor
Analysts said the progam selling was spurred by the sharp drop in Chevron.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances, with 843 issues lower in price and 622 higher.
Volume on the Big Board expanded to 162 million shares, from 145.9 million on Wednesday.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 0.96, to 347.59, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.44, to 192.38.
''With corporate cash flow diminishing and the Federal Reserve Board apparently not in a hurry to allow interest rates to fall, something had to give and that something was stock prices,'' said Kenneth S. Hackle, president of Systematic Financial Management in Fort Lee, N.J. ''Also tax-loss selling and losses in the arbitrage community are negatively affecting some big-name stocks.''
Traders said that if today's report from the Labor Department on unemployment provides evidence of a sluggish economy, hopes could be revived for interest cuts.
 
Pinnacle West Advances
Pinnacle West Capital was the most active stock as well as the biggest percentage gainer, climbing 4 7/8, to 10 1/4, on a volume of 9.2 million shares. The company agreed to provide $450 million in cash and securities to its Merabank savings and loan subsidiary, meeting a condition of an offer for Pinnacle West made by Pacificorp last week.
The Washington Post Company fell 9 1/2, to 261 1/2, after sliding more than 21 points in early trading. The Post company said it new of no reason for the decline.
Active blue chips included Lockheed, up 3/8, to 39 3/8; Warner Communications up 3/8, to 63 7/8; Philip Morris, up 1/4, to 42 3/8, and I.B.M., off 5/8, to 98.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.74, to 375.09, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.36, to 456.31.
In Tokyo, the 225-stock index closed at a record high for the 11th time in 12 sessions. The indicator rose 203.82 points, or 0.54 percent, to 37,858.11.

HEADLINE: October's Consumer Debt Rose at 5.7% Annual Rate

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Americans took out $3.34 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in October, resulting in the biggest increase in net consumer debt in five months.
The Federal Reserve Board said today that consumer credit advanced in October at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.7 percent, the sharpest increase since a 7.3 percent gain in May, when credit rose $4.21 billion.
Outstanding consumer credit rose 2.3 percent in September, a revision upward from the 1 percent increase originally reported. Net loan totals were adjusted to $1.37 billion, from $606 million. 
A large part of the October advance related to the timing of automobile loans, which grew $1.1 billion, or 4.5 percent, in the month after falling 3.2 percent in September.
Economists said that the auto loan figures reflected sales made in September, not October, because of a lag in approving applications and then reporting credit.
 
Credit Card Debt
''The timing of credit and the sales often don't match up,'' said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI-McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting organization. ''There's really a rush to get cars into the sales column, but if you sign an agreement to buy a car, you might not actually get the credit for another week.''
The category of debt that includes credit cards jumped to a 6.4 percent annual rate of growth from a 5.6 percent advance in September. Total revolving debt rose $1.04 billion, compared with a $904 million gain the previous month.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $1.23 billion, a 7.5 percent annual rate of growth, compared with a gain of $1.2 million, or 7.3 percent, in September.
Mobile home debts fell again, down $26 million, or a 1.4 percent rate of decline. These debts had fallen for seven consecutive months until rising $53 million in September, or 2.8 percent at an annual rate.
The various changes left total consumer debt in October at a seasonally adjusted $707.7 billion.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of U.S. Issues Fall Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped again in light trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for this morning's release of November employment data.
''Someone who is not involved in the process would yawn over the price declines we have seen,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''But if you are involved, the amounts of money get so large that a down move of any size hurts a lot of participants.''
The declines over the last few sessions have put prices at the low end of the fairly narrow trading range they have occupied since the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions in mid-November.
''Right now most participants sound awfully negative,'' Mr. Brachfeld said. ''But if the economic fundamentals have not changed, then this could be a modest buying opportunity.'' 
Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., said: ''The contents of the Fed's beige book on Wednesday tended to change the market's psychology somewhat. The market is kind of nervous going into the employment numbers, and expectations for an easing in credit policy by the Fed have faded quite a bit.''
 
Market Participants Unsettled
In addition to the beige book, which showed that the economy was ''stable to modestly expanding'' in November, market participants were slightly unsettled yesterday by a larger-than-expected increase in consumer credit and an initial unemployment claims number that was somewhat smaller than anticipated.
''Unless the employment numbers are very bad, and show a rise in non-farm payroll employment of around 100,000 or so, it would seem to me that the Fed will postpone any easing move until the Open Market Committee meets later this month,'' Mr. Stone said. ''At that point, our hunch is that they will probably go ahead and ease policy.''
The consensus estimate among credit market experts is that non-farm employment grew by about 150,000 jobs in November, compared with 233,000 in October.
Once again, price declines among Treasury securities were registered across the maturity spectrum.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 3/8, down 3/32, to yield 7.91 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 2/ 32, down 5/32, to yield 7.86 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 25/32, down 5/32, to yield 7.79 percent.
Treasury bill rates inched higher. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.67 percent, up two basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by five basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.39 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.28 percent, up four basis points.
 
New-Issue Activity
New-issue activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by an offering of $100 million worth of new 10-year notes by Baxter International. The 9 1/4 percent notes were priced at ''par,'' or $100, 1.375 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 7 7/8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. The notes, which are noncallable for life, have a final maturity of Dec. 15, 1999.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Traders in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues slipped by about an eighth of a point in very quiet trading.
Meanwhile, participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices dipped about half a point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Nov. 27. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading As Dealers Await Job Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed marginally higher against most foreign currencies yesterday, but trading was light.
Gold prices scored large gains in United States trading, after finishing somewhat higher in Europe. Technical factors were cited for driving prices higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery ended at $410 an ounce, up $5.10 an ounce from late Wednesday. 
Dealers said the dollar traded in a very narrow range throughout the session, as most traders waited for today's release of the November unemployment data by the Labor Department. The market consensus was that the report would show an increase of roughly 150,000 jobs, lower than the 233,000 jobs added in October, and an unemployment rate of 5.4 percent.
 
Cut in Interest Rates Seen
Unfavorable employment figures would further indicate that the economy is slowing and might encourage the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. Lower interest rates are bearish for the dollar because they decrease the value of dollar-denominated securities.
''Everybody is convinced that U.S. rates will go down,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
The West German mark showed continued strength. Traders noted that the mark remained extremely strong against the Japanese yen.
In New York, the dollar closed at 144.31 yen, up from 144.02 on Wednesday. It cost $1.5780 to buy one pound, up from Wednesday's $1.5765.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday,included: 1.7725 West German marks, up from 1.7660; 1.5900 Swiss francs, up from 1.5895; 6.0515 French francs, up from 6.0335; 1.1618 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1612, and 1,307.25 Italian lire, up from 1.303.25.
In London, gold rose to a late bid of $404.25 a troy ounce, from $402.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $404.00, from $403.75 bid late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metal Prices Rise; Move Tied to Stock Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices rose sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday. Traders said the advance was partly in reaction to a decline in stock prices.
Gold settled $4.10 to $5.10 higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $410 an ounce; silver was 6.5 cents to 7.2 cents higher, with December at $5.623 an ounce. 
''The sharp fall in the stock market caused a flight to quality buying in the precious metals market,'' said Jim Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York.
Mr. Steel said that many things had caused movement in precious metals prices, including dollar strength or weakness, interest rates and inflation. ''But what has given gold its bold moves have been the declines in the stock market,'' he said.
Silver prices followed gold in the upward surge, helped along by the perception that the metal has been sharply oversold in recent sessions, Mr. Steel said.
 
Cotton Prices Sharply Lower
Cotton futures were sharply lower on the New York Cotton Exchange as traders had difficulty unloading offerings because of a lack of buyers.
At one time, the March contract was down the limit before recovering some losses, said Ed Whitten, an analyst with the Balfour Maclaine Corporation in New York. He pointed out that commission houses were active sellers as prices moved below several support levels.
Cotton was 0.23 cent to 1.55 cents lower, with December at 63.97 cents a pound.
Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower in sluggish trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The slide in wheat prices was a result of the release Wednesday of the National Weather Service's 6-to-10-day forecast, which calls for precipitation in the winter wheat crop areas, said Susan Leighty, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York.
Wheat futures received little support from news that the Department of Agriculture has approved an offer by the Soviet Union for 410,000 metric tons of wheat under the department's Export Enhancement Program.
Under the program, private exporters can sell United States commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in some markets and collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies.
Corn futures traded in a narrow range, finishing lower as professionals and commission houses liquidated their long positions.
Soybean prices continue to be weighed down by a lack of export business and continuing good planting conditions in South America.
Energy futures were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange as prices fluctuated widely during moderate trading.
Heating oil continued to provide strength to the market, as another blast of cold weather is expected in the Northeast in coming days, analysts said.
Livestock futures were mostly lower and pork futures down sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Players and Owners Taking Divergent Courses in Talks

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Dec. 7

 BODY:
Not that anybody expected baseball's labor negotiations to proceed smoothly and quickly, but with the two sides talking on two different planes, the owners and the players will very likely take a long time to get nowhere.
That the two sides will proceed on divergent courses became obvious today. Donald Fehr, the union leader, made it clear that one of the players' primary goals in negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement will be to regain the salary-arbitration eligibility players gave up four years ago, when the eligibility requirement was raised from two years of major league service to three. The owners want to eliminate salary arbitration. 
Fehr, emerging from a meeting of the Players Association executive board, questioned comments attributed to Commissioner Fay Vincent in newspaper reports today. Vincent, who spoke with reporters at the owners' meetings in Nashville on Wednesday, was quoted as using the term ''economic warfare'' and talking about a negotiating deadline ''sometime after the middle of February.''
''I find it odd and troubling,'' Fehr said, ''that as negotiations begin and on the heels of announcements of 'we've got to have trust, we have to form a new partnership, we're going to persuade players things are going to be different,' that words like 'economic warfare' are coming out of their mouths and suggestions of setting deadlines, which means lockouts, are coming out.''
 
Owners Want New System
The owners have told the union they want to implement a new salary system, based on revenue sharing and a pay-for-performance scale. That concept has monopolized the attention that has been focused on the talks, which began last week. Fehr, however, stressed today that the players would have their own agenda to discuss.
''The players have every right and obligation,'' Fehr said at a news briefing, ''to propose the kind of system that they believe makes the most sense, and the owners clearly have the obligation to treat that just as seriously, if not more seriously, because it's a system they know and understand and that the parties have agreed to fundamentally in the past.''
The players, Fehr said, would have their proposals formulated by Friday. He said they would not make them public before they present them to the owners' labor representatives. But the proposals, or areas of concern, will focus on salary arbitration, players with less than three years of major league service, the 25-man and 40-man rosters and improvements in benefits, both for current players and retired players.
The talks resume in Los Angeles next Tuesday.
