HEADLINE: Army-Navy Sends Message to Philadelphia Officials

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE

 BODY:
The difference between Saturday's Army-Navy game and the 89 that preceded it is the location: Giants Stadium in New Jersey's Meadowlands. This is a one-time-only arrangement and also a subtle message to the city of Philadelphia, where 67 of the games have been played.
The contract for use of city-owned Veterans Stadium, the site of the game since 1980, has expired and the two service academies wanted Philadelphia to know they could take their contest elsewhere if they chose. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority was delighted to be the landlord and the host to the 8,900 men and women who make up the student bodies. 
The event, which begins with the parade of the Brigade of Midshipmen into the stadium at noon followed by the Corps of Cadets, will sell out all of Giants Stadium's 76,891 seats. The game has not always been a sellout in recent years at Veterans Stadium. The kickoff will be at about 2:30 P.M. and CBS is televising the game nationally without competition from other major college games because there are none.
Although it has often been said that past records mean nothing because of the intensity of the rivalry, that may not be the case this time. Army has much the superior team offensively, one that set a West Point record in its last game by rushing for 631 yards against Colgate in a 59-14 victory.
 
Navy Has 2-8 Record
The same afternoon, Navy was losing to Delaware, its third loss of the season to a Division I-AA team. Army routed its four I-AA opponents by a collective 194-71 and its overall record is 6-4 to Navy's 2-8. For the 10th time, the series record is tied again, 41-41-7.
In the Colgate game, the Cadets were without their starting quarterback, Bryan McWilliams, and after one quarter their best running back, Mike Mayweather. Both will be back for Navy, and Mayweather, a junior, needs only 56 yards to set a new single-season West Point rushing record and 81 to exceed the Army career rushing standard, 2,957 yards, set by Glenn Davis, the 1946 Heisman Trophy winner, in four seasons.
Navy, which last enjoyed a winning season in 1982, has no players like those. Once more the Midshipmen will be counting on Alton Grizzard, their junior quarterback who has started 24 of the last 32 games and has taken a lot of punishment along the way.
 
Navy Needs to Strike Early
McWilliams averages about four pass attempts a game in the Army wishbone offense and Grizzard, also from the wishbone, will throw more often than that. In nine games he has passed for 947 yards and also, as Navy's leading rusher, has run for 821 yards. But his net average is only 63 yards a game after subtracting 255 yards in losses from all the sacks he has taken.
Navy's best chance to keep Army from winning for a fourth consecutive time is to try to pass for early scores and gain a lead. The Cadets do not come from behind easily with their inflexible wishbone attack.
A victory over Army would be the first for Navy's coach, Elliot Uzelac, whose record is 7-25 in his third season at Annapolis. Navy football is in a trough. Recruiting hurdles cannot be entirely blamed because the other service academies have been doing well at fielding successful football teams.
 
Air Force Steals the Show
Air Force beat both Army and Navy this year to take away the Commander-in-Chief Trophy from the Cadets and the automatic invitation to the Liberty Bowl in Memphis, where Air Force will play Mississippi on Dec. 29.
This will be the last football game for Army's 14 senior starters and Navy's 7. One, Army's Mike Thorson, is a 5-foot-9-inch, 180-pound cornerback who has made 51 tackles and carries a 3.995 academic grade-point average as an economics major.
On Tuesday, Thorson was awarded a $4,000 graduate studies scholarship as a member of the National Football Foundation's scholar-athlete team and he is a candidate for a Rhodes Scholarship and a Marshall Fellowship. He also is the deputy brigade commander, the second-highest position within the Corps of Cadets chain of command. He will be starting his 23d consecutive game.

HEADLINE: AQUINO ACCUSES 3 OF LEADING REBELS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Dec. 8

 BODY:
In her first public appearance since the Philippine Government was nearly toppled, an angry President Corazon C. Aquino today named three men - the country's Vice President, its chief opposition leader and her own cousin - as the leading suspects in the abortive rebellion.
Wearing her signature bright yellow dress and speaking with few notes to a crowd of tens of thousands of supporters this afternoon, Mrs. Aquino vowed to ''go after these people who want to destroy our economy and who want to destroy the Filipino people.''
Mrs. Aquino's aides said the speech was specifically intended to counter charges that she was weak, indecisive and unwilling to risk open confrontation with her political enemies and with rebellious factions in the military. Mrs. Aquino rejected those charges today, saying, ''Just because I am a woman they belittle me.''
But she said nothing about how, or even whether, she would punish the military officers who staged a six-day rebellion in which 79 people were killed and more than 500 were wounded. Nor did she discuss how to cure the rampant economic problems and urban decay that rebels and many other Filipinos say prompted the rebellion. 
 
Holdouts Won't Surrender
She announced a doubling, to about $1.50 a day, of the amount that soldiers are paid for their incidental expenses, an effort to reward the military units that remained loyal to her.
As Mrs. Aquino delivered her speech, on the site of one of the huge rallies that helped put her in office in February 1986, the last holdouts in the rebellion refused to surrender.
The renegades who took Manila's Makati financial district returned to their barracks on Thursday, but the rebels holding an air base in Cebu, the nation's second-largest city, about 350 miles from Manila, broke off negotiations. To step up the pressure, the Government flew in hundreds of loyalist troops and appeared to be threatening an attack on the rebel position. The Senate also continued debating new restrictions to be announced here as part of the state of emergency.
In her speech, Mrs. Aquino stopped short of accusing anyone of starting the rebellion. She said a five-member commission she established earlier in the week would resolve such questions.
She spoke emotionally - in native Tagalog instead of English - about her three prime suspects. They are Vice President Salvador H. Laurel, who was in London and Hong Kong during the rebellion; Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, a leading opposition figure and the man who directed the military revolt against Ferdinand E. Marcos, which put her in power; and Eduardo ''Danding'' Cojuangco, her cousin and one of the nation's richest men, who left the country with Mr. Marcos in February 1986. Mr. Conjuango, who is under indictment here, slipped back into the country from California several days before the rebellion.
 
Presidential Ambitions
Speaking quickly, Mrs. Aquino first attacked Mr. Enrile, who was Minister of Defense under Mr. Marcos and under her. He turned against the Marcos Government in the early 1980's and was a leading force behind the junior officers who mounted the revolt against Mr. Marcos.
Senator Enrile and President Aquino split months after she took office, when he challenged her authority and questioned publicly her handling of the Communist insurgency. Mrs. Aquino dismissed Mr. Enrile in November 1986, when he was linked to a rumored coup attempt involving some of his closest military aides. He was later elected a Senator and has made no secret of his presidential ambitions.
Mrs. Aquino said she was enraged to learn earlier this week that a Senate committee looking into the rebellion included Mr. Enrile. ''Are we fooling each other?'' she asked today. ''He ought to be investigated instead of being the investigator.''
Mr. Enrile, a Harvard-educated lawyer, has said in recent days that he would welcome an investigation and would step down from the Senate committee. Mrs. Aquino said, ''It's good to see he has a little shame left.''
Gregorio ''Gringo'' Honasan, a renegade former colonel who was a leader of a 1987 coup and is believed to be deeply involved in this one, was once Mr. Enrile's security aide. But Mrs. Aquino did not directly say that Mr. Enrile was working with Mr. Honasan, a widespread assumption here.
 
'Flick Him Like a Fly'
As the crowd cheered, Mrs. Aquino then turned to Mr. Laurel, also known by the nickname ''Doy,'' who ran on her ticket in 1986 but later split with her. Mr. Laurel has been answering charges all week that in interviews while he was in Hong Kong during the rebellion. he said he would be willing to serve in a military government. Mr. Laurel said he was misquoted, but an impeachment effort was begun this week by Mrs. Aquino's loyalists.
She asked the crowd, ''Should I bother mentioning Doy or shall we just flick him like a fly?'' Mrs. Aquino rejected Mr. Laurel's calls for her resignation. And she recounted, as she has on other occasions, how he was out of town during several previous coup attempts, suggesting it was more than coincidental. ''I will never give up the presidency to him,'' she vowed.
Finally she turned to Mr. Cojuanco. ''The suspicious thing,'' she said, ''is that one week after he returned, there was a rebellion. Our next election is not until 1992. Those who want to be president will have to wait until then.''
 
'She Has Come of Age'
Mrs. Aquino's supporters were clearly relieved to see her beginning to swing back at her opponents, hoping that it will begin to win back the public support for her administration that has been rapidly deteriorating.

HEADLINE: CANADA UNNERVED BY SLAYINGS OF 14

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTREAL, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Although Canada has witnessed mass killings over the years, none have involved so many deaths, or so profoundly shaken the national psyche, as the rampage this week at the University of Montreal.
On Wednesday, a 25-year-old unemployed recluse, shouting ''You're all feminists!'' shot and killed 14 young women at the university's school of engineering, while wounding 13 other people, 9 of them women. Then he turned his semiautomatic hunting rifle on himself.
A three-page suicide note found on the body of the gunman, Marc Lepine, along with information provided later by the police, offered a picture of a man who felt he had failed at virtually everything, from getting into graduate school to falling in love - and blamed women for it. 
Apart from the public shock, anger and grief expressed in candlelight vigils and lowered flags across the nation, there is also a sense of shame here over the crime: a realization that the nation may not, as many Canadians had long supposed, be somehow less vulnerable to such horrors than its neighbors in the United States.
 
'A Kick in the Teeth'
''This thing has been a real kick in the teeth for sanctimonious types like me,'' said Prof. Elliott Leyton of Memorial University in Newfoundland, an anthropologist who has studied mass and serial killers. ''It shows we've fully entered the modern era and no longer have anything to be smug about.''
''When I first heard about it, I thought I was listening to something that had happened in California or New York,'' said Yuri Dayan, a cab driver who moved to Montreal from Israel 21 years ago. ''I thought, 'It's crazy - this isn't supposed to happen in Canada.' ''
There has been a rush of speculation on the workings of the gunman's mind, on whether Montreal's overburdened hospitals have the counseling resources to help avert such acts, and about the effectiveness of Canada's already strict gun-control laws. The gunman was able to purchase his American-made rifle in Montreal legally a few weeks earlier because he had no criminal record.
 
Violence Against Women
Mostly, however, the incident has focused attention on the issue of sexism and violence against women.
Some people, including many feminist groups, have characterized the shootings as an extreme version of a kind of male hatred that they believe has contributed to rapes, beatings and other forms of abuse of women.
''I think it's dangerous to treat this as an isolated incident,'' said Etoile Stewart, a member of the Concordia University Women's Collective, one of several student groups that sponsored a vigil at the murder scene on Thursday night. ''There are still men beating women, raping women, knifing women. Unfortunately, we live in a society where misogyny is encouraged.''
Several women students, including some who survived the massacre at the University of Montreal's engineering school, said they feared that such a mass assault could happen again -and that women studying in fields traditionally dominated by men, like engineering, could be more vulnerable.
 
'So Frightened, So Angry'
''Women everywhere were so frightened and so angry,'' said Jocelyne Cottier, the coordinator of the Concordia University Women's Center, a university-sponsored group that offers counseling and organizes discussion groups on women's issues.
Margaret Atwood, a Canadian novelist who has explored women's issues in her work, said that the killings of the 14 women, who ranged in age from 21 to 31, ''clearly touched many people.'' But she said she hesitated to make direct comparisons with violence in the United States or Britain.
''Every society has its craziness, which takes different forms,'' she said from her home in Toronto. ''Every incident is culture-specific.''
There was no indication that Mr. Lepine had used drugs or alcohol, the police said. He shared a large apartment with his mother, a sister and a male roommate. His suicide note, written in French, included an apparent enemies list of 15 prominent Quebec women, one of whom was said to be a provincial cabinet minister.
 
Typical but Atypical
Detectives, noting that Mr. Lepine had unsuccessfully applied for admission to the University of Montreal engineering school, said he may have been enraged that women were accepted into traditionally male fields while he was not.
Professor Leyton, author of the 1986 book, ''Hunting Humans: The Rise of the Modern Multiple Murderer,'' said that the gunman seemed superficially to fit the classic profile: a frustrated, lonely person from a conventional background who takes out all his aggressions in one suicidal assault.
But Professor Leyton said there was a striking difference in the Montreal shooting.
''This is one of the very few mass murder cases I know of in which women were specifically targeted,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Castro Says He'll Resist Changes Like Those Sweeping Soviet Bloc

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 8

 BODY:
In his bluntest public rejection yet of the profound political and economic changes now sweeping the rest of the Soviet bloc, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has vowed to resist all such reforms even if it means a parting of the ways with his allies.
''If destiny assigns us the role of one day being among the last defenders of socialism in a world in which the Yankee empire has succeeded in embodying Hitler's dream of world domination, we will know how to defend this bulwark to the last drop of blood,'' President Castro said in a speech delivered on Thursday in Havana and monitored here.
Mr. Castro's remarks were his first public comment on the state of East-West relations since last weekend's summit talks between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and reflected his growing ideological isolation within the Eastern bloc. At the meeting off Malta, Mr. Bush called on Mr. Gorbachev to do more to prevent Cuba from shipping arms to Nicaragua and to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador and also offered to assist Mr. Gorbachev in carrying out economic reforms. 
 
Doesn't Mention Names
Speaking at ceremonies honoring Cuban combatants killed in the course of ''internationalist missions'' in Angola, Ethiopia and other African countries, Mr. Castro did not criticize Mr. Gorbachev or any Eastern European leader by name. But he complained of the difficulty of building a Communist state when others are ''slandering socialism, destroying its values, discrediting the party and liquidating its leading role, doing away with social discipline and sowing chaos and anarchy everywhere.''
Mr. Gorbachev's policies of perestroika and glasnost, or restructuring and openness, have aroused interest in Cuba, which experimented briefly with a degree of economic liberalization early in the decade but then reversed course with a ''rectification'' program after Mr. Castro decided that some people were making too much money and egalitarianism was eroding. The Soviet leader received a warm popular welcome when he visited Cuba in April, but Mr. Castro has rejected many of Mr. Gorbachev's innovations as violations of Marxist-Leninist orthodoxy.
The transformations taking place elsewhere in the Soviet bloc coincide with Cuba's most serious political and leadership crisis in years. In July, several senior Cuban military officials were executed for drug trafficking in circumstances that have yet to be fully explained, and economic and morale problems have also forced Mr. Castro, who is 63 years old and has been in power for more than 30 years, to shake up his Cabinet.
The Cuban leader has long feared that the lessening of tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union will translate into changes in the military status quo in Europe that would increase Washington's ability to impose its own views elsewhere, including the Caribbean. He also remains firmly committed to the principle of ''proletarian internationalism,'' a justification for intervention abroad that he fears is on the wane elsewhere.
 
Soviet-Cuban Meeting
According to reports from Managua, the Soviet Ambassador there met with Nicaraguan and Cuban officials on Nov. 28, just days after Mr. Bush had blamed the Soviet Union for supplying arms to Mr. Castro that eventually ended up in the hands of rebels in El Salvador. ''We are hearing that he really read them the riot act,'' said a European diplomat based in the Nicaraguan capital.
The official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported on Thursday that American forces at Guantanamo Bay Naval Station had fired twice on Cuban sentries outside, calling the incident ''serious and of unpredictable consequences.'' Today, a Pentagon spokesman denied the charge, saying ''no weapons or rounds ever crossed the fence line.''
In his address, Mr. Castro justified the prohibition in Cuba of some Soviet publications, such as Sputnik and Moscow News. He said the measure was necessary because such publications were ''filled with venom against the U.S.S.R. itself and against socialism'' and have ''demanded the cessation of just and equitable commercial relations between the U.S.S.R. and Cuba.''
Since the early 1960's the Soviet Union has heavily subsidized the Cuban economy through such measures as the purchase of Cuban sugar at prices well above market levels and the sale at bargain rates of petroleum, some of which Cuba then resells to gain hard currency. Those subsidies, amounting to as much as $5 billion a year, have increasingly been questioned by Soviet officials as part of the economic restructuring that is under way.
'Negative Economic Consequences'
''From the crisis that has emerged in the socialist camp, we can only expect negative economic consequences for our country,'' Mr. Castro said.
Just hours before Mr. Castro's appearance at the war commemoration ceremonies, during which he was accompanied by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola, the Cuban Government for the first time announced casualty figures for the more than 400,000 soldiers and ''technical advisers'' it has sent to fight in Africa over the last 15 years. According to official statements, 2,289 Cubans have died abroad, more than 2,000 of them in Angola.

HEADLINE: Better Traps Being Built For Delinquent Parents

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEDIA, Pa., Dec. 8

 BODY:
The Delaware County Domestic Relations Court here has devised a new way to find people who fail to pay child support and elude arrest: the court advertises their names on a ''Most Wanted'' list 300 times a week on cable television and once a month in full-page newspaper advertisements.
''It's been very successful,'' said Francis J. Catania, president judge of the court. ''The Most Wanted list has helped us locate 33 people, over half of the people we have named. Many other people who felt they might be next on the list have also come in and made voluntary payments.'' 
Delaware County is not alone in circulating Most Wanted lists; Florida and Virginia began similar programs last month, and Maryland plans to start one in January. Public officials have discovered that programs to collect child support not only raise money for children whose parents have divorced or perhaps never married, but also pay for themselves by reducing welfare expenses.
With program budgets rising by almost 50 percent in the past five years, enforcement agencies have been able to use increasingly sophisticated collection techniques. Many use computers to search public data banks, including credit files and rosters of prison inmates, for clues about the location and financial affairs of fugitive parents. To increase pressure on late payers, Texas officials say that next week they will begin using a computer system that will automatically give credit bureaus the names of parents who are more than $500 behind in child support payments.
 
Tightening of Rules
Despite the recent gains in enforcing child support orders, specialists say far too little money is being collected to feed, house and clothe the children.
As a result of the 1988 overhaul of the nation's welfare system, Federal law now requires states to enforce guidelines insuring that support payments are consistent within a state. Payments previously varied from judge to judge, a situation that sometimes led to ''judge shopping.''
The new law also requires that the amount of court-ordered payments be withheld from the paychecks of parents who have been delinquent in providing money. By 1994 all child support payments will be automatically withheld.
The Federal Government reimburses states for up to two-thirds of the costs of their collection programs.
As a result of the new law, judges say they are demanding larger support payments and are quicker to strip delinquent parents, usually fathers, of their property instead of trying to collect back payments. ''I take away their rings and empty their wallets right in court,'' said Judge Charles D. McClure, chief judge of Florida's Second Judicial Circuit, which is based in Tallahassee.
 
Unfilled Needs Are Seen
But Federal and state efforts are not enough, according to a Congressional study made public on Thursday by Representative Thomas J. Downey of New York, Mr. Downey, a Suffolk County Democrat, is acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources.
''The good news is that the program seems to have improved since the mid-1980's,'' said Mr. Downey. He noted that the report, by the Congressional Research Service, found that state programs collected $4.6 billion last year, or almost double the $2.4 billion they collected in 1984.
''The bad news comes from census data, which show that we still are not doing a very good job at helping children who need support from their parents,'' he said.
The census data, based on a 1985 survey, indicate that only 25 percent of 8.8 million mothers who were owed child support were receiving full payments; half received nothing. Parents who do not have custody of their children made a total of $7.2 billion in payments that year, when $10.9 billion was due. But the Congressional study said the true needs of the children amounted to $30 billion that year.
The census survey shows the average child support payment, when adjusted for inflation, declined 25 percent from 1978 to 1985. The average annual payment in 1985 was $1,679 for one child, $2,597 for two, $2,800 for three, $3,739 for four or more. Child support payments were lowest for women who were less educated, minority members or never married.
 
Success of Collection Efforts
Last year, the Congressional study said, child support payments collected by state agencies helped 200,000 families leave the welfare system and partly reimbursed the state and Federal Government for welfare grants made to another 600,000 families. The study found that these savings in welfare payments more than covered the $1.4 billion cost of the collection programs, which also collected $3.2 billion in child support payments for 1.1 million families who were not on public assistance.
Armed with the innovative new methods of tracking down delinquent parents, agencies have been conducting countywide roundups of child support fugitives, often on Father's Day. And state officials say they expect to order more paternity tests now that the Government reimburses states for 90 percent of the laboratory costs; 300,000 tests were done last year to determine financial responsibility for children in cases where the father's identity was in dispute.
Advocates for custodial parents say the new enforcement measures do not go far enough, and advocates for noncustodial parents say some go too far.
Geraldine Jensen, president of the Association for Children for Enforcement of Support, a membership organization, supports the new enforcement programs, but says they need to be much stronger. ''There are great laws on the books, but we still don't have adequate local enforcement,'' she said.
 
'I Was Embarrassed'
David L. Levy, president of the National Council for Children's Rights, an advocacy group for noncustodial parents, opposes some enforcement actions. He argues that if states publish the names of parents who fail to pay child support, the states should also publish the names of parents who fail to comply with court-ordered visitation rights.
Publication of a ''Most Wanted'' list can be stressful for the whole family, but some people see no alternative. ''I was embarrassed by it,'' said Patricia A. Huddy, a resident of Ridley Park, Pa., whose husband's name appeared on the Delaware County list this spring. ''But anything they have to do to bring him is O.K. with me.''

HEADLINE: Jobs Gain but So Does Joblessness As Expansion of Economy Slows

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Despite a surge in layoffs and the eighth straight monthly decline in factory jobs, the economy continued to generate jobs in November, the Labor Department reported today.
But the gains were not as great as the increase in the labor force, so the unemployment rate rose one-tenth of a point, to 5.3 percent, the highest since January. In all, 119.5 million Americans had civilian or military jobs and 6.73 million were looking for work in November.
The civilian unemployment rate, excluding the 1.7 million members of the armed services stationed in the United States, also rose one-tenth of a point, to 5.4 percent. A one-month increase of less than two-tenths of one percentage point is not considered statistically significant. 
Today's figures, the first comprehensive reflection of the economy's performance last month, appeared to indicate further slowing of the seven-year-old business expansion.
According to the department's survey of households, employment rose by 236,000 and unemployment by 169,000. The department's separate survey of business payrolls, considered a more reliable measure of job growth, showed an increase of 210,000 jobs last month, more than expected.
But the implied strength was nullified by a sharp revision in the job growth figures for October. Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said the department had overestimated hiring in state and local education, ''an industry,'' she said, ''which is especially difficult to measure in the fall months.''
 
Lower Interest Rates Likely
The slowing of job growth made it more likely that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates again to head off a recession, and that likelihood prompted rallies in the bond and stock markets. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 10.66 points to close at 2,731.44.
Yet analysts remain divided on whether the economy will continue to expand this winter or slip into a modest contraction.
''In general, the numbers point to a continuation of an economy that's growing, but at a slow pace,'' said Darwin L. Beck, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation. He added that the November jump in layoffs was concentrated in the automobile industry, which has long been regarded as weak.
But Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at First Fidelity Bancorporation in Philadelphia, predicted that the gross national product would decline slightly in the last quarter of 1989, which would be the first quarterly contraction since the spring of 1986.
By common definition, a recession requires two consecutive quarters of decline; Mr. Levy said he expected a tiny gain in the first quarter of 1990.
 
Disquieting Surge in Layoffs
The number of laid-off workers jumped to 982,000 last month, 30 percent more than in October, and well above the past year's range of 750,000 to 875,000.
Officials and other analysts said the surge was not worrisome in itself but would be grounds for alarm if repeated. Mr. Levy said businesses had been cutting back payrolls because their profits were off and they were finding it harder to pass along higher costs to consumers.
The continuing decline in factory jobs was more clearly negative. In the overall decline of 27,000, as measured by the survey of payrolls, the biggest losers were in automobiles and electrical machinery. There were smaller declines in several other industries. On the other hand, there were gains in construction, machinery, printing and publishing, and oil and gas.
All four regions of the country showed an increase in unemployment, according to figures that, unlike the others, are not adjusted for seasonal variations. Unemployment rose two-tenths of a point in the Northeast, to 4.7 percent, and in the Midwest, to 5.5 percent; four-tenths of a point in the West, to 5.1 percent, and one-tenth of a point in the South, to 5.4 percent.
In New York State, unemployment rose to 5.2 percent from 4.7 percent in October; because it is based on a much smaller sample than the national figure, this increase may not be statistically significant. In New York City, where an unemployment survey was conducted for the first time in 20 months, the rate jumped to 6.5 percent, from 4.6 percent in March 1988. New Jersey's jobless rate was 5.1 percent in October, unchanged from October.
John Wieting, an economist for the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the New York City and New Jersey figures resulted from a slowdown in the economy since the October 1987 stock market crash. ''More people are looking for work on the backdrop of a slower economy,'' he said, adding that the figures did not indicate that a recession was imminent.
''The economy is in a stall because of the crash but it hasn't fallen apart,'' Mr. Wieting said. ''It has slowed and leveled off.''
Among the 11 largest states, Pennsylvania and Texas showed increases in unemployment of eight-tenths of a point, to 5.4 and 7.2 percent; Michigan showed a statistically significant decline of nine-tenths of a point, to 7.3 percent, despite the auto industry's woes. There was no immediate explanation for this decline, but it followed a large increase, 1.2 points, in September. These figures are seasonally adjusted.
Nationally, the unemployed had been without jobs for an average of 11.7 weeks in November, slightly less than the average in October. Ten percent of the unemployed had been idle for more than six months.
The payroll survey also showed big gains for health services, wholesale trade, finance and real estate. Christmas hiring in general merchandise and other retail stores met normal seasonal expectations.

HEADLINE: Irresponsible Publicity on the Fur Industry

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am writing to express my concern over the recent wave of publicity that has been given to anti-fur organizations. The foremost example was the season premiere of ''L.A. Law,'' which was aired on Nov. 2 on NBC television.
The show presented the fur industry in a very bad light, without the chance to defend itself. The main focus was several video clips of animals being caught in traps. After viewing this it is hard to make the audience realize that only a small percentage of furs are obtained in this manner. 
The majority of the furs come from ranch-raised animals treated with the utmost care and respect. There is no difference between a fur farm and a poultry farm, a cattle farm or a fish farm, and what is the difference between fur and leather?
Fur sales are down a bit, mostly due to overproduction, but also in part because of the furor caused by the anti-fur movement. There is still a demand for high-quality pelts like those produced in North America. The drop in the return on pelts has forced many trappers to go out of business. Therefore the car has taken the trapper's place. The numbers of wildlife killed and maimed on rural roads are proof of this.
The media for the most part have been very irresponsible in their coverage of the issue. They have chosen to cover a volatile and emotional issue without speaking to some of the largest fur producers in the world.
Although we were not asked, here is our response. The fur industry produces a renewable resource that makes use of the byproducts of other industries that would otherwise require their disposal. Fur farming generates more than $318 million in direct economic impact. Retail sales amount to $1.8 billion and have a positive impact on the international trade balance, since more than 50 percent of fur farmed in the United States is exported.
Most of all, the fur industry supports the right of a person to choose his or her own life style, and not impose his views on the rest of society.
 
A. A. RIETVELD
General Manager
Northwood Fur Farms Inc.
 Cary, Ill., Nov. 24, 1989

LENGTH: 892 words

HEADLINE: Unions, Docile Since '81, Show New Militancy

BYLINE: By A. H. Raskin;A. H. Raskin was for many years labor correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
The militancy that has made workers' movements so conspicuous in the struggle for human rights in Eastern Europe, China and Latin America shows incipient signs of resurgence in the U.S. trade unions for the first time since Ronald Reagan fired 11,500 striking Federal air traffic controllers and smashed their union in 1981.
The new mood was much in evidence at the biennial convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in Washington last month. Solidarity was the convention's central theme, and Lech Walesa was on hand to acclaim the federation's pioneer role as his group's earliest and most steadfast backer.
Oddly, a similarly effusive tribute to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. as a sparkplug powering the resistance of underground labor movements abroad came from President Bush, whose support for the federation in its domestic objectives has been almost as invisible as was his predecessor's. 
''Labor,'' the President told the convention, ''has been an enduring force for freedom - at times a cry in the wilderness, at times the conductor of a mighty chorus - rejecting all forms of totalitarianism, fascist and Communist alike. With each passing year, through the labor movement, freedom is finding its voice.''
The one thing the 800 delegates found missing from Mr. Bush's rhapsodic 30-minute testimonial to them as ''the beating heart of American liberty'' was any remotest suggestion that he would join the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in its drive to put workers' rights at the top of its agenda. For a decade, the federation has called for reform of creaky labor laws in ways that would make it harder for union-busting employers to misuse them as devices for frustrating organization and collective bargaining.
The convention's opening day had been marked by a thunderous demonstration in support of striking unionists at Eastern Air Lines, Nynex and Pittston Coal. The strike in which unions are in deepest trouble, and for which they most fault the Bush Administration, is the nine-month-old walkout of machinists at Eastern.
Labor's high command had hoped that a strike might be averted altogether. It counted on a governmental procedure that had been virtually automatic before the Reagan-Bush era - appointment under the Railway Labor Act of a Presidential fact-finding board to make settlement recommendations. Frank Lorenzo, Eastern's chief, ranks in labor's book as a cross between Genghis Khan and Ebenezer Scrooge.
When hope for peace vanished and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., with Eastern's pilots and flight attendants in the vanguard, formed a united front to bolster the machinists, labor turned to its Democratic friends in command of Congress to build a bonfire under the President. Last month, both houses passed a measure calling for a bipartisan commission to investigate the dispute and make recommendations within 45 days. This bill was on Mr. Bush's desk when he appeared at the convention to shower accolades on the federation for its activities - but only those remote from these shores. At the end of his speech, there was tepid applause (in contrast to the tumultuous ovations accorded Lech Walesa), but this was soon drowned out by a chorus of shouts: ''Sign the bill! Sign the bill! Sign the Eastern bill!'' The President gave his answer just six days later - a veto that all but doomed the strike. The pilots and flight attendants quickly abandoned the picket lines, leaving the machinists in desolate isolation as Mr. Lorenzo makes over his crippled airline.
How crucial Government intervention is to unions involved in siege-like strikes is being illustrated on labor's other principal battlefield of 1989 -the half-year-long strike of the United Mine Workers against the Pittston Company in the Appalachian region.
The miners seemed in desperate straits until Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole intervened in late October to appoint former Secretary W. J. Usery Jr. as a ''supermediator.''
Pittston was swift to welcome her departure from the hands-off policy that Mr. Bush cited as his reason for vetoing the Eastern bill. That left union leaders with no doubt that Pittston had given a signal to the White House that it was hurting badly enough to want a face-saving way out. This is fine with the miners, who now see their first real hope for a contract that preserves the proud traditions of this once mighty, now shrunken union.
It did not take developments of the volcanic kind that made Lech Walesa a convert to private entrepreneurship to enlist U.S. unions as stalwart believers in a free economic system. But a decade in which antiunion employers have taken comfort from lopsided administration of the labor laws, and from the exaltation of greed in public policy, has provided scant fortification for labor's faith. The ferment that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. helped fuel in Europe may not stay that remote.
In its resolution pledging solidarity with all major strikes, the federation urged every union to seek contractual provisions permitting its members to quit work on ''floating demonstration days.'' These would let labor mount citywide or even nationwide mass rallies or picket lines in aid of beleaguered unionists. That is a long way from a general strike on the overseas model, but it is a warning of restiveness in a movement that feels it has been too docile too long.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Names Eight Appointees, Including Four Deputy Mayors

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins named eight appointees to his administration yesterday, including an experienced Federal prosecutor to head the New York City Department of Investigation, with responsibility for uncovering corruption in government.
If confirmed by the City Council, the prosecutor, Susan E. Shepard, could face the prospect of pursuing an inquiry that is under way by the department into Mr. Dinkins's financial affairs. At a news conference announcing her appointment, she said that Mr. Dinkins had not discussed the issue with her and that she would decide on her own whether to conduct the investigation or leave it to someone else if it was not resolved by the time Mr. Dinkins took office on Jan. 1.
Later, in an interview, she seemed to go a step further, saying, ''It would seem clear to me that if there are some substantial allegations that require investigation, that invites investigation by someone other than a person appointed by the Mayor.'' 
As expected, the Mayor-elect filled the central posts at City Hall by naming four deputy mayors, led by Norman Steisel, a former sanitation commissioner who is not close to Mr. Dinkins but is highly regarded for his management skills, as first deputy in charge of day-to-day operations. Three trusted aides will fill the other slots.
 
Core of Official Family
Bill Lynch, Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager and former chief of staff in the Manhattan borough president's office, will be deputy mayor for intergovernmental relations, overseeing dealings with the City Council, borough presidents and political groups. Mr. Dinkins's acting chief of staff, Barbara J. Fife, will be deputy for planning and development, and Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, a former deputy borough president and now Financial Services Commissioner, will oversee finance and economic development.
They will form the core of Mr. Dinkins's official family along with Victor A. Kovner, a lawyer who will be Corporation Counsel, and the press secretary, Albert Scardino. Mr. Scardino is a reporter who stopped work yesterday at The New York Times. His resignation does not take effect until Dec. 31 so he can take owed vacation time.
The Mayor-elect also said yesterday that Mary Schmidt Campbell, whom he recommended for Cultural Affairs Commissioner in the Koch administration, would remain in that post.
Even as Mr. Dinkins filled some posts, his panel seeking candidates for Police Commissioner has scheduled an interview for tomorrow morning with Police Chief Lee Brown of Houston, one of the most prominent black law-enforcement officials in the nation, people close to the search said. Chief Brown, who has been mentioned as candidate from the beginning of the search, is expected to join the small group of serious contenders that includes Richard J. Condon, the current commissioner, and Joseph McNamara, a former commander in New York who is now Chief in San Jose, Calif. The committee is to recommend three to five names to Mr. Dinkins by Monday.
Ms. Shepard, who worked 10 years as an assistant United States attorney in Brooklyn, where she was chief of the major crimes and general crimes sections, is chief counsel of the State Commission of Investigation. A registered independent, she is married to a Republican, former United States Attorney Raymond J. Dearie, now a Federal judge in Brooklyn.
She would be the first woman to be Investigation Commissioner, an in-house investiagor whose principal duty has often been perceived as much to spare mayors the embarrassment of scandals on their watch as to root out wrongdoing. In her first encounter with reporters yesterday in a news conference announcing the appointments at the City University Graduate Center in midtown, she struck a note of cool and considered independence.
''My background is as a prosecutor,'' she said as Mr. Dinkins stood behind her. ''I consider myself a professional. My only role is to try to find out where people in city government are not functioning well, to look at it, investigate it as hard as we can and make a decision about what ought to be done about it.''
 
Inquiry on Apartment
Mr. Dinkins is the subject of an inquiry by the department into possible conflicts of interest or failures to disclose his stock interest in a company that has cable television franchises, holdings he says he transferred to his son. The department has also been investigating the acquisition of a subsidized apartment by a senior aide in Mr. Dinkins's office whose income may have exceeded the limits for that unit.
Ms. Shepard said she had not discussed the inquiries with Mr. Dinkins or city officials and had no inside knowledge of them.
''If at the time that I take office, there is still an investigation or investigations pending, I will review the material and I will make a decision myself about whether it's something that I feel it's appropriate for me to handle or whether it's something that ought to be handled by somebody else,'' she said.
She said an option might be to appoint a special prosecutor or a special counsel for the investigation. But, Ms. Shepard said, she could not make such a decision yet. Asked whether there would be an inherent conflict for her to investigate Mr. Dinkins, Ms. Shepard said, ''I would certainly say that there could be serious questions, at the very least, about the appearance'' of doing so.
 
Background Clearances Required
But in the subsequent interview, she seemed more emphatic, noting an investigation of Mr. Dinkins by someone he did not appoint would be ''for his protection, as well as for mine.''
Mr. Dinkins said all the appointments announced yesterday were subject to final background clearances by the Investigation Department. All the candidates have replied to preliminary questionnaires. Only Ms. Shepard is subject to City Council confirmation.
Asked how his senior staff would work, and whether Mr. Lynch, the architect of his victory, would have more sway than the other deputies, including Mr. Steisel, Mr. Dinkins said the hierarchy would depend on the idea under consideration. He praised Mr. Steisel for agreeing to accept an awesome responsibility and acknowledged that Mr. Lynch, Mrs. Fife and Ms. Hernandez-Pinero were from his inner circle. He said that was good.
''Bill and Barbara and Sally are friends and people with whom I've worked,'' he said. ''I know their abilities, their skills. I know how hard they work. I know they're good people, I know their instincts. I know that on many issues we would almost not have to communicate; they would automatically sort of think like I do.''
Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Steisel acknowledged that they disagreed on the question of building garbage incinerators. Mr. Steisel promoted the idea as sanitation commissioner; Mr. Dinkins has called for a moratorium of several years on plans to build the first one in Brooklyn.
Mr. Steisel said yesterday that he did not consider the issue as a ''litmus test'' and viewed the job of deputy mayor as carrying out a mayor's policy. He added that there were always many discussions and debates in that process. Mr. Dinkins said that he would not shrink from discussion and that if Mr. Steisel disagreed, he would say, ''Prove your case.''

GRAPHIC: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins announcing appointments. Included were Norman Steisel, third from right, first deputy mayor; Bill Lynch, deputy mayor for intergovernmental relations, and Barbara J. Fife, deputy mayor for planning and development. (NYT/Don Hogan Charles)

HEADLINE: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees;
Barbara Joelson Fife: Deputy Mayor

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
Barbara Joelson Fife is a classic case of civic leader become political leader.
She first became involved in civic affairs promoting the causes of the environment, parks, urban renewal and waterfront rehabilitation. It was natural for Mrs. Fife to jump first to the political arena and then to her first public office as special assistant. This year she became acting chief of staff to Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins. 
Soon she will move to the the warren of offices around the mayor's office in City Hall, where she will be one of four deputy mayors.
The 58-year-old West Side Democrat is also a rare politician - someone who managed to bridge the ideological gap in the Democratic Party when that schism was at its worst, during the Vietnam War era. Though a peace advocate, a liberal and reform Democrat, she was friendly with such Democratic Party leaders as Patrick J. Cunningham and Joseph F. Crangle.
Mrs. Fife, whose husband, Martin, is a successful businessman, raised four sons while active in efforts to clean up the Hudson River and Jamaica Bay, to build low-income housing in Clinton and to preserve parks.
Only one of her sons, Richard, is involved in politics or government. He is a political media consultant.
A graduate of Bryn Mawr College in 1952, she returned to formal schooling and received a master's degree in urban planning from Hunter College in 1983. She also lectured at Hunter and administered an urban internship program before her appointment to the Borough President's office in 1985.
She has lived almost all her life in the city. Born in Newton, Mass., she moved to New York as a child with her parents. Her father, Julius Joelson, owned a small chain of movie houses in the Bronx, and Mrs. Fife still recalls Sunday afternoon family outings checking the various JJ Theaters.
Until her move to the Borough President's office, she was a familiar figure in politics for 20 years as a Democratic state committeewoman from the West Side, chairwoman of the state committee reform caucus for half that time; treasurer of the Democratic state committee for the last four years and a Democratic national committeewoman for the last nine years. She said she would resign her party posts.
She managed the unsuccessful campaign of Carl McCall for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor in 1982, but in the mayoral campaign this year she ran the Borough President's office while Mr. Dinkins campaigned.

HEADLINE: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees;
Albert Scardino: Press Secretary

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
''The mayor of New York City is the second most important political figure in the country when it comes to setting the tone of public discourse,'' Albert Scardino said yesterday. ''To be able to help shape that tone is a truly remarkable opportunity for someone interested in public policy, which I am.''
Mr. Scardino, a New York Times reporter who stopped work at the newspaper yesterday, will have that opportunity as Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins's press secretary. His resignation at The Times takes effect Dec. 31 so he can take owed vacation time. 
''The mayor of New York is terribly important,'' Mr. Scardino said, ''because New York is the media capital of the world, and the media amplifies everything the mayor says. Dinkins, who is starting with immense good will in spite of some problems, has an opportunity to influence public discourse everywhere.''
In 1984, as editor of The Georgia Gazette, a weekly in Savannah, Mr. Scardino won a Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing. He founded the paper in 1978 and edited it for more than six years.
''We had a hand, directly and indirectly, in getting 38 public officials to be convicted of, or to plead guilty to, felonies,'' he said. ''A lot of them went to jail.'' 60 Days' Notice on Ads After Mr. Scardino won the Pulitzer, he said, a daily newspaper in Savannah backed some candidates who won in the next election. Once in office, the candidates withdrew the city's legal advertising from The Gazette.
''They gave us 60 days' notice,'' Mr. Scardino said. ''The Gazette went out of business on the 59th day.''
Several days later, he joined The New York Times.
Mr. Scardino, who is 41 years old, was born in Baltimore and was raised in Savannah, where his father, Dr. Peter L. Scardino, practices medicine. Mr. Scardino graduated from Columbia University in 1970, returned to Columbia for a year to study international affairs, and went to work as a reporter for The Associated Press in West Virginia, where he met his wife, Marjorie.
After working as a freelance, Mr. Scardino spent two years at the University of California Graduate School of Journalism at Berkeley, where he filmed a documentary about the Georgia Coast for his thesis. When efforts to sell the film foundered, he accepted the invitation of a group of Savannah lawyers to start The Gazette.
The Scardinos live in Manhattan, where his wife, a lawyer, is president of the North American edition of The Economist magazine. They have three children.

HEADLINE: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees;
Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero: Deputy Mayor

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
As a child, she says, she was extremely shy, and to this day her mother says, ''Sally never bothered anyone.'' This may surprise those who have worked for and with Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, New York City's Commissioner of Financial Services, who was named yesterday to be deputy mayor for finance and economic development.
Her colleagues characterize Ms. Hernandez-Pinero as anything but shy and reserved. They use words like aggressive, opinionated, determined and ambitious. And Ms. Hernandez-Pinero says that her shy days are past. 
''Some people like it, some people do not,'' she said. ''I have a lot of conviction about the things I believe in and I am forceful.''
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, 37 years old, a deputy Manhattan borough president under Mr. Dinkins, grew up in the Bronx, one of five children of parents who came to the United States from the small town of Moca, P.R. Her father worked as a building superintendent and a dishwasher, and her mother still works as a school lunch worker at Junior High School 45. Her parents live in Co-op City in the Bronx. Ms. Hernandez-Pinero attended Junior High School 44 and Bronx High School of Science before she went to Wesleyan University, where, she says, ''I officially came out, fighting one cause or another.''
 
'A Real Problem-Solver'
As commissioner, she emphasized assisting small businesses and not-for-profit companies.
She is still overwhelmed by her appointment as deputy mayor. Several colleagues questioned her ability to compromise and wondered if the large companies knew her sufficiently. They also said that her focus on smaller businesses was not suited for these times. But others were confident she would succeed.
''To some degree it is true that she is not completely familiar to the business community,'' said First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff. ''But it would be a big mistake for anyone to underestimate Sally. She is a very talented, gifted person and real problem-solver.''
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said she is surprised by those who say she is not a team player.
''I'm the type who prepares very hard to back up my point of view,'' she said. ''But I can find the middle ground, and if my boss says he wants to do it another way, I accept that and go on to the next thing.''
She and her husband, Hector Pinero, a vice president of a real-estate company, have two sons, ages 3, and 8 months.

HEADLINE: New Administration: Profiles of Dinkins's Eight Appointees;
Susan E. Shepard: Investigation Commissioner

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FREITAG

 BODY:
Susan E. Shepard, who was named yesterday to head the Department of Investigation, may soon find herself in the awkward position of inheriting an investigation of the man who hired her, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins.
Should that happen, Ms. Shepard said in a telephone interview yesterday, she probably would remove herself from the case.
''It would seem clear to me that if there are some substantial allegations that require investigation, that invites investigation by someone other than a person appointed by the mayor,'' she said. ''That's for his protection as well as for mine.'' 
Ms. Shepard, who is 46 years old and lives in Brooklyn Heights, sees her new position as an opportunity to combine her experience as a Federal prosecutor and as chief counsel for a state agency that investigates misconduct and corruption by local officials.
If her appointment is approved by the City Council, Ms. Shepard will take over an agency with 625 employees and a budget of $30 million. She would succeed Kevin B. Frawley.
 
Investigating Misconduct Charges
For the last three years, Ms. Shepard has been the chief counsel for the New York State Commission of Investigation. She is also a member of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Drug Enforcement Task Force.
The commission has no prosecutorial power, but it is the state's principal body for identifying abuses in state and local government through inquiries, public hearings and reports. It recently investigated allegations of misconduct by the Commissioner of Public Safety in Westchester County, and in the district attorney's office and the police department in Suffolk County, Ms. Shepard said.
Before her appointment to the state commission in 1986, Ms. Shepard served as an assistant United States attorney in the Eastern District for nearly 10 years. She headed the office's major-crimes section from 1983 to 1986.
Ms. Shepard, a native of Chicago, graduated from Radcliffe College with a degree in economics in 1965. She was an editor at Business Week magazine for three years before entering Columbia University Law School. After graduating from Columbia, she became a lawyer for the Justice Department's Antitrust Division.
In 1976, David G. Trager, then the United States Attorney in the Eastern District, appointed Ms. Shepard as an assistant attorney.
In 1984, Ms. Shepard married Raymond J. Dearie, who was then the United States Attorney in the Eastern District and is now a Federal judge. They have two children.

GRAPHIC: Susan E. Shepard (NYT)

HEADLINE: Robert Schleck, 64, A Research Analyst

 BODY:
Robert W. Schleck, a former foreign service officer, teacher and research analyst who conducted studies on economic issues in New York City, died of cardiac arrest on Nov. 29 at Leland Memorial Hospital in Riverdale, Md. He was 64 years old and lived in Mount Rainier, Md..
 
After graduating from Princeton
University, Mr. Schleck began his career as an intelligence analyst at the State Department and was second secretary at the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv during the Suez crisis in 1956. 
He returned to the United States to become a research analyst, first for the Public Affairs Research Council of Louisiana and then in New York at the Tax Foundation and the Economic Development Council.
After returning to Washington he worked as a senior research analyst with the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress.
In his later years, Mr. Schleck, who received a Ph.D. in public administration and public finance from New York University, taught at the Wakefield Country Day School in Huntley, Va. Mr. Schleck, a native of Elizabeth, N.J., is survived by his wife, Anne Louise, and his two sons, Paul William and Peter Michael, all of Mount Rainier.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1989

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 European Community leaders took an important step toward creating a central bank and a common currency, overriding objections from Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain. West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, endorsed a French position contending that the community needs to be strengthened so it can help Eastern European countries gain greater freedom and handle the growing prospect of German reunification. [Page 1.] A Soviet research institute is negotiating to become part owner of a Silicon Valley high-technology company. [33.] Mikhail S. Gorbachev's challenge is to find an alternative to capitalism that does not clash with the Russian sense of order and economic justice. Economic Watch. [33.] Budapest has asked Moscow to allow Hungarian trade with the Soviet Union to be settled in dollars, U.S. officials said. [34.] 
 
THE ECONOMY
 The long inquiry into Pentagon fraud edged closer to former senior Defense Department officials when the Loral Corporation, a New York military contractor, admitted in court that it had illegally obtained inside information from the Navy and Air Force. [1.] The economy continued to generate jobs in November, despite a surge in layoffs and a decline in factory employment, the Labor Department reported. But the gains were not as great as the increase in the labor force, and the unemployment rate was said to increase one-tenth of a point, to 5.3 percent, the highest since January. The Government also sharply lowered its estimate of the growth in jobs in October. [12.] Regulators seized New Jersey's largest savings association. City Federal Savings Bank had large real estate losses. [33.]
 
COMPANIES
 Chevron asked a Federal court to force Pennzoil to sell its 8.8 percent stake in Chevron, which was disclosed on Thursday, and to bar Pennzoil from buying more shares. [33.] Eastman Kodak said Kay R. Whitmore would succeed Colby H. Chandler as chief executive next year. J. Phillip Samper, Mr. Whitmore's chief rival, is to retire as vice chairman. [33.] Nissan has been sued by a California couple who contend that a boarder in their home was a corporate spy. [11.] Campeau said it had received several expressions of interest in Bloomingdale's. A deadline for proposals passed yesterday. [35.] Boeing said it would begin offering a new twin-engine jet. [35.]
 
MARKETS
 Eugene Laff was convicted on five counts of participating in a conspiracy to manipulate the prices of three over-the-counter stocks. He is the former chairman of Haas Securities. [33.] Prices of Treasury isues rebounded after a purchase by the ''Billion Dollar Buyer,'' the name dealers have given to a Japanese brokerage that engages in large transactions. [36.] Stock prices rose modestly. The Dow Jones industrials gained 10.66, to 2,731.44. For the week, the Dow lost 16.21 points. [36.] The dollar ended marginally weaker against most currencies after the Government report on the unemployment rate. On the Comex, gold closed at $411.80 an ounce, up $1.80. [42.] Pork belly futures prices plunged on the Chicago Board of Trade amid concern over lagging exports. Livestock futures were also lower. [42.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 Wall Street experts advise prudence to investors considering year-end changes. Individuals ''would do well to lower their expectations'' for 1990, one professional advises. Your Money. [34.] Researchers are using a newly patented gene to develop a vaccine against whooping cough that may not pose the dangers of the current vaccine. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Soviets Seek U.S. Venture

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8

 BODY:
A Soviet research institute is negotiating to become a part owner of a Silicon Valley high-technology company.
Such an investment would involve a contribution of Soviet technology in return for what would apparently be the first Soviet equity stake in a fledgling technology company. It could set a precedent for converting Soviet scientific advances into viable commercial products.
The deal would be highly unusual because the Soviet Union would be backing a risky venture in the United States, entrusting the American entrepreneurial process to produce a payoff. 
Most ventures between the two countries have involved joint ventures operating on Soviet soil under Soviet rules, according to experts on such ventures. The few joint ventures based outside the Soviet Union have involved less risky terms, like payment in advance for any technology licensed from the Soviet Union.
Under terms of a preliminary agreement, the Institute of Protein Research of the Soviet Academy of Sciences will contribute a new way to produce proteins for use in research and for pharmaceutical manufacturing. In return it will receive a 5 percent stake in Transgene, a biotechnology company being formed in the San Francisco Bay area.
 
Contracts and Approval Seen
 Sierra Ventures, a Menlo Park, Calif., venture capital company that is the main investor in Transgene, said it expected the final contracts to be signed in a few weeks. Petri Vainio, a Sierra Ventures associate, said Soviet Government approval is also expected shortly from Vladimir Ezhkov, deputy chairman of the Soviet State Committee on Science and Technology.
But Aleksandr Markov, an official of the Committee on Science and Technology, said in Moscow today that a final agreement had not been reached. Aleksandr S. Spirin, director of the Institute for Protein Research, said this week that unbeknown to Transgene, the institute has also been talking to two other American companies - both established concerns rather than start-ups - and has not yet chosen among the three.
The participants have also only started the process of applying for United States Government approval to export any technology that Transgene develops back to the Soviet Union, which would be part of the arrangement.
Silicon Valley, where fortunes can be made overnight and some executives cruise around in Ferraris and Jaguars, would have been considered anathema to the Soviet Union a few years ago.
But faced with a deepening economic crisis, the Soviet Union is trying all types of new approaches to advance its economy and generate hard currency to pay for imports. ''It is leading them to do things that in earlier years would have been considered treasonous,'' said Marshall Goldman, associate director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University.
Experts on Soviet business ventures said such an alliance of opposites could represent a new way of turning basic Soviet scientific advances into commercial products, while providing a new source of technological skill for Americans.
''You constantly hear of the wisdom of combining American ingenuity with Soviet research and turning it into useful products,'' said William D. Forrester, president of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council, a binational trade promotion group, who called the Transgene arrangement unique.
 
Putting Research to Work
 ''We have a lot of innovative technology but to implement it is a problem,'' said Aleksandr Yakovlev, deputy Soviet trade representative in Washington. But American start-up companies, he and others noted, have an unparalleled reputation for turning research advances into commercial gains.
The Soviet institute will realize a profit from its stake in Transgene if the company is successful and makes a public stock offering or is bought by another company. Sierra Ventures is putting up $1.85 million for a 50 percent share. The founders and employees will own the rest of the company.
Transgene will also lend the Soviet institute up to $500,000 over five years for research. That amount will be paid back if the technology is successful enough to earn sufficient royalties. To handle royalty payments and licensing, a joint venture would be set up in which Transgene would own 51 percent and the protein institute 49 percent.
Transgene is working on a new way to produce proteins, which include enzymes, hormones and virtually all other substances made by the body. Its technology could be an alternative to the genetic engineering now used to produce proteins like insulin, growth hormone and interferon that are sold as drugs.
 
An Expensive Process
 Genetic engineers mass-produce proteins by implanting the gene for production of that protein into bacteria or mammalian cells, which are then made to multiply. The cells are eventually killed and the protein of interest must be extracted from all the other proteins the cells produce, a costly process.
''You have to find the one protein you want out of hundreds or thousands,'' said K. P. Wong, a professor of chemistry at California State University in Fresno and a founder of Transgene. The two other founders have not yet been identified; they are biochemists who work for large food and drug companies and have not yet told their employers about Transgene.
Transgene will try to make artificial cells by putting ribosomes - the part of a cell that actually manufactures proteins - in a special vessel along with amino acids, the basic building blocks of proteins. The gene coding for only one protein would be inserted into the vessel, and the ribosomes would assemble the amino acids into that one protein.
While such artificial cells, known technically as cell-free translation systems, have been the subject of research for many years, it has been difficult to get them to work for more than a few minutes or produce more than tiny quantities of the desired protein, Professor Wong said. But the researchers at the Institute for Protein Research have a way to overcome these problems, he said.
Transgene plans first to make protein-synthesizing machines that could be used by biotechnology researchers to produce small quantities of needed proteins quickly. They would compete with machines now sold by companies like Applied Biosystems Inc. that can synthesize simple proteins by linking amino acids together in a purely chemical process.
For the longer term, the Soviet technology could someday be used for manufacturing proteins that serve as drugs.
 
Significant Advance Seen
 Two scientists not connected to Transgene said the Soviet technology appears to represent a significant advance in the area that could have promise for making proteins for use in research. But both scientists said they doubted it would be competitive with existing technology for mass-producing drugs.
Dennis Henner, director of the department of cell genetics at Genentech Inc, a leading biotechnology company, said it might be too expensive to supply pure amino acids and other ingredients for an artificial cell. With real cells, ''you feed them glucose and they provide all the components,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Caution, Patience: Advice for the 90's

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
For investors considering what year-end moves to make in their portfolios, the watchword from Wall Street experts is prudence. ''Nineteen-ninety may well be a year to sow rather than to reap,'' said Robert J. Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. ''Rates of return on stocks could well be below average, in general, after 10 years of far above-average returns in the 1980's.''
George J. Collins, president and chief executive of T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore-based investment and mutual fund manager, said, ''Individual investors would do well to lower their expectations and not take double-digit returns for granted.'' 
Both investment houses forecast a slowdown next year, which may keep a lid on the markets' overall performance, but they do not expect a recession. Both see pockets of long-term opportunity.
''A soft landing could lead to a soft takeoff,'' said John H. Laporte, president of T. Rowe Price's New Horizons and New America Growth Funds, noting that ''corporate cash flow remains strong and provides a solid underpinning to the market.''
He advises investors to keep high-quality stocks, but avoid borrowing to maintain positions, and expects small stocks, which have lagged in recent years, to become more attractive.
Mr. Farrell advises a ''strong position in long Treasury bonds and utilities'' along with plans to accumulate stocks in growth industries, when these shares show price declines. Favorable areas he cited include health care, pollution control, construction engineering, electrical equipment, natural gas, oil service and telecommunications, and he said he expected consumer stocks and financial issues to lose their leadership position.
He warned that portfolios dependent on an ever-rising market will not do well. Leveraged buyout activity will also decrease, he predicted, along with the chances for success in investing in companies that are likely takeover targets because of their underlying ''breakup'' value.
Interest rates next year are expected to be relatively stable, with comparatively low returns on cash and equivalents.
James Kochan, Merrill Lynch's chief fixed-income strategist, said, ''Municipal bonds appear to offer some of the best values in the fixed-income markets now,'' while intermediate-maturity agency, corporate and mortgage-backed securities should outperform Treasuries of similar maturities. ''A diversified fixed-income portfolio should include high-yield bonds at the current generous spreads to Treasuries,'' he added.
The ''junk bond'' market, said Richard S. Swingle, president of T. Rowe Price's High Yield Fund, with returns of 16 percent, is ''one of the most undervalued segments of the capital markets.'' Yields could reach 19 percent next year, he suggested, and the market could rally by midyear.
Most important international equity markets did well in 1989, noted M. David Testa, chairman of Rowe Price-Fleming International Inc. But the dollar's gains on the foreign-exchange markets trimmed the gains of American investors abroad.
Thomas R. Robinson, chief international equity strategist at Merrill Lynch, favors ''a more defensive strategy relative to world markets'' until the direction of global interest rates becomes clearer.
 
'The Prudent Speculator'
 For those who would like to master prudent, long-term investment strategies, Dow Jones Irwin has just published ''The Prudent Speculator - Al Frank on Investing'' ($22.95 in hard cover).
Mr. Frank, a former printer and college humanities teacher, was first drawn to the stock market in 1968 by his Ph.D. sponsor at the University of California at Los Angeles. He recalls that he found the market appealing as a participatory democracy and ''a way of making a living without working,'' while Ben Graham's book, ''The Intelligent Investor,'' was a ''fascinating intellectual exercise.''
Mr. Frank now manages $160 million for others, as well as publishing ''The Prudent Speculator,'' the newsletter that The Hulbert Financial Digest rated as the best performing for the nine years ended June 30. Mr. Frank's leveraged portfolio rose 461.4 percent in that time, compared with a 308.5 percent gain by the S.&P. 500.
Small investors belong in the market, Mr. Frank contends, if they buy ''small pieces of good companies and maintain them'' with at least a three-year outlook. He views Ford Motor, Chrysler, Reynolds Metals and Phelps-Dodge, for example, as undervalued companies.
The market is a good place to get rich slowly, he says, advising ''patience and selection and diversification and risk management.'' His book is a solid explanation of fundamental analysis. It is readable and understandable without being too cute as so many books for the popular market are.

HEADLINE: Hungary Asks Soviets to Base Trade on Dollars

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Seeking to expand trade with the West and bolster its economic efficiency, Hungary has moved to have its trade with the Soviet Union settled in dollars instead of rubles, State Department officials said today.
Other Eastern European governments are also seeking to free themselves from the ruble, but Budapest this week became the first to make a formal request to the Soviet Union for trade based on dollars, the officials said.
It is unclear whether Moscow has responded, or how. ''There is a testing of Soviet limits in so many areas these days that we are unwilling to say how far they will go here,'' one State Department official said. 
All trade between the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies is denominated in rubles, which have little value outside the Soviet Union. Eastern European countries have long complained that if they earn surpluses, they can spend the rubles only on Russian goods that they do not want.
 
Hungary Expects Surplus
 This year, Hungary is expected to earn a surplus of rubles, equivalent to about $1 billion, at the official exchange rate, in its trade with the Soviet Union. But Hungary has no plans to use the rubles, which are expected to remain in its account.
With dollars, Hungary and other Eastern European countries would be able to buy the better-quality consumer goods and sophisticated industrial products that they badly need, American officials said.
American officials expect Moscow to drive a hard bargain with the Hungarians. The Soviet Union now gives Hungary and other Eastern European countries a significant discount on the price of their oil purchases. Moscow could end the discount and insist that the Hungarians pay for the oil in dollars.
A shift from ruble-dominated trade is considered essential if Eastern European countries are to open their economies, establish market pricing and try to make their own currencies convertible into dollars or other Western currencies. Currently, these currencies are used exclusively in their home countries.
''It's a function of necessity if they want to have a rationalized price structure,'' said Joseph P. Tragert, economist at PlanEcon, a Washington-based research group specializing in Eastern Europe.
One American official just returned from Eastern Europe reported that many officials he spoke to consider nonconvertible currencies as much an obstacle to the purchase of Western products as Western export controls. ''They just don't have the money to buy anything,'' he commented.
Western governments strongly support efforts by the Eastern Europeans to give their currencies value in the world market.
One official said a plan was being drawn up for Poland, for example, in which Western governments and Japan would put $1 billion into a stabilization fund for the zloty to help make the Polish currency convertible.
The United States and West Germany, this official said, would each provide $200 million and Japan $150 million to the zloty fund. Britain is expected to contribute $100 million.
The plan is expected to be discussed at a meeting next week in Brussels of foreign ministers of 24 Western nations.

HEADLINE: Bush to Name Fed Governor

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
President Bush announced today that he would nominate David W. Mullins Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, to be a Federal Reserve Board governor.
Mr. Mullins, a former professor at the Harvard Business School, is the first person named by Mr. Bush to the seven-member board. The seat has been vacant since June, when H. Robert Heller resigned to become executive vice president of Visa International, the credit card company.
Mr. Mullins, who is 43 years old, is not identified with strong ideological positions. His academic speciality is in banking, capital markets and corporate finance and not in overall economic policy.
Nonetheless, he could provide a strong voice for the Treasury within the central bank. Recently, the Fed and the Treasury have been at odds. The Fed has insisted on keeping interest rates high as a means of fighting inflation. The Treasury has favored lowering rates to stimulate economic growth and bring down the value of the dollar.
Mr. Mullins was instrumental in drafting the Bush Administration's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry, and he had primary responsibility for guiding the measure through Congress this year.
