HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Midcontinent Airlines Closes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 8

 BODY:
Midcontinent Airlines Inc., a regional carrier that had been scaled down since Braniff Inc.'s bankruptcy filing, has ceased operations indefinitely. About 35 Midcontinent employees in Kansas City have been laid off, the carrier's chairman, Steve Gillette, said. The carrier had nearly 50 workers in its system, he said.

TICKER: PGP (PAR) (58%); PG (NYSE) (58%); 

INDUSTRY: NAICS325620 TOILET PREPARATION MANUFACTURING (58%); NAICS325611 SOAP & OTHER DETERGENT MANUFACTURING (58%); NAICS322291 SANITARY PAPER PRODUCT MANUFACTURING (58%); SIC2844 PERFUMES, COSMETICS, & OTHER TOILET PREPARATIONS (58%); SIC2841 SOAPS & OTHER DETERGENTS, EXCEPT SPECIALTY CLEANERS (58%); SIC2676 SANITARY PAPER PRODUCTS (58%); SIC2676 SANITARY PAPER PRODUCTS (58%);

HEADLINE: Japanese Purchase Aids Bond Rally

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rebounded and yields tumbled yesterday. Dealers said one reason for the market's rally was a substantial purchase of Treasury bonds by a Japanese brokerage house that many dealers refer to as the ''Billion Dollar Buyer,'' although the house has been known at times to sell just as equally large amounts of Treasury bonds.
Some dealers said the Billion Dollar Buyer was Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru International's New York office, which first drew notice in October because of its huge purchases. But Eishi Wakabayashi, executive vice president at the company, said in a telephone interview that he could not talk about any of its specific business. 
The Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, soared a half-point immediately after the opening, then eased slowly during the rest of the session. In late trading, the long bond was up 14/32, at 102 26/32, to yield 7.88 percent, down from 7.91 percent the day before and 7.86 percent a week ago.
 
Initial Impact of Job Data
 The fixed-income market thrives on negative economic news because it supposedly reduces the demand for credit and its impact on interest rates and inflation. Thus the Government report that unemployment had climbed to 5.3 percent in November might have been expected to enchance the value of outstanding fixed-income securities, and initially it did, However, several dealers, who asked not to be identified, said the initial euphoria in the bond market over the rise in unemployment for November quickly vanished when the Ocotber employment data were revised from a previously reported gain of 233,000 non-farm jobs to only 93,000.
''The big revisions are not only disturbing but raise questions about the methods used in compiling them,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Also unexpected in the Government's report was a decline of 27,000 manufacturing jobs last month. Normally, this decline, which was twice what many economists forecast, would have been bullish for the bond market. But dealers said the large revisions in the October data made this figure also suspect.
 
Quoted Price Paid
 ''In any event, the Billion Dollar Buyer materialized again and snapped up an estimated $1.5 billion of long-term Treasury bonds off the screen of a West Coast dealer and perhaps another $500 million from local dealers,'' Mr. Sullivan said. He meant the buyer simply paid the price quoted on the Telerate screen, rather than negotiating a more favorable price, as large buyers typically do.
Mr. Sullivan said: ''The fact that dealers were eager to sell such large amounts in a rising market to the so-called Billion Dollar Buyer tells us that dealer inventories may be larger than the Street thinks. In the midst of all this, the Federal Reserve was on the sidelines, which also suggests that it has no immediate intention to ease. Many of us think the Fed is comfortable with the funds at between 8 3/8 and 8 1/2 percent.''
Indeed, the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans and is thus considered the bedrock cost of credit, held steady at 8 3/8 percent, after trading a bit higher at 8 7/16 percent for most of the day.
 
Large Declines for Bills
 The discount rates on Treasury bills, usually most immediately influenced by the funds rate, posted large declines. The 90-day bills lost 10 basis points, at 7.59 percent; the six-month bills fell eight basis points, to 7.33 percent, and the one-year bill rate dropped 10 basis points, to 7.20 percent.
The Treasury announced that it planned to auction $9.75 billion of new one-year bills on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 10.66 but Is Down for the Week

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Helped by early strength in the bond market, stock prices rose modestly yesterday.
After shooting up nearly 17 points in the first half-hour, the Dow Jones industrial average traded in a narrow range through most of the day. It closed at 2,731.44, a gain of 10.66 points.
For the week, the closely watched market indicator fell 16.21 points, or six-tenths of a percent. 
On the New York Stock Exchange, rising issues outnumbered falling ones by 813 to 646.
Volume on the Big Board fell to 144.9 million shares, from 162 million on Thursday.
 
Speculation on Rate Cut
 Sharp downward revisions in the October non-farm payroll figures raised speculation that the November data might also be revised downward, showing a further weakness in the economy that could compel the Federal Reserve Board to ease credit by lowering interest rates.
The Labor Department reported that non-farm payrolls expanded in November by an unexpectedly large 210,000 jobs. It also showed that the number of new non-farm jobs created in October was revised to 93,000, from 233,000.
''The large adjustment in October non-farm payrolls took the edge off any ill effects from the higher November reported figures,'' said Gene Jay Seagle, chief technical analyst at Gruntal & Company. ''Investors are wondering if they should be so sensitized to statistics that change so readily. Still, the economy is more and more conducive to easing by the Fed.''
 
Year-End Rally Envisioned
 As year-end selling for tax reasons abates, Mr. Seagle said, the stock market is likely to find the going easier. He said a year-end rally could take the Dow above the 2,800 level.
''The market looks like a year-ago repeat, with the powerful peace catalysts introducing the third phase of the bull market into the new year,'' Mr. Seagle said. By late in the day the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond was up 14/ 32, to 102 26/32, to yield 7.88 percent.
In the broader maket, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.10 points, to 348.69, while the New York Stock Exchange composite gained 0.54, to 192.92.
Among individual issues, Pennzoil jumped 3 1/4, to 86 1/2, on speculation that Chevron might try to take over Pennzoil. Chevron announced that it was filing a lawsuit contending that Pennzoil had illegally accumulated its stock and that it had arranged a $5 billion line of credit ''to capitalize on opportunites that may develop.''
J. Hugh Liedtke, Pennzoil's chairman, reiterated that Pennzoil had no interest in taking over Chevron, which gained 1/8, to 66 7/8.
 
Report on Eastern-AMR Talks
 AMR slipped 3/4, to 64, after rising earlier, on a report that it was near an agreement to buy the Latin American routes of Eastern Airlines from Texas Air. Analysts said Eastern could get a cash infusion of $300 million to $400 million if the deal was completed. Texas Air benefited from the news, analysts said, rising 1 1/4, to 13 5/8.
Gainers among the blue chips included Coca-Cola, up 1 1/8, at 78; Du Pont, up 1/8, at 120 7/8; Exxon, up 3/8, at 49; Sears, Roebuck, up 3/8, at 38, and Chrysler, up 1/2, at 19 3/8.
Compaq Computer fell 3 3/4, to 85 7/8. Charles Wolf, an analyst at First Boston, lowered his rating on the company to a ''hold'' from a ''buy'' and cut his 1989 and 1990 earnings estimates.
Pfizer, which projected slightly lower earnings for the fourth quarter, dropped 4 3/8, to 69 1/8.
Tonka was among the bigger losers in percentage terms, falling 2 1/2, to 11 1/4. Citing lackluster holiday sales, the company lowered its revenue estimates for 1989.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index edged up 0.36, to 375.45. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.09, to 456.22.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Marginally Weaker; Gold Prices Soar in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended marginally weaker yesterday against most key currencies after the Government reported that the jobless rate rose last month to a 10-month high of 5.3 percent.
Gold rose in domestic trading following a big advance overseas.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $411.80 an ounce, up $1.80 from late Thursday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $411.50 an ounce, up $1.90. 
Currency dealers said the November unemployment data did little to move the dollar because it was within market expectations, although some traders were confused by a sharp revision in the previous month's figures.
The Labor Department said the rate for civilian unemployment alone increased to 5.4 percent in November from 5.3 percent in October - the highest level since January - despite the addition of 210,000 non-farm jobs last month.
While 210,000 is a moderately strong number for new jobs, the Government also sharply revised its job growth figures for October to 93,000 from 233,000.
 
'A Mixed Bag' of Data
 ''It's hard to know how much to react to data that are subject to revisions of that magnitude,'' said Trevor Woodland, a vice president and chief corporate dealer for Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. ''What we got was a mixed bag.''
In Tokyo the dollar ended at 144.27 Japanese yen, up 0.14 yen from Thursday's close. It traded at 144.20 yen in London, and 144.300 yen in New York, down from 144.305.
The dollar declined against the British pound, which traded at $1.5793 in London, compared with $1.5750 Thursday, and at $1.5825 in New York, up from $1.5780.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.7705 West German marks, down from 1.7725; 1.5970 Swiss francs, up from 1.5900; 6.04885 French francs, down from 6.0515; 1,304.00 Italian lire, down from 1,307.25, and 1.16225 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16175.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's figires, included: 1.7720 West German marks, unchanged; 1.5985 Swiss francs, up from 1.5920; 6.0565 French francs, up from 6.0560; 1,306.50 Italian lire, down from 1,308.00, and 1.1615 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1625.
The dollar, which on Thursday dipped below 2 Dutch guilders in Europe for the first time since Jan. 3, recovered to an even 2 guilders late yesterday.
Gold soared in London to a late bid of $411.55 an ounce, from $404.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, it rose to $409.25 an ounce, from $404. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold gained $2.74 an ounce to close at $407.75. Silver prices also strengthened. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery rose 2.1 cents an ounce, to $5.644. Silver closed in London at $5.64 an ounce, up from $5.60 Thursday.

HEADLINE: TOP AIDES TO BUSH ARE VISITING CHINA TO MEND RELATIONS

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The White House national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, made a surprise visit to Beijing today and said he had come as an emissary of President Bush ''to bring new impetus and vigor'' into United States-Chinese relations.
Ending a suspension of high-level contacts with China imposed after soldiers in Beijing killed hundreds of democracy demonstrators in June, Mr. Scowcroft said it was time for the United States and China to find areas where agreement is possible and ''to isolate for another time those areas of disagreement.''
Mr. Scowcroft was accompanied on the previously unannounced visit by Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State. Both men are friends and former colleagues of Henry A. Kissinger, who as President Nixon's national security adviser and Secretary of State led the way to normal relations with China and who is regarded warmly here. 
 
Briefing Beijing on Malta
The ostensible reason for the visit was to brief Chinese leaders on last weekend's Soviet-American summit meeting in Malta, but it was clear that President Bush had decided that it was time to end China's quarantine.
''We believe it is important that we not exhaust ourselves in placing blame for problems that exist,'' Mr. Scowcroft said at a dinner given by Foreign Minister Qian Qichen.
The United States had earlier welcomed the moves toward democracy in China and criticized the subsequent crackdown by the Chinese Army, but even though the White House reaction was mild compared to that of Congress, Beijing protested bitterly, accusing Washington of hypocrisy and interference in its internal affairs.
 
Critical of Change in Europe
China has also been critical of the changes sweeping the Communist movement in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, and of the close ties between Washington and Moscow.
The visit raised the possibility that a major irritant in relations between the two countries - the sanctuary provided in the American Embassy here to the dissident couple Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian - might also be resolved in these talks.
The Chinese have issued warrants for the arrest of the couple, who sought refuge in the embassy during the June crackdown, and called them counterrevolutionaries.
 
High Hopes Before Crackdown
Before the crackdown, the Bush Administration had high hopes for close relations with China, where Mr. Bush had been the American envoy and where he has many friends. The Administration reacted carefully to the killings in Beijing and tried to temper heated Congressional reaction.
In addition to banning high-level contacts, the Administration suspended military exchanges and arms shipments to China and used its leverage at the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank to defer new loans to China.
But contacts continued as usual in many areas as American officials said that a continuing relationship with China was too important to neglect or abandon in a period of such profound global change.
Even though there was a White House ban on high-level meetings, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with Foreign Minister Qian in New York during his visit to the United Nations in September. And the Administration allowed a waiver of the sanctions so commercial planes could be shipped to China.
 
For China, Obvious Pleasure
Chinese officials have reacted to this visit with obvious pleasure. Mr. Qian met with the Americans for two hours this afternoon before the formal banquet tonight. On Sunday, they are to meet separately with Prime Minister Li Peng, Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, and the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, before leaving for Tokyo to brief Japanese leaders.
The meeting with Mr. Deng, who is 85 years old, is particularly significant, since he retired from public life in November and had indicated that he was no longer going to meet high-level visitors.
In Washington, President Bush moved to try to head off Congressional criticism of the new opening to China. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said, ''The President has concluded that it is appropriate and in the long-term interests of the United States to inform the Chinese leadership of his discussions with the Soviet leader,'' Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
 
China Still 'Part of the World'
While President Bush ''deplores the tragedy of Tiananmen Square last June, China nevertheless remains part of the world around us,'' the statement said. ''The President views China as an important country in world affairs.''
Mr. Qian, in his banquet toast tonight, welcomed Mr. Scowcroft as ''an old friend,'' and said his visit shows the importance President Bush attaches to United States-Chinese relations, ''for which we would like to express our appreciation.' '
''As important as our differences are,'' Mr. Qian said, ''they cannot obliterate the major common interests between us.'' He said that the Chinese leadership believed that the visit ''will certainly be helpful in promoting mutual understanding, overcoming difficulties and removing differences between both countries so that Sino-United States relations may return to normal and further develop at an early date.''
In his toast, Mr. Scowcroft said that he and Mr. Eagleburger had come ''as friends, to resume our important dialogue on international questions of vital interest to both our nations.'' He said that in addition to briefing the Chinese about Malta, ''we also come today to bring new impetus and vigor into our bilateral relationship and seek new areas of agreement - economic, political and strategic.''
 
Seeking Common Ground
''Speaking as a friend,'' Mr. Scowcroft said, ''I would not be honest if I did not acknowledge that we have profound areas of disagreement - on the events at Tiananmen, on the sweeping changes in Eastern Europe.'' But in their meetings, he said, ''we seek to outline broad areas where agreement is possible and to isolate for another time those areas of disagreement.''
The Americans had also come, he said, ''to reduce the negative influence of irritants in the relationship.''
In the last three weeks, the Chinese have lodged three protests with the United States over Congressional moves to strengthen economic sanctions on China and to allow Chinese students currently in the United States to extend their visas. The last protest came on Friday when Vice Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu met with American Embassy officials here.
President Bush had vetoed a Congressional effort to allow Chinese students who feared persecution in China to remain in the United States, for which the President was widely criticized. But he had accomplished the same ends administratively, Mr. Liu said.
He said charges that students might be persecuted upon their return home were groundless, and said he had expressed ''our utmost indignation'' in a formal protest to the Americans.
Tonight, however, the talk was all conciliatory. Mr. Scowcroft said that it was President Bush's ''strong desire'' to see these talks make progress. ''Both sides must persevere, now more than ever,'' Mr. Scowcroft said. ''The sooner we set about this task, the better.''
According to the official Chinese press agency, '' talks on some major issues'' continued immediately after the banquet between Mr. Scowcroft and Mr. Qian. The agency said the talks today were ''helpful'' and ''constructive'' and took place in a ''friendly, sincere and frank atmosphere,'' the usual diplomatic catchwords for productive conversations with moments of bite.
American officials reached tonight would not comment on the talks or on the Chinese press agency's characterization of them.

A front-page picture caption last Sunday about a visit by American officials to Beijing misstated Qian Qichen's title. He is China's Foreign Minister, not Prime Minister.

LENGTH: 1760 words

HEADLINE: Playing Games With Labor Laws: When Work Fills a Child's Hours

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Right here, under the nose of the Federal Government, children not yet in their teens are working 20, 30 and 40 hours a week in flagrant violation of the child labor laws.
The children dart after commuters at subway stations, scamper door to door in affluent neighborhoods and ply the busy sidewalks just blocks from the White House, selling boxes of candy for $4 to $5 and keeping a dollar a box.
Federal labor laws prohibit most paid work for children under 14 years old so as to protect them from commercial exploitation and keep them in school, and the laws set strict limits on how much children under 16 can work after school and on weekends. But Federal and state officials say that in scores of communities, more and more employers, like many who manage candy peddlers, are flouting the laws.
The Labor Department says it found 22,508 children working in violation of the Fair Labor Standards Act in the 1989 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30. That is more than twice the levels of the first half of the 1980's and the highest since the law was enacted in 1938. New York State studied child labor last year and found 182 children working illegally in New York City. It also found 122 businesses, most of them garment makers, employing children illegally. 
 
Turning to Children
Officials say an important reason for the rapid rise in child labor violations is the nation's low unemployment rate, which has hovered around 5 percent for more than a year. Pressed to find people to do menial jobs, supermarket chains, fast-food outlets and pizza delivery shops have had to dig deeper into the population and are often turning to minors.
The children do not complain, nor do their parents; they like the extra money. Labor officials acknowledge that working in fast-food outlets or selling legitimate products door to door can help keep children away from drugs and other dangers as well as teach them the virtues of work. But sometimes teachers complain. They say the children are not doing their homework or are napping at their desks, condemning themselves to careers in the ghettos of the work force.
''It's not a bad deal for the kids if the businesses are run according to the law,'' said Kenneth Goldberg, chief of employment standards in the Maryland Division of Labor and Industry. ''But many are not run according to the law. They're fiddling with the law.''
Nor is the situation likely to improve quickly. State and Federal enforcement agencies say that because of budget constraints, they usually can only respond to complaints of violations, not go out and look for them. When they do go out, however, they find that the statistics just scratch the surface. ''We're really seeing an increase in child labor violations,'' said Nancy M. Flynn, the Labor Department's acting wage and hour administrator.
 
Door-to-Door Sales
Because of the ages of the children involved and the hours they keep, a segment of the door-to-door sales industry is an especially flagrant violator, the most insidious and the hardest to stop, according to advocates for children and labor officials. While some employers, including some candy distributors, respect the law, state and Federal officials say others do not.
In Washington, at 8:30 on one recent weekday evening, the violations were apparent. A boy who said he was 10 years old and another, a head taller, who said he was 11, were hovering at the top of an escalator at the Friendship Heights Metro station on the border of Chevy Chase, Md., and the District of Columbia. At the feet of each was a cardboard carton of boxes of peanut brittle and other candy.
As homeward-bound, prosperous-looking commuters reached the top of the escalator, the boys scooted after them, offering the candy for $5 a box.
They said that the ''van man'' who brought them to the station lets them keep $1 to $1.50 for each box they sell, but that they have to behave because he also fines them for cursing and roughhousing in the van or not being at their posts when he comes to pick them up. ''He tells you the rules,'' the older boy said. ''If you don't obey the rules, you pay $2.''
 
'He Lets Us Work to 11'
With some exceptions, like delivering newspapers, acting, selling cookies for charity and working in a family business, work for pay is prohibited for children under 14. When children are 14 and 15, Federal law permits employers to hire them for three hours on school days and no later than 7 P.M. On non-school days they can work eight hours and no later than 9 P.M.
Most states have their own child labor laws. A few, notably Oregon and Alaska, have more stringent regulations than the Federal Government.
The 11-year-old said the van man had picked them up at home that day, just after school at 4 P.M., and would be back to get them around 9 P.M. ''On weekends,'' the 10-year-old said, ''he lets us work to 11.''
Each boy carried a blue card to read to customers. It said: ''My name is -and I'm a member of the E & J Sales Club program. E & J Sales Club is a work and recreation program for community children after school.'' The club does not appear in any of the standard Washington or Maryland directories, and Federal and Maryland labor officials said they had never heard of it.
 
Names Change With Seasons
The officials said E & J may be one of scores of local distribution companies that change their names with the seasons and are often impossible to trace. The distributors are recruited by wholesalers and manufacturers. Some of these are legitimate operators, but others are not, the officials say.
''Internally, we have talked quite a lot about that,'' William C. Brooks, Assistant Labor Secretary for employment standards, said Friday. He said he had spotted children selling candy one evening recently after leaving work and dispatched an aide to go talk to some the next day. But the children rarely show up at the same place two days in a row, so the aide is still looking, he said.
''Where we see it, we'll get the appropriate people in there and see what we can do about it,'' Mr. Brooks said. He said the Labor Department's Baltimore office was investigating two distributors it suspects of operating around Washington.
William J. Gainer, director of education and employment issues at the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, told a forum on child labor here last month that with the rise in the reported infractions of the child labor laws, injuries to working children were also increasing.
 
Violations on the Rise
The laws restrict children from using hazardous machinery, like slicing machines and trash compactors. Yet children have often been found operating such devices. Mr. Gainer said the 33 states that participated in a poll he conducted reported that 48 children were killed on the job in 1987 and 1988 and that 128,000 were hurt.
Violations of child labor laws, in general, are on the rise, many states report. ''Approximately 50 percent of the businesses who employ minors in Michigan are in violation of some provision of the Michigan Youth Employment Standards Act,'' said Marsha Bowers, a youth employment specialist in the Michigan Department of Labor.
Frederick Seaman, assistant director of the Missouri Labor Department's division of labor standards, said: ''We're getting tons of this in the fast-foods industry, little mom-and-pop places in small towns. There's a lot more kids working now. In Missouri, a kid needs a certificate from his superintendent of schools to work, and these are increasing 25 and 30 percent a year. With more kids working, there are more violations.''
Mr. Goldberg of Maryland said 156 businesses in the state have been found in violation of Maryland's child labor laws, an increase from 133 last year.
 
Complaints From an Educator
In October, Mr. Goldberg's agency charged four candy company distributors with numerous violations of the child labor laws through their employment of 11 boys and girls 9 to 14 years old. It might not have done so, Mr. Goldberg acknowledged, were it not for the persistent complaints of Michael Zadjel, the principal of Mars Estates Elementary School in Baltimore.
Mr. Zadjel said he got involved a year ago, when a van with Florida license plates was in an accident in Baltimore's busy Harbor Tunnel and all five children aboard were injured and required hospital treatment. The next day, Mr. Zadjel said, ''a girl came in'' and said her brother had been in the van. ''She said he was selling candy and that he did it all the time,'' Mr. Zadjel said.
Mr. Zadjel spoke with other children who were having trouble with their schoolwork: '' 'Why didn't you do your homework?' I'd ask. 'We were selling candy,' they'd say. 'We didn't get home until 10 o'clock.' ''
In the past, many state labor officials have traced some of these operations, though not the one in Baltimore, to Gerald L. Winters, a wholesaler and manufacturer in northern New Jersey. Mr. Winters has operated nationwide door-to-door candy sales networks for a couple of decades, most recently with a company called Miller Candy Sales.
 
Settlement of $150,000
Last year, said William Burger, a Federal Labor Department lawyer in Atlanta, the Government settled a child labor law case against Mr. Winters in North Carolina, after he lost two court appeals and he agreed to pay $150,000 in civil penalties.
Efforts to reach Mr. Winters were unsuccessful. Phone service at companies with which he is said to be affiliated had been disconnected or their phone numbers could not be obtained through information. A spokesman, Michael W. Kempner, said: ''There's a new Gerry Winters out there. Winters made a lot of mistakes in the past because he was too zealous to help kids.''
Mr. Kempner is involved in a campaign by more than 50 candy distributors to relax what he called ''antiquated child labor laws'' to permit more door-to-door selling.
Others are pressing for tighter laws. Linda Golodner, executive director of the National Consumers League and chairwoman of the Child Labor Advisory Committee, set up by the Labor Department, said the committee had recommended a ban on most door-to-door sales by children under 16. The department has not disclosed its view.
''Most of the jobs these kids get aren't going to get them anywhere,'' Mr. Gainer of the G.A.O. said, ''and about 20 percent of young adults are functionally illiterate. If we're going to be competitive as a country, then I think we're going to have to concentrate on getting kids educated.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1688 words

HEADLINE: THE CHALLENGE OF KEEPING U.S. TECHNOLOGY AT HOME

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
Despite mounting concern about the nation's dependence on Japan and other foreign nations for important technology, keeping crucial components or machinery in American hands is proving exceedingly difficult.
The latest example of the trend is that the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, unable to find an American buyer for a division that makes equipment for manufacturing computer chips, has opened talks with a Japanese company.
American companies, whose worry is mainly directed at Japan, fear that if they become dependent on foreign companies they will not be granted access to the most advanced machinery or components as quickly as their foreign competitors, putting them at a severe disadvantage.
 
Profits Before Patriotism
But such fears are somewhat hypothetical, and American companies have been unwilling to hurt their own profits and anger their shareholders merely out of a sense of patriotism. This observation is true particularly because many of the businesses up for sale are seriously troubled and costly to turn around. 
And even when American companies are willing to make such investments, they are often outbid by Japanese companies, which can borrow money at lower interest rates in their country and face less pressure to produce quick profits on their investments.
 
A Series of Sales
One result is a continued series of sales that distress the nation. ''We all become national treasures after deals are made,'' said Dr. Sheldon Weinig, president of the Materials Research Corporation, a semiconductor equipment and materials company acquired by the Sony Corporation in August after an acceptable deal with an American buyer was not found.
Perkin-Elmer is the latest case in point. The company, based in Norwalk, Conn., said in April that it planned to sell its division that makes equipment used to make semiconductors - the silicon chips used in computers, telephones, missiles and other electronic products.
Its inability to obtain an adequate American bid prompted it to discuss a sale to the Nikon Corporation of Japan, although those talks eventually broke down. A sale to Nikon would have left American chip producers even more dependent than they already are on Japanese suppliers for the sophisticated machinery used to etch circuits on chips.
Since 1983 alone, the American share of the market for wafer steppers, a main kind of equipment used to make semiconductors, has declined to about 20 percent from almost 65 percent, while the Japanese share has risen to 72 percent from 35 percent.
 
U.S. Companies Just Saying No
In another case earlier this year, American semiconductor industry leaders urged the Government to block the sale to a West German company of the Monsanto Company's silicon business, the last big American-owned producer of the silicon wafers from which chips are made.
Robert C. McCormack, a Defense Department official, told the industry leaders that the Pentagon would try to block the sale if the semiconductor companies themselves would pool half the money needed to buy the operation. ''Not one of them was willing to put up a single dollar,'' Mr. McCormack said. The sale to Huels A.G. went through. And despite fears that the nation is becoming too dependent on Japan for computer memory chips, most American computer companies have decided against paying $5 million to $50 million to invest in U.S. Memories, a proposed cooperative venture that would make such chips. Unless it can come up with more investors in the next few weeks, the venture will fail.
 
The Root of the Problem
To some industry officials and analysts, the recent events indicate a failure of American companies to back their words with actions. ''Everyone is trying to optimize their own tree and the farm is being purchased,'' said Papken Der Torossian, president of the Silicon Valley Group Inc., an electronics company in San Jose, Calif.
''The Japanese are more intelligent about these large-scale strategic decisions than the Americans are,'' said Charles H. Ferguson, a semiconductor industry expert at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
But industry executives say the real problem is not that American buyers cannot be found for ailing companies but that companies are withering to the point where they have to be sold. What are needed, they say, are Government policies like cutting the Federal deficit and lowering interest rates, to make it easier for American companies to raise money for investments. Some suggested tax incentives to encourage American companies to buy from other American companies.
 
Hardly a Jewel
The Perkin-Elmer semiconductor equipment operation is hardly a jewel. The company missed a major change in technology about 10 years ago, and it has fallen behind Nikon and other competitors in the market for lithography equipment, which is used to shrink circuit patterns photographically onto silicon wafers.
Stephen J. Balog, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., estimated that Perkin-Elmer's semiconductor equipment division, with revenues of about $190 million, has had $200 million in operating losses and charges against earnings over the last three fiscal years. Perkin-Elmer executives declined to be interviewed, citing the talks over the sale of the business.
Still, Perkin-Elmer, with considerable technical and financial help from the International Business Machines Corporation, has developed a new machine, called a step-and-scan, that has the potential to leapfrog Nikon's technology. But even that machine came out about two years behind schedule and still needs work.
After spending more than $100 million of its own and I.B.M.'s money on the project, Perkin-Elmer still faces spending of $50 million to $100 million to perfect the product and advance it to the next generation of technology. And besides I.B.M., American semiconductor companies have been reluctant to order the machine.
Given its uncertain prospects, industry officials say, it is not surprising that the company decided in April to get out of the semiconductor equipment business, to concentrate on its core business of scientific instruments and to improve its profits.
These prospects will also make it difficult for other semiconductor equipment companies, most of which are very small, to buy the division. Some companies that produce semiconductors, including I.B.M. can afford a purchase but they do not want to become tool producers.
 
Fear of Political Backlash
Still an American buyer might be found. This possibility is especially likely because Nikon said two weeks ago that it is no longer negotiating, apparently because of a rising political backlash in the United States.
The leading American prospect is considered to be KLA Instruments, a semiconductor equipment company from Santa Clara, Calif. A consortium of companies might also be formed to make the purchase, industry executives said. In either case, If KLA or a consortium made the purchase, I.B.M. would be expected to somehow reduces the risk, either through financial backing or guaranteed purchases, industry executives said.
The Ateq Corporation, a privately held semiconductor equipment company in Beaverton, Ore., has bid for a separate part of Perkin-Elmer's operation, the electron beam division in Hayward, Calif., industry people said.
So far, Perkin-Elmer has not found any of the American offers adequate, no doubt because it expects to command a higher price from a Japanese company, industry people said. The company has an obligation to its shareholders to seek the highest price. Some analysts and industry people said the company hopes to receive as much as $200 million, while American companies might pay no more than half that amount.
 
Why General Signal Bowed Out
''We couldn't see how to bridge the difference between what we thought it was worth and what they thought it was worth,'' said Jack Halter, senior vice president of the General Signal Corporation, the other big American photolithography company. General Signal looked at Perkin-Elmer's business but did not make a formal bid and is no longer in discussions, he said.
It is in the interest of the American bidders to force Nikon to back away by raising a political outcry or to persuade the Government to veto the sale to a foreign company, as can be done under the 1988 trade act. Then Perkin-Elmer would have to accept the best American bid. That is what happened when Fujitsu Ltd. backed away from its plan to buy the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, allowing the National Semiconductor Corporation to buy Fairchild for about half the price Fujitsu was willing to pay.
 
Japan's Advantage on Rates
Japanese companies are willing to pay more partly because they have more. In addition, they have access to capital at lower cost than American companies. Japanese companies can borrow at interest rates of 5 percent while the United States prime rate is above 10 percent.
Moreover, Japanese companies often have profit levels that would be considered unacceptably low by Wall Street. They are willing to spend more time and money developing a promising technology without an immediate payoff.
Dr. Weinig, who is with Materials Research in Orangeburg, N.Y., said his company, like many small semiconductor equipment companies, was having trouble raising the capital needed to keep pace with rapidly changing technology.
The main option appeared to be a buyout by a Wall Street investor group that would have paid $8 a share - less than the stock's book value - and would have changed management and laid off numerous workers, Dr. Weinig said. So he went to Sony and within a few days arranged a purchase for $14 a share.
Sony retained the existing management. And instead of layoffs, ''they gave everyone a Sony Walkman, a copy of Morita's book 'Made in Japan' and an extra week's pay,'' said Dr. Weinig, referring to Sony's chairman, Akio Morita. ''They said to me, 'You have essentially unlimited capital.' I'm no longer concerned with quarterly profits. I can think of projects that take two years. It's a wonderful way to live.''

HEADLINE: Turks Fear Changes Undercut Ties to Europe

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Eastern Europe's shifting political map has left Turkey wondering from the sidelines whether it will end up a diplomatic loser when the dust settles.
In Ankara, senior officials applaud the recent developments and say they want to encourage further democratic change with offers of aid and credit to Poland and Hungary. But some Turkish political leaders and newspaper commentators express concern that the upheaval in Eastern Europe could come at their country's expense, especially if the change undercuts a two-year-old application for full membership in the European Community.
Eventual community membership is a cornerstone of Turkey's foreign policy, and a trump card has been the country's strategic importance as the largest armed force in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after the United States. 
But questions have been raised about what might happen if NATO and the Warsaw Pact began seriously to rethink their military alignments. As the skeptics see it, any change that might appear to dilute Turkey's importance as a southern bulwark of the Atlantic alliance could also undermine its campaign for community membership.
''Those countries who have some commitments vis-a-vis Turkey may reconsider those commitments,'' Suleyman Demirel, head of the conservative True Path Party, was quoted as saying this week in the Turkish press.
Bulent Ecevit, head of the Democratic Left Party and like Mr. Demirel a former Prime Minister, cautioned recently that ''Turkey's strategic importance has been declining in view of developments taking place between the East and the West.'' Government claims to the contrary, Mr. Ecevit said, are ''self-deceiving.''
Government officials do indeed take a different view, insisting that there is no link between Eastern's Europe's turmoil and Turkey's application to the 12-member community.
NATO is not about to go out of business tomorrow, they say. The Government asserts that Turkey's 800,000-member armed forces are internationally important not only because they defend a third of NATO's borders with the Warsaw Pact but because they patrol frontiers with Iran, Iraq and Syria. The Middle East will remain a sensitive region even after Europe sorts itself out, they say.
''Our geographical importance will not change,'' a Foreign Ministry official said.
Nevertheless, some Turkish officials worry that Western Europe may find the notion of ultimate integration with the East too powerful to resist, and may decide to leapfrog it ahead of Turkey on its agenda. In telephone interviews from Ankara, several officials described the situation in Europe as volatile. ''We want the process to be gradual,'' said Murat Sungar, a Foreign Ministry spokesman.
 
Poverty and Other Handicaps
Even without the added complication of Eastern Europe, Turkey's application to the European Community faces severe scrutiny. The country is relatively poor, its economy has faltered under an inflation rate of 75 percent, its human-rights record is widely criticized and its population of 55 million Muslims leaves many Europeans in doubt about the prospects for bridging cultural differences.
Turkish officials should get a better sense of their standing when they receive a major report, expected later this month, from the community's executive commission. For now, their main hope seems to be that the European Community will agree at least to begin negotiations before its scheduled economic integration at the end of 1992.
Among the events favoring Turkey are recent changes in Bulgaria, its neighbor and rival, where the longtime Communist leader, Todor I. Zhivkov, was ousted last month. Under Mr. Zhivkov, Bulgaria conducted a harsh campaign of forcibly assimilating ethnic Turks, which prompted an exodus of 310,000 people to Turkey last summer.
It is too early to tell if Bulgarian policy will change, Turks say. But a Foreign Minister official said, ''It is natural for a new government to reassess the previous government's mistakes.''

LENGTH: 647 words

HEADLINE: China Trip Seeks to Alter Americans' Perceptions

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Behind the decision to send President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, on a mission to Beijing was a desire by the Administration to get Congress and the public used to the idea of restoring normal diplomatic contacts with China.
An official said today that the Administration would like to treat the events in Beijing in June, in which hundreds were killed when the Government crushed the student-led democracy movement, as an unfortunate affair -which, while regrettable, should not be allowed to overshadow the strategic importance of Chinese-American relations.
Mr. Scowcroft's visit was formally a mission to brief the Chinese on the Malta summit meeting.
In announcing his trip, along with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the White House emphasized that the trip was a realistic effort to improve a troubled situation. 
''The President views China as an important country in world affairs,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. ''While he deplores the tragedy of Tiananmen Square last June, China, nevertheless, remains part of the world around us.''
''The President has concluded that it is appropriate and in the long-term interest of the United States to inform the Chinese leadership of his discussions with the Soviet leader,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
 
Don't 'Focus on the Past'
''This trip was meant to break some of the ice between us,'' thr Administration official said of the China trip. ''By sending a top White House official, it sends a political signal that we are now ready to resume relations on a more normal basis. We hope that we have reached the point where time heals all wounds, and that once the public gets used to more normalized contacts it won't be focused on the past.''
Administration aides said that the trip was kept secret at Beijing's request, apparently because the Chinese wanted to make certain that it appeared the Americans were coming to them on Chinese terms and not the other way around. The visit was announced by the White House at 2 A.M. today, after Mr. Scowcroft and Mr. Eagleburger landed in the Chinese capital.
Administration officials denied that the White House was trying to avoid criticism at home by making the early-morning announcement. They also said that despite speculation that Mr. Bush might travel to Australia and other Pacific countries next year, this diplomatic visit was not a prelude to a visit to China by Mr. Bush.
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on East Asia and the Pacific, called the trip ''a mistake'' and ''inappropriate'' in light of what he called China's continuing violations of human rights.
 
Bad Timing, Too
''This is a signal to the Chinese that the Administration is desperate to get back to business as usual without any improvement in human rights in the People's Republic of China,'' Mr. Solarz said. ''It is another example of the Administration kowtowing to the Chinese.
''The paradox is that this is happening precisely when the Soviet threat is diminishing and the strategic imperative of a close relationship with the Chinese is thus declining. ''This makes neither good moral nor strategic sense.''
The trip by Mr. Scowcroft to Beijing was only the latest example of President Bush's desire not to allow the June killings to create any kind of lasting strain in relations.
From the beginning of Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, the President and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have used restrained language to condemn the Chinese and have imposed the minimum sanctions they felt were politically acceptable at home. These included limited economic curbs, a ban on arms sales and on high-level military and diplomatic exchanges, and a decision to allow Chinese students in this country to extend their visas.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
U.S. Ties With West Germany Begin To Eclipse Relationship With Britain

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
While no one in the Administration will say so, it has become clear in recent months that the longtime ''special relationship'' between the United States and Britain is being overshadowed by an increasingly demanding relationship between Washington and Bonn.
It is not that Washington is downgrading ties with London, Administration officials say. It is simply bowing to the fact that at this moment in history Germany is Washington's main concern in Europe. From Washington's perspective, no issue has more potential to destabilize Europe today than unification of the two Germanys, and no single country has more economic resources to help stabilize Eastern Europe today than West Germany.
The development has begun to cause a bit of consternation in London, fanned by the Fleet Street press - concern that forced President Bush to make an early-morning phone call last week to reassure Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that the special relationship was still special. In addition, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d hastily added London to his trip to Europe next week, where his top priority is delivering a major policy address in West Berlin. 
The subtle shift in American attention from Britain toward West Germany is a result of a variety of factors, not all of which are strategic. Washington's affinity with London has always been based largely on history and culture as much as on shared interest.
The relationship with Bonn has been no less significant, but has always been rooted in the strategic realm, given the presence of more than 300,000 American troops on West German soil and West Germany's importance on the front lines of the East-West divide.
Mrs. Thatcher and former President Reagan ''tended to view themselves as fellow crusaders against Communism abroad and socialism at home,'' said Peter Riddell, the United States editor for the London-based Financial Times. Because they grew personally close -and were perceived to be close - Mrs. Thatcher had unusual access to President Reagan, and therefore unusual influence.
 
No Longer First Among Equals
While Mr. Bush has a cordial relationship with Mrs. Thatcher, he does not share her conservative ideological fervor or view her as first among equals as a source of advice.
Shortly after the Malta summit meeting was announced, the American Ambassador to Britain, Henry E. Catto Jr., suggested to some senior Administration officials that on his way home Mr. Bush stop in London to brief Mrs. Thatcher. No, one of the officials told Mr. Catto, if the President stopped off anywhere, it would be in Bonn, to chat with Chancellor Helmut Kohl. In the end, Mr. Bush stopped in Brussels and briefed all the NATO leaders together, but the night before he dined alone with one of them - Mr. Kohl.
In many ways the juggling of itineraries for Mr. Baker's trip, which begins Sunday night and will also include extensive consultations with all the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies in Brussels, illustrates the new challenges that he is facing as Secretary of State. As the threat from Moscow abates, Washington has had to devote more and more energy to making sure that the East-West cold war is not replaced by something of a West-West cold war.
But as events in Europe race ahead, Mr. Baker's preference for low-key, step-by-step diplomacy and coalition building are coming under pressure from allies seeking clear-cut, detailed American positions on issues from German unification to European integration - issues on which old friends like Bonn and London are divided.
''Baker is trying very hard to avoid juggling the two,'' an Administration official said of West Germany and Britain. ''The key is not to have to juggle. If you're juggling, you're in trouble.''
 
Washington Counting on Bonn
Mr. Baker and his aides, after two years running the Treasury Department, were already predisposed to viewing Bonn and West Germany's central bank as the real powerhouse in Europe.
But there are more structural factors at work as well. To begin with, as liberalization takes hold in Eastern Europe, West Germany, by dint of geography and resources, has become Washington's primary partner for managing change on the Eastern front. Washington is counting on Bonn, and in a way Bonn alone, to keep East Germany propped up economically and politically so any unification can come about in a smooth, gradual manner and as a result of free elections in the East. Washington has also ceded to Bonn the leading role in both coordinating and financing the Western alliance's aid program for Poland and Hungary.
Equally pressing is the fact that because the conditions under which any German unification might take place will have an enormous effect on how the United States remains in Europe -the brunt of American troops are based on West German soil - and on how well NATO holds together, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker have been obsessed with maintaining close consultations with Bonn to prevent any sudden lurch toward unification. Mr. Bush has been speaking with Mr. Kohl, or Mr. Baker with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, about once a week.
 
'A Reliable Ally'
''In a way, Britain is suffering now precisely because it is such a reliable ally,'' an Administration official said. ''Nobody is worried about Britain going neutral. There isn't any need for a lot of the constant consultations that we have with Bonn.''
It is not only that the United States needs Bonn now, but also that Bonn needs Washington more than ever. Of all West Germany's allies, the United States, because it is far away, is likely to be the one that is least opposed to German unification and best disposed to sell it around NATO.
To insure that any unified Germany is solidly anchored in the Western alliance, Mr. Bush has begun to promote tighter political integration of the European Economic Community. But this too has created a bit of tension with Mrs. Thatcher, who is less than enthusiastic about some aspects of the proposed European economic and political union as outlined by Jacques Delors, the head of the European Community's Executive Commission.
That plan calls for going beyond the creation of a single European free market in 1992 to establishing a single central bank and monetary union, a strong European Parliament and a ''social charter'' for the community that would standardize labor union rights, wages and welfare after 1992.
Administration officials say that when it comes to the European Community's economic policies, the United States is not going to ''pick sides,'' and would be the last country to tell Mrs. Thatcher that she must accept a social charter. But when it comes to closer political and security ties within the community, there is no question that Washington would like to see Mrs. Thatcher be more forthcoming.
''I think she should understand that she has a strategic interest in seeing the E.E.C., which is clearly going to be the core of the future Europe, promoting greater European political and security integration,'' a senior Administration official said. ''Instead of resisting that process, she should join it and shape it and not fear it. Back in the 60's when the British were arguing about whether to join the E.E.C., the proponents said the Americans won't take us seriously if we are just a small island off the Continent.''
That arguement was valid then, the official added, and it is still valid today.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Excerpts From Statement By European Community

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the statement today by the leaders of the European Community:
 
 Each day in Central and Eastern Europe, change is assering itself more strongly. Everywhere a powerful aspiration toward freedom, democracy, respect of human rights, prosperity, social justice and peace is being expressed. The people are clearly showing their will to take their own destiny in hand and to choose the path of their development. Such a profound and rapid development would not have been possible without the policy of openness and reform led by Mr. Gorbachev. 
Expressing the feelings of the people of the whole community, we are deeply gladdened by the changes taking place. These are historic events and no doubt the most important since the Second World War. The success of a strong and dynamic European Community, the vitality of the C.S.C.E. process and stability in the area of security, in which the United States and Canada participate, have contributed greatly to them.
These changes give reason to hope that the division in Europe can be overcome in accord with the aims of the Helsinki Final Act, which seeks, through a global and balanced approach and on the basis of a set of principles that retain their full value, to set up new relations between European countries whether in security, economic and technical cooperation, or the human dimension.
 
 
 
Strengthening Peace
 We seek the strengthening of the state of peace in Europe in which the German people will regain its unity through free self-determination. This process should take place peacefully and democratically, in full respect of the relevant agreements and treaties and of all the principles defined by the Helsinki Final Act, in a context of dialogue and East-West cooperation. It also has to be placed in the perspective of European integration. . . .
The European Council is convinced in the present circumstances that all must, more than ever, demonstrate their sense of responsibility. The changes and transitions that are necessary must not take place to the detriment of the stability of Europe but must contribute to strengthening it.
Far from wanting to derive unilateral advantages from the present situation, the community and its members need to give their support to the countries embarked on the road to democratic change. They deplore all the more so that in some countries this process is hindered.
The community and its member states are fully conscious of the common responsibility which devolves on them in this decisive phase in the history of Europe. They are prepared to develop with the U.S.S.R. and the other countries of Central and Eastern Europe, and with Yugoslavia, insofar as they are committed to this path, closer and more substantive relations based upon an intensification of political dialogue and increased cooperation in all areas.
 
 
 
Supporting Reforms
 The community has in particular decided to support the economic reforms undertaken in these countries by contributing - in collaboration with its Western partners - to the establishment of healthy and prosperous economies within the framework of appropriate structures.
The European Council has drawn up conclusions which illustrate this intention. For the future and in accordance with the developments taking place, the community is willing to implement still closer forms of cooperation with these countries.
At this time of profound and rapid change, the community is and must remain a point of reference and influence. It remains the cornerstone of a new European architecture and, in its will to openness, a mooring for a future European equilibrium. This equilibrium will be still better insured by a parallel development of the role of the Council of Europe, E.F.T.A. and the C.S.C.E. process.
Construction of the Community must therefore go forward: the building of European Union will permit the further development of a range of effective and harmonious relations with the other countries of Europe.

HEADLINE: New Turmoil Over Police in Houston

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
In the last six weeks, two Houston police officers have shot and killed motorists after traffic stops. Two other officers were found guilty in rape cases. One more was arrested for heroin possession, one was charged with coercing sex from a prostitute, one was reassigned amid charges of police harassment and two officers' houses were searched as part of a drug investigation.
The incidents have caused heated debate here. Some citizens charge that they show pockets of police corruption and racism, but officers describe them as symptoms of budget cutbacks and low morale.
In recent years the police force here has been widely described as a model of efficiency. It is headed by Lee P. Brown, who is being considered for the job of New York City Police Commissioner in the administration of Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, people close to the search committee said. 
''Currently Houston is seen as the leader, or one of the leaders, of progressive police departments in the country,'' said Mary Ann Wycoff, project director for the Police Foundation, a research organization in Washington. ''It's one of the most farsighted departments I know of.''
 
Incidents Eroding Confidence
But there is concern among officials in Houston that the recent events will tarnish that hard-won reputation. Anthony Hall, a Houston City Councilman, said: ''There has been significant improvement in the Police Department in recent years, but this shows there are still problems. I don't think it represents a crisis in the department as much as it has served to erode the confidence that has been carefully built up over the years.''
Less than a decade ago, the Houston Police Department was widely thought of as a wild, lawless group. Texas Monthly magazine ran a cover drawing depicting the department as a motorcycle gang. Among other things, a group of officers in 1977 beat a suspect and threw the handcuffed man into a bayou, where he drowned.
When Kathryn J. Whitmire was elected Mayor in 1981, she brought in Chief Brown, who is credited with soothing racial tensions and eliminating many undesirables.
Mr. Brown, who is black, increased black officers to 14.1 percent of the force from 8.5 percent and toughened the requirements, making two years of college mandatory. He created a neighborhood system, opening 19 storefront police posts around the city.
 
No Raise in Six Years
But the changes came at the same time that the oil bust put harsh economic constraints on the city. The Houston Police Department has not had a raise in six years, and salaries, which were among the five highest in the country, now rank 25th among the 31 largest police departments. Rookies start at $20,755 and earn $23,696 after a year.
Hiring was discontinued in 1986 and was not resumed until this year. A recent department study said the force needed nearly 1,000 more officers.
Salary and staffing were major issues in the fall mayoral campaign, with the police officers' union campaigning against Mrs. Whitmire, who was easily re-elected. ''It was demoralizing,'' Mark R. Clark, the president of the Houston Police Officers Association, said of the election results.
He uses the same word to describe the new incidents involving police officers.
On Oct. 31, Ida Lee Delaney, a 50-year-old black woman was fatally shot by Officer Alex Gonzales, who was off duty and was later found to be intoxicated. The police said Mr. Gonzales was wearing civilian clothes and driving a private car when he and two fellow officers tried to force Mrs. Delaney to the side of the road after she allegedly cut them off in traffic at 3 A.M. Mrs. Delaney fired shots at the pursuing car, pulled over eventually, then fired again, wounding Mr. Gonzales before he killed her.
On Nov. 15, Officer Scott Tschirhart, 27, killed Byron Gillum, a 24-year-old security guard he had stopped for speeding. Mr. Tschirhart told investigators that Mr. Gillum had reached for a gun on the front seat of car. Mr. Gillum was shot four times in back, once in the abdomen and once in the arm, the police said. It was the third time in six years that Mr. Tschirhart fatally shot someone. He was also disciplined for beating a handcuffed prisoner.
On Nov. 29, one of the leading critics of the department, the Rev. J. Don Boney, a Baptist minister, was arrested at midnight on a nine-year-old warrant for failing to pay child support. The arresting officer, Sgt. Don Harford, also arrested Mr. Boney last year on a heroin charge, but he was found not guilty. Arrests for nonpayment of child support are almost never made by the Police Department but are handled by the Harris County Sheriff's Department. Mr. Harford was reassigned by Chief Brown, who ordered an internal investigation.
On Dec. 5, Harold I. Burkett, a former officer, pleaded guilty to charges of rape, robbery and kidnapping. He was accused of locking a man in the trunk of a car in February, then abducting and raping the man's 19-year-old date. Mr. Burkett's lawyer has said his client was suffering a breakdown at the time. He has since left the force.
The two cases involving killings are still under internal investigation by the department.
A much-asked question in Houston lately is: ''Who is to blame?''
The public seems to blame the police. At a recent City Council meeting, 60 people spoke in the public comment period - three times the usual number - and described the officers as ''pill popping racists,'' ''terrorists,'' and ''assassins.''
The police, in turn, blame Mrs. Whitmire, noting that she had reduced the force and put a cap on salaries. ''It's hard to get perfection for $25,000 a year,'' Assistant Police Chief Thomas G. Koby said.
 
Mayor Blames Volume of Rules
Because of staff reductions, officers who should be in desk jobs are on the streets, some officers say. Mr. Tschirhart, for example, had been given desk work in 1985 after his second fatal shooting, but this year his desk job was eliminated.
The Mayor blames the system. There are too many state and union regulations on the discipline and dismissal process, she said in a telephone interview. ''I think the Chief needs more ability to fire people,'' she said. ''Right now he has to run a whole gamut of rules and regulations. His hands have been tied.''
Some, but not many, place the blame on Chief Brown. Mr. Clark, the union leader, said the Chief was not standing up for the majority of officers ''who are being given a black eye for the actions of a few,'' adding, ''The agenda he's most interested in is the Chief Brown promotion agenda.''
Some changes are being made, including the creation of an officers-at-risk program that would provide psychological help for officers accused of using excessive force. The Mayor backed formation of a citizens' review board, but the City Council blocked that idea.
Complicating the situation is the question of whether Chief Brown may leave Houston for New York. He did not return repeated telephone calls a reporter made to his office.
Mrs. Whitmire said she had spoken with Mr. Brown about the New York job and ''he told me he was interested in staying in Houston.''
''I believe that Lee Brown is the best police chief in the country,'' she said. ''I hope the Mayor of New York finds a good police chief - as long as he's not mine.''

Clark, president of the Houston Police Officers Association, called such incidents ''demoralizing.'' (NYT/F. Carter Smith)

HEADLINE: California Resumes Air War Against Invading Fruit Fly, Stirring Debate

BYLINE: By ALEXANDRA SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9

 BODY:
For the second time in this decade, California has undertaken vast aerial spraying of a pesticide over residential areas here in an effort to eradicate the Mediterranean fruit fly, fueling a renewed debate that pits protection of agriculture against environmental concerns.
Since a single fly was trapped near Dodger Stadium in August, helicopters have sprayed the pesticide malathion over 250 square miles of neighborhoods in Los Angeles County and Orange County.
The Mediterranean fruit fly is the most stubborn of several fruit flies that have threatened California crops in recent decades. An infestation of Oriental fruit flies was quickly supressed in 1974, as was a Mexican fruit fly invasion in 1984. 
As the work on the current infestation goes on, two questions arise: Is the pesticide dangerous to humans, and can the produce industry in California survive both the fly and the spraying?
 
State Produce Could Be Barred
State officials say they hope to eradicate the pest before it spreads to the San Joaquin Valley and threatens the $16.6 billion agricultural industry. The fly lays its eggs in 250 kinds of fruits and vegetables, rendering them unfit for sale. California's produce could be barred by other states and nations.
The spraying, which will cost about $12 million, has been challenged by residents and politicians.
''We still don't know if malathion is completely safe,'' said Richard Alatorre, a City Councilman whose district has been sprayed. ''We were told that DDT was safe, that Agent Orange and asbestos were safe, but the facts about malathion's long-term effects won't be known for another generation.''
A toxicologist, Brian P. Dolan, argued that even though malathion was a ''reasonably safe'' pesticide, it was still a toxic chemical that had not been fully studied and therefore should not be sprayed over dense urban populations until proven safe.
''Its toxicity still has not been well worked out, and now the E.P.A. is saying some of their research was flawed,'' said Dr. Dolan, a private internist in occupational medicine who is an expert on chemicals and how they affect humans. He has worked with California farm workers for the past ten years.
''My concerns are that with repeated sprayings, you increase exposure, which raises the risk of birth defects and cancer,'' he said. ''Nobody wants the Medfly to wipe out our economy, but there are still so many questions about the chemical being used.''
 
Officials Cite Small Doses
State agriculture officials insist that malathion does not hurt humans, especially not in the small doses used in aerial spraying. But people are advised to cover their cars with tarpaulins to protect the paint.
''This stuff has been around for 40 years and study after study has shown it doesn't harm people,'' said Gera Curry, a spokeswoman for the California Department of Food and Agriculture. ''Homeowners use it in their backyards. In Europe doctors apply it on the heads of children for head lice.''
In some areas, sterile Mediterranean fruit flies, bred in laboratories, are being released to breed with the invader; the mating will not take. But elsewhere a shortage of the sterile flies has caught officials off guard.
 
Spraying Goes On for Now
Until a new laboratory to breed sterile fruit flies is completed in Hawaii, California will rely on aerial spraying, Ms. Curry said. The pest is rife in Hawaii, but farmers escape extensive damage because the major commercial crops, pineapples and sugar cane, are immune to the fruit fly, Malathion was first used in California in 1981, after a year of debate in which the Governor, Edmund G. Brown Jr., delayed the spraying. That allowed a small infestation in Northern California to spread statewide. Farmers lost $100 million.
And the Governor's decision was believed to have been a factor in his losing a United States Senate race to Pete Wilson in 1982.
Since the 1981 sprayings, the Department of Health Services has conducted studies on the effects of malathion on humans, said Veda Federighi of the Department of Food and Agriculture. ''They concluded that malathion posed no adverse health effects to the public,'' she said, ''and we were dealing with a much larger area then.'' In 1981, about 1,400 square miles were sprayed.
 
Environmentalist Is Suspicious
Randall Toler, who heads the United States Green Party, an environmental group, said some studies indicated that the pesticide was harmful to humans.
''Studies in central Japan showed that malathion affected the liver enzymes and destroyed nervous responses in children and agricultural workers,'' said Mr. Toler. State officials argue that even if it was toxic, only one-third of an ounce of the pesticide is sprayed over an area of 60 by 100 feet.
Ms. Curry said, ''The dosage is the important thing and the amount we use is so small it's almost infinitesimal,'' adding, ''If you have a sick shrub in your backyard, you're going to use a lot more on that than we use on an entire city lot.''
Environmentalists say state officials did not give enough notice that neighborhoods would be sprayed.
''The officials know they can announce it and then spray a few days later and a community can't really get organized in that time to put out loud opposition,'' said David Bunn, a research director for Pesticide Watch. ''The state has learned that the faster they can reduce the notification time, the less likely people will protest.''
In an odd twist, Mayor Tom Bradley, agricultural officials and the press recently received a letter from a group called ''Breeders'' taking responsibility for the spread of the fruit fly and condemning the spraying.
The letter - officials say it may be a hoax - threatened to continue breeding and spreading Mediterranean fruit flies until the spraying becomes ''politically and financially intolerable.''

HEADLINE: Boston's Black Areas Mount New Secession Drive

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Roxbury section of Boston is a mix of red brick town houses, high-rise public housing projects and weed-covered lots. To the north stand the glittering skyscrapers of the downtown financial district; to the west, comparatively well-to-do suburbs like Brookline and Newton.
But Roxbury is a neighborhood besieged with problems like high unemployment, a high school-dropout rate, drug trafficking and almost nightly shootings. Forty-seven murders have been reported this year in the police district that includes Roxbury. That is more than twice the number of any other district in the city. 
Many residents say they fear that an influx of more affluent home buyers, already nibbling at the best housing stock, will force them out if they survive the neighborhood's other afflictions.
But under a plan being promoted with renewed vigor, Roxbury and three other predominantly black areas - Dorchester, Mattapan, and part of the South End - would be joined to form a separate city of 12 1/2 square miles with about 125,000 residents.
Supporters of the plan argue that it is not simply a matter of money, though they also say these neighborhoods have long been on the short end of every stick. More important, they say, is the power residents think they would have if the plan became reality.
 
Voters Rejected Plan Twice
''We used to think integration was the antidote,'' said Andrew P. Jones, a film producer and classical violinist who is a principal organizer of the plan. ''Now we think incorporation is the antidote. We would get what we need to exist as a viable community, not as a ghetto that's coming apart at the seams.''
The plan was placed on local ballots in 1986 and again last year. Both times it was defeated, though the margin of opposition narrowed from 3 to 1 to less than 2 to 1 last year.
Now organizers like Mr. Jones want the Legislature to approve a question for the voters next year that would authorize a commission to study the pros and cons of turning the neighborhoods into an independent city or town. Any charter produced by the commission would be voted on by residents whom it would affect. That would be almost a quarter of Boston's population of 600,000, including more than 90 percent of its black residents.
 
But Mayor Flynn Is Opposed
The concept has not met with universal approval. ''I don't think it's a good idea,'' said Bruce C. Bolling, a City Councilman whose district includes Roxbury. ''The overwhelming majority of the residents in the affected community do not want to create a separate municipality. However, there is concern about the overall direction of the community and what needs to be done to strengthen it.''
Mayor Raymond L. Flynn has opposed the idea every time it has come up, arguing that it would reverse important recent gains by blacks since the years of racial turmoil in the mid-1970's over court-ordered busing to end school desegregation. Many people here also say the plan would be a financial disaster for the new municipality itself; the area is largely residential, with a small tax base. Perhaps, the plan's supporters say. ''One of the problems has been the availability of information,'' said State Representative Byron Rushing, a Democrat whose district includes part of what would be the new city.
 
Money Records Called 'Key'
''This commission would have subpoena power and could obtain municipal records to see how much money is received and how much is actually spent on this area,'' said Mr. Rushing, who has filed a bill calling for the creation of the charter commission. ''That is key.''
Residents of Roxbury and other predominantly black neighborhoods have long suspected that more money is allocated for their neighborhoods than they actually see, Mr. Rushing said. But he said the desire to break off from the city should not be considered a criticism of the Mayor.
''It's criticism of a lot of mayors,'' he said. ''It's a criticism of the disenfranchisement and powerlessness of this community. You can't say the state of municipal services in Roxbury can be blamed on one administration. It's blamed on a series of administrations that did not have this community as its priority.''
Mary Hill, who lives and works in the Mandela Apartments, a subsidized housing complex in Roxbury, said she thought the plan would mean better times for her neighborhood. ''We'd have cleaner streets and get things that we don't get now,'' she said.
The latest strategy is expected to take at least four years to work its way through the system. Mr. Jones is confident. ''With persistence, people start to trust you,'' he said. ''Nothing tells the truth like time.''
