HEADLINE: The Baby Bells Scramble for Europe

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The Baby Bells, long seen simply as providers of local phone service, have ambitions to go global. Last week, U. S. West Inc. reached agreements to lay the world's longest fiber-optic cable across the Soviet Union and build a cellular phone system in Hungary, a first for Eastern Europe. A consortium including the Pacific Telesis Group won a multibillion dollar contract for the first private cellular system in West Germany, beating out bids from five other regional Bell companies.
In fact, these new ventures are only the latest evidence of the Baby Bells' efforts to become international giants. Frustrated by restrictions in the United States that keep them out of many businesses and limit their rates of return on local service, they are scouring the world for new opportunities. And Europe presents the brightest prospects. As 1992 approaches and the European Community's trade barriers begin to fall, the telecommunications market is becoming bigger, more competitive and freer from government control. And American companies are finding that Europe's progress increases their potential, too. ''We are simply recognizing that the opportunities for growth are greater outside the United States than within,'' said Eugene Sekulow, president of the Nynex International Company. ''Our primary business is still here within our region, but the marketplace is increasingly becoming a global one and Europe is where we see the most potential.' 
Calling the seven regional companies babies belies their huge bulk, ranging from $9 billion to $14 billion in annual revenues. So far, foreign operations make up only a small fraction of their business - less than 5 percent for Pacific Telesis, one of the most aggressive venturers abroad. But executives at most of the Bell companies believe their European revenues will grow much larger.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has long had a sprawling worldwide network. A.T.&T.'s long-distance rivals, the MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Company, also have extended their networks abroad. When A.T.&T. spun off the regional bell companies six years ago, they had only their local telephone operations.
But the Baby Bells are local no longer. Their incentive to branch out to Europe is great. Industry analysts estimate that the European market for mobile communications, including cellular telephones and paging beepers, could reach $9.7 billion by 1992. The demand for telecommunications services like stock quotes, electronic banking and travel reservations has a potential of $8.6 billion by 1992, and the market for networks that transmit computer data, $1.3 billion.
Most of the Baby Bells have approached Europe boldly, plunging into areas like cable television, computer services and fiber-optic cable. But one has remained cautious. The Ameritech Corporation believes that serving the Middle West carries far fewer risks than trying to span the globe. ''There are very high risks to understanding the marketplace, the cultural aspects and the strategic competitors,'' Gerald Mallik, president of Ameritech's foreign division, said.
The other Baby Bells, already earning close to their allowed returns from local telephone operations, are convinced that profits from unregulated businesses both domestic and international are crucial to future growth. In the United States, the Baby Bells have expanded into cellular telephone and paging services, computer maintenance, financial services, real estate and office equipment. But Government restrictions have prevented them from entering the businesses that they covet the most: telephone equipment manufacturing, long distance, electronic information services and cable television.
So the regional companies are targeting telephone markets across the Atlantic. For decades, European governments kept foreign companies from competing with domestic telephone monopolies. The huge privatization of British Telecom in 1983 and the progress of economic unification since then have produced a revolution in the telephone industry. Nations seeking the best, most advanced products and services, at the cheapest prices, are opening their telecommunications markets to competition.
''These countries are recognizing that they need state-of-the-art telecommunications to be economically competitive. They want to modernize quickly and many don't really care who does it,'' Charles W. Schelke, an analyst with Smith Barney said. ''The good news is that the United States has a knowledge advantage when it comes to telephone technology and services.''
The most fertile ground is in Britain, France and West Germany, which have allowed foreign companies to compete for licenses to provide cellular telephone service, beeping pagers and cable television. Other countries, especially those in Eastern Europe, are expected to follow suit.
European cable television licenses represent a prime opportunity for the Baby Bells to acquire franchises in high-income regions at much lower prices than they would cost at home, if that were allowed. Since most of the cable franchises are likely to be awarded city by city (unlike cellular franchises, which in Europe are national), the regional Bells have more opportunities to acquire licenses. The Southwestern Bell Corporation, for example, is helping to build new cable systems in the Liverpool region of England.
Investing in foreign cable systems allows the regional companies to gain experience in combining cable and telephone services. The cable contracts in Britain allow companies to provide telephone and television services over the same networks. And the Baby Bells plan to install fiber-optic cable, which can carry both telephone and video signals, in some European homes.
Regional Bell executives stress that their cable innovations are only one of the technologies they are trying out in Europe that they are forbidden from introducing in the United States. Many Bell companies plan to offer information services in Europe that they are restricted from offering at home. Although the United States has the world's most advanced telecommunications service today, they say, Europe could soon leap ahead. ''The United States does run the risk of losing some of our capability to other countries if we are kept out of these markets,'' said Edgar Brown Jr., president of Bell Atlantic International-Europe.
The Baby Bells also see a wealth of business opportunities in the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries like East Germany, Hungary, and Poland, where dramatic political and economic reforms are being introduced. The companies want to participate in the overhaul of their antiquated telephone systems in exchange for sharing in the operation of, and the profits from, the new telephone networks.
Despite the unprecedented liberalization of Europe's telecommunications markets, many barriers remain. Europe continues to have local telephone monopolies that are traditionally owned by the governments, providing them with strong revenues. Few countries allow private companies to provide plain voice telephone services, as the Bells provide in the United States. Eastern Europe presents the additional problem of repatriating profits where currencies are not convertible.
The Baby Bells' success throughout Europe will depend on how well they manage a complicated web of joint ventures and partnerships with foreign companies. Strategic alliances are the standard mode of operating overseas. The regional companies need the infrastructure, marketing, distribution and regulatory clout of their foreign partners as much as the partners need the Baby Bells' technical expertise.
''Managing joint ventures from across the ocean is a difficult task because the partners all have different objectives and functions, there are cultural and language barriers and the physical separation,'' said David Wenner, a senior partner and consultant at McKinsey & Company. Half of all the joint ventures American companies form abroad eventually fall apart, he said, adding, ''I am not saying it's impossible, but it takes close communications and understanding.'' The American telephone company wants to increase shareholder value; the European government wants an infusion of new technology and competition to benefit consumers; and European companies want to secure their roles in changing markets, he explained.
Pactel won the German cellular license only by conducting delicate negotiations with the Government and affiliating with a plethora of German companies. It will be a tough enterprise to manage, said C. Lee Cox, a Pactel group vice president, ''but the rewards are well worth it.''
 
PACIFIC TELESIS
 
A Triumph in West Germany
 A consortium including Pacific Telesis brought home one of Europe's biggest prizes last week: a license to build the first private cellular telephone system in West Germany. The group plans to build a digital system to compete with the overloaded, outdated network run by the Bundespost, the national telephone and mail company. Analysts say the contract - in a prosperous, densely populated market ideal for cellular services - could be worth about $6 billion in revenues over 20 years. No wonder that five of the other six regional Bell companies also bid. The Pacific Telesis team is headed by Mannesmann A.G., a West German engineering and steel company.
Pacific Telesis, serving California and Nevada with headquarters in San Francisco, has been one of the most aggressive Baby Bells overseas. Besides cellular, the company has invested heavily in wireless communications, cable television and information services.
In Britain, Pacific Telesis has acquired interests in three cable television companies - East London Telecommunications Ltd., Peterborough Cablevision and Norwich Cablevision - that together cover regions of 750,000 homes. They plan to test a new telephone service to businesses and homes over their cable television lines.
As part of a consortium that includes British Aerospace, Pacific Telesis is competing for a license from the British Government to build a personal communications network. Personal communications is an innovative technology that would use radio waves to provide wireless, digital telephone and information services.
Pactel also is looking at wireless telephone opportunities - cellular, paging services or personal communications - that may arise as Spain, Italy, and West Germany open their telecommunications industries to competition.
In Asia, Pactel is part owner of a Japanese national long-distance company and has received permission from Judge Harold H. Greene, who presided over the breakup of A.T.&T., to take part in laying a fiber-optic link between the United States and Japan. In Bangkok, the company has a beeper paging service with 40,000 customers, and in South Korea, a credit-card verification business.
 
 
 
NYNEX
 
Bringing High-Tech to Gibraltar
 Nynex, which serves New York and New England, boasts of its overseas expansion as a way to improve service for its increasingly multinational business customers. ''We are forming strategic relationships with telephone service providers in other countries to insure that the services we offer in the states are available in Europe as well,'' said Eugene Sekulow, president of Nynex's international subsidiary.
In practice, Nynex's goals appear as varied as its services and locales. It has offices in Hong Kong, Singapore, Geneva, Frankfurt, and London. Having acquired 50 percent of the Gibraltar Telephone Company, it plans to revamp the tiny British colony's antiquated system. Today, Gibraltar struggles along with a scratchy, distortion-prone network like the one the United States abandoned decades ago. Nynex intends to make the country a high-tech showplace, with fiber optics and other digital technologies, video teleconferencing and high-speed facsimile services. The company is convinced that Gibraltar, whose spot at the entrance to the Mediterranean Sea is making it a growing center for international commerce and trade, will require vastly improved telecommunications.
In London, Nynex is a member of the Phonepoint consortium that introduced telepoint service in London this summer. Telepoint is known as ''the poor man's'' cellular telephone because of its low price and lack of ability to receive incoming calls. Useful only in concentrated areas, it allows subscribers to make calls within 100 meters of special antennas.
Among other Nynex ventures in Europe:
* An agreement with Scandinavian Telecommunications Services to supply business telephone features like high-speed data and facsimile transmission between Scandinavia and the United States.
* Consulting contracts to provide telephone network management for British Telecom and France Telecom.
* A deal to supply computer software to the British financial services industry.
* An effort, under negotiation, to improve on primitive telephone service in Poland and Hungary.
 

 
BELL SOUTH
 
Another ATlanta Multinational
 BellSouth seems bent on building an international network to rival the reach of its Atlanta neighbor, the Coca-Cola Company. BellSouth has more than 2,000 employees in other countries, with a variety of joint ventures and acquisitions. Most of these operations are in Europe and Latin America.
BellSouth's European interests include 4 percent of Compagnie Financier Pour Le Radio Telephone, or Cofira, a French company that won a contract last year to provide France with cellular telephone service. In Great Britain, BellSouth joined with Phillips N. V. and General Electric of Britain to compete for a license to provide personal communications services.
Beyond Europe, BellSouth owns 30 percent of Argentina's cellular phone system that went into service last month. In Australia, BellSouth is the majority owner of Link Telecommunications, the nation's largest private paging and telephone answering company. It is negotiating to provide cellular phone service, yellow pages, and telephone network operations and equipment in China, and it has a joint venture to supply India's public telephone company with computer software.
 

 
AMERITECH
 
Careful,Cautiousand Slow
 More than any other Baby Bell, American Information Technologies Inc., or Ameritech, has been cautious about venturing abroad. Gerald Mallik, president of Ameritech's business development unit, is much quicker to discuss the obstacles and risks than the opportunities. Most foreign telephone companies are government owned and subsidized, making them formidable competitors, he said. Many countries limit foreign ownership in telecommunications concerns or require partnerships with local firms - policies that limit the returns to foreign investors. ''Generally, there is a lot of money out there chasing a limited number of opportunities,'' Mr. Mallik said.
Mr. Mallik said Ameritech, based in Chicago, would rather concentrate on serving the Great Lakes region, with high returns but few rate increases, than spanning the globe. ''But this strategy should not lead one to believe that we have no interest in the international market. We are very interested, it's just that these activities are new to us and we need to develop skill and expertise in this area,'' Mr. Mallik said.
Most of the company's foreign investments have been only token ones. It joined Bell Atlantic and MAN A.G., a major West German industrial equipment firm, to compete for the West German cellular license. It has acquired small interests in a British voice messaging company and in a Japanese publishing concern owned by the Nippon Telephone and Telegraph Company.
 

 
SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORPORATION
 
Cable TV and Phones for Great Britain
 Southwestern Bell, based in St. Louis, has moved aggressively into the cable television market in Britain. The company has taken an equity stake in the Oyston Cable Communications Group, which is building two new cable systems, in the Liverpool and Preston areas of northwest England, to serve as many as 230,000 homes and businesses. Initially, the systems will offer data transmission services for businesses, bypassing local telephone networks. Longer term, the cable systems are expected to offer far more entertainment and telecommunications options, including banking, shopping, information services and video selection features that will have the effect of giving each viewer many of the choices of a video store.
Southwestern also has purchased an interest in an Israeli cable company, Golden Channels Ltd., that serves Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. ''We believe that cable television is a very natural fit with our expertise in network design, engineering, maintenance, service and billing,'' said Robert H. Glaser, Southwestern's senior vice president for strategic planning. ''An added plus is that there are no barriers to entry like in the United States, and we can offer both television and what we know best, telephone services.''
Southwestern Bell has also invaded the British market with its Freedom Phone division, a leading distributor of public pay phones, feature phones, and cordless phones manufacturered by several suppliers.
Southwestern, too, formed a consortium to bid on the West German cellular franchise. The company continues to hunt for other cellular and paging service opportunities abroad, as well as contracts for networks to process business transactions between suppliers and customers.
Southwestern Bell's domestic service area stretches from Arkansas through Texas and into Missouri.
 

 
BELL ATLANTIC
 
Going into the German Nations
 Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia and serving much of the Eastern seaboard, has targeted the affluent German-speaking markets - West Germany, Austria and Switzerland - with an array of high-tech products and services. .
The company opened an office in Dusseldorf, West Germany, in September to develop new businesses including telcommunications consulting, some innovative services that integrate computers and telephones, and computer software systems for telephone networks. In Munich, Bell Atlantic has a computer sales, leasing and maintenance company. It also bid for the West German cellular license as part of a consortium that included Ameritech.
In 1987, Bell Atlantic acquired the European divisions of Sorbus, a computer maintenance and data communications company, from Bell Canada International. Sorbus has operations in Britain, France, Germany, Switzerland, Austria and Italy.
Bell Atlantic also provides software systems for telephone companies in Italy and Spain and it is scouting out wireless telephone opportunities throughout Europe.
 

 
US WEST
 
U S West Becomes Europe East
 U S West, based in Denver, is leading the Bell companies into Eastern Europe. Just in the past week, U S West signed a deal with Hungary to build Eastern Europe's first cellular system. Then came word that U S West had agreed to lead seven foreign companies and a Soviet ministry in the laying of a fiber-optic cable across the Soviet Union. The 12,000-mile line - the longest fiber-optic cable in the world - would improve long-distance service in the Soviet Union and connect Europe with Japan. ''It would be the missing link in what is becoming a global fiber network,'' Reynie Ortiz, president of U S West International, said. Both projects require the approval of the 16-nation Coordinating Committee for Strategic Exports, which limits the transfer of Western technology to the Eastern bloc. But the Bush Administration has considered trying to loosen some restrictions.
In Western Europe, U S West has invested heavily in cable television. The company has interests in seven cable television franchises in the Birmingham and South London areas of Great Britain, and owns part of Lyonnaise Communications, with cable networks in 13 areas of France, including Paris. U S West also is seeking to provide a personal communications network in Britain. In Asia, it belongs to a consortium that is building a cable network in Hong Kong.
Not every European project attracts U S West. It was the only regional Bell company that did not bid for the West German cellular franchise. Mr. Ortiz cited stiff competition and the high cost of preparing a bid. ''We are mainly interested in opportunities that show a lot of promise but have limited competition,'' he said. Analysts also mention U S West's disappointment last year at losing the French cellular contract to a consortium that included BellSouth.
U S West's network covers a large range - about 45 percent - of the mainland United States, from Washington east to Minnesota and south to New Mexico and Arizona. Analysts said the company's experience in stringing cable across frigid mountain ranges, barren deserts and vast plains helped clinch a deal in the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Light Is Trendy for China's Beer

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: QINGDAO, China

 BODY:
At the Qingdao Brewery, the vice director, Zhang Jianhua, held up a glass of Tsingtao beer and downed it with a smile.
''Americans have a misunderstanding that you get fat from beer,'' said the thin executive, back from a marketing trip to the United States. ''You can't get fat just from drinking beer. There is no fat in beer.'' 
He and two other scrawny colleagues say they are living proof that drinking a great deal of their comparatively heavy beer does not automatically bring an extra layer of flesh. Every evening the directors gather to taste the day's beer, and that usually means drinking at least two big bottles.
But for all the talk of beer not being fattening, the brewery, which has sold beer in the United States since 1973 and now supplies about 90 percent of the Chinese beer sold there, is hard at work on a new product - light beer.
Tsingtao's importer, the New York-based Monarch Import Company, says the lighter product probably will not be sold in the United States until late 1990 at the earliest, after it has been marketed in China and test-marketed in the United States. ''If you don't have a light beer, you forfeit a big chunk of potential business,'' said Michael J. Mazzoni, general manager of Monarch.
The move toward light beer seems to be a savvy one by one of the most savvy companies in China. Tsingtao has already redesigned its packaging and downsized its bottles to please the American market. Many of its top officials have traveled overseas, and at least one has studied beer-making in West Germany.
In the extraordinarily competitive imported beer market in the United States, it would be difficult, under the best of circumstances, for Tsingtao to significantly expand its sales. But the situation is complicated by obstacles facing Chinese manufacturers - a domestic credit crunch; a government that confiscates profits; a work force that is unused to international standards and often sees little incentive in diligence, and a relative lack of experience with foreign markets.
And, like other state enterprises in China, the brewery is struggling with an austerity program dictated by the central Government. China is now in the second year of a vigorously promoted three-year retrenchment, and a renewed emphasis on boosting exports makes American consumers a particularly important source of foreign exchange earnings for a company like Qingdao.
In addition, there is lingering international outrage at the repression of the democracy movement last June, although there is no formal boycott of Chinese products by American consumers.
The company does not admit to difficulties, however. Plant tours for visitors are confined to a sparklingly clean bottling production line set up with machinery imported from Germany, and extracting information is very difficult. It says only that its exports in general will show little growth this year.
Qingdao executives, like those at other Chinese companies, are unwilling to say much about anything. During a recent interview, officials sat sipping tea and beer and reciting statistics without notes, but they gave little hint of the company's aims or dilemmas.
The company says it has not been deprived of raw materials, although it admits it has had to pay higher prices. Executives say that sometimes their raw materials, like barley, are in short supply, and that they face stiff competition for the materials from collective and private enterprises that are sometimes willing to bid high prices. While they are granted a portion under quota at the low fixed price, they do not always get it, because the local or even national supply is short. This forces the brewery to buy raw materials at higher prices in the market or to use its precious foreign exchange on the international market.
Regardless of its export performance, companies like Qingdao are assuming greater prominence in China these days because the Government is trying to restructure the economy so that growth is driven by the state sector. For the last decade, China's economy has surged forward at an annual rate of about 10 percent, and in recent years, the greatest expansion has taken place in a sector composed of small and medium-sized collectives and even private enterprises, something that makes the Government uncomfortable.
The company voices support for the program, but it admits that the tightening of credit has created cash shortages. Loans, it says, have been ''limited'' - the company declined to say by how much - and payments for beer deliveries have slowed from local buyers also short of cash.
Nonetheless, the company expects to increase its pre-tax profits this year to the equivalent of $16.2 million, or about 22 percent more than the 1988 figure. The company also says it expects production to rise by only 3,000 tons this year, or less than 3 percent.
Since Qingdao is a state-run company, about half of its profits this year will be turned over to the state, a larger proportion than last year, leaving the company with the equivalent of $8.1 million, an increase of only 11 percent in after-tax profits over last year's figure. Typically, the better a company does, the larger the share confiscated by the state. As with most state enterprises, a large chunk of the brewery's profits is spent on bonuses for workers and other kinds of employee welfare, like housing.
Since the brewery's exports earn foreign exchange, most of which it turns over to the state for local money, it receives Government subsidies that sometimes come in the form of tax breaks. While Qingdao is extremely keen on exporting, its profit margin on exports is lower than on domestic sales because, it says, the market is so competitive and the costs are high.
The company exports about 60 percent of the beer it makes. The largest market is Hong Kong and Macao, followed by the United States with 10 percent of the company's overall production. Tsingtao beer is among the most visible Chinese consumer products sold there.
Imports of all Chinese beer to the United States this year through August have dropped 46 percent from 845,000 cases for the same period last year to 454,500 cases this year, according to statistics provided by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Volume for the month of July also dropped 77 percent over last year, while in May, the decrease was only 21 percent.
Monarch, Tsingtao's importer, says that high inventories and difficulties transporting the beer from China during the summer helped create the changes. It uses sales, rather than shipments of imports, to gauge Tsingtao's popularity. According to its statistics, sales of the beer in the United States have increased slightly from 1988 to an expected volume of 1.1 million cases in 1989.
In the United States, Chinese beer is sold mainly in Chinese restaurants of major cities, although it is distributed in many states. ''It's a curiosity beer that people might order because they're in a Chinese restaurant,'' said Allan Kaplan, a beverage industry analyst at Merrill Lynch. ''I don't think it's characterized as a high-quality brand beer that people must have because it's a fine beer.''

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN CHEMICALS;
PRODUCTIVITY IS UP COMMODITIES RELIANCE, DOWN

BYLINE: By Claudia H. Deutsch

 BODY:
In the late 1970's, chemical companies operated as though demand would never decline and prices would never stop rising. ''Everyone looked at the same tea leaves, predicted shortages and built at once,'' recalled William C. Kuhlke, vice president for polymers at Dewitt & Company, a Houston-based chemical industry consulting firm.
But when the bottom fell out of the world economy in the early 80's, demand slackened and a soaring dollar made exports even less attractive. The companies that had been selling everything they could process were suddenly not only selling as little as 65 percent of what they could make, but were forced to sell even that meager amount at prices that barely covered costs. 
The chemical industry learned a lesson - or so it seems. During the latest boom, plenty of new capacity has come on stream, but much of it was used to replace aging plants. ''Over the last several years, there's been greater growth in demand than in capacity,'' said William R. Young, a chemicals analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
But that could change. Several chemical companies both here and abroad have announced major new plants, which could lead to overcapacity in many commodities as early as 1992. In some products, like plastics, the industry is already selling all it makes. But in others, tight capacity is only temporary. For example, an explosion at a Phillips Petroleum Company plant in Texas in late October took off the market more than a billion pounds, or 19 percent of total industrywide capacity, of high-density polyethylene, which is used to make plastic bottles, stiff-plastic shopping bags and cable insulation.
But Phillips is expected to replace much of that capacity within six months, and several other companies have announced new plants. If prices continue to soften, those plants, along with several other commodity plants announced, may never be built.
Amoco, for one, has already postponed plans for a new olefins plant. ''There's been lots of talk about building more capacity for ethylene, polyethylene, ethylene oxide, and others, but you don't see many companies putting iron in the ground,'' said Mr. Zutty of Union Carbide.
Some of those plants may never have really been on the drawing boards. ''Often, companies will announce new plants as preemptive strikes to prevent others from building new capacity,'' said Patrick E. Baggett, an executive vice president of Chemical Market Associates Inc., a Houston consulting firm.
The companies most likely to build are those that need the output as raw materials themselves. For that reason, the Dow Chemical Company is almost certain to build new ethylene plants in Texas and in Canada. ''Even with the new plants, we will be net buyers of ethylene,'' said Enrique C. Falla, Dow's financial vice president.
And industry experts expect that the combination of new products and burgeoning global demand to quickly soak up any excess supply from other new plants. ''A simple thing like the conversion to plastic shopping bags or disposable diapers a few years ago made significant changes in demand that were hard to anticipate,'' Mr. Baggett said. ''This industry spends 5 percent of sales on research, so who knows what other products it will develop?'' Even so, the popularity of some of those products, like plastic shopping bags, can fade.
And who knows what countries will be the industry's major customers in the 90's? The United States will probably have a trade surplus in chemicals of close to $16 billion this year, and most economists expect the dollar to head downward again, helping exports even more.
Moreover, most American chemical companies have extensive manufacturing facilities overseas. ''Even if the U.S. goes into recession - and I don't think it will - the world economy is going to keep growing at about 3 percent a year,'' predicted Mr. Stuckey of DuPont. ''We're more concerned about whether this industry can meet the needs of the global economy than we are about temporary overcapacity.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of damage from an explosion in October 1989 at a Phillips Chemical plant in Houston. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: 1992 MEETS PERESTROIKA;
A New Europe Needs a New Currency

BYLINE: By FRANCOIS LAGRANGE; Francois LaGrange, an adviser to the the French Government, is vice chairman of Credit National in Paris.

 BODY:
The spectacular movement for democratization in Eastern Europe, with the highly symbolic collapse of the Berlin wall, will compel us as Europeans to seek a new order. German unification, a taboo subject until a few months ago, is becoming a realistic prospect. After Austria - a neutral country - it will soon be Hungary's turn to request associate status in the European Community.
The movement for democratization will not leave the Warsaw Pact unscathed. NATO will also have to evolve as the postwar Yalta order crumbles. A new European order is clearly on the agenda. 
In light of this, Europeans and people outside the region are asking if the goal of creating a single market, to be completed in 1992, will still be Europe's central program. The answer to this question must be a firm ''yes.'' In addition, the European Community must add to the single market program the economic and monetary union of its member countries. In this way, Europe will have the strength to deal with the rapid changes in the world.
It is commonly acknowledged that by launching the 1992 single-market project, Europe has gained new momentum. But however important this new momentum may be, the significance of the 1992 single market should not be overstated. That is because the individual countries of Europe remain autonomous and independent when it comes to control over economic and financial matters. The result is a conflict between growing economic integration on the one hand and fragmented political decision-making power on the other. This disparity between national and shared control cripples Europe's abilty to deal with the challenges of a globalizing world economy and a newly democratic Eastern Europe.
If Europe is firm in its goal of developing genuine economic and financial unity, it can only take place within the framework of a single currency. In the 19th century, the economic unification of Germany and of Italy was only realized after each of these countries created its own central bank. These central banks were then able to issue the German reichmark and the Italian lira, which were necessary in order to unify commerce within these countries. In the United States, the dollar is what made it a single market.
Today, with the purely national currencies circulating within the European Community member states, intra- and extra-Community trade is treated in an identical manner with respect to each country's trade balance and exchange accounts. Merchandise or services traded between Belgium and France - or France and Germany - have the same economic and financial significance as trade between France and Japan or the United States which are not community members. This means that trade still takes place in Europe as if the European Community did not exist. Every E.C. member country has to balance its accounts with the E.C. and the world.
This archaic and absurd situation handicaps all member countries and reduces their potential for economic growth. The United States does not have to take into account the balance of trade or different exchange rates between Texas and California or Michigan and Florida in its internal accounting. Europe should not have to either.
The advantages of a single European currency are clear: the disappearance of exchange operations between the economies of the 12 countries. Interest rates would be harmonized within the E.C. In addition, the European Currency Unit, the monetary unit of the single European market, would wield considerable economic weight and take its place alongside the dollar and the yen in managing the world monetary system.
Monetary integration would create a truly unified economic region, overseen by a European central bank system, somewhat analogous to the Federal Reserve. This would call for an economic union of closely coordinated budgetary, fiscal, monetary and even - to a certain degree - incomes policies.
Only a more integrated European Community - based upon a genuine economic and monetary union - will have the economic strength and united political perspective to welcome the democratizing Eastern European countries into its fold. Only an economically united Europe -leading possibly even to a confederation of European states - will have the strength to solve the problem of the reunification of Germany.
Since the days of the Marshall Plan, The United States has been a staunch supporter of the idea of a single, united Europe. The United States should continue to pursue this goal. A strong, united Europe will be a reliable partner for the United States in the quest for a new world order - an order in which both NATO and the Warsaw Pact undergo dramatic change.

HEADLINE: Perestroika Ole

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Nathan P. Gardels fails to support his assertion that Mexico's reform program amounts to selling off the ''national patrimony'' (''Perestroika Goes South,'' Nov. 12). Unfortunately, the move toward privatization is not nearly as extensive as he depicts it.
Mr. Gardels boasts that the number of state-owned enterprises have been reduced by 75 percent without noting that the reduction represents only 10 to 15 percent of the value of the state's assets, according to a study by the Mexican Treasury. 
Mr. Gardels marvels that only the railroads, electric power plants and extraction and trade of oil and uranium remain as the core of nationalization. But these industries - along with nationalized banking, telecommunications, basic petrochemicals and fertilizers, which he omitted - happen to represent the very infrastructure of the Mexican economy.
These industries are defined as ''strategic'' by the Mexican Constitution, and their privatization is strictly prohibited. President Salinas de Gortari himself has repeatedly stated that he has no intention of privatizing them. Yet unless they are privatized, it will be impossible for Mr. Salinas to establish the free-market economy he claims is his objective.
Unfortunately, without a political mandate, he has only nibbled at the state sector, reassuring the labor unions and other traditional constituents that he has given nothing away to the hated burguesia.
The limitations of Mr. Salinas's reform program, just like those of perestroika to which Mr. Gardels compares it, are nowhere more evident than in its failure to mitigate the acute misery in which the vast majority of Mexicans have lived since 1982.
Clearly, Mr. Salinas must privatize at least some of the money-losing, inefficient ''strategic'' industries, if he is to energize economic growth and satisfy pent-up consumer demand. And he must do so rapidly. In July 1991 elections will be held for a new Congress. This could turn into a plebiscite against the Salinas administration if he has not improved somewhat the lives of his 85 million fellow citizens.
 
DANIEL JAMES
President, Mexico-
United States Institute
Washington, Nov. 14

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
To Rescue the Thrift Rescue Plan

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOUR months ago, Congress swallowed hard and approved the largest Federal bailout on record, the rescue plan for the savings and loan industry that will spend $159 billion over the next decade. But already financial experts are warning that lawmakers are not finished with the problems of the industry.
They argue that the bailout legislation is seriously flawed. Basic causes of the thrift crisis were never addressed. The process of selling off sick S.& L.'s and their inventories of junk property is proceeding at a disturbingly slow pace. The reconfigured regulatory system is in disarray, and by 1991 Congress will have to put up even more taxpayer money. 
But even more unsettling, perhaps, are the questions being raised about whether the Government is actually capable of addressing the problems of the nation's financial system.
''It's amazing how quickly the problems with thrift bailout are becoming evident, and the magnitude at which they are growing,'' said Bert Ely, a financial consultant based in Alexandria, Va. ''I think it shows that the political process just cannot do a good job in dealing with financial risk.''
Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, said Congress had constructed ''a Rube Goldberg device which is proving to be very, very difficult to get off the ground.''
The events of the last week offered little encouragement. The nation's top regulator of savings institutions, M. Danny Wall, who had been assured of his position through the middle of 1991, tendered his resignation as director of the Office of Thrift Supervision. He said Congress had tried to make him a scapegoat for the industry's troubles and warned that it was demoralizing his agency.
The higher capital requirements created under the rescue plan took effect on Thursday amid predictions by financial experts that more than half of the nation's savings associations would disappear over the next few years.
And top banking regulators announced that the industry posted a $744 million deficit for the third quarter, primarily from losses on third-world loans and soft real estate markets in the Northeast and Arizona.
The core of the industry's problem was the intersection of the Reagan deregulatory environment and the resulting go-go banking environment, budget restraints that cut the regulatory staff and a willingness on the part of some members of Congress to yield to the demands of S.& L. executives. While the debate is still open as to whether reregulation or further deregulation is needed, those on both sides agree that it is essential to have enough examiners to enforce the existing rules.
What seems to bother analysts most is that while the bailout law established a mechanism that is meant to insure that a problem of similar proportions never happens again, the very structure may have the germ of another collapse.
First, they note that the legislation did nothing to revamp the nation's deposit insurance system, perhaps the primary cause of the savings crisis. The Government insures almost all deposits, especially at very large institutions, and this has enabled aggressive savings executives to take tremendous risks with depositors' money at Government expense. It has also meant that depositors have had to think very little about the soundness of the institution holding their deposits, thus imposing no private-sector discipline on the banking and thrift industries.
Some believe that the maximum deposit insurance has to be cut back from the current $100,000 level. Others, such as Mr. Ely, believe that the private sector has to assume more of the insurance risk. But the savings bailout bill did nothing, except to mandate a Treasury Department study which is due to be finished in 1991.
A second core issue is the existence of the savings and loan industry as a separate business, regulated by a separate agency. Many experts argue that the days of making money on 30-year mortgages is long past, that the traditional S.& L. is a dinosaur and that prolonging the industry's existence will only lead to higher failure costs.
Instead, the institutions that will prosper in the future will be modeled more after commercial banks and thus should be regulated by banking regulators.
Some argue that Mr. Wall's departure might hasten that process. Morale at the thrift office is said to be at an all-time low, particularly since the legislation removed several key areas of responsibility. And when the Congress looks at the need for more funds, probably in 1991, it might be willing to consider merging the two industries and their regulators.
''People have asked me whether now that Danny has gone will his successor be able to resuscitate the thrift industry,'' said Robert E. Litan, a banking expert at the Brookings Institution. ''I tell them that even if Paul Volcker were put in Danny's place it is not going to revive the industry.''
''Danny's successor should realize that it is his job to phase out this industry and this agency,'' Mr. Litan added.
But there are other problems with the legislation. For example, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was given vast new responsibilities by the bailout legislation, including running the deposit insurance fund for the thrift industry and managing the day-to-day business of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency chartered to spend $50 billion to find buyers for dying savings institutions.
But some members of Congress are warning that the F.D.I.C.'s staff is now taxed beyond its limits, having placed some of its ablest staff members at the new agency. The concern is that an overburdened F.D.I.C. could lapse in its role as regulator of thousands of state-chartered banks.
Moreover, the political dynamics of the F.D.I.C. have changed. Until the bill was signed by President Bush on Aug. 9, the F.D.I.C. was almost entirely independent of the Executive branch, reporting only to Congress. But as manager of the resolution corporation, it now has to answer to the Treasury Department. This has prompted speculation that the agency's chairman, L. William Seidman, might be preparing to leave, rather than chafe under directions from Treasury.
''At Christmas cocktail parties in Washington, the conversation is that Bill has made the decision to leave,'' said Mr. Guenther of the Independent Bankers. ''This is the guy who we can afford to lose least. Seidman's departure would take a very wise head out of play at a very crucial time.''
Finally, analysts warn that the shortage of funds at the R.T.C., as well as a fear by Government bureaucrats of being criticized for making sweetheart deals, will mean that major sales of large insolvent institutions are not going to take place anytime soon, probably no sooner than the middle of next year.
''That means that from the time Washington recognized it had a problem early this year until results, you will have an 18-month hiatus,'' said R. Dan Brumbaugh, a senior fellow at Stanford's Center for Economic Policy Research. ''That is just too slow. And it's an indication that the Government just should not be in this type of business.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For Aquino, Rescue Comes With Price Tags

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
AS they marched out of Manila's high-rise business district Thursday morning, recoilless rifles on their shoulders and bandoleers still strapped across their chests, the troops who had nearly toppled the Philippine Government were smiling and singing. Seeing the cameras, a few held their hands in the shape of a ''T,'' imitating referees calling a brief time-out in a closely contested game.
''As long as the cause is still there, it's not all over,'' said Capt. Danilo Lim, one of the many West Point graduates who led the biggest and most violent coup attempt yet against the nearly four-year-old Government of President Corazon C. Aquino. ''Look at this,'' Captain Lim demanded. ''Does this look like a surrender?'' 
In fact, it looked more like a reunion of old military classmates, which it was. Despite Mrs. Aquino's declarations of victory, it was not only impossible to judge winners from losers in the latest coup effort, in which 79 people died and more than 500 were wounded; it was also hard to tell which side some of the Government's leaders supported. By the weekend, Mrs. Aquino had linked the Philippines' Vice President, its chief opposition leader and an associate of the late Ferdinand E. Marcos to the attempt, and many of the military officers involved had disappeared into the hills and luxury homes around Manila.
No one believes that the few who were arrested will be harshly punished, largely because the Government fears alienating loyal military leaders who sympathize with the rebels' complaints, if not their tactics. Even Mrs. Aquino's closest aides said the Government was so weakened by the coup effort that another seems inevitable.
If anyone doubted that Mrs. Aquino was losing her grip on the ''people power'' revolution that ousted Mr. Marcos in February 1986, the events of the last 10 days proved it. By most accounts, without American air support at a critical moment, Mrs. Aquino's experiment in democracy probably would have ended. But that help vastly complicated the uneasy politics of the Philippines and did little to address the underlying sources of Mrs. Aquino's troubles: garbage that goes uncollected, telephones that don't work, rampant corruption and an economy that makes foreign investors nervous. The prospect of renewed instability makes all of those problems worse, as the rebels well know.
Most striking, perhaps, is how many Filipinos are now unconvinced that democracy is the answer to the country's crushing problems. When the rebels mounted their siege, no one rushed from their houses to rally support for Mrs. Aquino, whose popularity has been dropping steadily.
The quickest to sense this turn in opinion are the elite young officers of the Reform Armed Forces Movement, known as the ''R.A.M. boys'' and led by Col. Gregorio (Gringo) Honasan, a fugitive who led the 1978 coup attempt and is believed to have helped direct this one. The rebel officers view Mrs. Aquino as weak and indecisive - a widely shared view, even among many diplomats - though they have yet to articulate a clear ideology or alternative path. Most important, the officers see themselves as the best alternative power broker for the country.
In a rally of tens of thousands of supporters on Friday, Mrs. Aquino suggested that Vice President Salvador Laurel, who split from her camp several years ago, and Juan Ponce Enrile, a Marcos-era defense minister who also fell out with her, were among those egging the coup along, presumably to speed their own paths to the presidency. They issued murky denials.
 
One Reliable Weapon
Mrs. Aquino's fiery speech was intended to show that she too could fight. But in the midst of the coup attempt, she revealed that she had only one reliable weapon: the support of the United States, which used F-4 jets to put a ''cap'' on an air base captured by the rebels, who had already bombed Malacanang Palace while Mrs. Aquino was inside. The F-4's turned the tide without firing a shot. Even before the rebellion was put down, however, Mrs. Aquino began paying a price for this assistance, which only stoked the arguments of nationalists who say the root of most of the Philippines' economic and social troubles is overdependence on the United States. Mrs. Aquino has been fighting calls to kick out the American military bases here, and exploratory talks on renegotiating the leases were to begin this month. Now she is often cast as an American puppet, hardly in a position to drive a hard bargain with the Bush Administration.
The coup was also disastrously timed for the economy. Vital Christmas tourism is expected to suffer badly - and that at a time when foreign investors had only recently begun venturing back into the Philippines, convinced that the political scene was stabilizing and that the economy could keep growing at 6 or 7 percent a year.
Mrs. Aquino can no longer blame only the legacy of Mr. Marcos for the country's economic woes; he is dead and it is four years since he was in power. The R.A.M. movement - like the Communists and other anti-Manila factions - is betting she will fail to get Filipinos to focus on rebuilding the economy, and there are rumors that their next strategy is to systematically undermine economic life here. ''We have maybe a year or so to get it together,'' said one of her confidants. ''Or next time we won't be so lucky.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
At the Malta Meeting, West Met West, Too

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR President Bush, the summit meeting last weekend in Malta was not only a time to begin forging a new relationship with the East. It was also an opportunity for more clearly establishing Washington's role within the Western alliance.
During his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev aboard the Soviet cruise liner Maxim Gorky, Mr. Bush strived to assume the aura of global leadership that his critics have said is lacking. But he was careful not to appear to be dictating solutions to the Western allies. Indeed, the first thing Mr. Bush did when he got home on Monday was to call Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. 
It was after midnight in London, but Mr. Bush wanted to dispute reports in the European press that he had taken sides against Mrs. Thatcher in a debate over how fast European economic integration should proceed. Those reports were wrong, Mr. Bush said, and rumors of the demise of the ''special relationship'' were greatly exaggerated.
This week Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will go to Bonn and Brussels to discuss a NATO consensus on the question of German reunification. At the last minute he added London to his itinerary to try to ease Mrs. Thatcher's anxieties.
Mr. Bush also had to worry about how the summit meeting played back home. The Administration was criticized by conservatives who believe Mr. Bush gave more than he got at Malta. But Administration officials said they came away with just what they wanted from Mr. Gorbachev on Eastern Europe, arms control and the superpower relationship. Mr. Gorbachev assured Mr. Bush not only that he will not interfere in Eastern Europe, the officials said, but that he was actively encouraging the changes and happy with their pace so far. They said Mr. Gorbachev also indicated that he would not try to push the arms control agenda faster than the United States wants it to go. The only sour note, Administration officials said, was on regional conflicts like Central America. But even there, the tone was more conciliatory than in the past.
American officials said they had expected Mr. Gorbachev to express support for Eastern European reform. But, said one, ''It is one thing to sense it and quite another to hear it while you're looking the man in the eye.''
 
A Troublesome Proposal
Administration officials said they were astonished to see how much Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev agreed on Eastern Europe. They parted company when Mr. Bush expressed support for the eventual unification of the Germanys and Mr. Gorbachev did not. But there was not much anxiety over that point since the United States does not seem to want to accelerate the process anyway.
On arms control, Mr. Gorbachev made one proposal troublesome to the Americans, suggesting a ban on naval nuclear weapons. But he agreed to try to sign a treaty on strategic nuclear weapons next year. For his conservative audience at home, Mr. Bush noted that Mr. Gorbachev never challenged the ''Star Wars'' program.
The summit talks provided a fascinating glimpse into the superpower relationship at a time when the two countries' interests seem to intersect more and they can no longer count on dominating their alliances. American officials said they saw an improved economic relationship with the Soviet Union as serving two purposes: to demonstrate to Western Europe that Washington is doing its part to encourage change and to give Washington a toehold in the newly evolving arrangements between East and West.

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Even in California, Finally, Real Estate Is Not Hot

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CALIFORNIANS are begining to learn what Texans did five years ago and New Yorkers more recently: that what goes up in real estate may also come down.
Having sizzled long after the rest of the country had slowed, the California housing market has finally begun to cool off. The median selling price of existing homes was 3 percent lower in October than in September, according to the California Association of Realtors, and the pace of sales dropped, too, by 15 percent from last year. Experts cited the perception of over-inflated prices, cuts in defense spending and the recent severe earthquake as factors. 
But another development, or broad series of interrelated technological and economic developments, is also at play, some experts believe. Though most experts believe that local factors are still the main determinant in prices, some say the country's real estate market may be undergoing a fundamental change as new technology, expanding communications systems and ease of travel change the way the nation does business, adding to the housing price equation a new element that works to equalize market forces across the country.
More and more companies that have no real business reason to stay in a particular place are making a business decision to move to places where housing for their employees - or the employees they hope to attract - is more affordable.
David G. Shulman, director of real estate research for Salomon Brothers in New York, argues that the emergence of fiber optics, satellite communications, facsimile machines and airline hub-and-spoke systems has created a ''truly global village'' in which skilled employees ''can locate almost anywhere as long as they are 'plugged in.' ''
But others contend that such technology affects only a small portion of the economy. ''A fax machine doesn't replace a waterway,'' said Stan Ross, co-managing partner of Kenneth Leventhal & Company, Los Angeles-based accountants. ''You cannot replace fertile land with a telecommunications screen or direct contact in certain financial services with a computer message.''
As for California, experts are divided over whether the state is facing a lingering weakness in real estate values, as in New York and the Northeast, or just a small ''correction'' in a overheated market. But it appears for the moment at least that the nation is moving toward a kind of equilibrium in housing as the torrid markets on both coasts settle down and the long-depressed Midwest, particularly Texas, finally begins to pick up as companies see the virtues of cheap residential real estate.
''There is a relationship between what's happening in the East and the West,'' said Glenn E. Crellin, vice president for economics and research at the National Association of Realtors. ''Prices had simply gone up too rapidly for most people to buy. They're both going through some stabilization now. By contrast, the Midwest has become the most affordable region in the country.''
Kenneth T. Rosen, chairman of the Center for Real Estate and Economics at the University of California-Berkeley, discerns ''no relation at all'' between regional real estate markets. Housing in New York deflated by an unrealistic boom on Wall Street, he said, while the California market is more solid, with a diverse economy buoyed in part by large infusions of money from Asia.
Nevertheless, some experts see a diffusion of the population, driven by high housing prices. In California, for example, companies are not leaving the state so much as moving to its less expensive areas, said Christopher B. Leinberger, who owns the real estate consulting firm of Robert Charles Lesser & Co. He calls these places, like Ontario and Valencia in the outer orbit of Los Angeles, ''compromise locations.'' To the north, Sacramento, 80 miles east of San Francisco and with a median house 50 percent lower, is fast becoming an extension of the San Francisco area.
''In the labor-short 90's, where quality-of-life considerations and gaining access to workers will become increasingly important to corporate relocations, cities that offer both high quality of life and low housing prices are going to come out better,'' said Mr. Leinberger.
While bad news for sellers, the recent softening of the residential markets in New York, Boston and California is good news to industries that have been having trouble persuading skilled workers to relocate to those areas. Though West Coast prices had come down slightly of late, the California realtors group calculates that in October only 19 percent of Californians could afford the median priced home in the state at $194,000, compared to 47 percent of Americans generally in their home states.
Though the recent weakening has improved ''affordability,'' many business people say the high cost of living, along with the cost of complying with increasingly stringent environmental controls, is undermining the state's competitive position.
Robert Jackson, a planner for the McDonnell Douglas Corp., which does most of its commercial airliner production in Long Beach, Calif., said at a recent conference that his company faced a shortage of skilled labor, at least in part because the median house price in Los Angeles was 88 percent higher than in Seattle, home of McDonnell Douglas's chief competitor, Boeing. ''We have no intention of leaving,'' he said. ''But it's getting very tough.''

HEADLINE: HEADLINERS;
Holding Out

 BODY:
Socialism may be fraying at the seams, and glasnost, perestroika and compromise may be the words of the hour elsewhere, but Fidel Castro remains a purist. In a speech last week in Havana, Mr. Castro, who has been in power in Cuba for more than 30 years, expressed both a fierce support of socialism and an unease at being one of the few who do. ''If destiny assigns us the role of one day being among the last defenders of socialism in a world in which the Yankee empire has succeeded in embodying Hitler's dream of world domination, we will know how to defend this bulwark to the last drop of blood,'' he said. Mr Castro complained of the difficulty of building Communist states when others are tearing them down, and noted the possible consequences of a warming between the United States and the Soviet Union, which sends him so much support. ''From the crisis that has emerged in the socialist camp, we can only expect negative economic consequences for our country,'' he said.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 475 words

HEADLINE: The Taxi Industry Wins Again

 BODY:
In one respect, New York City's latest cab fare increase may be a blessing in disguise. It doesn't do riders any good, but it might remind Mayor-elect David Dinkins that if he means to serve the public, he has to fight the taxi cartel.
Mayor Edward Koch has tried repeatedly to weaken the city's industry monopoly. He came up with ways to increase the number of medallions -the artificially scarce, highly valuable licenses that breed inefficiency and corruption. But even that modest attempt died aborning. The city still has 11,787 medallion taxis licensed to pick up passengers - the same number allowed in 1937. 
A few other things are the same, or worse. It's still close to impossible to find a yellow cab outside of Manhattan below 96th Street. It's still a chore to get a cab in midtown during rush hour because there just aren't enough of them. It's still standard for cab drivers to bypass blacks.
It's also still standard for cabs to be in deplorable condition. A new inspection system may eventually change that, but right now, cab after cab is filthy, uncomfortable, even unsafe. Not enough have air-conditioning in summer; there's too little space between the back seat and the barrier, and that is often a collage of curling yellow stickers.
Good taxi service is impeded further by economics: the owners lease their taxis at such high costs that it's hard for drivers to make a decent living and almost impossible to attract skilled drivers. The Taxi Commission will soon start a better instruction course; still, many drivers, often struggling immigrants, don't know the city or the language.
The new fare increase will clearly hurt people who are forced to use cabs, especially the handicapped and the infirm elderly. The Taxi Commission insists the rise reflects true cost increases, but medallions still sell for $134,000 each, so the right to be in the taxi business is obviously worth a sizable investment, even at current fares.
The real problem, one that tinkering with fares can't touch, is the system of regulation. Protected from greater competition, taxi owners have a powerful incentive to resist providing better service and to push for ever-higher fares.
If Mr. Dinkins hopes to reform the industry, the goal must be to eliminate medallions altogether and let anyone who meets qualifications go into the taxi business. Those qualifications should include rigorous safety inspections and requirements for courtesy and non-discrimination - standards that should also extend to gypsy cabs and car services, which play an essential role in the boroughs but are largely unregulated.
Unless the Dinkins administration is willing to propound, and fight for, these thorough changes, it cannot claim to be interested in reform, only in submission to the industry. Once again, the public will pay more - and get less.

HEADLINE: Moscow Also Reconstructs Its Defense Thinking

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Is Moscow Cutting Its Military? Yes, by Necessity'' (Op-Ed, Nov. 17), Barry M. Blechman rightly points out that reductions in Soviet military forces diminish the threat posed to the West. But his failure to situate these cuts in a larger political framework of Soviet ''new thinking'' in foreign affairs yields an unimaginative and flawed policy prescription - to avoid reciprocal unilateral reductions.
Few analysts would dispute that economic imperatives are a prime motivating force behind Mikhail Gorbachev's initiatives. The burden of excessive military spending has already taken a tremendous toll on Soviet society and threatens to render the country a second-rate power. 
But to view Soviet actions solely as a response to economic hardship is to trivialize a fundamental shift in Moscow's conception of security manifested most vividly by abandonment of the Brezhnev Doctrine and strategic retreat from Eastern Europe. Moreover, the Soviet Union's unprecedented admission that its invasion of Afghanistan constituted a violation of international norms together with its constructive efforts to resolve regional conflicts cannot be plausibly explained by ''economic necessity.''
Having commenced the process of reconfiguring their forces toward less offensive postures, the Soviets have scored a conceptual breakthrough. Mr. Gorbachev understands security can be achieved only in tandem with the West. The present regime gives every indication it has learned the right lessons from history: menacing forces designed to deter aggression invite countervailing buildups that undermine security. Deterrence without reassurance is self-defeating.
The United States can and must respond with some new thinking of its own. There is a growing consensus that America's military-biased conception of security no longer corresponds to reality. Rather than just applaud Mr. Gorbachev for shifting resources from military to civilian uses, we should be implementing our own blueprint for unilateral force reductions. Not only will this strengthen the political position of detente-minded segments of the Soviet hierarchy; these savings might also be dedicated to restoring American economic competitiveness or improving our country's education system. United States security interests would be advanced on both fronts.
 
ROBERT G. HERMAN
 Ithaca, N.Y., Nov. 17, 1989
 
The writer, a doctoral candidate in government at Cornell University, worked with a NATO planning group.

HEADLINE: Peace Without The Khmer Rouge?

BYLINE: By Winston Lord; Winston Lord was Ambassador to China from November 1985 until April.

 BODY:
For years, policy makers have faced an excruciating dilemma in Cambodia: How to forestall both the return of the Khmer Rouge and the acceptance of Vietnamese aggression. Now that Vietnam has largely withdrawn from Cambodia, the decibel level of the debate has risen sharply, reflecting legitimate fears that the murderous Khmer Rouge might re-enact the killing fields.
There is no worse outcome. But such fears, orchestrated by Hanoi, drive some Americans to conclude that we should acquiesce in the reign of the Heng Samrin-Hun Sen regime. This is better than rule by the Khmer Rouge - but the worst of the alternatives. Here's why. 
First, the regime leaders, including Heng Samrin and Hun Sen, are ex-Khmer Rouge members with Cambodian blood on their hands. They threw in their lot with Vietnam, not out of moral compunction but to escape Pol Pot's executioners. Second, the regime was created and propped up by Hanoi and still gets large-scale Vietnamese and Soviet support. It has shown no meaningful signs of independence. Must we condone Vietnam's invasion by conceding its hegemony in Indochina?
Third, the Association of South East Asian Nations, whose security is most at stake, opposes a Cambodia run from Hanoi and presses for a neutral, independent nation led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk. Why do stout supporters of the U.N. blithely dismiss 128 countries that have just voted, by the largest majority ever, to reject the regime in Phnom Penh?
Finally, the fiercely nationalistic Cambodians, despite their hatred of the Khmer Rouge, have resisted Vietnamese colonization for a decade. Given a choice, they would surely choose a Sihanouk-led government. If, however, they selected Hun Sen, it is better that he win by vote than by international fiat. When we favor elections, often under difficult conditions, in Central America, Eastern Europe and around the globe, why the double standard for Cambodia?
Before rushing to yield Cambodia to Vietnam's control, let us consider the other options. One is the current policy of the U.S., the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, China and the international community.
It would allow the Cambodians to determine their own future through internationally supervised elections. This requires a transitional government led by Prince Sihanouk and including the forces of Hun Sen, the non-Communists and, unfortunately, the Khmer Rouge. They have powerful military forces that will not go gently into the night. Banned from any participation in a political settlement they will, with China's aid, prolong the civil war.
How can the Khmer Rouge then be shackled? Various measures toward this end have been put forward and have been endorsed by China - and even the Khmer Rouge.
Prince Sihanouk would head the coalition. The Khmer Rouge would be included; Pol Pot and others of his ilk would be excluded. All armed Cambodians, including the Khmer Rouge, would be regrouped in bases and disarmed; the cease-fire, segregation and disarming would be policed by a strong U.N. peacekeeping force. There would be free elections with international supervision; all factions would abide by the outcome.
We must assume the Khmer Rouge would grasp for power. And in coalions of bitter enemies, the thugs usually prevail. But the Khmer Rouge might be contained by cessation of Chinese aid, cooperation among the other three Cambodian factions and a large, effective international force.
Prince Sihanouk, who lost 15 family members to Khmer Rouge terror, subscribes to this scenario.
The issue of Chinese aid is central; without it the Khmer Rouge would be severely weakened. The U.S. has worked successfully to modify China's overall stance. Beijing has moved from solely supporting the Khmer Rouge, to backing the resistance coalition, to stipulating Prince Sihanouk as the genuine leader, to proposing specific commitments for controlling the Khmer Rouge.
I believe Beijing would agree to end its aid and constrain the Khmer Rouge as part of an overall settlement for a Sihanouk government.
Another approach is for the Sihanouk and non-Communist forces to dump the Khmer Rouge and join in a temporary alliance with the regime in Phnom Penh to organize the elections. The international community would have to insist that Prince Sihanouk be the real head, not the figurehead that Hun Sen and his backers demand. All parties would have to commit themselves to fair elections.
The incentives for the Phnom Penh authorities would be to gain international backing and to isolate the Khmer Rouge. Hanoi and Moscow might agree to a genuinely neutral Cambodian government to stave off a Khmer Rouge victory.
But this approach means continued fighting by Khmer Rouge, making countrywide elections very difficult. It would be hard to persuade China to halt its support for them, though we would point to the prospect of a Sihanouk government as a buffer against Vietnam, and Beijing may now be leaning toward limited rapprochement with Hanoi. We face these same problems, however, if we turn over Cambodia to Hun Sen - with all the additional drawbacks already cited.
Yet another alternative is Australia's suggestion for a U.N. trusteeship to replace the government and organize the elections. Prince Sihanouk apparently supports this general idea as a fallback.
This approach appeals in principle because it would dismantle the Hun Sen regime, serve as a further check on the Khmer Rouge and insure independent neutral administration of the elections. But it would be very complex to implement, and the Phnom Penh regime and Khmer Rouge are likely to oppose it.
Clearly any path is treacherous because the Khmer Rouge are treacherous. Reasonable people can disagree on the best route; no one should claim a monopoly on wisdom or morality.
But isn't it better to seek one of these three internationally supervised settlements and bridle the Khmer Rouge than to back one Communist faction against the other in an ongoing civil war? Isn't it better to strive for Cambodian self-determination, independence and neutrality than to impose a proxy government, reward aggression and fuel Vietnamese expansionism?
