HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Honolulu

BYLINE: By THOMAS KASER; THOMAS KASER is a staff writer for The Honolulu Advertiser.

 BODY:
Honolulu is an easy place to know and love if you give it half a chance. Some promoters call it a paradise, but it isn't. It is a city - commercial, expensive, noisy and tacky. It has traffic, drugs and street people. It also has abundant natural and manmade beauty, exceptional weather, exotic foods, friendly people, low unemployment, virtually no heavy industry.
Thirty years into Hawaii's statehood, Honolulu is still trying to shake its insular persona and become a cosmopolitan city. One reason the transition hasn't been easy is Hawaii's ethnic diversity. Everybody is a minority. In 1986 the state was 23 percent Caucasian, 23 percent Japanese, 20 percent part-Hawaiian, 11 percent Filipino and 23 percent everybody else. For better and for worse, everybody has a say. Public business tends to operate - excruciatingly - on a consensus basis, with its attendant slowness.
Honolulu has gone through two building booms since statehood and is currently in a third. Construction is also under way beyond the city limits. In the sugar cane fields west of Pearl Harbor, the state is promoting the development of housing, commercial centers, industrial parks and hotels. But tourism, not construction, continues to be the engine that drives Hawaii's economy. Record numbers of visitors have come almost every year since statehood. This year's projected total of 6.5 million - about 20 percent Japanese - should set another record. 
From December to March Waikiki beach is generally as crowded as midsummer. To get away from the crowds go to Diamond Head Beach, where walkways lead to the shore from lookouts near the Diamond Head Lighthouse, or a little farther out to Kahala Beach beyond Diamond Head. Winter is also the time of the big surf on the North Shore, especially near Sunset Beach.
 
Coming Events
Honolulu Symphony and Chorus (808-537-6191) presents Handel's ''Messiah'' at 8 P.M. Dec. 16 at Blaisdell Center Concert Hall; $8 to $22.
Michigan State and the Univerity of Hawaii play in the Eagle Aloha Bowl (808-947-4141) on Christmas Day. Kickoff 10:30 A.M.; $15 to $18.
The Annual Rainbow Classic, invitational tournament of collegiate basketball teams, is scheduled Dec. 27-30 in Blaisdell Center Arena (808-521-2911). Tickets: $3 to $8.
The annual college all-star game, called the Kodak Hula Bowl, is Jan. 13 at Aloha Stadium. Kickoff 10:45 A.M. Tickets: $12 to $15, including a post-game concert with Willie Nelson. Call 808-955-5541.
 
Museums
Iolani Palace (808-522-0832), the only royal palace in the United States, was occupied by Hawaiian royalty between 1882 and 1893. Tours are offered every 15 minutes between 9 A.M. and 2:15 P.M. Wednesday to Saturday. Admission: $4, $1 for children 5 to 12; under 5 not admitted.
The Bishop Museum (1525 Bernice Street; 808-847-3511) has exhibits on Pacific natural and cultural history. Through December it is open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday to Saturday and the first Sunday of every month, except Christmas Day. Starting Jan. 1, it will be open every day. Admission: $4.95 until Jan. 1, $5.95 thereafter. Honolulu Academy of Arts (900 South Berentania Street; 808-538-3693) is Hawaii's oldest and largest art museum with an outstanding Asian collection. Open Tuesdays to Saturdays 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., Sundays 1 to 5 P.M. Closed major holidays. Free.
The Contemporary Museum (2411 Makiki Heights Drive; 808-526-1322) contains art of the last 40 years. Open daily except Tuesdays, Christmas Day and New Year's Day from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Sundays noon to 4 P.M. Admission: $3.
Hawaii Maritime Center (Pier 7, Honolulu Harbor; 808-536-6373) displays artifacts on maritime history. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily except Christmas Day. Admission: $6, $3 for children 6 to 17.
Mission Houses Museum (553 South King Street; 808-531-0481) consists of three restored buildings that were the homes of missionaries. In December hours are 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. every day except holidays. Starting Jan. 1: 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuedsay to Saturday and noon to 4 P.M. Sunday. Admission: $3.50, $1 for children 6 to 15. On Dec. 16 there will be a candlelight stroll through the houses, outfitted with mid-19th-century Christmas decorations; $5, $2.50 for children (6 to 15). Reservations advised.
 
Sightseeing
Much can be seen by city bus (TheBus), which costs 60 cents in exact change and includes circling the island. Call 808-531-1611 for schedule and route information.
Downtown Honolulu, including the waterfront, financial center, Chinatown and Iolani Palace, can be seen on foot.
National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific (Punchbowl, 2177 Puowaina Drive; 808-541-1430) is a stop on city tours. It contains the graves of 34,672 veterans and dependents and overlooks the city. Open every day 8 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.
Evening cruises provide excellent views of Honolulu. The largest (282 feet, four decks) and most stable is the Rella Mae, operated by Windjammer Cruises (2222 Kalakaua Avenue; 808-922-1200). Cost: $39 for standard dinner cruise (with open bar and three shows); $55 for first-class dinner cruise (table service, premium food and drinks, three shows). Sunset cruise leaves at 5:15, returns at 7:45. Moonlight cruise leaves at 8:45, returns at 11. Guided tours of Honolulu and Oahu are offered by many companies, but the most intimate are those that use vans or minibuses. Two examples: E Noa Tours (1110 University Avenue, Room 306; 808-599-2561) uses 17-passenger minibuses. Its three-hour, 10-stop tour costs $16. Akamai Tours (2270 Kalakaua Avenue, Suite 1702; 800-922-6485 or 808-971-4545) uses 14-passenger vans. Its five-hour, five-stop tour of the city and Pearl Harbor costs $22.
The Waikiki Trolley (808-526-0112) is a motorized San Francisco-style cable car on rubber tires with a continuous narrated tour of historical points in central Honolulu; $10 a day for unlimited on-and-off privileges. Pay as you get on.
Arizona Memorial, Pearl Harbor (recording, 808-422-0561) is often crowded. Free tours are provided by the National Parks Service, starting with a short film at the visitors center, followed by a shuttle boat to the memorial. Tours from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M. daily except Christmas and New Year's Day. Best time to avoid crowds in December and January: between noon and 3 P.M.
Next door to the Arizona Memorial Visitors Center is the Pacific Submarine Museum and the deactivated World War II submarine Bowfin. Admission: $6, $1 for children (6 to 12). Open 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. daily except Christmas and New Year's Day. Call 808-423-1341.
Commercial submarine excursions off Waikiki are offered by the Atlantis Submarine (560 North Nimitz Highway, Suite 201C; 808-536-2694). Board the Rainbow I catamaran at the Hilton Hawaiian Village dock for shuttle to the submarine. The sub goes down 100 feet for viewings of marine life, coral and a sunken 174-foot naval tanker. The excursion, including catamaran ride and 45 minutes in the submarine, takes two hours. Cost: $67, $33.50 for children 4 to 12. (Children under 4 not admitted.) Excursions hourly from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M.
Climbing Diamond Head affords impressive views and is good exercise. A well-marked trail starts inside Diamond Head Crater. Slow walkers take an hour going up, 45 minutes coming down. A flashlight for tunnels is helpful but not necessary. Diamond Head Crater (with drinking water and restrooms) is open daily from 6 A.M. to 6 P.M.
 
Shopping
There's something for everybody in Honolulu, from tacky to elegant. Ala Moana Center, a five-minute bus ride from Waikiki, has 200 shops, including the flagship store of Liberty House (Hawaii's premier department-store chain) and Shirokiya (a large Japanese department store). Normally open five evenings a week, the center is open every night until Christmas.
Ward Center, a half-mile beyond Ala Moana Center, is replete with upscale shops and restaurants, as is Ward Warehouse, a block beyond Ward Center.
 
Where to Eat
John Dominis Restaurant, (43 Ahui; 808-523-0955) specializes in seafood. Subdued waterfront ambiance. Average cost for two with modest wine: $100 to $125.
On the beach in Waikiki: La Mer, at the Halekulani Hotel (2199 Kalia Road; 808-923-2311). This expensive second-floor restaurant overlooks the ocean. Popular items: kumu (a small and delicate reef-dwelling Hawaiian fish) baked in parchment with seaweed, vegetables and mushrooms. Dinner for two with modest wine: about $160.
The best-known Thai restaurants are those of the Keo's chain. The flagship (625 Kapahulu Avenue; 808-737-8240) is a favorite of visiting celebrities. Dinner for two with modest wine: about $40.
Honolulu's second-most popular cuisine after Thai: spicy Korean, especially at the three Kim Chee restaurants, which are open 10:30 A.M. to 9 P.M. daily. Closest to Waikiki is Kim Chee No. 2 (3569 Waialae Avenue; 808-737-0006). Unpretentious, offering barbecue chicken dinner ($4.80) or combination plate ($4.70).
 
Where to Stay
The Kahala Hilton (5000 Kahala Avenue; 800-367-2525 or 808-734-2211) is on the beach in quiet Kahala, a five-minute drive from Waikiki on the other side of Diamond Head. Rates for two: $195 to $475 a night.
In Waikiki: the Halekulani (2199 Kalia Road; 800-367-2343 or 808-923-2311). Elegant and upscale. Rates for two: $195 to $350.
Hilton Hawaiian Village (2005 Kalia Road; 800-445-8667 or 808-949-4321) is Hawaii's largest hotel with 2,523 rooms. Rates for two: $160 to $305.
Sheraton Moana Surfrider (2365 Kalakaua Avenue; 800-325-3535 or 808-922-3111) is on the beach in the center of Waikiki and was Waikiki's first resort hotel, opening in 1901. It reopened last March after a 20-month, $50-million restoration. Rates for two: $170 to $260.
Midrange: Aston Hotels (2255 Kuhio Avenue; 800-922-7866 or 808-922-3368). Hotel and condo rooms in Waikiki. Rates for two start at $74.
Also midrange: Outrigger Hotels Hawaii (reservations: 808-926-0679) is the state's largest hotel chain (22 hotels, all in Waikiki), with many inexpensive rooms.
Budget choice: Royal Grove Hotel (151 Uluniu Avenue in Waikiki: 808-923-7691). Family-owned. Rates for two: $36.50 to $50.

LENGTH: 5143 words

HEADLINE: CARTER REDUX

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING; Wayne King, a Times reporter, was chief of The Times's Atlanta bureau during the Carter Administration.

 BODY:
When Jimmy Carter returned to his home in Plains, Ga., in 1981, after losing the Presidency, he was an all-but-shattered man. He was pilloried as the author of America's malaise and the architect of its economic stagnation, and humiliated as the remaining 52 American hostages in Iran were released the day Ronald Reagan was sworn into office - after Carter's own rescue effort had died ignominiously in a remote desert in Iran. His personal finances were devastated: The thriving peanut warehouse he left in a blind trust when he went to the White House was $1 million in debt; he stood to lose his farms and perhaps even his house. What he had to look forward to after the Presidency, Jimmy Carter himself conceded, was a ''potentially empty life.''
But late one night, sitting bolt upright in bed, he said, ''Conflict resolution.'' And he told his wife, Rosalynn: ''I know what we can do with the Carter Center. We can have a place where people can go to resolve conflict.''
''I thought at first he must be sick,'' recalls Rosalynn Carter with some amusement. ''I've never seen him awake at night, even in the White House.'' 
The famous grin - wolfish or puckish, depending on one's view - is still there. So is the glacial temper, except these days it is aimed not at aides or the press. It was in full display last spring in Panama when he found that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, after allowing a free election in which his hand-picked candidate lost, decided to steal it back with phony tabulation sheets.
Furious, the former President stormed into the tabulation center, shoved several people aside, clambered onto the stage and thundered at the dozen distinguished Panamanians in the act of certifying the deceit: ''Son ustedes honestos, o ladrones?'' ''Que, que, que, senor?'' some responded, and Carter shouted again, ''Are you honest people, or thieves?''
It was Jimmy Carter at his Old Testament best. At a hurried news conference, he denounced the election as ''totally fraudulent.''
Several months later, in September, he was mediating peace talks between the Marxist-Leninist Government of Ethiopia and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, another Marxist group, which has been fighting for independence from Ethiopia since 1961. For the first time in 28 years, representatives of the combatants were meeting without conditions.
Then Carter was off to Nicaragua, at the invitation of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, to lay down ground rules for elections there next February. Carter also persuaded Ortega to allow 30,000 Miskito Indians, who had been living in Honduras and fighting the Sandinista Government since 1981, to return to their homeland in Nicaragua along with their exiled leader, Brooklyn Rivera.
It was also largely through Carter's intervention that President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia granted clemency in the fall of 1988 to eight political prisoners he had summarily sentenced to death. And it was also Jimmy Carter who, in conjunction with the International Committee of the Red Cross, implored President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia in August 1988 to free 220 Somalian prisoners of war who had been incarcerated for 10 years. Within a month, all 220 were free.
Suddenly, after nearly a decade in the political wilderness, Carter was back and seemingly everywhere, running a kind of shadow State Department - with the advice, consent and even encouragement of the Bush White House.
If he was the wrong man for the time when he became President in 1976, Jimmy Carter seems the perfect man for the diplomat-without-portfolio post. Nowadays, the President who made human rights a legitimate foreign-policy concern is devoting more and more of his time and attention to ending internal conflicts that in the last few decades have killed, maimed and dislocated millions of people.
His insistence on operating from a higher moral ground, which most Americans took as self-righteousness when he was President, works in his favor when opposing combatants in a civil war have no one else to trust. His singlemindedness - exemplified in his attempt to resolve the hostage situation in Iran, which Americans viewed as a hapless obsession and yet another indication of how nothing seemed to work at the Carter White House - is useful when longtime and obdurant foes refuse to budge from their respective positions.
Today, there are about two dozen continuing civil wars or insurrections, each killing more than a thousand people a year, and Carter says he is better able to deal with such conflicts now than when he was President. (The United Nations Charter has no provision for intervention ''in matters which are essentially within the domestic jurisdiction of any state,'' and the world body can intervene only if requested to do so by the government concerned or if it is given a mandate from the General Assembly or Security Council. Under these conditions, it is trying to broker peace agreements in Afghanistan, El Salvador and Nicaragua.) As a former President, Carter has considerable clout, but - with no official status in international affairs - he is not constrained by Administration foreign policy. ''I never profess to speak for my country,'' he says, seated in the living room of his home in Plains, ''although I always keep the State Department and the White House informed, and almost invariably I have their full support - certainly that has been the case since George Bush has been in office.'' That, he adds, was not always so: ''Quite often, my image and goals would be in conflict with those of President Reagan, and I didn't get any support from his ambassadors. In fact, sometimes they would deliberately put impediments in my way.'' In 1983, for example, he informed the State Department that he planned, as a private citizen, to visit Peru, Brazil, Argentina, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Mexico. ''They objected strongly to my going at all,'' he says, ''saying there were security threats to my life, that the Governments would be embarrassed, and so forth.'' He went anyway. ''In Costa Rica, when I finally arrived there - I met with the contras in Costa Rica before going to Nicaragua - I found that the Ambassador had canceled all my appointments, all the appointments we had laboriously made, unbeknownst to me.''
And when he arrived in Peru, on his way to Argentina, ''I was informed by the American Embassy in Argentina that massive demonstrations were planned against me, that [President Raul] Alfonsin and his Foreign Minister had requested I not come. I checked with the Peruvian Ambassador, who said the report was incorrect. I flew from Peru to Buenos Aires and I found all those reports made to me by the American Embassy were totally false. Alfonsin and the Foreign Minister were eager and delighted that I came. We would go out in the street and crowds of people would gather around and clap and shake my hand. This was a difficult time for me to implement the policies of the Carter Center.''
The accommodation with the Bush White House derives in part from a thaw in the ideological chill that permeated the Reagan years, but also from a more pragmatic approach to world affairs under George Bush. Jimmy Carter is simply useful. (There is now a secure telephone on his desk in Plains for calls to Foggy Bottom and, occasionally, the White House.) ''Obviously, it's in our interest to have stability in the Horn of Africa,'' said a senior State Department official during the Ethiopian-Eritrean talks at the Carter Center, ''and a settlement in Ethiopia would contribute to that. Equally obviously, the United States Government isn't in any position to mediate the Eritrean conflict. So what Mr. Carter is trying to do down in Atlanta suits our interest just fine.''
Even Elliott Abrams, the implacable foe of almost anything that bore the imprimatur of Jimmy Carter while he was Assistant Secretary of State in the Reagan Administration, concedes it ''makes a great deal of sense'' that Carter is able to involve himself in conflicts other individuals and organizations are unable to intrude upon.
Abrams, a lawyer now in private practice, also cites what he calls ''the decline of these internal conflicts as an East-West issue.'' The possibility of a resolution to an internal conflict - in Ethiopia, for example - is greater if the conflict is not one in which the United States and the Soviet Union are engaged as proxy enemies. And these days, the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ''less interested,'' says Abrams, in maintaining involvement in the Ethiopian-Eritrean war or in similar conflicts around the world.
Today, Jimmy Carter, as a kind of court of last resort, is the first President since Herbert Hoover (box on this page) to play so active a role in world affairs after leaving the White House.
From the beginning, Carter did not want just a library - ''a monument to me,'' as he puts it. But with the decision to have an ''active'' center, he and Rosalynn Carter undertook the 18-month task of raising the $27 million the center ultimately cost.
Set on a hill where, Carter notes, Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman watched the Battle of Atlanta, the Carter Presidential Center houses a staff of some 130 in four interconnected buildings that meld futuristic design with classical columns. A think tank and ''conflict resolution'' hub, the center is a sort of vest-pocket World Health Organization, miniature United Nations and ad hoc Department of Health and Human Services.
An integral part of the Carter Center is Global 2000 Inc., an international aid organization striving to eradicate various diseases and improve agricultural productivity in third-world countries. The health program - run by Dr. William H. Foege, a former head of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta - has targeted the Guinea worm, which incapacitates 10 million Africans each year, as well as river blindness, polio, measles and rabies. Led by Dr. Norman Borlaug - an agronomist who won the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize for bringing the Green Revolution to India and Pakistan - the agricultural program is tripling corn and sorghum production among small farmers in the African nations of the Sudan, Ghana, Tanzania and Zambia, through the use of high-yield seeds and fertilizers.
The Presidential library and museum are operated with Federal funds, but the other activities of the center, budgeted at $16 million a year, are financed by public and private donors, including many average citizens, the Houston philanthropist Dominique de Menil, the Carnegie Corporation of New York, and the Rockefeller, Ford and Hewlett Foundations.
Most of the money for the center's third-world programs comes from abroad: a donation from the Government of Norway financed the Eritrean-Ethiopian talks. The Bank of Credit and Commerce International, based in London, is another backer. A principal donor to the programs operated by Global 2000 is the Japan Shipbuilding Industries Foundation, whose chairman is Ryoichi Sasakawa, a 90-year-old Japanese industrialist who made his considerable fortune in speedboat racing, a major sport in Japan.
The Carter Center officially opened in 1986, but it began operations in 1982, in temporary Atlanta quarters at Emory University, which still operates the center in a sort of joint venture with the Carters. (The former President is also a Distinguished Professor at Emory, lecturing on such subjects as military ethics and conducting ''town-meeting forums'' for students, faculty and visitors.) Flanking the entrance of the center are framed photographs from the Carter Presidency. Along one wall of the reception area outside Carter's office are facial studies of him by Andy Warhol: the prominent Carter lips sharply outlined, eyes almost mascaraed.
Carter works in an airy office that looks out over a Japanese garden donated by Atlanta's Japanese-owned YKK zipper company. The garden has a pond in which the former President has been seen dipping a fishing rod in the company of his 2-year-old granddaughter, Maggie.
Much has been said about how the boyish President aged when he was in the White House (overnight, it seemed, he went from 55 to 65), but though the hair is thinner and all but completely silver, both Carter, who is 65, and the former First Lady, who is 62, look exceptionally fit.
Although more relaxed than he was in the White House, Carter remains a workaholic. At the Carter Center, where they have an apartment, the Carters are up by 7:15 in the morning, unless the pressure of events dictates an earlier hour. He has a granolalike breakfast concocted by his wife. The two of them run three-and-a-half miles when their schedule permits, and then both usually repair to their adjoining studies.
Rosalynn Carter's involvement in the work of the center - ''unfinished business,'' she calls it - is no less than the former President's. In the White House, she attended Cabinet meetings, and today their activities are still done in tandem. ''I like skim milk, Jimmy likes whole, so we buy milk with 2 percent butterfat,'' she noted in ''Everything to Gain,'' the book she and her husband wrote. It is a revealing passage. It would never occur to the Carters to buy separate but equal quarts of milk.
The Carters write their own speeches (they both have heavy speaking schedules) and books. He tends to make careful notes on things of importance. During the nine days of negotiations between the Eritreans and Ethiopians at the Carter Center, for instance, the former President - sometimes with the parties face to face, sometimes with them in different rooms with Carter shuttling back and forth - always tapped out on his word processor the precise wording of sensitive matters, and gave copies to each side, to avoid quibbling later.
He says he has not changed. ''It's interesting and gratifying to see the media collectively saying there is a new, different Jimmy Carter, managing the affairs of the Carter Center competently, not uptight, not trying to push his religion forward. But I haven't changed. As far as the press is concerned, there is a revision of perspective.''
But Jimmy Carter of today has an easier, more comfortable public presence. If he could remake his Presidency, what would he change, he was asked at a recent town meeting in Atlanta. He shook his head, his eyes twinkled, the grin emerged. ''I'd order another helicopter,'' was his Reaganesque response. Clearly, there has been a mellowing of his take on the abortive hostage-rescue mission.
And at the 10th anniversary reunion of some 2,000 Carter Administration officials and staff members in Washington recently, he said that he had been asked repeatedly by reporters to comment on Reagan's multimillion-dollar visit to Japan (the fee was $2 million). He said he had told the press he was reluctant to criticize another former President, ''But here, among friends, I can be more candid. And I can say, if any of you hear of another deal like that, let me know.''
There is among the Carter folk a sense of honorable expiation. Addressing the former President at the reunion, Oregon Gov. Neil Goldschmidt said, ''Whether in kindness to the homeless or the poor and dispossessed of foreign lands, or on behalf of political prisoners around the globe, you have carried the dignity and character of the American Presidency to high ground - on which is posted a sign: 'Not for Sale.' ''
''After eight years of greed, indifference to human suffering,'' he continued, the Carter Presidency was ''a Sabbath celebration.''
Carter himself was more restrained. ''When I look around this room at the tremendous crowd,'' he said from the podium in the ballroom of the Omni Shoreham, ''and think of what you have meant to the country, and the latent ability you have, I have one thought: Why don't we take over again!'' The crowd roared its approval. Carter came back to earth. ''That was my first thought. My second was just to express my deepest thanks.''
''I'm Jimmy Carter, and I'm running for President. I will never lie to you.''
It played. Jimmy Carter was elected the country's 39th President as America was recoiling from the imperial Presidency of Lyndon B. Johnson and the corruption of Richard M. Nixon. America in 1976 was tired of it all: the artifice, the deceit, the misuse of power. But it didn't last. America probably still yearns for an imperial President - a Roosevelt - and if he is not that, at least one with whom the average Joe can identify - a Harry Truman or a Ronald Reagan. Jimmy Carter was none of these, even if he carried his own suitcase and banned ''Hail to the Chief.''
He was, and is, a man without pretense. A man who took himself seriously - perhaps too seriously. Erwin Hargrove, a political-science professor at Vanderbilt University and author of the 1988 book ''Jimmy Carter as President: Leadership and the Politics of the Public Good,'' calls Carter a ''man without a mask.'' And that, Hargrove believes, was part of his problem. A President needs a mask, an image; a President cannot be mere flesh and blood.
Ronald Reagan always kept up his side of the bargain - at no time did he let his mask slip. He got away with ''killer trees,'' and when he, in a futile peacekeeping mission in Lebanon, lost 241 American servicemen, he did not suffer a loss in popularity. Ronald Reagan was the hero of 100 Saturday-morning matinees; Jimmy Carter, the fumbling man of malaise, lusted only in his heart and fled from ''killer rabbits.'' Harry Truman didn't wear a mask, but he didn't need one. He also played poker - and the fifth that rounded out the foursome was often I. W. Harper. Jimmy Carter was a teetotaler, and his rectitude made people uncomfortable, as if in that very rectitude there was implied opprobrium. He made the three-martini lunch seem not just a tax dodge but something vaguely immoral.
Carter had many problems as President, some of his making, many not. The oil embargo was hard to foresee, but Americans blamed him for the long gas lines. We invented oil, didn't we? We blamed him for the endless agony of the hostages held in Iran. They called us the Great Satan, and we didn't do anything! And when we did, the helicopters crashed. What do you mean, the helicopters crashed? Above all, we blamed him for the terrible economic condition the country was in. What he could do, he did tentatively and too late. ''He got into a position of power not at a helpless moment,'' observes the economist Henry Kaufman, but rather at the beginning of an economic expansion when economic management can be effective. But the new President's reluctance to rein in the expansion for fear of inducing a new recession, combined with his own inability to calm the jitters of the economic community, led to what some called the ''20-20'' economy of 1980 - a prime rate and an annualized inflation index close to that figure.
By the end of Carter's first term in the White House, malaise was everywhere. Carter contends he never used the word ''malaise'' in the speech on the energy crisis he gave from the Oval Office in the summer of 1979. And that is true.
He said: ''The true problems of our nation are much deeper, deeper than gasoline lines or energy shortages, deeper even than inflation or recession.'' What he saw was ''a crisis of confidence . . . a crisis that strikes at the very heart and soul and spirit of our national will.''
Carter still thinks it is among the best speeches he ever gave. It outlined the conservation measures, alternative-energy initiatives and other measures that are likely the best longterm hedges against Arab oil dependency. But it was, unquestionably, a speech about malaise. And whatever he may have intended, most Americans took it as a hectoring speech, feeling that they were being blamed for the nation's problems - even for a crumbling Presidency.
Thus Jimmy Carter, whose vision of a better world may well have been ahead of his time, fell afoul of the immediacy of empty gas tanks and 20 percent interest rates and the image of blindfolded Americans enduring God-knows-what at the hands of fanatics halfway across the world.
Nonetheless, looking at the Carter Presidency in 1989, a historian may well find much to applaud. If nothing else, none of the American hostages in Iran were killed. The combined four-year budget deficit during the Carter Administration was $227 billion (the eight years under Ronald Reagan, $1.3 trillion). Furthermore, the Carter years were free of the conspicuous corruption - the Iran-contra and Housing and Urban Development scandals, the savings and loans debacle -that plagued the Reagan Presidency.
Carter also managed the Camp David Accord between Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Egyptian President Anwar el-Sadat, the Panama Canal Treaty and SALT II (although it was possibly symbolic of his growing political impotence that he failed to get Salt II ratified). And, indeed, it was his own negotiations that ultimately gained the release of the American hostages in Iran - but not in time to save his Presidency.
The carters concede their return to life in Plains after their eviction from the White House was difficult, not least because of financial problems.
When he assumed the Presidency, Carter put his profitable peanut warehouse in a blind trust. When he returned four years later, after three disastrous years of drought, the warehouse was almost $1 million in the red. Carter, typically, had been meticulous about keeping himself in the dark about the warehouse finances. Even today, when he talks about it, his face tightens and his eyes look pained. ''I couldn't believe it,'' he says quietly. ''It was a horrible shock. I didn't know what to do.''
What he did was sell the warehouse for $1.2 million, enough to pay the debt, with a modest cushion. The sale saved the Carters from the painful option of selling all or part of two family farms totaling 2,000 acres - or possibly the four-bedroom home, on 170 acres, they built in 1961 after several profitable years at the peanut warehouse.
Former Presidents don't starve; Carter's Presidential pension is $99,500. But with the warehouse sold and the farmland largely leased to farmers, he had no clear future. It was, he recalls, ''deeply discouraging.'' For a time, Rosalynn Carter, angry and shattered, consoled herself with the fanciful dream that her husband would run again and regain the White House while he, harboring no such illusions, maintained an outward cheeriness he concedes was artificial. By the summer of 1981, both had substantial book contracts, the concept of the Presidential center was forming, and the Carters began what they still like to call ''proving there is life after the White House.''
Duty, to them, is sustaining. Each year, they find the time to spend a week or so wielding hammer and saw on behalf of the Habitat for Humanity, a nonprofit Christian enterprise based in Georgia that constructs housing for the poor and homeless at home and abroad.
The former President is also finance officer of the 130-member Maranatha Baptist Church (''Total received for 2 Sundays in October: $1,482.19''). He often mows the church lawn while Rosalynn Carter vacuums the carpets and the upholstered pews. And he teaches Sunday school when he can, which these days is perhaps once a month. ''The church is the center of our social life,'' he says. ''It's like breathing for us.''
Still, Carter can be snippish. When his Secret Service driver takes a wrong turn on a tour of Plains, Carter explains the route, then adds thinly, ''Or we could go where you want to go.'' But bantering over football scores is more the norm.
Plains, with a population of 653, has scarcely changed since the early 1960's, when Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter built their home there. In blue jeans, open-collared shirt and heavy workman boots, Carter is easy, chatty. At the small public-housing project where he and his wife lived for a year in 1953 after he got out of the Navy - broke - he observes that ''there was quite a stigma then to white people living in public housing. So there was no trouble getting in.'' The Carters started a fertilizer business, made $234 the first year, but the next year made more than $5,000 and so had to move out of the housing project.
When the Japanese millionaire Ryoichi Sasakawa visited the Carters in 1981, Carter recalls, he expressed consternation that a former President lived in ''such a humble cottage.'' Although it is hardly that, the four-bedroom brick bungalow looks as if it might have been built by a moderately successful small-town peanut-warehouse operator in 1961.
Today, of course, one is admitted through an electric gate operated by a Secret Service agent in a guardhouse (the agents occupy a leased home a few hundred yards from the Carter bungalow). The cat is named Misty Malarky Ying Yang. The Carters laid the pine floors in the attic themselves, for added storage, when they came back from the White House. They bought a 20-acre plot alongside a white-water stream in the north Georgia hills and built a log-cabin retreat there; Carter also built the furniture (he is an accomplished woodworker).
At the Kountry Korner restaurant, where lunch for four comes to $18, the regulars greet the Carters much as they would anyone else, with questions about the family and remarks on how good they look. The former President orders black-eyed peas, English peas, buttered carrots and pear salad, corn bread and unsweetened tea. Rosalynn Carter has the same, but no mayonnaise on the pear salad. Are they vegetarians? No, he says, ''but we haven't bought any beef or pork since we left the White House. But we eat fish and game that I kill, and we eat some venison. The Secret Service agents hunt on my place and they bring me venison, and I shoot turkey and doves and quail. The agents harvest about 30 deer a year from our land. That is, that I know about.'' The smile flashes.
''It holds down poaching,'' he says. ''Everybody knows the Secret Service has my farm leased.''
The day before, a Sunday, at the Maranatha Baptist Church, Carter took as his text the last chapter of the Book of Daniel, which he confessed he failed to understand completely, but which he told his class of about 50, most of them elderly tourists, is God's call to duty in the face of adversity.
''He is telling us, don't waste our time, don't waste our talents, don't waste our intelligence. We can have a faith that can transcend failure. . . . We can have an existence that has purpose . . . what do I want to achieve - to expand and strengthen the Kingdom of Christ?''
Afterward, he was asked if that sort of biblical admonition compelled him to continue to work 12-hour days, tirelessly circle the globe, talk far into the night with warring factions with neither side budging, only to awake with the next dawn to start it all over again.
Jimmy Carter smiled his face-splitting smile, as if it were all the greatest of fun, and said, ''Sure!''
 
LIFE AFTER THE WHITE HOUSE
 
THOMAS JEFFERSON
 
3d President (1801-1809) . . . left office at age 65 and continued to be influential through successive Presidents James Madison and James Monroe . . . established the state-supported University of Virginia, designed the buildings, supervised their construction, gathered the faculty, planned the curriculum . . . at age 71, studied Plato's ''Republic'' in the original and concluded the philosopher was highly overrated . . . a believer in scientific farming, he conducted many experiments at his home, Monticello.
 
JOHN QUINCY ADAMS
 
6th President (1825-1829) . . . like his father, John Adams, the second U.S. President, he was a one-termer who left office widely disliked by the country and his party . . . but in 1830 he was elected to Congress as the representative from the Plymouth, Mass., district - the only former U.S. President to become a member of Congress . . . served eight successive Congressional terms and, as a champion of the antislavery cause, was far more effective as a Congressman than he was as a President . . . died in 1848, at age 80, during a Congressional session.
 
ULYSSES S. GRANT
 
18th President (1869-1877). . . before distinguishing himself as a Union commander in the Civil War, he had failed as a farmer and businessman . . . in 1860, at age 38, he was a clerk in his father's leather store . . . after leaving the White House (and a scandal-ridden second term), he bought a house in New York City and became a partner in a banking house, investing all he had in it but paying no attention to its management; a few years later, the firm failed - a result of systematic fraud by two of the partners . . . he began a career as a writer for Century Magazine and completed his only book, ''Personal Memoirs,'' which earned his family $450,000, four days before he succumbed, at age 63, to cancer of the throat.
 
THEODORE ROOSEVELT
 
 26th President (1901-1909) . . . the hyperactive former President went on African safaris, traveled incessantly, haranguing all who would listen . . . he became a contributing editor of Outlook magazine, wrote for Metropolitan Magazine and the Kansas City Star, and published books on history, politics, travel and natural history . . . he found it impossible to stay out of state (New York) and national politics and in 1912 staged an unsuccessful attempt to run, once again, for the Presidency . . . in 1916 he hoped to become a Presidential candidate . . . in January 1919, at a time when the way was being paved for him to become the 1920 Presidential candidate, he died in his sleep; he was 60.
 
WILLIAM H. TAFT
 
27th President (1909-1913) . . . after leaving office, he was appointed Kent Professor of Law at Yale University . . . in 1918 he became a member of the National War Labor Board and was a staunch supporter of American participation in the League of Nations . . . appointed Chief Justice of the United States in 1921, he quickly improved the efficiency of the Supreme Court and served in that post until ill health forced him to resign in February 1930. He died, at age 73, a month later.
 
HERBERT C. HOOVER
 
31st President (1929-1933) . . . a peripatetic and tireless mining engineer and relief worker who circled the globe and saw war and famine before he became President, he returned to the same work after leaving the White House . . . Harry S. Truman asked him to help organize relief during the great famine in Europe of 1946 . . . in 1947 and in 1953, he presided over what became known as Hoover Commissions to look into ways to correct government inefficiency, waste and rising costs ... he devoted the last decade or so of his life to writing books and his memoirs, and died in 1964, when he was 90.

PUB-DATE: December 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42, Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: A LITERARY HIGH-WIRE ACT

BYLINE: By Marshall Blonsky; Marshall Blonsky teaches semiotics at Queens College and The New School for Social Research. He is completing a book, ''American Mythologies,'' for Oxford University Press.

 BODY:
THERE IS UMBERTO AND THERE IS Eco. Umberto is the author of ''The Name of the Rose,'' an experimental whodunit that overnight became an international best seller; Eco is professor of semiotics at the medieval University of Bologna. Umberto has now written ''Foucault's Pendulum,'' a novel that is seducing the American literary establishment but was at the center of a heated, yearlong critical debate in Italy. Some Italian critics believed it was a plotless distortion of history written by a buffoon who used his knowledge of publishing ways to manipulate the market. Others considered it the first novel of a new, global, collage culture. The American critics have deepened the ambiguity: Some have refused to consider ''Foucault's Pendulum'' a novel, but have praised it as a dazzling philosophical entertainment.
Eco, in love with history, is a medievalist; Umberto, the first in his family to attend a university, adores Flash Gordon and ribald jokes about Wonder Woman. Eco - the name means echo - is inextricable from his native Italy, his memories of hunger during the Second World War and his old school friends. He's also the first Italian writer of his generation to produce a truly worldwide blockbuster of a novel: ''The Name of the Rose'' sold 9 million copies in 36 countries. 
If readers go along with the critics' largely favorable verdict, the ''Pendulum'' will surpass the ''Rose.'' In America, six weeks after publication, there are 275,000 copies in print, and the book is high on the best-seller list. In just seven years, Eco has gone from a $4,000 advance for the ''Rose'' to a figure reported to be more than $1 million for the ''Pendulum,'' from an erudite linguistic scholar into a mega-celebrity on the cultural scene.
One night during a lecture tour in 1984, after an occasionally barbed dialogue with Susan Sontag before almost a thousand people at New York University, the novelist sat, withdrawn and silent, in a Greenwich Village restaurant, unwilling to participate in the animated conversation of the Harcourt Brace Jovanovich editors and publicists around him. ''The Name of the Rose'' had been published a few months before. He pulled from his breast pocket a French article about himself and handed it to me without a word. He wasn't bragging. It was simply a gesture to connect with someone from his past (I've known him for 15 years), to distance himself from the commotion around him. At the age of 52, he was famous and he was scared.
LAST JULY, WHEN ECO ARRIVED IN NEW YORK BEFORE TRAVELING to the Indiana University campus in Indianapolis, where he was to deliver one of the keynote speeches at the International Summer Institute for Semiotic and Structural Studies, I picked him up at the Gramercy Park Hotel and took him to the bustling Trattoria dell'Arte. The restaurant, designed by Milton Glaser, is nicknamed ''Il Naso'' because of its giant nose in the window and its noses of famous Italians from Dante to Jimmy Durante on a painting behind the bar. ''Yours should be there,'' I offer. He contemplates the two icons of Italian culture in silence, as if trying to figure out where he belongs.
Since our last encounter, he's thickened slightly at the waist. ''The Alitalia stewards know me and they spoil me - too many martinis,'' he sighs over antipasto. Even the Italian stewards are part of the Italian mama complex, members of the extended family that is so much a part of that culture.
He brightens briefly when he notices on the wine menu a Gavi di Gavi Soldati la Scolca. ''Ahh, I know the man who makes it - my neighbor in Piedmont.'' Another instance of the Italian national network.
Over the mixed seafood grill Eco informs me that he's about to buy a two-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village for his son Stefano, a 26-year-old New York University graduate student. ''And now I will have a room of my own instead of these impersonal, sterile $200-a-night hotel rooms,'' Eco says. ''New York is not an American city. It's a European, Mediterranean city that just happens to be on your side of the Atlantic.'' His owlish eyes sparkle behind his big glasses.
Eco is a cultural curiosity, equally mobile in the Old World and the New. He has shown up for dinner still dressed in his transcontinental uniform - jeans and a blue-checked Italian sportcoat. ''I began wearing blue jeans in the days when very few people did,'' he wrote in ''Travels in Hyperreality'' (1986), ''but always on vacation. I found -and still find - them very comfortable, especially when I travel, because there are no problems of creases, tearing, spots. . . . It's only in the past few years that I've had to renounce this pleasure because I've put on weight.'' He's less a victim of fashion than of the new middle-class esthetic of moderation, which frowns upon any sign of embonpoint. The days when a bulging waistline was an expression of European joie de vivre, the image of a successful bourgeois man, are over.
Eco's worldly manner belies his scholarly vocation. The world traveler drinking martinis on Alitalia - Eco flies business class - is a world-class scholar who was deeply influenced by Charles Sanders Peirce, the late 19th-century pragmatic philosopher whose work anticipated modern semiotics; Eco's doctoral thesis was on ''The Esthetic Problem in St. Thomas.'' Brought up as a devout Catholic, he was recently accused by L'Osservatore Romano, the official Vatican newspaper, ''of profanations and blasphemies, buffooneries and filth, held together by the mortar of arrogance and cynicism in which the man of letters in his lofty dignity delights.''
In December 1988, the Pope himself, two months after the Italian publication of ''Foucault's Pendulum,'' condemned Eco before an audience of 5,000 pilgrims as ''the mystifier deluxe,'' telling the pilgrims that human life ''does not move inevitably toward death and nothingness'' - a phrase taken almost verbatim from the ''Pendulum.''
''We - are - not - as - those - that - believe'' - Eco slowly pontificates, satirizing the Pope's pseudo-excommunication - ''that - there - is - no - truth, no fixed point in this world.'' He laughs. ''It was his job to say that, O.K., O.K. The whole affair was nothing but an invention of the newspapers that needed to have an Italian Salman Rushdie,'' he says, attempting to reconcile God and the devil. ''I received calls from English newspaper asking if the Catholics were hunting me and trying to kill me. They believed that the Catholic Church is like Khomeini, so I was obliged to defend and protect the Catholic Church against those Anglicans.''
Born in 1932, Eco came of age in the postwar years. During the war, his family fled to the countryside to escape the bombing. ''We were not poor,'' he said, ''yet it was impossible to find food. I am preoccupied with the new generation who do not know what does it mean starving during the war, starving, with my mother crying because she couldn't have flour, could not find the farina with which to make. . .'' The memory is too much, and he can't finish his sentence. (Even at this emotional moment language is paramount in his mind. On the verge of tears, he stops to ask: ''What is the difference between 'flower' and 'flour'?'') ''The generation older than mine was blasted by the war,'' he resumes his narrative. ''Destroyed. And we arrived on the scene - at the end of the war we were 13, 14 years old - young and innocent. We were the first generation that could take a flight to Paris. And once I used the expression: 'We are the avant-garde in Wagon Lit,' sleeping cars, because we went to our conferences by sleeping car, by airplane. It was so easy for us to be in touch with everybody. At the age of 23 I met Stravinsky. It was only 'Nice to meet you, sir,' but I met him. We were not people at the margins, we were in the center.''
Eco feels he was blessed by another catastrophe. ''You understand, I am 57 years old and I still hold power - aJU small power - in my university. If the generation younger than me had prospered, the generation of '68, I would be retired now. But they were destroyed by confrontation. Some of them became terrorists, some of them escaped to the East with an Indian guru. It was a tormented, tortured, disgraceful generation. So I am privileged because those ahead of me were destroyed by the war and those behind me self-destructed. I feel I have been a filthy opportunist.''
 
WE MEET AGAIN a week later at the president's house at Indiana University in Indianapolis. It's a 20-room mansion, formerly the home of the pharmaceutical tycoon Eli Lilly. Eco, alone in the house, feels uncomfortable and regrets that the campus is dry - ''a typical Anglo-Saxon bigotry.'' He also regrets that there are no ashtrays in the house. Before going to a cocktail party, he steps out on the balcony to sneak a smoke. ''The housekeeper doesn't let me smoke,'' he says in a warm, throaty Italian accent, drawing on his cigarette and contemplating the campus lawn in the vastness of middle America. ''And there's only a single beer in the fridge.''
A few minutes later, martini in hand, he's doing his Eco-shtick (I heard it 11 years ago) before an audience of charmed academics on the terrace of the chancellor's house next door. ''The French have admitted at last that the Gauloises are pure poison,'' he says, talking with his yellow cigarette hanging out of the corner of his mouth. ''You see, it's papier mais, corn paper. You don't need fingers to hold it. You can talk around it, blowing smoke all the while in front of you.'' He demonstrates. ''And from behind the smoke comes French philosophy, comes la semiologie, and some of them actually rolled the Gauloise around the entire mouth as they lectured. Sartre, Barthes could do it.'' For Eco, Sartre and Barthes are still alive, side by side with Madonna and Indiana Jones.
Eco was in Indiana for the 14th annual meeting of the Semiotic Society of America, an organization he helped to found. An adept at interpreting the signs and messages that drive our consumer society, he was distressed to learn that the audience for his keynote speech - ''The Semiotics of Fakes and Forgeries'' - would include not only members of the Semiotic Society, but also marketing types from something called the International Institute on Marketing Meaning.
''I don't like it and I feel embarrassed,'' he complains a few hours before his speech. ''Personally, even in my country, I have always avoided meetings like this. I prefer to feel free to criticize certain phenomena without being directly involved with their production. Mr. Nader does not sit down with Mr. Ford and I sit with Nader and not Ford.''
But that contradiction, too, yields meaning. Semioticians are sign-struck. To them, everything can be endowed with meaning - a sign. ''Not only are words signs,'' Eco wrote in the Times Literary Supplement in the fall of 1973, ''but also gestures, images, nonlinguistic sounds like the chimes of Big Ben. Obviously devices (such as flags) created by man in order to indicate something are signs, but so are, in ordinary language, the thread of smoke that reveals a fire, the footstep in the sand that tells Robinson Crusoe a man has passed along the beach, the clue that permits Sherlock Holmes to find the murderer.''
''We are not always interested in things insofar as they are immediately consumable but insofar as they can stand for something else,'' Eco explained to me one afternoon. ''You see here behind us old books,'' We were sitting in the lounge of the Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue.
''It gives you the impression you are sitting in the library of an aristocratic mansion. Yesterday I had a look at the books. They're interesting books, but not so rare. The poems of Longfellow, the writings of Lord Chesterfield. You can pull out a book and read it but that is not the function of this small library. The management wants you to consider yourself a sophisticated traveler and not a tourist on a budget.
''You don't need a semiotician to understand this. The management understands it better than I do. The guests in this hotel read these signs perfectly. Everybody knows how to make love but sexologists study and classify and define the way people make love. A semiotician tries to find the laws of the universe of signs.''
Eco spontaneously applies his analytic eye to his own fiction. Some Italian critics consider this approach contrived, as if he had deliberately used his ''mysterious science'' to write a best seller. ''Before Eco,'' says Gian Carlo Ferretti, a professor of contemporary Italian literature at the University of Sapienza in Rome, ''the writer was a craftsman who handed in his text to the editorial machine while remaining outside it.'' Eco, because of his interest in semiotics and his years of editorial experience, is often accused of working from the mind and not from the heart. ''Eco is like an engineer who stays inside the machine because the knowledge of the machine gives him also the knowledge of the market,'' says Ferretti.
Teaching semiotics is as much a passion with Eco as writing is. ''I teach out of intellectual and biological necessity,'' he says. ''When you write, you make certain assumptions, you take for granted the reader understands your premises. Not so with students. They ask a question and suddenly disconcert you.
''With students you need to know more. Young people are exciting, they're challenging. When I was young, I was always the youngest of my group. Now, I'm always the oldest of my group. If I were now the youngest,'' he says, laughing, ''it would be pretty pathetic.''
In a way, it's his reading of cultural change that gave Eco the inspiration for the new novel. ''I started it when I realized that in many European and American bookstores, in the same shelves in which in the 60's were the works of Marx, Gramsci, Marcuse and Adorno, now there were books on the Age of Aquarius, on the New Age, on Indian philosophy, tarots and so on,'' he says. ''After an excess of political and economic interpretation of life, the so-called radicalism or Marxism of the generation of '68, there has been a collapse of such utopia, and many of these people went in search of something mysterious, supernatural and occult. There has been a turn of a whole generation, yearning for mystery, for revelation, for illumination. That's what 'Foucault's Pendulum' is about.'' Once the novel's concept was clear in his mind, Eco went scouting locations, like a film director. He made a pilgrimage, as he puts it, to centers of Templar esotericism in France and Portugal. ''And I spent nights and nights walking alone from 2 A.M. to 4 A.M. through Paris.'' To acquaint himself with the mental geography of his characters, ''I pillaged all the bookshops in at least 10 cities in Italy, France and America.'' He bought some 1,500 books on occultism plus 400 or so rare books - ''more than I used for the novel, but at this point I was caught by this new mania.''
''Foucault's Pendulum'' is figural - to borrow a term from the deconstructionist critic Paul de Man. It has a multiplicity of meanings. Eco says: ''The reader will recognize that my story only occasionally concerns three editors who publish occult books and could actually be three politicians trying to understand what happened in their country, three agents of the C.I.A., three philologists trying to decipher an old parchment, three archeologists trying to figure out where a stone came from, three psychiatrists dealing with paranoid people, three lovers obsessed by jealousy and constantly suspecting each other, or two lovers.''
They are also a composite portrait of the leading post-structuralist philosopher Jacques Derrida - ''Foucault's Pendulum'' is, among other things, a roman a clef. It was Derrida who insisted that a writer cannot control his writing, that a text - as writing is known in those circles - invariably takes on a life of its own, independent of the author's intention. ''Nothing expresses the final truth but everything is a symbol for something else and for something else and for something else,'' says Eco. As Casaubon, one of the maniac editors in the novel, puts it: ''I was prepared to see symbols in every object I came upon. . . . Our brains grew accustomed to connecting, connecting, connecting everything with everything else.''
THE BIDDING FOR the paperback rights took place in November. Given the high advance for the hard-cover, Harcourt originally demanded a floor of almost $1 million - too much for Warner, Eco's previous soft-cover publisher. Ballantine Books, betting on Eco, paid more than $1 million.
''It's tough, your second book,'' a Warner executive told me. ''The first time, Eco was this great literary find, supported by the publicity tour in which he was charismatic. The critics were afraid to say they didn't like the book. It would have showed them up. I don't think they're going to fall over themselves to love the new one.''
But they did. In a barrage of positive reviews, The Boston Globe, the Kansas City Star and The Village Voice were among the negative few. In England, however, more thumbs were down. Even Salman Rushdie, writing from his safe house somewhere in England, blasted the book. ''Foucault's Pendulum,'' he wrote in The Observer, is ''humorless, devoid of character, entirely free of anything resembling a credible spoken word, and mind-numbingly full of gobbledygook of all sorts. Reader: I hated it.'' ''It looked like the Ayatollah's attack on him,'' Eco retorts. ''Rushdie did the same to me. But some months ago, I belonged to a group of writers invited by The New York Times to defend the right Salman Rushdie had to express freely his opinion, and I keep going in the same direction.''
''Foucault's Pendulum'' is a didactic pseudo-encyclopedia explaining everything you wanted to know but were afraid to ask about European culture and history. It gives you names, dates, events you never heard of before - signs of history and culture you can drop at work or at home - whether you understand them or not. Eco said, ''In Italy they published a dictionary of all the strange names and quotations in the novel'' - Dizionario del pendolo di Foucault.
''I don't think that the reader of the book should know the exact meaning of everything. Suppose I am a film maker and I show you a character walking in the dark in a castle holding only a candle, and you come to ask me: 'Would you put a lamp on the scene to illuminate it?' But why? If I wanted the scene to be dark it's because that darkness has a meaning. So if I want to overwhelm you with a lot of mysterious magic spells and names it's not because I presume that you are a scholar of the Warburg Institute. I want you to feel this unbearable, suffocating accumulation of strange and exotic and magic spells. The reader has to understand I am making puns of ideas and so I use an enormous amount of material some of which even I don't know.''
He was afraid the book's difficulty would sink it in America, and was alarmed by the big promotional compaign that his publisher had in the works. ''Please don't sell it as soap,'' he told his publisher, Peter Jovanovich. He went through the roof when he learned over the summer that Harcourt was maneuvering to get him on television shows like ''Today'' and ''CBS This Morning.'' Most writers would have rejoiced at a $250,000 promotion budget - three times what the best European writers get as an advance. Eco thwarted it.
''Not for modesty or for Franciscan heroism that I oppose big promotion,'' he insists, ''but because I know publicity can have a negative influence on critics. I told them, I reprimanded them, I was severe with them.''
And as Eco commanded, so it was done. ''Foucault's Pendulum'' was launched at the venerable Morgan Library and at the Jewish Museum in New York, where Eco debated Moshe Idel, among the world's leading cabalistic scholars, and in Washington at the Smithsonian, which sponsored ''An Evening with Umberto Eco.'' What did he want? I asked him the night he arrived in New York for his promotional tour. ''To be taken seriously,'' he answered. ''We are a Catholic civilization, which is exactly the opposite of what Max Weber told of the Protestant civilization. For the Protestant civilization, economic success is a sign of the benevolence of God, while for our civilization, poverty and suffering are proofs of his benevolence. Success, on the contrary, is the proof that God is ready to send you to hell.''
Avoiding this fate has been no easy matter. Carla Tanzi, the foreign rights manager for Eco's Italian publisher, Bompiani, has received a score of movie offers for the ''Pendulum,'' among them an offer from Dino de Laurentis for 600,000,000 lire ($450,000) and a 5 percent royalty, given as a rule only to the happy few. ''They're calling from Los Angeles,'' she said, ''and they haven't even read the book.''
''I'm not selling it to the movies,'' Eco declares. ''I want the book to stand on its own.''
Dwelling among contradictions - worldly fame and literary immortality, secular riches and academic monkhood - has made Eco's life an eternal pendulum, but he could also be seen as a synthesis of the commercial and the classic. His sensibility embraces the old and the new, Europe and America, guilt and appetite, traditional and popular culture, logic and fantasy, anonymous scholarship and center-stage celebrity. ''Listen,'' Eco says animatedly, ''Someone accuses Woody Allen, in one of his films, of taking himself for God. And Woody Allen says, 'Everybody has to choose his own models.' O.K. Every writer has to choose models, but that doesn't mean that one pretends to have matched the model.''
Eco has moved into a space that other writers of fiction have abandoned: the great master of Western literature. Yet as a communications expert, he's aware of the transitory nature of our cultural objects. The survival of the book industry depends on discovering the new, not on preserving the ''classic.''
Whatever its virtues and defects, ''Foucault's Pendulum'' is a book that makes large claims. Eco wants to establish a whole new tradition -the genre of all-inclusive, anything-goes writing. Alberto Moravia called the ''Pendulum'' ''a university lecture with a short novel inside.'' In the United States, reviewers have even decided not to apply traditional canons to the book. ''You may call the book an intellectual triumph, if not a fictional one,'' Anthony Burgess proclaimed in The New York Times Book Review. ''No man should know so much. It is a work not of the literary man but of one who accepts the democracy of signs.'' In Eco's imagination, highbrow and lowbrow merge. Durante and Dante: It's the post-modern choral style.
ONE AFTERNOON IN THE early fall, Eco is sitting on a couch in his new, still-unfurnished apartment in New York. His son's electric guitar and keyboard are on the floor by the window. The books are still in boxes. A toy King Kong is climbing a kitsch Empire State Building. Eco is in a relaxed mood. ''I remember that after graduation with my friend Furio Colombo'' - a critic and the chairman of Fiat U.S.A. - ''one evening in Milano at the age of 22, we said: 'We have finished university, we are starting new jobs but what do we really want to do with our lives?' And I remember to have answered:
'I want to make a book and a kid, because they are the only ways to overcome death, a paper thing and a flesh thing. Lovemaking alone, for all its pleasures, is stupid; nothing comes of it. But my death can have a sense if somebody survives me and continues. And I write a book, not to have a success now but with the hope that in the next millennium, it will be still at least in a bibliography or in a footnote. And if I like the success now, it's because probably it helps the book to survive.''

HEADLINE: IN SHORT;
FICTION

BYLINE: By PAMELA CYTRYNBAUM

 BODY:

REBEL WITHOUT A CLUE. By Holly Uyemoto. (Crown, $17.95.) In this deceptive novel, adult concerns like power, fame, intimacy and mortality are tackled expertly, as is realistic dialogue laced with the macho accents of two male adolescents. But the writer is neither an experienced author nor a man. Holly Uyemoto, a 19-year-old who lives in northern California, delves into the flashy, sometimes fatal world of easy money, sex and drugs, and emerges with a terrific book. ''Rebel Without a Clue'' is a straightforward tale of the twisted lives of Christian Delon, a thoughtful teen-ager loafing away the summer after his high school graduation and mired in the sludge of the idle rich of Marin County, Calif., and Thomas Bainbridge, his best friend, who at 18 is the ''highest-paid male model in our economically disturbed world,'' a lanky youth with ''wide eyes the color of 7-Up bottles,'' chiseled cheekbones - and AIDS. ''I found myself scrutinizing him closely,'' says Christian, ''afraid he'd disappear right before my eyes. The enormity of the situation hadn't begun to set in but I knew that it meant sooner or later I would only see him in photographs and behind my eyelids. Suddenly I couldn't stop looking at him.'' Christian follows Thomas from brightly lit movie sets to Hollywood soirees attended by characters like a ''balding columnist'' wearing eyeliner and various ''acclaimed talents'' who ''lick mirrors and razors and each other's noses.'' Breaking this destructive cycle, Christian is left with hope for himself but only ambivalence for his dying best friend - a sophisticated ending for an admirable first novel.

HEADLINE: ANGST IS A KILLER

BYLINE: By JAY GUMMERMAN; Jay Gummerman is the author of a collection of stories, ''We Find Ourselves in Moontown.''

 BODY:

DUCKS
By Helen Hodgman.
121 pp. New York:
Harmony Books. $16.95.
In the opening paragraph of ''Ducks,'' the Australian writer Helen Hodgman's third novel and her first to be published in America, 13 ducks become caught by their feet in a South London pond that has frozen overnight. Soon a big dog named Angst happens along and bites each duck off at the knees. 
The remaining duck stumps are a troubling image to Hazel, a 40-year-old unemployed widow, mother and divorcee, who is currently the live-in lover of Moss, a divorced mother, freelance designer and member of the Women's Design Collective, a radical feminist organization whose exact goals are never made very clear. Hazel is adrift - this much is certain - and the slaughtered ducks are a small sample of the chaos that surrounds her and everybody else in the novel. ''Ducks'' is made up of a series of vignettes, each roughly half a page in length, that encompass multiple points of view, numerous settings and several decades.
Besides Hazel and Moss, the novel's characters include Elvis, Moss's young son, who lives with Hazel and Moss; the Bogeyman, a junkie whom Elvis takes to be his father; Clarice, Moss's mother, a widow who is rediscovering sex; Harold, Moss's former husband, a devotee of a bizarre religious cult known as the Kali Kosmic Konsciousness (KKK); the Leader, the Lady Eleanor, Moon Baby III and a skinny witch named Sylvia, all members of the KKK; Mrs. Birtwhistle, Harold's dying mother; le Professeur de Judo and Lucienne, Hazel's former husband and her daughter, who live in Vancouver, British Columbia; Ted, Hazel's dead husband (before le Professeur de Judo), whose insurance compensation check sustains Hazel and Moss; Lark, Hazel's lesbian lover (before Moss and le Professeur de Judo); the members of the Women's Design Collective (Manny, Maureen and Sue, as well as Buster and Beulah, a lesbian couple with their own baby); Walter and Daphne, a businessman and his novelist wife; their children, Albert, Benjamin, Felix, Felicity, Dominic and Rupert; plus their aforementioned duck-eating dog, Angst. Add to these a trash novelist called the Southern Belle, Hazel's dead-but-animate mother, Johny Holy Joy, Martha, Marian, Renate, Miss Binns, Hooper and Iris Tatters, and you've got quite a cast.
The constant shifting between these characters' lives works for a while - an interesting sychronicity interweaves them, and the world becomes a timeless web that all its inhabitants are by necessity caught in - but the technique quickly wears thin. Characters are introduced and then dropped, so that by the time we get back to them we may have forgotten who they are or what predicament they're in. Also, few of the scenes are sustained for very long; just as we feel we might be getting our footing, another situation is hurled at us, involving yet another character. New characters, in fact, are still popping up three-quarters of the way through the novel, which is especially disconcerting in a book that's only 121 pages long.
The events in ''Ducks'' are equally frenetic. In addition to duck slaughter, the plot contains references to indecent exposure, child molestation, snuff movies, hard drug use, vandalism, artificial insemination, kidnapping, sadism, masochism, cult worship, nuclear bomb-wielding terrorists, a murder plot, gangrene, amputation, an actual murder, mayhem, cannibalism, gang rape by police officers, suicide, coma, euthanasia, death by cancer, death by accident, a Nazi concentration camp, hallucinations and goddess manifestation, not to mention a whole lot of sex involving a whole lot of people.
Of course, the chaos of modern existence seems to be very much the point here. But unfortunately, with so many people and so much going on, everyone and everything seems distant. It's impossible to empathize, especially when there's an omniscient voice looming over the prose, a voice that keeps making comments and wisecracks. Even a good spoof, if this is how ''Ducks'' is intended, needs to lay out a set of rules - at least implicitly - for the reader to follow. But ''Ducks'' doesn't seem to have rules. Does anyone need to read a novel to feel that life is random?
Ms. Hodgman's first novel, ''Blue Skies,'' cast the world in an eerie light; the setting, an arid suburb on the Australian island of Tasmania, seemed to reflect perfectly the values of its ultra-modern inhabitants, whose primitive urges kept burrowing through their smooth surfaces. Everything that happened to and because of these lost people was off-kilter, yet entirely believable and deeply felt. ''Ducks,'' while certainly off-kilter, never quite gets near enough to touch.
 
A VISIT FROM THE BOGEYMAN
 As she did every Sunday at 6.30, Moss telephoned her mother in Bournemouth.
Yes, she'd adore to have Elvis for a while provided she could call him David.
Moss put him on the train, keeping her fingers crossed that he'd not set light to anything. She needn't have worried. David wouldn't dream of doing such a thing. He loved to visit his Grandma's house. In particular he loved the high-ceilinged, silent sitting-room with hundreds of tiny glass animals on every flat surface. . . .
He enjoyed the afternoon walk they always took with the dachsie, down through the winding chines to the promenade, where they left Fritz to roam . . . while they went to their favourite tea-room.
The best part though . . . was coming back in the late afternoon, when he'd race ahead to open the front door . . . and run down the hall to the room where the creatures all waited dull with dusk for the moment he'd switch on the wall lamps. Then what an intricate shimmer of whispers would ring out as the room turned shiny and snug and Granny swept in, saying, ''Time for a sherry, I think,'' as though there were ever any doubt about that, or anything else in the world for that matter. . . .
Later he'd go upstairs to sleep in Mummy's old bed surrounded by the things he supposed she didn't want any more.
One night in this room Elvis dreamed a terrible dream of the Bogeyman all wrapped in knives and blood. His grandmother found him perched on top of the wardrobe, beyond reach and beyond tears. . . .
''But there's no such thing as Bogeymen, David. Surely Mummy's told you that?''
''Mummy doesn't know,'' said Elvis.
 
From ''Ducks.''
