The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2164 words

HEADLINE: TALKING TO HIMSELF, BUT VERY LOUD

BYLINE: by JONATHAN D. SPENCE; Jonathan D. Spence, who teaches modern Chinese history at Yale University, is the author of ''The Question of Hu'' and of ''The Search for Modern China,'' which will be published next spring.

 BODY:

THE SECRET SPEECHES OF CHAIRMAN MAO
From the Hundred Flowers to the Great Leap Forward.
Edited by Roderick MacFarquhar,
Timothy Cheek and Eugene Wu.
561 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The Council on East Asian Studies/
Harvard University Press. Paper, $15.
Two Chinese texts for the day: ''It's good to have a bit of disturbance. Students making a disturbance is not equivalent to rebellion. . . . I say let them agitate to their hearts' content. . . . Make the process of the disturbance serve as an educational process, serve as a political course.'' And: ''The People's Liberation Army is for dealing with imperialism, not for dealing with the people. The People's Liberation Army is the son of the people. How could the son [of the people] ever oppose the father of the people?'' 
These observations, so poignant in light of the demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in May and June and the subsequent Beijing slaughter, were made by Chairman Mao Zedong 32 years ago, in February and March 1957. Mao was trying to get support for what became known as the Hundred Flowers Movement, a broad-based airing of views on the problems facing China, which he believed would dissipate the tensions that had arisen since the suppressions of the Hungarian and Polish risings in 1956. The reassurances Mao offered to intellectuals, party workers and students, in many informal speeches and off-the-record discussions, had the effect desired. By the spring of 1957 the movement was in full swing, and a deafening chorus of complaints was surfacing in every available forum.
Unfortunately for Mao, the complaints were directed not only at shortcomings in the political, economic and intellectual life of China, but at the Communist Party as an entity, and at Mao himself as an authoritarian and incompetent leader. Bitter and chagrined, Mao backed off from his support of the Hundred Flowers and joined forces with more conservative cadres who had never wanted the campaign in the first place. By the summer of 1957 the party was conducting a full-fledged ''Anti-Rightist Campaign'' against those who had been most outspoken. At least half a million Chinese were punished for having answered the chairman's call.
Mao gave hundreds of informal speeches, containing phrases and thoughts similar to those quoted above, but very few of them made their way into the five volumes of his official collected works. For the Mao canon was too important to be left to Mao, and batteries of senior comrades and editors were at hand to tidy up his work, remove indiscretions and try to reach a point of view consistent with whatever the party line of the time happened to be. However, for over 30 years Mao was the most revered and most feared person in China, and his words were stored in countless ways by those who heard them - in secret party archives, internal memos, private notebooks, tape-recorded transcripts. When the young Red Guards were encouraged by Mao in 1966 and 1967 to lash out at the senior officials in the party, the bureaucracy and the educational establishment, they customarily ransacked the homes and offices of their victims. In the course of these raids, much confidential material came to light. Some of it was used as evidence against the senior personnel concerned. If the words were Mao's, they were transcribed by Red Guards and circulated in various published or informal ways, as evidence - if more was needed - of Mao's creative originality as a thinker. Occasionally bits of these collections reached scholars in the west and were translated there; two important examples were the pieces published by Jerome Chen in 1970 as ''Mao Papers'' and by Stuart Schram in ''Mao Tse-tung Unrehearsed'' (1974).
Now, in ''The Secret Speeches of Chairman Mao,'' Roderick MacFarquhar, a professor of government at Harvard University, together with Timothy Cheek of Colorado College and Eugene Wu, the librarian of Harvard's East Asian collection, have edited a remarkably comprehensive collection of these informal Maoist texts. Wisely, I think, they have chosen to focus on just two key events in China's recent history, rather than using a scattershot approach that would give a little taste of many topics.
Their focus on The Hundred Flowers Movement of 1957 and the Great Leap Forward of 1958 is particularly apt, because each presents such a different side of Mao's character and his approach to politics. The Hundred Flowers texts show Mao almost as a petitioner among his own people, ''a wandering lobbyist,'' as he described himself in a talk to army cadres in Nanjing. He is genial, relaxed, sharp in comment but open to give and take. The Great Leap Forward texts, by contrast, show a much darker side of his character - angry, impatient, visionary, uninterested in arguments that might have brought him back to earth.
Obviously, these texts, by such a major political actor, collected in such informal ways, raise complex problems of authenticity. Mr. Cheek, in an opening essay called ''Textually Speaking,'' confronts this problem directly, reflects on the pros and cons of the authenticity of different texts, collates various speeches from different editions with their variant forms and with official published versions where possible, and concludes the speeches published here are genuinely the words of Mao. Mr. Cheek knows the field extremely well and has had the help of an international array of Chinese analysts, along with the bibliographic skills of Mr. Wu (who directs an essay of his own to similar problems), so I accept this judgment, especially since Mr. Cheek is not dogmatic about the works in question and tells us when he has doubts.
As Mr. Cheek nicely phrases it, in Mao's earlier official collected works, Mao himself accepted the need for a ''consensual approach to his own deification,'' whereas in the official collections published by the Communist Party since Mao's death in 1976, one gets a kind of ''academic theology'' in which '' 'scientific,' linguistic and historical analyses seek to contribute to a living faith.'' In contrast, the Red Guard editions that never ceased praising Mao, ''genius'' editions as Mr. Cheek calls them, provide both ''a gold mine of political and psychological data for Mao studies'' and ''a cesspool of run-on sentences, obscure grammar, and simple nonsense for the translator.''
Three other essays by eminent China scholars help to give us a valuable set of contexts in which to read Mao's informal texts. Mr. MacFarquhar's opening essay, as one would expect from the leading expert on both the Hundred Flowers Movement and the origins and implementation of the Great Leap Forward, gives an excellent overview of Mao's state of mind as he argued with his senior party colleagues over the need for change and criticism at the center. Benjamin I. Schwartz gives a moving analysis of Mao's ''deep anxieties, soaring exaltations, injured pride, deep resentments, and unexamined complacencies.'' Mr. Schwartz concludes that the ideas behind the Great Leap were more central to Mao's being than those of the Hundred Flowers, and presented an apocalyptically utopian view of the fusion of his mind with those of China's masses (as opposed to the bourgeois intellectuals) that represented Mao's ''final spiritual resting place.'' Merle Goldman, looking at the Mao of the late 1950's from the vantage point of her deep familiarity with the manifestations of political and literary dissent in China, explains how the Hundred Flowers slogans sprang from Communist Party intellectual history - specifically, from an earlier 1951 Maoist analysis of the Beijing Opera tradition and from the roots of a historiographical academic debate that Mao refused to pass judgment on. She also shows how Mao was enraged with his propaganda chiefs and newspaper editors, and concludes, forcefully, that Mao comes across in these talks as ''contradictory, repetitious, and obsessed.''
What, then, are the central contributions made by this new collection to our knowledge of China? Perhaps the greatest is that they show us how much frank discussion was in the air during this strange period of Chinese history, and how difficult it sometimes was for Mao to get what he wanted despite his immense prestige. The final impression is that Mao felt so far above the fray, even while so grubbily absorbed in it, that he ceased to have any clear sense of the country's terrible suffering. People really had become ciphers to him, mere details on the way to some ultimate colossal goal. ''In the past during the revolution numerous people died without asking anything in return. Why can't it be like that now?'' Mao asked his senior colleagues in August 1958 as he discussed the Great Leap. Maybe they should think of letting the peasants have two days' rest a month, he ruminated a little later, but then at once modified the thought: ''during the busy season, rest a little less,'' he said, and eat and sleep at the work site too, to save precious time. ''This point should be written in the documents but not be talked about too much,'' he told his colleagues. Sometimes Mao's thoughts strayed to stranger zones: to great wide roads in every commune with no trees on their verges so that every road would be an airport; or to a world of Chinese so healthy that physicians would have no patients, and could go till the fields and do research.
Almost everything Mao was saying in 1957 was something students and workers wanted to discuss with their own Government in 1989. Perhaps most ironically, it was presumably Hu Yaobang, then directing the Communist Youth League, who tried to give Mao accurate information on student unrest. Hu Yaobang's own death in April 1989 was the initial spark that culminated in the June tragedy, even though the deeper causes had been smoldering a long time. As Mr. MacFarquhar says, this 1989 Tiananmen crisis ''would almost certainly have the same numbing effect on China's intellectual elite as the Anti-Rightist Campaign, and could deter rural and urban entrepreneurs and foreign investors.''
As we can now see, thanks to these texts, the paradoxes at the center of this Government were paradoxes that lay also at the heart of Mao's being. Or, as Mr. Schwartz puts it so beautifully in his essay: ''In the end, on the level of his final abstract vision, Chairman Mao may be not so much 'alone with the masses' as alone with himself.''
 
THE CHAIRMAN, UNEDITED
 One added richness in this strange and absorbing book is that if we so choose we can take any one of Mao's off-the-cuff draft speeches and then see how it compares with the final party version (if there is one). To do this in the case of one of Mao's most famous speeches, ''On the Correct Handling of Contradictions Among the People,'' is a fascinating exercise. The history of this speech is more than usually devious, since Mao initially delivered it on Feb. 27, 1957, to a large group of nonparty intellectuals and bureaucrats, whom he was trying to persuade to join in the Hundred Flowers Campaign. It was not published at the time, to Mao's anger. But after he himself swung against the protesters, he apparently acquiesced in the publication of a totally revised version in The People's Daily of Peking on June 19, 1957. This latter version was doctored to make it appear that Mao wanted the Hundred Flowers Campaign to serve as a vehicle of class struggle, and that he anticipated trouble from the start.
The ''speaking notes'' for the original speech that have now surfaced bear almost no relation at all to the mood or content of the dogmatic and tedious June 19 version. The newly discovered version occupies 58 pages of ''The Secret Speeches of Chairman Mao,'' and there is a surprise on nearly every page. Some examples must serve for the whole: Mao's frank discussion of the troubles in Poland and Hungary, his sense that the people wanted two news agencies in competition with each other, his analysis of the way China's national bourgeoisie is not an enemy, his frank announcement that 770,000 Chinese were killed in the mass campaigns of 1950 to 1954, his portrayal of the constructive role of student protests in modern Chinese history, his analysis of problems in China's cooperatives and his estimate that in some areas 15 percent of the households were ''lacking grain,'' his mention that many Chinese now feel ''disgust with Marxism.'' Among other important things Mao discussed in February that never made it to the June text were the urgent need for birth control in China, the fact that 40 percent of school-age children had no schools to go to, and the fact that during 1956 China had been troubled by a mass of protests and strikes: 7,000 students protesting in 28 different cities, according to Communist Youth League figures, and 50 strikes conducted by urban workers, some involving over 1,000 workers, according to statistics Mao admitted were still incomplete.
 
JONATHAN D. SPENCE

HEADLINE: STYLISH TO THE END

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SHENKER; Joseph Shenker is president of the Bank Street College of Education.

 BODY:

A FIRST DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY
What Our Children Need to Know.
Edited by E. D. Hirsch Jr.
with William G. Rowland Jr. and Michael Stanford.
Illustrated. 271 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95.
The debate is not about Kermit the Frog versus the Three Little Pigs, Willie Mays versus Babe Ruth or investment versus savings. Some of these terms are defined in E. D. Hirsch Jr.'s well-presented new effort, ''A First Dictionary of Cultural Literacy,'' and some are not. The issue is really whether our primary educational focus should be on rote memory of certain facts - any facts - or on developing the tools and processes whereby students learn. 
This new book, which succeeds Mr. Hirsch's philosophic treatise ''Cultural Literacy'' and its successor, ''A Dictionary of Cultural Literacy,'' presents 21 neatly designed categories of terms, definitions and concepts in such subjects as American history, geography, the natural and physical sciences, mathematics, literature and mythology. Accompanied by photographs, line drawings and well-made maps, this compendium was compiled with the assistance of hundreds of teachers, administrators and parents from all 50 states. According to the author, it represents nothing less than 80 percent of what every child should know by the the end of sixth grade.
In essence, the Hirsch dictionary purports to add up to much more than the sum of its definitions. Not only does it propose to serve as a measuring stick for youngsters' store of culture-based knowledge, but it also pretends to serve as a vehicle for a successful life. The subtitle proclaims directly and emphatically that these are the facts that students ''need to know.'' The introduction elaborates, stating that schools are widening the gap between haves and have-nots by teaching skills rather than facts, thus sending a clear if misleading message to parents: If your child knows these facts, he or she will be part of the ''haves'' society.
Underlying this book is Mr. Hirsch's belief that the lack of a common knowledge base is widening the gap between the privileged and the underprivileged in our society. Joining the legions of critics of the schools, he paints a picture of an increasingly illiterate society with growing numbers of dropouts contributing to a growing underclass of have-nots. According to Mr. Hirsch, who teaches English at the University of Virginia, creating a body of facts, information and concepts that everyone learns in common would lead to greater ease of communication among all classes of people.
The problems Mr. Hirsch is concerned about are hardly new; they've been with us ever since the great wave of immigration at the end of the 19th century - ever since, that is, we became a truly pluralistic society. And the debate about how to achieve community amid diversity is not new either. Then as now, some argued for a set body of knowledge to be learned across the country, while others argued for a curriculum that was more locally determined and that took into account the needs and capacities of the learners. Then as now, educational reform was seen as the cure for social and economic ills.
Can we honestly put an entire country's economic shortcomings at the doorstep of our schools? Aren't there other major factors that have helped to create and in fact widen the gap between the privileged and underprivileged - factors like racism and the recent decline in funding for social programs, for example?
Mr. Hirsch also ignores a lot of what we know about how children learn. First of all, learning is active. Gone is the day when we naively believed that children were pure empty tablets waiting to be printed on, or empty receptacles waiting to be filled (to use two common metaphors). Children are active, curious, opinionated and selective. Tell a 7-year-old that a cloud is a mass of condensed water or ice particles (a term defined by Mr. Hirsch in the dictionary), and the child's eyes are bound to glaze over. But set up an experiment that demonstrates condensation, and the child is bound not only to become interested but to remember what condensation and clouds are all about. Experiencing the reality behind the concepts, an essential part of early learning, insures understanding and knowledge that becomes a part of the learner.
Second, learning is social. Children learn in the classroom through interaction with their teachers and with one another. This back-and-forth human exchange about the curriculum provides motivation and excitement, helps children to be engaged in their learning and supports them in their struggles to learn what they need and want to know.
Third, children come to school already knowing a great deal; they learn in many other places, and often they learn more profoundly there than they do in school. The confidence and self-esteem all children need in order to achieve and to become productive adults is more likely to develop in schools where their knowledge, their experiences and their cultures are respected and taken as a starting place for their schooling.
Addressing the issue of educational content without simultaneously considering processes whereby children learn creates an unnatural dichotomy. In learning, form and function are inseparable. Children need healthy, positive, common schooling experiences, in addition to a common curriculum core, if they are truly to acquire the kind of knowledge that will prepare them for the pluralistic society in which we live. Simply remembering the same facts will not produce a classroom of tolerant, curious and participatory citizens.
If one wanted to ignore Mr. Hirsch's assumptions and look specifically at the definitions, there is no end to the arguments that one could have. For example, under United States Geography, Arizona is defined as ''a state in the Southwest.'' Is this definition an appropriate indicator of cultural literacy? If one is to know what Arizona is, shouldn't one know a little something about it - that it is where the Grand Canyon is, or that it is populated, in part, by Navajos?
In sum, this dictionary is much less than it appears to be. Taken without its pretentious introduction and organization, the book is worthy of shelf space in the young reader's library - just as a specialized crossword puzzle dictionary is useful for the crossword game. But beware of considering it a trusty guide, index or dictionary for the pursuit of precise knowledge - for use by parent, teacher or child. And clearly, Mr. Hirsch's ''First Dictionary of Cultural Literacy'' is not a necessary tool for a fulfilling, successful life.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 3, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1781 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
Free Agency Sets Record for Number of Signings in One Day

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The trade mart never had a chance. Its cousin, the free-agent market, overwhelmed everything and everyone in its relentless path.
''With all the free agents out there, they dominated the discussions,'' Dave Dombrowksi, the Montreal Expos' general manager, said, reviewing last week's winter meetings in Nashville. ''You spend all your time talking to an agent, and you're mentally exhausted afterward. If you don't get him, you're frustrated on top of it and you have to regroup. Everybody kept saying they had to go back and regroup. I never heard that expression used as much as I heard it during the week. But it's true.''
Dombrowski and his fellow general managers had reason to feel overwhelmed. Last Thursday, 12 free agents reached agreement with teams for a one-day record in the 14-year history of free agency. With the seven free agents who accepted contracts the previous day, a two-day record was established. Twenty-four free agents worked out new contracts during the week. That, too, was a record. 
The date Dec. 7 has become the date to watch in free agency. Last year, 11 free agents gained new contracts on that date, only one less than the 12 who reached agreement on Dec. 7 this year. In 1987, the number was eight. On only one other day, Jan. 8, 1986, have as many as eight free agents signed new contracts.
Based on this year's frenzied activity, perhaps at next year's meetings the players' agents can set up the kind of booths that each year fill the hotel's exhibit hall, enabling vendors to show off their wares to visiting major league and minor league club officials. Instead of perusing uniforms, equipment and merchandise, general managers can negotiate contracts with the agents, strolling from booth to booth. At the front of the hall, a large scoreboard can keep track of the amount of money spent.
''It's like there's this giant credit card in the sky and everybody keeps drawing on it,'' Sandy Alderson, general manager of the Oakland Athletics, said.
The Athletics and the Expos were the teams hardest hit by free agency. The Expos lost three-fifths of their starting pitching rotation and are virtually certain to lose the outfielder Hubie Brooks, too. Three members of the Athletics signed with other teams, stripping the World Series champions of a significant amount of their depth. Gone are Dave Parker, Tony Phillips and Storm Davis.
''Obviously, we're affected to some extent,'' Alderson said. ''Each of those players played an important role for us last season. But we still have the nucleus of our team intact. The new economics will prevent us from keeping that nucleus unless we begin making choices now.''
The Athletics chose not to give Parker the two-year contract he sought (Milwaukee did), not to give Phillips more than perhaps $1.5 million for two years (Detroit gave him $4 million for three) and not to come anywhere near matching the $6 million Kansas City gave Davis for three years.
The Athletics re-signed Ken Phelps as a free agent to assume part of Parker's designated-hitter role. Barring a trade or a signing, Todd Burns could take Davis's spot in the rotation. They need a utility infielder.
Oakland's status in next season's American League West race could be determined more by the improvement of other teams than by any slip the Athletics may suffer.
The California Angels, who already had good pitching, added Mark Langston. If they could sign Mark Davis for their bullpen and Robin Yount for the outfield, deals that would sorely strain the giant credit card in the sky, the Angels would be formidable.
The Royals, with Davis joining the rotation, have strengthened their pitching, as they wanted to do, but Davis won 19 games with Oakland (despite a 4.36 earned run average) because of the team's strong relief crew (he averaged 5.5 innings per start).
 
Game Goes Round and Round
Eventually, general managers will get around to making more trades. When they do, Lee Smith will leave the Boston Red Sox and relieve elsewhere (Jeff Reardon has supplanted him). Tim Leary will most likely move into a pitching rotation other than Cincinnati's, maybe the Yankees'. Kansas City seems intent on trading Danny Tartabull.
Houston wants to trade Bill Doran, its second baseman, but clubs are wary of his back. The Astros offered Doran to Milwaukee for Glenn Braggs, but the Brewers would rather trade Rob Deer. Seattle is looking to trade Jeffrey Leonard, Atlanta has Gerald Perry to swap for a catcher and Baltimore would trade Phil Bradley for the right hitter.
 
Tigers Finally Succumb
The Tigers actually signed Tony Phillips to a three-year contract for $4 million? The Tigers signed Lloyd Moseby, another free agent, to a two-year contract for $3 million? The Tigers? Yes, the same Tigers who long have been one of the staunchest foes of free agency. Free agents and the Tigers always went together like pastrami and pizza. So why the sudden change in philosophy?
''It's not a change,'' Jim Campbell, the club's president, said. ''It's maybe surfaced a little more. We've always taken the approach that we consider each individual case at the time. We haven't signed too many free agents, but we've done things we haven't taken public. We made offers to Bobby Grich and Wayne Garland, but we never went public with it. Why? Because if you do, it might discourage the kid you might be replacing. I'd rather take a beating than have the kid think we're trying to replace him.''
Grich and Garland were among the first group of 25 free agents in 1976. The Tigers signed another of those 25, Tito Fuentes.
But their interest, public or private, in free agents was highly questionable. In the days when clubs drafted negotiating rights to free agents, the Tigers went for five successive years, 1978 through 1982, without drafting rights to anyone. After Fuentes, they didn't sign another free agent (from another club) until 1983, then not again until Phillips and Moseby.
''The Pettis deal woke them up,'' a man familiar with the Tigers' thinking said.
Tom Monaghan, the owner, and Campbell, the source said, recognized that the team, which finished with the worst record in the majors, had to be changed. Bill Lajoie, the general manager, asked how they could change it if they weren't going to pay players.
Gary Pettis was a prime example. The Tigers' busiest outfielder last season, Pettis was a free agent but defected to the Texas Rangers, who included a $160,000 signing bonus in his three-year, $2.66 million contract.
''The only reason they lost Pettis,'' the source said, ''was they refused to pay a signing bonus. They lost Pettis for a $160,000 signing bonus.''
The Tigers are suffering from famine in their farm system, and they cannot afford to trade the few marketable players they have. Once the realization sunk in that the team had a better chance of becoming worse than better, the Tigers began pursuing free agents.
''Money wasn't going to stop them from putting a competitive team on the field,'' the source said.
They signed Phillips first, snatching the infielder - he will play third base - away from the Yankees, whose trade with Cincinnati for Tim Leary fell through because of their inability to get Phillips. The Tigers tried to sign a first baseman, Kent Hrbek or Pete O'Brien, but failed in spite of their luxurious offers. They succeeded in their next quest, adding Moseby to their outfield, and they continue to survey the remaining field of free agents.
Reflecting on the $15.5 million offer to Hrbek, Campbell said, ''When you stop to think that we offered a kid three times more than Mr. Fetzer paid for the franchise in 1956 or 1957, it boggles your mind. But everything has gone up.''
Including the rating of the Tigers' connection to reality.
 
Gullickson Is No Ryan
A year ago the Houston Astros refused to give Nolan Ryan more than $1.2 million to extend his nine-year tenure with them. Not surprisingly, the remarkable right-hander bolted to the Rangers, where he surpassed the 5,000-strikeout plateau and pitched a series of near no-hitters.
Now the Astros sign a pitcher, Bill Gullickson, who has pitched in Japan the last two seasons, and they give him a guaranteed $900,000 and will pay him an instant $510,000 additional for a total of $1.41 million if he opens the season with them. Gullickson will also earn $13,000 for each start and $6,500 for each relief appearance. If he makes 30 starts, his bonus would total $390,000 for a neat package of $1.8 million.
 
Reds Look Down the Road
The Cincinnati Reds traded John Franco, their No. 1 relief pitcher, and continue to try to trade Tim Leary, one of their starting pitchers. The Reds wanted to find more late-inning relief work for Rob Dibble and thought it would be more harmonious to team him with Randy Myers than with Franco, the established veteran (Manager Lou Piniella saw first-hand that teaming Sparky Lyle with Rich (Goose) Gossage didn't work in the Yankees' bullpen in 1978).
The Reds, however, have other reasons for their trades. Franco was part of a significant contingent of front-line players who can be free agents after next season, and the cost of signing them all would be enormous. With Franco gone, the group includes Eric Davis, the team's No. 1 hitter; and Danny Jackson, Tom Browning and Leary, members of the starting rotation. The Reds can have Myers for three seasons before he can be a free agent.
 
SIGNS OF THE TIMES
 
In recent weeks, free agents and other players have signed contracts providing some of the biggest raises ever achieved in baseball. These have been the largest percentage increases, based on average annual value of their old and new contracts.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Cunningham Still Hears About That Sweet Moment

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
This has been a particularly swinish season, even by the bullyragging standards of the National Football League. So many coaches and players have indulged in charges of cowardice, foul play and even bounty hunting that one amateur bacteriologist fears an outbreak of the dreaded ''Ditka virus.''
Fortunately, in the midst of this brutish business, one individual produced one scintillating play that saved the season almost single-handedly. Or single-footedly, in this case. 
Said effort took place last Sunday in a vital contest between the New York Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles, two old foes from the days when stalwarts played both offense and defense, if you can imagine that.
With the wind blowing garbage straight out of the toxic swamps of east Jersey, at right angles into the players' faces, last Sunday's game seemed destined to be decided by one epic play.
''That's the history between these two clubs,'' said Randall Cunningham, the Eagles' quarterback-historian.
That one play happened in the fourth period, after the Giants had pinned razzle-dazzle Randall on the 2-yard line. If this were a sport of versatility like soccer or rugby, one of the lads on the field would have had to boot the ball out of danger. But this is football, so one expected to see the quarterback trot obediently off the field and turn the punting over to an automaton.
But as the ball was snapped, one suddenly became aware that Cunningham himself was standing in the end zone. Before one could say ''Sammy Baugh,'' Cunningham had kicked a punt so pure, so true, that one suspected the network of providing sound effects: wooomp! Like a cannon.
The ball soared like something Roy Hobbs would have kicked if Bernard Malamud had made the Natural a footballer instead of a slugger-pitcher. It just took off, aided of course by the brutal wind, hypnotizing a young man named Meggett who wanted no part of that possibly radioactive object.
When it stopped rolling, the punt had traveled 91 official yards, third longest in history. Naturally, the Eagles won the game, after which the Giant coach, Bill Parcells, castigated young Meggett, his quarterback, Phil Simms, and a young lineman named Moore for allegedly having an anxiety attack that caused him to miss most of the game. Moore said it was the flu. Well, there's something going around this season. Ditka virus.
Since Sunday, Cunningham has discovered that everybody wants to talk about that collision between shoe leather and football leather. Quarterbacks, after all, don't do punts anymore.
''Yeah, everybody says, 'Good punt, good punt,' '' Cunningham admitted during a brief interlude from practice. ''I think it's one of those plays that people will remember, a play with special meaning.''
Cunningham should have been on the sidelines, talking with somebody in a baseball cap with a headset connection to coaches in the eaves. But John Teltschik had been injured, and Max Runager had been coaxed out of retirement, and Cunningham, once the nation's leading punter while at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, had been put in a state of ready alert.
''Before the game, Buddy told me he might want to run a fake punt,'' Cunningham said, referring to Buddy Ryan, the head coach. ''I said, 'Fine.' With the wind at our back, I signaled him that I wanted to punt.''
He had that increasingly rare instinct that he could get his team out of trouble one way or the other, like Larry Bird in a basketball huddle snarling, ''Just give me the doggone ball.''
''Everybody did their assignments,'' Cunningham said of the blocking. ''The snap came back and the wind affected it, made it dip real fast. I knew I hit it pretty hard, but it was not a good spiral and it wouldn't turn over.''
A baseball fan on the telephone asked Cunningham to compare the punt to a Reggie Jackson-Jose Canseco home run, sometimes referred to as ''getting all of it.'' Cunningham said, ''Gee, I don't know, I never played baseball,'' but he accepted the comparison to that rare tee shot when the golf ball feels that it might fly clear over Mount Blanc.
In a sense, that football is still airborne, sighted on every biff-bam-pow segment of the evening news, soaring like a runaway Sputnik or an eternal comet, in orbit forever. It gives us something to dream about when the going gets grubby, as it certainly has this season.
It was only a few years ago that Tom Boswell of The Washington Post gave us 99 Reasons Why Baseball Is Better Than Football. In these inflationary times, the list is now up to about 135.
In a sport always preaching teamwork and respect, Mike Ditka announced to the world that his Chicago team had quit a few games back. Joe Walton, the coach of the Jets, was offended when his running back, Freeman McNeil, was devastated at innocently destroying an opponent's knee.
The players have hardly been immune. Jim Burt, dropped by the Giants and picked up by the 49ers, said he would love to run over his old coach, Parcells, on some sideline, any sideline. Oh, yes, and Jim McMahon blew his nose at a reporter who had dared to ask him a question. That was a few months ago, but there has been no reaction from the Chargers or the league. Without instant replay, it appears, they are lost. Also, a Miami defender accused Ken O'Brien of the Jets of flinching at the goal line.
But far worse than a quarterback protecting his battered body was the crouch by the Players Association. After a few losses in court, the leaders announced that the association might decertify itself.
Another low moment came when Jimmy Johnson of the Dallas Cowboys, who combs his hair with buttered toast, said he had heard that Buddy Ryan had set a bounty on the Cowboys' quarterback and kicker. The N.F.L. says there's no proof of anything, but the two teams go at it again this afternoon and the league presumably has spotters all over the stadium to catch any bounty hits. Personally speaking, I'd rather see Randall Cunningham punt.

LENGTH: 1530 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVE: Housing Rehabilitation;
The 'Turnkey' Approach Tried in Harlem

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IT is only one small building, but the transformation in progress at a vacant and rundown five-story walk-up at 460 Convent Avenue, at the corner of 150th Street in central Harlem, has something to say about the way gut-rehabilitated housing can be produced for low-income working people and the homeless in New York City.
The developer is Housing & Services, a nonprofit housing corporation. The builder is a small Queens contractor. The construction lender is the Atlantic Bank of New York. And the entity promising to provide the permanent mortgage for the 21 apartments when construction is finished is the State of New York, through the Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
What is unusual about this project, as opposed to hundreds of similar ones being done for low- to moderate-income people in vacant, city-owned, tax-foreclosed buildings, is that it is being done on a ''turnkey'' basis: The project is guaranteed a permanent state mortgage of $1.6 million once it is completed to the agreed-upon specifications. The guarantee enabled the builder to obtain the construction loan. 
The ultimate owner, in this case, will be a nonprofit community corporation, the Genesis II Museum of International Black Culture. The beneficiaries will be 21 low-income families, 12 of them paying rent of $485 or $610 a month for one- or two-bedroom apartments, and eight paying welfare-rent allowances, currently $312 a month for a two-bedroom and $225 for a one-bedroom. One apartment is for the superintendent. The welfare families have ''very low'' incomes - under 30 percent of the median for the metropolitan area, or less than $10,000.
While this is only one small project, it is notable for the different approach it takes from the ones that New York City has adopted for a much bigger pipeline of housing it is gut-rehabilitating for the same income level of beneficiaries, including some who are in transitional facilities for the homeless.
The issues these projects raise have nothing to do with the availability of public money for the effort. In fact, more than enough money for production is already available from state and city sources to produce more units than the delivery system can effectively build. Delivery time is often interminable, especially in those programs designed and built entirely or in part to assist the homeless, and costs per unit are sometimes unacceptably high.
Facing a city-owned inventory of 53,000 vacant apartments when he took office as Housing Commissioner in 1986, Paul A. Crotty began to implement a $5.1 billion, 10-year housing plan that included efforts to recycle 53,000 vacant units. Under Mr. Crotty's successor, Abraham Biderman, 38,000 of these units have construction commitments or have reached the construction phase.
BUT a large part of the production is turning out to cost much more than expected. The original estimate for average hard costs - labor and materials - was $60,000 to $65,000 an apartment. But in the South Bronx, the 893 units that were contracted out to Lehrer McGovern Bovis as construction manager, with the Settlement Housing Fund as prospective manager, have been built to higher specifications and are producing hard costs of $90,000 an apartment, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development reports.
And 727 Harlem units, for which Tishman Construction Corporation is the construction manager and the New York City Housing Authority is the prospective manager, are turning out to have hard costs of at least $100,000 a unit.
The New York City Community Preservation Corporation, a bank consortium that is the principal construction lender for the vacant-building rehabilitations, has managed lower hard costs. Its technique, as an experienced construction lender for rehabilitations of both occupied and unoccupied buildings, has been to put owner-builders at financial risk of losing their profits if they do not finish within budget on time. If costs rise, the builder swallows the losses because the permanent loan, already committed, is fixed.
Over 15 years, the corporation has been construction and permanent lender for rehabilitations of 23,500 apartments, usually in occupied buildings. In the city's Vacant Building Program, one phase of the 10-year program, it is the financier as construction lender for 3,500 apartments being built or completed. Hard costs have averaged $56,000 an apartment.
The average city subsidy per apartment has been $36,000, usually in the form of a 1 percent loan. Rents are typically $150 to $175 a room a month, or $550 to $700 a month for a two-bedroom apartment. Consistency and uniformity in the development process have been essential for success, said Michael D. Lappin, president of the corporation.
He also says, and the state's turnkey project suggests it as well, that more low-overhead small builders can be drawn into the rehabilitation of city-owned buildings than have been so far. To keep costs down, they must risk losing profits if cost schedules are not met. After the job specifications are established, city reviewers should be out of the picture and the construction lender should supervise.
However, not many construction lenders are ready to accept the risks themselves. If there are cost overruns, who will bail them out if the permanent mortgage committed by the city, for example, is inadequate to cover building and operating costs?
Thus the state's turnkey approach may have limited application unless the state itself is ready to accept more risk through stronger guarantees to swallow cost overruns. The lenders will be timid, but Mr. Lappin thinks there is no shortage of willing builders. ''Initial concerns that there would not be a sufficient number of qualified builder-developers to undertake the projected scale of rebuilding of city-owned buildings have proven unfounded,'' he said.
According to builders, this can be achieved for very-low-income, debt-free housing, so long as the development process is free of bureaucratic delays and they get payments on dependable schedules and reliable construction specifications that are not altered during construction.
In Harlem, the state is experimenting with this approach in the Convent Avenue rehabilitation. The permanent-loan commitment of $1.69 million comes from appropriation of $128 million the Legislature set aside for turnkey gut-rehabilitations to benefit low-income people statewide.
The nonprofit developer, Housing & Services, evolved in 1987 into an independent concern to assist community organizations after years of work as an affiliate of the Vera Institute of Justice, with responsibility for finding housing for ex-offenders.
For the Convent Avenue project to work as a turnkey, said Claire Haaga, president of Housing & Services, the nonprofit developer needs site control from the city and an experienced, reliable contractor ''with whom we're comfortable working'' and a bank willing to provide construction financing. The budget, said Ms. Haaga, is tight.
The builder-contractor, Constantine D.& B. Ltd. of Queens., for a fee of $1.319 million, or $62,800 an apartment, will be obliged to complete the project within 13 months of the construction-loan closing this month with the Atlantic Bank. A hard-cost budget of $62,800 in a gut-rehabilitation is within the range of what the city and state agree is reasonable.
It has been possible for the small nonprofit developer with no equity assets to undertake such a project, said Ms. Haaga, largely because it had developed a successful relationship with an experienced contractor. The predevelopment period must be short - in this case five months - so the contractor can make realistic bids that will hold up by the time the construction loan was funded. Also, the contractor and construction lender must be confident of flexibility and quick decision-making from the developer during the construction process, she said. Adjustments are usually necessary.
On Convent Avenue, the total state mortgage commitment of $1.69 million, or $80,500 an apartment, allows $306,000 for soft costs, or $17,700 an apartment. This includes $5,700 an apartment for interest on the 11 percent construction loan, assuming the job is finished and turned over to the state in 12 months.
When projects drag out, total costs can go up ''another 20 percent easily'' - or to at least $100 a square foot, said Constantine Ioannou, president of Constantine D. & B. At $100 a square foot, it would cost the government $2 million to build 20 new debt-free apartments. Mr. Ioannou is a general contractor who has built market-rate condominiums in Harlem and is a regular customer of the Atlantic Bank.
When the construction lender has confidence in the contractor, it may be willing to make such a loan to a nonprofit developer that is not risking its own cash. But it will also need assurance that if there are cost overruns and the scenario fails, it will be able to foreclose and rent out the project at market rates sufficient to justify the loan. Without this assurance, the government probably will have to be ready to assume the risk, take over the project and swallow the loss.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Wallingford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
INCORPORATED in 1670 on the same 39.6 square miles of the Quinnipiac River Valley that it occupies today, Wallingford is one of Connecticut's oldest towns and one of the most stable. The scent of its early agricultural economy still drifts downwind from the handful of remaining dairy farms where cows graze, withered cornstalks rustle in the wind and pumpkins dot the wintry fields.
Beginning in the 1830's, industrial growth focused largely on sterling silver and silver-plate manufacturing, giving Wallingford and its neighbor, Meriden, a monopoly on the country's silver production for more than a century.
After World War II the industry succumbed to competition from stainless steel and imports, and in 1986 the Wallace International Silver Company, the last of the major concerns, was bought out by the Syratech Corporation and moved to Syracuse.
A serious hole in the economy was averted over the last two decades by companies - among them Bristol-Myers, Northeast Datacom, American Cyanamid, Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation and Revere Aerospace - that settled into four new industrial parks and along the town's central north-south business strip between Route 15 and Interstate 91. 
The rest of Wallingford is residential, containing some 16,000 dwellings, of which fewer than 2,000 are condominiums.
From 1950 to 1970 the population doubled, to 36,000. Since then growth has slowed but is poised to take off again once the market improves because the town has more than 4,000 acres of vacant residentially zoned land. It also has comparatively low housing prices and a convenient location 10 miles north of New Haven, 25 miles south of Hartford and straddling I-91 and Route 15.
James McLaughlin, of McLaughlin Real Estate, whose company is one of 20 local real estate concerns, said ''the town can be likened to a shirt, with a collar that's half blue and half white.'' These days the white collars are gaining. ''More than half the buyers are from out of town,'' he said.
In 1986 minimum zoning in the eastern sector was increased to three acres as a protection for the watershed. This has forced the construction of larger homes at prices that local people can rarely afford. For the first time Wallingford homes are approaching the million-dollar mark and are finding buyers.
A 5-bedroom, 4,100-square-foot Tudor with a 20-foot-high, oak-beamed greatroom paneled in cherry, granite kitchen counters and marble and hardwood floors was recently sold for $900,000 by Geremia Development Corporation at its Turnberry Estates, a subdivision being built on Turnberry Road. ''In Greenwich this house would go for $2 million,'' Bryan Geremia, company president, said.
THIRTY lots on the 100-acre, cluster-zoned tract range from 1.5 to five acres. A three-acre vacant parcel recently sold for $225,000; a colonial was sold for $600,000 and a Cape Cod is available for $745,000. A million dollar-plus home will be built in the spring.
Twelve homes at Woodlands, a clustered subdivision of 58 lots on 75 acres off Mansion Road, have been sold for $330,000 to $410,000 with four bedrooms and up to 3,600 square feet. Homes at Countryside East off Pond Hill Road sell for around $240,000.
A 252-unit condominium complex called Judd Square, almost completed at 42 South Cherry Street, was converted from a century-old drapery-rod factory.
''The buildings are like the Rock of Gibraltar, with 16-inch-thick walls,'' said Theodore Lendler, a partner in Judd Associates, developers of the $20 million project.
Old areaways have been turned into landscaped atriums with access from common hallways. One- and two-bedroom units of 900 to 1,100 square feet are selling for $72,000 to $99,000 and the developers offer mortgages at 6 percent based on a 30-year amortization, with a balloon payment of the balance in 10 years.
A condominium conversion of 120 units by a local developer, Donald Ahearn, on Parker Street is called Parker Perry. The former wire factory, built in 1882, has units at $80,000 to $100,000. Mr. Ahearn also built a number of rental projects, including 112 two-bedroom units at The Towers, off Harrison Road. Prices average around $500 a month for 1,100 square feet.
There are also more than 200 resales, which are priced from $120,000 to $350,000-plus, with the largest percentage in the $150,000 to $250,000 range. Prices are more than one-third less than for comparable homes in Fairfield County.
While 1,200-square-foot, 30-year-old Cape Cods at $120,000 are too expensive for local first-time buyers, they are not for young people from other towns. Louise Denegre Josun, a Hartford lawyer, moved to a 100-year-old house on Fair Street three months ago with her husband, a teacher in New Haven. ''We grew up in Cheshire - now outside our price range and too suburban,'' Mrs. Josun said. ''Here we have parks, shopping, the library, all within walking distance.''
She hopes that her street will be included in a proposed historic district of 17th- to early 20th-century homes along Main Street, so far stalled because of homeowners' fears of restrictions. ''The Choate campus I think helps stabilize the neighborhood,'' said Mrs. Josun, which she described as ''taking a step back in time - a close-knit atmosphere with a sense of community. You don't get much of that any more.''
Choate Rosemary Hall, a prep school where tuition, room and board are $14,800 a year, occupies 400 acres on Christian Street. Few local families can afford Choate, which is coed and the only private school in town, but the public school system, with 6,000 pupils in 7 elementary, 2 middle and 2 high schools is well regarded.
SIX years ago the town began a differentiated diploma program, in which high-school students may take more difficult English and math exams each year, qualifying them for a differentiated diploma, ''a certificate indicating that they have gone that extra step,'' said Clelia Tenerowicz, assistant superintendent for curriculum. About 65 percent of Wallingford's students go to college.
In a partnership with Bristol-Myers, the high schools run eight-week summer programs for advanced math and science students.
New Haven's theaters, restaurants and museums provide most of Wallingford's cultural and night life, except for concerts by the Wallingford Symphony Orchestra and theatrical productions housed in the Paul Mellon Center for the Arts on the Choate campus. In addition, the Oakdale Summer Musical Theater in Wallingford features concerts by such name entertainers as Julie Andrews and Kenny Rogers.
The newest gathering spot is a Super Stop and Shop supermarket that opened a few months ago on Route 5, where townspeoplemeet friends and socialize on Saturday mornings.
Golfers pay initiation fees of $4,500 and $7,500 respectively at the Wallingford Golf Club and Farms Country Club. The Farms Club also offers tennis and a swimming pool. Annual dues are $3,200 and memberships are for families only. At times there is a seven-year waiting list. Family dues at the Wallingford Golf Club are about $1,300, less for singles. Admission takes about a year. An 18-hole golf course open to the public on the grounds of the Pilgrims Harbor condominiums on Harrison Road charges $8 and $12 daily, depending on the day and time. Annual memberships are $1,000 to $1,300.
There is no charge for use of the town's 11 public tennis courts or for many of the 145 recreation programs, from belly dancing to hockey. Walking trails cover 15 miles through some of the eight parks. Scuba diving lessons at the high-school pool cost $80, swimming in the outdoor community pool - as big as two football fields side by side - costs $4 a season and aerobics with free baby-sitting is $35 for 40 classes in eight weeks.

Government: Mayor and nine-member Town Council elected to 2-year terms. Mayor now William Dickinson, a Republican.
 
Boys and Girls Together: Choate, long regarded as an exclusive boys' prep school (John F. Kennedy, Paul Mellon, the financier, and Alan Jay Lerner, the composer, were graduates), was founded for girls in 1890 by Mary Atwater Choate. Boys were admitted in 1896 in a separate building. Around 1900, when the girls outgrew their quarters, they were given a free site in Greenwich, establishing Rosemary Hall School for Girls. In 1974 the girls moved back, occupying a new Choate complex. Among the female graduates are the actresses Jamie Lee Curtis and Glenn Close. To mark its 100th anniversary in 1990, the school will dedicate a new science building donated by Mr. Mellon and designed by I. M. Pei.

HEADLINE: Taping Suit Perplexed By Who Was Wronged

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
HALF a dozen lawyers from around the state gathered at the Attorney General's Office in Hartford last month to open the book on a series of narrow legal questions that will reverberate in Connecticut through 1990 and perhaps beyond: How many people might have had their telephone conversations improperly recorded by the state police over the last 15 years? And how are they to be notified that they might have been wronged?
If a person was arrested by the state police and later acquitted, can sealed records be reopened to send the formal legal notices required under Federal court rules? Finally, how are all the groups of possible victims - from state troopers calling their wives or husbands to defendants calling their attorneys - to be divided for legal representation when the case finally comes before a judge?
Lawyers for both sides said the questions, although technical, will form a key framework for the civil lawsuit filed last month in Federal District Court in Bridgeport against the state police by the 200-member Connecticut Criminal Defense Lawyers Association. Specifically, the questions will determine whether the case will become a class-action suit, and if so, what classes or groups of plaintiffs will be eligible to participate. 
The suit was filed after the state police taping system came to light during pre-trial testimony in a manslaughter trial in Waterbury in late October. It charges that the state police violated the United States Constitution by depriving defendants of an unfettered right to legal advice and the Federal wiretapping laws by taping other parties without their knowledge.
 
F.B.I. Takes a Look
The 982-member police force has also come under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorney's office, which has taken custody of tens of thousands of hours of tapes made at the 12 state police barracks in Connecticut. The State Public Safety Commissioner, Col. Lester J. Forst, has resigned under pressure from Gov. William A. O'Neill and the No. 2 official at the state police, Lieut. Col. John Mulligan, has been demoted.
Taping policies at four municipal police departments - Milford, Torrington, Wallingford and Willimantic - are also being scrutinized in the Federal investigation, and at least eight other local departments have been identified by the state as having the technical capability to record calls improperly.
Lawyers and state officials say that although much remains unknown about whether top officials violated civil or criminal laws, putting together the broad classes of people who may have had their rights violated will be an important first step in determining the extent of the taping.
''You've got individual troopers; you've got former troopers, retired troopers, dispatchers who are employees of the state police but not troopers,'' said Garrett M. Moore, a Waterbury lawyer who is representing the police troopers union in the class-certification discussions. ''Then you've got to look at those who have been arrested. You've got bail bondsmen, vendors who filled the soda machine at the barracks and called the boss to find out about the next stop. Stranded motorists. There are classes and subclasses.''
Lawyers involved in the discussions say the main variable in defining the groups is information. They said that although the police began taping telephone calls from police barracks in 1974, it is not known yet what records exist from that time or how many names can be culled from the files. Finding out how much information exists will also affect the cutoff date for the suit. In other words, will the suit cover callers taped from 1974 to the present, or from 1980 to the present, or some other date?
What could severely limit the flow of information are the state laws already on the books that are designed to protect some criminal defendants. For example, a person convicted of drunken driving who volunteers for an accelerated rehabilitation program has his record officially expunged of the conviction - that is, in fact, a key inducement encouraging people to take the option. Lawyers also said that although Federal court rules require personal notification if at all possible in class-action cases, some people would probably not want to come forward.
''Suppose a guy was arrested for solicitation in 1983 and never told his wife,'' said one lawyer involved in the talks who asked not to be identified. ''Now we send a letter, and she says, 'What's this?' ''
Another variable is knowledge. Under Federal wiretapping law, it is legal to tape telephone conversations if at least one party in the call knows the tape is rolling, a caveat that allows police agencies across the country to tape emergency 911 calls, for example, as long as operators know that while on the job, their conversations with the public will be recorded. That issue puts the state police troopers union in a special class, since the existence of the system was known within the force, and lawyers for the state are expected to argue that most troopers knew and are therefore ineligible.
Underlying much of the class-certification issue is strategy. Although lawyers for the state police declined to comment on the class-certification discussions, other participants said they thought the state would probably cooperate with the Defense Lawyers Association in defining at least some classes as broadly as possible.
 
Compromises Expected
They said they expected some compromise in restricting how far back in time to take the suit's coverage, but that the state would also have some motivation to avoid lots of individual suits by lumping as many plaintiffs as possible into this one case. Lawyers for the state police are from the Attorney General's office and from a private law firm retained by state insurers as co-counsel.
One lawyer who has so far filed two individual suits against the state police, John R. Williams, says he thinks such broad classes may benefit of state. Although the potential financial liability would increase with broadly defined classes, he said, many individuals can fall through the cracks, leaving the final number of plaintiffs lower than if the classes were small and intense efforts were made to notify all would-be participants.
''One of the problems with class-action suits is that it is often too difficult to notify everyone, so they cut corners,'' Mr. Williams said. For example, he said, newspaper notices, a common method of notifying people, would likely be missed by large numbers of undereducated people from lower socio-economic groups who comprise a disproportionate number of the those arrested by the police.
''People can get easily lost,'' said Mr. Williams, who plans to file two more individual Federal suits against the state this week on behalf of former criminal defendants. ''I hope that won't happen, but there's always a danger.''
 
Question of Intent
Regardless of who becomes involved in the suit, lawyers for both sides said the real crux of the taping issue will concern the question of intent. Under Federal law, a person who intentionally tapes a telephone call without the knowledge of either party is guilty of a civil offense punishable by a minimum $10,000 fine for each violation. If the person who made the tape is found to have had intentions to use the material for improper purposes - getting leads for criminal investigations, for example - the violation becomes a criminal offense punishable by up to five years in prison and $250,000 in fines.
According to a report presented to Mr. O'Neill last month by the Attorney General, Clarine Nardi Riddle, the Chief State's Attorney, John J. Kelly, and Mr. O'Neill's legal counsel, Howard G. Rifkin, the state police essentially blundered and mismanaged its way through 15 years of taping policies to a point where some privileged conversations between lawyers and their clients were violated. But the report, based on 3,500 pages of memos and interviews with 14 past and present senior state police officers, said the police had no intent to use or abuse the information that the tape machines gathered.
Since the study was released, reports of taping by other police agencies around the country have increased the likelihood that Connecticut's story may not be unique. According to a report in The Hartford Courant, the state police in West Virginia has routinely taped telephone conversations between suspects and their families or lawyers for as long as 20 years. The article also said some local police departments in Georgia and New Mexico had been accused of improper surveillance of converations between lawyers and their clients.
In issuing the report on the taping practices of the Connecticut state police, Ms. Riddle stressed that it was not the final word on the case, because the other investigations were still in progress. Responses from critics of the report also indicated that its conclusions would continue to be debated. For example, United States Representative John G. Rowland, who is considered the front-runner for the Republican gubernatorial nomination next year, has already begun using the taping issue against Mr. O'Neill.
''It was not credible to have the administration investigating the administration,'' he said in a statement after the report was released. ''Who was responsible for this policy? We still do not know.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Ballot Questions Provide A Lesson For All

BYLINE: By Finn M. W. Casperson; Finn M. W. Caspersen, chairman of the Beneficial Corporation, is a member of the New Jersey Corporate Alliance for Intelligent Growth, a coalition of leading business organizations participating in public review of the proposed New Jersey State Plan for Development and Redevelopment.

 BODY:
RARELY receiving the intense attention focused on the vote for candidates, the outcome on ballot questions can be an equally telling test of the mood of the electorate.
Their mood was tested in New Jersey on Election Day by five important bond questions worth $890 million.
In this period of marked fiscal constraint and diminished public resources, voters decisively approved all five. The issues will pay for critical programs for the environment, including farmland and open space preservation and clean water, and for human services and corrections facilities. 
This sweeping affirmation shows solid support for government investment in long-term planning to meet needs that citizens see as clearly as their elected officials do.
The questions appeared on the ballot in plain language with no lip reading required, and the voters spoke loudly and clearly in their favor.
The result speaks emphatically to acute public awareness of the balance between public needs and resources, and the expanding private marketplace. It demonstrates that a public in possession of the kind of financial-impact information it needs and should have does not shirk from a commitment to the general good.
Taken together, the decisive judgment on the referendums demonstrates that New Jersey's public has a universal understanding of the impact of growth and sound policies to address them.
In every case, the bond financing makes only partial payment of the cost to accomplish all that needs to be done. Still, each bond issue addressed a significant public need, which implicitly or explicitly, and by more than mere coincidence, reflects aspects of the State Plan for Development and Redevelopment.
The plan is a massive and complex prescription for a state guide to growth.
In the spirited debate about the plan, the bond votes offer a lesson about participation by an informed public and its appreciation for the line at the bottom of public policy.
But where the bond issues told the public the exact cost and the conditions for spending the authorized funds, the plan lacks similar clarity. It sets out needs, obligations and policies without stating their cost.
At the heart of the plan lies concern for preserving as much of New Jersey as can be protected in its natural form. That is an overriding goal and a daunting task in the nation's most densely populated state.
A substantial unanswered question concerns the need for an accounting of the economic impact of the plan. Another concern is for public access to the process by which the plan is moving toward adoption by the State Planning Commission and its working arm, the Office of State Planning.
The plan will never go before the voters in a referendum like the bond issues. But parts of it may as it engenders new proposals to capitalize public policies.
The greater opportunity the public has to comment and to know that its comments are reflected in the final document, the greater chance the plan will have to gain public support.
Informed comment calls for information. The public needs to know what the costs will be to government and so ultimately to itself as individual voters and taxpayers. It is the kind of knowledge that the election showed the public can handle when it has the information.
To accomplish its goals for growth management, New Jersey is going to have to ask the voters to say yes to other bond issues in the future. Let's start to talk now about what they will do and what they will cost.

PUB-DATE: December 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1417 words

HEADLINE: Stormy Exchanges Over Fate of City Manager in New Rochelle

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
NEW ROCHELLE, the self-appointed ''Queen of the Sound,'' was delighted last summer when a publication crowned it the city with the best prospects in the state for economic success in the l990's.
The editors of the Empire State Report, which analysed conditions in New York's 20 largest cities, hedged its findings by saying that even ''a high-scoring city could be harmed by indecision or bickering.'' In New Rochelle today, that warning has a prescient ring to it.
Two weeks ago, the City Council voted 3 to 2 to suspend the City Manager, C. Samuel Kissinger, a l5-year veteran of city government. The Council majority charged that Mr. Kissinger had failed to keep Council members informed and to implement City Council directives, and had mismanaged David's Island, a proposed $1 billion luxury condominium development. 
 
An Injunction Is Obtained
Mr. Kissinger, who said he would oppose an effort to dismiss him, won a court injunction last Wednesday that barred the City Council from taking any further action on the matter until this week. Arguments in the case will be heard at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow, before Supreme Court Justice Gordon W. Burrows in White Plains.
The injunction prevented discussion of Mr. Kissinger at a special meeting of the City Council that had been called by Mayor Leonard C. Paduano for last Wednesday evening. The agenda for the meeting would have included Mr. Kissinger's rebuttal to the charges made against him by the Council and then a vote by the Council on a proposal to dismiss Mr. Kissinger as City Manager.
The effort to remove the City Manager was led by the outgoing Democratic Councilman, Robert Schaefer, who said his actions had been prompted by a recent auditors' report. The report criticized accounting procedures at the city's agency for affordable housing, the New Rochelle Neighborhood Revitalization Corporation.
The review found that $77,500 was unaccounted for and that lawyers' fees of $266,200 had not been paid.
Calling the Neighborhood Redevelopment Corporation ''horribly mismanaged,'' Mr. Schaefer blamed the City Manager. He said Mr. Kissinger's ''nonfeasance'' and ''negligence'' were ''adequate grounds for dismissal.'' Mr. Schaefer, who has served on the City Council for nine years, did not seek re-election in November.
But Mr. Kissinger's suspension has been strongly opposed by two of the five Council members - Linda J. Levine, a Democrat, and Don Zaccagnino, a Republican-Conservative - as well as an incoming Democratic Council member, Ruth Kitchen.
These three argue that the housing agency is the responsibility of the City Council. They characterized the suspension of Mr. Kissinger as a move for power by a lame-duck coalition and said the coalition was reacting more to the coming changes in the makeup of the City Council than to any substantive information.
These two Council members and Mrs. Kitchen have issued a joint statement promising to ''remove anyone forced upon us by this lame-duck coalition.'' But the current majority, which includes Mayor Leonard C. Paduano, a Republican; Dr. Francis. X. Judge 2d, a Republican; and Mr. Schaefer, believe they are empowered to hire a permanent replacement.
 
The Right to Fire and Hire
''At this late date, we probably won't find anyone top notch,'' Mr. Schaefer said. ''But if someone is found who is marvelous, why should I disagree?''
Mayor Paduano said, ''The charter says the Council has the right to fire the city manager, period.'' He added that the current Council also had the right to hire a new manager immediately.
''Mr. Schaefer has the duty to the day he leaves office to do what is right for the city of New Rochelle,'' Mayor Paduano said. ''Just because he has 30 or 40 days to go doesn't mean he can't think properly.''
 
'A Travesty on Government'
In their statement, the minority members of the City Council called the decision to remove Mr. Kissinger ''irresponsible,'' and its timing ''critically damaging'' to a city that is just beginning talks on its $60 million budget and has just installed a new Director of Development.
''This is a travesty on government,'' said Mrs. Kitchen, who ran in the November election on a platform of strong support for the city manager and received a l,500-vote plurality over her nearest rival.
''There was no question about where I stood with the voters,'' Mrs. Kitchen said last week. ''Bob Schaefer stole the mandate of the election. What a way to go out with a bang.''
The current bickering about the City Manager reflects the Council's own indecision and lack of direction, Councilwoman Levine said, as well as a response to constituents' frustrations. ''There has been little movement in New Rochelle for the past l0 years,'' Mrs. Levine said. She described the city as one in which ''a deteriorating downtown has continued to deteriorate while other areas have been overdeveloped.''
Traffic and density has increased along Pelham Road, one of the city's main arteries, and will increase more even though the tax base has not grown. Residents, she said, feel ''they have given up their peace and quiet and a place to park, while gaining little.''
The Council, in Ms. Levine's view, has felt pressured to accept developer's proposals without requesting changes. ''Several members feel if we don't accept the proposals as is, we won't get anything,'' she said.
 
Looking for Someone to Blame
With opposition from residents to such projects as the David's Island development and the expansion of the New Rochelle Mall, the Council members are looking for someone to blame, Ms. Levine suggested. But blaming the City Manager, she said, was ''wrong, completely.'' ''He does what his bosses, all five of us, tell him to do,'' she said. ''If we do not direct, he does not manage.''
''Our job is to set policy, and it's the City Manager's job to carry it out,'' Mr. Schaefer responded. ''For the last two years, I urged the City Manager to check the management procedures of the housing agency but he refused.''
Saying he had planned ''to fade into the sunset'' at the end of his term, Mr. Schaefer explained that ''when this report came out, we had to do something Mr. Kissinger should have done in the first place.''
 
Whose Responsibility?
The Neighborhood Revitalization Corporation, Mr. Kissinger said last week, is not his responsibility under the bylaws of the City Charter. ''If you are interested in my being involved,'' Mr. Kissinger said he told Mr. Schaefer, ''get a Council resolution passed; because without the authority, I have no responsibility.''
He planned to fight his dismissal, Mr. Kissinger said, because he is proud of his 15-year record as City Manager and because he likes the job.
In the last decade, he said, reviewing some his accomplishments,half a million square feet of new office space or rehabilitated commercial space was created in the city; 300,000 square feet of industrial space was renovated; and 700 new condominiums were built.
''Our bond rating has been maintained at A1, our financial house is in order and our government has operated without scandal,'' Mr. Kissinger said. ''I'm proud of my record, and I want to remain the City Manager.''
 
Support From Business
Mr. Kissinger has received strong support from the city's business community. Some business leaders said last week that they were concerned that the dispute in the City Council threatens the growing interest in development in New Rochelle and could delay a number of planned projects.
The city is involved in three major development projects. There is the proposed $1 billion David's Island condominium development off the coast, a $300 million urban-renewal effort in the vicinity of the present railroad station, and the $30 million expansion of the new Rochelle Mall. The mall plan includes a 12-screen cinema complex and a 188,700-square-foot office building; it was approved by the City Council last month.
Sidney Mudd has for l4 years served as president of the New Rochelle Development Council, an organization of business people that was created toform a partnership with the city in an effort to stop its economic decline.
''We are on the very threshold of many things that will make the development of New Rochelle finally come true,'' Mr. Mudd said. The firing of the City Manager would produce ''a chaotic condition and will set things back considerably,'' he added. ''Developers will look askance and say, there goes New Rochelle again.''

HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SUN;
Caribbean Choices, Grand and Budget

BYLINE: By STANLEY CARR

 BODY:
For some travelers heading for the Caribbean islands and the Bahamas, the goal is a grand resort that in one way or another offers what is perceived to be the best: comfort, elegance, service and, for some guests at least, sports facilities that are either a few steps away or easily arranged. For others, just being where the sea water is 75 degrees when it's snowing up north may matter more than luxury.
The following survey of islands from Anguilla to Virgin Gorda focuses on opportunities for savoring some of the grandest - and most expensive - resorts and settling in at smaller hotels and inns where hedonism may be less well defined but where vacations are often enjoyed just as much at lower cost. Accommodations in the budget category are generally $100 or less a day for two, sometimes with meals included. The information here is based on information gathered from reports from the islands in the last few weeks and includes such upscale hideaways as Sandy Lane in Barbados, the Tryall in Jamaica and Guanahani on St. Barthelemy. Budget choices range from the Frangipani on Bequia in the Grenadines, the Sea Breeze on the Dutch side of St. Martin and Scout's Place on Saba. 
Not all the islands, of course, have major hostelries to match those on the busier islands. Little Saba, for example, is among places where rates for the most expensive are little more than relatively modest lodgings on other shores. The 10-room Captain's Quarters, one of Saba's most comfortable places, charges $110 a day for two, including Continental breakfast. Elsewhere in the islands, in some hotels, a standard room at around $100 may fit the budget category while a neighboring suite at the same resort may cost twice as much. Luxury, of course, is seen differently, so travelers with specific expectations should check with a travel agent or hotel before booking.
Some islands have had good news along with the memory - and its effect on the public consciousness - of Hurricane Hugo. Hugo may have blown away three months ago, but its aftereffects still hover. Just how much damage it will inflict on the high season, which begins officially next Friday, is difficult to predict. But many tour packagers, travel agents and vacationers now busy making reservations realize that only some of the islands were badly mauled by the storm.
The hurricane swept through the eastern Caribbean from Dominica to Puerto Rico. Other islands badly hit were the United States Virgin Islands (St. Thomas, St. John and St. Croix), the British Virgin Islands (Tortola and Virgin Gorda), Guadeloupe, St. Kitts-Nevis and Montserrat, which at the best of times has fewer than 100 hotel rooms, although it has several rental villas as well. These islands (except St. Croix) and others have announced that many hotels will be open either at the start of the season or soon after, but not all their rooms will be available. Many are still being repaired or renovated. Vigorous cleanup operations on islands where there was severe damage have in some cases gone a long way toward regaining normal conditions.
They are the islands where air service is being improved this season. Direct or, better still, nonstop flights attract more visitors. Cayman Airways begins nonstop flights to Grand Cayman in the Cayman Islands from New York on Friday, Saturday and Sunday from Dec. 15. Martinique and Guadeloupe are to have nonstop service from New York on Saturdays and Sundays starting Dec. 16. The carrier is Minerve Airlines, a French charter company that has been flying to the French Caribbean from Paris for several years. Grenada, an island recovering not from the storm - which roared north of it - but from its political upheaval in 1983, had a disappointment. American Airlines said it would start daily direct flights from New York to the island via San Juan from Jan. 31, then postponed the plan until June.
