On islands that did suffer damage, there will be fewer rooms than usual, at least in the early part of the season. The Long Bay Hotel on Tortola, for example, had about 25 of its 48 rooms in service two weeks ago and did not expect to have them all in use until January. On St. John, the Caneel Bay recently reported that of its 170 rooms, 60 were in use. In St. Croix, where hundreds of homes were devastated, a few hotels are open and several plan to be by the end of this month, but few tourists are expected.
Tourist officials emphasize that most islands were either not hit by the storm or suffered only cosmetic damage that has been mostly repaired.
Unless otherwise stated, the room rates given in this report are for a double room per day. Many hotels also offer M.A.P (Modified American Plan), providing breakfast and lunch or dinner at an additional daily cost. Throughout the Caribbean, government room taxes are added to hotel bills and these vary from 5 to 10 percent. Some hotels also add a service charge, generally from 5 to 12 percent.
 
ANGUILLA
 
ANGUILLA TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, N.Y. 11768
(800-553-4939 and 212-869-0402)
 
Overview
Weddings and tennis are talking points on this eel-shaped British colony close to St. Martin. Officials say there has been such a marked increase in nonresident marriage ceremonies that a store and a travel agency - the Sunshine Lady and Malliouhana Travel and Tours, both in The Valley, the main town - are acting as counselors and suppliers for couples arranging weddings and receptions. Ceremonies are held on beaches and in resorts as well as in churches. A fact sheet outlining marriage regulations and requirements has been issued by the tourist board.
The 16-mile-long island goes into this winter with tennis courts, including several lighted for night play, at 13 of the hotels. One of the larger resorts, the Cap Juluca, for example, now has three courts, and several smaller properties like Rendezvous Bay and Cinnamon Reef also have them. The growth in the sport has prompted a plan to run an island-wide tennis program, but it is likely to be a summer rather than a winter event. An inter-resort tournament for residents and visitors is scheduled for next July. Cap Juluca is planning to add a spectator court.
An official said Anguilla escaped serious damage from the hurricane and sent building supplies and light poles to Montserrat and St. Kitts and Nevis to help with repairs on those islands.
 
Accommodations
Cap Juluca, the clifftop Malliouhana - with its Moorish design - and Coccoloba Plantation, all with about 50 rooms, are among the island's grander places. At Cap Juluca winter room rates start at $395 a day, including Continental breakfast. The hotel will introduce two three-bedroom and three five-bedroom villas, each with its own pool, this season, renting at $1,100 and $1,700 a day. Pimm's, the resort's restaurant, has added 30 waterside seats. Malliouhana's daily rates start at $420 and Coccoloba's at $325. Coccoloba's rates include Continental breakfast. Both of these resorts have expanded their restaurants.
Among places with lower prices is the Rendezvous Bay, where hotel rates start at $100. It has just added two villas with rates from $175. Anguilla also has some family-run guesthouses offering accommodations without frills. Rates at the Inter Island, at Lower South Hill, which attracts many scuba divers and students, are $50 a day for one of its 12 rooms; rates at Yellow Banana, in Stoney Ground, also with 12 rooms, are $30, and at Casa Nadine, in The Valley, 4 rooms, $25.
 
Transportation
From New York on American or Pan American to San Juan and St. Maarten (Dutch), then on American Eagle from San Juan and on Winair or Tyden Air from St. Maarten. From Miami on Eastern to St. Maarten or B.W.I.A. to Antigua, then on L.I.A.T. From St. Thomas with Air B.V.I. and Winair. Daily boat services every half hour from Marigot (St. Martin) to Blowing Point: $8, one way, $12 at night.
 
ANTIGUA
 
ANTIGUA DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-541-4117)
 
Overview
Antigua and its small sister island of Barbuda (with 55 hotel rooms) begin the winter season with all its hotels and tourist facilities in operation despite the hurricane, which disrupted electricity and water supplies for a few days and blocked some roads. Repairs have been completed at hotels that were damaged.
A new restaurant and nightclub will provide added interest to visitors. The French Quarter on Runaway Bay, named from the New Orleans section, will offer Cajun Creole specialties as part of its menu. After dinner and continuing till sunrise, the nightclub will usher in some New Orleans atmosphere with jazz played by some of Antigua's finest musicians. A new hotel, the K-Club Resort on Barbuda, will also open its doors, offering 24 bungalows, a nine-hole golf course and two tennis courts.
Among older attractions are the restored Nelson's Dockyard, a base for modern yachtspeople, which also includes a museum and the Georgian Clarence House, the remains of Fort Berkely nearby and, in St. John's, Government House and the Cathedral.
 
Accommodations
The more luxurious of Antigua's 40 hotels include the 300-room Ramada Renaissance Royal Antiguan on the western side of the island three miles from St. John's, the capital. There are 270 rooms in the main tower as well as one- and two-bedroom cottages, all air-conditioned. The hotel offers a variety of water sports, eight tennis courts, horseback riding and evening entertainment. Rates range from $135 a day to $180 for the best rooms and up to $900 for a suite. The St. James's Club overlooks Mamora Bay amid 100 acres on the southeastern coast and charges from $450 a day, with rates rising to $600 for a suite and $850 for a villa sleeping up to six people. The rates include breakfast and dinner. Villas may be rented at lower rates without meals.
Other luxurious hotels like the Halcyon Cove ($210 to $295 daily) and the Divi Antigua Beach Resort, formerly the Anchorage ($349 to $369 with breakfast and dinner), are on the northwest coast on Dickenson Bay, two miles from St. John's, while the Half Moon Bay Hotel ($295 for standard room to $596 for a two-bedroom cottage, all with breakfast and dinner) lies on the east coast 12 miles from the capital and has a nine-hole golf course and five tennis courts.
Among hotels in the budget category are the 34-room Barrymore, a mile outside St. John's, with accommodations at $78 to $84 a day, the Dian Bay Resort, a group of villas 10 miles out on the northeast coast, at $118 and $130 a day, and the Antigua Beachcomber, with 36 rooms starting at $100, on the north shore.
 
Transportation
Nonstop flights from New York, Miami and other major cities on American, Pan Am, Eastern and B.W.I.A.
 
ARUBA
 
521 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10175
(212-246-3030)
 
Overview
This Dutch island with an average winter temperature of 82 degrees has miles of white-sand beaches and dozens of natural sites such as Crystal Mountain (where attractive pieces of quartz may be found), wildlife preserves and caves containing murals painted by Arawak Indians more than 500 years ago. The main street of the capital, Oranjestad, has just been turned into a modern mall, eight blocks long, containing about 90 clothing, jewelry and other shops. A free bus serves the mall from most major hotels. At night, the high-rise resorts offer casinos, dancing and floor shows.
A long-time Aruba restaurateur, John Chemaly, recently opened Valentino's at 43E Noord (telephone 33455), specializing in northern and southern Italian cuisine. Dinner for two runs about $75 to $100. Among appetizers is seafood crepes. The linguine pescatore entree is a combination of lobster, squid, jumbo shrimp, mussels and clams. At Heidelberg, 136 L. G. Smith Boulevard (26888 and 33020), now in its ninth year, the 15 entrees, at $12 to $15, include sauerbraten, schnitzel, roast goose and broiled catch-of-the-day. The wine list is entirely German.
 
Accommodations
All room prices are for seven nights and meals are not included. The island's telephone code is 599-8.
Holiday Inn Aruba, 230 L. G. Smith Boulevard (23600, or in U.S.A., 212-355-2660), has 387 rooms at rates of $1,155 to $1,540, double, plus 11 percent service charge and 5 percent government room tax. An additional 210 rooms are now completed, and this wing is expected to open during the 1989-90 winter season with the same rates. The hotel is on the beach and has four restaurants, supper club, nightclub, pool, casino, lighted tennis courts, masseur, 15 shops and, in the rooms, satellite television.
Aruba Concorde Hotel-Casino, 77 L. G. Smith Boulevard (24466, or in U.S.A., 800-327-4150), has 500 rooms at $1,470 to $1,610 double plus 11 percent service charge and 5 percent government room tax. There are also one-week tour packages beginning at $958 a person. On the beach, with five restaurants, nightclub, concert ballroom, pool, casino, lighted tennis courts and satellite television in rooms.
In the budget category is Bubali Lodge, 1050 Bubali (21355), which has 13 rooms and apartments ranging from $250 to $450 plus 10 percent for both service charge and government room tax. All rooms and apartments contain TV and kitchenette. Restaurant on premises. Beach two miles away.
Another less expensive place is Turibana Plaza, 124 Noord (27292 or, in U.S.A., 203-854-5377), with 18 apartments with rates from $455 to $700 plus 10 percent service charge and 5 percent government room tax. All contain satellite TV and kitchenette. Restaurant, laundromat on premises; supermarket is a block away, and island's celebrated French Bon Pan bake shop is also close by. Two miles from beach.
 
Transportation
From New York daily on American, and Tuesday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday on A.L.M. Antillian Airlines. From Newark daily on Continental. From Miami daily on A.L.M. and Wednesday and Saturday on Viasa. There is also service twice daily on American out of Miami with a change of plane in San Juan.
 
THE BAHAMAS
 
BAHAMAS TOURIST OFFICE
150 EAST 52d STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10022
(212-758-2777)
 
Overview
The islands of New Providence and Paradise Island, known to most as Nassau and Grand Bahama (site of Lucaya and Freeport) include large tourist cities with big hotels and casinos. These attract most visitors to the Bahamas but the chain consists of more than 700 islands, most of them unihabited. In the Abacos, to the northeast of the more popular centers, the main island of Abaco and many smaller cays appeal to visitors usually more interested in fishing, diving and sailing than in the night life and shopping of Nassau and Freeport. To the southeast are the Exumas, more remote and less populated but with excellent fishing and spectacular reefs. On the smaller islands most hotels have no telephones or televisions in the rooms. Most of the communication is by radio.
 
Accommodations
Among the grand hotels is the Ocean Club (809-363-2501 or 800-321-3000) on Paradise Island, a bridge-span's distance from the lights of Nassau. The grounds are elegant with formal gardens and cloisters on the harbor side and white beaches on the ocean. The property dates from the 1930's when a Swedish industrialist began developing what was then called Hog Island. It was later bought by Huntington Hartford, the A.&.P. heir, who brought in the cloisters and had them reassembled and had the gardens planted in the tradition of Versailles. The pink hotel with 18-hole golf course and 9 clay tennis courts has 71 rooms and villas. Prices start at $190. Men should wear jackets in the dining rooms.
Harbour Island is a little community off the northeast coast of Eleuthera. Many feel its two-and-a-half-mile beach of powdery pink sand is the best in the Caribbean. Dunmore Town, one of the oldest communities in the Bahamas, looks like a small New England town in pastel with picket fences and gingerbread porches. The Pink Sands (809-333-2030 or 914-241-8770) faces 900 feet of ocean beach and sits on 16 acres of a tropical bird reserve. The 45 guest rooms are in a collection of stone or wood cottages spread thoughout the property. Pink Sands is low key for those looking to relax; coats are not required for dinner and children are welcome. There are three hard-surface tennis courts, and fishing, sailing and skin diving can be arranged. Bicycles and golf carts are the prime transporation and are available for runs around the two-square-mile island. Rooms with three meals range from $275 to $325 a day.
Windermere Island Club (809-322-2538 or 212-839-0222 or 800-237-1236) is on private Windermere Island, which is connected to Eleuthera by a bridge. The resort has 37 beachfront rooms or suites and 20 private villas on the beach, some with private pools. The resort offers tennis, water skiing, volleyball, windsurfing and barbecues on two beaches. Prices start at $320, breakfast and dinner included.
In the less expensive category is the Stella Maris on Long Island, 90 miles long and 5 miles across at its widest, at the southern tip of the Exumas. Here the pace is slow and the fishing and diving excellent. The Stella Maris (meaning Star of the Sea) Inn and Estates (809-336-2106 or 800-426-0466) sits on a bluff overlooking the ocean and offers 60 rooms in the hotel, cottages and apartments. There is swimming, sailing, deep-sea and bonefishing, cycling, boat cruises, tennis and weekly cave and cocktail parties, and the diving program is exceptional. Rooms start at $96; a two-bedroom villa for four people is $240.
In Georgetown on the island of Great Exuma the pace quickens considerably during regattas in the early spring when sailing yachts gather from all over the Bahamas. There another cheaper hotel, the Peace and Plenty (809-336-2551 or 800-525-2210), has 32 rooms overlooking the bay (a good vantage point for the races). Boats ferry guests twice a day to Stocking Island to swim and explore the beaches.
Diving and fishing (both deep-sea and bonefishing) can be arranged through the hotel. Rates begin at $98 a night.
The island of Green Turtle Cay is across the bay from Great Abaco and is home to the Green Turtle Club (809-376-2572). The 32-room hotel is a five-minute walk from the beach. Fishing and diving trips can be arranged at the hotel, and small motorboats are available to explore nearby islands. As in most of the restaurants in the area, dress for dinner is less casual (jackets not required) but reservations are a must. Most restaurants have only one sitting, and dinner is ordered when reservations are made. Room rates start at $140.
 
Transportation
From New York on Bahamasair (from Newark), T.W.A. and Pan Am (Kennedy) and Delta (La Guardia). Bahamasair flies from Nassau and Freeport to the Family Islands. USAir, Bahamasair, Eastern and Continental fly into the Governor's Harbour or Rock Sound airports on Eleuthera from either Fort Lauderdale or Miami. Flights on supplementary airlines are available from Fort Lauderdale and Nassau to the North Eleuthera Airport where connections are made to Harbour Island by water taxi.
 
BARBADOS
 
BARBADOS BOARD OF TOURISM
800 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-986-6516 and, outside New York, 800-221-9831)
 
Overview
Visitors looking for a new way to see the 166-square-mile island can explore it aboard five-seat helicopters this winter. Depending on the length of flight, the trips cost $22.50, $50 and $180 and are available with Bajan Helicopters (809-425-0688). Those who prefer studying life beneath the waves may take the Atlantis II, which does daily trips at depths down to 150 feet. The sightseeing submarine carries 28 passengers and a crew of 2 and makes several dives every day for a fare of $58 (half price for children aged 4 to 12). Passengers are taken by motor launch to the sub a mile off Bridgetown.
A free program gaining popularity is the Sunday morning hikes conducted by the Barbados National Trust. The five-mile hikes cover a differrent area each week and are led by escorts who give brief talks on geology, history, agriculture and other topics related to the route. The hikes begin at 6 A.M. and are divided into three categories: fast pace, medium pace and stop and stare. Visitors needing transportation to the starting point should call the national trust at 809-426-2421.
The National Trust's open house program, in which homes of historical and architectural interest can be viewed by the public, will be run on Wednesdays from Jan. 17 to April 4.
The new highway connecting Grantley Adams International Airport with the west coast was completed last spring.
Barbados has seen a big growth in water sports activities on both the south and west coasts. These include jet skiing, wind surfing, diving, para-sailing and surfing. Other sporting activities include horseback riding and golf, which is played mainly at the Sandy Lane Hotel and Rockley Resort. Sandy Lane has just spent $1.5 million on its course in an effort to rebuild the bottom nine.
 
Accommodations
Most regular visitors, if asked to name the most elegant property, would proably say the Sandy Lane, a hacienda-style building in landscaped grounds on a sheltered west coast bay. The hotel is renowned for its country houseatmosphere and comforts. It also has the island's only 18-hole golf course as well as 5 tennis courts, 2 of them floodlighted. A room for two at the Sandy Lane costs $480 to $610 a day.
The Royal Pavilion Hotel at Porter's in St. James, a resort nestling in acres of tropical gardens, celebrates its second anniversary this month. There are tennis courts, some lighted for night play, and water-sports facilities. Complementary afternoon tea is served to the accompaniment of piano music.
Weekly rates from Jan. 4 to 26 and Feb. 26 to April 22 for oceanfront junior suites at the Royal Pavilion will be $2,765, or $395 a night. From Dec. 22 to Jan. 3 and Jan. 27 to Feb. 24, the rates will be $3,010 or $430 a night. The junior suites, the hotel's most popular, have one large room and a patio overlooking the ocean. Royal Pavilion also has one-bedroom suites priced at $790 a night; in the peak period the rate rises to $860. Breakfast and dinner are provided for another $65 a person a day. The hotel has a total of 75 suites.
The Hilton International, at Needham's Point, St. Michael, offers suites from $1,092 to $1,470 for seven nights, with breakfast and dinner at an extra $42 a person a day.
Comfortable and less expensive is the Asta Apartment Hotel, at Palm Beach in Hastings, Christ Church, which has studio apartments at weekly rates of $630, and $700 for the deluxe studio; one-bedroom suite, $791; two-bedroom suites, $1,386. The rooms are fully furnished with kitchens, stoves, refrigerators and utensils. Guests having breakfast and dinner at the hotel each pay an extra $24 a day. The Asta provides a minibus service into Bridgetown on weekdays, live entertainment two to three nights a week and a manager's party on Wednesdays.
The Caribee Hotel, at Hastings, Christ Church, charges $525 a week for a single beachfront room and $595 for a double beachfront room, with breakfast and dinner added for $25 a person a day. Guests are invited to weekly rum punch parties, and entertainment is provided three times a week.
 
Transportation
From New York: American, B.W.I.A. and Pan Am; from Miami: B.W.I.A. and Pan Am.
 
BONAIRE
 
BONAIRE GOVERNMENT TOURIST OFFICE
275 SEVENTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10001
(212-242-7707)
 
Overview
There are no traffic lights or expressways in Bonaire, an uncrowded, 24-mile-long island north of Venezuela in the Netherlands Antilles. The island is regarded as both a sport-diving capital and a haven for solitude seekers, and more than a quarter of it is a government wildlife park teeming with pink flamingos, iguanas and the wild progeny of donkeys and goats brought in centuries ago by Spanish, English and finally Dutch administrations. Bicycling and hiking are popular to sites like commercially harvested salt ponds, government aquaculture stations, bird sanctuaries and wilderness stretches. Recently discovered small caves are now being explored by tourists as well as residents. There is but one sizable town, Kralendijk, the capital.
 
Accommodations
All room prices are for one or two people for seven nights. No meals included. The island's telephone code is 599-7.
Among the grander hotels is the Flamingo Beach Hotel and Casino, on J. A. Abraham Boulevard (telephone 8285). It has 145 rooms with rates from $980 to $1,435 plus 10 percent service charge and $2.30 a person daily government tax. On beach and in town, it has two restaurants, two pools, shops, lighted tennis and the island's only casino. Water sports include diving lessons. Sunset cruises and picnics to smaller island available. Dancing and live entertainment five nights a week in the restaurant.
Sunset Beach Hotel, 75 Kayagobernador Debrot (8448), has 145 rooms from $650 to $1,050 plus 10 percent service charge and $2.30 a person daily government tax. On beach a mile from town, the Sunset offers a restaurant, boutique, pool, tennis, table tennis, miniature golf, billiard and card room on premises. Watersports available.
Vacationers looking for cheaper accommodations might consider the Carib Inn, J. A. Abraham Blvd. (8819), with nine rooms (some with kitchenettes) at weekly rates of $413 to $623 plus $2.30 a person daily government tax (no service charge). The Carib is on the beach in town and includes a restaurant, pool and a fully equipped dive shop. The Carib's proprietor, Bruce Bowker, an American diver, says nondivers are always welcome.
Hotel Rochaline, 7 Kaya Grandi (82860), has 25 rooms with rates of $315 to $350, government tax included and no service charge incurred. Also on the beach in town. The hotel has a restaurant.
 
Transportation
From New York nonstop on A.L.M. Antillian Airlines on Friday; on American daily with change of plane at Aruba, connecting with Air Aruba, or Curacao, connecting with A.L.M. Also from New York on A.L.M. Tuesday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday with change in Curacao. From Miami nonstop on Saturday and Sunday on A.L.M.
 
CAYMAN ISLANDS
 
CAYMAN ISLANDS TOURIST BOARD
420 LEXINGTON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10170
(212-682-5582)
 
Overview
Scuba diving and snorkeling along coral reefs, along with other water sports, dominate the scene on this three-island British colony, and facilities are centered on Seven-Mile Beach, a stretch of white sand shaded by feathery casuarina trees on Grand Cayman. Visitors will find no shortage of activities, although there are no new tourist attractions this season. The 28-passenger Atlantis submarine offers day and night excursions from Hogside Bay on Grand Cayman for $58 a person. Two-person submarines are available for rent from Research Submersibles for $245. For land lovers, the Pirates World and Treasure Museum features exhibits on the islands' history and their pirates past.
Grand Cayman is the resort center; Cayman Brac, a wilderness area 90 miles away, and its neighbor, Little Cayman, are hideaways for vacationers who want to hike in solitude. Brac's woodlands have a great variety of cactus and orchids, and its caves are also an attraction. Mangroves and lagoons are features on Little Cayman, and bonefishing is available there.
 
Accommodations
For those seeking luxury and a classic resort atmosphere, the 235-room Hyatt Regency Grand Cayman offers a variety of accommodations across from Seven-Mile Beach on West Bay Road. The hotel's Regency Club, in a separate building from the colonial-style Regency, has a concierge who arranges travel and entertainment plans. A Continental breakfast is served daily and cocktails and hors d'oeuvres are served each evening in the club lounge.
Hyatt's winter rates, double occupancy, start at $235 a day for a standard room (with limited view) and $310 for a room with a view of the island's only 18-hole golf course, and go up to $400 for the Regency Club and higher for larger suites. The units also includes terrace rooms with large furnished patios at $335. Rooms overlooking the tennis courts or English gardens are $285. The hotel offers tennis, swimming, scuba diving and snorkeling. A pedestrian walkway connects the hotel to the oceanfront beach club that includes one of the hotel's three restaurants. Reservations: 800-233-1234.
In the less expensive bracket is the Coconut Harbor Hotel offering poolside rooms at $135 a night and rooms with ocean views at $160. Each room has a minikitchen. The 35-room hotel about three miles from Seven Mile Beach caters to divers and offers scuba and snorkeling trips. A shore diving facility also is available. It has an outdoor restaurant and bar. Reservations: 809-949-7488.
The Holiday Inn Grand Cayman is on West Bay Road across from Seven Mile Beach and features a pool, tennis courts, a dive shop and scuba and snorkeling. Local musicians perform on stage at the beach bar during the week and limbo contests are held on weekends. Standard rooms are $185 a night and rooms with ocean views are $258. Reservations: 809-947-4444.
 
Transportation
Cayman Airways will offer direct flights to the islands from Kennedy Airport beginning Dec. 15. The airline also flies from Miami, Atlanta, Tampa and Houston. Northwest Airlines flies from Miami.
 
CURACAO
 
CURACAO TOURIST BOARD
400 MADISON AVENUE, SUITE 311, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-751-8266)
 
Overview
Willemstad, the capital of this Netherlands Antilles island near Venezuela, has much afoot for the winter season. One night a week, Ban Topa (Let's Meet) will be held. It's a three-hour street fair where visitors can rub elbows with Curacao culture. The annual pre-Lenten Carnaval season gets underway with a parade in town on Jan. 13, followed by the colorful tumba (Antillean rhythm style) dance festival outside the capital Feb. 6, 7 and 9, and the final Grand Parade with over 1,000 marchers in Willemstad on Feb. 25.
The Underwater National Park now stretches along the entire 30-mile eastern coast with attractions for divers and passengers in glass-bottom boats. The city's Seaquarium has been expanded to accommodate three restaurants (international, Mexican, Antillian), where patrons are issued free Seaquarium tickets. Tickets otherwise cost $5. One restaurant specializing in the region's most popular cuisine is Indonesian Rystafel, 13 Mercuriusstraat, Salina, a Willemstad suburb (telephone 612606). Dinner for two runs about $50 to $65.
 
Accommodations
All room prices are for seven nights and meals are not included. The island's telephone code is 699-9. Princess Beach Hotel and Casino, Dr. Martin Luther King Boulevard, Willemstad (614944 or, in the United States, 800-223-9815), has 202 rooms at rates of $630 to $840 single and $770 to $1,120 double, plus 12 percent service charge and 5 percent government tax. On beach in town and next door to Sequarium. Two restaurants, cocktail lounge, two pool bars, saltwater pool, tennis, casino, shopping arcade on premises. Free shuttle bus to downtown shops and free cocktail party Fridays. Holiday Beach Hotel and Casino, 31 Pater Auwensweg, Willemstad (625400 or, in the United States, 800-223-9815), has 200 rooms at rates of $560 to $630 single and $665 to $735 double plus 12 percent service charge, 5 percent government tax, and a daily $3 (per room) energy surcharge stipulated by the Government in this part of Willemstad. On beach with two restaurants, cocktail lounge, freshwater pool, lighted tennis, casino (recently redone to become island's largest), shops on premises. Satellite TV in rooms.
Among budget hotels is the Van der Valk Plaza Hotel, Plaza Pier, Willemstad (612500), which has 245 rooms and charges $385 a person, plus 5 percent government tax; no service charge. The hotel, formerly the Curacao Plaza Hotel and Casino, is in the downtown shopping district overlooking the busy harbor entrance. Restaurant, two cocktail lounges, pool, casino, game room, shops on premises. Satellite television in rooms.
Trupial Inn (formerly Country Inn), 5 Groot Davelaarwijk, Willemstad (78200), has 66 rooms and 8 suites (some with kitchenette) at $364 (room) and $574 (suite), tax included; no service charge. The inn stands in a quiet residential area well inland. Restaurant, laundry, tennis, pool, sauna on premises. Cable television in rooms.
 
Transportation
From New York daily on American, and Tuesday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday on A.L.M. Antillian Airlines. From Miami daily on A.L.M.
 
DOMINICA
 
CARIBBEAN TOURISM ASSOCIATION
20 EAST 46TH STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-682-0435)
 
Overview
This island of jungle-covered mountains that has always attracted nature lovers was hit by Hurricane Hugo. The Coconut Beach Hotel was badly damaged but is now open and accepting reservations for the winter. A number of other hotels, particularly in the north, were flooded, and roads blocked by fallen trees. The main devastation was to the farms: 70 percent of the banana crop was destroyed.
Bird watching, scuba diving and hiking are popular, and some visitors explore on rented jeeps and mopeds. Driving is on the left and steering wheels on the right, so it is necessary to take a driving test at the Police Traffic Department in the capital, Roseau, before being allowed to drive on the narrow roads. A new dive and water-sports center, designed to serve the entire island and expected to be ready for the season, is being built on the grounds of the Castaways Beach Hotel.
A $6 exit tax, payable in United States dollars, is collected at the airport.
 
Accommodations
Dominica's hotels are small and it does not have luxury accommodations. The Castaways (809-449-6244), 13 miles from Roseau, charges $100 for a double room. Breakfast and dinner cost an additional $20 per person a day. It has 27 rooms, facing the Caribbean, all with private shower or bath. Some have air-conditioning (an extra $5 a night), some have fans. It has a restaurant featuring French and Creole cuisine and two bars, one on the beach. Room service available during the day. Hotel facilities include one hard tennis court available for $4 an hour during the day; it is lighted for night play at $6 an hour. Snorkeling equipment is $6 an hour. Scuba diving and other water sports, including motor boat cruising, spear and game fishing, can be arranged by the hotel. Reservations: I.T.R. (800-223-9815).
The Anchorage (809-448-2638), on the beach, one-half mile from the capital, is a three-story hotel, with 32 rooms with private bath, air-conditioning in most, a pool, restaurant and lounge. Hiking and bird watching tours can be arranged at hotel desk, buffet dinner with music one night a week. Boutique and car rental on property. Hotel desk can arrange photo safaris. A room is $60 a night, double. Meal plans optional. Reservations: Robert Reid (800-223-6510).
Portsmouth Beach (809-445-5142), a beachfront hotel with 90 balconied rooms and 18 cottages, has a pool and is within walking distance of the Coconut Beach and Mike's restaurants. The rooms are $60 a day for two, $70 for three and $75 for four. The cottages, sleeping up to four people, rent for $100 to $150 a day. Car rental on the property; hiking, bird-watching, canoeing and photo safari tours can be arranged. Nearby attractions are the ruins of Fort Shirley, rowing along Indian River and hiking at Mount Diablotin. Reservations: Robert Reid (800-223-6510).
The Reigate Hall Hotel (809-448-4031) has 15 rooms, air-conditioned, and balconies with ocean view. The better double rooms are $140 a day and have radio, television, telephone and minibars. Facilities include a freshwater pool, one hard-surfaced tennis court that is free during the day - it is lighted for play at night at $5 an hour - a sauna, exercise room, bar and restaurant. Transport to the beach is available for a fee. Reservations: I.T.R. (800-223-9815).
 
Transportation
Dominica is not served directly from the United States mainland. Visitors fly L.I.A.T. from San Juan, Antigua, Barbados and St. Lucia. Air Caribe serves the island from San Juan.
 
DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
 
DOMINICAN REPUBLIC TOURIST INFORMATION CENTER
485 MADISON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10022
(212-826-0750)
 
Overview
Though manufactured goods have joined minerals and agriculture in the republic's economy, tourism remains the largest industry. The country occupying the eastern two-thirds of the island of Hispaniola (shared with Haiti) occupies 18,700 miles and has a population of about 6.5 million. It boasts the most guest rooms in the Caribbean, more than 16,000, in hotels, inns and guesthouses.
The principal areas visited by tourists are Puerto Plata and Santo Domingo, which both have casinos, Sosua, Punta Cana, Juan Dolio, Boca Chica, Samana and La Romana. In the Puerto Plata resort area in the north, the casinos, beaches and skylift are among the attractions. Sosua, set behind a white sand beach, is a quiet town where in 1940 Jewish refugees of World War II were welcomed. Altos de Chavon in La Romana is an artists' retreat that has a branch of the Parsons School of Design. The Shrine to Our Lady of Altagracia is in Higuey, east of Santo Domingo, where pilgrimages are made by the faithful every Jan. 21 to honor this patron saint of the Dominican Republic. On Feb. 27, half a million people will parade for Independence Day on the capital's seafront boulevard, called the Malecon.
On arrival in the Dominican Republic, visitors must purchase a $10 tourist card and, on departure, pay a $10 exit tax, both in United States dollars.
 
Accommodations
Service tax of 10 percent plus government tax of 11 percent are added to room bills. In restaurants, 10 percent service tax and 6 percent government tax are added to checks. All-inclusive hotel rates usually include these taxes, but vacationers should ask before booking. Some of the hotels overlap both the grand and budget categories. In some places, a standard room could be classified as budget while the cost of a neighboring suite is far more expensive.
In the east of the country, on a white sand beach, is the Punta Cana Beach Resort. This secluded 105-acre estate beside a coral reef has 10 clay-surface tennis courts with day and night play. Visits are arranged to nearby working cattle ranches and Taino and Arawak Indian burial grounds. Nature walks and seaside horseback riding are also available, as well as wind surfing, sailing, snorkeling and water skiing. Deep-sea fishing and scuba-diving expeditions can also be arranged. Rates with breakfast and dinner range from $156 a night for a double room to $408 for a three bedroom suite. Reservations: I.T.R., 212-545-8469; 800-223-9815.
In the northern coast resort area, a quiet retreat 73 miles from the airport and 57 miles from town (a $50 taxi ride) is the Discovery Bay Club, an all-inclusive retreat in the fishing village of Punta Rucia. Set on a white sand beach, the resort has 28 air-conditioned rooms. Facilities include movies every night (two shows a week), water sports, including scuba diving and deep-sea fishing, boat rides to nearby islands and horseback riding. A room for two costs $280 a night with all meals. Reservations: AMHSA Hotels, 800-828-8895 and 212-545-8469.
An elegant hotel in Santo Domingo is the Jaragua Resort, on the Malecon, sporting a 20,000-square-foot casino, four lighted clay tennis courts, pool, and golf (by advance reservation) at the Santo Domingo Country Club. The addition of a proposed health spa to the resort has been delayed. There are 355 rooms, all with private bath, air-conditioning and telephone; five restaurants and bars and live entertainment. Rates range from $165 for a garden-view double room to $710 for a tower oceanview suite. Reservations: 800-937-6070.
In the less expensive category, one hour from Santo Domingo, on a beach called Juan Dolio on the south coast, is the Hotel Metro and Marina with 180 rooms, including 3 suites, and two restaurants, the formal Puerto and the outdoor Velero. Facilities at this hotel, opened a year ago, include two pools, one for children, a Jacuzzi bath and two lighted clay-surface tennis courts. A standard room with two double beds (sea view with balcony must be requested) is $110 a night; a suite (bedroom with queen bed and sitting room with sofa bed, ocean view), $250. Reservations: Utell International, 800-448-8355.
Near Sosua and on the shores of the Puerto Chiquito Beach is the Sand Castle Luxury Beach Resort with private and conference accommodations. This unusual complex, comprising three-story fantasy-like buildings with rippled terrace buttresses resembling waves, has 240 rooms. Standard $70, superior with mountain view $80, with ocean view $100. Suite with mountain view $100; with ocean view $120. Suites have living room, dining room and bedroom. Two tennis courts (free during the day; $10 at night), horseback riding, two freshwater pools, discotheque, Jacuzzi bath, beauty parlor; boutiques, gift shop, five restaurants. Reservations: 800-446-5963.
 
Transportation
From New York and Miami: American, Pan American and Dominicana. Continental flies to Santo Domingo and Puerto Plata from Newark. American Eagle flies from San Juan to the Punta Cana resort area.
 
GRENADA
 
GRENADA DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM
141 EAST 44th STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-687-9554)
 
Overview
Expansions and improvements at some of the hotels and at recreational facilities continue as the island's tourist industry revives. In the first six months of this year, tourist officials say, stay-over visitors increased by 10 percent compared with the corresponding period in 1988. About 25 percent of visitors are from the United States. The new Camahogne Park on Grand Anse Beach, in the hotel development area four miles from St. George's, the capital, has changing cubicles and a children's playground, picnic huts and snack bar. On St. George's Carenage waterfront, the trellised Pedestrian Plaza with benches and flowering plants provides a haven for watching boats in the harbor. Annandale Falls, a 15-minute drive into the hills from St. George's, now has changing facilities for those who wish to bathe in the pool under the falls. There is a snack bar and a garden featuring spices and traditional medicinal herbs. Entrance is free. Phone 440-2452.
At the interpretation center near the crater lake of an extinct volcano, Grand Etang, 25 minutes' drive from St. George's, displays illustrate flora and fauna, and video presentations show historic and other places of interest. Nature trails with picnic sites lead into the rain forest around the lake and, for the more adventuresome, longer trails penetrate the mountain range. Guides are available. Entrance to the center and use of facilities is free. Phone 440-7425.
 
Accommodations
Ramada Renaissance Hotel, on Grand Anse Beach four miles from St. George's, with 184 rooms on 20 acres of tropical garden, is Grenada's largest hotel. Rooms have satellite color television, double or king size beds, balcony or patio, air-conditioning and direct dialing phone. Facilities include tennis courts, volleyball, shuffleboard, water sports, two restaurants with international and Creole cuisine and a pool. Room rates are $158; suites from $300. Beachfront rooms are an additional $25. Reservations: 800-228-9898.
Spice Island Inn, on Grand Anse Beach, offers three types of accommodations: suites with private pools; beach suites with whirlpool baths, and beach suites. All are air-conditioned. Modified American plan rates include room, breakfast and dinner, tennis (all-weather court), water sports, room service and concierge service. With a $55-a-person additional daily charge, guests also get lunch, tea, Grenada Golf Club membership (10 minutes by taxi), bar service, tour of botanical gardens (approximately two hours), unlimited use of house wine and fully stocked mini-bar in room. M.A.P. rates for two: $350, $275 and $240. No children under 5 in season. Reservations: 809-444-4258 and 4423.
The Hibiscus Hotel is among the budget choices, with rates of $60 for a room, $70 for an efficiency and $95 for a two-bedroom unit. Children under 12 free. The efficiencies and two-bedroom cottages have refrigerator, stove and utensils. Breakfast and dinner cost an extra $25 a person a day, $20 for children. The Hibiscus is five minutes' walk from Grand Anse Beach and its air-conditioned rooms have color television, telephone and patio. Pool and restaurant. Reservations: 809-444-4233 and 4008.
Siesta Holiday Apartments, five minutes from Grand Anse Beach, has air-conditioned units with balcony, equipped kitchen, laundry and maid service, telephone, television. Pool, restaurant, minimarket. There are three types of accommodations: studio, $70; one-bedroom, $95; two-bedroom, $100. Children under 10 free. Breakfast and dinner are available for $20 a person a day and $12 for children. Reservations: 809-444-4646 and 4647.
 
Transportation
Pan American and American fly daily from Miami and New York to Barbados, connecting with L.I.A.T. to Grenada. B.W.I.A. daily from New York and Miami, some flights direct and some with a change in St. Lucia or Antigua.
 
GUADELOUPE
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
The French island continues its recovery from the disruption that Hurricane Hugo brought to all activity on the eastern end of Grande-Terre, the eastern wing of the butterfly-shaped island. Most hotels and guesthouses will be operating for the coming season, and six of the largest properties in Gosier and Bas du Fort have been open since shortly after the hurricane. Officials report that few beaches were damaged, and in some places Hugo even brought in added sand; the main and secondary roads are open; vegetation is regaining its tropical color; the golf course is in full operation, and cruise ships are calling at Pointe-a-Pitre. The tourist board can supply information on the conditions, including projected opening dates for hotels that have not yet resumed operations.
A French charter company, Minerve Airlines, is to operate two direct flights a week to Guadeloupe (and Martinique) from Kennedy Airport, starting Dec. 16. The French West Indies Sales Center (212-986-5092) can supply details.
Early in 1990, the world's largest and most technologically advanced sailing ship, Club Med I, will begin cruise trips from Guadeloupe. The 610-foot vessel has 201 cabins and two suites. The seven-day itineraries from Guadeloupe will stop at several islands including St. Martin and St. Barts. Prices for the voyages will range from $1,290 to $2,350 a person.
Guadeloupe's aquarium, the largest in the Caribbean, on the Place Creole just off the main highway outside the Bas-du-Fort Marina on Grande-Terre, has added a 21,000-gallon tank through which visitors can walk by means of a glass tunnel while watching sharks up to six feet long. The aquarium's 20 tanks contain species from all over the Caribbean. Admission is about $4.80, and $2.40 for children under 12. Hours are from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. every day. I.D. Tours bills itself as Guadeloupe's first travel agency to specialize in participatory tourism. It will arrange for visitors to take part in such activities as a fish-net haul with local fishermen, riding in an ox cart and meeting Guadeloupeans at home. Although the agency's operations were suspended temporarily because of hurricane damage, it now is offering partial service with headquarters at the St. Francois Golf Club and it can be reached by calling 590 88.41.87.
 
Accommodations
The only hotel with a deluxe rating is the waterside Hamak, with 56 rooms, in St. Francois on the eastern end of Grand-Terre. The vegetation on the grounds was badly damaged in the storm but the surving plants are now recovering their color. The hotel, which has a small airstrip, is across from the island's golf course. Rates for a room for two, without meals, range from $280 to $380 a day, plus 15 percent service and tax. The Meridien Hotel, which has been closed since being damaged in the hurricane, says that it is spending nearly $2 million on repairs and renovations. Reopening is planned for Dec. 21.
Among several small accommodations in the budget category is the seven-room Mini Beach, several minutes' walk from the beach at Ste.-Anne. It offers horseback riding and bicycles. A double room with Continental breakfast is $80 to $120. Another budget place is the Relais du Moulin, at Chateau Brun near Ste.-Anne. It has 40 rooms and charges $100 to $115 for two a day, including Continental breakfast.
 
Transportation
From New York on American via San Juan, and there is daily service from San Juan on Air France; from Miami, Air France on Saturday and Sunday. Also, from St. Martin, on Air Guadeloupe.
 
HAITI
 
HAITI NATIONAL OFFICE OF TOURISM
18 EAST 41st STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-779-7177)
 
Overview
Political turmoil, repression and violence have crippled the tourist industry of a country always admired for its mountainous beauty and unspoiled beaches. But while some hotels have closed down, other hotels and restaurants familiar to visitors in the past still cling to life. Club Med, whose Haiti Magic Isle facility is one of the most beautiful of their holdings, says that ''if all goes as we anticipate, we expect to open in the latter half of 1990.'' Club Med closed its 350-room Haiti club in 1987. It will reopen without modification, since a grounds staff has continued to maintain the property.
The Haitian Government closed its New York Tourist Office last year, but it was reopened this fall.
United States travelers require proof of citizenship and a round-trip ticket. Departure tax is $15. A recent law requires that money not be exchanged on the parallel market and that only the official rate of five gourdes to the dollar is legal. American currency can be used everywhere, but change may be given in local money.
 
Accommodations
Hotel Oloffson (509-1-3-4000), the darling of artists, writers and jet setters, is confident that adding two luxurious suites, one with an 8 by 8-foot mahogany bed, will attract its nostalgic former clients. This historic hotel is comprised of an imposing gingerbread mansion and cottages on the grounds, and it has a freshwater pool, two bars (one poolside) and a restaurant. Room prices remain the same the year round. A cottage with a queen-size bed or two double beds is $70 a night, double occupancy; suite, $120. The hotel recently installed a fax machine (509-1-3-0919). A resident troupe performs a folkloric show each week. The hotel's permanent art exhibit features 13 of the new avant-garde Haitian artists. Richard Morse, a Princeton graduate, Haitian musician and owner of the hotel, says he is determined to make the Oloffson regain its splendor. Reservations: I.T.R., 800-223-9815.
Hotel El Rancho (509-1-7-2080/4) has 105 air-conditioned rooms and a casino, and it is still considered the most luxurious hotel in Haiti, with its two pools, Jacuzzi bath and hard-surface tennis court (free during the day, $5 an hour for night play). A room with two doubles or one king-size bed costs $110 a night and a suite with a king-size bed is $200. Reservations: I.T.R., 800-223-9815.
Glorifying the gingerbread architectural period of Haiti, the Hotel Kinam (509-1-7-0462) in the suburb of Petionville, offers one of the most comprehensive revivals of this period with its 38 rooms and 3 suites, all with air-conditioning, color television and phones for local calls. Rooms run from $70 a night, suites from $80 to $110. The Kinam restaurant, a popular dining spot and open every day until midnight, offers Creole and French cuisine. Transportation From New York and Miami: American Airlines and A.L.M.; from Miami: Eastern, Haiti Trans Air, Pan Am.
 
JAMAICA
 
JAMAICA TOURIST BOARD
866 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-688-7650)
 
Overview
The devaluation of the Jamaican dollar (now 6:50, instead of 5:50, to the United States dollar) may encourage independent travelers this winter, but the all-inclusive package trend continues to flourish. Super Clubs's all-inclusive Grand Lido opened in Negril in November. Other recent additions where one price pays for all meals, wine and sports facilities - Sandals Negril and Sandals Ocho Rios - are now well established. Eden II near Ocho Rios is closed pending reincarnation as another Sandals property. New hotels for this season include Swept Away on the beach in Negril, a sports and health-oriented villa complex scheduled to open before the end of December; the Gloucestershire, moderately priced and conveniently situated opposite Doctors Cave beach in Montego Bay; the Palace in Port Antonio, small and elegant with an elaborate swimming pool shaped like the island of Jamaica.
New tour: Helitours Jamaica, based in Ocho Rios, offers helicopter tours and charters for a bird's-eye view of the island. The rates are $40 a person for a 15-minute hop, $85 for a 30-minute tour and $170 for an hour. New combination: Crystal Springs, a bird sanctuary, orchid garden and camping ground near Buff Bay, Portland, now offers regular open-air musical events. Shows include jazz, pop and reggae. New festival: The first Jamaica Carnival scheduled for April 14 to 22 will be modeled on the Trinidad and Tobago Carnival and will feature costumed bands, street dancing and a Calypso Monarch contest in Montego Bay, Ocho Rios, St. Mary and Kingston.
 
Accommodations
Tryall Golf, Tennis and Beach Club comprises villas scattered over a former sugar plantation and a small Great House Hotel on a low hill overlooking the ocean: low-key luxury, tennis pro and tennis courts, a championship golf course, private white sand beach, water sports, elaborate pool and swim-up bar at the Great House, boutique, beauty salon and commissary. The golf club, normally restricted to guests and members, will be the venue Jan. 15 to 22 for the Jamaica Classic golf tourney with top players of the U.S. Ladies' Professional Golf circuit.
Daily rates: Great House, from $280 to $360 double occupancy, including breakfast, afternoon tea and dinner. Add $12 room tax and 10 percent service charge. Villas: a two-bedroom unit, $3,750 a week; three bedrooms, $5,000; four bedrooms, $6,000.
The small and classy Plantation Inn, Ocho Rios, has a private white sand beach, full range of nonmotorized water sports, sauna, Jacuzzi bath, pool, exercise room, tennis courts, free access to Upton Golf Club, boutique, beauty salon, nightly entertainment. Rates, from $310 to $560 (penthouse) for two a day, include breakfast (room service on private balcony), elevenses, afternoon tea and dinner. Add $12 tax and 10 percent service charge.
In the budget category is the Fantasy Resort, Montego Bay, opposite Doctors Cave Beach. Oceanview rooms with balcony. Pool, Jacuzzi bath, exercise room, video room, disco, piano bar, tennis courts. A double room is $100 plus $10 tax and 10 percent service charge. Breakfast and dinner cost another $30 a person a day plus 10 percent service.
Heart Academy in Runaway Bay overlooks the golf course and ocean. Some of the staff are trainees from the affiliated hotel school. Small and friendly. Pool, piano bar, entertainment, satellite TV, access to private beach, bicycles. A winter package of three nights and four days is $246 a person (double occupancy) or $199 a person (triple) and includes breakfast, dinner, airport transfers and beach shuttle. Without meals, the price is $50 a person a day (single), $30 a person (double). Add room tax $10 and 10 percent service charge. Transportation Air Jamaica from New York, Miami, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Tampa. American from New York and Miami. Continental from Newark. Eastern from Atlanta and Miami.
 
MARTINIQUE
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
The scheduled airlines do not fly directly to the French island of Martinique from New York, but a French charter airline, Minerve, plans direct service on Saturday and Sunday from Kennedy Airport, beginning Dec. 16. Information on the flights can be had from the French West Indies Sales Information Center (212-986-5092).
A new, comprehesive admission ticket to most of Martinique's major museums, monuments and other cultural sites is now available for a single fee of about $5.50. Known as the TAC (Ticket d'Acces Culturel), it is valid for one year from the date of purchase and is available at the Departmental Historical Museum and the Transportation and Commerce Museum in Fort-de-France; the Volcanological Museum and the Historical Museum in St. Pierre; the Gauguin Museum in Carbet, and elsewhere.
A permanent exposition salon for art of all kinds, The Gold Dolphin, opened recently in the capital, Fort-de-France, at 7 Boulevard Chevalier-Ste.-Marthe. Also new is the art and gem gallery called Artibijoux, 89 Rue Victor-Hugo. Specializing in Haitian paintings - both traditional native and modern - the gallery also displays crafts, such as wooden- and wrought-iron sculpture, ceramics and decorative rugs.
Motorhome holidays have now been added to the vacation scene. Best suited to visitors who know some French, the camper vacation can be ideal for families with children. In Martinique, the vehicles are rented by West Indies Tours, Beauregard 97240, Le Francois (596- 54.50.71).
 
Accommodations
There are no really grand hotels on Martinique, but islanders consider Le Bakoua at Pointe du Bout to be the best. Its 140 rooms cost $230 to $308 a day. The largest hotel is the Meridien, with 300 rooms, and its rates, with Continental breakfast, are $221 to $271, although during the Christmas and New Year period the rate is $456 for two and guests are obliged to take breakfast and dinner.
Visitors find it difficult to book rooms beside the sea at under $100 a day, but the 24-room Diamant Les Bains on the beach in Diamant charges only $78 for two. The new Auberge de la Montagne Pelee in the mountains at Morne Rouge charges $42 for its eight rooms, and the 15-room St. Aubin, within walking distance of the beach at Trinite, charges $78. Martinique Cottages in Lamentin has eight rooms at $70 for two; it is not on the beach but has a good restaurant and is near the airport.
 
Transportation
From New York on American via San Juan; from San Juan there is daily service, except Friday, on Air France. From Miami: Air France on Saturday and Sunday. Air Martinique flies to the island from St. Martin.
 
MONTSERRAT
 
MONTSERRAT TOURIST BOARD
110 EAST 59th STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10022
(212-752-8660)
 
Overview
The full force of Hurricane Hugo smashed across this mountainous, 39-square-mile island southeast of Antigua, and its inhabitants are still busy cleaning up rubble and repairing buildings. Damage to the electricity supply was so great that engineers decided to rewire the whole island, including the telephone system, and full restoration of services is not expected before the New Year. Many families have been illuminating their homes with kerosene lanterns. The water supply, officials said, was good in most areas.
Efforts to encourage visitors to reserve the rooms that will be ready this month have been hampered by the impossibility, until recently, of calling from the United States. The tourist board's office in Plymouth was destroyed, and the employees moved to new rooms with a different number - 809-491-2444 - in the government headquarters. ''We are still on the map,'' said Ernestine Cassell, director of tourism, in Plymouth. ''We originally feared that the island would not be able to accommodate tourists until mid-1990. However, thanks to the tireless efforts of the Montserratians, aided by teams of workers from all over the world, a number of badly damaged hotels expect to have rooms ready.''
 
Accommodations
The Vue Pointe, one of the main properties, plans to reopen a total of 15 rooms among its 28 cottages and 5 rooms this month. Public areas such as dining room and pool area escaped damage.
An opening date has not been scheduled for the other main hotel, the Montserrat Springs, but it hopes to welcome some visitors this season after a complete overhaul of its 6 cottages and 17 rooms.
The island has always had a variety of villa accommodations. The three Villas of Montserrat will reopen Dec. 15. Others planning to open this month include the Shamrock Villas and some properties managed by Neville Bradshaw Agencies.
 
Transportation
From Antigua, Guadeloupe and St. Kitts on Montserrat Aviation Services and L.I.A.T.
 
PUERTO RICO
 
COMMONWEALTH OF PUERTO RICO TOURISM COMPANY
575 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-599-6262)
 
Overview
The island in the Caribbean with the most visitors (about 2.9 million during the year ended last June) is still recovering from the hurricane. However, although major hotels sustained millions of dollars in damage when Hugo thrashed much of the island Sept. 18, none were forced to close more than a few days and all are looking forward to a strong winter season. The two hotels suffering the most damage were the grande dame of Puerto Rico's tourist industry, the Caribe Hilton Hotel, and the Condado Plaza Hotel, which are separated by a small bay in the heart of San Juan's tourist area. At the Caribe Hilton, the ceiling of several public rooms on the second floor of what is known as the tower collapsed. The windows of some of the rooms in the tower blew in, the rain soaking rugs and bedding. Several trees in the gardens, including an Indian laurel that was planted when the hotel opened in 1948, were toppled. ''We brought in two 90,000-pound cranes to right the tree,'' said Raul Bustamante, the Hilton's general manager.
The hurricane forced the Condado Plaza into its fourth renovation in about two years. The top floor of La Concha Hotel was closed while the roof was repaired. Hyatt spent a fortune relandscaping the grounds of its Dorado Beach Hotel and adjacent Cerromar Regency Hotel.
The Luis Munoz Marin International Airport suffered about $20 million in damage, but neither of the two runways was damaged and a few planes resumed arrivals two days after the hurricane. The winds downed thousands of trees and ripped the leaves from others, which were left as bare as a New England forest in winter. But Puerto Ricans point out that nature rebounds quickly in the tropics.
 
Accommodations
With its crescent-shaped beach, two swimming pools and eight tennis courts, numerous restaurants and nightclub, the Caribe Hilton continues as the jewel of hotels in San Juan. For its 40th anniversary celebration, the Caribe Hilton has booked a Brazilian review into its enlarged and refurbished nightclub, the Club Caribe. High-season rates, beginning Dec. 18, are $200 a day for a single room and $260 for a double.
The recently restored Radisson Normandie Hotel alongside the Hilton was built in 1939 by an eccentric millionaire, Felix Benitiz Rexach, who loved all things French. The building was patterned after the superstructure of the French liner Normandie. From Dec. 23, the Art Deco-style hotel will charge from $140 for a single and $155 for a double.
About 20 minutes' drive from San Juan are the Cerromar Regency and the adjacent Dorado Beach, both operated by the Hyatt chain. They have 4 Robert Trent Jones-designed golf courses, 21 tennis courts and miles of beaches. The Cerromar has what it bills as the world's largest river pool meandering through its gardens. It features honeymoon, family, golf and tennis packages starting at $489, double occupancy, for four nights. Regular rates start at $235 daily at the Cerromar and $299 at the Dorado Beach.
In a more moderate vein in San Juan is the off-the-beach Excelsior Hotel where winter rates are $80 single and $107 double. Lower prices are also available at the 15 small hotels and inns called Paradores Puertorriquenas, promoted and sometimes owned by the government.
Parador El Guajataca is a 38-room hotel on the Atlantic outside the little town of Quebradillas on the north coast. Its long beach is too wild for swimming but the hotel has a pool and nice rooms. The rates at El Guajataca start at $57 for a single and $60 for a double. Across the island on the south coast, the Caribbean shore, is the Parador Villa Parguera, near Phosphorescent Bay, whose waters light up like thousands of fireflies when disturbed. The Parguera's rates are $60 for all rooms, double or single.
Hacienda Gripinas in the mountains outside the town of Jayuya is a 19-room inn with a pool and little else beyond friendly charm. The rates are $35 single, $40 double.
 
Transportation
From New York, Miami and Atlanta on American, Eastern and T.W.A. From Philadelphia: USAir Delta Airlines provides service from the West Coast. Pan American World Airways is scheduled Dec. 15 to resume flying in and out of Puerto Rico from Miami.
 
SABA
SABA TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, N.Y. 11768
800-344-4606
 
Overview
Although Saba, in the Netherlands Antilles, was a victim of Hurricane Hugo, it has made a good recovery, according to officials on the island. They say that tourist facilities escaped major damage, and that most private homes have been repaired. Already all of the remaining trees are covered with foliage, thus quickly erasing the damage done to the forested part of the island, a resident reports. All tourist facilities will be operating this winter.
Brigadoon, a new tourist restaurant in Windwardside, is open for business. It is owned and operated by Gregg Johnson. It would seem that the Johnsons have it this season as the Captain's Quarters Hotel will be operated from now on by Joe and Locky Johnson.
Saba's No. 1 attraction is diving. The three dive shops - Sea Saba, Saba Deep and Wilson's Dive Shop - are all preparing for an increased number of overnight visitors and a flow of day trippers from neighboring St. Martin. Because of the increased diving activities, a recompression tank has been acquired by the local hospital and will be operating by the end of the year. The Royal Netherlands Navy, which donated the four-person chamber, is providing technical and medical training for volunteers from the local diving community. The tank will be the only one of its kind in the Eastern Caribbean.
Saba prides itself on being the ''Unspoiled Queen'' of the Caribbean, and there is growing concern among the 1,000 islanders about overdevelopment. (Construction of a 25-room hotel, the island's largest, is expected to start in March. It will be managed by Sheraton.) This concern is tempered by the knowledge that Saba's limitations are its best assets. No beaches, no casinos, few hotels. Most visitors are divers, hikers, artists, writers and retirees. Although 25,000 visitors a year seems a lot for a five-square-mile island, Saba's island government is convinced that it can safely accommodate 50,000 visitors a year without doing damage. A Saba Conservation Foundation has been formed to preserve the island's beauty.
 
Accommodations
Captain's Quarters Hotel has 10 rooms and a swimming pool. Winter rates are $85 for a single room, $110 for a double, with Continental breakfast.
Scout's Place has rates of $65 for a single, $85 for a double, with breakfast. A 5 percent government tax on rooms and a 15 percent service charge are applicable at both hotels. There are also some smaller guesthouses: Cranston's Antique Inn and Caribe Guesthouse in The Bottom, the capital, and Sharon's Ocean View in Hellsgate. Apartments range from the luxurious Juliana's to small Saban cottages.
 
Transportation
Saba is served by Winair from the Dutch side of St. Martin and St. Eustatius with five daily flights. Charter flights are also available from St. Kitts and Nevis by Air St. Kitts-Nevis (809-469-9241).
 
ST. BARTHELEMY
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
The French island's sixth annual St. Barts Music Festival, Jan. 24 to 28, in the capital of Gustavia and the small town of Lorient, will include both music and ballet. Claude Bolling, the French pianist; Brian Reagin, solo violinist and concertmaster of the North Carolina Symphony and Valentina Kozlova, formerly of the Bolshoi Ballet, are among the artists. Tickets, from $9, will be sold through the St. Barts Tourist Bureau and on the wharf in Gustavia. Further details can be obtained from Frances Debroff, 6847 Juniata Place, Pittsburgh, Pa. 15208 (412-362-6619).
 
Accommodations
Grand hotels include the Guanahani, with 64 rooms on the beach from $325 to $415 a day and suites from $560, and the Castalets, which is on a hillside and has 10 rooms with rates from $140 to $495, including Continental breakfast. Ten percent for tax and service is added.
No hotels on the beach charge less than $100 a day. Among the budget hotels is the Sunset, in the capital of Gustavia. It has eight rooms at $92 to $110 a day for two. The 12 rooms of Tom Beach are near the water, at St. Jean, and they are $135 to $160. The Hostellerie des Trois Forces - the owner is an astrologer - is a 12-room lodge in the hills at Vitet that charges from $120 with Continental breakfast.
Among new accommodations is La Residence St. Barth, on a hilltop at Petit Cul de Sac in the northeast part of the island. There are 12 one-bedroom and 8 two-bedroom apartments, each with living room and equipped kitchen. Amenities include satellite TV, video and direct telephone, and there are six swimming pools and views of the Atlantic and Caribbean. Full maid service. Private terraces. Rates: $225 a night for one bedroom, $300 for two. Reservations through International Travel & Resorts (800-223-9815).
 
Transportation
From St. Maarten (Dutch side) on Air St. Barthelemy and Winair, and from St. Maartin (French side) on Air Guadeloupe; from St. Thomas and San Juan on Virgin Air; from Guadeloupe and Antigua on Air Guadeloupe. Catamarans sail daily from Philipsburg, St. Maarten, and a motorboat goes from Marigot, St. Maartin, three days a week.
 
St. Croix
 
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-582-4520)
 
Overview
Visitors will notice many fallen trees, buildings that were severely damaged and a busier-than-usual downtown Christiansted, where an influx of Federal officials and business people helping with repair efforts has increased activity in recent weeks. Some duty-free stores have reopened in Christiansted. Frederiksted shops are not expected to reopen until the pier is ready to accommodate cruise ships, probably in late January. Most of the island's popular restaurants are open.
The island may not have power fully restored until early 1990. Hotels either have electricity or their own generators. By the end of December, 90 percent of telephones and all business phones are expected to be working. During repairs, phone service can be erratic. The St. Croix Hotel and Tourism Association has a toll-free number for people needing help with reservations: 800-524-2026.
The new Carambola Beach Resort and Golf Club is not scheduled to reopen until spring, when repairs and renovations should be completed. Golf is available at the Buccaneer Hotel. Most beaches are in good condition. Horseback riding through the rain forest (Jill's Equestrian Stables) or on the island's East End (Hidden Valley Stables) will cost about $40. Sailing to Buck Island is also $40. The Cruzan Rum Distillery offers free tours. The Whim Greathouse and Museum, displaying a sample of 18th-century life, is open. Admission: $4 for adults and $1 for children.
 
Accommodations
The Buccaneer (800-223-1108 or 809-773-2100), a 147-room beachfront resort, is managed by the third generation of its founder. It has a health spa, 18-hole golf course and eight tennis courts. All water sports are available. The Terrace Restaurant features Continental cuisine, the Mermaid Restaurant is casual. Entertainment nightly in the Terrace Lounge. Rates for two people for seven nights: $2,170.
All 38 rooms at the Cormorant Beach Club (800-548-4460 or 809-778-8920) are on the beach. Its restaurant features casual daytime dining and Continental cuisine in the evening. The Cormorant's restaurant and bar are reserved for hotel guests until dinner, when they are open to the public. Rates include breakfast, lunch and all drinks until 5 P.M. Seven nights for two people: $2,450.
For smaller budgets there is the King Christian (800-542-2012 or 809-773-2285), a harborfront hotel with a freshwater swimming pool and 39 air-conditioned rooms. With its in-town location, it is a quick walk to duty-free shopping and Christiansted restaurants. A room for two for seven nights, $525.
Cottages by the Sea (800-323-7252 or 809-772-0495) consists of 17 cottages, with kitchens, on the beach in Frederiksted, at the quiet end of the island. With few other hotels nearby, the beach is uncrowded. Two people staying seven nights pay $504. A 7.5 percent hotel tax is added to all rooms.
 
Transportation
American, Pan American and Midway fly into St. Croix from New York. These and other airlines also have flights to San Juan, where there are commuter plane flights to the island.
 
St. Eustatius
 
ST. EUSTATIUS TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, N.Y. 11768
800-344-4606
 
Overview
Hurricane Hugo inflicted extensive damage to private homes and harbor facilities. Work has been going on since the storm and most of the damaged houses and tourist facilities have been repaired. St. Eustatius, or Statia, as this Dutch island is known, played a prominent role in supplying the rebels during the American Revolution. It paid dearly for this support as Adm. George Brydges Rodney invaded the island in 1781 and laid waste its Lower Town, the ruins of which are a major tourist attraction nowadays. Other attractions are a walking tour taking in the history of the island, the Historical Foundation Museum and the rain forest in the crater of the extinct volcano named the Quill. The eight-square-mile island has a population of approximately 1,800 people.
Among new developments, both in town, are the addition of eight rooms to the Talk of the Town, a bar and restaurant, and the reopening of Hotel Gloria, a small guesthouse that had been closed for several years.
There are two dive shops: Golden Rock Dive Center and Dive Statia. All dives are boat dives and include guided tours, tanks, weight and weight belt. Remnants of 18th-century harbor life can be seen by divers in the old shipwrecks, pieces of pottery, pipe stems and occasional blue trading bead.
 
Accommodations
St. Eustatius has two small hotels on the bay in Lower Oranjestad. The Old Gin House, a faithful reconstruction of an 18th-century building that once housed a cotton gin, charges $125 a person, double occupancy, with breakfast and dinner, or $90 European plan. Three people each pay $105 or $70. Rates at the Golden Era are $88 for two or $104 for three, European plan.
There are other small guesthouses and apartments, including the Henriques Apartments in town, with rates ranging from $15 a person a day.
 
Transportation
From New York, nonstop to the Dutch side of St. Martin on American, then on Winair. From Miami, direct flights to St. Martin on Eastern Airlines. LIAT and Winair fly to St. Eustatius from St. Kitts.
 
ST. JOHN
 
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-582-4520)
 
Overview
Most of St. John looks as if Hurricane Hugo barely touched it. Visitors will notice some missing palm fronds, but the island remains lush and green. Beaches are as beautiful as ever, as is the snorkeling and diving. With few exceptions, the island has full electrical power and telephones are working. Mongoose Junction, the shopping area a brief walk from the ferry dock at Cruz Bay, has added more shops, including jewelry and clothing stores. The Annaberg Sugar Mill ruins provide an insight into the island's history. No admission charge.
 
Accommodations
A 7.5 percent hotel tax is added to all rooms.
The renowned Caneel Bay (809-776-6111) suffered damage in the storm, but the resort is ready for the season. At least 60 rooms of the total of 170 are available, and 32 have been remodeled. All three restaurants will be open by Christmas. The Sugar Mill Restaurant was recently renovated, enhancing the character of the 18th-century building. Fresh seafood and pasta dishes are the specialties. Guests receive unlimited use of such facilities as tennis courts and sunfish boats. The rate for two people for seven nights, including breakfast, lunch and dinner: $4,130.
The 254-room Virgin Grand Beach Hotel (800-323-7249 or 809-776-7171) has landscaping that is difficult to match, and it survived the storm remarkably well. The contemporary design of the hotel and buildings complements the symmetry of the 34 acres of gardens. A quarter-acre swimming pool appears to blend into the nearby sea. The Fronds Restaurant serves Continental cuisine; two other restaurants are more casual. Wind surfing, tennis and snorkeling are available. The rate for two people for seven nights, including breakfast: $2,065.
For smaller budgets there is the 14-room Cruz Inn (809-776-7688), a gathering spot near town for St. John residents. Popular videos are shown Thursday and Saturday nights, and drinks are served at the bar nightly. The inn offers a comfortable West Indian-style ambiance. None of the rooms are air-conditioned, but all have fans. Bathrooms are shared. The rate for seven nights for two people is $525 and includes Continental breakfast.
 
Transportation
Travelers fly to St. Thomas to catch one of the many ferries from Charlotte Amalie or Red Hook, reached by taxi, to Cruz Bay on St. John. The V.I. Seaplane Shuttle from Charlotte Amalie to Cruz Bay harbor is not operating.
 
ST. KITTS AND NEVIS
 
ST. KITTS-NEVIS TOURIST BOARD
414 EAST 75th STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10021
(212-535-1234)
 
Overview
The two-island nation - St. Kitts and its partner, Nevis, are separated by a two-mile-wide strait - was among Hurricane Hugo's casualties. But most accommodations plan to be open, at least partly, and several new projects are being constructed. Roads and airport are open and the ferry across the strait to Nevis is running. Among the hotels that were victims of the storm that swept away trees, plants, roofs and shingles were the Cliffdwellers, on Nevis, which was destroyed, and the Zetland Plantation, also on Nevis, which was badly damaged but may reopen with some new rooms in February.
On St. Kitts the storm delayed the completion of the seven-mile road, now open, that provides access from Frigate Bay to the southeast peninsula, which contains some of the island's best beaches. A spur road to Banana Bay and Cockleshell Bay is being built, and the Deputy Prime Minister, Michael O. Powell, said both sites have been purchased by developers who intend to construct resorts. One of the developers is Sandals, the group that operates all-inclusive resorts on Jamaica, and it hopes to start work at the site of the former Banana Beach Bay Resort in January. On Nevis, the Four Seasons group is building a resort with an 18-hole golf course at Pinney's Beach, where a noted beach was washed away by Hugo. An island official said that the employees on the Four Seasons site were released by the hotel to do reconstruction work after the storm and played a big role in Nevis's recovery.
Meanwhile, the two islands plan to capitalize on their opportunities for divers intrigued by sunken ships. One of the four dive operators, who lists a dozen wreck sites for visitors who care to explore them, said that until now most divers have been content to study underwater life and caves, including the series of coral grottoes on the west side of Nevis. The tourist board says official records list more than 390 ships sunk in their waters between 1492 and 1825.
 
Accommodations
On St. Kitts, Rawlins Plantation lost the roofs of 2 of its 10 cottages but reopened in November after repairs. The winter rate of $375 includes breakfast and dinner and afternoon tea. The Golden Lemon opened with 12 new cottage rooms this month. Double rooms, with breakfast and dinner, are from $285, and there are villas with pool from $380. A New Jersey bookseller, Art Keusch, his wife, daughter and son-in-law, will open Ottley's Plantation, a converted greathouse and separate cottages, in January with 15 of a planned 65 rooms.
Less expensive choices in St. Kitts are the Fairview Inn, a cottage complex with rooms from $88 to $98, and the Fort Thomas Hotel, overlooking the Basseterre Bay, which charges $85 and $95.
On Nevis, the 16-room Mount Nevis Hotel has been open without interruption and has added a water-sports facility with shops on Newcastle Beach. Rates for two are $170 and $210 a day. The Hermitage Plantation Inn, Croney's Old Manor, Golden Rock Estate and Nisbet Plantation are among the island's small inns opening their doors this month.
Budget: Pinney's Beach Hotel, within walking distance of Charlestown, the capital, has rooms at $100, or $150 with breakfast and dinner.
 
Transportation
St. Kitts from New York on B.W.I.A. on Sunday and Thursday, and daily from San Juan on American Eagle. From Antigua and other islands on LIAT.
Nevis from Antigua on LIAT or Carib Aviation and from St. Kitts on LIAT. There are two ferries a day, except Thursday and Sunday, in each direction between St. Kitts and Nevis. The fare is $5 one way.
 
ST. LUCIA
 
ST. LUCIA TOURIST BOARD
820 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-867-2950)
 
Overview
Tourism is a major generator of foreign exchange and employment on this former British colony, which became fully independent a decade ago. Last year, tourist arrivals reached a record 214,000, compared with 202,000 the previous year. Expenditures by tourists also set a new mark, $125 million. The islanders call their home the ''Helen of the West.''
The southwestern town of Soufriere, 26 miles from the capital, Castries, boasts the towering twin cone-shaped mountains known as the Pitons (2,619 and 2,461 feet tall). Soufriere is also the home of the world's only drive-in volcano, the bubbling Sulphur Springs (actually remnants of former volcanic activity), which have been active for several centuries. Nearby are mineral baths that are said to be beneficial for respiratory complaints.
Throughout the 238 square-mile island are sites of historic significance, a testimony to the more than 150 years of military and naval conflict between the British and the French for possession of St. Lucia, which changed hands 14 times between the two powers.
New for this winter is a thalassotherapy center, which offers seawater massages, thermal jet baths, algae bubble baths, salt loofah rubs and Swiss needle showers. Situated 14 miles from Castries, it was opened recently as an extension to the 102-room all-inclusive hotel known as Le Sport. The hotel offers what it calls a body holiday, a program that promises adventure, fun and relaxation through a variety of indoor and outdoor sports and live nightly entertainment. The center includes an air-conditioned gymnasium and an aerobics studio.
 
Accommodations
St. Lucia boasts a range of luxurious, medium and low-budget hotels and guesthouses, more than 2,000 rooms altogether. Its accommodations this winter include the first phase of the Windjammer Hotel, at La Brelotte Bay, a 15-minute drive from Castries. The complex is a series of 16 hillside villas and suites designed to harmonize with the surrounding contours. Each villa features covered terraces and sundecks with private plunge pools and has television and casette players. VCR's are available on request.
