The Windjammer also offers tennis, golf, horseback riding, scuba diving, nature tours, sightseeing expeditions and special excursions for children. One-bedroom suites at Windjammer are $210 to $250 a night, while villas range from $300 to $390 (two bedrooms) and $450 to $490 (three bedrooms) a night.
Three miles from the city is the Cunard La Toc Hotel and Suites, more than 200 rooms classified in seven categories with rates ranging from $215 to $425 a night. Like Windjammer, La Toc is near the beach. All the finer resort facilities are offered with the hotel's compliments. Five tennis courts, an 11-hole golf course and water sports and instruction are available. All major hotels on St. Lucia present nightly entertainment, much of it with a local flavor that emphasizes the island's bilingual cultural heritage.
Among the several low-budget hotels is the redecorated Vigie Beach, across the street from Vigie Airport, with rooms ranging from $55 to $125 a day. Across the Castries Harbor is the 32-room Taipon Reef Hotel, close to La Toc, with rates between $60 and $65, including Continental breakfast. Its rooms are air-conditioned, and golf, tennis, pool and reef snorkeling are available nearby.
 
Transportation
From New York: on American Airlines, via San Juan, to either Hewanorra Airport or Vigie in St. Lucia; or on B.W.I.A., with a stop in Barbados, or via Antigua, with a connection on L.I.A.T. From Miami on B.W.I.A.
 
ST. MAARTEN
 
ST. MAARTEN TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
275 SEVENTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10001
(212-989-0000)
 
Overview
The Dutch side of the island shared with French St. Martin suffered some damage from the hurricane, but officials say life was back to normal after a week. Here, vacationers have a wide choice of resorts, some with casinos and nightclubs as well as tennis courts and boats, and the cruise port of Philipsburg is a center of duty-free shopping along Front Street. Major expansion is planned in the port, with construction starting next year on a new Great Bay Harbor that will eventually provide berthing space for nine ships instead of five. St. Maarten is negotiating with shipping lines to position Philipsburg as a base port for cruises.
Visitors will find some new eating places, including Alba (42100), an outdoor restaurant specializing in Italian dishes near the Treasure Island Hotel. It is open every day for lunch and dinner, and brunch with champagne is served on Sundays. Another, serving light dishes all day, is the Turtle Bar, which has its own boat dock, giant turtle and tropical fish pond on the Airport Road.
Housekeeping facilities can be rented through Simpson Bay Beach Rentals (201-438-6700), which has several houses in the western part of the island - two bedrooms and four bedrooms - that it says are larger and better equipped than the usual vacation villa. The rates, $275 a day for two bedrooms and $425 for four, include taxes, daily maid service and airport transfers. Another rental company, St. Martin Rentals (599-5-44330), lists more than 30 properties, including two-bedroom villas at $2,250 a week.
 
Accommodations
The Oyster Pond Yacht Club is near Dawn Beach at the eastern end of the island, and guests are advised to rent a car, since the area is somewhat remote. Oyster Pond has two tennis courts and a marina and offers fishing and water sports. There are two bars and a restaurant. The 20 rooms range from $150 a night, with Continental breakfast, to $390 for a tower suite with ocean view. A meal plan available with a stay of at least five nights is $40 a person a day, providing full breakfast and four-course dinner. No children under age 10.
On the western side of the Dutch sector is the Maho Beach Hotel and Casino, which has 240 rooms, all with air-conditioning and balconies and some with kitchenettes. There are three restaurants. In addition to the casino, there is a discotheque as well as a shopping arcade and a beauty salon. The hotel's new Comedy Club presents stand-up comedians. The cover charge is $10 a person; no minimum. Outdoors, include tennis (four courts) and water sports. The daily room rates range from $165 to $475.
Among the budget hotels are the 45-room Seaview, in the center of Philipsburg across the street from the bookstore that sells major American newspapers. There's a casino in the same building. Double rooms cost from $75 to $150 a day.
The small Sea Breeze Hotel, which has been in operation for a year, is close to Bel Air Beach. Breakfast and lunch are served. Rates for two are $65 to $75. A 5 percent government tax is added to all room rates; most hotels charge a 10 to 15 percent service charge.
 
Transportation
From New York on American and Pan Am daily and on A.L.M. on Saturdays; from Newark daily on Continental. From Miami on Eastern and Pan Am, from San Juan on American.
 
ST. MARTIN
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-757-1125)
 
Overview
Dynasty Yachts, which rents yachts from the Port La Royale Marina in Marigot, in the French sector of the island shared with Dutch St. Maarten, has new offerings for the season: mini cruises (from two days) and hotel-boat packages (a week divided between hotel and yacht). The price for a one-week cruise (which leaves from the Lonvilliers Marina next to the hotel at Anse Marcel) for up to six people is $6,900. More information and reservations: Dynasty Yachts, Marigot 97150, St. Martin, French West Indies (590 87.85.21).
 
Accommodations
The island has a new grand hotel this month: the Mont Vernon, which has just opened at Orient Bay with 220 suites with private terraces facing the sea. It has a restaurant seating 400. Loews Reservations (800-223-0888) are representing the hotel, which will eventually include a 150-seat meeting room and duty-free shopping arcade. Rates are $215 for a double, with full American breakfast and including service and tax. The established classic among the hotels is La Samanna, at Baie Longue, where rates range from $500 to $640, plus 10 percent tax. The hotel has 85 rooms. The largest hotel is L'Habitation, at Anse Marcel, with 253 rooms; daily rates are from $285 to $350, with suites starting at $375.
Budget travelers can turn to inns like the new Caraibes-Story offering five studios on a beach at $90, including Continental breakfast. In Marigot the Royale Louisiana, with 68 rooms, charges $86, and Continental breakfast is included. Rates of $91 to $146 apply at the Hevea, with eight rooms, at Grand Case; it has a restaurant but is not on the beach.
Among new properties this season is the Simson Beach Marine Hotel, with 128 studios and 48 duplex apartments, on the lagoon shore of the neck of land that extends west from Marigot, in the area called Nettle Bay. The hotel, scheduled to open next weekend , will offer complete resort facilities, with pool, restaurant, bar and boutique. Each of its two-story buildings have loggia with wooden balcony and interior furnishings in wicker. High season rates are $176 for a double.
 
Transportation
From New York on B.W.I.A., A.L.M., American and Pan Am; from Miami on Pan Am. Planes land at Queen Juliana Airport in the Dutch sector and visitors transfer to the French side by hotel car, taxi or rental car.
 
St. Thomas
 
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212-582-4520)
 
Overview
Frequent visitors to St. Thomas will notice minor changes because of the hurricane, mostly a thinning of the foliage. But the island is green, its beaches clean. Hoteliers and others in tourist-related businesses were quick to make repairs. All but a few of the Main Street duty-free shops in Charlotte Amalie are open. Golf is available at Mahogany Run Golf and Tennis Resort. Three restaurants are not expected to reopen at least for the early winter season - Club Z, Fiddle Leaf and Frigate at Mafolie - but scores of others are ready, from roadside food stands to fine dining establishments. The owners of Fiddle Leaf hope to reopen at a new location in town.
All utilities were damaged by the storm. With the exception of a few isolated residential areas, the island is expected to have full power this month. Television is limited to selected programs, news and sports events on the local PBS station. Some hotels and bars have satellite dishes. Cable television is not due to return until late spring or summer. By mid-November about 80 percent of the island - including most hotels and businesses - had telephone service. It is expected to be fully restored by January.
Coral World, the aquarium-by-the-sea, unveiled its $1 million, 80,000-gallon reef tank last month. Its underwater observatory was damaged and some fish were lost in the hurricane, but everything was repaired and replaced in time for the grand opening of the new tank , which features a coral reef and surrounding sea life. Admission: $10; $6 for children.
Most charter boats withstood the storm. All-day sails, including snorkeling, lunch and beverages are available for about $65 a person, and plenty of deep-sea fishing charter boats are available.
 
Accommodations
A 7.5 percent hotel tax is added to all rooms.
The newest hotel on the island, the Elysian (800-343-4079 or 809-775-1000), which opened on Cowpet Bay Sept. 1, is also one of its smaller ones, with 66 rooms and suites (172 by 1991). All rooms are air-conditioned, have a large balcony, mini-bar and tropical-style bamboo and rattan furniture. Other features: room service and concierge. A health club and water-sports center will open in January. The beachfront Palm Court restaurant features New American and Continental cuisine with a Caribbean accent while the Courtyard Grille offers more casual dining near the free-form swimming pool and grotto waterfall. Rates for two for seven nights: $1,750.
Frenchman's Reef Beach Resort and Morningstar Beach Resort (800-524-4200 or 809-776-8500), the island's largest resort, has remodeled most of its 520 guest rooms and added extensive landscaping. Among its five restaurants is Windows on the Harbor, offering a seafood selection nightly, and Tavern on the Beach, providing an elegant atmosphere for dining by the sea. Entertainment includes a new Calypso Carnival show. Winter rates for two for seven nights: $1,820.
Cheaper lodgings can be had at the Danish Chalet Inn, in Charlotte Amalie (800-635-1531 or 809-774-5764). Mary and Frank Davis are the hosts of this 13-room inn overlooking the harbor. Continental breakfast is served on the gallery every morning as the cruise ships come into port. An honor bar leaves it up to the guests to deposit $1 a drink. Some rooms are air-conditioned; all have fans and telephone; bathrooms are shared. For seven nights the rate for two is $455.
 
Transportation
American, Pan American and Midway Airlines serve St. Thomas and St. Croix from New York, Eastern Airlines from Miami, Continental from Newark. The V.I. Seaplane Shuttle from San Juan is not operating. Most of its seaplanes were destroyed. However, Eastern Metro Express and American Eagle, as well as other smaller airlines, offer several flights each day between St. Thomas, St. Croix and San Juan.
 
St. Vincent
 
ST. VINCENT AND THE GRENADINES TOURIST OFFICE
801 SECOND AVENUE, 21st FLOOR, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-687-4981)
 
Overview
Hoteliers in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a nation of 32 islands and cays stretching south from the largest island, St. Vincent, are taking advantage of Government legislation aimed at encouraging the expansion of accommodations and construction of new properties. They are being given duty-free concessions to import building supplies and furniture. Most of the hotels and guesthouses have fewer than 15 rooms, and they cater mostly to the sailing set, although some visitors come just for the swimming and the islands' serene beauty. After St. Vincent, Bequia, a favorite stop for yacht people, is the largest, and the other inhabited ones are Mustique, Canouan, Mayreau, Union, Petit St. Vincent and Palm Island. Coral gardens with a wealth of marine life are close to the shores of most of the islands.
An 2,500-foot airstrip for light planes is being built in Bequia. On St. Vincent, the Sunset Shores Hotel has added 8 rooms for a total of 27. Wallilabou on St. Vincent's western coast has been declared a port of entry to facilitate southbound boats.
 
Accommodations
One of the most exclusive is the Young Island Resort, 200 yards off St. Vincent's south coast. Guests at its 29 cottages and suites, set along beach and hillside on the 25-acre enclave, take trips in the resort's two 44-foot yachts. Winter rates for two, with breakfast and dinner, are $295 to $495 a day.
On Admiralty Bay in Bequia, nine miles south of St. Vincent, the Plantation House Hotel stands on 10 acres of palm trees and fruit groves and has rose-colored cabanas with verandas as well as rooms - about 25 units in all - in the central plantation house. It also has a restaurant, tennis court and dive shop. Room rates are $210 to $240, including breakfast and dinner. Transfers are arranged from St. Vincent to Bequia by powerboat at a cost of $80 for two each way.
Mustique's only hotel is the Cotton House, where the 19 rooms come with breakfast, lunch and dinner and are priced at from $450 to $500. The 22-room Petit St. Vincent Resort on Petit St. Vincent provides winter rates on request; last summer the rate was $300 for two, including three meals.
Among less expensive lodgings in St. Vincent are the Indian Bay Beach Hotel Apartments, with room rates of $62, including breakfast, and the Umbrella Beach Apartments, priced at $48. On Bequia there's the Frangipani, $40 to $80 for two, and the Friendship Bay Hotel, from $175, including breakfast and dinner. Union Island's Clifton Beach Hotel charges $60 a person, including breakfast and dinner.
 
Transportation
From St. Lucia to St. Vincent on L.I.A.T., Inter-Island Air Services and Air Martinique. From Barbados to St. Vincent on L.I.A.T. Passengers transfer to other islands by boat or small plane. Also from Barbados to Mustique, Canouan and Union on Mustique Airways and Tropicair.
 
TORTOLA
 
BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS TOURIST BOARD
370 LEXINGTON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-696-0400)
 
Overview
The expansive white beaches and most of the tropical vegetation of Tortola, the largest of the islands, have returned to form following Hurricane Hugo, as has most of the tropical vegetation. Most of the B.V.I.'s 300 bareboat and 45 crewed yachts, which escaped the worst of the storm at moorings in sheltered coves, are back in service. Boats are a major ingredient of the tourist scene on Tortola and elsewhere in the archipelago because about 60 percent of visitor traffic is related to sailing. Sailors make visits ashore but spend most of their time on the water.
All of the island's hotels are open for the season. The only one of the seven badly damaged hotels in the B.V.I. that will not open this season is the sole hotel on Peter Island, about five miles south of Tortola. Dive operators on Tortola say that such wreck sites as the Rhone, a British mail ship that sank after a hurricane in 1867, have been made more interesting by Hugo, which shifted the vessel and revealed some bottles and other previously undiscovered artifacts. The Rhone broke in half and its steel wreckage, preserved on the sandy bottom off Salt Island, across Sir Francis Drake Channel from Tortola, is home to myriad species of fish.
Tree surgeons have been at work repairing the J. R. O'Neal Botanical Gardens. The site of the Mount Healthy Windmill in Brewers Bay, built more than 150 years ago, has just been opened to the public as a picnic area.
 
Accommodations
A five-minute boat ride north of Tortola, Guana Island Club offers 850 acres of undisturbed fauna, sand and seclusion. Small, whitewashed stone cottages on the site of a Quaker sugar mill plantation overlook the ocean from a mountain ridge. The island is a privately owned nature preserve with walking trails and undisturbed beaches at the exclusive disposal of guests. The staff stresses a family setting, from the rotating seating chart for meals to the evening Pictionary games and parlor rap sessions. Two tennis courts and water sports are available, as well as excursions to other islands. Weekly rates, including all meals, are $3,255 for double occupancy; $13,020 for the three-bedroom Grenada Villa; and $48,300 to rent the entire island for seven nights. There are accommodations for up to 30 people. Bar charges, motorboats and transfers to the island are additional, as well as 7 percent room tax and 12 percent service charge. The owners can be reached at 914-967-6050.
Back on Tortola, Prospect Reef Resort in Road Town offers a greater variety of activites, including in-house scuba center and charter operation, lighted tennis courts, pitch and putt golf course, Olympic-size swimming pool and private beach. The resort also has a grocery store, beauty salon and car rental business on the landscaped 40-acre estate. With 131 rooms, the resort offers a variety of accommodations. There are seven grades of rooms at daily rates (meals not included) ranging from $110 for a double to $360 for a two-bedroom, two-bathroom villa (800-356-8937).
Among less expensive properties is the Sea View Hotel (809-494-2483) at the western edge of Road Town. It sits on a hillside overlooking Road Harbor and has a small pool, bar and restaurant serving local specialties. Visitors should not expect luxury: none of the rooms have air-conditioning, though they do have ceiling fans and balconies. The hotel is within walking distance of several restaurants and the main ferry dock, the base for various interisland excursions. Daily rates at the Sea View range from $40 for a small bedroom for two to $75 for a studio sleeping three and $160 for a suite for four people (not including meals).
On the other side of the island from Road Town, in scenic Cane Garden Bay, Rhymers Cane Garden Beach Hotel (809-495-4639) offers some of the amenities of resort hotels at budget prices. Guests can windsurf, sail, snorkel or take a leisurely ride in a paddleboat. The beach bar and restaurant are lively night spots, as are nearby Stanley's, a popular steel band venue, and Quito's, home of a performer on the acoustic reggae guitar, Quito Rhymer.
Rooms include kitchenettes, television, air-conditioning and phones. Daily rates are $70 for two.
 
Transportation
Tortola is served by Air BVI, American Eagle, Eastern Metro and LIAT from San Juan and Air BVI from St. Thomas. Or by the Speedy's or Native Son ferryboats from St. Thomas, a 45-minute ride. Both charge $27 round trip.
 
TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO
 
TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO TOURIST BOARD
118-35 QUEENS BOULEVARD, FOREST HILLS, N.Y. 11375
(718-575-3909)
 
Overview
Trinidad has opened a new $2 million cruise ship complex in Port-of-Spain, the capital, which is enjoying growing popularity as a port of call for Caribbean cruise ships. Among vessels now calling at the port are Cunard's Countess, cruising the Caribbean from San Juan, and the Stella Solaris of Sun Line, which includes the port and Tobago, Trinidad's sister island, in some of its combined Caribbean and South American itineraries. Several craft shops are now in place at the new cruise complex. And the devaluation of the Trinidad and Tobago dollar, now at $4.25 to the United States dollar instead of $3.60, may help visitors find bargains.
Also opening in time for the winter season will be an improved deep-water harbor and expanded airport at Crown Point in Tobago.
In Trinidad, the flora and fauna of the Caroni Wildlife Sanctuary, with its scarlet ibis, egrets and many other birds, is one of the island's many excursions, along with the Pitchlake and the Wildfowl Trust tour, which allows the visitor entry to La Brea Museum's gallery and history of the largest known deposits of natural asphalt in the world. There is also the Pointe-a-Pierre Wildfowl Trust, housed within a petrochemical complex, where visitors see endangered species of waterfowl, migrating North American birds and many other species of wildlife. Another nature study tour favored by birders takes vacationers to the Asa Wright Nature Center nestled at 1,200 feet in the mountains of the Northern Range. One attraction there is a breeding colony of the nocturnal oilbird.
Visitors can go to the steelband yards, where musicians are tuning up for the carnival scheduled for Feb. 26 and 27. Along with the bands there will be new calypso tents in town where visitors may listen to the latest calypso songs in a runup to major competitions during the week prior to carnival. During the Christmas season, extending into January, there's a chance to sample such traditional foods as pastelles, pelau, roti, black fruit cake, ponche-de-creme, rum punch, sorrel and ginger beer as well as parang (musical) festivities. The island's biennial festival of classical and folk music in Port-of-Spain attracts thousands of competitors and is scheduled from March 5 to April 7.
In Tobago a major sporting event is the newly labelled B.W.I.A. Pro-Am Golf Tournament, formerly known as the Johnnie Walker Pro-Am, which takes place from Jan. 28 to Feb. 9 at the Mount Irvine golf course. B.W.I.A. is the national airline of Trinidad and Tobago.
 
Accommodations
In Trinidad, the 400-room Trinidad Hilton (809-624-3211), overlooking the city as well as the spacious Grand Savannah, home of horse racing, soccer and cricket events, tops the list among the luxury hotels. Its rates range from $120 (American) a day for a single room to $240 for a luxury suite. At carnival time, room prices start at $178.
At the other end of the city is the Holiday Inn (809-625-3361), with its revolving restaurant and bar on its rooftop and its pool with bar in the water. It's a short walk from downtown Port-of-Spain. Rates range from $90 a day for single rooms and $100 for doubles to $160 for suites. Breakfast and dinner cost an extra $30 a person.
There is a host of budget hotels and bed-and-breakfast outlets on the island, many of them in and around the capital. At Monique's, at 114 Saddle Road, Maraval (809-628-3334), on the outskirts of the city, rates are $28 single, $35 double and $40 triple. Meals are an extra $4 for breakfast and $8 for dinner. The Chaconia Inn, also on Saddle Road, Maraval (809-628-8603), charges $60 to $70 single and $70 to $80 double - without meals. In the south is the 51-room Farrell House Hotel at Claxton Bay (809-659-2230). Its single rate is $35; double, $45, and triple, $50.
At the Kapok Hotel (809-622-6441) on the edge of the city, the 71 rooms cost $60 single, $73 double, and $86 triple.
In Tobago, luxury accommodations include the Mount Irvine Bay Hotel (809-639-8871), with its 18-hole golf course; rates range from $138 for rooms for two and $165 a day for cottages for two. Breakfast and dinner costs an extra $35 a person. At the Crown Point Beach Hotel, prices include cabanas at $65 a day, one-bedroom apartments for two, $90, and two-bedroom apartments at $120. Breakfast and dinner cost an extra $17 a person.
Among the new hotels is Arthur's-on-the-Sea (809-639-0196), lying between two of the most popular beaches on the island: it is four minutes' walk to Store Bay and seven to Pigeon Point. Rates: from $70 a day for two and $85 for three, and the deluxe rooms at $110. Breakfast and dinner: $20 a day per person. Kariwak Village (809-639-8545) has 18 rooms with air-conditioning and they cost $75, double; breakfast and dinner: $25 a day per person.
 
Transportation
Trinidad and Tobago is served daily by major airlines including Pan Am, American and B.W.I.A., daily from New York. An air bridge service between Trinidad and Tobago is operated by B.W.I.A., with flights every half-hour from 6:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.
 
TURKS AND CAICOS
 
TURKS AND CAICOS TOURIST BOARD
GRAND TURK, TURKS AND CAICOS, BRITISH WEST INDIES
(800-441-4419, on island; 516-261-9600, United States representative)
 
Overview
Sport diving and snorkeling are major activities for visitors on these largely undiscovered and quiet islands, which are in two groups southeast of the Bahamas. They were bypassed by the hurricane. Admirers of the British colony talk of its many miles of uninhabited beaches, pure white or gold, and the tremendous visibilty under water. There are nine dive operators in the islands, two live-aboard dive boats and 15 hotels with diving packages. But its rustic atmosphere is beginning to change as more hotels move in, following the lead of Club Med Turkoise, which established itself on Providenciales, known as Provo, some years back. The club can accommodate up to 600, many of whom make use of the sailing and water-sports equipment provided.
A Sheraton Hotel, with 250 rooms, is scheduled to open on Provo on New Year's Day, and a Ramada resort on the same island is expected to be ready by February.
The colony's salt industry is being revived by a Florida company that is using mechanization to harvest salt on the island of Salt Cay.
 
Accommodations>
As yet, the Turks and Caicos lacks a grand tradition in hotels. Most accommodations are small. But Le Deck on Provo and the Kittina on Grand Turk are among the most comfortable. Le Deck, three minutes' walk from the Grace Bay beach, has 26 rooms. Room rates are generally $125 a day. The Kittina, on the water and within walking distance of Cockburn Town, has 43 units, ranging from oceanview rooms at $95 to suites at $140 and two-bedroom suites for $210. A full-service dive operation is affiliated with the hotel. One budget option, the Salt Raker Inn on Grand Turk, has installed telephone, TV and air-conditioning in many of its rooms; rates range from $45 to $105 a night. On Provo, the Mariner at Sapodilla Point has 25 rooms at around $95. Diving enthusiasts can live aboard the Aquanaut (800-348-9778), anchored off the town on Grand Turk. Rates for a seven-night stay, including unlimited diving and all meals, are $1,255 a person. The Aquanaut carries five passengers.
 
Transporation
From Miami to Providenciales and Grand Turk on Pan American. T.C.N.A. (Turks and Caicos National Airlines) offers daily service betweeen islands in the colony and service to Nassau and Freeport, the Bahamas, and Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. Bahamasair flies once a week from Nassau to South Caicos.
 
VIRGIN GORDA
 
BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS TOURIST BOARD
370 LEXINGTON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212-696-0400)
 
Overview
A small mountainous island of 1,000 permanent inhabitants, Virgin Gorda has 1ong been known as a secluded haven of deluxe resorts. Hurricane Hugo ran up a bill of several hundred thousand dollars but caused little permanent damage.
The grottoes formed by huge granite boulders lining the island's southern beaches suffered minimal erosion during the hurricane. Locally known as The Baths, this attraction has been enhanced by the addition of a hillside bar overlooking the boulders and the ocean. However, the Spanish copper mine ruins were battered by the hurricane - a section of the top level was destroyed - and has been roped off in anticipation of repair work.
 
Accommodations
From formal dinners in the Polynesian-style seaside dining pavilion to the full-service yacht harbor, Little Dix Bay (809-495-5555) is one of the most elegant resorts in the Virgin Islands. The 500-acre property includes a white sand beach along Sir Francis Drake Channel, as well as a tennis complex with resident professional. Activities include horseback riding, water sports, tours to surrounding islands and nightly movies.
Octagonal cottages built on stilts offer living quarters with sizable private balconies. Not all of the accommodations are individual cottages, but all are equally comfortable. Each room overlooks either the channel or tropical gardens. The weekly rates are $3,465 for single and $3,955 for double. Several special plans offered, such as scuba, honeymoon and a combined vacation with the Caneel Bay Resort in St. John in the United States Virgin Islands A very private vacation is also available at Biras Creek (809-494-3555), which is on its own isthmus in North Sound. Reachable only by boat, Biras Creek arranges a taxi from the airport to the Gun Creek ferry dock. Dinghies are available to guests, as are bicycles to tour 140 acres lined with nature trails, gardens and two tennis courts. The hotel's private beach borders a small bay offering both water-skiing and wind surfing, depending on the wind conditions. The open-air dining room perched atop the castellated main building overlooks the seaside freshwater pool. The cuisine has a European flavor, including an excellent wine cellar and afternoon tea. The brightly decorated suites each contain a bedroom, living room and private outdoor shower. Weekly double occupancy rates, including all meals, range from $1,860 to $2,760.
The only hotel on the island with rates under $100 a night is the two-story Ocean View (809-495-5230), which resembles a low-budget estate house nestled in lush vegetation. The 12 guest rooms come with mix-and-match furnishings and ceiling fans. The hotel has a bar, restaurant, sundeck and small piano lounge and is across the street from the Virgin Gorda Yacht Harbor, where guests can take advantage of the nightclub, grocery store and dive shop. Rates for a double room are $420 to $480 a week.
 
Transportation
From San Juan on Eastern Metro, American Eagle and Air BVI and from St. Thomas on Air BVI. Also from Tortola on Air B.V.I. Ferries run on some days from Tortola and St. Thomas.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 31, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - FinalDecember 17, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A listing of Caribbean islands on Dec. 10 omitted some B.W.I.A. flights from Miami. B.W.I.A. flies daily to Aruba and Curacao and twice a week to Martinique.
The listing also referred incorrectly to the status of a Sheraton hotel under construction on Providenciales in the Turks and Caicos Islands. An opening date has not yet been set.
Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 10 about resorts in Jamaica misstated the locations of five Sandals properties. They are in various parts of Jamaica, not just in Ochos Rios.
An article on Nov. 19 about the Imperial War Museum in London misstated the date of the 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. As several readers have written to point out, it will be on Dec. 7, 1991, not 1990.
A listing of resorts in the Caribbean on Dec. 10 misidentified a hotel on St. Barthelemy. It is Castelets.

HEADLINE: A Woman Blessed With the Gift of Compassion

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
BISHOP Rosetta Wheeler, head of the 80-member Mount Hebron Church of God in New Haven, ran her hand along her living room wall and gave thanks. She gave thanks for the chairs and the tables and the soft drink she held in her hands. She then told the story of North Carolina where, as a sharecropper's daughter, she picked cotton from dawn until dusk and went home to sleep in one bed with five of her sisters and brothers. One day, she said, she knelt in a ditch and prayed that she be given a better life.
''And God granted me this new life, and that's why I'm always giving thanks,'' she said. ''Because he rescued me from North Carolina. And I will never forget North Carolina.''
Bishop Wheeler, who this week celebrates her 35th year as the head of Mount Hebron Church of God, on Winchester Avenue, a Pentecostal church she founded, evoked such memories to illustrate why she became a consumate humanitarian. 
The recipient of numerous humanitarian awards, she began this holiday season by cooking several Thanksgiving meals from her kitchen which were then sent to the homes of needy families; indeed, she will continue that through Christmas. ''All my pots are big pots,'' she said. An enclosed patio inside her Hamden home stores boxes of donated clothes that she plans to distribute in the coming weeks to local families and to an orphanage her church sponsors in Haiti. A few days before Christmas she will place 300 toys for the neighborhood children under the Christmas tree at Mount Hebron, in the Newhallville section of New Haven.
Despite a series of ailments that have forced her to walk with a cane, Bishop Wheeler - the impetus behind 102 low-income Government subsidized homes in New Haven - has no plans to slow down. ''There's no alpha or omega to my work,'' she said. ''As long as someone needs me, I am willing.''
The Rev. Curtis Colfield, who heads the Immanuel Baptist Church in New Haven, one of the largest congregations in the city, with 3,000 members, has known Bishop Wheeler for 43 years. ''You won't find a better source of help than Rosetta Wheeler,'' he said. ''She's one of these rare, charismatic individuals who has the talent to take on an astounding number of projects and see them through.''
A meticulous dresser easily recognized by her wide-brimmed hats and long-flowing capes, Bishop Wheeler grew up on a farm outside Maxton, N.C., of 10 children. Describing herself as a born preacher, she recalled standing on a mound of dirt in the middle of a cotton field delivering a sermon to her brother Danny, who served as her congregation. ''And when I wasn't preaching to Danny, I was preaching to the birds or the farm animals,'' she said. ''I always had high spiritual aspirations.''
Later she supported her family by chopping and selling wood for $2 a cord. After saving money from running a vegetable and fruit stand, she moved to New Haven in the middle of the 1940's and lived with two uncles, both alcoholics. Finding the situation unbearable, she sought work through an unemployment office, where, for a day's work baby-sitting, she received $20. ''I remember looking at the man in the unemployment office as if he'd made some mistake,'' she said. ''I never in my life thought that anybody could earn that much money in one day.''
Soon after, she began a job as a live-in housekeeper for a heart specialist in New Haven. Within the next few years she completed high school and attended a night school program to qualify as a licensed practical nurse.
From there she moved to New York, where she attended Pentecostal church services and worked in a hospital. All the while, she said, she longed to become a minister. ''My wings were just too wide and the hospital corridors just too narrow for what I wanted.''
When she returned to New Haven in the late 1940's, she began missionary work, holding Bible study classes in the private homes of the elderly. Word spread about the young woman's oratorial talents and before long she was able to fill rooms to capacity.
In 1954, after eight years of teaching, she was ordained a Pentecostal minister. Along with her 100 parishoners she moved into a storefront building on Winchester Avenue and called the new church Mount Hebron Church of God. She furnished the church with chairs that she bought from a thrift shop and later found a pulpit. In the early days she shared her ministry with another pastor, who walked out after the two disagreed over the direction of the church. He took half the congregation with him. Bishop Wheeler recalled that the ordeal ''tore the church to cinders'' and that it took several years to rebuild the congregation.
''Pastoring a church is like riding a bus,'' she said. ''When you first get on, it's full, but by the time you get downtown, it starts emptying out. The only thing to do is turn around and start over again.''
 
A Refuge
From its beginning, Mount Hebron served as a refuge to its surrounding community. A year-round clothing bank was established where parishioners would hang the coats, shirts or dresses on a stockade fence next door for anyone to claim. Meals were cooked and delivered to the needy, and several parishioners took in foster children. Bishop Wheeler, who has four grown children of her own, counted some 100 children that she has taken care of over the years. ''I took them out of jails, off the streets and out of the arms of strangers,'' she said. ''We always tried to make room in our lives.'' In 1974, after serving as a minister for 20 years, she was ordained as one of the first female Pentecostal bishops in Connecticut. (In the Pentecostal, which has 3.7 million members, church, ministers and bishops are ordained regionally.) Despite her pastoral experience and her record as a community activist, many local clergymen rejected the ordination, arguing that the Bible never specified that women could be bishops.
''You could also argue that the there isn't anywhere in the Bible that says a woman can't be a bishop,'' said Bishop Wheeler, who is accustomed to defending her title. ''In other words, God is gender blind.''
Mr. Colfield of Immanuel Baptist recalled when she was elected the president of the Hill-Dwight Ministerial Alliance, the first woman in that post, in the late 1970's. The coalition of clergymen had been trying for months to get Government to build a large cooperative housing project.
 
'A New Place to Live
''After Rosetta was elected, several members quit because she was a woman,'' Mr. Colfield said. ''Others protested that the housing project would never get off the ground with her in charge. Then at the first meeting she stood up and raised the H.U.D. application papers over her head and shouted, 'Whether I do it with you or without you, I'm going to see that 72 families are given a new place to live!' and she did.''
Five years later, Bishop Wheeler, along with another Pentecostal minister, acquired the Government money to build another 20 duplexes two blocks from her church. The homes were completed in 1983. In 1987, Bishop Wheeler received the Humanitarian Award from the New England International Christians for Unity and Social Action; the award was accompanied by letters of congratulations from President Reagan and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. She stores her plaques from the ceremony along with dozens of other service awards in a large cardboard box.
These days Bishop Wheeler spends much of her time trying to raise money for the Haitian orphanage sponsored by her church. One of her fund raisers is a banquet held every spring to honor women in their 80's who have served as foster mothers or have dedicated time to other areas of community service. This year's banquet honored 68 women and was attended by the Mayor of New Haven.
 
Requests for Help
During a recent Sunday service at Mount Hebron, a visiting minister sang with the parishioners, ''I am a soldier in the army of the Lord.'' Amid the sound of tambourines, cymbals and three-part harmonies, Bishop Wheeler, who has been known to chase drug dealers off nearby street corners, sat quietly behind the pulpit, her presence dominating the room.
In her hand she held a letter from a Polish man describing the grim conditions in his country and asking Bishop Wheeler if her church would sponsor his family, thereby enabling them to come to the United States. It was one of many requests she receives each week from people requesting her help.
A blueprint of the church she hopes to build rested on her chair. She carries it with her almost everywhere she goes, showing it to those who might be able to help her raise the $1 million needed to see the project through. ''It's got to get done,'' she said, acknowledging that it would not be easy.
A parishioner who overheard her responded: ''If she says it will get done, it will get done. Because if there's one thing the Lord gave Bishop Rosetta Wheeler it's a knack of getting things done.''

HEADLINE: A Shop Where Youths Learn to Work for More Than Money

BYLINE: By NANCY KENNEDY

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
IN September a submarine-sandwich shop opened here on Sussex Street. Every day since, the small restaurant and takeout business has attracted lunch crowds of St. Michael's Hospital employees and students from the New Jersey Institute of Technology and Rutgers University across the street.
Behind the counter of Jersey Mike's, Newark teen-agers work at the grill, fill hoagie rolls and ring up sales. The scene is the same as in thousands of sandwich shops across the country.
In this shop, however, the teen-agers are not just paid employees; they are also in effect part owners. 
The venture is a cooperative effort by an array of government, social and business entities. Its intent is to break the cycle of poverty, drugs and despair that so often befalls inner-city youths, of whom roughly 1 in 5 is unemployed. If the shop is successful, it could prompt more such efforts in the city and, if organizers have their way, across the country.
''This is a marvelous opportunity for young people to acquire hands-on business experience operating their own retail store,'' Mayor Sharpe James said. ''It provides these young people with the chance to acquire skills needed to turn their lives around.''
It was almost two years ago that Barbara Bell, chief executive officer of the Newark Boys and Girls Club, began looking for a way to give the club's participants a taste of the business world.
''We wanted to reach out to the total child, not just pick up a corner of a child's life,'' Ms. Bell said. ''But in social work, we don't always have real-world experience to offer.''
The club's opportunity came when Ms. Bell met Steve Mariotti, a businessman and a former New York City schoolteacher. In the early 1980's, Mr. Mariotti founded a New York City-based charitable organization, the National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship, that provides underprivileged youths with business training.
Mr. Mariotti and Ms. Bell began planning for the involvement in business training of the Newark club, which provides educational and recreational programs for about 5,000 city children.
Besides the club, the plan included the participation of residents of the Ogden Street House, a state-operated halfway house for juvenile offenders.
''These are kids that have fallen into a trap, the drug trade, life on the street corner,'' said Peter Lisenco, coordinator of programs at Ogden. ''Nothing in their history had shown them that their life could be any different. Now we can instill hope and a sense of accomplishment.''
The final part of the plan was to find a business where the young entrepreneurs could use their training. A search led to Peter Cancro, a 32-year-old Wall Township businessman known for his interest in community service.
Mr. Cancro, the founder and president of Jersey Mike's, a franchise operation, offered to open the 26th Jersey Mike's store. In May, an 800-square-foot storefront on Sussex Street was decided on.
Antwan Dawes, the 17-year-old day manager of the shop, was there when they pushed open the door of the storefront, which in its last incarnation was a bodega. ''It was a mess,'' he said.
Over the next two months, a group of teen-agers fixed up the storefront, transforming it into the now-clean, brightly lighted Jersey Mike's. Mr. Dawes, who had at one time worked with his uncle in a construction business, pitched in with the others, building counters, painting, cleaning windows and preparing storerooms.
The group's efforts paid off. The employees piqued neighborhood interest by sending out menus and offering samples and coupons. Opening day brought a crowd. The newly trained staff sliced, sprinkled, wrapped and sold 80 sandwiches in the first lunch hour at the shop.
John Hughes, Mr. Cancro's training manager, said: ''After opening day, I told Peter, 'Let's close down all of our suburban shops and go into the urban areas!' We were all left with such a great feeling. The kids are so genuine, and they want to do a good job.''
Since the shop's opening, the business has consistently met its goal of grossing at least $1,000 a day, six days a week. Barring any unexpected downturn, the store hopes to report annual sales of about $350,000.
The City of Newark, through its Office of Employment and Training, recently approved a $100,000 grant for the shop.
When the shop becomes profitable, the Boys and Girls Club and the Ogden Street center will share in the profits, each retaining 40 percent. The remaining 20 percent will go into a fund for the Boys and Girls Club's Ready program, an early education enrichment effort. That program hopes to start businesses for children to benefit from when they reach employment age.
Half of the Odgen Street center's share - which represents 20 percent of the shop's total profits - will be distributed as monthly bonuses to the young workers, Mr. Mariotti said. It has not yet been determined how the funds would be allocated.
''If we had just paid wages, we wouldn't really have addressed the problem,'' Ms. Bell said. ''We thought they should also share in the profits.''
It is also planned that the youths will eventually be given at least 40 percent of the stock, which is now held by a corporation set up by the Boys and Girls Club. The details of the arrangement have not yet been worked out.
 
Classes Completed by 300
For the program participants, Mr. Mariotti has boiled down his Harvard business degree course work into 80 one-hour classes. Over the last two years, 300 Newark youths have completed Mr. Mariotti's classes, and 500 are now being taught by him. He also teaches the toughest of students - inmates at Rikers Island.
Though not all the program's participants get to work at Jersey Mike's, those who do are not pressured to move on. The program, however, does encourage participants to move up into management positions, with the goal of someday running their own businesses.
Mr. Mariotti works with the youths not employed at Jersey Mike's, helping them find jobs. Children as young as 8 years old are taught in the program, but employees at Jersey Mike's must be at least 14.
Even before the youths begin the program, they are well equipped with business skills, Mr. Mariotti said.
''Kids from the inner city, especially those who have worked in the drug industry, have more business experience than the vast amount of people,'' Mr. Mariotti said. ''They know about sales, marketing, business strategy and record-keeping. They have proved they have the mental toughness, the street smarts any entrepreneur needs.''
The high point of the training is a trip to a wholesaler, where Mr. Mariotti gives each student $15 to spend on items of his choice. When the young entrepreneurs find they can resell the items for more, their education comes into focus.
 
Seeing Themselves as Equals
''Kids in the retail drug trade or involved in car theft can make hundreds or thousands of dollars a day,'' Mr. Mariotti said. ''But I think they would rather earn $25 or $30 a day in legitimate business. It's not the money, but the fact that they've been left at the bottom of the hierarchy. When suddenly they see themselves as equal to other human beings, it's like lifting the Empire State Building off their shoulders.''
Mr. Dawes, a member of the class that began in July, bought $12 of candy at a wholesale store. Peddling the stock to his friends, he eventually pocketed $25.
The experience has been a turning point for Mr. Dawes, who recently finished his term at Ogden House. Today, his motivation to succeed is simple. ''I don't want to get into any more trouble,'' he said. Asked where he would be if he had not entered the business program, he quietly answered, ''Locked up.''
At the shop, Mr. Dawes began by working at the grill. He has been promoted twice in less than three months, becoming manager last month. In that time, his salary has increased to $7 an hour from $4 an hour. He works eight hours a day, six days a week. ''I've never worked as hard, but it's fun,'' he said.
He wholeheartedly endorses Mr. Mariotti's efforts. ''I learned a lot of good things about business in his class,'' Mr. Dawes said, ''how to make sales, how to open a store. He's all right with me.''
 
Getting a Chance at 17
And Mr. Cancro knows what it is like to be young and hoping for a shot at success. At 17, he was offered the chance to buy the original Mike's submarine shop in Point Pleasant, where he had worked since he was 14.
The problem was the $125,000 asking price and a 72-hour deadline. His family had no money, and bankers had no faith in a teen-ager who by law was not even old enough to operate the shop's meat slicer. Mr. Cancro finally found a believer, a former high school football coach of his who put up two-thirds of the money and persuaded investors to join him.
''I was 17 and a football coach gave me a shot,'' Mr. Cancro said. ''What inspires me is that 17-year-old.'' The Boys and Girls Club bought into the Jersey Mike's franchise with the backing of an anonymous donor.
For its part, Jersey Mike's has waived its usual franchise fee, which amounts to 5.5 percent of the shop's annual gross sales, a saving to the shop of about $20,000 a year, Mr. Cancro estimated. The franchise also provides training for each of the shop's employees and keeps a close watch on operations. There are weekly meetings with the store's management.
 
The Satisfaction of Working
''Working for your money can be one of the greater satisfactions of life,'' Mr. Cancro said. ''We want as many youths as possible to learn that before they think of other ways.''
Other ventures of this sort may depend on the support of corporations willing to put up the money for their start-ups. Wanting to see that come about, Mr. Cancro has been in discussions with several major corporations, including Coca-Cola.
Graduates of the entrepreneurship program are almost unanimous in their desire to make their own futures. Mr. Dawes has, for the first time, opened a bank account. ''I want to save for the future,'' he said. Some of the savings, he says, are earmarked for birthday presents for his baby daughter, who will be a year old on Christmas Day.
With his earnings, Mr. Dawes also helps to support his mother, with whom he lives. When asked whether he would like to own his own shop one day, he answered: ''Yes! Yes! Soon! I can do it. I know I can.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of trainees preparing sandwiches at Jersey Mike's; Steve Mariotti with Barbara Bell (pg. 20) (NYT/Frank C. Dougherty)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-DATE: December 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 18, Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1504 words

HEADLINE: Wooed By Developers, Stables Resist

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
HORSE racing may be the sport of kings, but in Westchester horseback riding is the sport of commoners, say the co-founders of the Westchester Horse Council, the equine industry's voice in the county.
''Horse people come from all types of backgrounds,'' said Elizabeth Bartholomew of Chappaqua. ''Secretaries on comparatively modest salaries own horses. Middle-class families own horses and so do heads of multimillion-dollar corporations. It's an egalitarian sport.''
John D. Baruc of New Rochelle, who has been riding in Westchester all his life, agreed. ''Mention horses and people think polo, but visit any barn on any given Saturday and what you'll find are recreational riders that represent a real cross-section of the population,'' he said. 
''It's the most democratic sport I know,'' said Mr. Baruc, adding that 70 percent of the horses in the county are used for recreational riding while 13 percent are bred for racing. The rest are either work horses or used for special projects.
Ms. Bartholomew and Mr. Baruc were instrumental in forming a Westchester County chapter of the New York State Horse Council in 1983, to address the problems facing professional and recreational horsemen. The New York State Horse Council is a nonprofit organization founded in 1906 to provide a voice for people interested in horse-related activities.
''What many people don't know is that Westchester is the greatest county of horse activity in the nation,'' Ms. Bartholomew said. ''For decades horses have added to the quality of life here and helped preserve open space.''
''They also produced more than $90 million a year for the local economy, the revenues generated by horse-related goods and services,'' Mr. Baruc said. But state agricultural officials have just released a report showing that the number of horses in the county has fallen by 36 percent, to 8,500, over the last decade, ranking Westchester second to Saratoga County among the state's 61 counties.
''Nationwide Westchester is known for its horses, and I'm sad to see us lose first place, although I'm not surprised,'' said John Xanthopoulos, owner of Thorobrook Farm in Harrison and the current president of the Westchester Horse Council.
''Developers want our land and are willing to pay sky-high prices for acreage,'' he said. ''In lower Westchester, especially, the pressure to sell is strong when offers of $500,000 to $800,000 for an acre of raw land are normal. My own farm of 4.2 acres on Kenilworth Road is surrounded by million-dollar homes. Developers come knocking on my door all the time, but I'm not selling out. I love the business.''
Mr. Xanthopoulos said that he spends more than $65,000 a year to maintain Thorobrook Farm, and that his costs are steadily going up.
 
How the Finances Look
''We charge $780 a month for boarding a horse, which is on the low end for the private barns,'' he said. ''Only the two county-owned stables, Twin Lakes and West Wind on California Road in Eastchester, charge much less. They charge $260 a month. But space is limited to 65 horses.''
Mr. Xanthopoulos boards 35 horses, and he owns another 35 horses at Thorobrook Farm that are used for lessons or leased to riders. He said that space for horses had steadily decreased in Westchester.
''We lost 70 to 80 spaces when Hillair Stable in White Plains was sold to a developer two years ago,'' he said. ''Eleven houses are planned for the site.''
The 58-year-old Boulder Brook Club in Scarsdale, now known as the Scarsdale Riding Club, is an example of what is happening in Southern Westchester.
''Boulder Brook was one of the best-known riding clubs in the country,'' Mr. Xanthopoulos said. ''Its stables once accommodated 150 horses. Now most of the land belongs to the Village of Scarsdale and has been converted into athletic fields and all that remains of the original club is a landlocked indoor rink.''
Stiff environmental laws, mandating the removal of manure in dumpsters every three to four days, have also added considerably to the cost of doing business.
 
Considering the Shovel Work
''What two years ago we shoveled and gave to the nurseries, now costs $500 to $700 every time we rent a 39-yard dumpster and deliver it to the nursery,'' Mr. Xanthopoulos explained. ''Now we are lucky if the nursery will accept the manure without charging an additional $50 to drop it off. Yet the nurseries use the manure - mix it with soil and then resell it for $30 to $40 a yard. Although our rising costs have to be passed along, there is a limit. We don't want to price ourselves out of the business.''
In northern Westchester, where large horse farms abound, one of the largest is the 120-acre Old Salem Farm in Lewisboro, owned by Paul Greenwood, a financial industry executive. Boarding fees at Old Salem Farm, including training the rider-owner, are $1,500 a month.
In terms of income, Old Salem Farm is a multi-million business. The farm has 70 boarding horses, trains riders and conducts horse shows regularly. Yet, said Mr. Greenwood, although the number of patrons steadily increases, mounting costs are also a concern.
 
Compensation Fees Up
''Our liability insurance went from $25,000 to more than $125,000,'' Mr. Greenwood said, adding that Old Salem Farm now has to pay 11.45 percent of each employee's salary for workmen's compensation - ''and that includes the 15 who work in the office.'' Businesses normally pay about .35 percent to cover office workers for workmen's compensation.
Mr. Greenwood suggested that the county could help the horse industry survive by coming up with a tax-abatement plan. ''We at Old Salem Farm pay the largest school tax in North Salem and yet no one goes to school,'' he said, by way of example. ''We pay the largest property tax and yet we don't require any of the services. I wish the county would consider putting us in a special category. It would help insure the future of horse farms.''
The county has already helped insure the future of recreational riding in lower Westchester by rebuilding the bridle path that runs along both sides of the Hutchison River Parkway, Mr. Baruc said.
''We have County Executive Andrew O'Rourke to thank for working with us on the preservation and rebuilding of the bridle path,'' he said. ''As part of the highway-renovation program, the state was all set to bulldoze the trail out of existence, but Mr. O'Rourke literally got on a horse and rode the trail and decided he'd work with us to save it for the riders of Westchester.''
Ms. Bartholomew noted that ''not only was the path saved from being cut up into little segments, it's now a safer trail with a better surface.''
''Riders now can go from Eastchester across Interstate 287,'' she said, ''and we have permission to continue on the trail through the Texaco property to SUNY-Purchase and Pepsico, and there's also talk of reconnecting with the Greenwich Riding Trail Association in Connecticut.''
The trails, Ms. Bartholomew emphasized, are for multi-recreational use, equally pleasant for bike riders and hikers.
''But the best place to ride in the world may be the new Rockefeller State Preserve Park in Pocantico,'' she said. ''There are 750 beautiful acres there. And room for everyone, including parking space for horse poeple who bring their horses in trailers. People not only ride there, they drive horses in pairs and do all sorts of terrific things.''
 
The Problem of Zoning Laws
Ms. Bartholomew attributed many of the problems of horse people to lack of uniformity in zoning laws. ''What we need are common zoning standards applied in the county,'' she said. ''Now, every municipality has its own zoning codes. People who sit on zoning boards don't necessarily care or understand the importance of horses to the county. It's really the fault of the horse-owning population for not taking a more active role on zoning boards.
''I don't believe that the horse population in Westchester has dropped 36 percent in the last decade. What I think is happening is that people don't report accurately the number of horses they own because they fear that zoning regulations will work against them. Horses add a lot to the quality of life in Westchester.'' Paul A. Schosberg agreed. Mr. Schosberg, head of the New York League for Savings in Scarsdale, and his wife breed thoroughbred horses on their Pine Lane farm in Lewisboro.
''When we moved to Westchester in 1970, my wife saw it as an opportunity to do something she had always wanted to do,'' Mr. Schosberg said, ''and that's breed horses. She grew up in Scarsdale and has always enjoyed riding. We were lucky enough to buy eight acres and a barn from a retiring equine vet. The breeding farm is mostly my wife's business. She upgrades the stock every year and the operation has been profitable most years.''
Horse farms, Mr. Schosberg said, are a way to preserve open space. ''Esthetically, in my mind, there's no sight better than miles of green pastures, white fences and grazing horses,'' he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORGANIZATION: THOROBROOK FARM (HARRISON, NY); OLD SALEM FARM (NORTH SALEM, NY)

GEOGRAPHIC: ;WESTCHESTER COUNTY (NY)

SUBJECT: HORSES; REAL ESTATE HORSES (91%); EQUESTRIAN SPORTS (90%); HORSE & PONY PRODUCTION (90%); HORSE RACING (90%); REAL ESTATE (89%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (77%); EQUINE PRODUCTION (77%); MIDDLE INCOME PERSONS (76%); WAGES & SALARIES (71%); FAMILY (71%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (65%);

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
4 POWERS TO MEET ON GERMAN ISSUES

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The Ambassadors of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France will meet here on Monday to discuss the rapidly evolving relationship between East and West Germany, an Allied statement said today.
The four nations were prompted to hold the meeting, their first on the Berlin situation in 17 years, by the actions of Germans on both sides of the border. The Germans are rapidly taking practical steps that would make political and social unification possible while skirting political and legal technicalities and, in the view of several Western diplomats here, simply ignoring the prerogatives of the Allies.
The four nations, which occupied Germany after World War II, are still sovereign in both halves of divided Berlin and have not met formally together since 1972, when they signed the Quadripartite Agreement on the city's status that they had reached the preceding year.
 
A Modest Formal Agenda
The Allied statement today said the formal agenda would take up a suggestion made in 1987 by President Ronald Reagan when he was here to discuss improving the safety of air traffic routes through East Germany to the city, as well as the subject of sports and youth meetings. 
But the background to the hastily called meeting is the growing concern by all four powers that the rapid change in East Germany, whose Communist Party elected Gregor Gysi as its new leader on Saturday and will change its name next week, has set in motion a process of disintegration of the postwar European order that none of them can control.
Although Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to arrive here Monday night, American officials in Bonn said he would not attend the conference, which will involve the three Ambassadors to West Germany - Vernon A. Walters of the United States, Sir Christopher Mallaby of Britain and Serge Boidevaix of France - and the Soviet Ambassador to East Germany, Vyacheslav I. Kochemasov.
All four nations have occupation sectors on German territory and in Berlin. In practice, they have delegated much of their sovereignty in Berlin to German officials, though legally West Berlin is not part of West Germany.
But today the Germans are much more likely to act without consulting their allies than they were in the past.
The most significant instance of this recently was Chancellor Helmut Kohl's outlining of a 10-point plan for German unity in a speech he made to Parliament late last month without any prior consultation with the Western allies.
According to officials in London and Paris, both President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher were considerably annoyed at the lapse. Mr. Kohl said after this weekend's European summit meeting in Strasbourg that his discussions with the other 11 leaders had been ''complicated.'' They agreed on a statement recognizing the right of the German people to restore unity through self-determination, but within the context of existing alliances and state borders.
 
Regular Visits by Mayors
Since the East German border was opened on Nov. 9, hundreds of thousands of people have been pouring over to visit every day in what amounts to reunion, if not reunification, and between 1,500 and 3,000 a day decide to stay permanently in the West.
The changing realities are felt in ways big and small. Mayors Walter Momper of West Berlin and Erhard Krack of East Berlin have been visiting each other regularly since Nov. 9, and today they visited the outdoor Christmas bazaar near West Berlin's Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church together, signing autographs among the Christmas trees for a crowd that was half East Berliners, half West Berliners. On Saturday they will visit the Christmas market in East Berlin, off the Alexanderplatz.
Asked what the allies thought of such mayoral meetings, Mr. Momper looked puzzled and said: ''They'd welcome it. They could come down and drink a little mulled wine with us.''
The municipal authorities on both sides of the wall are now beginning to talk about ways to improve water and sewer service, increase the number of telephone lines, fight drug and currency smuggling, and cut sulfur dioxide emissions to reduce foul-smelling smog that repeatedly covers the city.
 
Allies Responsible for Berlin
But Allied diplomats in East and West say that legally the Germans cannot formally assert responsibility for Berlin as a whole. That is reserved to the Allies, who reaffirmed it most recently in the 1971 four-power agreement on the city's status.
Though they have delegated most of their rights to their respective German allies - West Berlin adopts West German law as its own, and East Berlin is recognized by the Soviet Union as the capital of East Germany - they jealously guard other privileges like sovereignty over airspace.
One Western envoy said privately that the United States was in danger of being dealt out of Central Europe if it did not soon assert a stronger interest in how things evolve here. ''The Germans are going ahead without us,'' he said. ''And in Washington we don't even seem to be aware of it.''
The difficulty is that the Allies have often sought to assert that interest, intruding in petty ways that are beginning to offend West Berliners not old enough to remember the days of the Berlin airlift in 1948-49, which enabled West Berlin to survive a Soviet blockade.
 
British Helicopter Evicted
A few days after the Berlin wall was opened last month, the British authorities sent a helicopter to hover over the western side of the Brandenburg Gate, in their sector, to make sure crowds there did not get out of hand. A senior British diplomat was talking to a reporter on one of those days when the telephone rang. ''It's the damned Germans,'' he said, ''telling me to get my chopper off the Brandenburg Gate.''
A Berliner flying into the city on British Airways the other day said: ''When Lufthansa gets permission to fly here, these planes will be empty. We'll remember how British Airways treated us all these years.''
Klaus Bolling, a journalist who lives in Berlin and formerly headed West Germany's diplomatic mission to East Germany, said: ''The Allied military attaches all behave at times like representatives of their national airlines. The Allies are being shortsighted.'' Only airlines in the hands of American, British or French owners can fly in and out of Tegel and Tempelhof airports in West Berlin. Lufthansa, the West German airline, has suggested to the East German authorities that Lufthansa and Interflug, the East German carrier, start direct services to the West from Schonefeld airport on the outskirts of East Berlin. The two lines have initiated direct connections between Leipzig and Frankfurt and between East Berlin and Hamburg, but the allies, who control the air corridors over East Germany, have been reluctant to grant them long-term rights.
As an economic interest, the allied monopoly on commercial flights to West Berlin is small potatoes compared with the possibilities that may soon open up for West German business in East Germany.
 
Business Trip to Dresden
Today, for instance, Lothar Spath, the Governor of the West German state of Baden-Wurttemberg, flew to Dresden with a delegation of West German business leaders, to discuss cooperation agreements, joint ventures and other practical steps with their East German counterparts. They were greeted by Dresden's Mayor, Wolfgang Berghofer, who said, ''The two German states will always remain the heart of the common European house.''
On Thursday, Helmut Haussmann, the West German Economics Minister, will arrive in East Berlin for talks with his counterpart, Christa Luft. The agenda includes East German plans for economic liberalization, West German help in rebuilding East Germany's transport and communications networks, and insuring the security of investment and joint ventures involving Western companies. Chancellor Kohl, who promised a ''completely new dimension of economic aid'' to East Germany if it moved toward democracy, is to meet with Prime Minister Hans Modrow in Dresden on Dec. 19.
But, the daily Der Tagesspiegel pointed out today, West German business leaders are already way ahead of them.
''For most companies - on both sides - the German question no longer seems to be an obstacle,'' the paper said. ''All of them have plans in the desk drawer for cooperation. Not arguments over technical terms but practical day-to-day steps will bring down the borders. 'Reunification' at the basic economic level has already taken place.''
 
Gorbachev Cautions West
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pledging that the Soviet Union will not allow harm to come to East Germany, has warned the West against taking advantage of the turmoil there.
In a speech to the Communist Party Central Committee, Mr. Gorbachev reaffirmed that Moscow would not interfere in the changes taking place in Eastern Europe and said all East Europeans had the right to decide their fate.
But he made clear that he considered any move toward German reunification destabilizing and that Moscow would resist Western attempts to push the issue. His speech was delivered on Saturday and published today in Pravda, the party daily.
