PUB-DATE: December 11, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1921 words

HEADLINE: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
Near the edges of Times Square, new office towers and hotels are climbing toward the gray winter sky - an image of progress wrapped in glass and steel.
But in the neon heart of the neighborhood, especially along 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, life and the skyline have been frozen in place as the delay in developing the area goes into its ninth year.
The area, traditionally a hub for everything from the legitimate to the marginal to the outright criminal, remains a gathering spot for runaways and tourists, for longtime shop owners and young immigrants, for theatergoers and security guards, for drug dealers and their customers. All this is bathed in the blazing lights of huge electronic billboards, movie house marquees and book stores that call themselves ''adult.''
 
'Exciting' and 'Disgusting'
''It's exciting,'' said Leonard Washington, a 14-year-old from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. ''It has a lot of games and cheap movies. You feel protected because there are so many cops around.'' 
But for Marcia Bell, 37, who works in the area as a legal secretary, the bright lights illuminate decay - trash swirling down the street, streams of urine in the doorways, shattered liquor bottles on the sidewalks and legions of hollow-cheeked men whispering about drugs for sale as police officers stand nearby.
''It's the most disgusting seven minutes of my day,'' she said, describing her walk along 42d Street from her job to the subway. ''You're always stepping between the drugs and the money.''
The pace and face of Times Square could soon change. Work on a $2.5 billion 42d Street development project -delayed for years by court challenges - may finally begin by the middle of next year, according to the state agency overseeing the program.
''I think we're out of the woods,'' said Brian K. Kell, a spokesman for the New York State Urban Development Corporation. ''We think all the significant litigation has been decided.''
If the project goes according to the agency's vision, it should be substantially completed by about 1994, nearly 15 years after it was first proposed and opposed. #4 Office Towers Planned Under the plan, four office towers will loom over 42d Street, joining about 15 skyscrapers now under construction or near completion in the area. The more than 40 adult book stores and peep shows that dot Times Square will be swept away and nine once grand theaters restored.
By the time the dust settles, 20 buildings will have been demolished and more than 400 businesses displaced.
In the meantime Times Square remains what it has been for decades, a midtown carnival midway - both enticing and menacing.
Times Square is a crossroads above and below its streets, said William Kornblum, director of the Center for Social Research at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York City. Mr. Kornblum's graduate students once estimated the pedestrian traffic in an hour on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues to be 3,600 people.
 
Heavy Traffic Underground
The traffic flow is similar beneath its streets. Five subway lines converge under Times Square, and more than 120,000 people a day hustle through the Times Square subway station, making it the second busiest in the city. Only the Grand Central subway station handles more people.
Above ground, people have long flocked to the area to sample its smorgasbord of restaurants, theaters and movie houses. Many of the nightclubs that were once common have long gone, but along 42d Street a customer can still see two first-run movies for the price of one.
''This is like a big social area,'' said Theo Butts, 20, a Bronxite, as he stood on the corner of 42d and Broadway, trying to decide which movie to see. ''There's a lot of different things to do here. We don't have this stuff in our neighborhoods.''
But Times Square is suffering, Mr. Kornblum said.
''Many parts of the city are getting more dangerous, and especially the segregated low-income parts of the city,'' he said. ''And the violence is spilling over into public places. That's Times Square.''
 
A Magnet for Crime
In 1988 an average of six to seven crimes a day were reported on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
''I think it's probably worse this year,'' said William H. Daly, director of the Mayor's Office of Midtown Enforcement. ''Criminals gather there to plan their forays into other parts of the city and into other parts of Times Square.''
What a difference a block makes. A yearlong total of 39 crimes were reported on 42d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Mr. Daly said.
Mr. Daly's agency was created 14 years ago to clean up Times Square by aggressively enforcing city building codes and business licenses. When it started, Times Square was overrun by the commercial sex trade.
''Forty Second Street has always been a naughty zone,'' Mr. Daly said. ''In the 60's it became a sex zone, a red-light district. Now the problem is crack and acts of violence.''
But he added: ''I would hate people to get a one-sided view, that it's all trouble spots. There has been a lot of progress over the last 14 years. But crack has really complicated our efforts.''
The commander of the Midtown South Police Precinct, Deputy Inspector George F. Brown, said robberies and assaults in the Times Square area were up in August, September and October.
The inspector said he had increased the number of officers patrolling the area in uniform, on horseback, on motor scooter and in plainclothes. He declined to say exactly how many more officers had been deployed.
 
A Narcotics Marketplace
In Times Square, there is little rest for the wicked or the good.
Even on a cold night and well into the next morning last week, drug dealers were out in force. They stood in packs on the corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue, hopping up and down to fight the chill, and in one's and two's along the street.
From darkened doorways that often glowed with the flicker of a cheap cigarette lighter at the end of a crack pipe, the dealers hawked their wares to almost everyone who passed, from middle-aged men in suits hurrying into the adult book shops to sandy-haired young men from New Jersey, looking for thrills and a little marijuana.
''We came over here to get some beers and maybe cop some weed,'' said a 20-year-old from across the river who said his name was Harry Kramer. ''Drugs rule New York. And this is the place to get them.''
It was shortly before 2 A.M. in front of the Port Authority Bus Terminal. As Mr. Kramer left to buy a can of beer, his friend, who refused to gave his name, said he wanted only to get out of the area in one piece. Minutes before, the two men had been chased across Eighth Avenue by an eager drug peddler.
''Another friend of mine got his butt kicked around here,'' the man said. ''They pulled out some guns and took his money.''
Indeed, violence is in the wind blowing through Times Square.
''The drug addicts come around the corner like thirsty warmongers,'' said Jeff McCalvin, 24 and unemployed, who said he ''hangs out'' on Eighth Avenue.
''Any unsuspecting cat they see, they attack,'' he said. ''They dive on him like the linebackers on the Giants.''
On Sept. 18 at 8:30 P.M. at 42d and Eighth Avenue, a drug dealer was shot and killed in a dispute with another dealer. On Nov. 25 a police officer, a suspect and a passer-by were wounded in a gunfight that started when the officer spotted a young man with a gun on Seventh Avenue near 43d Street.
Ali Nettles, 24, has been hanging out in Times Square for 15 years. He said money drew him to its dirty streets.
''Thousands and thousands of dollars can be taken from people who don't know what they're doing,'' Mr. Nettles said. ''There are all kinds of cons you can run on the tourists, on the foreigners. If you can't get a dollar down here, there's something wrong with you.''
 
'Anything for Money'
When the confidence games fail, Mr. Nettles said, many people, including himself at least once, turn to robbery.
''I just got out of jail for robbing somebody at the Port Authority,'' he said. ''But I only did that one time. I ain't a robber.''
Jeff Cohen earns his money not on the street, but behind the counter of The Funny Store, a novelty shop on Seventh Avenue a few steps from 42d Street. His family has operated the store since the 1950's.
Mr. Cohen said that in the last few years he had noticed a marked difference in the neighborhood. ''People are more desperate,'' he said. ''They'll do anything for money.''
His customers are tourists and teen-agers shopping for magic tricks and practical jokes. Plastic vomit is a big seller.
Mr. Cohen said he was opposed to the redevelopment project because it would put his family out of business. The Urban Development Corporation promises to help businesses relocate, but in the novelty trade, Mr. Cohen said, location is king.
''If you're on 18th Street and Ninth Avenue, it's not the same,'' he said. ''See the floor, it's worn out from people coming in here.''
Seven blocks away the floors of the new Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza Hotel are like shiny ice.
The 765-room hotel, which rises 46 stories above Broadway between 48th and 49th Streets, opened Dec. 1. A week later its second-floor lobby was filled with guests waiting for rooms and a drink from the still unfinished bar.
Daniel Risi, the bartender, said he hoped the new hotel and other buildings going up in and around Times Square would rejuvenate the area.
''It won't end crime,'' he said. ''Like prostitution won't end. But the cleaner the area, the better it'll look and, who knows, maybe it'll attract a more sophisticated criminal.''
Down the street on Broadway near 46th Street, a Salvation Army captain, Andres Lugo, and a volunteer, Clark (Shorty) Erskine, stood guard around their red collection kettle. The night before two thieves stole the kettle from a 65-year-old volunteer. Mr. Lugo retrieved the empty kettle from the police.
On the corner, about a dozen young men circled a cardboard box playing a confidence game called three-card monte. Their laughter mingled with the sound of Captain Lugo's bell.
''They scare people away,'' Mr. Lugo said, pointing to the men on the corner. ''People don't want to pull out their money with them around.''
Mr. Lugo said the new hotels and office buildings made Times Square ''cosmetically nicer,'' but will do almost nothing to improve the lives of ''the little guys on the street.''
''I feed 150 people daily at our post on 47th Street,'' he said. ''It doesn't change. It doesn't get any better.''
 
And Now 'Zombies'
At 1:40 A.M. a dozen people were sipping hot chocolate and coffee in a narrow fast-food restaurant on 42d Street. Some of the men were talking loudly and flashing wads of cash - mostly $1 bills.
They talked about discos and guns and making money.
''Did you read about that dude in the paper the other day?'' one man asked his friends. ''He got busted with a whole bunch of ice.'' ''Ice?'' ''That new stuff,'' the man said, referring to a powerful smokable methamphetamine. ''What's it do to you?'' ''You don't want to mess with it,'' the man said. ''They say people walk around like zombies.''
Then the man walked slowly across the floor, rolling his eyes toward the ceiling. ''Is it like crack?'' ''It's worse than crack,'' he said. ''It kills more people.''
The men laughed and shook hands and then stepped into the cold, dark morning that had settled over Times Square.

LENGTH: 863 words

HEADLINE: DENG CITES A NEED TO REPAIR U.S. TIES

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 10

 BODY:
China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, meeting the first high-level American officials to visit here since the June killings in Tiananmen Square, said today that the two countries must restore and improve their strained relations in the interest of world stability.
''We share common desires and common needs,'' Mr. Deng told Brent Scowcroft, national security adviser to President Bush, and Lawrence S. Eagleburger, American Deputy Secretary of State. ''In spite of the disputes and the differences between us, after all, Chinese-American relations have to be improved. That is something necessary for world peace and stability.'' 
Mr. Scowcroft replied that the United States agreed, ''and we are interested in working with you to promote that.''
The visit of Mr. Scowcroft and Mr. Eagleburger was announced by the White House only after they arrived in Beijing early yesterday morning as special envoys of President Bush.
The Chinese have regularly said that relations with the United States, deeply strained since the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in June, could only be improved by American initiatives, and this daylong visit appears to have been such a gesture.
While the Chinese have focused attention on the visit with much pleasure and publicity, American officials have treated the affair gingerly, providing little information about the meetings or their substance.
For example, the official New China News Agency said tonight that Mr. Scowcroft had ''described his visit as positive, constructive and beneficial,'' but American officials showed no willingness to make such characterizations.
 
Steps Taken by Bush
After the Chinese killed hundreds of protesters in June, President Bush imposed an embargo on high-level exchanges, ordered some economic sanctions and suspended all military and civilian weapons sales to China.
He has also allowed Chinese students in the United States who fear reprisals on their return home to remain in America, an action that has drawn Chinese objections, most recently on Friday.
Mr. Deng, 85 years old, formally retired from his last official post last month, but he said it would be ''impolite and unreasonable for me not to receive a personal emissary of my friend President Bush.''
''I think we should say it is the common desire of our two sides to put an end as soon as possible to the disputes between China and the United States prevailing ever since June of this year,'' Mr. Deng added. ''Because we share common desires and common needs, I think in the end we can find a solution.''
Mr. Scowcroft and Mr. Eagleburger left this afternoon for Tokyo to brief Japanese officials on the Malta talks.
An American official said only that the two days of discussions here had laid ''good groundwork'' for better relations. The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Li Zhaoxing, called the conversations useful and constructive.
''I think both sides are happy about the discussions,'' he said. ''Both sides expressed willingness to overcome their differences.''
 
The Nixon Relationship
Mr. Deng - working with the Nixon Adminstration, in which both Mr. Scowcroft and Mr. Eagleburger held high posts - rapidly forged a close Chinese-American relationship as a counterbalance to Soviet influence.
Despite significant changes in the Soviet Union under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, including a conciliation of sorts with China, Beijing and Washington officials both seem happier to be on speaking terms again.
When Mr. Deng met former President Richard M. Nixon here a month ago, he accused the United States of having promoted the Chinese democracy movement and added that Washington had been ''involved too deeply.'' There were no such comments today. Mr. Scowcroft and Mr. Eagleburger, though wary of commenting on the substance of today's discussions, did describe Mr. Deng as weaker and less able to concentrate than in his February meeting with President Bush.
''There has been some slipping,'' an official said. ''Deng was jovial as ever, but seemed to have some difficulty focusing on people. While he usually looks people directly in the face, his eyes sort of glazed over Scowcroft.''
The officials said that one of Mr. Deng's daughters sat behind him and retranslated the English with his native Sichuan accent, which created an echo effect, and that she touched him on the arm when it seemed appropriate for him to speak.
Mr. Deng began the meeting, the American officials said, by saying in Chinese, ''I'm so glad President Carter sent you,'' but corrected himself after having been nudged by his daughter.
 
Criticism by a Top Senator
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Special to The New York Times) - Senator Claiborne Pell, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, today criticized the White House mission to China, saying the Administration should have waited until China improved its human rights policies before seeking closer ties.
''At the very time that freedom is sweeping through Eastern Europe, we should be sure the United States stands for freedom and democracy in Asia as well,'' Mr. Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, said in a prepared statement.

HEADLINE: Baker, in a Call to Shevardnadze, Asks Action on Central America

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Days after the Malta summit meeting, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reiterated in an hourlong phone conversation with the Soviet Foreign Minister that Moscow must take stronger steps to stem the spread of Soviet-made arms in Central America, both men said in programs broadcast today.
Administration officials said Mr. Baker had told the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, at Malta last weekend that he wanted to call him later in the week to go over in more detail subjects that he felt had not been explored fully during the meeting; the summit sessions off Malta were curtailed by high seas and foul weather.
The fact that Mr. Baker spent almost the entire conversation on Thursday discussing Central America, a subject on which Mr. Bush had already gone into detail with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Malta talks, probably had as much to do with domestic American politics as United States-Soviet relations.
After the Malta meeting, many commentators and politicians in the right wing of the Republican Party criticized the Bush Administration for offering Moscow a broad array of economic incentives, apparently without getting anything in return. The criticisms focused on Central America, where Nicaragua and Cuba have reportedly been providing Soviet-made arms for the latest rebel offensive in El Salvador. 
 
A Political Price
An Administration official said that during the conversation Mr. Baker ''made it absolutely clear'' to Mr. Shevardnadze that there would be a political price for Moscow if it did not do more to insure that the Nicaraguan Government allows free elections in February and that Managua and Havana stop shipping arms to leftist guerrillas in Central America.
The official added that Mr. Baker had told Mr. Shevardnadze that the Bush Administration was, to some extent, going out on a limb in offering Moscow economic cooperation and that it could not continue to do this while the Soviet Union allowed its allies in Central America to support insurrections.
Mr. Shevardnadze, the official said, ''did not make any promises.''
''There is no deal here. But I think after talking with Baker he had a better appreciation of the problem.''
Asked about the conversation with the Soviet Foreign Minister on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' Mr. Baker said that ''what he really said was this is something that bears some thinking, some looking at.''
''I went into a bit more detail on points that we have made before, that they need to do a little bit more leaning on their clients in Central America to stop these weapons from going to the F.M.L.N,'' Mr. Baker said, referring to the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the Salvadoran rebel coalition.
 
'An Interesting Proposal'
The Baker-Shevardnadze conversation was not initially disclosed by Mr. Baker. He was asked about it today only after it was disclosed earlier by Mr. Shevardnadze in an interview on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation.'' That interview, through an interpreter, was conducted Friday in Moscow.
''We discussed Central America,'' Mr. Shevardnadze told his interviewer, ''and some other questions as well, but mostly Central America. We suggested - and I think that it's an interesting proposal that should be seriously discussed - that talks should begin between Central American countries about reducing weapons generally, about having defensive sufficiency over there.''
''But that, I would say, is a long-term question,'' he added. ''I think at the present time, we must make sure that those agreements that were reached by the presidents of the Central American countries be implemented. Here, of course, Nicaragua, Honduras, the Soviet Union, and naturally, the U.S., have certain obligations and responsibilities. We must help that agreement to be implemented.''
Mr Baker spoke before he was to depart for talks this week in London, Berlin, Bonn and Brussels on the changes sweeping Eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: Congressman Is Seeking to Balance Constituent Jobs and Military Budget

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BREMERTON, Wash., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Guns and butter are pretty much the same thing in this small community on the western shore of Puget Sound, the home of one of the few Navy yards that can overhaul nuclear-powered vessels.
So it was more than passing curiosity that brought the local Navy brass and Bremerton's business leaders to the Officers' Club to hear Representative Norman Dicks tell how the thawing of the cold war and the reduced Soviet threat in Eastern Europe might affect the Navy's share of the shrinking Pentagon budget.
Across the sound, Seattle and Tacoma are enjoying commercial growth almost independent of the military presence here. Chang Mook Sohn, the chief economic adviser for Gov. Booth Gardner, said, ''The growth is well balanced because the Seattle region has been diversifying in trade and computer technology, and we are in a position to offset some of the potential defense cuts.'' 
 
Shipyard and Base Are the Keys
For Mr. Dicks's Bremerton constituents, fortune remains linked to the shipyard and the Navy's Trident base and Keyport torpedo station 20 miles north of here. The constituents are counting on their shipyard's unique role on the West Coast, and counting on the Trident subs being the last to go at the bargaining table if arms control proceeds more rapidly than anticipated.
''I see the Navy playing a major role,'' Mr. Dicks, a six-term Democrat, reassured his constituents. True, he said, the military construction budget had been ''savaged,'' but he had made sure the allotments would include $18 million for the first installment of a three-year package to upgrade repair facilities at the yard's Pier 4.
Mr. Dicks, a former linebacker for the University of Washington, is as aggressive on the House Appropriations Committee as he was on the football field.
On Capitol Hill, ''Stormin' Norman'' looks out for this state's interests as head of the Subcommittees on Defense, Military Construction and the Interior. He learned that part of his job at the knees of the masters, Senators Warren G. Magnuson and Henry M. Jackson.
For nearly four decades, they saw to it that few spending bills left the Senate without money going home for some highway, hospital, water project or military installation.
 
The Influence of the Elders
''Maggie used to say, 'Norm, don't ever let these guys get into new construction - overhaul and repair work, that's where you get stability,' '' said Mr. Dicks, who was Mr. Magnuson's administrative aide before he ran for Congress himself in 1976.
On broader questions of military policy, the 48-year-old Congressman's views on the military tend to reflect the conservative influence of Senator Jackson. Like the late Senator, Mr. Dicks has managed to create an an important role in this arena while watching out for the interests of the Boeing Company, the Seattle-based aerospace giant to which 1 out of 10 jobs in the state is related.
His district, centered in Tacoma, does not include Boeing, but 15,000 residents of the district work at Boeing, which is a principal subcontractor on the B-2.
As Mr. Dicks toured the district last week, he was blunt about the likelihood that the Air Force would be buying fewer than the 132 bombers originally envisioned, but he told the constituents that nearly 75 percent of Boeing's business was now commercial rather than military.
 
Economists Are Confident
Private economists say that at worst, cancelling the B-2 program would mean workers would be easily absorbed into a growing commercial market. About 7 percent of the workers in the Puget Sound region hold military-related jobs, says the Governor's economic adviser.
Tacoma is more concerned about the Fort Lewis Army base, home of the Ninth Infantry Division, and the McChord Air Force base, a military airlift center that may become home to the new C-17 transport.
The day Mr. Dicks spoke to business leaders in Lakewood, adjacent to the two bases, the local newspaper had a front-page article reporting that the Ninth Infantry had been singled out as the most likely for elimination.
Mr. Dicks phoned Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. He reported later that no final decision had been made. But he told the business leaders he believed the Ninth was vulnerable. He said Army officials had led him to expect that some other division, perhaps one brought back from Europe, would be transferred to Fort Lewis to replace the Ninth. A Misdirected Focus? ''Inevitably, there is going to be a draw-down in the Army,'' Mr. Dicks said. ''I don't think we should look at this as something ominous even though we may have problems right here in the Sixth District. The economy is strong, and if we have to go through this transition, this is the best time to do it.''
Glenn Pascall, a Seattle economist and public policy consultant who has carried out studies for the state on the effect of the military presence in Washington, said that in some ways real production in Tacoma would boost the city's economy.
Mr. Pascall says that both Representative Dicks and retired military people in the district focus too much on a military-based economy and neglect private development. For example, he said, local business groups and politicians should be looking at the opportunity to convert McChord into a commercial airport if the Air Force decides to abandon it.
Mayor-elect Karen Vialle of Tacoma said that residents of Tacoma were used to worrying about the ups and downs of Pentagon budget-making. ''We really don't know what's going to happen,'' she said. ''We're relying on Congressman Dicks to manage these impacts.''

HEADLINE: More Republican Lobbying of H.U.D. Is Disclosed

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Several prominent Republicans and party supporters, not identified in Government files made public earlier this year, have acknowledged that they also lobbied former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and his aides on behalf of development projects, some of which received Federal assistance.
Their names expand the list of well-known Republicans who have benefited personally or obtained assistance for others under multibillion-dollar Department of Housing and Urban Development programs in the Reagan Administration.
The newly disclosed lobbying contacts also provide further evidence of a pattern under Mr. Pierce in which consultants and others with political ties figured in the department's awards process. As a rule, there is nothing illegal about the contacts, but lawmakers and Federal investigators have questioned whether money was awarded regardless of merit.
These lobbying efforts also appear to offer significant examples of how Mr. Pierce, who has indicated that he generally did not participate in the selection of projects to receive assistance, would become involved when called upon by political allies. 
 
Some Who Contacted Pierce
Among those now identified as lobbying the housing department or having been involved in its programs are the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, a veteran of the civil rights movement; Thaddeus Garrett, a longtime friend of President Bush, and David M. Barrett, who headed the organization Lawyers for Reagan in 1980.
Mr. Barrett was identified in H.U.D. documents. Mr. Abernathy and the others were identified in recent interviews with current and former agency officials.
Mr. Pierce's chief lawyer, Paul L. Perito, said in an interview that there was ''nothing illegal or improper'' in whatever dealings Mr. Pierce may have had with Republicans promoting housing projects. The meetings, he said, ''are typical of a Cabinet secretary.''
''Mr. Pierce made himself available to Republicans as well as Democrats,'' Mr. Perito said. ''There is no suggestion nor evidence that as a result of some meeting or as a result of some internal process within H.U.D., that Mr. Pierce received anything of value.''
 
Weeks of Lobbying
These are the newly identified H.U.D. consultants and aid recipients:
* Mr. Abernathy, who endorsed Ronald Reagan in the 1980 election, and whose anti-poverty organization received an agency subcontract, worth as much as $75,000, to provide economic analysis. But the organization's executive vice president said the group had so far received only about $3,000. The award followed weeks of promoting the organization within the housing department, the official said.
* Mr. Garrett, who was Mr. Bush's domestic policy adviser when Mr. Bush was Vice President, and who said through a spokesman that his consulting firm was paid about $9,000 for lobbying H.U.D. and other work on a hotel rehabilitation project in Akron, Ohio. The spokesman, Nicholas T. George, the general counsel for Mr. Garrett's firm in Washington, said that the firm spent dozens of hours over several weeks on the project, and that he was certain that Mr. Garrett's lobbying effort helped secure the $1.8 million grant in 1987. The firm would have received a total of $36,000 if the project had been completed, Mr. George said. But problems in removing asbestos from the site prevented completion.
* B. Melvin Hurwitz, who was a Congressional liaison for the Agency for International Development in the Reagan Administration, and who assisted The Woodlands, an affluent planned community near Houston, in obtaining a $200,000 grant in 1985 from one of Mr. Pierce's two major discretionary funds. H.U.D. documents show the money was used to build a firehouse and emergency treatment center.
Mr. Hurwitz, who was under contract as a lobbyist and legal adviser for an energy company based at The Woodlands, said he put in ''literally months and months and months'' pursuing the grant. And he said there was nothing surprising about the award, since The Woodlands was created in large part through the assistance of housing agency programs in the 1970's.
* Former Mayor Charles Evers of Fayette, Miss., a friend of Mr. Pierce's, said that shortly after a meeting with Mr. Pierce in Washington about two years ago, his city received a discretionary grant of $300,000 to rehabilitate low-income housing. ''I spoke to him as a Republican, and as a black man,'' Mr. Evers said in an interview. Mr. Evers and his successor said the money had been used wisely.
Internal agency documents also show that Mr. Barrett, a Washington laywer who is also a major housing developer involved in H.U.D.-related programs, met repeatedly with at least two senior agency officials in 1986 and 1987.
Federal investigators and news reports have previously identified a large number of prominent Republicans who participated as consultants or developers in H.U.D. programs, including former Interior Secretary James Watt, former Housing Secretary Carla Hills and Paul Manafort, a top campaign adviser to President Bush.
Earlier this month, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh opened a formal criminal investigation to determine whether a special prosecutor, known under Federal law as an independent counsel, should be appointed to investigate Mr. Pierce.
Mr. Abernathy, the former president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, is also the founder of an anti-poverty organization, the Foundation for Economic Enterprises Development, or FEED, that was hired as a subcontractor on a 1985 grant.
In an interview, Mr. Abernathy said that he created the foundation shortly after he endorsed Mr. Reagan's candidacy in 1980 and that the group hoped to establish job training programs for unemployed black youths. ''I was impressed with Reagan's talk about jobs and income for the youth of America, blacks in particular, and so we founded the organization,'' he said.
The foundation's executive vice president, James E. Peterson, recalled that he met with Secretary Pierce before the subcontract was awarded to the organization, and was initially told by the Secretary that H.U.D. would be unable to help.
''But I didn't give up,'' Mr. Peterson said. And later, he said, following conversations with top aides to Mr. Pierce, the organization was offered the subcontract, worth from $50,000 to $75,000, on a $280,000 grant intended to encourage the participation of minority businesses in Federal development programs.
The grant was awarded to One America Inc., a consulting firm. A former senior housing department official, who asked not to be named, said One America was directed by Mr. Pierce's senior staff to name FEED as a subcontractor. The head of One America, Elaine B. Jenkins, denied that, saying that she chose the organizationlargely because of Mr. Peterson's experience in poverty programs.
The relationship between One American Inc., a consulting firm that received the grant, and its subcontractor, FEED, did not end amicably. Mr. Peterson said the organization has only been paid about $3,000 from the subcontract, which required the firm to analyze economic conditions in selected areas. Mrs. Jenkins, said the organization did not deserve additional payments because it had not performed adequately.
 
Rent Subsidy Program
Mr. Barrett, who headed Lawyers for Reagan and was chairman of Mr. Reagan's 1980 transition team at the Securities and Exchange Commission, was a 50 percent owner in at least two Oklahoma housing projects that received rent subsidy guarantees from H.U.D.'s Section 8 Moderate Rehabilitation program.
One of Mr. Barrett's projects in Tulsa received a $1.7 million contract in April 1987.
Mr. Barrett is a friend of Thomas Demery, Assistant Secretary for Housing under Mr. Pierce and one of the officials who directed the rehabilitation program. Agency records show that Mr. Barrett was also in touch with Deborah Gore Dean, Mr. Pierce's executive assistant at the department.
Mr. Barrett has not returned phone calls for comment. Mr. Demery said final decisions on the Tulsa project were ''not made by me,'' and added, ''I had never had any discussions with Mr. Barrett about Mod Rehab - period.''
A lawyer for Ms. Dean, Joseph A. Artabane, said his client did not do any favors for Mr. Barrett, ''none whatsoever.''

HEADLINE: Like a Godzilla Working the Forests of Oregon;
Why the Job Loss

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It's always tricky to argue statistics, particularly when a source is not given and a point is being made.
Karen-Alicia Robertson asserts that ''four of every 10 dollars that Oregonians earn are made from the harvesting and cutting of trees'' without giving a source for her figures (''Oregon: Put Through the Mill,'' Op-Ed, Nov. 27). Ms. Robertson uses this statistic to imply that 40 percent of the jobs in Oregon will be lost if the remaining stands of old-growth trees in the national forests are preserved.
The truth, however, is that the real threat to timber jobs in Oregon is the timber industry itself, and the most telling statistics are these: in the last 10 years, employment in Oregon's timber industry has fallen by 20 percent while the amount of timber cut in the state's national forests has risen by 18 percent (i.e., according to the U.S. Forest Service, 18 percent more was cut in 1988 than in 1978, with fluctuations in cut levels, but a general rise in the years in between). 
There are two principal reasons for this, and neither of them is zealous environmentalists, as Ms. Robertson and the timber industry would have us believe. They are automation and the export of raw logs from private lands. According to a State of Oregon study, 3.5 billion board feet of raw logs were shipped from the Pacific Northwest to Japan in 1988 alone. That cost the region 37,000 jobs in wood processing.
The frustration and fear of Pacific Northwest logging communities are understandable, but their anger at environmental groups that have gone to court to block some timber sales is misplaced. Timber production is at an all-time high, higher than can possibly be sustained for long under any conceivable logging schedule.
The economy of the region will change no matter what anyone does now. Ms. Robertson scoffs at tourism as a replacement for lost logging jobs. Her numbers for Oregon's economy (42 percent wood products, 40 percent agriculture, 18 percent everything else) differ remarkably from the State of Oregon's own (6 percent wood products, 3.9 percent agriculture, 90 percent everything else).
No matter what economic figures you use, however, the fact remains that the ancient forests are almost gone, and whether they are saved or not won't make much difference for the future of logging jobs in Oregon. It will, however, make all the difference in the world for the northern spotted owl and numerous other creatures that require old-growth forests for their survival and for the trees themselves. We should save what we can now, while there's still time to do so.
 
FREDRIC P. SUTHERLAND
Pres., Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund
 San Francisco, Nov. 30, 1989

HEADLINE: We Must Help Besieged Salvador

BYLINE: By Vin Weber; Vin Weber, Republican of Minnesota, is secretary of the House Republican Conference.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For more than a month, Americans have watched El Salvador turn ugly. Staring at the blood and chaos, Americans are now asking, once again, whether U.S. policy there is working. It is. Ten years ago, El Salvador was ruled by a military junta. Today, it is a working democracy that has held four fair elections.
Ten years ago, political killings skyrocketed to nearly 800 a month. Before the recent outbreak of violence, political murders - though still too frequent - had dropped to under 20 a month. 
Ten years ago, El Salvador's criminal justice system was in tatters. Today, the rule of law, though still uneven, is taking root.
Some in and out of Congress have pointed to the recent violence as justification for limiting or cutting off U.S. aid. Instead, the attack on democracy in El Salvador today makes our assistance even more critical.
U.S. policy has been successful in El Salvador because it has been bipartisan. And the continuing aid formula, which Ronald Reagan and Democratic leaders agreed to in the early 1980's ($3 in economic aid for every dollar in military help), has made a difference.
U.S. aid gave us the leverage to help El Salvador hold its first free election in decades, in 1984. And it has given us the leverage since then to help democracy last.
The proof: 56 percent of El Salvador's registered voters cast their ballots in 1989 (higher participation than our last Presidential election), despite widespread death threats from the rebels. International observers declared the election valid and the presidency changed party hands, peacefully, for the first time in El Salvador's history.
In fact, it is El Salvador's democratic success, not its failure, that motivated the latest rebel offensive. Watching their own influence decline as each election bestowed new legitimacy on the Government, the guerrillas concluded that they faced political extinction. Their surprise attack, like the Tet offensive in the Vietnam War, was designed to win a political victory even if it failed militarily.
We must not let that happen. The rebels showed their true stripes when they took American civilians captive at the Sheraton Hotel. Their reign of terror against small town mayors and sitting judges rivals that of the Colombian drug cartels. If there remained any doubt, the crash of a plane carring Soviet-made surface-to-air missiles confirmed that the rebels are being supplied by Nicaragua. Such incidents, considered alongside their boycott of elections, make the rebels' call for peaceful negotiations dubious.
The leftist guerrillas will succeed only if we draw the wrong conclusion from the cold-blooded murder of six Jesuit priests. Those who argue that we should eliminate aid say that the killings overshadow the progress of the last 10 years.
In fact, just the opposite is true. Cutting off aid would undermine the rule of law, weaken the Government and siphon power to the extremes on the left and right. The result would mean more, not fewer, killings.
Instead, we need to renew our support for El Salvador's criminal justice system in order to track down, prosecute and punish those who commit such crimes. Though that system is fragile, U.S. aid is helping to improve it. For example, not one demonstrator has been killed in organized marches since 1986, thanks to improved training for El Salvador's police force, paid for with U.S. funds.
Reacting quickly to the latest killings, El Salvador's President, Alfredo Cristiani, immediately called in a U.S.-funded special investigative unit. So far, the unit's members have been slow to interview military units, a step the U.S. has insisted they take. We need to speed up that process. But if we eliminate U.S. aid, the unit will evaporate, along with our best chance of controlling extremists.
Less-than-perfect democracies often must contend with political violence; more than 100 were killed in the recent Indian elections. Although violence has not disappeared in El Salvador, our policy is working. We must not forget the lessons of the last 10 years and abandon this fledgling democracy when its life is most threatened.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Bank Takeover May Imperil Other Realty Lending

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The Government takeover of New Jersey's largest savings institution last Friday could cramp the state's already ailing real-estate market by making other lenders more cautious about backing large housing developments and office projects, experts said today.
For home buyers, the collapse of the City Federal Savings Bank also will temporarily dry up one of New Jersey's largest sources of residential mortgages. And businesses that have already applied for loans from City Federal will be delayed as their applications undergo review by Government regulators who have taken the bank. City Federal, which has $9.8 billion in assets and $7.3 billion in deposit accounts, collapsed primarily because it had many real-estate loans in New Jersey, Florida and Texas that went bad, the regulators said. 
The savings institution is the second-largest to be placed in Federal receivership, after Gibraltar Savings of Los Angeles. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that was named the bank's receiver, now controls 280 savings institutions, including four in New Jersey besides City Federal.
The takeover had been expected for at least a month. Still, when Federal regulators appeared at the bank's headquarters in Somerset at 2 P.M. Friday, the region's housing and commercial office construction industries were shaken. ''I think every major lending institution in the state is taking a very, very cautious look,'' said Thomas J. Stanton, chairman emeritus of the National Westminster Bank, N.J., in Jersey City and chairman of the New Jersey Committee of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit agency that studies and makes recommendations on public issues in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut. He said City Federal's problems would add to the hard times in the state's real-estate market since Wall Street firms began large layoffs after the stock market dropped dramatically in October 1987. There is a growing backlog of unsold condominiums and unleased office space.
Mr. Stanton said City Federal's insolvency would make other lenders even more reluctant to back new housing and office projects and could indicate that other savings institutions that lent money too freely will have troubles. ''Real estate goes in cycles, so I don't think this is going to be a big disaster,'' he said. ''But in the meantime, for some less strong institutions there are going to be real problems.''
City Federal, with 77 branch offices in New Jersey and an additional 28 in Florida, became a major investor in commercial and residential real-estate projects during the 1980's. But as the decade wore on, those investments proved to be riskier than anticipated.
By last Sept. 30, City Federal showed a third-quarter loss of $224 million, with $747 million in loans that were either past due or not paying interest.
One of the most visible of the bank's real-estate lending ventures is Port Liberte, a $750 million complex of 2,250 apartments and town houses on a system of man-made canals at the Hudson River's edge in Jersey City. About 360 of the units, and much of the canals, have already been built, but sales have been reported to be slow.
City Federal led a consortium of several financial institutions, eventually including National Westminster Bank, in financing Port Liberte. Mr. Stanton of National Westminster said some of Port Liberte's problems are shared by other projects around the state. During the economic boom years of the 1980's, cities and towns required developers of large projects to put in all the roads, sewers, water lines and other services at once, he said, even if the housing or office space was to be constructed in stages over many years.
''On a lot of those projects, as the economy slowed, developers stopped building, but they had to go ahead with all that infrastructure,'' he said.
 
Decline in Building Permits
According to the New Jersey Department of Labor, building permits for apartments and houses in New Jersey reached a peak of 57,074 in 1986 and have been dropping since. The most recent figures available show 40,268 permits were issued in 1988.
Mr. Stanton said lenders may now use different criteria for determining whether to back a project. ''When things were booming, you could look at where a project was located, the quality of the building that was going on,'' he said. ''Banks are now going to be looking at the strength of the builder rather than of the project.''
This could mean that small development companies and builders will find it far more difficult to obtain financing, while big companies with established records and the ability to withstand a prolonged economic slowdown will continue to attract funds.
''I don't think it's City Federal that is going to make them do that - I think they've started to do that already,'' said Peter S. Reinhart, senior vice president of K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, a leading builder. Mr. Reinhart, who is president of the New Jersey Shore Builders Association, said that City Federal had a small part of Hovnanian's overall line of credit but that he did not think the takeover ''will make a difference for us.''
 
Declared Insolvent
The takeover Friday meant that the bank was declared insolvent by the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision, which then appointed as receiver the Resolution Trust Corporation, an agency created in August to oversee institutions seized in the savings-and-loan rescue program.
Jack P. Shinn, an Illinois banker who until last December headed his own troubled savings bank, has been appointed chief executive of City Federal, now renamed City Savings Bank F.S.B. On Sunday afternoon, telephone operators at the bank's Somerset headquarters were already using the new name.
A team of 20 managers and 20 lawyers will assist Mr. Shinn as he reorganizes the bank.
Bank branches were open for at least part of the day on Saturday and Mr. Shinn said few depositors withdrew savings. He said that he did not expect a run on the bank on Monday but that preparations were being made just in case, with plenty of cash on hand.
''No one has to be concerned about insured savings,'' Mr. Shinn said. ''The new City Savings Bank even assumed all liabilities for uninsured accounts.''
 
No Loan Applications
Under Federal regulations, deposits in savings institutions of up to $100,000 each are insured. Amounts above that are not covered, but in this case, he said, such savings would be protected.
He said the only change that consumers would notice when business resumes Monday is that mortgage and personal loan applications are no longer being accepted. He said the bank would have to make sure it has enough assets to cover additional loans, but it could be a week before new applications are again accepted.
In the meantime, mortgages that have already been issued will continue to be serviced and consumer loans that are already approved and being processed will not be affected. But loans to businesses have been put on hold, pending a review, even if they have already been approved, Mr. Shinn said.
''If it's a good solid loan that produces a good asset, we'll go forward with it,'' he said, ''But that's something that will take more time to determine.''

HEADLINE: Spur Economy, 2 Civic Groups Urge Dinkins

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Two prominent business and civic groups, in a message to Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, urged the new administration to stimulate the city's flagging economy.
In a report delivered to Mr. Dinkins over the weekend, the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry said the city should adopt as goals for each of the next four years the creation of 15,000 private-sector jobs and one million square feet of new office construction - about the equivalent of a skyscraper - outside of central Manhattan.
To help reach what it acknowledged were difficult goals, the groups said regulations on development, especially those involving environmental reviews, should be revamped and tax incentives, including those for projects in parts of Manhattan, should be continued.
 
'Passive Approach' Opposed
Although mindful that the city will need new revenues to address drug abuse, AIDS, homelessness and other problems, the groups warned that increasing certain taxes would be self-defeating. They cited taxes on telecommunications, one of New York's strengths, and on energy, an already expensive commodity important to the financial services industry. 
''The city must avoid a passive approach which sees economic growth as the result of things beyond its control - interest rates, Federal trade policy, market swings or other factors which the city can only watch from the sidelines,'' the report said.
In an interview, Ronald K. Shelp, president of the partnership and the chamber, said the groups had sent the report to Mr. Dinkins because they ''believe the incoming administration has to realize that you can't solve the city's social problems without continued economic growth.''
Barbara J. Turk, a senior adviser to Mr. Dinkins, said, ''We agree that we need to encourage economic growth.'' She said some of the report's recommendations, including a more equitable state school-aid formula and more help for minority-owned businesses, were positions that Mr. Dinkins took during the campaign.
But one point of disagreement between him and the two groups is commercial rent control, which the Mayor-elect supports in some form. The report said such control would ''not only tend to discriminate against future tenants of business property, but also significantly reduce the confidence of the investment community in the long-term value of New York City as a site for such investment.''
Stanley E. Grayson, the outgoing Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said several of the ideas in the report, like a formal effort to recruit businesses from other cities to New York, had already begun.
Mr. Grayson said a goal of 15,000 new jobs a year was ''a good thing to focus on.'' But, he added, ''the question is how to get there.''
 
Dialogue Opened by Koch
In issuing the 12-page document, the chamber, which represents the city's business community, and the partnership, an affiliated organization of business and civic leaders, have joined in a dialogue with the emerging city administration that began when Mayor Edward I. Koch gave a speech to the City Club last month. Mr. Koch warned against several programs and policies supported by Mr. Dinkins.
Two weeks ago Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, suggested that spending in next year's city budget be limited to the level of this year's revenues, a drastic no-growth approach. He also suggested that the new administration consider deferring raises for city workers or negotiating modest increases that would be accompanied by cuts in the municipal work force through attrition.
As the city's economy, which expanded rapidly for much of the decade, cooled in recent years, its fiscal prospects have dimmed. With little or no job growth and corporate profits lagging, the city faced tax revenue shortfalls that in October prompted Mr. Koch to begin $200 million in spending cuts and to take other actions to balance this year's budget and reduce the deficit projected for next year.
But next year's budget, a preliminary version of which is due in February, a month after Mr. Dinkins is to be sworn in, is complicated by contract talks with city workers, lawsuits blocking the sale of the New York Coliseum site and growing fiscal problems in Albany, which could jeopardize aid on which the city is counting.
 
'New Cadre' of Managers Sought
Still, the chamber and the partnership said the new administration had an opportunity to recruit a ''new cadre'' of middle and senior managers with ''fresh ideas and new approaches.'' The groups offered to serve as a referral source for applicants from private enterprise.
At the other end of the work force, the report suggested that the Board of Education issue a ''Certificate of Employability,'' along with a diploma, to high school students who successfully complete a semester of work in addition to school. Such a certificate would reassure potential employers, the report said.

HEADLINE: From Prague to Fifth Ave., a Transplanted Salon for Czechoslovaks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM G. BLAIR

 BODY:
As their embassy mansion was in Prague, the spacious Fifth Avenue apartment of William and Wendy Luers has become a sort of salon, information clearing house and meeting place for people fascinated by what is happening in Czechoslovakia.
''You get hooked on this or that particular country and you can't get out of it and we are hooked on Czechoslovakia,'' said the 60-year-old Mr. Luers, whose final post as a career diplomat and specialist in Soviet and East European affairs was a three-year stint as Ambassador to Czechoslovakia. Since 1986, he has been president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
During their years in Czechoslovakia, the Luerses became acquainted with many of the dissident intellectuals who have emerged as leaders of the Civic Forum opposition to the Communist Party, including Vaclav Havel, the playwright. 
 
Matching People With People
Of the American Embassy, Mrs. Luers, who is 49, said: ''We ran a hotel in Prague. We invited American writers to meet Czechoslovak writers and American painters to meet Czechoslovak painters, and so on.'' Now, they are doing the same thing from New York.
Since returning to this country, the Luerses estimate, they have helped organize visits to Czechoslovkia for 500 Americans from the cultural and business worlds.
In recent weeks, as the political pendulum in Eastern Europe began to swing dramatically from Communism to democracy, ''we've had four calls from American businessmen who are interested in investing in Czechoslovakia and need to know who to talk to there,'' Mrs. Luers said. Among other callers are journalists seeking to develop sources from the Luerses' wide contacts.
''Our friends in Prague know that if we send them somebody, they are to be trusted and they should see them,'' she said.
 
A Cultural Visit
One of the Czechoslovak dissidents, Zdenek Urbanek, a leading translator of Shakespeare and a close friend of Mr. Havel, has been staying with the Luerses since October, the start of a three-month cultural visit to the United States. It is his first visit in 25 years.
Last Thursday night, in their apartment across from the museum, the Luerses gave a reception for Mr. Urbanek that was attended by about 40 influential Americans and Czechoslovak emigres in the fields of art, education, architecture, business and the news media.
Before the reception, Mr. Urbanek, a 72-year-old widower who is fluent in English, told an early arrival that he had recently called Mr. Havel from New York and asked if he should cut short his visit and return to Czechoslovakia. ''He told me, 'No, stay there and represent us and explain to the Americans what's going on,' '' Mr. Urbanek said. And that is what he did, with a gentle warmth and sincerity that impressed his listeners and prompted questions from them on how best America could support his country.
''Money is a very useful thing,'' Mr. Urbanek began, to laughter, and then explained that the ''economy needs the first and very patient help from the West.'' He said that initially the ''most important instruction'' that Americans could offer would be in industrial management. Equally helpful, he said, would be advice on constitutional law and institutional development, ''even though the systems in Europe and America are very different.''
 
'Intellectual Dimension'
For Mr. Luers, his continuing absorption with Czechoslovakia and writing on his specialty provide ''the intellectual dimension'' to a new career that centers on ''raising money and running the business side of the museum.'' He believes that ''having a broader function'' is helpful to him as the museum's president.
Central to that broader function is the International Research & Exchanges Board in Princeton, N.J., known as Irex. For 20 years, it has been the main channel for scholarly exchanges between America and the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Since 1986, Mr. Luers has been one of 15 nonsalaried members of a board that includes former Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas and Vartan Gregorian, the president of Brown University and former president of the New York Public Library.
In the fall of 1988, Mr. Luers was chairman of the board's first United States-Czechoslovakia roundtable conference, held in Princeton, on political and economic affairs. He would have led the second conference, held this fall in Prague, but had to remain in New York to welcome President Bush to the museum during a visit.
 
A Weeklong Conference
Next year, the Luerses, Irex and New York University will be involved in a weeklong conference scheduled for March that is expected to bring about 60 Czechoslovak intellectuals, many of them Civic Forum adherents, to the university to discuss with Czechoslovak literature and culture over the last century with their American counterparts.
More immediately, the Luerses are planning to spend a week in Czechoslovakia between Christmas and New Year's. ''I want to get a close reading of what's happening,'' Mr. Luers said. ''Because of my knowledge of the people and the country, I can catch the subtleties that often escape in day-to-day journalism.''
The Luerses were last in Prague in August, when, Mrs. Luers said, they were hosts for a dinner at a restaurant called U Sedmi Angelu, or At the Seven Angels. ''Half the guests inside were from Civic Forum,'' Mrs. Luers said, ''and we were told that half the people outside were from the secret police.''
''We're going to do it again this time,'' she said, ''without the secret police.''

HEADLINE: Yale's Black Studies Said to Founder

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Yale University's black studies program, one of the oldest in the nation and long considered one of the best, is in disarray, professors in the program say.
As Yale is grappling with issues of racial representation on its faculty, the African and Afro-American studies program finds itself with holes in its roster and, the professors say, no clear sense of direction.
Its chairman, Edmund Gordon, announced his resignation in October, two weeks after a university committee criticized Yale's record on hiring and keeping minority professors and its commitment to affirmative action. Mr. Gordon cited frustration over delays in hiring faculty members.
Two other senior professors angrily cut their ties with the program this year, and its leaders have struggled to replace or cover for others who have been lured away by competing institutions. 
Gerald Jaynes, a professor of economics and African and Afro-American studies who will take over as chairman in January, said there had been a clear decline in the program's national standing.
 
'Far Ahead' 3 Years Ago
''Three years ago we were so far ahead of other institutions that we could have filled the first five slots in the rank,'' he said.
''One of the attractions for me to come here, as a straight economics professor, was the excitement of joining a large group of the most dynamic, creative scholars in Afro-American studies.''
But in the last few years, he said, that excitement has disappeared and the faculty is lacking a sense of purpose or direction.
Over the years, the number of students in the program has remained fairly constant. About 400 now take courses, and seven are majoring in the studies. The program has 11 professors, all of whom also teach in other disciplines. At one time the program had 15 professors.
Since its inception in 1968, the program has grown from a study of the black experience in the United States to embrace African and Caribbean cultures. It approaches all from a variety of disciplines.
General courses like ''Black Literature'' and ''Problems in Afro-American History'' have given way to ''Topics in Swahili Literature,'' ''Psychological Perspectives on African-American Experiences in the United States'' and language instruction in Hausa, Yoruba and Zulu.
 
Dissension Reported
This diversity breeds dissension, Mr. Jaynes said, as faculty members argue over what areas of study and the world should receive emphasis.
Even where the faculty is in agreement, the nature of the field poses problems, said Michael Cooke, an English professor who has taught in the program. Because black studies encompass so many different disciplines, the program must keep up with debates and trends in all, he said.
If disputes over emphasis and the demands of the field are unusually pressing today, they have been made far more difficult by the recent losses of faculty members in critical disciplines, including economics, history and political science.
Stanford, Wisconsin, Ohio State, Cornell and other universities have begun to draw off many of the best black studies professors, Mr. Gordon said.
Yale's losses are largely a function of its success, he said, observing: ''When people get here, they become targets. Other people go after them.''
 
Cornell Moves Ahead
Cornell University, which recently hired two Yale professors, is widely regarded as having surpassed Yale nationally in black studies.
Robert L. Harris Jr., director of Cornell's Africana Studies and Research Center, said it had built a strong base in the social sciences since its creation in 1969. ''We've balanced that off in the last three or four years by getting two great humanists from Yale,'' he said.
For John Blassingame and Adolph Reed, it was dissatisfaction with Yale, rather than the lure of another institution, that led them to resign from the program.
Mr. Blassingame, a history professor who was chairman of the program from 1980 to 1988, became embroiled last year in a long, bitter exchange with university officials after he said in a speech that ''affirmative action at Yale is but a fiction, equality only a name.''
 
Accusation and Denial
In his letter of resignation, which was published in the campus newspaper, Mr. Blassingame, who remains a member of the history department, accused administrators of trying to shackle the program.
The administrators vehemently denied that.
Mr. Reed, a professor of political science, also severed his ties with the program last spring.
Yale's need to fill these vacancies has brought to the surface a debate that has been going since the program's birth.
Because it is not its own academic department, the Afro-American studies program cannot unilaterally grant tenure to its professors. Instead they must also hold appointments in one of the traditional disciplines. Critics complain that this relegates Afro-American studies to second-class citizenship.
But Mr. Gordon said: ''I don't regard African-American studies as a discipline. I want professors of English, psychology, philosophy and history who favor a joint appointment.''
 
Debate Over Tenure
The danger of giving appointment power to the black studies program, he said, is twofold. For one thing, it might lead minority students considering careers in higher education to gravitate to black studies rather than to the older disciplines, thereby creating a kind of unintentional self-segregation.
''Alternatively there is the possibility that programs like this would be standing alone, commanding no respect from the disciplines, having no support from them,'' he said.
But Mr. Jaynes said Yale's system allowed qualified candidates for black studies to ''fall through the cracks'' between disciplines. He said he would support a decision to grant tenure appointment to the African and Afro-American studies program in special cases.
''This program is mature enough to make good decisions,'' he said.
Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the university's president, said he thought the program's disarray had been ''much exaggerated.''
He cited the hiring of one junior professor and the promotion of another in the past year as evidence that ''if you get past some of the noise and the static over the past year, the program is showing the sort of vitality that we want it to have.''
The possible addition of Edward Kamau Brathwaite, a professor of Afro-Caribbean culture at the University of the West Indies, next year would give Yale ''as strong a program as it's ever had,'' Mr. Schmidt said.
Mr. Jaynes said his aim would be to try to recapture some of the lost sense of mission and spirit in the program, to get the faculty thinking about what direction to take in the curriculum and to decide what appointments need to be made most quickly.
''The impact hasn't really hit yet,'' said Anita Wells, a senior who is majoring in the program. She said its problems would most affect younger students choosing a major.
''It's saddening,'' she added. ''But it's not completely in demise. It's going to take interested students and interested faculty to keep it going productively, but it's going to survive.''

HEADLINE: ON YOUR OWN;
The Inside Track for Winter Running

BYLINE: By MARC BLOOM

 BODY:
WHILE running in the bitter cold can be invigorating, your pace will be too slow to achieve gains in fitness. To get faster, you will have to run on an indoor track.
Track running can be beneficial year-round, but it is particularly vital when icy roads, high winds and heavy clothing prevent intensified training outdoors. The tedium of running laps forces you to train creatively, experimenting with speed work, as opposed to simply jogging through the season. 
There are at least a dozen indoor tracks in the metropolitan area from which to choose. They include those at the McBurney Y.M.C.A. (20 laps to the mile) and the West Side Y.M.C.A. (23.6 laps) in Manhattan, and the facilities at Columbia, Fordham, Princeton and Fairleigh Dickinson Universities. Pratt Institute in Brooklyn has an excellent eight-lap-to-the-mile track. Call first to check on availability and fees.
Try to train indoors at least once a week. It helps to have a partner. This way, you can take turns setting the pace, and you have someone to share the burden of the added stress.
Pack some warm clothing for your workout. Not all facilities are well heated, and some can get drafty. Also take an extra pair of running shoes. Some people do their warm-ups in training shoes, then change to a lighter model for the pace work.
Remember that speed work is a relative term. Essentially, it means running faster than your average training pace. Any running that causes you to push qualifies as a form of speed work.
There are four variables to work with: pace, distance, number of fast runs and rest between fast runs. Each element can be adjusted to modify or intensify a workout.
Give yourself at least an hour for your workout. Make sure you stretch first. Do more stretching than you would normally do. Speed work is unforgiving, and if your muscles are tight, you increase the risk of injury.
Then, jog a mile or two as a warm-up, leaving on your outer gear. Get the feel of the track, and stick to the outer lanes so you will not be in anyone's way. Also, the turns are not as sharp in the outside lanes, so these lanes are easier on your body.
After jogging, walk a couple of laps to relax and focus on your workout. Try to marshal all of your energy toward the task of running for speed, with economy. Take off your sweatsuit, change to lightweight shoes if you have them, stretch a bit more, and you will be all set.
Start off with four repetitions of a half-mile each. Run them at about a 10-kilometer racing pace. If, for example, you run 10 kilometers at 7 minutes per mile, then do your halves in 3:30. If you do not have race times to draw upon, run the halves at roughly a minute faster per mile than your typical training pace. A nine-minute miler would run the halves in 4:00 each.
After each half-mile, jog/walk for the same amount of time that it took you to do the run, with three minutes as a minimum rest interval. During each run, relax and develop a smooth rhythm; you should not have to fight your way through it.
Carry your arms close to your body, and move them up and back easily with fists unclenched. Your neck and shoulders should feel loose. Your legs should not shuffle, but glide with knees high.
Chances are, the first two half-miles will feel like a piece of cake. The third may be a bit hard. The last may bring on the feeling of rubbery legs. To finish keenly, aim for an even pace, not only from one half-mile to the next, but also within each half.
After the speed work, take a drink, walk a couple of laps, jog another mile or so, and repeat your stretching routine. Make your next day's workout an easy recovery run.
If you miss your time goals, do not be hard on yourself. The turns and tight confines of an indoor track result in slow times. And the smaller the track, the slower the times.
From week to week this winter, work with the variables to make progress. First, add to the number of fast runs, gradually advancing to eight repetitions. Then, run them faster. Finally, reduce your rest time. The runner starting with four 3:30 half-miles can have a goal of eight half-miles in 3:00 to 3:15 with a three-minute rest between each.
Mix in other distances as well. One week, run 440's; another week, 660's. Or, in the same workout, do a 440, a 660, an 880, a 660, a 440. This is known as a ladder or pyramid workout.
Eamonn Coghlan, world indoor mile record-holder, recommends the quarter-mile for speed work. He says the gentler pace of half-miles may not quicken leg action or turnover. To him, the ideal speed workout builds to six quarter-miles with a minimum rest interval of two minutes.
If speed work is not to your taste, you can still use an indoor track for your distance runs. Do not count laps; simply set your watch and run for a specified time. Midway, reverse direction to balance the stress.
And if you hear someone shout ''Track!'' from behind, move farther to the outside. Indoors, runners doing speed work get the right of way.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Chile Is Getting Independent Central Bank

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 10

 BODY:
In the first attempt in Latin America to free a central bank from Government control, Chile's central bank will begin functioning autonomously on Monday under a five-member board. The governing panel was named last week in a surprisingly harmonious agreement between the departing Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet and a coalition of the expected winner of this week's presidential elections.
In a ceremony on Saturday that marked the freeing of the bank from control of the Finance Ministry, Andres Bianchi, the new president of the central bank, said the accord was a sign that ''as never before, there is very wide consensus in the country on the importance of keeping the economy in equilibrium.''
He promised that the board would cooperate with the next Government ''to assure that public spending does not exceed the limits imposed by the productive capacity of the economy and the available money.'' The central bank will direct monetary and exchange-rate policies and regulate the financial system. 
Those responsible for the step hope that removing the bank from the political process will help maintain monetary stability. In the past, Chile has had high inflation, a problem that is now causing turmoil in several other Latin American countries.
Mr. Bianchi, a 53-year-old economist who studied at the University of Chile and at Yale, has been the assistant executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America, based in Santiago.
A man without political affiliation, he was the consensus choice of the Pinochet Government and of Patricio Aylwin, the Christian Democratic Party leader who is favored to win the presidency in Thursday's elections.
Mr. Aylwin leads a 17-party alliance that includes the Socialist, Radical and Humanist Parties. Polls give him a substantial lead over the two other presidential candidates, former Finance Minister Hernan Buchi and Francisco Javier Errazuriz, a leading businessman.
The appointment of two economists from the Aylwin camp to the new central bank board, along with two from the current Government, seems to indicate that the Pinochet Administration recognizes that Mr. Aylwin will be the next President.
Those from the Government are Brig. Gen. Enrique Seguel, who was president of the central bank for five years and has been Finance Minister for eight months, and Alfonso Serrano, an economist educated at the University of Minnesota, who has been the bank's vice president.
Also named were Roberto Zahler, an economist identified with the Christian Democratic Party, and Juan Eduardo Herrera, an economist affiliated with the Socialist-oriented Party for Democracy. Mr. Zahler, who did graduate work at the University of Chicago, has been working for the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America. Mr. Herrera, who completed advanced studies at Cambridge, has been in private business.
 
Criticism at First
Mr. Aylwin and his economic advisers initially criticized the central bank changes decreed by the military regime as an effort to hang onto as much power as possible and prevent the elected Government from having full control over economic policy.
But when the names of the directors were announced last week, there was universal approval from economists and others in the Aylwin alliance, as well as from businessmen and Government supporters.
Likewise, Interior Minister Carlos Caceres, who tenaciously negotiated between General Pinochet and the opposition, received universal praise. Mr. Caceres, a businessman who was named Interior Minister last year after General Pinochet lost a plebiscite intended to keep him in power, has been the primary liaison between the Government and the opposition in the transition toward democracy.
Alejandro Foxley, the Christian Democratic economist who is expected to be named Finance Minister by Mr. Aylwin, said Mr. Caceres, despite difficulties, ''persisted until he got the accord.''
Another man closely involved in the negotiations, who asked not to be identified, said the role of Mr. Caceres ''was incredible - without him it would not have been possible.''
 
Sending Clear Signals
Mr. Foxley said the Aylwin team's support for the new bank board was intended ''to give a clear signal to the country, especially the private sector, and to the international financial community, that when we say we are committed to working with private business and political groups that now support other candidates, those are not just words.''
He and other economists of the Aylwin alliance have sought to assure the country that once in office, they do not intend to retreat from the free-market economic program that has brought strong growth to Chile in recent years.
