HEADLINE: Lackluster Season for Retailers

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The 1989 Christmas shopping season is not exciting either retailers or consumers, as sales run even with or slightly ahead of last year, despite a wave of price-cutting.
''The shoppers are apathetic, they've cut back their discretionary spending and they're concerned about the future,'' said Walter F. Loeb, senior analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''I see a real gain in the season of only about 1 percent to 1 1/2 percent over last year.''
Some analysts noted that business in smaller cities is stronger than in urban centers, particularly since competition is less keen in the smaller markets. 
 
'Season Is Good So Far'
Herb Ross, president of Bonton/ Pomeroy, based in York, Pa., with stores in Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia, said: ''The season is good so far. We think our efforts to improve service in our 32 department stores, the extra sales help we put on and our increased attention to being in stock on basic goods have paid off.''
After a strong Thanksgiving weekend, retailers in New York and other big cities are trying a variety of techniques to head off a lackluster holiday season.
On Saturday morning, Macy's in New York held a three-hour sale from 8 to 11, with prices reduced 10 to 50 percent. Several days before, Bloomingdale's notified charge customers that they could buy any apparel for 25 percent off during a 10-day period. Abraham & Straus and Macy's have been holding one-day sales at prices of 40 percent off on some merchandise, and Lord & Taylor has been promoting price cuts of 20 to 50 percent. 50% of Annual Profits The holiday season is always an intense time in retailing, since it accounts for 25 percent of annual sales and 50 percent of profits. This year the anxiety has been heightened by the number of stores that are up for sale or in high-debt situations and have cut prices to generate cash flow.
Widespread price-slashing had been anticipated this year because of the number of store chains put up for sale, closing or under financial pressure. This wave of promotions developed early, even in the first weeks of November.
Walter Levy, a New York retail marketing consultant, commented: ''One of the season's phenomenons is that the stores for sale really must produce revenues to get good bids. So the Campeau, L. J. Hooker and B.A.T. Industries stores being sold are promoting considerably, and the competition must react.''
Bloomingdale's, for example, which the Campeau Corporation put up for sale in September, has been promoting ''very slightly more'' than last year, a spokesman said, in an attempt to revive slower departments.
Other companies put on the block are Saks Fifth Avenue, in New York; Marshall Field, in Chicago, and the J. B. Ivey Company, in Charlotte, N.C., all owned by B.A.T. Also for sale are Bonwit Teller, in New York, and Sakowitz, in Houston, owned by Hooker. B. Altman, also owned by Hooker, is closing its six stores, including its Manhattan flagship, with a two-month final sale, and the Miller & Rhoads department stores in Richmond, owned by Allied Stores, are going through a similar process. The inventory of the former Alcott & Andrews stores is being cleared out in a New Jersey warehouse.
 
'Very Slightly Ahead'
At Bloomingdale's, a spokesman said: ''We are very slightly ahead for the season compared to 1988. Business is proceeding according to our plan, which is that there would be minimal, almost flat gains in the first three weeks starting after Thanksgiving Day, a double-digit gain in the fourth week and a big single-digit gain the fifth week.''
Abraham & Straus, also owned by Campeau, was an exception among leading retailers in reporting excellent business. ''We are running above plan, with a 10 to 11 percent sales increase in our same stores,'' a spokesman said. ''That does not include our new store in Manhattan, which is doing very well.'' He said A.&S. had not increased its promotional efforts over last year. People in the trade noted that A.&S. had been successful in turning itself around in recent years.
''It's been good but not great, and we've had to promote reduced prices more than we expected,'' said Andrew E. Newman, chairman of Edison Brothers Stores Inc., a large St. Louis retailer that operates the Chandlers and Baker shoe chains and the Jeans West and J. Riggings apparel stores. He declined to give any figures.
 
'Not Exciting' at Stern's
Lawrence Stone, chairman and chief executive of the Stern's department stores in New Jersey and New York, said: ''The season so far is not bad, but it's not exciting, either. So far, in our stores more than one year old, we are running about even with 1988. Customer behavior is more price-driven than ever, and all the retailers are having price promotions.'' The Stern's stores are also owned by Campeau.
The Woolworth Corporation, one of the largest American retailers, had a strong November, and business since has been ''reasonably good,'' said Harold E. Sells, its chairman and chief executive. ''We expect the season to show at least a middle single-digit gain in our stores at least a year old, and it may be better than that.''
The season so far is ''not too strong but not weak, either,'' he said.
The low price inflation in general merchandise this year is expected to help retailers eke out a better Christmas, said Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the National Retail Merchants Association in New York.
She said she expected the season to end with a year-to-year increase of 5.5 percent. With an inflation rate of less than 2 percent, that would produce a real rise of more than 3 percent. In 1988, the Christmas season ended with an 8.3 percent gain. With inflation of 3.1 percent, the real gain was thus 5.2 percent.
 
Inventories Are High
''Inventories are currently high at a good many stores, but these should be pared considerably with the many price-cut sales under way,'' she said.
Many retailers hope that the sales tempo will improve as the season advances and that the 31 shopping days in the season, compared with 30 last year, will produce extra business.
Last year, the holiday season got off to a slow start but business soared in the final week, giving many retailers a better season than they had expected.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
East Europe Tries a Mild Capitalism

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The mild capitalism emerging in Eastern Europe, though unthinkable in these Communist nations just a few years ago, is a far cry from the free-market economics practiced in the West - and will probably remain so for a long time.
Recently, millions of East Europeans have come out four-square for free markets. Yet the popular uprisings in Eastern Europe have focused mainly on dethroning the authoritarian Communist parties that have ruled for more than 40 years. Economic change is another matter, not yet addressed in East Germany or Czechoslovakia, and still in an early stage in Poland and Hungary. Among the Balkan states, only Bulgaria is responding to the pressure for change.
But already the major economic challenges confronting the Governments of Eastern Europe are clear-cut, and so are the social conflicts these nations will face in trying to make the wrenching transition from old ways to new, in the view of more than 15 economists and East European experts. 
 
Lifelong Job Security
The key decision, the experts agree, will be whether or how far to dismantle the centralized Communist economic systems and move instead toward free-market capitalism, with its private ownership and its potential for creating a society of winners and losers. Indeed, ideological support for Communism may be fading quickly, but not for two of its attributes: lifelong job security and equal incomes across most of society.
''The biggest issue is egalitarian income distribution. Only Poland and Hungary have had experience with haves and have-nots,'' said David Kemme, chief economist at the Institute for East-West Studies in New York.
The Eastern Europeans are being pushed toward market economics by what Josef C. Brada, an Eastern Europe expert at Arizona State University, describes as the breakdown of a bargain.
''People put up with the state systems because they perceived a kind of social compact where the state would provide a stable standard of living in exchange for exercising so much authority,'' he said. ''But the Communist Party could not keep its part of the bargain.''
Eastern Europe's experience underlines the stark contrast between state-run economies and free-market systems.
In the former, the state owns factories, farms, homes and buildings, and determines their use, parceling out a nation's wealth in the form of wages, investment, education, pensions, a weapons industry, public works and the like. The state guarantees jobs for most workers and sets wages, taking little account of differences in individual proficiency, so there is not much incentive, beyond one's conscience, to work, innovate or take chances.
Still state-run systems, however flawed, were able to channel Eastern Europe's resources into steel-making, autos, petrochemicals, weapons and other major industries after World War II. Despite persistent shortages of consumer goods, the various national economies grew and living standards rose - until the 1980's.
Since then, growth has averaged about 1 percent a year, or less than one-third the rate for East Europe in the two previous decades, according to PlanEcon, a Washington-based research organization.
The reason is that while state-controlled systems might be good at initially pulling a nation up by its bootstraps, they have failed to adapt to shifts in supply and demand, new technologies and changing circumstances.
 
Run by Bureaucrats
An economy run by bureaucrats and state orders is ill-suited to fostering high-technology industries, like computers and semiconductors, which depend on innovation and risk taking. These traits have been nurtured mainly in Western-style free-market economies, with their privately owned companies, securities markets and big incomes for professionals and skilled workers.
As a nation's economy grows and matures, it becomes less manageable by a state bureaucracy. ''No Government, anywhere, has the manpower or the skill to ride a complex, modern economy all the way down to the corner grocery store, anticipating people's preferences and requirements,'' said Robert Heilbroner, the economic historian. ''The markets do this better.''
The downside to free markets, of course, can be unemployment - relatively few jobs in the United States and Western Europe are guaranteed - and huge differences in income, a phenomenon that only Hungary and Poland among Eastern European nations have begun to accept openly, after a decade of experimenting with private enterprise.
Here is where the Eastern European nations stand in the process of reforming their economies:
 
Poland
Kicking Socialism Cold Turkey
Poland, with 38 million of Eastern Europe's 140 million people, seems determined to go the furthest in the direction of free markets. Since midyear, the Polish Government has been dismantling its socialist economy almost cold turkey.
Many state-owned companies are up for sale, with the possible buyers including management, employees or foreign investors. Lack of a buyer could force a money-losing company to close.
The selloff program is being held back in Poland and other Eastern European countries by such previously unheard-of problems as determining a proper selling price for a money-losing state company and raising capital in a nation that lacks private banks or bond and stock markets in which potential buyers can raise money.
But Poland is already suffering the inevitable consequences of its ambitious drive toward private enterprise. Even the staunchest advocates of the effort, among them Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University economist, acknowledge the developing hardships.
Unemployment could reach 5 percent by early next year, up from almost nothing now, said Mr. Sachs, who is an adviser to the Solidarity Movement and an architect of the Polish strategy. ''Disparities in income are becoming evident and they will be greater in the future,'' he added. ''Many people will make a lot of money; many others won't at all, and that could cause a backlash.''
Layoffs are becoming legal as a cost-cutting measure, as the Government cuts subsidies to steel mills, shipyards and other money-losing manufacturers - although the private sector cannot absorb the newly unemployed. What is more, price controls are being eliminated, a process that helped to create an inflation rate of more than 50 percent a month lately.
 
Pain of Inflation
Inflation is hard on Government workers with their limited wages. These public employees, paid less than $100 a month on average, account for 70 percent of the 19 million Polish labor force. Those in the private sector - mostly in farming, construction and light manufacturing -have more buying power, from profits, wages and other income more generous than Government pay.
The great hope of the Solidarity movement, which controls the Government, is that foreign investment will pour in, soon, to greatly expand the private sector and provide work for the unemployed. And billions in foreign aid from the United States and Western Europe will touch off a boom, raising everyone's living standard and thus making income disparities less noticeable.
''The cushion of foreign financing is essential to produce results and to avoid unrest,'' Mr. Sachs said. As a precaution, he advocates a Government safety net of unemployment insurance, job retraining, health care and the like - a system similar to those in most Western European countries.
But Poles appear to be accepting the creation of a society of haves and have-nots. Solidarity, which originated as a union movement and evolved into a political organization, no longer calls strikes to protest that one group of workers earns less than another.
Bartlomiej Kaminski, a professor of government and expert on Poland at the University of Maryland, noted the change on a recent visit to his homeland. ''I had not been back since 1980,'' he said, ''and what struck me was the acceptance of the inevitability of inequality. Everyone's looking out for his own opportunity to make money.''
 
Hungary
An Established Private Sector
Traditionally a more entrepreneurial, freewheeling society than its Eastern European neighbors, Hungary, with 11 million people, began adopting some free-market policies roughly a decade ago. Today, the private sector accounts for about 25 percent of Hungary's economic activity, said Paul Marer, an Indiana University expert on Hungary.
But in Hungary, selling off state enterprises does not have the same priority as in Poland. ''Some people think that in a short period, you can privatize a socialist economy, but it can't be done quickly,'' said Janos Kornai, a Harvard University expert on Hungary.
Short of privatization, the Hungarian Government has tried to make its huge state sector simulate free-market conditions. Many managers are elected by employees, as if they were shareholders, rather than appointed by the central Government. Instead of taking orders from a ministry, as they did under the old system, managers bargain with Budapest over production targets, price levels, capital investment and materials purchases. And they get bonuses for increasing profits, as do chief executives in the West.
In addition, many enterprises are organized as cooperatives, with autonomy to market their own goods and keep some of the profit.
Though some companies are up for sale, financing is a huge obstacle to privatization. Throughout Eastern Europe, banks are state owned, and governments, not bankers, decide which enterprises get loans. In Hungary, most money goes to state enterprises or to pay down a $20 billion foreign debt.
 
Seeking Venture Parnters
To overcome the shortage of funds, Hungary has aggressively sought out Western companies as joint venture partners, becoming the Eastern European country of choice for these arrangements. Magyar Posta, the telephone company, for example, signed a joint venture agreement last week with U S West Inc., the regional telephone company based in Denver, to build a cellular telephone network in Budapest.
Some state-owned companies are being sold to foreigners, or to a company's Hungarian managers, in Western-style leveraged buyouts, if the managers can raise financing abroad.
The General Electric Company, for example, announced last month an agreement to pay $150 million for a majority stake in Tungsram, a big light bulb manufacturer and exporter. And the Hungarian managers of Apisz, a paper company, tried to buy the company for $12 million, with Citicorp financing. But the Apisz deal was suspended, for reasons that underscore a major difficulty in selling state enterprises in Eastern Europe. The suspension came last month amid charges that Apisz's managers were trying to enrich themselves by buying the company on the cheap.
Part of the problem was that in a nonmarket economy, without competing buyers and sellers, the market value of the buildings and lands could not be determined.
Such problems convince many economists that privatization in Eastern Europe should proceed slowly, with some enterprises not sold at all.
 
Natural Exceptions
In Mr. Kornai's view, these should include the natural monopolies -railroads, airlines, telephone companies and utilities, now mostly state owned in Western Europe. Such enterprises, supplying necessary service without competition, set arbitrary rates anyway.
The Hungarian Government has gone far in allowing its citizens to establish private companies, although the entrepreneurs are still restricted in such things as how much they can borrow and how many people they can hire (fewer than 500 a company).
Most private activity is in farming, small machine shops, restaurants, retail stores, barbers, tailors, home construction, computer software and medical services. Small stock and bond markets have taken root to help with financing, and Budapest now has suburbs of expensive homes, with swimming pools and tennis courts, for the new business class.
''A basic issue in the whole reform process in Eastern Europe is giving up the notion of equity for all,'' Mr. Kemme said. ''The Poles and the Hungarians have gone further in this than the others. They are trying to convince themselves that there is some merit - some benefit to society - in the notion of unequal distribution of income, or just inequality.''
But if Hungarians are accepting inequality, they are doing so in part because they have managed to blunt the issue, Mr. Marer says. State employees earn $300 a month, on average, an income well below earnings in the private sector. But the majority of the five million people in the labor force earn extra money by moonlighting for private companies or selling food grown on garden plots.
 
East Germany
Strict Adherence To State Planning
East Germany, with more than 16 million people, is the wealthiest East European nation. Its work force is disciplined and well-educated. It benefits from a special trading relationship with West Germany. And it is regarded by many Western analysts as proof that a state-run economy fails to generate sufficient wealth in today's complex industrial world unless it is leavened with private ownership.
Until the current upheaval, East Germany was tenacious in preserving central planning, with all its trappings of full employment, free medical care, low-cost housing, free education and price controls that make the staples of life affordable even on East Germany's low wages.
Although East Germany produces an array of goods, relying as little as possible on imports, most state enterprises operate at a loss, requiring huge state subsidies. These subsidies, in turn, produced a $70 billion budget deficit last year, officials acknowledged last month.
But such losses are almost inevitable, economists say. East Germany's factory managers have been paid primarily to meet production goals set by the state, and they often hoard raw materials to keep their factories operating, sometimes forcing other plants to curtail production for lack of supplies. The managers' salaries are not tied to product quality or cost control or replacing old machinery.
East German investment, in fact, was cut back sharply in the 1980's to preserve cash needed in part to service a $20 billion foreign debt. The small amount that was spent went mostly to microelectronics and robotics, potential export industries.
When it comes to exports, in fact, East Germany's state companies, with all their shortcomings, can be quite efficient, managing to sell sophisticated high-quality printing equipment in the United States, for example - testimony that state planning works when it channels resources into priority industries, said Sam Bowles, a University of Massachusetts economist.
 
Chronic Shortages
The Government provides jobs for virtually everyone in the labor force of nine million people. And it keeps prices low enough so that Germans, earning an average of $100 a month, can afford all the staples, though there are chronic shortages of consumer goods.
In one sense, the wage is more than enough. East Germans, like so many consumers in centrally planned economies, often prefer to save part of their wages, rather than buy the available shoddy merchandise. This savings ''overhang,'' a common phenomenon in Eastern Europe, would produce a burst of inflation in East Germany if price controls were eliminated and borders were open to sought-after foreign consumer products, economist say.
If East Germany opens the door to foreign investment, West German companies, in particular, would probably purchase profitable enterprises, like the printing equipment plants, business executives say. But what happens to the thousands of people left unemployed when the unprofitable ones - the outdated chemical plants and auto factories, for example - are forced to close?
The unemployed could migrate to jobs in Western Europe. But the principal hope, said Irwin Collier, an expert on East Germany at the University of Houston, ''is that foreign investment will pour in, creating new businesses and jobs. No one knows yet whether this will happen; no one has dealt with the unemployment issue at all. The economic discussions are just beginning.''
 
Czechoslovakia
A Serious Threat Of Unemployment
The economic debate is also just beginning in Czechoslovakia, a nation of nearly 16 million people, where the Communist Party has just been dethroned, raising the prospect of some movement toward private enterprise, now almost nonexistent.
As in other Eastern European nations, public attitudes about reform are deeply ambivalent. A recent poll found 47 percent of Czechoslovaks want their economy to remain state-controlled while 43 percent want a mixture of state control and private enterprise. Only 3 percent favored capitalism.
Inflation is less of a problem in Czechoslovakia than elsewhere in the East bloc countries because, despite some shortages, the Czechoslovaks have managed to spend much of their income - the eight million workers earn an average of nearly $300 a month - on what is available in the stores.
''If prices were allowed to float, you would get maybe a 15 percent price increase the first year and then equilibrium,'' said Mr. Brada of Arizona State.
But the unemployment potential is great. Most of the labor force works in industry, principally at mammoth, behind-the-times factories that make steel, machinery, textiles, chemicals, shoes and vehicles.
 
Falling Behind Slowly
Central planning helps to explain why Czechoslovakia's heavy industry, which account for 60 percent of the gross national product, fell slowly behind the technology curve.
''Basically the managers of these companies are production oriented; they are rewarded for the number of items coming out the factory door,'' Mr. Brada said. ''Not much attention is paid to updating existing machinery or seeking new technologies. No one loses a job or a salary for this shortcoming.''
Yet in spite of the system, innovation has occasionally flowered in Czechoslovakia, as illustrated by the development of the jet textile loom, a world-class product. ''It was largely, if you will, an accident,'' Mr. Brada said. ''A small, self-motivated group somehow got interested and designed the loom. They managed to have their new machine produced in Brno, at a machine-gun and rifle factory. Weapons require exacting quality controls, and so did the loom.''
It has not been updated recently, however. The original design group is no longer active, Mr. Brada said.
Most of Czechoslovakia's products have been sold to the Soviet Union and other East European countries. But as these buyers withdraw and Eastern Europe turns to the West for goods and new technology, the new Government will be forced to make changes, seeking foreign investment and perhaps shuttering some factories.
''Whatever happens, the employment guarantee will end,'' Mr. Brada said.
 
Bulgaria
A Lot of Smoke, Not Much Fire
Among the Balkan countries, Yugoslavia is absorbed in preventing ethnic rivalries from splitting the country, and Albania remains an isolated bastion of Marxism-Leninism. Only Bulgaria has been embroiled in Eastern Europe's upheaval, installing a new leadership headed by Petar T. Mladenov. Though a Communist, he is regarded as more open to market reforms than Todor T. Zhikov, the man he replaced.
But Bulgaria is different from many of its neighbors - closer to Russia in culture than to Europe, still throwing off more income from agriculture than from industry, and willing over the last four years to experiment with diluting central planning.
Central planning brought heavy industry in the postwar period, converting Bulgaria from a rural country into a nation that supplied the computers used in the Soviet space program.
''Zhikov was fascinated with computers,'' said Michael L. Wyznan, a Bulgaria expert at Illinois State University. ''He channeled a lot of money into the industry and sent people to the West to study. Still, the computers are mostly West German and American models, assembled in Bulgaria. Only the Soviets would buy them.'' In theory, Bulgaria should be on its way to a free-market economy. A host of new laws, ordered up by the Zhikov regime, call for such capitalist devices as a commercial banking system, considerable autonomy for state companies and their partial sale to shareholders.
''But while the legal framework is there, central planning and state control is still the dominate feature,'' said Marvin R. Jackson, whose specialty at Arizona State University is Bulgaria and Rumania. ''Bulgarians say there is a lot of smoke but not much fire.''
 
Rumania
An Economy In Shambles
Through all the turmoil, Rumania has remained outwardly calm. Nicolae Ceausescu, among the world's most repressive Communist leader, even organized a demonstration last month in support of his regime.
But beyond the show, the economy is deteriorating rapidly and the nation's 23 million people live wretched lives, said Mr. Jackson, who said he received frequent reports from Rumanian contacts.
Food is rationed severely. The cities are without street lights. Fuel is provided to heat homes only part of the day. Hospitals lack medicine and other supplies, and public transportation in Bucharest is so dilapidated that getting to work is difficult.
Why haven't Rumanians reacted? No one is quite sure. The Ceausescu regime's police force is cited as one reason. And Mr. Ceausescu, in power since 1965, wins support by dispensing favors, mostly special access to consumer goods.
To Mr. Jackson and other experts, Rumania is an example of state planning run amok. Seeking self-sufficiency, the Ceausescu regime invested in steel plants, petroleum refineries and other heavy industries, borrowing abroad to do so.
And then Mr. Ceausescu, his nation near bankruptcy in the early 1980's, decided to pay the $10 billion debt entirely, and fast, rather than bargain for delays, as others in Eastern Europe did. Imports were halted and huge quantities of food were exported to raise the hard currency for debt repayment.
''The main problem with Rumania is that it tries to be too self-sufficient,'' Mr. Jackson said. ''This is the egomania of one man. Probably not since Stalin has economic policy been so centralized in one person.''

HEADLINE: Business and the Law;
Old Train Tracks Provoke a Dispute

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton

 BODY:
THOUSANDS of miles of land and hundreds of thousands of property owners and tourists may be affected by a case involving Patricia Preseault of Burlington, Vt., who says all she really wants is to grow trees and plants along a path on her property.
Since 1967, Mrs. Preseault and her husband, J. Paul, have lived on a patch of land near Lake Champlain with a majestic view of the Adirondack Mountains. When they moved in, the parcel also contained a 150-by-215-foot-long train path, part of an easement, or right of way, granted by the property owner in 1899.
Fourteen years ago, Vermont and the railway ripped up the tracks. Rather than returning the path to the Preseaults, the rail was turned into an asphalt trail, and whizzing bicylists and meandering pedestrians replaced the clamorous trains. Mrs. Preseault says she does not mind the traffic, but she and her husband want the property back, or at least some compensation if it is to be used by hikers and bikers. The action, Preseault v. Interstate Commerce Commission, is no small matter. 
Each year, about 3,000 miles of train tracks around the nation are abandoned, and how the Supreme Court decides the Preseault case could determine who benefits and who loses from the policy of converting unused rail paths into trails.
Thirteen states have joined with Vermont, the Bush Administration and a number of conservation and trail associations in arguing that there is nothing wrong with converting rails to trails. The Preseaults' supporters include several farm groups and the National Association of Realtors, which contend that since the original easement was for train tracks, the Government must compensate the Preseaults for the conversion. The case began nine years ago, when the Preseaults asked a Vermont court to decide who owns the strip of land. In 1985, the Vermont Supreme Court dismissed the action. It reasoned that only the Interstate Commerce Commission, which regulates railroads, had the authority to decide whether the rail line had been abandoned.
Two years earlier, Congress had amended the National Trails System Act to increase the number of trails at minimal cost to the Government. The amendments gave the I.C.C. the authority to transfer rail easements to a local government or private organizations that would assume liability and upkeep. Based on the new law, the commission in 1986 approved a rails-to-trails conversion agreement with Burlington.
Lawyers for the Preseaults argued last month that the Federal law amounts to a taking without just compensation, which is forbidden by the Fifth Amendment. They also maintained that the rails-to-trails policy exceeds the commerce clause of the Constitution, because the professed interstate interest of the Federal Government - banking abandoned rail paths for possible use in the future - is a sham.
''The fact is, and everyone will admit it off the record, railroad banking for the future is a fiction,'' said Michael Berger, a partner at the Los Angeles firm of Fadem, Berger & Norton, who represented the Preseaults before the Supreme Court.
Lawyers for the Federal Government contend that the conversion to trails is an economical way to preserve the paths in case train tracks are again installed.
A unanimous panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York agreed, dismissing the argument that the rail banking was a sham and calling the preservation of the rail corridors ''remarkably efficient.'' The appeals panel also rejected the notion that the easement granted in 1899 was for the specific purpose of running only a railroad track.
Rarely has the Supreme Court struck down a law because it violates the commerce clause, and experts expect that if the Preseaults prevail, it would likely be on principle of eminent domain - that they have a right to be compensated for the seizure of their property. That would be only a partial victory because it would mean that the couple and others would have to continue to pursue their cases in the United States Court of Claims.
For his part, Mr. Preseault, a former pilot at Eastern Airlines who was told by the airline that his job had been filled when the pilots' union voted recently to return to work, says the case is a simple matter of being left alone. He disagrees with the National Wildlife Federation, the National Audubon Society and Natural Resources Defense Council, which want to preserve the trails for the public.
''They can't resist meandering off the bicycle path onto our property,'' he said, referring to the cyclists and hikers. ''We don't like being ornery people by asking them to leave. We turn out looking like bad guys. They ask 'What's the harm?' The harm is we lose all our privacy.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Uncertainty Keeping Anxiety High

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
In sharp contrast to the languorous close of most years, anxiety levels among credit market participants are likely to remain high as 1989 nears an end, and the source of their uncertainty is the Federal Reserve.
Virtually certain just weeks ago that the Fed would ease credit policy at least once, and perhaps twice, before the 1990's begin, the central bank's statements and actions since late November have only served to confuse participants about its intentions. And Friday's report on employment conditions in November, which many hoped would help clarify the economic outlook, did not live up to those expectations.
The report, which showed a larger-than-expected increase in non-farm payroll employment and a stunningly large downward revision in the October figures, left analysts with essentially the same view of the economy that was in place before the numbers were released. 
 
Weakness Is Seen
''To me the employment numbers confirmed that the economy is weakening, but they gave no sign we are falling apart so rapidly that we are on our way to a recession,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Kleinwort Benson Government Securities.
''I think the Fed will respond by easing the overnight Federal funds rate to at least 8 1/4 percent,'' he added, ''but it is hard to tell when they will do it. From the market's perspective, the longer the Fed waits the more it hurts.''
Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm, said: ''By themselves, the employment numbers are not necessarily enough to prompt the Fed to move. But at least they insure the Fed will stay close to an easing move for the rest of the month. Almost any number that shows surprising weakness could be a trigger. That means we are likely to see considerable day-to-day uncertainty for the next couple of weeks.''
 
Policy Committee to Meet
At this juncture Mr. Kahan and others said that the most logical time for a further move by the Fed, which has pushed the funds rate down by 1.25 percentage points so far this year, to 8.50 percent, would be after members of its policy-making Open Market Committee meet in Washington next Monday and Tuesday.
''Christmas sales numbers are the key,'' said David A. Wyss, chief financial economist at Data Resources Inc., an economic forecasting firm. ''If the Fed sees reports from retailers showing that sales are weak, then they could ease after the Open Market Committee meeting.''
Apprehension about what the Fed will or will not do is a more or less constant condition among credit market participants. But the worry seems to have a sharper edge now because it is generally perceived that over the last month or so dealers have taken on big inventories of securities in expectation of another easing move.
A commonly used proxy for dealer positions, the overnight rate on repurchase agreements, appears to bear this out. Securities dealers use repurchase agreements as a way to finance inventories by temporarily offering their securities as collateral for borrowed money. The interest rate they pay on the borrowings is known as the repurchase rate.
 
Near Federal Funds Rate
Generally, overnight repurchase rates tend to trade at a slightly lower rate than the overnight Federal funds rate, often about 20 basis points, or hundredths of a point. But for the last few weeks the repurchase rate has traded at the same level or a slight premium to the Federal funds rate.
At the end of last week overnight repurchase agreements were offered at 8.48 percent. Meanwhile, the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market was 8 7/16 percent.
''The fact that the repo rate has been trading so closely with the funds rate has been cited as evidence that dealers are long securities in anticipation of a rally,'' Mr. Crandall said. ''But a lot of those securities are Treasury bills.''
To accommodate the rise in short-term bills, Mr. Crandall said, dealers have hedged themselves in the futures markets and elsewhere.
According to his calculations, the supply of outstanding short-term bills peaked last week at about $260 billion. Over the summer, by contrast, there was only $200 billion worth of outstanding bills.
 
Less Pressure Expected
''In the next two weeks $19 billion worth of cash management bills will be redeemed,'' he said. ''That should take away the pressure on the repurchase agreement rate.''
If analysts are right, economic data due out this week, including reports for November on retail sales and consumer prices, may also make dealers breathe a little easier.
Continued poor automobile sales will likely crimp any big upward move in the retail sales numbers, which are due out Wednesday. And after rising by four-tenths of a percentage point in October, the producer price index for November is apt to show a much more modest rise of perhaps one-tenth to two-tenths of a percentage point. Lower food and energy prices are being cited by analysts as the reason for the slip.

HEADLINE: Treasury Selling Bills Today and Thursday

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of issues this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Thursday the Treasury will also have an auction of one-year bills.
Late Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.59 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.33 percent. The one-year bill was at 7.20 percent. 
The Student Loan Marketing Association plans to announce today the interest rate for $500 million in short-term floating-rate notes, due June 14, 1990, which will be priced at a spread to the bond equivalent rate of the 91-day Treasury bill. Interest will be adjusted the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction.

HEADLINE: Honduran Leader Walks Out on Talks

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Tuesday, Dec. 12

 BODY:
A summit meeting among the five Central American Presidents was suspended late Monday night when President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras stormed out of the session after the dispute with President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua.
The Costa Rican Minister of Information, Jorge Urbina, told waiting diplomats and journalists that Mr. Azcona had abruptly returned to his San Jose hotel. After quarreling with Mr. Ortega over Nicaragua's refusal to drop a lawsuit it has filed against Honduras before the International Court of Justice regarding the presence of armed Nicaraguan rebels on Honduran soil.
Officials from the other four Central American countries expressed hope early today today that Mr. Azcona might be persuaded to return to the talks, although the five delegations were to return to their countries today. The sudden walkout appeared to highlight the most intractable point of disagreement in the regional peace process and it threatened to leave the five Presidents at an impasse in a moment that the sponsor of the peace process, President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, has described as the most tense and dangerous of the 28-month peace process. 
 
Subject of Friction
The court case, which has been used by Nicaragua to pressure Honduras to evict the contras from its territory, has been a subject of deep friction between the two countries, and an important element in recent peace negotiations. In August, Nicaragua agreed to drop the lawsuit in return for Honduran approval of an accord calling for the dismantling of the contra bases by Dec. 5, but the claim was reinstituted when the deadline passed with no progress on disbanding the contra army.
Diplomats who participated in the two-day summit meeting here said Nicaragua had attempted to use the court case to force Honduras to accept a new agreement demanding that American aid to the contra army be channeled through an international commission established by the regional Presidents. Avoiding Conflict With U.S. But Mr. Azcona was believed to have rejected that demand which would bring his country into direct conflict with the United States, which provides substantial economic and military support for the Honduran Government.
The second day of the talks Monday was overshadowed by sharp new concern over pre-election violence in Nicaragua, where a clash between Sandinista youths and Government opponents on Sunday left one person dead and at least 11 others wounded.
The Nicaraguan Government attributed the violence, which broke out at an opposition rally, to what it called terrorism by the leading anti-Government coalition, the National Opposition Union.
But a bipartisan group of American observers who witnessed the fighting said that it was deliberately provoked by Sandinista mobs, which have been used in the past by the Nicaraguan Government to intimidate and harass its opponents.
The American observers, sponsored by the Washington-based Center for Democracy, said the mobs used machetes, stones and other weapons to provoke an all-out fight with an opposition crowd estimated at 10,000 people. They asserted that continued violence would make it impossible to hold elections in Nicaragua in February.
''What we saw was an outrage,'' said one member of the group, Robert Beckel, who managed the Presidential campaign of Walter F. Mondale in 1984. ''There was no doubt among any of us at the scene that the violence was instigated by the Sandinistas.''
The attack on Sunday, in the town of Masatepe, south of Managua, followed more than six weeks of increasing election violence that opposition leaders and witnesses have blamed on Sandinista mobs. It has increased anticipation of a new report to be released this week by the United Nations officials assigned to observe Nicaragua's election process.
Officials familiar with the report say it will include detailed accounts of Government harassment of opposition marchers in recent demonstrations.

HEADLINE: Soviets Trying to Become Team Player in Mideast

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Asserting that it wants to be a force for moderation in the Middle East, the Soviet Union has moved away from a policy of confrontation with the United States and now indicates that it prefers partnership with Washington in the diplomacy of the region.
The casualties of the policy change, thus far, have been those Arab nations and factions - notably Syria and Libya - that once felt assured of unstinting Soviet protection as they embraced bellicose policies toward Israel.
But it is less clear who may become the beneficiaries of the new policy, as Arab nations seek to define their own roles in the new arrangements and Moscow confronts a serious obstacle to its quest for more influence: it does not have diplomatic relations with Israel. An improvement in relations with Israel is considered a prime goal of the new policy.
''If we are to play an even more active role in the Near East, of course we need to have representatives of our own in Tel Aviv,'' a commentator, Aleksandr Bovin, wrote recently in the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia. 
Yet, despite a quickening dialogue with Israel, Soviet officials say that diplomatic relations, severed since the Middle East war of 1967, cannot be restored until the Israeli Government displays some new and substantive flexibility in the effort to bring peace to the region.
''The Russians have to come up with some positive development'' affecting Israeli attitudes before restoring ties, said Tahsin Bashir, a respected Egyptian political analyst. ''If they play with Israel alone, they will have no standing'' in the Arab and Muslim world.
Over the last two years, from Cairo to Teheran, Moscow's shift away from confrontation has been keenly felt in a patchwork of initatives that seem designed to spread its influence in the region while propping up Soviet national interests in general.
''I think the Soviets wish to have stability and not to have any surprises in regional conflicts,'' said Judith Kipper of the Brookings Institution in Washington, in a telephone interview. ''After Europe, the Middle East is the flashpoint.''
 
Arms and Diplomacy: 2 Powers' Approaches
In its details Soviet policy, particularly toward the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, remains sharply divided from that of the United States. And like Washington, Moscow continues to supply arms to regional clients as a means of cementing influence. ''Arms transfers play a very large part in Soviet diplomacy,'' said Ian Anthony, a researcher at the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute.
But on a broader scale, the Arab world increasingly faces the differences between Moscow and Washington, differences that have enabled the Arabs to trade on the superpower rivalry.
In February, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, set the tone for Moscow's desired new relationship with the Middle East. He toured Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Iraq and Iran in what American officials depicted as an attempt to play catch-up with Washington's dominant position in most parts of the region - both as arms supplier and as diplomatic center-weight.
''The policy of pushing each other out of the region has to be abandoned in favor of constructive cooperation for the sake of peace and tranquillity in the Middle East,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said.
The Soviet Union, the news-feature agency Novosti said in September, has ''abandoned the naive stance'' whereby ''a country whose ties with the United States were strained was considered a friend of Moscow.''
The Soviets, said Mr. Bashir, the Egyptian analyst, are ''matching their deeds to their rhetoric.''
Egyptian enthusiasm did not extend to Libya, which has bought billions of dollars worth of Soviet weapons, including Sukhoi 24 attack bombers, but which now feels threatened by the prospect of being at odds with its onetime sponsor.
Libya's press denigrated the Malta summit talks between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ''The rules of the international game will not change,'' one newspaper there said. ''The only difference between Yalta and Malta is the difference between the letter 'Y' and the letter 'M.' ''
 
U.S. Striped-Pants Set Is Less Than Delighted
Moscow's intention, according to Western officials, is to carve out for itself a far more influential role in an area dominated by the United States, using the language of cooperation as a lever. The overtures do not seem particularly welcome among some American diplomats, jealous of their influence in many parts of the Mideast. Earlier this year, moreover, Mr. Bush said that the Soviet role should be limited.
Yet, officials, diplomats and other analysts, both from the region and beyond, say that recent Soviet policy has produced a patchwork of changed relationships in support of the bid for influence.
Many Israelis are pleased. ''Israel can only benefit from the changes in Eastern Europe and Soviet policy. We've gotten more diplomatic relations, economic opportunities and an increase in Soviet Jewish emigration,'' said Yossi Olmert, a specialist in Arab affairs who has just become head of the Government press office in Jerusalem. ''There's no problem here for us. There's no taboo any more - people want to talk to us.''
Moscow has moved to a closer relationship both through permitting Soviet Jews to emigrate in large numbers and by direct high-level contacts. Foreign Minister Shevardnadze met in Cairo with his Israeli counterpart, Moshe Arens, in February.
The new warmth has spurred criticism from radical Palestinians like Ahmed Jabril, leader of the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command. Mr. Jabril has bitterly criticized the Soviet decision to permit increased emigration as being supportive of Israel.
Egyptian and mainstream Palestinian officials see benefits from a closer Soviet involvement in the region, advantages comparable to that from American participation.
Fearful of losing Arab backing, however, the Soviets have set conditions for restoring diplomatic ties. ''As long as Israel refuses to move forward for a real settlement and convening an international conference, what would the meaning of relations be?'' a Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister, Yuri M. Vorontsov, asked last week.
 
Paying Lip Service To Idea of a Conference
Israel opposes the idea of an international peace conference, and Washington is at best lukewarm to it. But in its official declarations at least, Moscow has maintained support for the idea, a central plank of Arab policy, without seeking to block the current American effort to establish a direct Palestinian-Israeli dialogue.
In 1987, Moscow brokered a reconciliation of sorts between Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and hard-line opponents that re-established the P.L.O. leader's authority.
Mr. Gorbachev also urged Mr. Arafat to embrace the conciliatory policies agreed to a year ago at a meeting of the Palestine National Council, the P.L.O.'s parliament in exile, in Algiers. At that meeting, the P.L.O. said it recognized Israel's right to exist as a state in the region, renounced terrorism, and established an official dialogue with the United States.
Such moves contrast sharply with earlier Soviet support for radical positions and opposition to discussions with the United States.
''It is beyond doubt that the American-Soviet dialogue played a part in promoting the the official dialogue between the United States and the P.L.O.,'' Novosti said last month.
In Cairo, Mr. Bashir, the Egyptian analyst, said, ''We don't want the Soviets out of the Middle East. We want them to be in a cooperative mood.''
 
Syrians, With the Most To Lose, Learn to Adjust
But it is in Damascus that the shift in Soviet policy has been most keenly felt since Moscow let it be known that it no longer supported President Hafez al-Assad's drive for what he calls strategic parity with Israel.
Syria believes that Israel will not come to terms with the Arabs until the Arab world can match its military strength. For years, the Soviet Union withheld criticism of the idea, but this year it has begun to advocate a new military doctrine called ''reasonable defense sufficiency,'' according to Soviet and Western officials in Damascus.
This shift undermines Mr. Assad's strategy toward Israel, and Damascus has protested the fact that the Soviet Ambassador, Aleksandr I. Zotov, discussed the idea with Western reporters recently.
But the new policy is depicted by Soviet officials as reflecting a wider trend away from confrontation. ''Our military conception is now one of defense,'' the Soviet Ambassador in Cairo, Gennadi Zhuravlev, said.
Economic constraints have also persuaded the Soviets to remold their military policies toward clients which, like Syria, have run up big debts for which there is little prospect of repayment soon. Syria is estimated to owe Moscow $15 billion for arms purchases.
Soviet officials, however, say that there is no intention of abandoning Syria, their most prized Mideast ally, and the only one bordering Israel. Some Israeli assessments suggest that Moscow's arms supplies have been reduced, but, according to Mr. Anthony of the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, the change has mainly been in the kind of weapons that Syria has received.
''There has not been a decline in volume but a change in the nature of arms transfers to Syria,'' he said, citing as an example air-defense systems ordered after Israeli planes mauled the Syrian Air Force during the Lebanon war of 1982.
Diplomatically, Moscow has sought to use its relationship with Damascus to draw itself closer to the mainstream of Mideast diplomacy by arranging a reconciliation between President Assad and Mr. Arafat. That attempt, however, foundered in February on the deep animosities between the two men.
Possibly in response to the new Soviet attitude, and certainly in response to overtures from Washington, President Assad has opened more intensive contacts with the United States over the last year.
 
Potential Trouble Spots: Lebanon and the Gulf
Diplomats and specialists in Arab affairs see the closest convergence of American and Soviet attitudes occurring in Lebanon, where both superpowers have endorsed an Arab League peace formula that effectively legitimates the presence of Syrian soldiers and acknowledges Damascus's influence.
In the Persian Gulf, Moscow has traditionally taken the long view. But these days, the Soviet Union confronts a more direct geographic threat from the Islamic Government in Iran, which is seen as capable of sowing unrest among Muslims in the southern Soviet republics.
Its approach to Iran is thus far more closely geared to perceptions of national interest than to worries about cooperation with Washington.
For 10 years after the Islamic revolution of 1979, the Iranian leadership reviled the Soviet Union as much as it did the United States. But in February, Mr. Shevardnadze seemed to score a victory with a visit to Teheran that foreshadowed less hostile relations.
''Iran is on their border, and the Soviets have 70 milliom Muslims,'' said Miss Kipper of the Brookings Institution. The Soviet concern is that ''Iran won't exploit the situation on the other side of the border.'' Some see other processes at work. ''The Soviets are trying to keep a foot in both camps,'' Mr Anthony, in Stockholm, said of Moscow's policy toward the Arabs and Iranians confronting one another across the Persian Gulf. Since its withdrawal from Afghanistan, the Soviet Union has emerged from opprobrium in the Islamic world caused by its fight with Muslin guerrillas there. It has pursued a new relationship with Saudi Arabia and maintained close military ties with Iraq.
''The Iraqi Army is almost totally dependent on the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Anthony said, adding, ''From the Soviet perspective, they don't want either Iran or Iraq to emerge as a dominant regional power.''
 
Soviet Missile Worries At a Time of Change
Concern by both Moscow and Washington over the region's volatilty has grown with the proliferation of ballistic missiles, a concern emphasized last week when Iraq said it had sent a huge rocket into space.
American analysts have said that the Soviets are also worried by the presence of medium-range missiles close to their borders at a time when similar missiles are being dismantled in Europe.
Heino Kopietz, an analyst at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said that while sales of other weapons to Mideast countries by both the West and the Soviet Union would continue ''as a diplomatic tool, the interest in limiting missiles is shared by Moscow and Washington.''
''The fear in both capitals,'' he said, ''is that these missiles might be deployed or deployed more easily'' in the Mideast than elsewhere, and thus offer a more serious threat to stability.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush Versus Quayle?

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
When he surprised the world by choosing Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana as his running mate, George Bush said he wanted a Vice President just like he himself had been in the Reagan Administration - loyal, quiet and on the team.
When Senator Quayle surprised no one by accepting Mr. Bush's offer, he echoed the boss. That was just the kind of Vice President he wanted to be. Yes, sir. 
A year later, the relationship has not worked out quite that way. Or has it?
One can search the records of the Reagan Administration from beginning to end and find no example of Vice President George Bush ever speaking out so publicly and independently as Vice President Dan Quayle has been doing. Mr. Quayle, moreover, has been taking his own line on perhaps the most important subject of all - Soviet-American relations and how the President should conduct them.
Sounding just like the right-wing conservative he is, Mr. Quayle has warned strongly against ''getting caught up in the magnetic personality'' of Mikhail Gorbachev - just what many conservatives think Mr. Bush did at the Malta summit conference. The Vice President also castigated the Soviet Union for its totalitarian system, just after Mr. Bush at Malta went further than any President has in offering to do business with that system and to help it change and adapt.
In general, Mr. Quayle has taken a far more anti-Soviet, anti-Gorbachev position than anything said at Malta by the President, or than what seems to be the emerging Administration policy of working with Mr. Gorbachev for an improved Soviet economy, better Soviet-American relations and peaceful developments in Eastern Europe.
White House spin doctors first leaked the line that this apparent conflict between Mr. Bush and his Vice President was deliberate. Mr. Quayle was only doing what the President wanted - soothing the Republican right wing, which Mr. Bush seems to be in constant fear of losing. Thus, while he warmed up to Mr. Gorbachev at Malta, Mr. Quayle was reassuring the right wing that its views were still represented at high levels in the Bush Administration.
The Vice President himself has now ditched that approach. In fact, at a Manhattan news conference, he said there was ''nothing inconsistent'' with Administration policy in anything he had said since Malta. Mr. Bush wanted to see Mr. Gorbachev succeed, but also meant to conduct foreign policy in a ''cautious, prudent manner,'' he said. Presto! No difference.
If the White House spin-doctor leakage is correct, little harm has been done because the Soviets and other foreign nations are too sophisticated politically to believe that real U.S. policy is being expressed by the Vice President at home rather than by George Bush at Malta. The right wing, however, would have every reason to feel insulted and held in contempt - for its members also are too knowledgeable to think Mr. Quayle's line, rather than Mr. Bush's, reflects actual policy. Confirming Mr. Bush's worst fears, right-wingers might even resent such a condescending effort to gull them.
If Mr. Quayle, on the other hand, is to be believed that there's ''no good-cop-bad-cop strategy,'' then once again this Administration has suggested - as in Mr. Bush's multiple views on abortion - that words have no real meaning, voters have no ability to hear and understand them, and what's said yesterday can be undone by what's said today. If Americans are really being asked to accept that there's ''nothing inconsistent'' in Mr. Bush's and Mr. Quayle's words, we're all being treated with contempt.
Maybe that attitude is one reason Mr. Bush, violating all precedent and the common-sense rules of politics, has announced already that the inimitable Mr. Quayle will be his running mate again. Since no one can read the future, Mr. Bush's usual prudence and caution should have caused him to withhold that endorsement until nearer 1992.
But if you think words don't matter anyway, what's to lose? You can try to mollify the right wing by blessing Dan Quayle today, then give him the gate tomorrow, and gullible Americans will perceive ''nothing inconsistent'' in such cynicism.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Lower East Side Group Sues H.U.D. on Project

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A group of Lower East Side residents sued the Federal Housing and Urban Development Department yesterday, contending that financing for a housing project there for the elderly was illegally approved because of political pressure from Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
The plaintiffs are seeking to stop the project because it would be built at the corner of East Ninth Street and Avenue C, which they are using as a park. 
Mr. D'Amato, who is not a defendant in the lawsuit, denied that he had done anything improper. He said he supported the project because the city needed housing for the elderly.
The lawyer for the plaintiffs, Harry Kresky, said the lawsuit's claims were based on an Oct. 26 article in The New York Times in which David S. Burns, the H.U.D. economist in New York, said he had been improperly pressured to support the project.
The suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan seeks a court order to stop the H.U.D. financing and to halt the transfer of the city-owned land to the developer, Lower East Side Housing Coalition Development Inc., which is named as a defendant in the suit.

COMPANIES
 
The head of Columbia Savings and Loan is resigning as part of a sweeping effort to disentangle the institution's huge ''junk bond'' portfolio from its savings and loan business. Thomas Spiegel, the primary architect of Columbia's strategy, said he would devote his time to setting up and managing an operation that would own the junk bond portfolio. [Page D1.] President Bush said for the first time that the bailout of the savings industry might not be enough to cover the actual cost of the industry's problems. [D13.] 
 
Two competing biotechnology companies have valid patents to a valuable new drug produced with recombinant DNA technology and used to combat anemia in patients suffering from kidney failure, a Federal magistrate ruled. The decision left neither Amgen nor Genetics Institute able to claim a clear victory. [D1.]
 
BellSouth agreed to terminate its merger agreement with Lin, whose board recommended that Lin merge instead with McCaw Cellular. In return for ending its agreement with Lin, BellSouth will receive $66.5 million, and McCaw will contribute $26.5 million to a Los Angeles cellular phone company of which BellSouth owns 85 percent. [D1.] The British Government awarded licenses to build three wireless networks for telephone and information services to international consortiums that include Pacific Telesis, U S West and Cable and Wireless. [D5.]
 
Wyse Technology will be sold to a group from Taiwan for $10 a share in cash, the company announced. The deal is believed to be the first tender offer for a publicly traded American company by a company from Taiwan. [D5.]
 
The push by Pennsylvania banks to combine continued, as Pittsburgh's largest bank and its largest savings institution agreed to merge. [D2.]
 
Ciba-Geigy will sell two electronic systems subsidiaries, including Spectra-Physics, to focus on its core pharmaceuticals, chemicals and vision care businesses. [D5.]
 
A.T.& T. will cut about 8,500 positions in 1990, in addition to the 25,000 it eliminated this year. [D5.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Saudi Arabia's oil company is the largest in the world and three other national oil companies owned by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries now rank among the world's 10 largest, the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said. Their rankings reflect the expansion of the companies into refining and distribution in recent years. [D1.]
 
The I.M.F. signaled it would give its approval to Poland's efforts to convert to a market-oriented economy, unlocking billions of dollars of Western assistance for the beleaguered country. [A17.]
 
The U.S. seems certain to overtake West Germany as the world's biggest exporter this year, the head of GATT said. [D9.]

HEADLINE: The Rising Dominance of OPEC

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Reflecting its expansion into refining and distribution, Saudi Arabia's oil company has emerged as the largest oil company in the world, the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said in its issue that was published today.
Three other national oil companies owned by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, those of Venezuela, Iran and Kuwait, rank fourth, fifth and tenth, respectively, the industry newsletter said.
The Saudi Arabian Oil Company, also known as Saudi Aramco, has always been a major producer of oil, as have the oil companies of other OPEC nations. But in recent years they have moved to become integrated oil companies that refine and market what they produce. 
 
Rankings Reflect Success
As a result, OPEC nations now refine more than 14.3 percent of the world's oil, compared with 8 percent in 1979. That shift in strategy has been previously noted, but the rankings issued today by the newsletter, which is published in New York, demonstrate how successful they have been.
While this trend would seem to contain potential dangers for major oil-importing nations, the Saudis and many other Persian Gulf officials have noted that their presence in Western markets carries with it an obligation to help promote economic stability.
''It is a sign of the times,'' said Gary Ross, president of Petroleum Industry Research Associates, a consulting firm in New York. ''Inevitably the reserves of these OPEC countries are putting them in a position to be the major players in all aspects of oil markets. One might say it is the end of one era and the beginning of another.''
The most important conclusion of the newsletter's study is that the power and reach of what were once the largest oil companies, like the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, now No. 2, and the Exxon Corporation, now No. 3, are declining, primarily because their access to oil reserves is strictly limited.
 
Backed With Infinite Reserves
And the presence of OPEC national oil companies in world oil markets continues to grow and is backed with almost infinite reserves that are expected to last well over 100 years.
''I think what it tells us about the future of the world oil markets is that national oil companies from OPEC are going to be the dominant force of the 90's,'' said Thomas Wallin, a senior editor of the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly who participated in the study.
The industry newsletter said it had based its rankings on a detailed study of ''six basic operation indicators, including oil and gas reserves, production, product sales and refining capacity.'' It added that the rankings ''draw on data from about 100 firms worldwide, excluding Communist countries, for 1988.'' #128 Years of Production A chart shows that Saudi Aramco has at least 128 years of production from its enormous oil reserves, which are estimated at more than 250 billion barrels of oil. By contrast, Exxon, based on its current reserves of 7.4 billion barrels of oil, has only 11 years of production ahead of it.
Other OPEC giants with huge reserves include Kuwait, with 171 years of production ahead; Iran, with 110 years; Iraq, with 101 years; Libya, with 61 years, and Venezuela, with 80 years.
By contrast, Royal Dutch/Shell has reserves that will last 14 years, the Mobil Oil Corporation has 12 years of reserves ahead of it, the British Petroleum Company can go on pumping for 13 years, and the Chevron Corporation for 9 years.
Until a few years ago, reserves in the ground mattered little, and an oil company's weight was measured primarily by its financial reach and the distribution network of refineries and gasoline stations it had to get its oil, or oil it purchased, to clients.
 
Spread to Asia Predicted
Now, more OPEC countries have the money to expand their distribution networks and are acquiring refineries and gas stations from the largest established companies, in effect replacing them in many markets in Western Europe and the United States. Eventually that process will spread to Asia, OPEC officials say.
In recent years, the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation has bought a vast refining and distribution network in Belgium, the Netherlands, Britain, Sweden, Denmark, Belgium and Italy, with a total volume of about 300,000 barrels a day.
Saudi Arabia has bought a large refining and marketing network by entering into a joint venture with Texaco Inc. last year on the East Coast of the United States, with a total refining capcity of 600,000 barrels a day. Venezuela has bought into the Gulf Coast of the United States and agreed to joint ventures in West Germany and Sweden with local companies.
Libya has slowly purchased a distribution network in Italy and a refinery in West Germany, joining Kuwait in entering the West European market directly.
 
Bigger Refining Role
Even as the OPEC nations increase their share of refining and distribution, the presence of large oil companies like Exxon, Texaco and Mobil is shrinking. Kuwait, for instance, purchased much of its West European network from what was the Gulf Oil Corporation, which was acquired in 1984 by Chevron.
Oil experts said the exclusion of Communist countries, most importantly the Soviet Union, from the study was of little consequence since Moscow's production ability has been declining. The Soviet oil industry is in serious trouble because of inefficient management, poor drilling techniques and lack of investment.
PlanEcon, a Washington-based consulting firm that specializes in the economic affairs of Soviet and Communist countries, estimates that the Soviet Union's oil production will drop this year by 300,000 barrels, to 12.15 million barrels a day. More importantly, says a PlanEcon economist, Charles Movit, Soviet oil production ''will continue to decline through the early 1990's,'' to around 11.6 million barrels a day, before stabilizing.
 
'Only 14' Are American
Among the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly's main conclusions is that ''companies from 34 different countries make up the top 50, with the historically dominant United States oil industry accounting for only 14.''
The study says 30 of the 50 largest oil companies are entirely state-owned or largely state-owned and ''they are getting better at acquiring downstream refining and marketing assets in consuming countries,'' like refineries and gasoline stations.
The state-owned oil companies include Petroleos Mexicanos, Indonesia's Pertamina and Algeria's Sonatrach, but by far the largest belong to Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iran, Iraq, Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates and Libya. Those seven nations hold well over 70 percent of the world's reserves of oil and gas.

HEADLINE: BellSouth Terminates Pact With Lin

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The BellSouth Corporation agreed today to terminate its merger agreement with the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, whose board recommended last week that Lin merge instead with McCaw Cellular Communications Inc.
The merger, which values Lin at nearly $6.8 billion, would reinforce McCaw's position as the largest cellular telephone company in the country.
Lin had asked BellSouth to terminate their agreement, which it accepted on Sept. 11. Some Wall Street analysts had predicted that BellSouth would come back with a new offer. 
But William O. McCoy, president of BellSouth Enterprises, said today that the previous offer, a non-cash proposal made in September, was the best it could do.
 
A Matter of Realities
In return for ending its agreement with Lin, BellSouth will receive $66.5 million.
In addition, McCaw will contribute $26.5 million to Los Angeles RCC's Inc., of which BellSouth owns 85 percent and McCaw 15 percent. The California company owns an equity interest in the Los Angeles Cellular Telephone Company.
''Our merger would have created the premier cellular company in the world, but such decisions ultimately must reflect economic and strategic realities,'' Mr. McCoy said.
McCaw's chairman, Craig O. McCaw, said BellSouth's announcement ''clears the way for us to complete our acquisition.''
After BellSouth's announcement, its stock price rose $1, to close at $54.50, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock of Lin and McCaw fell in over-the-counter trading, Lin by $2, to $122.25, McCaw by 75 cents to $38.25.
 
Dividend Had Been Planned
Under the Lin-BellSouth deal, BellSouth would have received 50 percent of the stock of the combined company. Before the completion of the merger, Lin would have spun off its television stations to stockholders and paid each shareholder a special dividend of $20 a share.
The McCaw-Lin deal calls for McCaw to buy 21.9 million shares of Lin. It already owns 5.1 million Lin shares and would end up with just over 50 percent of Lin's 53.9 million common shares.
In its initial bid, on June 6, McCaw proposed a buyout of all Lin stock at $120 a share, or a total of nearly $6.5 billion.
Lin and McCaw tried to negotiate an agreement, but when their talks broke down, Lin agreed to the BellSouth deal.
Lin, based in New York, has cellular telephone businesses in New York, Los Angeles, Dallas, Philadelphia and Houston as well as interests in broadcasting and publishing. McCaw, based in Kirkland, Wash., is the nation's largest cellular phone company, with a concentration in numerous smaller markets.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Slip in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched lower in very sluggish trading yesterday, and market participants said that activity was likely to remain spotty for the rest of the month.
''There are some statistics due out this week that could generate some interest, but it will only last for an hour or two and won't produce a consistent flow of business,'' one Government bond trader said. ''Instead of looking forward to the next number, what people are really looking to is next year, when everybody's slate gets wiped clean.''
Among the reports to be released later this week are retail sales and producer price data for November. The retail sales numbers are expected tomorrow, with producer price numbers set to be made public on Friday. 
 
Jobless Report Inconclusive
Market participants are awaiting fresh information because the November employment report released last Friday failed to provide any compelling new insight about the health of the economy.
Many traders believe the Federal Reserve Board will not move to ease credit policy further until there are additional signs of weakness in the economy.
However, some analysts said the employment data did provide clues that were missed or overlooked.
''The economy is a lot weaker than the financial markets are willing to acknowledge,'' said Robert M. Giordano, a partner and director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
''The employment report says the economy is not growing this quarter. There is no dramatic downward pressure on the economy, but the weakness that has surfaced in certain areas of manufacturing is starting to spread. Right now, the Fed is a step behind the economy, and we think they will take one more step to ease policy before the end of the year.''
 
Funds Rate Eases to 8 3/8%
Yesterday the Fed chose not to conduct open market operations, and the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market softened a bit from the 8 7/16 percent level it has occupied for the last few sessions. By late in the day the funds rate, the rate most closely controlled by the Fed, was at 8 3/8 percent.
Participants in the secondary market for Treasury securities said that trading was exceptionally slow, even for a Monday, often the slowest day of the week.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds were offered at a price of 102 3/4, down 2/32, to yield 7.88 percent. Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, down 2/32, to yield 7.82 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 31/ 32, down 1/32, to yield 7.76 percent. 6-Month Bills at 7.41% Rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills moved higher at the weekly auction yesterday. Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.60 percent, up from the 7.55 percent average rate at last week's sale. Meanwhile, bids on six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.41 percent. A week ago, six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.30 percent.
New issue activity in the market for investment-grade corporate bonds was highlighted by an offering of $200 million worth of 10-year notes by Texaco Inc.
The 9 percent notes, which mature Dec. 15, 1999, were priced at par, or $100, to yield 1.18 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 7 7/8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The issue is noncallable for life.
Traders in the secondary market for corporate securities said that prices of most issues were essentially unchanged at the end of a very quiet trading session.
The tax-exempt bond market also began the week on a very quiet note. Municipal bond traders said prices were little changed on the day.
With roughly $2 billion in new issues expected to be priced later this week, activity should pick up, municipal bond traders said.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Foreigners As Owners

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Foreign ownership of United States factories, banks and other businesses has increased in recent years, but most fears about adverse economic consequences from foreign control are unwarranted, according to a study released today by a Washington research group.
The Institute for International Economics said that contrary to some arguments, the growth of foreign ownership had not translated into a loss of jobs for Americans and that foreign companies had paid their United States workers the same as domestic concerns. 
The institute argued against changing United States laws to block foreign investment, saying that even in the area of national security, foreign ownership was not of concern.
''Even with the recent growth in foreign ownership, foreign firms play a smaller role in the United States economy than in the Canadian and major European economies,'' wrote the report's authors, Paul Krugman, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Edwin M. Graham, a business professor at Duke University.
The study said foreign companies accounted for 7 percent of total United States employment in manufacturing in 1986 compared with 21 percent in France, 14 percent in Britain and 13 percent in West Germany. By contrast, foreign-owned companies employed only 1 percent of manufacturing workers in Japan.
