HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Down; Rate Speculation a Factor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday against major foreign currencies in light trading.
Dealers said firm interest rates in West Germany, political changes in East Germany and speculation of further interest rate increases were supporting the mark at the dollar's expense. The dollar closed in New York at 1.7610 West German marks, down from 1.7705.
Also depressing the American currency were reports that the Federal Reserve sold dollars for yen as part of an effort to improve the trade imbalance.
''It's probably just a message, and the market as usual overacted,'' said Robert Ryan, senior trader for the Bank of New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose by 0.38 Japanese yen, to 144.65 yen. It traded at 144.47 yen in London, and at 144.375 yen in New York, up from 144.30 on Friday.
The dollar was weaker against the British pound, with sterling buying $1.5895 in London, up from $1.5793 late Friday. The pound fetched $1.5937 in New York, up from $1.5825.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's quotes, were: 1.5915 Swiss francs, down from 1.5970; 6.0200 French francs, down from 6.0485; 1,301.00 Italian lire, down from 1,304.00, and 1.16375 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16225.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with those on Friday, were: 1.7660 West German marks, down from 1.7720; 1.5970 Swiss francs, down from 1.5985; 6.0370 French francs, down from 6.0565; 1.9950 Dutch guilders, down from 2.0000; 1,304.25 Italian lire, down from 1,306.50, and 1.1632 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1615.

HEADLINE: Devaluation In Argentina

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The Argentine Government announced a series of economic measures late Sunday night, including a devaluation of its currency, and banks and foreign exchange houses were closed today to give them time to digest the actions.
The Government devalued the austral to 1,000 to the United States dollar from the previous rate of 655 to 1, bringing the currency in line with its black market value. 
State-controlled gasoline prices were increased by about 60 percent, bringing the price of a gallon of regular gas to the equivalent of $1.44.
To help Argentines cope with the measures, the Government authorized December pay increases for public and private employees.
Unions, which had already been staging pay strikes, said the raises were not enough. Commuter train lines were halted today and court clerks pledged to renew their boycott that disrupted the judicial system nationwide last week.
The measures - particularly the pay increases and the devaluation -almost certainly will stoke inflation that has grown at triple-digit rates in 14 of the last 15 years.
The last economic adjustment, on July 9, devalued the austral by 54 percent, tripled public service rates and imposed wage and price guidelines. That helped bring monthly inflation down to 5.6 percent in October from 197 percent in July, but fueled labor unrest.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Rebound Is Predicted In Advertiser Spending

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
Advertiser spending in the United States in 1989 has not kept pace with the increase in the gross national product, although it should rebound in 1990, said Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson. Mr. Coen, speaking yesterday at the annual Paine Webber media conference in New York, attributed the decline this year primarily to the normal post-Olympic-year drop in advertising and to sluggish newspaper advertising sales.
In 1989, when the G.N.P. rose 7.2 percent, without adjustments for inflation, advertising expenditures rose just 5.8 percent. Last year, the Olympics contributed to a 7.9 percent rise in advertising.
Mr. Coen predicted that in 1990 ad spending would increase 6.2 percent. ''We do see signs, under the surface, that ad demand is picking up,'' he said, citing factors like a slowdown in mergers involving consumer-products companies. ''A gradual return to the production and marketing of consumer products and services is setting in,'' he said in his report.
Overseas advertising expenditures continued to grow much faster in 1989 than domestic spending, Mr. Coen said, rising 11 percent when measured in local currencies.

TITLE: ADVERTISING (TIMES COLUMN)

INDUSTRY: SIC7311 ADVERTISING AGENCIES (57%);

HEADLINE: William C. Woodward, Executive, 76

 BODY:
William Carl Woodward, a former executive with the Aluminum Company of America, died of respiratory arrest following surgery yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 76 years old and lived in Pittsburgh and Washington. 
Mr. Woodward was associated with Alcoa for more than 40 years. He retired in 1977 as vice president of research and development. In 1971 he was president of the National Alliance of Businessmen, a nonprofit organization created by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968 to find jobs for the hard-core unemployed.
Mr. Woodward, a native of Monessen, Pa., was a graduate of Allegheny College and Harvard Business School.
A widower, he is survived by a daughter, Cynthia Woodward of Manhattan, and a son, William Carl Jr., of Atlanta.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Baker, in Berlin, Outlines a Plan To Make NATO a Political Group

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POTSDAM, East Germany, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Seeking to give some American direction to the rapidly changing events in Europe, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today outlined proposals for transforming NATO from a primarily military organization to a political alliance.
Mr. Baker's proposal, made in a speech to the Berlin Press Club in West Berlin, was part of the most comprehensive and detailed set of ideas to emerge from the Bush Administration to deal with the upheavals that are reshaping the European political landscape.
Mr. Baker said he hoped that his ideas for recasting existing institutions like NATO, the European Economic Community and the Helsinki process could help channel the ''peaceful revolution'' under way in Europe into a stable, democratic new order.
Mr. Baker, in his speech, also proposed that the United States and the European Community work together to strengthen their ties. He urged support for changes in Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and East Germany and suggested that the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe be reshaped into a framework for ''openness'' between NATO and the armies of Eastern Europe. In addition, Mr. Baker repeated President Bush's views on German reunification. [Excerpts, page A18.] Directly after his speech, Mr. Baker slipped into a Mercedes limousine and traveled to East Germany to deliver another message in a previously unanounced round of talks with East Germany's Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, as well as with several East German opposition leaders. 
Those talks were held in Potsdam, not far from the hall where Truman, Churchill and Attlee gathered to meet with Stalin in 1945 to frame Germany's postwar occupation, and they were made at the first visit of an American Secretary of State to East Germany. Potsdam lies just 20 miles southeast of Berlin.
While American officials would not say so explicitly, they left a clear impression that Mr. Baker's primary purpose in seeing Mr. Modrow was to do what he could to shore up his Government in the hope that it might survive long enough to conduct free elections now scheduled for May. In other words, after refusing to visit East Germany for 45 years because it was considered to have an illegitimate, unrepresentative regime, an American Secretary of State finally made such a trip. Officials also said that Mr. Baker wanted personally to urge the opposition to keep its movement nonviolent and to approach the issue of German reunification with sober restraint.
The Bush Administration seriously fears that the East German Government might collapse and force a disorganized, de facto unification with West Germany before either Germany's neighbors or the Soviet Union are prepared to accept it. Although he discussed the idea of visiting East Germany with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in a telephone call last Thursday, Mr. Baker only decided to go this afternoon after being assured by the American Ambassador to East Germany, Richard C. Barkley, that his visit would not provoke further instability.
Speaking to reporters after his one-hour meeting with Mr. Modrow, who is considered a leader of the liberal wing of the East German Communist Party, Mr. Baker said: ''I felt it was important that we have an opportunity to let the Premier and the people of the German Democratic Republic know our support for the reforms that are taking place in this country. We also wanted to make it very clear that we support the process of reform in a peaceful manner, and we are very anxious to see the process move forward in a stable way.''
Officials who attended the meeting said that Mr. Baker told the East German leader that if his country were to follow in the footsteps of Poland and Hungary, it could expect to receive a sympathetic hearing from the non-Communist industrialized nations should it seek economic assistance.
 
Modrow Is Reserved
Mr. Modrow was quite reserved when the two men emerged in a drizzle from their meeting at Potsdam's Interhotel, saying only that East Germany ''tries in its relations with the United States to be a stable element.'' Tipping his hat to Moscow, Mr. Modrow added that East Germany was also ''a building block in the ''common European home,'' which was how President Mikhail S. Gorbachebv describes his vision of a united Europe.
As dramatic as Mr. Baker's visit to Potsdam was - he made the 40-minute drive escorted by a bevy of West German and then East German motorcycle policemen, and crossed into the East over the famous Glienicke Bridge, scene of many East-West spy swaps -it was his Berlin speech which will likely have the more lasting impact.
In his speech, Mr. Baker emphasized that NATO would have to transform itself from primarily a military organization to more of a political alliance. It can do this by concentrating more on ''arms control agreements, confidence-building measures and other political consultative arrangements.''
In particular, Mr. Baker called for NATO to establish an ''arms control verification staff'' that would assist member governments in monitoring compliance with the conventional arms control agreement now being negotiated in Vienna by NATO and the Warsaw Pact, as well as future agreements that are bound to follow. NATO, Mr. Baker said, should also explore if it can play more of a diplomatic role in solving regional disputes.
 
On European Community
On the European Community, Mr. Baker said that as the 12 members of the E.E.C. became more political and economically intertwined after they merge into a single unified market in 1992, their organization will become the core of the new Europe. As such, it will be the main anchor insuring that any unified Germany remains in the Western camp, and the main magnet drawing Eastern Europe toward the free world.
Given that fact, Mr. Baker proposed that the United States and the community ''work together to achieve, whether in treaty or some other form, a significantly strengthened set of institutional and consultative links.''
American officials are increasingly viewing the new situation in Europe as an ideal way for them to get more of a foothold into the European Community and to get more of a say in its economic deliberations.
Mr. Baker also declared that if Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and East Germany adopt changes similar to Poland's and Hungary's, the community and the non-Communist industrial nations should support them as well.
 
Helsinki Act Considered
The Secretary of State suggested that the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which produced the 1975 Helsinki Final Act, consecrating Europe's postwar boundaries and establishing a common baseline for human rights, be transformed into a new framework for promoting greater openness and transparency between NATO and the armies of the East and, more importantly, into a vehicle for promoting free, multiparty elections throughout Europe.
The conference is the only organization that brings all of East and West Europe under one umbrella, said Mr. Baker, and, as such, it would be an ideal framework for providing practical technical advice to the East Bloc countries on how to make ''the transition from stalled, planned, economies to free competitive markets.''
Mr. Baker repeated that any process of German reunification should be consistent with the four principles outlined by President Bush in his speech in Brussels last week - specifically that reunification should emerge from a free vote in both East and West Germany, that it should come about gradually, that it should not involve any redrawing of German borders and that whatever new state might emerge would have to remain committed to both NATO and the European Community.
 
A Comprehensive Framework
While some of the ideas Mr. Baker laid out were not new, and others were not fully fleshed out, they nevertheless provided the first reasonably comprehensive framework for how the Bush Administration actually intends to go about trying to develop what the President has called ''a Europe whole and free.'' Whether events in Eastern Europe will slow down, or remain stable enough to make implementation of this framework possible in the coming years, no one in the Secretary's delegation dared to predict.
Before Mr. Baker made his speech, he met in the morning with the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and the Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Mr. Genscher then escorted Mr. Baker for a visit to the Berlin Wall and Potsdamer Platz, once Berlin's equivalent of Times Square, which is where the East Germans first began to erect the barbed wire that eventually grew into a cement wall.

HEADLINE: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
In a rare statement by a member of the judiciary, a Federal judge in Manhattan called last night for the legalization of all drugs that are now illegal, including marijuana, heroin and crack.
In a speech at the Cosmopolitan Club in Manhattan, the judge, Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court, called the war on illicit drugs ''bankrupt.'' He said 11 1/2 years on the bench had convinced him of the futility of sentencing criminals convicted of violating drug laws and the frustration of ''seeing our justice system overwhelmed by a social phenomena.''
Judge Sweet, a former Federal prosecutor, became the first Federal judge to propose publicly that illegal drugs be made legal, according to the Drug Policy Foundation. The foundation, an international nonprofit research organization in Washington, is devoted to exploring alternatives to the current national drug policy. 
 
Public Support by Others
The 67-year-old judge also joined the ranks of a small but growing number of former and present government officials, commentators and academics who have argued that the present policy, of aggressively prosecuting drug sellers and users, be reconsidered.
Others who are making this argument include former Secretary of State George P. Shultz; the economist Milton Friedman, who has received the Nobel Prize; William F. Buckley, the conservative columnist, and Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore. Legalization has been promoted most vigorously by Ethan A. Nadelmann, who teaches at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University and who has been credited by public figures with opening their minds to the idea.
The White House and Congress have opposed the idea. The Bush Administration has said that legalization would be an ''unqualified national disaster'' and would create many more addicts. Earlier this week William J. Bennett, the National Drug Policy Director, accused proponents of legalization of advancing ''morally scandalous'' arguments.
When Congress addressed the issue last year, it passed an anti-drug law that declared that legalization would be an unconscionable surrender in a war in which ''there could be no substitute for total victory.''
 
Public Opinion Not Supportive
Public opinion appears to support that position. In a poll of 1,537 adults conducted in April by the National Opinion Research Center, respondents said by a ratio of 5 to 1 that marijuana should not be made legal.
Judge Sweet, appointed by President Jimmy Carter in 1978, was a Deputy Mayor of New York City under Mayor John V. Lindsay from 1966 to 1969. He helped supervise treatment programs for addicts.
He is considered by colleagues and lawyers who have appeared before him as bright, diligent and moderate, but not among the most influential of Federal trial judges. Nonetheless, his speech reflected the frustration of a number of Federal and state judges who, in recent interviews, said they have come to believe that too much reliance is being placed on the courts to solve the nation's drug problem.
Judge Sweet's speech at the Cosmopolitan Club was not a public event; only members of the club were permitted to attend, although the judge provided a text of his speech shortly before delivering it.
 
Comparison to Alcohol
The judge argued that illicit drugs should be treated like alcohol: they should be taxed and made illegal for minors. He added that if the drugs were legalized, drug use, like alcohol consumption, should take place outside of work.
While many of his arguments in favor of legalization have been made by others, the judge's remarks were nonetheless extraordinary, coming from one who regularly helps enforce the nation's drug laws and orders the incarceration of those convicted of narcotics possession and drug dealing.
The judge said that the enormous increase on the docket of criminal drug cases, which by law must generally be heard within 10 weeks of indictment, was forcing long delays in civil matters. The problem has become so severe, he said, that in September no juries were available in the Federal District Court in Manhattan to hear civil trials.
He proposed that the state set the prices of the legalized drugs and the amounts that could be sold, and set up or license outlets for their sale. People should be able to buy quantities ''at will,'' he said. But he added that no one without a doctor's prescription would be able to buy a lethal dosage at one time. The drugs would be made by pharmaceutical companies, he said, and any sales outside of the state-recognized system of distribution would be considered a crime, as it is with the consumption of alcohol in some states.
The speech did not address where the pharmaceutical companies would purchase the raw materials, like coca, which is now harvested mostly in the Andean nations in South America.
 
Present Efforts Found Wanting
Judge Sweet said that efforts to combat the spread of illegal drugs had failed to put a dent in trafficking or use. Instead, he said, these efforts had proved to be onerously expensive and had ''come close to causing foreign excursions, subversions and caused us to reconsider whether or not, as a nation, we wish to employ assassination as an expression of policy.''
''From Dionysus or Noah's vines on, mind altering by alcohol has been part of Western culture,'' Judge Sweet said. ''Not so marijuana, cocaine, heroin and crack. However, these substances, to a greater or lesser extent, and in varying degrees, do alter one's consciousness, one's view of the world. Even as alcohol dulls the suppressor and enhances one's view of oneself, cocaine gives a sense of exhilaration, heroin a glow, a warmth, and marijuana a sense of relaxation and ease. What then is wrong?''
The judge compared the current state of drug policy to the prohibition of alcohol earlier this century and said that the abolition of drug laws would eliminate the profit motive, the gangs and the drug dealers. He added that it would make it easier to identify and treat people with drug addiction problems, especially through the use of the almost $9 billion now going to criminal prosecutions and tax revenues generated from drug sales.
He said it would be illogical to legalize some mind-altering drugs while continuing to deny more potent or addictive substances, like crack.
 
Crack Would Be Legal, Too
''To draw distinctions on the degree of addiction may not be empirically possible, nor does it appeal to logic and symmetry. In my view, you don't outlaw 120 proof while permitting 80.''
He said research might soon yield an andidote to crack addiction, adding that the increasing numbers of crack cases flooding the family courts, where judges are being forced to supervise abandoned or crack-addicted children, ''demonstrates the failure of our present prohibition.''
''We should identify those at risk and reach out to provide alternative services and ultimately hope,'' he said. ''There is no present evidence that prohibition has, or will, break this vicious cycle of dependence and abandonment.''
The judge conceded that society must anticipate that legalization would lead to increased use of narcotics, as the repeal of prohibition initially led to greater consumption of alcohol.
''The gamble,'' he said, ''would have to be that addressing the underlying causes, providing safe narcotics and treating the users, would ultimately result in a healthier America. If it is otherwise, it will be because our citizens have lost the capacity to act affirmatively and to control their individual addictions.
''The present climate seems to me to be optimistic: there is an emphasis on health, diet and what one ingests,'' he said. ''If our society can learn to stop using butter, it should be able to cut down on cocaine. If it cannot, no prohibition can be effective.''

HEADLINE: Spending Can Be Cut in Half, Former Defense Officials Say

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Laying the foundation for a fundamental political debate, military experts from previous administrations told Congress today that the $300 billion annual Pentagon budget could be safely cut in half over the next decade because of the reduced threat from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
''By such a shift,'' said Robert S. McNamara, Defense Secretary in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, ''we should be able to enhance global stability, strengthen our own security and, at the same time, produce the resources to support a much-needed restructuring of the economy.''
Lawrence J. Korb, an assistant Defense Secretary in Ronald Reagan's first term, agreed with Mr. McNamara's assessment. ''Such a development can have a dramatic impact on our economic well-being and our competitive position in the world,'' he said. 
 
Many Debates Lie Ahead
Mr. McNamara and Mr. Korb testified before the Senate Budget Committee in the first of what is expected to be dozens of Congressional hearings by many different panels over the next year on how to cut the military budget and how to spend the money that is saved.
A debate over how to spend what is being called the ''peace dividend'' is likely to be joined when Congress reconvenes next month. Many lawmakers and lobbyists for social causes dream of a windfall that would allow additional spending for education, drug control, housing and other programs. But economists in and out of the Government caution that the amount of new money available in the first few years will be modest and will be needed to reduce the budget deficit.
The witnesses urged today that Pentagon spending not be cut with a cleaver but rather be reduced gradually and systematically. And Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the Budget Committee, warned, ''Those who are looking for an instant pot of gold at the end of the rainbow are going to be disappointed in the short term, for sure.''
 
Great Opportunity Seen
But today's hearing was pervaded by an atmosphere of great opportunity in the years ahead to make basic changes in the way the country spends its resources. Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the budget panel, spoke of ''this unique moment in world history'' and ''the dawn of the primacy of domestic economics.''
Mr. McNamara and Mr. Korb said they were not qualified to address how the billions of dollars saved at the Pentagon should be reallocated, but they had similar ideas on which Pentagon programs to pare. Both suggested average annual spending cuts of about 5 percent, or $15 billion, over the next decade.
Mr. McNamara, who is 73 years old and who writes and speaks widely on military and international affairs, suggested that arms control talks with the Soviet Union could lead eventually to a 50 percent cut in nuclear forces and conventional forces in Europe.
Meantime, he said, the Pentagon should reduce the number of aircraft carriers to 12 from 15 and scrap production of the B-2 bomber and railroad-based MX missile. He urged that work on the Star Wars missile defense system and Midgetman missiles be limited to research. He suggested that plans for the F-14 fighter plane and the Marine Corps' Osprey aircraft, which could take off like a helicopter and fly like a plane, be discontinued, and that the Pentagon be given blanket authority to close domestic and foreign military bases.
 
Buildup But No War
Mr. Korb, who is now director of the Center for Public Policy Education at the Brookings Institution, made similar suggestions. ''You've just had a wartime buildup without a war,'' he said, adding that ''the rush toward modernization of our strategic and conventional forces should be slowed down.''
Mr. Korb suggested that, by the turn of the century, active-duty Army and Air Force strength could be cut by half and active-duty Navy forces by about one-third.
While the hearing was taking place on Capitol Hill, President Bush was meeting with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to discuss the military budget for the next fiscal year.
An Administration official said last week that the President had decided to propose a military budget of $295 billion for fiscal year 1991, which begins next Oct. 1. That is the same as the budget in the current fiscal year, and it would reduce Pentagon purchasing power by 2 percent to 3 percent once inflation is taken into account.
 
Focus on Intelligence Data
At another Congressional hearing, Paul Wolfowitz, Under Secretary of Defense for policy planning, confirmed that a new intelligence assessment, in preparation for months, concludes that the United States would have an earlier warning of a Soviet invasion of Europe than had been previously believed. , .
Earlier warnings permit less extensive, and therefore less costly, contingency measures. Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said Congressional budget writers had been misled this year because the new intelligence estimate was withheld, perhaps inadvertently. Mr. Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, warned that the Pentagon faced a loss of credibility and deeper budget cuts if Congress felt it was not receiving accurate estimates of the Soviet threat.
Across the Capitol, Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the top Republican on the House Budget Committee, urged his colleagues not to overestimate the immediate effect of reduced military spending on the budget.
''Defense savings will help, but they will be small in the total scheme of fiscal affairs,'' he said.
Most authorities expect Congress to approve about $290 billion in military spending for fiscal year 1991. In the odd way budgets are calculated, that would mean a saving of $10 billion to $15 billion, because the figure is that much less than what would be needed to keep pace with inflation.
However, that is only one-quarter to one-third of the approximately $40 billion that must be cut from the budget deficit to meet the requirements of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law.

HEADLINE: More Pessimistic Dinkins Warns Of Fewer New Programs for City

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, adopting the fiscal pessimism that a faltering economy has forced upon him, warned New Yorkers yesterday not to expect major increases in city services next year and said, ''Government simply cannot afford to do all that needs to be done.''
Speaking to nearly 1,000 business and civic leaders at a breakfast sponsored by the Association for a Better New York, Mr. Dinkins outlined a much more modest vision than the expansive one he had offered in his campaign.
In his most emphatic statements so far on the need for financial restraint, he echoed similar calls sounded by the Koch administration and a number of business people in recent weeks.
 
'Like to Think That I'm a Realist'
At best, Mr. Dinkins said, the city can strive to do about the same with less. ''We have run smack into a wall at a time when the need to increase services to meet the problems of drug abuse and AIDS, infant mortality and a crumbling infrastructure has never been greater,'' said Mr. Dinkins, who made such causes a centerpiece of his campaign. 
After the speech, Mr. Dinkins was asked if he was a fiscal conservative. He smiled and said: ''It's really a question of the circumstances at the time that one is talking. I don't call myself a fiscal conservative. I would like to think that I'm a realist, however.''
But some city officials said Mr. Dinkins's assessment still seemed too optimistic. Mayor Edward I. Koch, responding to reporters' questions, said that if tax revenues continued to decline, the city could not keep its budget balanced without real spending cuts or tax increases.
''I'll be watching to see how he does this,'' Mr. Koch said at City Hall later in the day.
At the same time, Mr. Koch said of Mr. Dinkins's comment that government could not do everything: ''Doesn't it sound like me? I think so. I wonder if the same people will attack him that attacked me for that statement.''
After his speech, Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that his goals were more modest than those described in his campaign.
''If I had the resources,'' he said, ''then I'd want to see to it that we had drug treatment everywhere, that we had job training for everybody. I'd want to expand the assistance for persons with AIDS and on and on and on. We don't have the ability to do that.'' The speech at the Sheraton Centre in midtown Manhattan was generally a broad appeal to lower expectations.
''The opportunities exist,'' Mr. Dinkins said. ''It will take planning and cooperation. It will sometimes require that we sacrifice individual interests for the greater public good.''
Mr. Dinkins noted that the Koch administration has asked city agencies to identify possible savings of 1 percent in the current fiscal year and 4 percent in the year that begins July 1, and that certain agencies have been asked to reduce their capital budgets to hold down debt service. He said ''these tough targets will produce a list of options for us to consider.''
''The current administration is establishing helpful constraints within which we will set our own priorities as the budget process unfolds beyond January,'' he said, making his strongest statement on his intention to hold down spending, even at the expense of new programs he has supported.
 
Less Expansion Planned
Mr. Dinkins took pains to say that he envisioned eliminating planned increases in services, not layoffs or large reductions in existing services. ''Some of the things that a lot of us would like to get done are really expansions,'' he said. ''So the failure to expand in certain areas as opposed to cutting services is what I'm speaking of.''
Mr. Dinkins's acting chief of staff, Barbara J. Fife, said later that his comment about avoiding layoffs applied to the rest of the current fiscal year that ends on June 30. ''We haven't addressed the subsequent fiscal year yet,'' she said.
But Mr. Koch noted that the few discretionary increases in the current budget were for services like the police. ''With respect to enhancements that he would like to use to balance the budget, there aren't really very many,'' Mr. Koch said. ''I mean the enhancements are more cops, more funds for drugs. I doubt that he wants to eliminate those.''
Besides more police officers, Mr. Koch said increases in the work force involve correction officers and child-care workers, whose services are effectively required. ''So I don't see how he could save money by reducing or elimating those positions,'' he said.
The Koch administration has already begun to put in place $530 million in cuts, fee increases, a bond refinancing and other actions to close a budget gap in the current fiscal year, and state officials have predicted additional revenue shortfalls of up to $170 million in the city's $26 billion budget by June.
 
You Have to Say It First
One senior city official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the outgoing administration believed real service cuts would be necessary. ''If I were advising him, he's got nothing to lose by the toughest possible talk now,'' the official said. ''If you can't say it, you can't do it.''
In the speech, Mr. Dinkins said: ''We will have to make some very difficult choices as we defer some plans for now. I do expect, however, to make modest but meaningful progress toward meeting challenges such as those presented by drug abuse, AIDS and homelessness. My job over the next four years is to restore our capacity to fully meet the needs of all New Yorkers.
''The key to this effort is our ability to attract and retain businesses, and to maintain a qualified work force,'' he added. ''A strong private sector is the engine that enables us to do that which we must do to serve our citizens.''
While the fiscal problems of the city today are not of the same kind and not as severe as those of the mid 1970's, Mr. Dinkins said, ''to succeed, we must come together as we did 15 years ago with the same spirit of urgency and resolve'' in cooperation between the public and private sectors.
 
Won't Give 'Away the Store'
Mr. Dinkins said the city must work to reduce crime and improve the quality of life, continue to provide low-cost financing for businesses, build affordable housing and fight for its share of state education aid to help finance its programs.
''Some believe that compassion requires giving away the store,'' he said. ''But let me assure you, as the chief executive of New York City, I wll use city funds as investments, and I will apply certain principles to my investment decisions.''
He then outlined five broad goals, pledging to invest money already earmarked for economic development in programs that build businesses and jobs; emphasize preventive programs that save money in the long run; implement the recommendations of a management study conducted for the Koch administration by private business people; seek more state and Federal grants, and show that offering better services can also save money.
For example, Mr. Dinkins said, people with AIDS who no longer need acute care are better served in intermediate care settings, which cost less.

HEADLINE: Beijing View Of the Furor

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 12

 BODY:
President Bush is taking something of a chance in the surprise visit to Beijing over the weekend by a special emissary: that the Chinese leadership will quickly reduce the repression that has followed the crushing of democracy protests in June.
The President's decision to send his National Security Adviser, Brent Scowcroft, to Beijing effectively broke his Administration's ban on high-level exchanges with the Chinese, and it has been sharply criticized in Washington as a kowtow to an unrepentant and unappreciative Chinese leadership widely despised for its killings of unarmed demonstrators.
Yet rather than a kowtow, some Western and Asian diplomats here say, the American move is likely to be interpreted by the Chinese as a gesture made from consideration and strength, and which will put the leadership under some obligation to respond to American concerns.
The Chinese are well aware of their unpopularity and isolation in the world, which extends from the West through the rapidly shifting socialist states, whose headlong abandonment of rigorous party control has been criticized by the Chinese. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union is regarded as a dangerous madman by Chinese leaders, who see him as a larger threat to party hegemony in China than any Western influence, diplomats say. 
 
Areas Where Bush Seeks Changes
The East Germans even welcomed the Dalai Lama recently, which is said to have caused near apoplexy here as the Nobel Committee prepared to give its peace prize Sunday to the exiled Tibetan monk for his struggle against Chinese rule.
The Chinese are also aware, that argument goes, that President Bush has received significant criticism for Mr. Scowcroft's visit and is bound to be hit with more as soon as Congress comes back into session. They also know that such criticism, which is founded on human rights, will not easily be stilled by the usual talk about China's importance to the United States for regional stability in Southeast Asia, Afghanistan, Korea and Taiwan.
And they are also cognizant that a true warming of relations and future visits by crucial figures like the Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas F. Brady, and the Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney, let alone by the Vice President or President, will depend on some form of quid-pro-quo response, however indirect, to answer Mr. Bush's requirements and needs.
American influence would also be required to free loans China needs from international agencies like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, or to allow the Chinese to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which Taiwan, its application on hold out of deference to China, is already qualified to join.
 
A More Blunt Washington
Areas where the President would like to see movement by the Chinese include a lifting of martial law, including in Tibet; a halt or at least a reduction in the pace of trials and executions of those who took part in the pro-democracy demonstrations; a return to normal contact with the Western embassies and a reduction of their enforced isolation; a resumption of the normal flow of information into China and of intellectual contacts, and two particularly American concerns: a formal halt in Chinese medium-range missile sales, especially in the Middle East, and a resolution of the problem of Fang Lizhi and his wife, Li Shuxian, leading Chinese dissidents who took refuge in June in the American Embassy and who are subject to arrest.
Geopolitics aside, an improvement in China's deeply tarnished reputation in America and in the West requires such moves, particularly at a time when changes in Moscow make the old arguments that a close relationship with China is vital to restrain an aggressive Soviet Union seem somewhat hollow.
Those issues are said to have been made clear to the Chinese in the weekend meetings, which non-American diplomats take as a sign that Washington is being somewhat more blunt and aggressive with the Chinese, who are in the midst of leadership struggles about the depth and nature of their relationship with the West.
Some Chinese, arguing for a turn away from the West, are comparing foreign influence in China now to the period of the Boxer Rebellion at the turn of the century, when the Empress Dowager, after years of enforcing Western privileges under the unequal treaties, gave her sanction to the cry: ''Destroy the oreigner!'' setting off an international invasion and march on Beijing.
 
Concern Over Tokyo's Reaction
Other diplomats are not so sanguine, however. Some mid-ranking American officials said privately that they were astounded and dismayed by the Scowcroft visit, which was closely held and meant the sudden return of the American Ambassador, James R. Lilley, from home leave.
Some worry that the intended message will not get across to Chinese leaders, or that they will take it as a gesture of Realpolitik-based support, no matter their past actions. Others said they feared that the visit would be taken as a green light by the Japanese to resume business as usual with China, diplomatic and commercial. There is also some concern that the visit will undermine the element in the party struggle that seeks changes, already on the defensive with the removal as party general secretary of Zhao Ziyang, simply by resuming public business with his rival, Prime Minister Li Peng.
There is a wide acceptance of the dictum of China scholar Jonathan D. Spence that outsiders cannot change China. But it is in the nature of American diplomacy to believe that China can, nevertheless, be influenced. President Bush, who feels he knows China after serving as an envoy here, has taken his gamble. But no one seems very clear about whether it will be a success.

HEADLINE: Thatcher Defends Refugee Policy

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong would continue, to deter other Vietnamese from fleeing to the colony in the hope of making their way to the West.
Mrs. Thatcher defended the Government policy in the face of criticism from abroad and discomfort at home after the first refugees were expelled under her policy yesterday. She was joined by her Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd. 
 
Lull Is Temporary
While Mr. Hurd said there would be no more deportations until the House of Commons held a major debate on the issue next Tuesday, he made it clear the lull was temporary. Indeed, he indicated that the Government was eager to talk with Vietnam about ways to return people at a faster rate.
Mr. Hurd stressed that the 51 people flown to Hanoi today did not qualify as refugees under international agreements. About 4,000 of the 57,000 Vietnames in detention camps on Hong Kong have already been through a screening and appeals process and are awaiting involuntary repatriation. Ultimately, as many as 40,000 of the 57,000 are expected to be deported.
''Illegal immigrants have to be returned to their country of origin,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in a debate in the House of Commons. She added that the people of densely populated Hong Kong could not cope with the flood and were ''suffering greatly.'' Other British officials added that overcrowding in the detention camps had to be relieved.
The Government also came under attack from human rights groups like Amnesty International, which questioned the adequacy of the screening that determined which Vietnamese were really refugees who had fled their country for fear of persecution.
But in general, Mr. Hurd and Mrs. Thatcher shrugged off criticism. Other Western countries were unwilling to take the Vietnamese, and a nearly yearlong effort to persuade them to return voluntarily failed.
In the debate in Parliament, several politicians lashed out against the United States. Its war with Vietnam had played a big role in creating the economic misery behind the boat people crisis, and its hard-line policy against Vietnam since the war had only added to the misery, they said.
''Until American policy changes, the flow of refugees will continue,'' one Member of Parliament said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Plans Summit Talks on Saving Children

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 12

 BODY:
A ''world summit for children'' is being planned here next September to mobilize money and resources to save the lives of 50 million children, who the authorities predict would otherwise die in the next decade.
The gathering has been scheduled for Sept. 26 and 27, and timed to coincide with the opening of the 1990 United Nations General Assembly, when world leaders traditionally gather in New York.
James P. Grant, the executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund, known as Unicef, said in a recent interview that between 40 and 60 heads of state or government are likely to attend the session. He said invitations to the meeting would be issued later this month by leaders of Canada, Egypt, Mali, Mexico, Pakistan and Sweden, the sponsors. 
''This will be the first ever North-South-East-West Summit,'' Mr. Grant, said, adding that both President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev were expected to take part.
Mr. Grant said the goal of the meeting would be to obtain a top-level political commitment to save children in the 1990's, particularly through the redirection of military and defense savings resulting from the easing of East-West tensions and the winding down of regional conflicts.
In its annual report today, Unicef says that spending an additional $2.5 billion a year on proven health maintenance techniques would save the lives of 50 million more children under the age of 5 in the 1990's.
This would reduce the number of children dying each year from preventable diseases from some 14.5 million at present to about 8 million by the year 2000, the report says.
Unicef says that such a sum of money, while large, equals only 2.5 percent of the roughly $145 billion spent by developing countries on armaments each year and is equivalent to what the American tobacco industry spends each year advertising cigarettes.
Welcoming the meeting, Representative Tony P. Hall of Ohio, the chairman of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Hunger, said today that it ''will focus on the most solvable of the world's problems. The rewards from a sucessful summit would be tremendous.''
Mr. Grant defended his goal of saving 50 million children's lives in the 1990's as technically feasible through inexpensive modern techniques to fight dysentry, diptheria and other diseases that are the main killers of young children in the developing world.
But he also argued that current efforts to stabilize world population and reduce human pressure on its resources would not suceed until infant mortality rates fall further in the developing world and parents are assured that their children will survive.
''Reducing infant mortality rates in the last decade of this century will produce lower rates of population growth in the next,'' Mr Grant said.
In its survey, titled ''The State of the World's Children,'' Unicef says governments of the developing world are now devoting half their annual resources to military spending and the servicing of foreign debts.
The report says that as a result the condition of children is deteriorating throughout the developing world as living standards fall and governments cut back on social spending in an attempt to make their economies more efficent at the urging of aid donors and international financial institutions like the World Bank.
In the world's 37 poorest countries, the report says, spending on education has declined by about 25 percent in the last decade.
Unicef also says the position of poor children is deteriorating in both the United States and Britain, despite a decade of steady economic growth. The number of homeless families is rising in both countries while in the United States the number of children living in poverty has risen by 3 million in the last 10 years, from 11 percent of the child population to over 15 percent today. In New York City, 40 percent of the children were found living in poverty.
A free copy of the report can be obtained by writing to Unicef, 3 United Nations Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10017.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Excerpts From Baker's Speech on Berlin and U.S. Role in Europe's Future

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the speech today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d at the Berlin Press Club, as provided by the Federal News Service:
It is a great honor for an American to speak at this time in this city. For me and for millions of my fellow citizens, Berlin is the crucible of half a century of history.
Here we have seen clearly what elsewhere hid in shadows.
Here the ambiguous disclosed its true nature.
Here we made the choices and took the stands that shaped today's world. 
In 1945, pictures of a bombed-out Berlin brought home to us the terrible cost of war.
In 1948, the Soviet Union stalked out of the Four Power Control Commission and blockaded Berlin - the clear declaration of cold war.
In 1953, Berliners staged the first popular revolt against Soviet tyranny in Eastern Europe.
In 1961, the Berin Wall closed the last escape hatch from the prison camp of nations which Eastern Europe had become.
In 1971, the Quadripartite Agreement on Berlin epitomized the terrible dilemma of detente - the proposition that cooperation between East and West assumed the continued division of this continent.
Then in 1989, the most important event - certainly the most dramatic - of the postwar era occurred, right here in Berin. Eastern Europe: Berlin's Vital Role On Nov. 9, the wall became a gateway. Berliners celebrated history's largest, happiest family reunion. And all of us who watched these scenes felt, once again: We are all Berliners.
Once more images from Berlin flashed around the world, images that again heralded a new reality. This new reality has its roots in those older Berlin scenes - the scenes of West Berlin's dramatic postwar reconstruction; the scenes of Allied aircraft supplying a blockaded city; the scenes of American and Soviet tanks facing off at Checkpoint Charlie.
By standing together, in Berlin as elsewhere, Western nations created the essential preconditions for overcoming the divisions of this city, of this nation, and of this continent.
As these recent events have unfolded, the Soviet Union has shown a remarkable degree of realism. And President Gorbachev deserves credit for being the first Soviet leader to have the courage and foresight to permit the lifting of repression in Eastern Europe.
But the real impulse for change comes from an altogether different source: the peoples of Poland, of Hungary, of Czechoslovakia, of Bulgaria, and of East Germany. They have freed themselves. From the Baltic to the Adriatic, an irresistible movement has gathered force - a movement of, by, and for the people. In their peaceful urgent multitude, the peoples of Eastern Europe have held up a mirror to the West and have reflected the enduring power of our own best values. In the words of Thomas Jefferson, the first American Secretary of State, nothing is more certainly written in the book of fate than that these people are to be free. ... Free Governments: Planning the Future Now, as President Bush stated last week, the task before us is to consolidate the fruits of this peaceful revolution and provide the architecture for continued peaceful change.
The first step is for free men and women to create free governments. The path may appear difficult, even confusing, but we must travel it with understanding. For true stability requires governments with legitimacy, governments that are based on the consent of the governed.
The peoples of Eastern Europe are trying to build such governments. Our view, as President Bush has told President Gorbachev, is that the political and economic reforms in the East can enhance both long-term stability in Europe and the prospects for perestroika. A legitimate and stable European order will help, not threaten, legitimate Soviet interests. An illegitimate order will provide no order at all.
Free men, free governments, are the building blocks of a Europe whole and free. But hopes for a Europe whole and free are tinged with concern by some that a Europe undivided may not necessarily be a Europe peaceful and prosperous. Many of theguideposts that brought us securely through four sometimes tense and threatening decades are now coming down. Some of the divisive issues that once brought conflict to Europe are re-emerging.
As Europe changes, the instruments for Western cooperation must adapt. Working together, we must design and gradually put into place a new architecture for a new era.
This new architecture must have a place for old foundations and structures that remain valuable - like NATO - while recognizing that they can also serve new collective purposes. The new architecture must continue the construction of institutions - like the E.C. - that can help draw together the West while also serving as an open door to the East. And the new architecture must build up frameworks . . . that can overcome the division of Europe and bridge the Atlantic Ocean.
This new structure must also accomplish two special purposes. First, as a part of overcoming the division of Europe, there must be an opportunity to overcome through peace and freedom the division of Berlin and of Germany. The United States and NATO have stood for unification for 40 years, and we will not waver from that goal.
Second, the architecture should reflect that America's security - politically, militarily, and economically -remains linked to Europe's security. The United States and Canada share Europe's neighborhood.
As President Bush stated in May, the United States is and will remain a European power. And as he added last week, the U.S. will maintain significant military forces in Europe as long as our allies desire our presence as part of a common security effort. This is our commitment to a common future, a recognition of a need for an active United States role in Europe, a need even acknowledged by President Gorbachev. ... Arms Pacts and Peace: Conventional Forces In May of this year, President Bush suggested to his NATO colleagues that it was time to begin considering new missions for NATO.
For over 40 years, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has secured peace in Europe through both deterrence and dialogue with the East. Today, NATO is working in Vienna to build a new security structure for Europe, one in which the military component is reduced and the political is enhanced. This is NATO's first new mission.
A conventional forces agreement is the keystone of this new security structure. In May, NATO adopted President Bush's suggestion to seek such an agreement on an accelerated timetable. President Gorbachev has responded to this opportunity positively. And we have moved significantly closer to concluding an agreement limiting conventional armaments from the Atlantic to the Urals. ...
Today, I further propose that the Ministers of the 23 NATO and Warsaw Pact nations take advantage of our February meeting in Ottawa . . . to review the status and give a further push to the Vienna Talks on Conventional Forces.
As we construct a new security architecture that maintains the common defense, the non-military component of European security will grow. Arms-control agreements, confidence-building measures and other political consultative arrangements will become more important. . . . NATO will become the forum where Western nations cooperate to negotiate, implement, verify and extend agreements between East and West.
In this context, the implementation and verification monitoring of a conventional-forces agreement will present a major challenge for enduring security. . . .
I therefore invite allied governments to consider establishing a NATO Arms Control Verification Staff. Verification will remain a national responsibility. But such a new staff would be able to assist member governments in monitoring compliance with arms-control and confidence-building measures in Europe. . . .
As the East-West confrontation recedes, and as the prospects for East-West cooperation advance, other challenges for European and Atlantic security will arise. They point to NATO's second new mission. Regional conflicts - along with the proliferation of missiles and nuclear, chemical and biological weapons -present growing dangers. Intensified NATO consultations on these issues can play an important role in forming common Western approaches to these various threats.
Third, NATO should also begin considering further initiatives the West might take . . . to build economic and political ties with the East, to promote respect for human rights, to help build democratic institutions, and to fashion, consistent with Western security interests, a more open environment for East-West trade and investment.
Finally, NATO may have its greatest and most lasting effect on the pattern of change by demonstrating to the nations of the East a fundamentally different approach to security. . . . The reconciliation of ancient enemies, which has taken place under the umbrella of NATO's collective security, offers the nations of Eastern Europe an appealing model of international relations. ... Role of European Community The future development of the European Community will play a central role in shaping the New Europe.
The example of Western cooperation through the European Community has already had a dramatic effect on Eastern attitudes toward economic liberty. The success of this great European experiment, perhaps more than any other factor, has caused Eastern Europeans to recognize that people as well as nations cooperate more productively when they are free to choose. The ballot box and the free market are the fundamental instruments of choice.
But the European experiment has succeeded not just because it has appealed to the enlightened self-interest of European producers and consumers. This experiment has succeeded because the vision of its founders encompassed and yet transcended the material. This experiment has succeeded because it also held out the higher goal of political as well as economic barriers overcome, of a Europe united. ...
As Europe moves toward its goal of a common internal market, and as its institutions for political and security cooperation evolve, the link between the United States and the European Community will become even more important. We want our trans-Atlantic cooperation to keep pace with European integration and institutional reform.
To this end, we propose that the United States and the European Community work together to achieve, whether in treaty or some other form, a significantly strengthened set of institutional and consultative links. ...
We suggest that our discussions about this idea proceed in parallel with Europe's efforts to achieve by 1992 a common internal market so that plans for U.S.-E.C. interaction would evolve with changes in the community.
The United States also encourages the European Community to continue and expand cooperation with the nations of the East. The promotion of political and economic reform in the East is a natural vocation for the European Community. That is why we were exceptionally pleased with the agreement at the Paris Economic Summit that the European Commission should assume a special role in the Group of 24 effort to promote reform in Poland and Hungary. ..
I am confident that creative new arrangements can be devised to encourage and sustain the process of political and economic reform in the countries of Eastern Europe, while at the same time preserving the integrity and the vitality of existing institutions. We need to offer the nations of the East hope, opportunities that can be seized as they take steps toward democracy and economic liberty. . . .
We see no conflict between the process of European integration and an expansion of cooperation between the European Community and its neighbors to the East and West. Indeed, we believe that the attraction of the European Community for the countries of the East depends most on its continued vitality. And the vitality of the Economic Community depends in turn on its continued commitment to the goal of a united Europe envisaged by its founders - free, democratic and closely linked to its North American partners. ... Germany and Berlin In a New Europe A new Europe, whole and free, must include arrangements that satisfy the aspirations of the German people and meet the legitimate concerns of Germany's neighbors. . . . At last week's NATO summit, President Bush reaffirmed America's long-standing support for the goal of German unification. He enunciated four principles that guide our policy. ...
One, self-determination must be pursued without prejudice to its outcome. We should not at this time endorse nor exclude any particular vision of unity.
Two, unification should occur in the context of Germany's continued commitment to NATO and an increasingly integrated European Community, and with due regard for the legal role and responsibilities of the Allied powers.
Three, in the interests of general European stability, moves toward unification must be peaceful, gradual, and part of a step-by-step process.
Four, on the question of borders, we should reiterate our support for the principles of the Helsinki Final Act.
President Bush concluded that an end to the unnatural division of Europe, and of Germany, must proceed in acordance with and be based upon the values that are becoming universal ideals, as all the countries of Europe become part of a commonwealth of free nations.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 529 words

HEADLINE: Full Slow Ahead in Germany

 BODY:
''Wir sind ein Volk,'' proclaim the Christian Democratic party posters suddenly evident in Bonn: ''We are one people.'' That sentiment is so powerful that few West German politicians can resist it. But one people is not the same as one economy or one state. Once the rush of sentiment subsides, it will take time to work out the economic and political differences between the two Germanys. And the architects of a new international structure that can accommodate one Germany will need at least as much time. 
Gaining the needed time may not be easy, especially if East Germans are impatient. But there may be no more important task for statesmen on both sides of the Berlin wall. That's why it is so welcome that Chancellor Kohl of West Germany has slowed his rush to proclaim confederation, and that Secretary of State Baker has now spelled out America's reasons for Germany to proceed gradually.
How much time is there to manage the unification process? It is likely that economic differences will set the pace. West Germany's high standard of living draws East Germans west, but many still want the security of their Socialist safety net. With open borders, Bonn expects a large influx of East Germans eager for the better things in life, unless it does something now to encourage them to stay home. It intends to provide more subsidies.
They will be wasted, however, unless economic differences can be bridged. East Germans will have to decide what kind of economy they want. Opposition groups are eager to try democratic socialism, a mixture of Western-style markets and Eastern-style social welfare. Others will urge unification as the only way up the economic ladder.
Instead of facing up to these economic imperatives, Chancellor Kohl last week chilled East and West with a 10-point reunification plan. He included no timetable but seemed eager. He spoke of confederation, an idea that would doom two German states - and doom their continued membership in the separate NATO and Warsaw Pact alliances. That membership is necessary to reassure East and West during a time of transition.
What did Mr. Kohl have in mind? Domestic politics, it now appears. In a hurry to catch the tide of German sentiment, he consulted with no one outside West Germany, or even outside his party. That's why there is worldwide relief over his clarification backtracking on confederation. ''I am consciously not talking about confederation,'' he now says. ''Such a step raises questions we cannot answer today because of the fact that the two states in Germany belong to different alliances.''
Mr. Baker pointedly reminded Bonn that the Four Powers have authority in Berlin, and over unification. Even so, even if every government, East and West, concurred, the most important variable in reunification may still be the East Germans. At the moment they are angry, and small wonder. They have just learned about the excesses of the kleptocracy that ruled from elaborate villas. Their thirst for vengeance could breed violence.
The very volatility of their passions makes even clearer the need for everyone involved, in Germany and out, to work for gradual, orderly unification.

HEADLINE: No One Can Control Runaway Medical Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It has been several years since the diagnosis related group, or D.R.G., system of fixed reimbursement to hospitals began, and now Congress is contemplating an expenditure target plan to control physicians' fees within the Medicare program.
The basic mechanism of expenditure targets (E.T.'s) will place a ceiling on the money spent on a specific operation or procedure annually. Should the expenditures for a procedure exceed the guideline, the payment for each procedure would be lowered in the following year to remain within the limit. Both the D.R.G. and E.T. programs have meritorious aspects. But just as medical expenditures have risen rapidly despite D.R.G.'s, so the new system will not solve the problem. 
''The Limits of Medicare'' (editorial, Nov. 27), which supports the new plan's effort to control the problem, loses sight of the hidden weakness that will make it fail, just as previous efforts failed. Such commentaries generally desire that the American Medical Association and local peer review panels will discipline the medical community to control abuse.
Will it be the A.M.A., which has fought Dr. Arnold Relman's efforts to limit physician ownership of facilities that provide such expensive ancillary services as CAT scans and magnetic resonance imaging? Dr. Relman's attempt to show the conflict of interest when physicians send patients to the establishments they own falls on deaf ears at the A.M.A.
Is the leadership to come from physicians who deliver without Caesarean section the babies of only some 10 percent of patients with previous Caesarean sections, although the evidence is clear that 60 percent to 70 percent of those women could safely deliver vaginally?
Will it come from a medical establishment that knows many hysterectomies, prostatectomies, bypass surgery and other operations are not necessary, but makes almost no effort to change the situation?
Is it to be in an environment that has almost excluded the time-honored morbidity and mortality conferences in which physicians, primarily pathologists, challenged other doctors to explain their actions?
In defense of the medical community, will it be young physicians who enter the ranks of private medical care with high ideals and high standards only to find themselves in an economic quagmire? With massive overhead expenditures in a highly competitive market, high standards begin to develop shades of gray when patients are seen that might be managed conservatively or by some immediate operative procedure.
The outcome of the expenditure target system will be the reverse of what the A.M.A. has stated. Physicians will not do fewer procedures because of lower reimbursement. Unethical physicians will do as they have done in the past. More unnecessary procedures will be done at a lower fee.
Thirty-seven million people receive no basic medical services, including prenatal care. As the costs keep rising, more and more people are likely to fall out of the economic safety net necessary to obtain services.
The ethical forces in the medical establishment are unwilling to take real action, and Congress appears unable to face the problem.
Medicine today is like a lifeboat sinking under the weight of a massively burgeoning budget. To stay afloat, we throw overboard the more than 37 million who cannot afford to pay.
 
HERBERT H. KEYSER, M.D.
 San Antonio, Nov. 28, 1989
The writer is author of ''Women Under the Knife.''

HEADLINE: Port Authority Puts Off Final Vote on Toll Rises

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
Under a barrage of public criticism and a threatened veto by Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has put off final action on a sweeping increase in bridge and tunnel tolls and the PATH train fare.
''It's on hold,'' a spokesman for Stephen Berger, the executive director of the Port Authority, said yesterday.
The 12-member Port Authority board was to have voted on the proposal tomorrow. But on Monday, the board chairman, Philip D. Kaltenbacher, told his colleagues that the toll and fare increases - along with the rest of the $2.9 billion budget for 1990 - had been taken off the agenda. 
He said the board wanted to give Governor Kean, Governor-elect James J. Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York ''an opportunity to review further the facts and figures and alternatives.''
 
Florio Opposes Quick Vote
On Dec. 1, Mr. Berger announced that he would ask the Port Authority board to approve a $1 increase, to $4, in the $3 round-trip bridge and tunnel tolls, effective April 1. Also, the one-way PATH rail fare, now $1, would rise to $1.25 on December 16, 1990.
The postponement is for at least four weeks. By the next scheduled board meeting, on Jan. 11, Governor Kean's successor, Mr. Florio, will have been in office for five working days. Mr. Florio cautioned the board yesterday against voting on the toll and fare increase on Jan. 11.
''If it's going to happen on my watch,'' he said, ''I expect to be thoroughly informed so I can make a rational, balanced decision.''
''The options are more than just approve or disapprove,'' Mr. Florio added. ''It is also possible to suggest modifications.''
 
Kean 'Not Satisfied'
A spokesman for Governor Kean, calling the postponement of the vote ''appropriate,'' reiterated that Mr. Kean was ''not satisfied that the increase is justified.''
''He wants the same kind of detailed economic analysis that was offered in 1987,'' when Governors Kean and Cuomo approved the last increase, the spokesman, Carl R. Golden, said.
Mr. Berger's surprise announcement that he would seek the increases startled and angered many commuters. At the time of the 1987 rise, the Port Authority assured the Governors that no new increases would be needed until mid-1991 at the earliest.
Mr. Berger has said that an increase is needed now because of reduced revenues caused by a regional economic slump, rising costs, and a major refurbishment of Port Authority properties.
Mr. Cuomo's role in the postponement of the vote was not clear. Late yesterday, he issued a one-sentence statement in Albany that ''we agree that it was appropriate to withdraw the request and ask for additional information.''
The postponement is the second time in less than two weeks that a public transportation authority in the metropolitan region has bowed to public and political pressure over the issue of fares and tolls.
 
Friday Vote on Transit Fares
On Dec. 2, the New York City Transit Authority dropped a proposed 25-cent fare increase over the $1 bus and subway fare and said it would seek a 15-cent increase instead.
On Friday, the Transit Authority's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is to vote on the revised bus and subway proposal. It will also vote on a proposed $4.60 fare for express buses - now $3.50 - and increases averaging 25 percent on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and Long Island Rail Road.
On Nov. 30, the Taxi and Limousine Commission approved an 11.5 percent increase in yellow cab fares.
In July, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, an M.T.A. agency, imposed a 25 percent toll increase for its six major bridges and two tunnels.
 
Either Governor May Veto
The Governors of New York and New Jersey have the right to veto any Port Authority board decision within 10 working days.
Mr. Kean's spokesman insisted that the Governor's desire to put off the vote pending receipt of more extensive figures was not designed to leave the decision up to his successor, Mr. Florio.
''It's not a factor at all,'' Mr. Golden said, noting that Governor Kean had approved two earlier increases. ''In 1987, the toll and fare increase was accompanied by a very detailed analysis by an outside agency. The Port Authority's latest proposal did not have that kind of information.''
Under Mr. Berger's proposal, round-trip tolls would go up on the George Washington, Bayonne and Goethals Bridges, the Outerbridge Crossing and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels.
The new PATH fare would increase to $1.25 from $1, while discounts would be offered for the elderly and those buying multitrip tickets.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
College Graduates Facing More Money and Fewer Jobs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 12

 BODY:
College graduates next spring will earn more money but find fewer job opportunities, a survey of United States employers indicates.
Hiring will be down 13.3 percent compared to last year, according to the 19th annual survey by the University of Michigan's Career Development and Placement Services office.
The average starting salary for a graduate with a bachelor's degree will be $25,256, up 3.3 percent from a year ago. The expected starting salary for those with master's degrees in business administration will be $39,840, a 3.1 percent increase. Generally starting salaries will be $33,740 for master's degree graduates, up 3.3 percent, and $37,111 for graduates with doctoral degrees, a 2.4 percent increase. 
As in recent years, engineering majors will get the highest starting salaries for new college graduates, with chemical engineering leading the way at $33,380. Mechanical engineering ranks second at $32,256, while electrical engineering is at $32,107, followed by computer science at $31,389 and industrial engineering at $30,557.
 
Lowest Starting Salaries
The lowest starting salaries will be for graduates in human ecology-home economics, $18,157; journalism, $18,255; natural resources, $18,840; retailing, $18,909, and advertising, $19,662.
The survey released Sunday was based on responses from 479 employers in business, industry, government and educational institutions.
Patrick Scheetz, who directed the study, said reasons for the drop in planned hiring included limited growth in new business; mergers and buyouts; increased global competition, and slow turnover of current employees.
Industries that are expected to have large increases in hiring include public utilities, up 29.4 percent; metal products, up 24.2 percent; petroleum, 22.1 percent; construction and building materials manufacturing, 19.3 percent; and printing, publishing and informational services, 13.7 percent.
Those expected to have decreases included automotive and mechanical equipment, down 58 percent; electronics, 24.5 percent; government administration, 20.9 percent; aerospace, 20 percent; the military, 16.8 percent; and diversified conglomerates, 13.7 percent.
The survey also found that the greatest job opportunities are in the Southwest. Next best is the Northeast, followed by the Southeast, North-Central, South-Central and Northwest states.
In addition it found that employers requiring drug testing of new college graduates rose to 47 percent of those surveyed, up from 32 percent last year and 27 percent the year before. Testing for alcohol was required by 25 percent of those surveyed, up from 14 percent. Testing for AIDS was required by 4 percent of employers, a slight increase of 3 percent for the 1988-89 graduates.
