PUB-DATE: December 13, 1989

SECTION: Section B; Page 16, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 827 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
In Dylan Thomas's ''Child's Christmas in Wales,'' the poet recalls the ''useless presents'' that he and other youngsters used to receive, like books that ''told me everything about the wasp except why.''
The ''why'' question was one that came to mind frequently on Thursday, when representatives of the National Governors' Association and the White House gathered at a hotel in Washington to hear testimony on setting national goals for education.
High government officials in the United States do not usually sit around tables hammering out such goals in agriculture, commerce or other areas of national life. Why education? And suppose - as is likely - they do come up with a set of goals suitable for framing or putting on bumper stickers. What do they do with them? 
The governors' motivation can be explained pretty simply. They are scared to death about the quality of schools.
Like everyone else, they read those international studies showing that millions of American college students would have a tough time graduating from high school in Japan or West Germany. Unlike everyone else, governors are regularly reminded of the importance of good schools, not only for attracting business, but also for holding down the cost of social services.
Studies of preschool programs in this country and Europe have consistently found that money invested in early childhood education is returned many times over in the form of less need down the road for remedial teaching, law enforcement and health care.
''The governors realize that businesses in their states can't compete with low wages alone anymore,'' the education aide to the governors' association, Michael Cohen, said. ''You have to have a quality work force.''
For four years the association has been pushing an ambitious agenda of change, recommending, for example, that schools be given more autonomy in the way they are managed and parents more discretion in selecting their children's schools.
The governors' efforts received a boost when President Bush assembled them for an ''education summit'' in Charlottesville, Va., in September. Out of that came the Governors' Task Force on Education, with a mandate to formulate a set of national goals for education by February.
The hearings last week, the first public follow-up to the summit, gave groups like the Children's Defense Fund and the National School Boards Association a chance to contribute their views.
Chester E. Finn Jr., who headed educational research for the Reagan Administration, ruffled some feathers by telling the panel that -presumably excluding himself -they were listening to the wrong people. ''These people are the blob, the ones who gave you schools the way they are now,'' he said.
But a Presidential assistant for economic and domestic affairs, Roger Porter, came back with a plea for cooperation among parents, educators, business people and others, and ''a lot less finger pointing.'' And indeed, there was at least the appearance of consensus.
The expressed differences of opinion seemed to be more technical than philosophical. Not surprisingly, the politicians spoke more eloquently about measuring educational results than did practitioners like teachers and superintendents. When it came to the well-supported goal of assuring that every child is prepared for school, the governors seemed to be thinking in more ambitious terms than the White House. ''To the governors, readiness for school means physically healthy, not just intellectually prepared,'' said a staff aide.
The panel seems well on track to produce its list of goals. But how are they to be carried out? Frequent comparisons were made with John F. Kennedy's commitment to put a man on the moon by the end of the 1960's, a pledge that was made long before anyone knew how to pull that off. But that analogy only goes so far.
''Kennedy had a structure in place to do the job, and it was a Federal structure,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''We're talking about changing the behavior of people in a highly decentralized system.''
One obvious possibility is the issuing of an annual national report card showing how well schools are doing in relation to whatever goals are set. The problem here is that the technical means for measuring outcomes, like whether children can reason in a sophisticated manner, are still in the embryonic stage.
The president of the National Center for Education and the Economy, Marc Tucker, urged the panel to set up a ''quasigovernmental authority'' to keep the goals in the limelight and to refine and update them regularly. He also called for a national school-leaving examination that students would be required to pass to obtain a high school diploma. ''The trick is to create incentives to meet whatever goals are set,'' he said.
For the moment, though, the governors and the White House representatives have pointedly shelved the ''what next'' questions, figuring that they are akin to explaining why wasps.

HEADLINE: 18 Nations Ban Steel Subsidies

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
The Bush Administration announced today that countries that provide two-thirds of the steel imported into America had signed agreements to end Government subsidies like low-cost loans and export incentive payments that help their steelmakers.
S. Linn Williams, the deputy United States trade representative, called the accords ''historic.'' He said it was the first time that any country had agreed with any other country to limit domestic subsidies.
The pacts were disclosed in connection with a two-and-one-half year renewal of an import quota program that keeps steel from signatory countries below 20 percent of that sold in the United States. They are the first steps in an ambitious Administration effort to negotiate a global prohibition on Government aid to all industries under the so-called Uruguay Round. The Uruguay Round trade talks with more than 100 countries began in 1986 and will end next December. 
 
Long-Standing Grievance
Myriad subsidies of products entering the United States are a long-standing grievance of American business, which welcomed today's accords.
The pacts with the 12-nation European Community and six other countries - Japan, South Korea, Brazil, Mexico, Australia and Trinidad and Tobago - include commitments to prohibit subsidies for steel production, as well as to keep markets open for steel.
They also incorporate a mechanism for binding arbitration. Countries that violate the agreements face the threat of having their steel shipments to the United States reduced under the quota program. #1992 Expiration Date The agreements and the quota program itself expire on March 31, 1992, but the United States hopes by then to have the major provisions incorporated by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world's free-trade charter, as a result of the Uruguay Round negotiations.
''We believe that these agreements will be the building blocks for progress in the round on eliminating trade-distorting subsidies and opening markets,'' Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said in a statement distributed as she was leaving for a series of meetings in Europe.
Foreign governments were willing to sign the accords because of a growing sensitivity to the rising cost of taxpayer support of industry. Ella Krucoff, an official at the European Community office in Washington, said that the community had had restrictions on steel aid in place since 1985 and that the new agreement ''goes along very well'' with these curbs.
For Brazil, Mexico and other developing countries, a cut in subsidies is a key element of programs of economic adjustment worked out with the International Monetary Fund.
Rejecting the American steel industry's demand that import quota protection be extended for five more years, the Bush Administration last July announced that the program would be terminated in two and one-half years, but that it would seek the subsidy-banning accords.
The Administration is continuing to negotiate with three more countries, Austria, Finland and Yugoslavia.
 
'Additional Discipline' Seen
The American Iron and Steel Institute, representing 25 of the biggest integrated steelmakers, said it was still worried that import market shares could rise sharply after March 1992, when the quotas are removed, but added that the pacts announced today should bring ''additional discipline'' over foreign steel subsidies.
The big steel companies are expected to monitor the agreements closely and bring violations to the attention of American trade officials.
The agreements ''are solid first steps toward market-oriented trade based upon enforceable commitments to eliminate steel subsidies and to open markets,'' said Frank R. Corral, chairman of the Steel Manufacturers Association, representing smaller, more specialized producers, known as minimills.
Jack Andresen, staff director of the House Congressional Steel Caucus, said he thought that ''pursuit of the international consensus is admirable, and hopefully they will create a level playing field for steel.''
 
Level Put at 19.1 Percent
Under the new quotas, the European Community and 16 countries have agreed to an overall restraint level of 19.1 percent of the domestic market. Countries that have not signed restraint agreements account for an additional 4.5 percent of the domestic market, based on 1989 import figures.
Under the first five years of the quota agreement, 17 countries and the European Community were held to 18.36 percent of the United States market. South Africa is the only country in the original quota group that did not negotiate a new restraint arrangement.
Of the quota countries, Japan is the big loser. It had been given 6.19 percent of the American market in the first five years. For the first 15 months of the new agreement its share is 5 percent. This will rise to 5.3 percent in the second 15 months.
Each percentage point is worth nearly one million tons of steel. 18 Million Tons in 1991 About 17 million tons of steel over all will be permitted into the United States next year under the new arrangement, rising to about 18 million tons in 1991.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Buyout Fever: The Patient Lives

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WITH Michael Milken under indictment and the market for ''junk bonds'' under water, ''leverage'' has become a four-letter word. Corporate buyouts constructed on pyramids of debt, goes the conventional wisdom, have weakened once mighty industries and deprived Washington of billions in corporate income taxes.
The latter charge seems on target: Interest payments to banks and bondholders, unlike dividends to stockholders, are tax-free to corporations. But the idea that leverage inevitably transforms aggressive, innovative companies into myopic, cash-starved basket cases is far from obvious. 
Much publicized failures, like Southland and Revco, have been matched by much publicized successes, like Metromedia and Safeway. That is why a new study by Frank Lichtenberg of Columbia University and Donald Siegel of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., is so significant.
Using Census Bureau data from hundreds of plants, they measured the impact of leveraged buyouts on what many economists believe is the best gauge of efficiency. And strikingly, leveraged buyouts come out smelling like roses.
Leveraged buyouts, in which investor groups purchase companies with borrowed money, can sometimes be the cure for all that ails. A buyout narrows the division of interest between managers and owners, increasing executives' personal incentives for strong performance, typically stock options. Correspondingly, the penalties for failure, bankruptcy, or at very least, loss of managerial control, are also increased.
On the other hand, the big debts incurred to banks and bondholders narrow managers' margin for error - or bad luck. And that may force companies to cut back on research, to skimp on maintenance, or to sell off promising operations that suffer from an anemic cash flow.
Mr. Lichtenberg and Mr. Siegel measured what happened to some 1,100 manufacturing plants involved in leveraged buyouts worth $35 million and more between 1981 and 1986. And they compared the results with what happened to some 20,000 plants not involved in leveraged buyouts. The benchmark for comparison was ''total factor productivity'' - output divided by an index of the labor, capital and materials used in production.
On average, the rate of productivity change over the five-year span was 14 percent higher in the newly leveraged plants than in plants in the same industry that were not involved in leveraged buyouts. And where the managers themselves bought out the stockholders, the difference in productivity growth was even greater - 20 percent.
These figures should not come as a great surprise to those who see leveraged buyouts as an excuse to extort more effort for less money from line workers by threatening to close or sell off divisions. But according to the study, savings in labor have come at the expense of middle managers. On average, both hourly wages and total hours on the job increased after a company was bought out.
The record on research outlays holds similar surprises. Cash poor, the manager of a leveraged buyout has an incentive to risk the company's long-term prospects by cutting back on projects with a distant productivity payoff. But Mr. Lichtenberg and Mr. Siegel's findings suggest that the increased need for income is more than offset by a privately held company's discretion to plan beyond next quarter's earnings report.
Research and development spending as a percentage of company sales, they discovered, rose faster for the buyout companies than for others. So, too, did the proportion of engineers and scientists to the company's total labor force.
Steve Hanke, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, points out an important qualification. The plants studied were involved in leveraged buyouts before 1987 - before investment bankers seeking BMW's had spread leveraged buyout fever to every nook and cranny of corporate America. It is possible, even likely, that the percentage of successes in the first wave of buyouts will not be matched by more recent ventures.
Still, the Lichtenberg-Siegel study is dramatically changing the character of the scholarly debate over leveraged buyouts.
Everyone agrees that stockholders have benefited from buyouts, realizing the full value, or more, from their assets. And everyone agrees that some people have lost jobs and Washington has lost tax revenue in subsequent asset shuffles. But this is the first attempt to measure the overall effect of leveraged buyouts on current and future productivity. And it represents a big victory for those inclined to give the benefit of a doubt to any market transaction between consenting adults.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Purchasers See Slower Growth

 BODY:
The association of the nation's purchasing managers has predicted that the United States will avert a recession in 1990, but that growth will be only moderate.
In its semiannual forecast, the National Association of Purchasing Management said economic growth would be weak in the first half of next year and then pick up. 
The purchasing executives also expressed widespread uncertainty about the economy, with the principal worry being the threat of recession or a severely slowing economy.
''There will be weakness in almost all the industries related to automobiles, and that includes steel, tires, plastics and electronics,'' Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of materials management for Pitney Bowes Inc., said at a news conference in New York. ''Also, housing-related industries will show some weakness next year, including lumber.'' Growth is expected in chemicals, pharmacueticals, food and beverages and paper, Mr. Bretz added.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at a One-Year Low Against a Soaring Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
West Germany's mark dominated foreign exchange trading yesterday, strengthening on firm interest rates in that country and talk of a reunified Germany that helped sharply depress the dollar and other currencies.
In both New York and Europe, the dollar hit the lowest level since December 1988 against the mark, traders said. The dollar was quoted in London at 1.7335 marks, off from 1.7660 marks late Monday, and in New York at 1.73225 marks, down from 1.7610.
''The scenario here is that interest rates in Germany will stay firm, while United States rates are trending down because the economy is slowing,'' said Earl I. Johnson, a currency trader at Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. ''It's not so much the dollar's weakness as it is the mark's strength. The mark is the place to be right now.''
The mark has risen sharply in recent weeks amid rapid political and economic changes in East Germany. Traders speculate that West Germany's economy will flourish, pushing interest rates higher, as boundaries between East and West diminish. High interest rates tend to support a currency.
The dollar also weakened against other major currencies in New York trading.
It traded at 143.97 yen in New York, down from 144.38 Monday. It dipped below 6.00 French francs for the first time since Dec. 16, 1988, finishing at 5.9185 francs in New York, down from 6.0200. And sterling rose to $1.6085 from $1.5937 in New York.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.5732 Swiss francs, down from 1.5915; 1,284.75 Italian lire, down from 1,301.00, and 1.16255 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16375.

HEADLINE: Last Laps for East Germany's Olympic System

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Inside the Gymnastics and Sports Club of Berlin, life seemed as normal as ever today. A men's volleyball team practiced under the watchful eyes of its coach. A group of pre-teen-age boys played soccer, four-on-four. Five little girls pranced through the moves of a gymnastics routine they will perform Saturday as part of the club's Christmas show.
One would never know that outside the complex and beyond, a country was in the midst of political reform. Yet because East Germany holds sports so dear to its heart, those inside the club are not likely to remain unaffected by the changes, which continued today when all the officers of the national sports authority resigned, as expected. 
 
Old Way Losing Favor
''It cannot be the old way; that is too difficult, and our economy is not so good,'' said Hannelore Generlich, a former coach with national gymnastics teams who was working with the little girls.
In what form sports will continue is one of the more intriguing subplots of East Germany's current political mystery. As an interim coalition government grapples with new ideas five months in advance of parliamentary elections, sports leaders are debating how the future resources from the government might be applied.
While it is generally assumed that those in power will accede to public demands of more money for local and regional sports programs, some of East Germany's elite athletes are wondering if a reallocation of funds will damage the country's mighty Olympic factory. Only the Soviet Union and the United States have won more medals than East Germany has in the last six Olympics.
 
Unwilling to Recede
''If that is so,'' Ulf Timmermann said of a possible government cutback, ''then, yes, we will have some problems competing in the Olympics as we did in the past. But we will not give up this position voluntarily.''
Timmermann, the 1988 Olympic shot-put champion, is one of the Berlin club's most celebrated members. Speaking amid the grunts and groans of others at practice, his own workout ended, he reflected on the possible changes for the country's top athletes and the system that produces them.
In general, he envisioned only minimal, if any, retrenchment by the Government, and was thus not terribly alarmed over the possibility of major damage to the system.
Another of the club's elite athletes, Heike Hartwig, a former women's national shot-put champion, agreed, saying: ''Western athletes have shown us they can compete without so much government support. If we are put in that position, we can demonstrate our levels of performance.''
If budgets were cut back - a greater possibility if the Communist Party wins only minority representation in the May elections - Timmermann said sports authorities might be forced to consider reducing the number of sports in which the country would try to excel at the international level.
 
Truly an Elite
Until now, East Germany has always taken a lean approach to elite sports. Its national teams are composed only of athletes judged by coaches to be potential medal winners, unlike the United States, for example, which fills every available slot no matter what the athlete's chances for a medal may be.
Also, the East Germans de-emphasize many team sports, like ice hockey and field hockey, because a team can win only one medal. For that reason alone, Timmermann said, future austerity could force sports leaders to de-emphasize team sports in which the country has had success, like volleyball and handball.
In any case, he added, federations for all sports will likely investigate new ways to supplement whatever government subsidies they receive, as a safeguard against any shortfalls.
''Elite sports need other resources,'' he said. ''We now have a chance to earn much more than in the past. Marketing, for example. To now, there has been very, very little effort. Our national team has had only one commercial deal, with Adidas.
''But we can also have advertising on our shirts, signs in our stadiums. I am sure we can sign contracts with big enterprises to earn much more than we have before.''
 
Some Revisions Already Made
Some efforts are already under way. The track and field federation is considering raising money by allowing more athletes to participate in more Western meets. Timmermann said he and other East Germans had competed only rarely each summer on the Grand Prix circuit, which pays athletes according to their performances.
In the future, he said, an athlete would split the winnings with the federation. In the past, the federation has kept all the money, except for a small daily living allowance.
The soccer federation is negotiating with first-division clubs in Western Europe to transfer players on a limited basis. Such an arrangement is viewed by sports officials here as a way of discouraging talented players from defecting while generating revenues at the same time.
The transfer fee would be shared by the federation and the players, who would remain eligible for East German national teams.
The notion of one country's renting an athlete to another is not uncommon. But East Germany has indulged only once, in altered form, by allowing Katarina Witt, the Olympic figure-skating champion, to perform in Western ice shows.
While Timmermann and Hartwig acknowledged that they would enjoy any extra money from competitive or marketing endeavors, they stressed that in these uncertain times, supplemental income would better serve the system.

HEADLINE: Key Ideas Are All Divac Needs to Be a True Laker

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INGLEWOOD, Calif.

 BODY:
It was only in the days after the Lakers had selected Vlade Divac in the first round of the National Basketball Association draft last June that Mitch Kupchak at last got through by phone to the 21-year-old center in Yugoslavia.
''I spoke to the kid, which was interesting in itself,'' Kupchak, the team's assistant general manager, said at the time.
Divac, one of Europe's most heralded players and certainly one of the N.B.A.'s more intriguing selections, soon arrived in the United States, and it was then that the full scope of a language problem became evident, with many nuances.
''It's when he winks that you know he has no clue,'' one Lakers official said of Divac. 
''And if he says, 'Yeah, yeah,' more than once in a sentence, rest assured he's in trouble,'' said Mark McNamara, a backup center for Los Angeles and one of the many people who have both officially and informally tried to assist Divac in learning English and surviving in the N.B.A.
 
'Simple Verbs'
McNamara teaches from comparable experience, having played in both Italy and Spain and having spoken neither Italian nor Spanish.
''The people I could understand best were those who made the conscious effort to speak simply,'' McNamara said. ''Simple verbs, present tense, no slang. It can be a super hardship if you let it be.
''Vlade, though, is a wonderful imitator. It's amazing how well he copes. He can pick out key words, and though technically he may not know what the word means, he associates it with a play.''
The Lakers, for their part, have begun to associate the following words with the play of the 7-foot-1-inch Divac: ''naturally gifted,'' ''offensively explosive,'' ''potentially dominating.'' In 19 games going into last night's contest at Charlotte, N.C., Divac had averaged 8.1 points and 5.8 rebounds in just over 17 minutes a game, and along the way collected his share of assists and steals. Against the Hornets, whom the Lakers beat by 103-89, he scored only 2 points.
 
'Picked Up His Pace'
''His offense is clearly polished, and he doesn't even realize how good a defensive player he could be,'' said Mychal Thompson, the Lakers' starting center. ''And he's picked up his pace, gradually gotten the European style out of his game. He used to sort of lope down the court like a giant deer. Now, he's galloping like the rest of us.''
Vlade Divac (pronounced VLAH-day DEE-vatz) understood pretty early in life that, given his height, things stood to be different for him. He was born in the small town of Prijepolje, but left by age 12 to pursue his accelerated career in basketball. By 16, he was playing in Yugoslavia's senior league. A year later, he owned a gold medal from the World University Games. Three years after that, he had a silver one placed around his neck at the Olympics in Seoul.
Marty Blake, the director of scouting for the N.B.A., rated him the second-best player outside the United States after Sarunas Marciulionis, now with Golden State. Jerry West, the general manager of the Lakers, who were confronted with having to replace the retired Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, thought Divac would go anywhere from 8th to 16th in the draft. As it turned out, Divac hadn't gone anywhere by the time the Lakers selected 26th.
''I came here because it was my dream to play in the N.B.A.,'' Divac said recently. ''I thought that in three or four years, I'd be a good player. My dream now is to play in the All-Star Game.''
 
No Comfort Zone
In a sense, Divac plays in an All-Star Game of sorts nightly, for the caliber of basketball he encounters game in and game out far outstrips that which he was accustomed to dominating. There's no zone defense to be played, no comfort zone to be found.
''Vlade is not the protypical back-to-the-basket center,'' said Pat Riley, the Lakers' coach. ''He needs seasoning, he's got to study both the game and the opposition. But he's a bright kid. And I haven't sensed any desperation or anxiety. He's learned enough of the terminology to understand.''
That terminology, of course, includes Riley's own personal lexicon of directives and labels, expressions like ''rip'' and ''power.'' Additionally, Divac has had to struggle on the court to keep on the same page as Magic Johnson, the Lakers' improvisational wizard of a point guard.
''He tries to make it easy for me,'' Divac said of Johnson. ''He's a good person first. And second, he's the best player.''
 
Speculation and Hope
Just how good a player Divac can eventually become is a matter of speculation and hope. Divac, who for a couple of days last summer fretted over reports that his deferment from mandatory military service had been rescinded, appears to be safe for at least the three years of his contract.
He has given up cigarettes, been married, relocated to an apartment in Marina del Rey and been assigned both a tutor and an interpreter. And, of course, his salary has increased exponentially, a fact of life that has helped cushion his ego's deflation.
''At first, it was hard, because my wife had English in Yugoslavia and she was ahead of me,'' Divac said earlier in the season. ''But now I am starting to put things together, and that is better.''
He couldn't have been welcomed any more warmly than he has been by fans at the Forum. They cheer his entrance and applaud his every point. ''I don't know, maybe they like me because I am a new guy in a new country,'' Divac said. ''But I don't really know.''
He has, though, come to conclude at least one thing. ''After four months, I have decided,'' Divac said with a smile and no wink, ''L.A. is my city.''

HEADLINE: SOVIET JEWS LEAVE AT A RECORD PACE, MANY FOR ISRAEL

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The number of Jews streaming out of the Soviet Union has reached a record. Not counting people departing this month, more than 62,500 Jews have left this year, surpassing by more than 20 percent the high of 51,320 set in 1979.
In recent years most Soviet Jews have gone to the United States. But because of immigration limits imposed by Washington recently, the number of Jews going to Israel has increased dramatically in recent months. As a result, Israel is bracing for its greatest flow of immigrants since its early days of independence four decades ago. #750,000 Over 6 Years Possible More than 11,000 Soviet Jews left in November - the first time the figure exceeded 10,000 in a month - and almost 2,000 of them arrived here, 10 times the number who came to Israel in January. The number of emigres is monitored closely by Israeli officials and the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, a nonprofit American group.
Early this week the Government projected that Israel might absorb as many as 750,000 Soviet Jews in the next six years, an addition of 20 percent to the nation's Jewish population. 
Although the projection may be exaggerated, several hundred thousand Soviet Jews have in fact requested Israeli visas, largely because they fear increasing nationalist turmoil in the Soviet Union and because of the American decision to admit fewer Soviet refugees.
 
Problems of Jobs and Housing
An influx even close to the projection would enhance Israel's sense of national identity after years in which more Jews have emigrated from the country than arrived, but it would also pose major problems for the country. It is accepted wisdom here that Israel is simply unequipped to handle immigrants in those numbers, and many Israelis resent such a migration at a time when unemployment is already high and housing already scarce.
But for Israel, the numbers are only half the problem. The people in this wave are different from other large groups of Jews to come to Israel or Palestine since the ''first aliyah'' from czarist Russia 100 years ago.
Most of the Soviet citizens coming now are not Zionists. In fact, they have little if any Jewish identity. And many people worry that their lack of Jewish zeal might make it more difficult for them to weather hard times in their new homeland.
Tugging sleepy children and overstuffed carry-on bags, about 65 of these immigrants arrived at Ben-Gurion International Airport in Lod just before dawn Monday. Like many other Soviet citizens stepping off planes that are landing here almost every day, these people looked startled, even a bit disturbed, as two dozen yeshiva students greeted them, chanting, clapping and singing traditional Jewish songs the Russians had never heard.
''This aliyah is different from the Soviet aliyah of the 70's,'' said Lizy Zlotnik, an Absorption Ministry official who handled paperwork on the new immigrants at the airport. ''Most of these people are very educated. These are Russians. They don't know anything about Judaism, and they don't really care about it.''
As part of the liberalization under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Union has made leaving the country much easier for the nation's 287 million citizens, including its estimated two million Jews. A new emigration law is expected to be enacted early next year, removing most restrictions on travel abroad. Some Soviet officials estimate that four million Soviet citizens will emigrate in the next few years. President Bush has already promised trade concessions to Moscow once the law is enacted.
Many of the new Jewish immigrants are leaving the Soviet Union ''because Russia is in turmoil, and they are afraid of what will be left for them when it ends,'' said Simcha Dinitz, chairman of the Jewish Agency, the quasi-Government organization largely responsible for settling immigrants.
 
Fear of Nationalist Movements
With all the assertive nationalist movements now spreading across the country, ''we are scared,'' said Leon Kostavitch, a 26-year-old engineer who had just arrived. ''It's dangerous to be there. The country is in revolution, and we don't know what's going to happen for us.''
''When the dust settles from all this turmoil,'' Mr. Dinitz said, ''it will be the minorities who suffer.''
In addition, there are unconfirmed reports from some immigrants arriving here of spreading anti-Semitism, particularly in Uzbekistan, the largely Muslim Soviet republic that is also home to about 250,000 Jews.
Israel and the Soviet Union do not have diplomatic relations, and for now the emigrants are flying to Bucharest, Vienna or other cities before flying on to Tel Aviv. But Israeli officials say the national airline, El Al, has signed an agreement with Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, to begin direct flights between Moscow and Tel Aviv early next year. The commercial agreement has not yet been approved by the Soviet Foreign Ministry, the Israelis say. But if and when it is, the number of Jews coming here is likely to grow even faster.
 
Concern About Lack of Zeal
Even with direct flights, it is not likely that all of the several hundred thousand people who have applied for Israeli visas will move here. But whatever the final number, the lack of awareness of Judaism among these immigrants creates ''some real challenges for absorption,'' said Natan Sharansky, a leader among Soviet Jews here.
Faith and Zionist zeal, most people here agree, help carry many of today's new immigrants through the difficult challenges and hard times that Israel almost invariably presents.
As he waited in line at the airport to register with immigration authorities, one of the arrivals, Oleg Finkelstein, a 24-year-old from Leningrad, said, ''I've never practiced Judaism, but I guess I'm interested in learning about it because it's what keeps the people of this country together.''
 
The Music Is Strange
For now, Mr. Finkelstein, like the others, had to be prompted to stand when the yeshiva students began singing ''Hatikva,'' the national anthem. When the yeshiva boys held hands and danced in a circle, singing ''Havenu Shalom Aleichem,'' one of the best-known Jewish folk songs and dances, hardly anyone in the group of new arrivals seemed to recognize it.
In most cases those people came to Israel because this is the country that invited them and for no other reason. They are simply looking for a better life and hope they can find it here. ''These are people who want to come and succeed in their work,'' Mr. Sharansky said.
Many might just as well have gone to the United States. But in September the Bush Administration, citing humanitarian, financial, political and bureaucratic concerns, set a ceiling of 50,000 on the number of Soviet refugees in each of the coming years.
 
Feast or Famine
Israeli officials warmly welcomed the American changes, knowing that the Soviet Jews who could not get into the United States would most likely come here.
But as the numbers swell, Mr. Sharansky and others are openly complaining that Israel simply cannot handle the flood. The nation is hard pressed to find housing and jobs, partly because of the economic troubles that the Palestinian uprising has helped to spawn.
''We don't like the fact that our Government isn't ready despite all our warnings,'' Mr. Sharansky said.
While Israel desperately wants Jews to move here to fulfill the tenet of Zionism that Israel be home for all the world's Jews, immigration from all sources has been at relatively low levels for years. Slightly more than 20,000 people moved here in 1980, but in most years since, the number has fluctuated between 11,000 and 14,000. In recent typical years, far more citizens have left than have arrived, a fact that deeply wounds many Israelis.
Though the number of emigrants is not known - most of them move to the United States illegally - the coming wave of Soviet Jews may tip the balance back at last.
The Soviet Jewish emigres counted so far this year give 1989 the highest total for any year since the National Conference on Soviet Jewry began tabulating emigration statistics in 1968. The previous peak, in 1979, occurred during the Carter Administration, when Washington and Moscow completed a strategic arms treaty before relations soured over the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. An earlier period of relatively high emigration came in the early 1970's, during the Nixon Administration, in the so-called era of detente.
 
Better to Smile Now
As Israelis warmly welcomed the new arrivals at the airport on Monday morning, the yeshiva boys' organizer summed up the situation when he told his charges: ''The most important thing is to smile at them because you know they are coming and are going to have a lot of trouble. So smile now.''
But despite the smiles at the airport, Israel is involved in an angry internal argument over the resentment many people feel about the Government's efforts to find jobs for all the Soviet newcomers while thousands of longtime residents remain unemployed. The nation's unemployment rate stands at 9.1 percent.
Early this month, the Government started a classic Israeli political quarrel when it issued statistics showing that nearly half a million of the country's 4.5 million citizens are now living below the poverty line, $390 a month for a family of two.
With that news, the daily newspaper Yediot Aharonot wrote: ''Things that were whispered under the surface are beginning to burst through. A surge of Russian immigrants is about to arrive, and at least a few residents of the Jewish state, it is now clear, don't want them.''
Mr. Dinitz and others suggest that the arrival of well-trained Soviet immigrants will help the Israeli economy. But that could take years. And in the short term, at the airport, the newcomers have little idea what awaits them.
Mr. Finkelstein said he may not know much about Judaism, ''but I know how to work.
''I know if people want to work, then this country will find us jobs.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1282 words

HEADLINE: From Guns to Butter;
With Cutbacks Likely in Military Spending, Debate Will Center on Where Cash Will Go

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
No one knows how much money will become available or when. But a consensus has emerged here that improving relations with the Soviet Union will permit the United States to spend tens, perhaps hundreds, of billions of dollars less on the military in the 1990's than was believed possible only weeks ago.
The question facing the Bush Administration and Congress is: How will this windfall be allocated? The debate is likely to dominate American politics in the next decade.
Some, like Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, see the lessened need for military spending as an unparalleled chance to cut taxes and pump new money into the private economy.
Lobbyists for social causes say the United States has a golden opportunity to use what is being called the ''peace dividend'' to meet problems in education, housing, drug control and other areas that were overlooked in the hard-fisted Reagan Administration. 
Indeed, many who follow politics see this as a rare turning point, when the focus of policy making in America is dramatically shifting from an emphasis on the military to a concentration on social and economic issues.
''This moment in history,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, represents ''the dawn of the primacy of domestic economics.''
The debate will be joined when Congress reconvenes next month. Will a lack of design prevail as it did when new money came on the books as the Vietnam War wound down? Will the money go to those who shout the loudest or pay lobbyists the most or develop the most memorable slogans? Or will the politicians agree on a plan for distributing the windfall?
Many analysts wonder whether the politicians are up to the challenge. They observe that President Bush, who must chart the course, has shown little appetite in his first year in office for making long-range, controversial choices and that Congress has repeatedly failed the test of self-discipline.
''The word 'plan' has gone out of style,'' said Prof. James David Barber of Duke University, one of the nation's preeminent political scientists. ''What has happened in American politics is its drift to sentimentality and emotion, which substitutes for the facts that face you at the moment.''
 
Some See Squandering
Prof. Alan S. Blinder, chairman of the economics department at Princeton University, who is a student of Government policy making, is equally pessimistic. He said Mr. Bush and Congress would correctly identify that the money would be needed for highways, bridges, sewer systems, water projects and other areas where the nation's structures are crumbling. But he said he was confident the money would be spent not where it was needed most but in the districts of powerful members of Congress or in the parts of the country hardest hit by military cutbacks.
The Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said this week he would try to coordinate the efforts of lawmakers, but he conceded this would be difficult. ''Democracy,'' he said, ''is frequently an untidy process in which the interests of various sectors, both geographically and in terms of our economy, compete for limited resources.''
Many economists and politicans are trying to dampen the enthusiasm over the potential windfall. They warn that in the first few years the money saved will be needed to eliminate the huge budget deficit, and they caution that a recession would make moot the projections based on continued economic growth.
President Bush added his voice in this vein recently. ''When I hear now 'peace dividend,' '' he said, some people think ''if you cut defense spending by $10 billion, we can take that money and spend it on something else. They all have a wide array of programs. We can't do that. We've got enormous budget problems.''
But the amount of money available late into the next decade is likely to be sizable. Two military experts from previous administrations - Robert S. McNamara, Defense Secretary in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, and Lawrence J. Korb, an Assistant Defense Secretary in Ronald Reagan's first term - told Congress on Tuesday that the $300 billion annual military budget could safely be cut in half by the turn of the century. That anticipates a 5 percent, or $15 billion, reduction in Pentagon spending each year below this year's level, adjusted for inflation.
Other experts are not convinced that such deep cuts can be achieved, but they agree that absent a reversal in the world events, large reductions can be expected each year.
A $10 billion cut in the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1, 1990, would, as the President observed, amount to only a quarter of the $40 billion needed to meet the requirements of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law. But if another $10 billion is cut each year, that would mean $20 billion in 1992 for other uses, $40 billion in 1994, $60 billion in 1996 and $100 billion in 2000.
The Government had a similar opportunity 20 years ago. From 1968, during the height of spending on the Vietnam War, to 1976, the military budget fell, in 1990 dollars, from $302 billion to $195 billion. The way it was spent was hardly noticed. Without a plan or a much public debate, most of the money went to increased Social Security benefits and Medicare payments.
More spending on Social Security and Medicare are not likely this time around. But there is no shortage of unmet needs.
Pressure has been building for years for money to meet the public health emergency of AIDS, to provide day care for working parents, to improve education, to help the elderly finance long-term care, to house the homeless and to address the many environmental problems. Almost without exception, economists believe the long-term prospects for the economy are dismal if the country and its citizens do not save and invest more money.
In addition, the General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, has identified these ''unavoidable'' costs, among others, in the future:
* Repairing or replacing the nation's 240,000 deficient bridges will cost about $50 billion, and maintaining highways in their 1983 condition will cost an additional $315 billion. These costs are shared by Federal and state governments.
* Cleaning and modernizing the troubled nuclear weapons plants could cost between $100 billion and $130 billion.
* Modernization of the air traffic control system could cost $25 billion.
* Eliminating hazardous waste on military bases could cost as much as $14 billion.
* Tens of billions of dollars must be spent to upgrade the computers of the Internal Revenue Service and other agencies and to replace the Government's long-distance telephone system.
* It will cost more than $20 billion to repair the deteriorating stock of public housing and billions more to prevent privately owned, subsidized low-income housing from being used for other purposes.
Moreover, Senator Gramm is not alone in wanting to cut taxes. A cut in the capital gains tax rate, which President Bush and a majority in the House and Senate supported this year, could cost billions of dollars in lost revenue by the middle of the next decade.
Support is building in Congress for a more generous tax break for individual retirement accounts, at a cost of billions more. And the most vocal advocates of the poor are pressing for expanded tax credits for workers. To sort out these priorities and ''spend the money in the way it would be most productive for the nation,'' Professor Blinder said, ''we'd have to have especially skillful leadership.''
Will it happen? ''I don't see it coming from this President or this Congress,'' Mr. Blinder said.

HEADLINE: Zaire's Battered Economy Inspires Optimism

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
Western economists here say this country's long-moribund economy is showing promising signs of recovery.
Since January, Zaire, after years of mismanagement and political instability, has devalued its currency, put a brake on Goverment spending, trimmed civil servants from its bloated bureaucracy and increased tax revenues by tightening collection procedures.
These measures, and a perceived new readiness by Zairian officials to tackle their enormous problems with politically unpopular remedies, prompted the International Monetary Fund to assess Zaire's economic performance so far this year as positive and satisfactory.
''The program has been implemented effectively,'' said John Calvin Williams, the I.M.F. representive here, ''and it has already begun to bear fruit in a number of areas.'' 
For example, Mr. Williams said, since March Zaire's inflation rate has averaged 2.5 percent a month, down from nearly 9 percent a month in 1988. At the same time, he said, the spread between the official and the parallel market exchange has been been reduced to less than 10 percent.
For the first six months of this year, revenues from taxes and export receipts have exceeded expenditures, producing a small budget surplus, the first since Zaire gained independence from Belgium nearly 30 years ago.
''In this context, it's a fairly remarkable turnaround,'' said an African diplomat here, noting Zaire's near-legendary reputation for mismanagement, corruption and wasteful spending.
The optimism, however, is hedged with caveats. Western and Zairean economists and bankers say it is too early to well whether Goverment officials will stay the course. Although Zaire's economic perfomance this year has been impressive, the statistics have yet to be translated into better living conditions. Per capita income in Zaire, which is the size of the United States east of the Mississippi, is just $150 a year.
Analysts here are also concerned about whether the Government will be able to restrain spending in 1990, since it has already committed itself to a number of projects, notably constructing housing and convention space for a summit meeting of French-speaking nations. Costly celebrations are also likely next year on the 30th anniversary of Zaire's independence, the 25th anniversary of the governing party's founding and President Mobutu Seso Seko's 60th birthday.
In the early 1980's, Zaire's economy effectively collapsed. The causes were diverse: a slump in the price of copper, agricultural neglect and, by many accounts, seemingly endemic corruption.
After some hesitation, Mr. Mobutu threw in his lot with fundamental economic changes prescribed by the international monetary fund and carried out the program with dictatorial powers. He stuck to the I.M.F.'s stringent guidelines, including a string of devaluations. The value of the zire, the nation's currency, is an eighth of what it was in 1979.
''We were the I.M.F.'s best pupil,'' Pay-Pay Wa Syagasighe, the head of Zaire's central bank, said recently.
In 1986, however, Zaire abruptly abandoned the program, protesting that it had become a net exporter of capital to Europe and the United States. ''The I.M.F. programs cost us $2 billion in outflows against only $1 billion in inflows,'' President Mobutu complained in an interview last fall. Within months, however, the budget deficit skyrocketed, and inflation was back to 100 percent. Foreign investors began to flee.
Last May, after several months of protracted negotiations, the Government signed a new $253 million credit agreement with the I.M.F., under which it again committed itself to an economic reform program.
Analysts here say they have been especially impressed by Zairian efforts to crack down on fraud and abuse in the customs service.
An economist with an international assistance agency said, ''Everyone is being made to pay customs duties and taxes now, even the previously untouchable political elite, and that has never happened before.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Aid to Poland and Hungary Pledged by Western Nations

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Western governments announced plans today to step up their economic assistance to Poland and Hungary as part of a 24-nation effort to help the two countries make the difficult transition from centrally planned to market economies.
Meeting at the foreign minister level, a Western task force on Poland and Hungary also held open the possibility of major aid packages for other Eastern European countries that opt for democracy and capitalism. East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia were mentioned.
The main decisions taken today involved completion of pledges to a $1 billion emergency fund for Poland, which is to be available for use early next year and approval of the idea of a $1 billion loan to Hungary, for which the schedule has not been determined. Many of the 24 governments are already giving aid directly to Poland and Hungary, but they also agreed to coordinate their assistance through the Western task force. 
Underlining the importance of outside help, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d noted that after political change has taken place in different countries, a new challenge emerges when ''the economies must put food on the tables and goods on the shelves of stores.'' And he added: ''Here is where we can help, indeed must help, if we are to meet the call of history.''
 
Fear of Unrest
The extreme difficulties facing Poland and Hungary were echoed in statements to today's meeting by the two countries' Foreign Ministers, who stressed the social costs and political risks involved in introducing such concepts as competition and privatization to economies that have been state-run for 40 years.
''We are resolved to carry out our program, even if its implementation generates social conflicts at the start,'' Hungary's Foreign Minister, Gyula Horn, said. But he warned that if it brought a sharp decline in living standards, ''the outcome may be a general wave of social unrest'' and ''mass support for conservative and retrograde forces.''
Poland's Foreign Minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski, said, ''The results of our economic changes will be viewed by other countries in the region as either an encouragement or a warning.''
The idea of setting up the Group of 24 to help Poland and Hungary was born at the summit meeting of the seven major industrialized nations in July. Members of the Group of 24 include all European countries outside the Soviet bloc as well as the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand, with coordination of aid put in the hands of the European Community.
 
More Food Needed
While Poland and Hungary were dealt with together on the grounds that both countries were simultaneously moving toward democracy, it was apparent to Western governments that the situation in Poland was most critical, particularly because of the fear of food shortages as winter approached.
The first priority has therefore been food shipments, with $385 million worth of food delivered to Poland this year by members of the Group of 24. The ministers noted today that new food shipments would be needed by Poland early in 1990, and they called for contributions. ''The urgent need for medical supplies was also recognized,'' they said in a statement.
The key pillar in Poland's medium-term program, though, is a $1 billion stabilization fund that, among other things, will enable Warsaw to carry out a daring program of monetary reform early next year, including making its currency convertible.
Although several governments have previously made pledges, the $1 billion target was only reached today. Along with a $200 million grant from the United States, contributions included a $250 million line of credit from West Germany, a $150 million loan from Japan, a $100 million gift from Britain and $100 million loans from France and Italy. Japan's loan marked its first participation in an aid program for Eastern Europe.
Stressing the urgency of Poland's need, Mr. Baker said it was important for the funds to be made available as soon as possible. He added that, over the next three years, the United States will provide a total of over $800 million in assistance to Poland and $80 million to Hungary.
The Secretary of State also announced that the United States would provide $200 million toward a $500 million ''bridge loan'' to tide Poland over until it completes negotiations on a $700 million standby credit from the International Monetary Fund. United States officials said an agreement between Poland and the I.M.F. was just weeks away.
 
Climate for Investment
Hungary, which is now seeking parliamentary approval for a tough economic program worked out with the I.M.F., was also given approval for a $1 billion adjustment loan already approved by the European Community. The loan, which is tied to conclusion of an agreement with the I.M.F., is aimed at sustaining market-oriented changes.
Other key elements in the Western aid package include granting preferential treatment to Polish and Hungarian exports, financing a vast range of management and technical training programs, stimulating new environmental protection programs and helping to create a climate for foreign investment. The total value of aid pledged so far, including both grants and loans, is around $814 million.
The somber tone of today's meeting was set by the Polish and Hugarian Foreign Ministers, who spoke early in the day and then withdrew so their proposals could be debated in private.
Mr. Skubiszewski said his Government planned to fight inflation by reducing the budget deficit, cutting subsidies and raising taxes. But he added, ''Unemployment, the extent of which is difficult to predict today, will make its appearance in Poland.''
The Polish Foreign Minister also said his nation had plans to privatize state companies and would for the first time create a stock market and a private banking system. Noting that the country needed relief from payments on its $38 billion foreign debt, he invited foreign creditors to swap debt for participation in Polish companies.
 
'Unpredctable Shifts'
While expressing gratitude for Western help, he said inadequate coordination of food aid had brought problems, with some countries sending food, like butter, that was not needed in Poland. He said he hoped future shipments would comprise mainly cereals.
Hungary's Foreign Minister emphasized the difficulties of abruptly transforming a state-run economy. ''The simultaneous effort to build a social and economic fabric of democracy may result in unpredictable shifts, which may undermine economic and social stability,'' he said.
Mr. Horn added that ''unpopular but necessary measures'' were being taken throughout the economy to maintain its credit-worthiness and to create ''a healthy property and enterprise structure.'' But he, too, complained about the burden of maintaining payments on the country's $10 billion foreign debt.
He stressed that Hungary had not misused this money, but he recalled that commercial banks made the loans in the 1970's for business reasons. ''In that period,'' he went on, ''the objectives of these credits were not aimed at transformation of the economic system or at the creation of democracy.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Europeans Praising Baker Blueprint

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's blueprint for a new European order won generally favorable reviews today from European statesmen and commentators, but privately many officials predicted that Washington will have a difficult time putting its vision into practice.
In a speech in Berlin on Tuesday, Mr. Baker outlined the Bush Administration's view of what he called ''a new architecture for a new era'' in Europe. The thrust of his speech was to provide a series of ideas on how institutions like NATO, the European Community and the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe can be transformed in ways that will both enable them to adapt to the changing European landscape and help insure that this landscape changes in ways that won't wreak havoc.
A spokesman for Jacques Delors, the president of the community, said Mr. Baker's speech was ''right in line'' with Mr. Delors's thinking. A few miles away at NATO headquarters, Secretary General Manfred Worner said he was ''fully in line with Secretary Baker's political proposals,'' particularly a suggestion that NATO establish a new arms control verification staff. 
But behind the praise, many questions are being raised as to how the United States will go about carrying out some of Mr. Baker's proposals -not because those proposals are being seen as particular naive or wrongheaded but because they require such radical changes in long-established European institutions.
 
Repeat of Bush's Plan
For example, Mr. Baker in his speech repeated President Bush's four-point plan for German unification. That plan endorses German unity on the condition that it come about as a result of free voting in West and East Germany, that West Germany remain a member of the European Community and NATO, that unification is not accompanied by any enlargement of Germany's postwar borders and on the condition that it take place ''step by step.''
The problem, as Mr. Baker discovered in his talks in Potsdam on Tuesday with East Germany's Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, is that many East Germans are not in a step-by-step mood. As Mr. Modrow explained to Mr. Baker, the push for unification from East Germans is being driven not so much as nationalist impulses but by consumer impulses, not by visions of a grand Germany but visions of videocassette recorders.
''It is the East German consumer who is going to decide the fate of Central Europe,'' remarked a NATO diplomat. ''Baker outlined a very sensible framework for unification, but I don't know if it is ever going to implemented. East German workers don't want 'socialism with a human face.' They want capitalism. If people continue to leave at the rate they are, the infrastructure of the East German Government and medical system is going to collapse. It is not something you can stop with Government statements.''
 
New Missions for Alliance
As for NATO, Mr. Baker argued that because the Soviet threat is diminishing it must find new tasks to maintain its cohesion and relevance, it was time to begin discussing new missions for the Western alliance. NATO, he argued, has to be seen not as a transitory institution aimed at confronting a military threat, but as a good in itself, as a structure that binds Western Europe and the United States and gives a sense of shared destiny.
But that is easier said than done. Mr. Baker offered three proposals: That NATO establish an arms control verification staff that could help members monitor what are expected to be a wide range of conventional arms control agreement between East and West in the coming years, that NATO involve itself more in trying to solve regional conflicts and that NATO consider taking on some more political and economic responsibilities, like promoting free trade or free elections or environmental protection in Europe.
But for NATO to confront such issues its members would have to agree not only what they are against - a Soviet invasion - but what they are for. One NATO official said: ''We have lived off the Soviet threat for a long time. The question is, Is there life after threat?'' While NATO already has economic, environmental and scientific research wings that could easily assume some broader functions, the idea that NATO could get involved in tackling such thorny regional issues as the Middle East, southern Africa or Central America is viewed as unrealistic, given the conflicting priorities of the various members.
 
Ties With European Community
Maybe the most radical idea Mr. Baker offered was that the United States consider signing a treaty to significantly strengthen the ''institutional and consultative links'' between Washington and the European Community. Mr. Baker had several motivations for making this proposal. With the 12 members of the community due to merge into a single 320-million-person market in 1992, it is going to be a major economic and politial force in the core of any new Europe. The community will be responsible for anchoring a unified Germany in the West and attracting Eastern Europe toward free markets. Given that enlarged role, the Bush Administration wants to make sure that it has some formalized mechanism for influencing decisions before they are made.
At the same time, Mr. Baker is apparently trying to exploit the European desire to see America continue to play a role on the Continent to get a toehold into the European Community. As the community becomes a huge single market, the United States has to make sure that its trade interests are being protected, and its interest in areas like product standards in the European market.
Pulling off such an institutionalized arrangement, said one senior community official, would be ''very, very complicated.'' The community is getting involved in regulating everything from pesticides to telephones and if the United States sought private consultations every time a tariff was being raised ''we would need 5,000 people here,'' said one American official. More important, there would likely be political resistance, led by France, for anything that suggests Washington is becoming a de facto 13th member of the European Community. The French have tended to view the community as their vehicle for exercising influence throughout Europe and NATO as America's vehicle. American diplomats believe Paris still harbors the hope that one day ''NATO will wither away'' and the community will become the dominant political and economic force in Europe.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Expert From Cold War Analyzes East Germany

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 13

 BODY:
It was unusual and surprising for the Secretary of State to quote word for word and at some length from a cablegram by the United States Ambassador to East Germany, since such messages are customarily treated as secret by the State Department.
But the reading of the cablegram in Washington last weekend by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was an acknowledgment of the authority of its author, Richard C. Barkley, one of the State Department's few remaining specialists on German affairs, expertise that in the heyday of the cold war was held by scores of Foreign Service officers.
''Yes, everyone is surprised when a cable is quoted,'' he said in a brief interview on Monday. ''But I was pleased because I thought I was right.'' 
As dramatic changes sweep East Germany and raise the prospect of German reunification and a transformed Europe, Mr. Baker has evidently depended to no small degree on Mr. Barkley's perception of events as they unfold on the ground. A Western diplomat here said it was a recommendation by Mr. Barkley's Embassy that persuaded Secretary Baker to travel to the East to meet Prime Minister Hans Modrow in Potsdam on Tuesday.
When Mr. Baker disclosed the contents of Mr. Barkley's cablegram last weekend, he did so apparently to counter reports that the country might be turning so chaotic that there was a threat of Soviet intervention. The Ambassador wrote that ''despite the disorder born of change, the East German Government still runs, the people work and the economy produces.''
''Demonstrations continue peacefully amidst rumors of potential violence,'' it continued. ''The pace of this revolution is breathtaking.''
 
A 'Balanced' Ambassador
The language of the cablegram is the mark of the man, calm and collected, precise and concise.
''Balanced'' is how Dragan Rancic, the East Europe correspondent of the Yugoslav newspaper Politika, described Mr. Barkley. ''He is the man who makes you rich when you talk with him,'' he said.
Mr. Barkley, who turns 57 on Dec. 23, is the sixth American Ambassador to serve here since diplomatic relations with the Communist Government in East Berlin were opened in 1974.
This is his third tour as a diplomat in Germany, in addition to service in West Germany in the Army in the mid-1950's and study at the University of Freiburg. He entered the Foreign Service in 1962.
 
Only 8 Full-Fledged Diplomats
The American Embassy here is rather small, with a staff of 100 in a five-story building, but only 8 of them function as full-fledged diplomats at a time when East Germany is in the throes of its greatest political crisis since it was founded in 1949.
Still, it is probably a larger staff than that of the American Embassy that was closed in December 1941, when Hitler declared war on the United States. That building, situated two blocks west next to the Brandenburg Gate, was destroyed by bombs in World War II, and the land was sold to East Germany when diplomatic relations were opened.
Mr. Barkley, a native of Chicago, lives with his wife, Nina, and their 4-month-old child, Katharina, in an almost palatial red-brick house that probably belonged to an industrialist in the Niederschonhausen borough on the northern edge of the city.
The Barkleys have close contacts not only with past and present East German political leaders, but also with writers, artists, dancers and musicians. Unlike current and past ambassadors to Bonn or East Berlin, his German is fluent and finely nuanced.
Now, with East Germany on the American political map for the first time in a big way, the Barkleys have also had to play host to a half-dozen or so Congressional delegations, with more on the way. ''They have all been good,'' Mr. Barkley said diplomatically of the ones that have already been here.
Mr. Barkley graduated from Michigan State University in East Lansing in 1954 and later earned a master's degree in European history at Wayne State University in Detroit.
His Foreign Service postings have included Finland, the Dominican Republic and South Africa, in addition to Bonn and West Berlin.
Asked to describe the essence of his job, he replied: ''This is really unknown territory for most Americans, and we are just finding our way to each other. Most Americans are amazed and at the same time impressed by the resolve of the East German people.''

HEADLINE: Drugs in Atlanta: A Lost Generation

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 13

 BODY:
It was a decade ago that 29 young blacks, most of them children, died here in a series of murders that shook Atlanta to its core and transfixed the nation.
But after peering into the tiny coffin of 7-year-old Terrell (Tiger) Weaver last month, Louise Watley found herself thinking that what is happening now is even worse, not because of what is extraordinary about it, but because it is becoming routine.
''A child gets killed, people say, 'It's a way of life, another one gone,' '' said Ms. Watley, head of the tenants' group at the Carver Homes housing project here. ''They ask whose child it was and say there's nothing you can do about it. The missing and murdered children situation was horrible, but these drugs aren't costing us 30 children. They're costing us a whole generation.'' 
The latest statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation show Atlanta with the nation's highest crime rate, but there is no reason to believe its drug problems are much different from those of other big cities. What is different is the memories of a decade ago.
 
End of a Painful Period
The cases of the missing and murdered children, which played out from 1979 to 1981, ended in the conviction of Wayne Williams, son of local schoolteachers. He was found guilty in two murders and implicated in 24 of the 29 deaths. Many local blacks were not convinced Mr. Williams was guilty of all those crimes, but his conviction for the most part ended one of Atlanta's most painful periods.
''In both cases, the children are victims, helpless to defend themselves,'' said State Representative Mable Thomas. ''And in both cases, it just kept going on and on, no end or relief. The kids who should be living are dying too young, and we are helpless to stop it.''
In angry meetings last week, frustrated residents of public housing projects compared their plight now to the situation a decade ago. Some urged that the National Guard to be called out to protect them from rampant, drug-related violence.
Others sought a special police force for the 50,000 people, about 10 percent of Atlanta's population, who live in the city's 42 housing projects.
 
Victim of Random Shooting
Sometimes the victims are innocent children like Tiger Weaver, who was hit in the chest in a random shooting in what the police believe was drug-related violence on Nov. 12. Two other children and a teen-ager were wounded in the shooting. Two months earlier, a 12-year-old girl, Bricola Coleman, was raped and killed at her home in an apartment complex ravaged by drug use.
Sometimes the victims are youngsters in age only, like 16-year-old Michael A. Penix, who was shot and killed while trying to rob drug dealers in another apartment complex.
At least 12 youths under the age of 16 have been homicide victims thus far this year. Officials say it is difficult to be sure how many of those deaths were related to drugs, but the death toll is less than that of the era of missing and murdered children.
But the number of homicides this year is at a record high: 226 as of last week, compared with 146 in 1985.
Residents like Ms. Watley say the toll of killings, record numbers of child abuse cases and ruined lives dwarfs the trauma of a decade ago. And parents in high crime areas, accustomed to the crack of gunshots punctuating each night, do not need statistics to fear for their children.
 
'The Drugs Are Everywhere'
''I never let them outside here,'' said Lisa Jones, a 22-year-old mother of three who lives in the same project as Ms. Watley. ''I take them to my mother's to be outside.''
She remembers the fear of a decade ago, when she was a child, but says: ''This is worse. It's worse because the drugs are everywhere.''
It is also different because no one believes the problem now can be solved by law enforcement alone.
''You can bring in the National Guard from all over the U.S. and it won't do any good,'' said Jabari Simama, a member of the Atlanta City Council. ''We have to stop the demand by looking at the economic reasons why a kid would get involved with drugs. A Band-Aid can be put on cancer for so long.''
But that is little consolation to Ms. Watley when she looks at the basketball court where Tiger Weaver used to play, or sees the 13-year-olds running around with loaded pistols, or when she sees the children sent to school half dressed and unfed because their mothers are more interested in drugs than in mothering.
''When this started, the kids involved were the ones people expected to get in trouble,'' she said. ''But now it's the ones in Boy Scouts and the ones involved in activities in the community. They're all out there selling drugs. We've lost half a generation already. If we don't do something, we'll lose all of it.''

GRAPHIC: Lisa Jones, a resident of Atlanta, with her children (NYT/Alan S. Weiner)

LENGTH: 545 words

HEADLINE: Why Rush to Surrender on Drugs?

 BODY:
Federal District Judge Robert Sweet adds his voice to those who call for legalization of drugs, along with George Shultz, the former Secretary of State; William F. Buckley, the columnist; Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore, and Milton Friedman, the economist. But the judge offers no persuasive new insights. Instead he demonstrates how frustration with the drug problem clouds common sense. 
Judge Sweet is exasperated by ''seeing our justice system overwhelmed by a social phenomena.'' Legalizing drugs, he asserts, would immediately relieve the burden on law enforcement and free billions of dollars for drug prevention and treatment. That's a superficially seductive argument that ignores fact.
Justice is overwhelmed mainly because, despite all the declarations of a War On Drugs, government hasn't begun to provide the necessary resources. In that sense, to call for legalized drugs now is to surrender without a serious fight.
But even if society had begun to fight, the argument for legalization remains deeply flawed. Its supporters acknowledge the need for regulation; they typically envision addicts lining up for drugs during business hours at a public dispensary. Such a system may be plausible for heroin. Addicts maintained on regular daily doses can lead normal lives. Thousands already do so on methadone. But the current besetting curse is crack, and crack is different. Addicts binge on it, rather than nodding off regularly. To satisfy crack addicts, a dispensary would have to be open at all hours, and serve all customers, no questions asked. To regulate supply would defeat the goal of reducing the law enforcement burden. Criminal gangs would rush to serve all who prefer to avoid the rules.
The alternative to regulation is free access to crack. But that would likely produce a surge of new addiction - and a health catastrophe.
Crack use causes paranoia, often violent, that continues after the drug wears off. Women reluctant to inject heroin are quick to smoke crack. As a result, crack has generated a horrendous wave of child abuse. The exchange of sex for crack by binging addicts spreads syphilis and AIDS.
All these ugly trends would grow dramatically if crack were more freely available. Promoters of legalization say maybe not. But there is little evidence to support so stupendous a contradiction of common sense.
In the end, Judge Sweet thinks legalization, and the shifting of money to drug treatment and attacks on broader social problems, could produce a healthier America. Yet drug treatment for crack remains in the primitive stages, and cures for broader social ills are far from clear. The judge bases his optimism on the current public interest in diet. ''If our society can learn to stop using butter,'' he says, ''it should be able to cut down on cocaine.''
That is an airy, remote response to the victims of crack: the underweight, addicted infant struggling for life in intensive care . . . the battered child awaiting a foster home . . . the deranged homeless man picking fights in a city shelter . . . the AIDS patient slowly dying in a crowded hospital ward.
Those who call for legal crack can do so only by averting their eyes from these realities, and from the first requirement of a War On Drugs: to fight.

HEADLINE: It's Time to Rethink U.S. Policy on El Salvador;
The Lesser Evil

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A major misconception in the debate over United States policy on El Salvador is the belief that cutting or conditioning United States aid will lead to takeover by the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front of El Salvador. Such a belief presumes that the Salvadoran military and right wing are so stupid that they would not move for a negotiated settlement of the war or would not meet the conditions of our aid if they thought that our aid cuts would seriously weaken their military position and cause them to lose the war. 
If the Salvadoran right-wing senses that its future in El Salvador depends on negotiating peace and respecting human rights, it will clean up its act. But what if El Salvador's ruling elite rejects United States requests for human rights and negotiations, and instead decides to fight on without our military and economic aid? I think we would have to face the fact of the eventual rise in El Salvador of a left-wing government similar to Nicaragua's government.
More important, I think we would have to face the fact that such a leftist regime would be a lesser evil for the Salvadoran people (and even for the United States) than continuation of an extreme right-wing regime that does nothing to relieve the wretched poverty of El Salvador's poor majority, that offers little to end the long, bloody (and for the United States, costly) civil war and that continues to carry out or at least to allow the brutal violation of its people's human rights.
 
WILLIAM H. GRADY
Los Angeles, Nov. 26, 1989
