HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Dithering in Moscow

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Do we want perestroika to succeed? Let's see when it took root.
In the summer of 1982, Moscow's military leaders where shocked into the realization that in a major conflict with U.S. armed forces, the U.S.S.R. was doomed to lose.
The unexpected fierceness of Afghan resistance and the subsequent U.S. arms buildup had already sowed the seeds of perestroika, but a specific event that dramatically showed Kremlin leaders the need for systemic modernization was the ''Peace in Galilee'' campaign in Lebanon.
New U.S.-built planes piloted by Israelis destroyed 80 new Soviet-built MIG planes piloted by Syrians, without a single Israeli loss. In addition, vaunted new Soviet tanks were mauled by superior Israeli-built armor. 
In this revealing clash-by-proxy between the superpowers, Western technology, training and tactics won overwhelmingly. When Brezhnev died a few months later, Soviet marshals backed Yuri Andropov's K.G.B. reform faction.
The push of technological necessity developed unforeseen momentum. The puppet regimes acting as a buffer on the Soviet Army's western front were too costly to maintain; 540,000 Red Army occupation troops have gone into a ''bastion mode'' to avoid conflict with freedom-hungry locals.
This momentum of change set American policy makers to agonizing over whether we should help Mr. Gorbachev.
Hawks have been saying we should let the Soviet system sink, because only desperation and deprivation will force the sort of radical economic change - private property, market prices, individual decision-making -that will insure the implantation of political freedom.
Doves, contrariwise, have declared the cold war over; they consider the continued occupation by the half-million Soviet troops, as well as continued support of warlike outposts of empire, to be mere vestigial remnants of a wished-away era. They want perestroika to succeed, lest its failure lead to reaction or Bonapartism.
George Bush, fearful of a potential ''who-lost-Gorbachev?'' charge, has sided with the doves. At Malta, he handed Mr. Gorbachev all the economic openings the Soviets have long desired, asking nothing. On top of that, he agreed to subordinate troop withdrawals to missile reductions. In return, the Soviet leader listened to his complaints about arms to Central America without getting angry.
The rationale behind the Bush largesse is that our generosity will encourage Moscow's best impulses, strengthening Mr. Gorbachev's hand against the meanies. We will not be propping up the Communist system, the dovish argument goes, but by offering trade and credit we will be weaning it away from totalitarianism.
This is the tactic called pre-emptive concession, part of the grand strategy of aggressive acquiescence. The Bush style is at least consistent, in operation both in Moscow and Beijing, which is more than can be said for critics who would kowtow only in Moscow.
Will this extension of trust deliver results? Will the Soviet Communist Party submit to political challenge, and will its failed central planners offer more economic freedom?
When events are in the saddle, answers arrive speedily. At the Congress of Deputies Andrei Sakharov moved to consider ending the party's power monopoly; Mr. Gorbachev was not ready and brushed him aside.
Well, say our doves, political competition would be too much too soon, encouraging ''instability,'' the new code word that frowns at striking while the iron is hot; first must come changes in economic philosophy.
That notion was promptly kicked in the head by Mr. Gorbachev's handpicked Prime Minister, Nikolai Ryzhkov, who proudly declared ''the state is the owner of the means of production'' and outlined a Five Year Plan that enshrines central planning and blocks incentives for hard work.
This leap backward cannot be what Mr. Bush had in mind when he extended his offers of trade and aid. The fuzzy talk of ruble convertibility within an Eastern economic bloc already looking westward represents a failure of will by the Gorbachevites; they are paralyzed by the prospect of a loss of power and will not take the action necessary to save their nation.
Yes, we want perestroika to succeed - if, and only if, that means wresting power from a kakistocracy and vesting sovereignty in the people. If it means making the Soviet Union safe for cosmeticized Communism -if it means delaying and denying the worldwide surge for freedom that has so surprised the men who set it in train - we want perestroika to fail.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
For Mayor-Elect, Belt-Tightening Ahead of Time

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
''My campaign,'' David N. Dinkins declared repeatedly as a candidate, ''is about change.''
Yet as Mayor-elect of New York City, the thrust of his appointments so far and of his reassuring remarks to the city's business community has been less about change than about continuity.
Mr. Dinkins's address Tuesday before the business and civic leaders who comprise the Association for a Better New York could have been delivered verbatim by his rival for the Democratic nomination, Mayor Edward I. Koch. The difference, Mr. Dinkins's advisers acknowledged, was largely one of emphasis and good intentions. His challenge will be to persuade his core constituencies that, for the time being, good intentions are going to have to be good enough. 
''They know that I care,'' Mr. Dinkins said. ''I don't say to people, 'Pull yourselves up by your bootstraps,' failing to note that they wear no boots.''
Mr. Dinkins had campaigned as a soul mate of the downtrodden, suggesting that his candidacy embodied some hope, which was better than none. He also believed that, as a liberal, he was obligated to persuade business leaders that he would not bankrupt the city with social programs. Some supporters suggested that he bore an even greater burden because he is black. As a candidate, he conceded that some goals would be fulfilled not immediately, but by the end of his term. Even before his inauguration, he is soberly lowering expectations further.
''Government simply cannot afford to do all that needs to be done,'' Mr. Dinkins said Tuesday. He promised only ''modest but meaningful progress'' in dealing with drug abuse, AIDS and homelessness, causes that had been among the cornerstones of his candidacy. But what some people praised as his sensitivity to business concerns and fiscal realities was described by some others as a squandered opportunity.
''He told them what they wanted to hear,'' said Mitchell L. Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center.
''Leadership would have been going to them and saying, 'I need you to help provide services because government can't.' ''
Mr. Dinkins did mention a campaign to recruit business and civic leaders to adopt public schools. He argued that investment in some drug treatment programs and residences for AIDS patients would prove economical. But the theme of his remarks to the business community was not to worry, which, in turn, worried some advocates who, Mr. Dinkins had hoped, might continue to support him on faith.
''I sure won't,'' said Robert M. Hayes, chairman of the Coalition for the Homeless. ''Obviously we can't have a bankrupt city budget. Just as obviously we can't have a mayor with bankrupt integrity who makes a promise and then says, 'I was only kidding.' '' Mr. Hayes cited support for targeted tax increases. He suggested that investing more in preventive services would require vision and courage, and that ''in the long run, such vision and courage will be seen as the prudent course.''
Mr. Dinkins's supporters predict that black New Yorkers, in particular, will be more patient and will appreciate even the stylistic contrast with Mr. Koch if Mr. Dinkins succeeds in apportioning immediate budget cuts fairly and in outlining a broader vision.
''Your approach to this budget is different from your approach to an administration,'' said Assemblyman Albert Vann of Brooklyn. ''Any reasonable person would recognize that, though New Yorkers tend not to be very reasonable.''
The Rev. Herbert Daughtry promised to hold Mr. Dinkins ''lovingly accountable.'' Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the hospital workers union, said the constituency that elected Mr. Dinkins was seeking ''an activist government'' and ''if things don't change, certainly people will be disappointed.'' Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, challenged Mr. Dinkins to define ''how he plans to do things differently with the money he does have.''
Mr. Koch likes to recall the elderly Brooklyn woman who pleaded with him to ''make it like it was.'' Mr. Dinkins's constituents, with less rosy memories, hope he will make things better. He has been Mayor-elect for only five weeks. He will not submit his own version of the city budget until spring. But at the end of four years, he was asked during the campaign, how should average voters measure him? ''Look at those things that I have said that I care about and that they care about,'' he replied, ''and see if I've made any progress in those areas.''
The campaign, Mr. Dinkins had said, was about change. The question facing Mayor Dinkins is when New Yorkers will say it's about time.

HEADLINE: Decline Seen In Home Prices In New Jersey

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 13

 BODY:
The days of steeply climbing house prices are over, and the 1990's could begin with prices dropping by as much as 12 percent, according to a report released today by Rutgers University based on three million house sales in New Jersey.
''This really is the end of a housing and economic era in New Jersey and the Northeast region,'' said Dr. James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning who wrote the report with Dr. George Sternlieb.
The study, ''New Jersey Home Prices,'' confirms what anyone who has bought or sold a house or apartment this decade already knows: prices have gone out of sight. But the sheer mass of the data gives new insight into how the increases have profoundly changed the market in nearly every one of the 567 municipalities in the state. 
The authors said that although their data were drawn just from New Jersey the trends and general conclusions can be applied to the entire New York metropolitan region.
 
Cooling in Mid-1988
Using computers, the authors examined all house and apartment sales in the state from 1965 to mid-1988, a total of three million transactions. They show that although house prices here remained at or below national levels through the beginning of this decade, they soared starting in 1985.
From 1980 to mid-1988, the median sales price rose to $141,900 from $57,500, with many communities, among them Alpine and Saddle River in Bergen County and Mantoloking in Ocean County, exceeding that by hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Since then, however, prices have cooled considerably, with no increases seen. In some cases, there have been declines, a trend that could continue, depending on the economy.
Although the high prices eventually shut out many people from the housing market, the authors warned that the end of the decade of rapid appreciation could strand those who bought at the peak between 1985 and 1988. Significant social shifts could also develop, among them an increase in traditional forms of savings and a decrease in the number of moves that people make.
 
'A Super Piggy Bank'
''A house is not merely a home in America; it's a super piggy bank,'' said Professor Sternlieb, former director of the Rutgers Center for Urban Policy Research and now university professor at the school. ''We're starting to see some cracks around the end, but it still may be the best piggy bank around, if people just hang on.''
Professors Sternlieb and Hughes are working on the Rutgers Regional Report, a three-year effort to produce a statistical portrait of the New York, New Jersey and western Connecticut region. The immense record of sales transactions was collected by the state to determine the distribution of aid to municipalities. Professor Hughes said the information might be the most comprehensive record of home prices in the country.
Several forces were behind the drastic changes in New Jersey, Professor Sternlieb said, but it stemmed mainly from the 500,000 jobs created between 1982 and 1987 and the increasing demand for housing. Mortgage rates also declined to single digits, and Federal income taxes were cut. There was also something of a buying frenzy because buying a house came to be seen as a sure way to increase a family's equity.
 
Small, Prosperous and by the Sea
For many, it was. The community with the highest median sales price is Mantoloking, a borough of huge houses sandwiched between Barnegat Bay and the Atlantic Ocean that had 433 people in 1980 and an estimated 439 in 1987. It is the lone municipality in the state with a median sale price of $1 million. That is a 189 percent increase since 1985 and a 450 percent rise since 1980, when the median price was $225,000.
Mantoloking might be atypical because it is on the beach. But other towns in the 10 highest-priced communities show similar increases. In Bergen County, Alpine saw prices rise 530 percent in the decade, to $880,000, and Saddle River had a 340 percent increase, to $875,000.
In Essex County, the median price in North Caldwell rose to $341,250 from $123,500. Prices in Westfield, in Union County, climbed to $255,000 from $95,375, and in Weehawken, a township in Hudson County with the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel and several miles of Hudson River waterfront, the median price went from $55,000 to $230,000.
 
At the Lower End
Even those towns with the lowest prices, most of them huddled around the southwestern end of the state, an area of farms and small towns, saw a surge in the decade. From 1980 to 1985, Commercial Township, a community of 4,600 people on Delaware Bay, had the lowest median prices, rising to $18,000 in 1985 from $12,500 in 1980. By last year, however, its median sale had reached $25,000, pushing the town past Camden, whose median price of $21,250 is the lowest in the state.
Other major cities fared better, especially near the end of the price rise. From 1985 to 1988, Newark's prices increased 89 percent to $85,000, and New Brunswick's almost doubled, to $131,000.
The housing bubble burst after Wall Street started laying off stockbrokers in 1987. Companies started to cut back, the high prices made many corporations move employees elsewhere and the demand for housing eased. Houses that had sold in three months were sitting on the market for nine months or longer, and sellers began lowering their expectations.
Professor Sternlieb said house prices had already declined in spots and could drop 4 to 12 percent next year, depending on economic conditions will determine whether prices remain depressed.
 
Adjustment in Attitudes
The realignment could change the way that people think about housing, Professor Hughes said. Instead of stretching to buy as much house as possible and banking on appreciation, buyers may be content with less housing and put more money into savings accounts.

HEADLINE: Number of Poor in Boston Is Found to Decline

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The number of people living in poverty here declined in the economic boom of the 1980's, a study by a nonprofit organization has found.
But the study by the Boston Foundation concluded that many of those who recently made their way out of poverty are the most likely to be hurt by the economic problems that have produced a fiscal crisis in the state, leading to $500 million in cuts in government spending and talk of more cuts and taxes.
''This survey was done last fall and spring, at the high point of the Massachusetts economy,'' said the study's chief investigator, Dr. Paul Osterman, at a news conference Monday, when the findings were released. 
In programs to aid the poor, like job training and education, ''Boston and Massachusetts were among the most generous places in the country,'' said Dr. Osterman, an associate professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management. ''But this population is highly vulnerable to economic downturns and is going to be damaged by the developments in state policies that we are seeing now.''
 
Level Called Understated
Advocates for the poor said the study might understate the amount of poverty because it did not include groups like the homeless and the elderly, which include large numbers of poor people.
People were classified as poor if they earned less than $14,500 for a family of four, which is 125 percent of the amount used in defining the Federal poverty line. The higher amount is used by many state and city agencies because it better reflects the cost of living in Boston. The Federal standard is $11,612 for a family of four.
The study was based on information gathered in interviews from November 1988 and April 1989 with 16,916 households located by making random telephone calls and by going door to door in selected neighborhoods. Figures from the 1980 United States census, adjusted to exclude the same groups, were used for comparison.
The study found that from 1980 to 1989, overall poverty among Boston families fell to 19 percent, from 23.5 percent. Among single parents, poverty decreased to 40.5 percent, from 60.5 percent, and among single individuals, to 5.9 percent, from 22.5 percent.
The breakdowns by race reveal the most about who was left behind as the economy flourished. Among white single parents, the poverty rate declined to 25.7 percent from 56 percent over the period. For black single parents, there was a decline to 35.2 percent from 59.9 percent.
For Hispanic single parents, the poverty rate increased, to 78.7 percent this year from 74 percent in 1980.
 
Groups Excluded in Study
The study, financed by a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, which is sponsoring similar studies in five other cities, excluded college students, the elderly, the homeless, Asians and other ethnic groups who did not fall into the major categories. The exclusions meant that only about 387,700 of the 600,000 people living in Boston were reflected in the study.
''We excluded college students because there are so many of them,'' said the foundation's project director, Wendy D. Puriefoy. ''We excluded the elderly because so much work has been done on them, and the homeless because a great deal is known about them.''
Kip Tiernan, the founder of a women's shelter called Rosie's Place, said the study could not be considered a serious examination of poverty without including the homeless, the elderly and others.

COMPANIES
 
Campeau has run into its biggest cash squeeze yet, forcing its two American retail subsidiaries to say for the first time that they had to consider the possibility of filing for bankruptcy protection. The cash problem stems from payments and interest on $5.04 billion in debt and an inability to obtain additional loans. [Page A1.] R. H. Macy's losses worsened in the quarter ended Oct. 28. It said it would cut back its new-store openings sharply in the next two years. [D8.] 
 
GAF and a senior executive were found guilty of illegally trying to manipulate the stock of Union Carbide in 1986 after an unsuccessful attempt to take over the company. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Easing Business Cycles: The Wichita Experience

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WICHITA, Kan.

 BODY:
This plains city of 300,000, which once boomed as a railhead for Texas cattle, runs these days on airplane production. But unlike the time of the Chisholm Trail, Wichita is far from a one-industry town, and its albeit bumpy ride in the 1980's illustrates a mix of forces that operate in today's diversified economy to blunt both boom and bust.
Confounding those who have repeatedly predicted an imminent lapse into recession, the United States economy has now been growing for seven years, more than three times as long as the average peacetime expansion and second only to the expansion from 1961-69 that encompassed the Vietnam War.
Although few if any experts would say that recession has been permanently banished from American economic life - indeed, some analysts see a slump already under way -many of them note that this remarkable stretch of sustained growth has coincided with some fundamental economic changes, like a larger role for the service sector and an increased international exposure for American business. These shifts in the structure of the American economy suggest that downturns have become fewer and probably less severe. 
 
Uncontrollable Events
Wichita's experience also provides an example of how statistics gauging a $5 trillion national economy mask a myriad of individual gyrations of growth and slump that are often more pronounced than in the nation at large.
Indeed, Wichita demonstrates that a city's fortunes, even allowing for the leveling effects of an increasingly service-oriented economy, owe much to the way uncontrollable or unforeseeable events affect its specific business structure.
''I describe our economy as a five-cylinder engine,'' Gerald S. McDougall, professor of economics at Wichita State University, said, referring to the city's five major industries -small-airplane manufacture, oil and gas, agriculture, military aircraft and the hospitals that make Wichita a regional health-care center.
The overall American economy, except for the second quarter of 1986, when there was a small and belatedly recognized decline in the gross national product, has expanded for 84 straight months. Even with the recent faltering in the manufacturing sector, many analysts say there is a good likelihood of continued growth. The odds, they say, have been considerably enhanced by the changes that have prompted a rethinking of the American business cycle.
Thus, instead of sharp boom-to-bust cycles, the United States economy in recent years has fluctuated within a more narrow range. ''It's been a series of mini-expansions and mini-setbacks within the national expansion,'' said Francis H. Schott, chief economist for the Equitable Life Assurance Society. This muted pattern, he added, is ''the key reason why the recovery has lasted seven years.''
 
'Rolling Readjustment'
Innumerable down-and-up Wichitas, in other words, have counterbalanced up-and-down Houstons, Peorias, Detroits and Spartanburgs in a process economists have come to call ''rolling readjustment.'' Indeed, only Florida ''has been completely free of having some sort of slowdown'' during the 1980's, said James F. Smith, an economist who teaches finance at the University of North Carolina.
Most specialists also commend the Federal Reserve for its conduct of monetary policy, particularly when it moved aggressively to cut interest rates at the time of full-blown recession alerts in late 1984 and mid-1986.
Here in Wichita, where manufacturing's share of the work force has fallen to 26 percent of jobs from 32 percent a decade ago, service jobs have increased sharply with the rise of industries like telemarketing and franchising and the growth of health services. It is true that some of this increase reflected a trend in which manufacturers began to contract with service companies to perform payroll, janitorial and other functions they formerly did for themselves. Still, the gain in service jobs helped minimize the pain when the light-airplane business went sour in the early 1980's.
Service jobs, while often paying less, are generally less subject to shifts in the business climate than production jobs.
 
A Manufacturing Boom
Despite its unusually diversified economy, Kansas's biggest city lagged badly in coming out of the 1981-82 national recession. It was jolted again in 1986 when the price of oil collapsed. Now, showing that economics, like politics, is intensely local, the city is enjoying something of a manufacturing boom even as American factory activity sags.
Wichita's main producers of small aircraft - the Beech Aircraft Corporation, the Cessna Aircraft Company and the Learjet Corporation -produce more such planes than the rest of the country.
The city also gets economic contributions from the 10 franchise operations that have headquarters here, including locally founded Pizza Hut; from the McConnell Air Force Base, and from the state university, which has 17,000 students.
 
'We Got Clobbered'
Growth was strong during the 1970's, skirting even national downturns, but just after that four of the ''cylinders'' conked out. ''We got clobbered,'' Professor McDougall said.
The market for small planes all but disappeared, plummeting 50 percent in dollar value - much more in number of units - between 1981 and 1983.
This debacle was the result of stratospheric interest rates, fears about fuel supplies and liability lawsuits, recession belt-tightening by corporate buyers and a product-cycle transition from pistons to jets.
Agriculture and oil and gas suffered here as elsewhere in the great disinflation of the early 1980's, when the Fed's credit-tightening to bring down inflation led to steep drops in commodity prices. Wichita's oil companies, most of them small and many with marginal properties, suffered disproportionately as prices tumbled below costs of production.
Even revenue from medical care slumped after the Government tightened Medicare reimbursements.
This left Boeing Military Airplanes, benefiting from the Reagan Administration's military buildup, as the only major expansionary force.
 
A Slow Recovery
Although Wichita's unemployment rate at its worst averaged 8.5 percent in 1982, a point below the national average, the early part of the decade was a grim period here and the city did not start to pull out of recession until about 18 months after the nation at large. Indeed, it was not until 1987 that employment here regained its pre-recession peaks.
The three small-plane producers, now employing 11,000 workers, appear to have been significantly strengthened by their takeover during the first half of the decade by outsiders who could finance research and development. Beech, now beginning to deliver its new Starship business turboprop, was acquired by Raytheon, while Cessna was acquired by General Dynamics and Learjet by Integrated Acquisitions, a Wall Street entity.
Wichita's vast Boeing operation is likely to get plenty of new commercial business to make up for any contraction in military spending, so the city finds itself well positioned for any new downturn.
''We've got a manufacturing base in the only industry in which the U.S. is still the world's dominant player,'' said Marvin L. Wynn, chief operating officer for Wi/Se, a city-county development agency.
 
Mood Is Cautious
But for all the signs of resurgence, including a continued assault by new developments and shopping malls on the wheat fields at the edge of town, the mood among Wichita's business people and shoppers is one of caution.
Retail sales have grown scarcely at all in recent years, after adjustment for inflation, and the baffled salesmen at Bulger Cadillac-Oldsmobile on down-at-the-heels East Douglas Street suspect that the lack of customers reflects much more than a hangover from the recently settled Boeing strike.
Roy Jones, retired from his truck dealership in nearby Hutchinson, was asked recently at the Towne East Square mall about his mood. Gesturing toward the stores, where his wife and another relative had disappeared, he said: ''There's belt-tightening. I told 'em not to buy anything.''

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
At Avis Europe, Solving a Puzzle

BYLINE: By Sarah Bartlett

 BODY:
WITH a palpable slowdown of debt-financed takeovers in the United States, Wall Street merger experts view the prospect of an integrated European market in 1992 and closer ties with a newly emerging Eastern Europe as providing their next frontier. Yet, as the recent experience of Avis Europe P.L.C. shows, acquisitions in Europe can present a dizzying array of problems and challenges that can have large effects on a deal's ultimate cost.
Until recently, Avis Europe was an independent company that had been spun off from its parent in 1986, when the rental-car concern underwent a leveraged buyout. This summer, a consortium of Avis Inc., the General Motors Corporation and Lease International, a Belgian company, decided to acquire the company in a $1.6 billion transaction. As a result, Avis now owns about 9 percent, G.M. 26 percent and their Belgian partner 65 percent. 
To acquire the company, and allow for a healthy increase in working capital, the consortium intends to arrange a permanent loan of about $2.5 billion, and therein lies the problem. The consortium's headquarters, and therefore the logical source of the debt, are in London. Yet British interest rates are around 14 percent, five percentage points higher than those in France and seven percentage points higher than those in West Germany, to name but two of the many other countries where Avis operates and where much of the income to service the debt will be generated.
There were other reasons to get the debt out of Britain. Among them was that if the debt was more equally distributed across the Continent and serviced with local currency, the consortium could minimize its exposure to currency fluctuations. ''There was a substantial benefit to getting the debt down to the operating entities,'' said Louis Perlmutter, a senior partner at Lazard Freres & Company, which structured the transaction. But that was no simple matter. Each of the more than 11 other countries has a different set of laws governing how much money can be transferred out of the country, how much debt can be assumed by a local subsidiary, and how much interest they will allow to be deducted from corporate taxes.
To be sure, as 1992 approaches, many of these corporate and accounting conventions are likely to become more standardized, and recent discussions about a common currency and central bank could ultimately lead to a far simpler deal-making environment. In addition, few European companies have the breadth of operations that Avis has.
Nevertheless, the acquisition of a company that operates in even two or three European countries will result in many of these same considerations, and in the interim period when many highly leveraged transactions are likely to be consummated, issues like those that Avis faced are likely to be similar for many other potential acquirers. ''These kinds of transactions will have increasing applicability in the future,'' said Charles E. Golden, the treasurer of General Motors. To facilitate the Avis transaction, Lazard designed a computer model to figure out the optimal placement of debt to minimize taxes, maximize the effect of lower interest rates and avoid running afoul of corporate laws on currency and dividend outflows.
To help unravel the puzzle, Lazard worked with its London cousin, Lazard Brothers, and the Paris office of the law firm Debevoise Plimpton. In addition, local tax and legal consultants were hired in many of the countries where Avis operates. The solution arrived at, after nearly 10 weeks of analysis, was the equivalent of 10 leveraged buyouts.
Of the $2.5 billion permanent financing that the consortium is in the process of arranging, about 80 percent will be placed outside Britain. Besides the high interest rates there, the low corporate tax rate in Britain limited the amount of interest that could be deducted. In Britain, the corporate tax rate is 35 percent, compared with 42 percent in France and Portugal, 46 percent in Italy and 50 percent in West Germany.
On the other hand, there are laws in West Germany, for instance, that limit how much a local company can borrow in relation to its own earning power. Similarly, when Lazard tried to plan for a subsidiary to send dividends or earnings back to the British parent, it faced a host of different withholding tax levels. In Spain the tax is 20 percent, but in Portugal and Belgium it is only 15 percent.
''Every time we solved one problem, four others arose in other jurisdictions,'' Mr. Perlmutter said. He would not put a figure on how much Avis ultimately saved by spreading its debt across Europe, nor was he willing to divulge how much Lazard charged for providing this service.
Europe may indeed be the land of opportunity to American corporations and Wall Street deal makers. But if the experience of Avis Europe is an example, aspirin would seem to be one necessary ingredient for a successful deal.

HEADLINE: GATT Talks With China

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Chinese delegates were asked numerous questions about their economic policies as GATT member states reopened talks on Beijing's bid to rejoin the world trade forum, officials said today.
The working session of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade this week is the first since Beijing crushed China's pro-democracy movement last June. 
The Chinese Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, Shen Jueren, said his country's three-year program to control high inflation had not changed the direction of the economic overhaul begun a decade ago.
Other delegates questioned him about the role of the private sector, price policies, changes in import licensing systems and the availability of foreign exchange.
The United States, the 12-nation European Community, Canada, Australia and Switzerland were prominent among the questioners, the officials said.
The exchanges occurred at a private two-day session of a GATT working party that has been considering an application by China submitted for membership three years ago.
China was a founding member of GATT, which sets rules for about 80 percent of world trade based on free-market principles. It quit in 1950 after a Communist government came to power but it applied in 1986 to regain its seat. It now has observer status.

HEADLINE: Current Account Trade Gap Shrank 29%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The deficit in the broadest measure of the nation's trade shrank 29 percent in the third quarter, to $22.69 billion, the smallest trade gap in almost six years.
The Commerce Department said today that the current account deficit narrowed by $9.40 billion from a second- quarter imbalance of $32.08 billion. The third-quarter deficit was the smallest since a $20.9 billion imbalance in the first quarter of 1984. 
The improvement reflected a big jump in the overseas earnings of United States companies. But economists, who noted that the earnings rise mostly reflected a weaker dollar, said the report did nothing to change their view that the nation's trade deficit will remain stuck at a high level through most of the next decade.
The current account, also known as the balance of payments, measures not only trade in merchandise but also trade in services, the category that includes investment earnings between countries.
 
Surplus in Services Sector
For the third quarter, the services category registered a surplus of $8.72 billion after posting a $1.66 billion deficit from April through June, the first services deficit in three decades.
But the services swing from deficit to surplus was attributed almost totally to changes in the value of the dollar. In the third quarter, the dollar was declining, meaning that the profits that United States earned in foreign currencies were worth more when translated into dollars.
The big swing in services helped offset a small increase in the merchandise trade deficit, which climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent to $27.75 billion in the third quarter, and a rise in foreign aid and pension payments, which climbed 27 percent, to $3.66 billion.
Analysts predict that the services account will dip permanently into a deficit sometime early in the 1990's, reflecting the fact that the United States is now the world's largest debtor nation.
The nation's net debtor position stood at $532.5 billion at the end of last year and is expected to worsen by an additional $100 billion this year.
Through the first nine months of this year, the current account deficit was running at an annual rate of $113.55 billion, down modestly from $126.55 billion in 1988.

HEADLINE: Changes On Benefits In Texas

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Texas lawmakers approved changes on Tuesday in the way benefits would be assigned to workers for job-related injuries and deaths, with business groups and insurers triumphing in a long feud with trial lawyers and union officials.
The fallout from rising insurance rates, coupled with growing underwriting losses reported by many insurers in Texas, had dampened the state's economic recovery and was a factor in forcing some businesses to expand beyond state borders. $1.41 Versus $1.22 Insurance companies have reported increasing underwriting losses in the state, paying out $1.41 in claims and expenses for every dollar of premium received from employers in the last five years, compared with $1.22 nationally. 
''In the long term, these changes should help stabilize the system,'' said Nick Huestis, a vice president for workers' compensation issues at the Texas Association of Business, a lobbying organization in Austin. ''In three or four years, we hope we will get significant rate reductions.''
Senator Carl A. Parker, a Democrat who led the opposition to the new law, told The Associated Press that the changes would prevent many injured workers from obtaining fair benefits. Another opponent, Senator Kent Caperton, also a Democrat, said before voting that the bill was ''evil, wicked and mean.''
Soaring medical expenses and the unusually active involvement of trial lawyers in settling benefit disputes contributed to what in 1990 will be a fourfold increase in yearly premiums paid by businesses in Texas since 1983, to $4 billion. 25% of Settlements In other states, lawyers are involved in 8 percent of benefit settlements. In Texas, the figure is more than 50 percent. Trial lawyers in most states receive 15 percent of settlement payments; in Texas they receive 25 percent.
Gov. Bill Clements, a Republican, is expected to sign the bill, which would also restrict access to jury trials by workers, employers or insurers to issues related to how state-appointed mediators ruled in a case.
Under the current law, the administrative ruling could not be reviewed by a jury, and disputes were tried by lawyers as if a state-appointed mediator had never heard the case.
The Texas system also pays unusually low benefits to severely injured and permanently disabled workers, compared with benefits in other large industrial states. The new law, which takes effect in January 1991, raises the maximum weekly payment to $416, from $238, for such workers, as well as for widows and orphans of workers killed on the job.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Increased By 0.8% in November

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In a report providing some reassurance that economic expansion will continue into 1990, the Commerce Department said today that retail sales climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the biggest gain since August.
But while this was a bigger and broader advance than was generally expected, economists noted that it was accompanied by revisions showing poorer sales than previously estimated for September and October. The November gain thus resulted almost entirely from the reduction in the earlier two months, and was therefore more illusory than real, preventing any outbreak of enthusiasm about the holiday sales period.
''I don't read a lot of strength into these numbers,'' said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. ''The image of the consumer is that they're not doing much.'' 
Tending to support this view was a separate report today from the nation's auto makers showing that sales of cars made in the United States fell 28 percent in the first 10 days of December from the 1988 period.
 
Responding to Bargains
Nevertheless, various analysts took some comfort from November's sales figures, which did at least suggest that consumers continue to spend when offered bargains. The rise, said Richard W. Rahn, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, ''may indicate that consumers are responding strongly to price discounts'' that have become prevalent in the Christmas shopping season. With incomes rising and inflation subdued, he said, ''fears of a poor Christmas season should abate with this report.''
This, in turn, suggested that the Federal Reserve may be a bit less eager to take its next step toward lower interest rates, a move that is still widely expected to occur in the wake of next week's meeting of its main policy-setting body, the Federal Open Market Committee.
The increase in November's sales embraced both durable goods -those expected to last at least three years - and nondurables, with drugstores the only category showing a decline.
 
Durable Goods Up 0.7%
Durable goods were up seven-tenths of 1 percent over all from the October level, as building materials climbed 2 percent, gains at auto dealers were five-tenths of 1 percent and sales at furniture stores rose 1.6 percent.
Among nondurables, which rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, gains at general merchandise stores were seven-tenths of 1 percent; at food stores, eight-tenths of 1 percent; at both gasoline stations and eating and drinking places, nine-tenths of 1 percent, and at apparel stores, 2.4 percent. The decline at drugstores was one-tenth of 1 percent.
All except furniture and food stores, however, posted sales declines in October, which is now shown to have suffered a 1.3 percent overall decline instead of the 1 percent drop initially estimated.
September's advance was pared back by the Commerce Department today to three-tenths of 1 percent, from seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Sales for November, at $144.56 billion, were actually slightly below the $145.29 billion now established for September, adjusted for seasonal and holiday differences but not for inflation.
 
'Still Rather Sluggish'
Last month's sales were 3.6 percent above those of November 1988, but analysts noted that sales fell slightly in real terms - when adjusted for inflation - because consumer prices over the last year have risen by about 4.5 percent.
''Retail sales this year are still rather sluggish,'' said Brian S. Wesbury of Stotler Economics, in Chicago, commenting on today's results. But he also said he took some comfort in the fact that the consumer could at least be enticed with price cuts.
''It seems like everything in America is on sale,'' said Mr. Wesbury, who said he had expected discounted prices to erode retail sales in November but who now say lower prices served instead to enhance sales.
If so, this suggests that consumers may have begun heavy holiday shopping earlier than usual this year, perhaps setting a pace that cannot be sustained and leading to December disappointment.
 
A Sampling of 3,200
The department's survey of retail sales is based on 3,200 sampling units - retail chains, individual stores, restaurants, auto dealers - that supply their results by mail or phone. Many, however, base their bookkeeping on weekly intervals ending on Saturday, so for November the department had to estimate results for the final five days of the month.

HEADLINE: New-Home Completions

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Completions of new homes fell by 3.5 percent in October, to an annual rate of 1.31 million units, in the second consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department said Tuesday.
The department also revised September's decline to 5.5 percent, to a rate of 1.36 million units, from a previously reported drop of 9.3 percent. 
The figures offered further evidence of weakness in the housing market, with both home construction and sales at a sluggish pace.
Economists predicted the housing market could get a lift if mortgage rates came down further, but so far buyers have been reluctant to purchase homes and builders have been cautious about starting new projects.
The department said October completions were 13.5 percent lower than in October 1988.
Completions of single-family homes rose 2.7 percent, to an annual rate of 978,000 units, while multifamily dwellings fell 18.1 percent, to 334,000 units.
Housing completions were down in all regions, falling 7.6 percent in the Northeast, 2.7 percent in the Midwest, 1.9 percent in the South and 4.4 percent in the West.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Flat Or Off a Bit

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were unchanged to slightly down for the week ended yesterday.
Noting that the economy remains sluggish, analysts say they expect money fund yields to continue their slow descent for the next few months. They also see the Federal Reserve determined to check inflation but in no hurry to ease short-term interest rates. 
But Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said he believes a rising unemployment rate going well into the first quarter of 1990 will force the central bank to act more decisively. 7-Day Yield Off 5 Basis Points Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market mutual fund declined 5 basis points, to 8.21 percent, while the 30-day yield, which usually lags behind market activity, fell 3 basis points, to 8.26 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Assets of taxable funds fell by $49.4 million, to a total of $361 billion - a small decline compared with previous weeks.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios declined by a day, to 43.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that were surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market fund again had the best return, with a yield of 9.13 percent, down a basis point from last week and 92 basis points better than the average yield this week.
 
Rise in Tax-Exempt Assets
Tax-exempt assets increased $705 million, to $71.7 billion, as the average seven-day compounded yield remained unchanged at 5.71 percent. For investors seeking a taxable equivalent, that rate means the yield would be 7.91 percent for those in a 28 percent tax bracket and 8.52 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
Three funds tied for top performer in the tax-exempt category this week. The Evergreen Tax-Exempt Money Market fund, the General California Tax-Exempt Money Market fund and the Calvert Tax Free Reserves Money Market fund all posted a 6.28 percent return, down 5 basis points from a week ago and 57 points better than the average.
By contrast, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed the average yield for a bank money market account was down 2 basis points, to 6.35 percent, while the average yield for a six-month C.D. fell 3 basis points, to 7.98 percent.
For C.D.'s with longer maturities, yields were also down. A one-year C.D. fell 4 basis points, to 8 percent, and a two-and-a-half-year C.D. fell 2 basis points, to 7.96 percent, with the five-year certificate off 3 basis points, to yield 7.96 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Higher as Dow Rises by 8.96 Points

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
The stock market moved higher yesterday in more active trading, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.96 points, to 2,761.09.
Advancing stocks on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declining issues, 791 to 734. Volume on the Big Board climbed to 184.7 million shares, from 176.8 million on Tuesday. 
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.02 points, to 352.75, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index added 0.57, to 195.01.
 
'A Filtering Process'
''The market continues to go through a filtering process whereby quality and high-yield issues continue to attract retail and institutional money,'' said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management in Princeton, N.J.
''Specifically telephone, oils and utilities are exhibiting strength on good cash flow and high yields,'' he said. ''These issues also are generally recession proof.'' The Dow utility average yesterday hit another record, rising 1.82 points, to 233.46.
Mr. Barbanel pointed out that technology stocks continue to be under pressure, partly on expectations that the market share of Europe companies will grow.
Digital Equipment dropped 2 3/8, to 82 5/8; I.B.M. fell 1 1/8, to 95 7/8; Motorola slipped 5/8, to 57, and Hewlett-Packard dipped 3/8, to 45 3/8.
Oil issues, which had been strong on Tuesday, were mixed yesterday after an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, Richard Pzena, removed ''buy'' recomendations on seven stocks. Mr. Pzena said oil prices were likely to decline by $2 to $3 a barrel in the next few months from their recent price of $20.50 a barrel.
Exxon slipped 1/2, to 50 3/4; Royal Dutch Petroleum slipped 3/8, to 76 3/8; Texaco dipped 7/8, to 56 1/4; Philips Petroleum was unchanged at 25 7/8; Unocal added 1/4, to 30 7/8, and Amoco was off 3/4, to 54 7/8.
Traders said stocks also received an early spurt from a larger-than-expected increase in November retail sales of eight-tenths of 1 percent. Many economists had expected zero growth for the month. October's increase was revised downward to 1.3 percent from a decline of 1 percent.
Woolworth gained 1 5/8, to 63, and J. C. Penney rose 1 1/4, to 72 1/8, as both benefited from the retail figures as well as a strong buy recommendation from Kidder, Peabody & Company, analysts said.
Tomorrow the merchandise trade figures for November and producer prices report will be released.
The Chemical Banking Corporation was the most active stock, slipping 5/8, to 31 1/2, on a volume of nearly 3.1 million shares.
UAL was the biggest point loser, falling 8, to 168 3/4. Traders attributed the drop to expectations that no new deal for the airline holding company would result from yesterday's meeting of the UAL board.
The drop in UAL, and other airline stocks, helped depress the Dow transportation average by 8.54 points, to 1,203.59. AMR was off 3/4, to 64; Pan Am slipped 1/4, to 2 5/8, and USAir eased 3/8, to 35 3/8.
Actively traded blue chips included A.T.&T., up 1 1/2, to 46 5/8, and Philip Morris, up 1/4, to 43.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index edged up 0.64, to 378.05, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index added 0.71, to 451.14.

HEADLINE: Aerospace Decline Seen

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Aerospace Industries Association today predicted a moderate decline in sales in the 1990's because of cuts in United States military spending as East-West tensions ease.
The trade group said in a year-end report that civilian and military aerospace sales were expected to grow this year by 5 percent, to $120.6 billion, but that industry profits would fall by 13 percent, to $4.3 billion. 
''I do not minimize the impact on our industry of the defense spending cuts we know are coming,'' the association's president. Don Fuqua. said. ''We are braced for heavy weather.''
Mr. Fuqua said 1990 sales would rise to $137 billion. But, he added, there will be a decline in military spending in the next decade that will be only partly offset by increased civilian sales.
''We do not expect an impact of catastrophic dimension but rather a moderate decline in real inflation adjusted sales volume, with gains in nondefense business offsetting to a considerable degree the indicated reductions in defense business,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in very light trading again yesterday, as dealers shrugged off a report that suggested that consumers, who account for two-thirds of the economy, remained active last month.
Market participants pushed prices lower immediately after the Commerce Department disclosed that retail sales rose by eight-tenths of a percentage point last month. The gain was much higher than most Wall Street analysts had been anticipating.
Closer inspection of the numbers disclosed that much of the buying was related to Hurricane Hugo and the earthquake that shook Northern California, and therefore could not be viewed as truly representative of consumer buying patterns. Perhaps more important, analysts said, was the fact that retail sales figures for the previous two months were both revised downward. 
''The revisions to the September and October figures were so negative that they really drained the amount of gain recorded for November,'' said Neil M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''Once you slice through the numbers, the headline of up 0.8 percent loses a lot of its power.''
 
Traders Seem Unimpressed
Traders also seemed unimpressed by an anemic sales performance by Detroit in the first 10 days of December. The nation's auto manufacturers reported yesterday that sales during the period fell a steep 28 percent, to a 5.5 million annual rate.
''That number overstates the weakness,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''But if they get any weaker, they will have to start listing sales individually.''
Mr. Fine and others said the real import of the sales figures lay in future production and employment levels in Detroit. ''You will see a lot more plant closings and layoffs'' in the first quarter of 1990, said Ram Bhagavatula, chief financial economist at Citicorp Investment Bank.
Still, some market participants said the retail sales numbers might have been strong enough to persuade the Federal Reserve Board to delay any further easing of credit policy.
 
Easing at Fed Expected
''After today, you have to maybe look for the Fed to ease sometime after the first of the year,'' one government bond trader said. ''Things seem to be going O.K. for the Fed, and I would guess that they might want to take a look at the December employment report before they move again.''
Yesterday the Fed gave no sign it intended to change its current policy course, and Treasury securities remained mired in the narrow trading range they have occupied all week.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 26/32, up 3/32, to yield 7.87 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 13/ 32 late yesterday, up 1/32, to yield 7.81 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.72 percent.
As expected, the Treasury announced late yesterday that it would sell $10 billion worth of new two-year notes on Tuesday and $8 billion of four-year notes on Wednesday.
The two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.71 percent following the announcement. The four-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.73 percent.
Treasury bill rates rose again yesterday, extending an advance that has persisted all week.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.67 percent, up three basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills were offered at 7.43 percent, up five basis points. And one-year bill rates rose two basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.25 percent.
Elsewhere, United Parcel Service of America Inc. made its first foray into the public debt markets yesterday, offering $700 million of debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Demand for the issue was so strong that its size was increased from $500 million. The funds will be used to finance the company's expansion overseas.
The 8 3/8 percent U.P.S. debentures, which mature April 1, 2020, were priced at $99, to yield 8.467 percent, 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/8 percent 30-year Treasury bonds at the time of pricing. The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Late Tuesday Secured Finance Inc., a special-purpose company set up by the Kroger Company, offered $450 million worth of bonds backed by commercial mortgages. This is the first time that commercial properties of a single company have been used to back a public debt offering in the United States.
The 9.05 percent bonds, which are backed by a guarantee from Financial Security Assurance Inc., were priced at $99.75, to yield 9.08 percent, 1.25 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 7 7/8 percent ten-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. The BT Securities Corporation, Salomon Brothers and Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as co-lead managers for the underwriting, which is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very light yesterday, traders said.
Prices of most corporate issues were little changed. Municipal bond market participants said that prices of most issues improved by about a quarter of a point.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Decline Sharply As Soviets Reject Changes

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as the Soviet Union rejected changes that many investors had hoped would lead to a gold-backed Soviet currency.
Futures prices of silver and platinum also plunged.
Separately, heating oil for delivery in January rose for the 11th straight trading session. 
Gold futures fell $9.80 to $10.80, with the contract for delivery in December settling $9.80 lower at $408.10 an ounce; silver finished 12.8 cents to 13.8 cents lower on the Comex, with December at $5.544 an ounce.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum futures sank $13.70 to $14.10, with the January contract settling at $504.70 an ounce.
From mid-October through late November, gold soared from near $360 an ounce to almost $420, partly on speculation that the changes sweeping Eastern Europe would include a move by the Soviet Union to back its currency, the ruble, with gold.
Such a move would greatly increase the value of the ruble on the world market, where it is now almost useless, so the Soviet Union could improve its trade with other countries.
A gold-backed ruble was apparently not discussed by the Soviet Parliament yesterday, but they rejected other radical economic changes. That disappointed gold traders who had hoped for some strong indication of change, analysts said.
''There's been a lot of speculation but so far not anything done, and I think that's kind of frustrated people,'' said Stephen Platt, metals analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. ''People were looking for something out of the Politburo.''
James Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York, said the gold selloff also appeared linked to the persistent rumor that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had offered to resign.
January heating oil futures surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange following the American Petroleum Institute's report late Tuesday of an unexpectedly large reduction in American stocks of petroleum distillates last week. Extremely cold weather in Europe and the United States has kept demand for heating oil strong. Other energy futures were mixed. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent lower to 12 cents higher, with January at $20.77 a barrel; heating oil was 0.60 cent lower to 0.66 cent higher, with January up 0.66 cent at 67.96 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.10 cent to 0.20 cent lower, with January at 51.93 cents a gallon.
